description: In his interview with the Wall Street Journal, Mitch McConnell finally mentioned a few sort-of specifics about what spending cuts the GOP wants: raising the Medicare age, charging higher premiums to affluent Medicare recipients, and changing the price indexing of Social Security. But how much does all this amount to?

title: The Real Scandal Behind Benghazi
description: For conservatives, the Benghazi scandal is a Watergate-like presidential cover-up. For liberals, it is a fabricated Republican witch-hunt  aimed squarely at Susan Rice, a candidate to succeed Secretary of State Hilary Clinton. For me, Benghazi is something else: a call to act on an enduring post-9/11 problem that both political parties ignore.

title: Transgender Latinas Find a Refuge in Queens
description: Two years ago, smugglers buried a woman named Joselyn in Matamoros, a Mexican border city that attracts immigrants waiting to cross into the United States. Several men encased her body in dirt, covered her face with leaves and told her to wait until Border Patrol agents had disappeared to dig herself out.

title: Disruptions: Silencing the Voices of Militants on Twitter
description: Twitter, perhaps more than any other social media outlet, has become one of the most powerful tools to promote democracy in the Middle East.

title: The Vanishing of the Nuns
description: In 1965, when the average age of a baby boomer was 10, there were 180,000 nuns in the United States. Today there are about 56,000. But even more dramatic than this decline is the age of the average Roman Catholic sister  74 years old.

title: Twilight and Lincoln Thrive at Box Office
description: Post-Thanksgiving audiences dined on cinematic leftovers over the weekend. The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn  Part 2 (Lionsgate) repeated as the No. 1 movie at North American theaters, taking in an estimated $17.4 million, for a three-week total of about $254.6 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. Skyfall (Sony) was a close second, taking in $17 million, for a four-week total of about $246 million. Steven Spielbergs Lincoln (Disney) placed third, with ticket sales of $13.51 million; Lincoln, a leading Oscar contender, is turning into a runaway hit, at least as far as serious historical dramas go these days, taking in about $83.7 million over four weeks. DreamWorks Animations struggling Rise of the Guardians (Paramount) was a whisker behind, taking in an estimated $13 million, for a two-week total of $48.9 million. Another Oscar contender, Ang Lees Life of Pi (20th Century Fox), was fifth, selling about $12 million in tickets, for a two-week total of $48.4 million. The weekend included one notable flop: Killing Them Softly, a drama starring Brad Pitt and released by the Weinstein Company (with financing from the Oracle heiress Megan Ellison), arrived in seventh place, taking in about $7 million.

title: A Round of Golf for Presidents 42 and 44
description: President Obama took advantage of the unseasonably warm December weather on Sunday to head to the golf course with his most prominent campaign surrogate, former President Bill Clinton.

title: European Financial Officials Will Meet, Again, to Address the Greek Crisis
description: BRUSSELS  They meet yet again. And once more, the agenda will be dominated by a looming deadline in the unfinished business of Greece.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (Lifetime) FINDING MRS. CLAUS (2012) When Santas wife (Mira Sorvino) feels neglected by her distracted husband, she travels to Las Vegas to help a small girl with a Christmas wish  and to treat herself to a bit of a fling. With the aid of some magic sparkle dust, Mrs. Claus is transformed from frumpy to fabulous, and Santa (Will Sasso, above, with Ms. Sorvino) trails after her, trying to make amends. But what happens in Vegas may end up affecting the holiday around the world.

title: Negotiators Leading Talks on Fiscal Crisis Defend Stands
description: WASHINGTON  At a stalemate in their talks to avoid a self-imposed fiscal crisis at the end of this month, the lead negotiators for the White House and Congressional Republicans used the Sunday morning news shows to defend their positions and blame the other side for the impasse.

title: With Carbon Dioxide Emissions at Record High, Worries on How to Slow Warming
description: Global emissions of carbon dioxide were at a record high in 2011 and are likely to take a similar jump in 2012, scientists reported Sunday  the latest indication that efforts to limit such emissions are failing.

title: Islamists Protest Egypt Court
description: Demonstrations by President Mohamed Morsi's Islamist supporters prompted Egypt's Supreme Constitutional Court to cancel its session Sunday.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) BABY PEGGY, THE ELEPHANT IN THE ROOM (2012) Peggy-Jean Montgomery, left, a daughter of a professional cowboy turned stuntman who moved his family to Hollywood, was 19 months old when she captured the attention of the director Fred Fishbach. Impressed by her plucky demeanor and good behavior, he cast her in some of Century Studios comedy shorts, sometimes opposite Brownie the Wonder Dog. As the third great child star of the silent era, after Baby Marie and Jackie Coogan, Peggy made about 150 shorts in all, working eight-hour days, six days a week, and performing stunts like being held underwater and escaping a burning building. In 1923 she earned the nickname Million-Dollar Baby when Universal lured her away from Century with the chance to make feature films for $1.5 million annually. But soon her father and the producer Sol Lesser argued about her salary, and Lesser not only fired her but also blackballed her in Hollywood. By the age of 11 Baby Peggy was a has-been. When she reached adulthood, she discovered that her family had spent her earnings  more than $2 million. Calling herself Diana Serra Cary, Peggy became an author and film historian as well as an advocate for laws protecting child actors. This tribute begins with Vera Iwerebors documentary, filmed shortly before the actresss 90th birthday in 2008. It is followed by Captain January (1924), a silent feature about a lighthouse keeper (Hobart Bosworth) who raises a child found washed ashore in a ships wreckage, at 9; and three of her few remaining shorts: Carmen, Jr. (1923), a spoof on Bizets Carmen and the tango, at 10:15; Such Is Life (1924), loosely based on Hans Christian Andersens Little Match Girl, at 10:30; and Peg o the Mounted (1924), about a pint-size Mountie who hunts down a gang of moonshiners, led by a giant of a man played by Jack Earle, who stood roughly 7 feet 7 inches.

title: Stores Shut in Protest as New Strife Grips Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  As Syrian government forces pressed their counteroffensive on the outskirts of Damascus and a car bomb exploded in the central city of Homs, merchants around the country closed their shops over the weekend in response to a call for peaceful protest, suggesting that the civil disobedience movement, though overshadowed lately by intense fighting, still has the ability to mobilize Syrians.

title: Nets Guiding Force Is Still Searching for His Scoring Touch
description: MIAMI  Deron Williams had ice strapped to both knees, his left thigh and his right wrist, none of which ached as much as his battered self-esteem.

title: Airbus Parent Expected to Alter Base of Its Investors
description: PARIS  The board of European Aeronautic Defense & Space, the parent company of Airbus, was expected as early as Monday evening to announce a significant restructuring of its core shareholder base that would, for the first time, give the German government a direct stake in the group on par with that of France.

title: Hollande Victory May Be Pyrrhic
description: When it ended a face-off with the worlds biggest steel company Friday evening, the French government cast the outcome as a job-saving victory.

title: Knicks Stay Perfect at Home as Wallace Steals Show
description: In Sundays matinee at Madison Square Garden, the player who created the games most intriguing, head-scratching moment was also the player who could not stay on the court for more than two minutes. Some Knicks fans groaned and others applauded as they watched Rasheed Wallace leave the court before he could even break a sweat.

title: Operation Rolling Tantrum
description: Oh, boy. This isnt going to end, even when or if a deal is reached on defusing the austerity bomb; John Boehner has just declared that hes going to hold the full faith and credit of the United States hostage every time we hit the debt limit. Nor will it be a case of holding the nation at gunpoint until it meets GOP demands; Republicans are signaling that they dont intend to make any specific proposals, theyre just going to yell and stamp their feet until Obama soothes them somehow.

title: What the Swing Counties Tell Us About the Future of American Politics
description: WASHINGTON  In the eight states where President Barack Obama and Gov. Mitt Romney competed fully there were 94 so-called swing counties that voted for George W. Bush in 2004 and the Democrat in 2008; in November they split, Obama winning 48 and Romney 46.

title: Samba Purred Serenely, With Stealthy Metaphor
description: Paulinho da Viola, limber and elegant at 70, is a messenger of samba de morro, the music of the 1930s from the hills around Rio, in its calmest form. At Carnegie Hall on Wednesday he represented an almost precommercialized culture, an idea of Brazilian popular music that hardly acknowledges the happening of bossa nova in the 50s, let alone pagode and samba-reggae or any other digital-age development. A losing battle, you might think.

title: Homages to Mom, With a Pinch of Sentiment and Literary Side Dishes
description: Has Mommie Dearest seen its day? To judge by two memoirs by New York insiders, fewer writers have mothers like Joan Crawford  or Momma Rose  than they used to.

title: Better Late Than Never, a Nod to Pierrot Lunaire
description: If you are a classical music fan and you are breathing, it is likely that you will encounter Stravinskys Rite of Spring this season. May 29 is the 100th anniversary of that works tumultuous premiere in Paris, and the celebrations are already in full swing.

title: A Growing Repertory for Swaying Hips and Busy Feet ...
description: When Robert Battle took over as the artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater last year, it was the equivalent of being given the helm of a luxury cruise ship. In the scrappy modern-dance world most directors are still in paddle boats.

title: ... Not to Mention the Essence of a West Indian Heritage
description: In 1978 the Jamaican choreographer Garth Fagan had an idea for a dance that would explore his West Indies origins. He also wanted to try something new: By stripping away the decorative elements of African and Caribbean dance he aimed to reveal its essence. The resulting From Before is one of Mr. Fagans most admired works.

title: McElroy Replaces Sanchez and Leads Jets to Victory Over Cardinals
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  One after another, the two quarterbacks appeared in the Jets interview room. The first ambled in still wearing his cleats, his eye black and his uniform pants. He smiled. He joked. He dissected the touchdown pass that resuscitated an offense, a team, a stadium, and when he was finished, he left.

title: Lending a Slide and Scoot to a Jazz Beat
description: Although jazz and tap dance grew up together, a tap-dancer performing at a jazz club is a fairly rare event these days. And what Maurice Chestnut was doing at the Jazz Standard last week is even rarer: not headlining or sitting in but playing as the fourth member of a quartet, the Timeline Band of the esteemed pianist Geri Allen.

title: Missouri Bishops Conviction Leaves Clergy Divided
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  In the three months since Bishop Robert W. Finn became the first American prelate convicted of failing to report a pedophile priest, lay people and victims advocates have repeatedly called for his resignation.

title: Arden Court
description: Photos of the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater in Paul Taylors 1981 work.

title: Philosophy and the Poetic Imagination
description: Perhaps now more than ever, we spend our days immersed in language. We communicatetalk, write and readthrough a burgeoning array of forms and technologies. But most of us rarely stop to think about how language works, or how come we succeed in getting our ideas across in words. It all seems to happen naturally. Poets, novelists, speechwriters or the merely curious sometimes confront these questions, but it is a job that often falls to linguists and philosophers of language.

title: Monty Python Sued Over Spamalot Money
description: The musical Monty Pythons Spamalot (with Michael McGrath, above left, and Tim Curry) has earned hundreds of millions of dollars on Broadway and abroad, but how some of that money should be distributed is in dispute, the BBC reported. Mark Forstater, a producer of Monty Python and the Holy Grail, the film on which Spamalot is based, is suing Monty Python members over royalty rights. Mr. Forstater argues that he has not been adequately compensated since the musical opened in 2005 on Broadway, where it grossed more than $175 million during its initial run. Three Python members, Eric Idle, Michael Palin and Terry Jones, are scheduled to appear in court in London.

title: Alabama-Georgia Classic Merely a Warm-Up
description: ATLANTA  In the aftermath of a college football classic as close and tense as any game this season, as good or better than any Southeastern Conference final that came before, Alabama lingered on the Georgia game, on what just happened. The Crimson Tide topped the Bulldogs on Saturday, but barely, victory not assured until the game clock read all zeros.

title: Honors for Amour at European Awards
description: Amour, the latest film from Austrian director Michael Haneke, almost performed a clean sweep at the European Film Awards on Saturday in Valletta, Malta, where it won for best picture, best director for Mr. Haneke, best actress for Emmanuelle Riva and best actor for Jean-Louis Trintignant. The film follows an octogenarian couple played by Ms. Riva and Mr. Trintignant as they deal with illness; it was also written by Mr. Haneke, but he did not win the screenwriting prize. That went to Tobias Lindholm and Thomas Vinterberg for their film Jagten (The Hunt), about a teacher in a Danish village who is wrongly accused of child abuse. Voted on by 2,700 members of the European Film Academy, awards were also given to Steve McQueens Shame for cinematography and editing and to the Italian filmmaker Bernardo Bertolucci for lifetime achievement.

title: Mix-and-Match Ensemble Erases Borders With Enthusiasm
description: Quixotic aims filled Red Hot + Cuba at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Saturday night, the second of its two shows there. Andres Levn, a Venezuelan musician and producer who frequently visits Cuba, set out to bring Havanas abundant live music to New York City, sampling some of the citys diverse scenes  the idealistic Latin-American folk-rock called trova, the retro Cuban style rekindled by the Buena Vista Social Club and the revved-up, funked-up Cuban salsa called timba  with a group of 24 musicians.

title: Big Boys Lay Out Their Oscar Bait
description: LOS ANGELES  At the Governors Awards banquet of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences here on Saturday three weathered honorees  the stuntman Hal Needham, the documentarian D. A. Pennebaker and the film advocate George Stevens Jr.  held the spotlight through most of the night.

title: Leery of a Merger, a Hospital in Brooklyn Plans to Declare Bankruptcy
description: A financially troubled hospital serving a largely African-American and Caribbean niche of central Brooklyn is planning to declare bankruptcy this week, hospital officials said on Sunday, raising concerns that New York State may force it to close or merge with another institution.

title: Sprawling Love Story, Abridged
description: It was good to catch up with the career of the Chinese opera star Zhang Jun over the weekend. When I last encountered him, in Shanghai in 1998, Mr. Zhang, then 23 and also an aspiring pop singer, was rehearsing Liu Mengmei, the male lead role in the classic Chinese opera The Peony Pavilion for a production by Chen Shi-Zheng with the Shanghai Kunqu Opera Company, which was intended for the Lincoln Center Festival.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Rebound, as Demure as Ever
description: LAS VEGAS  This city doesnt necessarily mean the end, not anymore. Its a town of summation, site of neither genesis nor graveyard. For a singer a residency here isnt merely a sinecure for the once-was but a confirmation of cultural saturation. If you can make it here, youve made it everywhere.

title: Fall North American Championships
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Sunday was the last day of play at the American Contract Bridge Leagues Fall North American Championships here. Ten teams qualified for the final day of the premier event, the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams, led by Monaco, captained by Pierre Zimmermann. The James Cayne team, winner the last two years, was eighth.

title: Uneasy About Online Medical Records
description: To the Editor:

title: Facing Rising Sea Levels
description: To the Editor:

title: Restraint-Free Care for Nursing Home Residents
description: To the Editor:

title: If You Signed Norquists Tax Pledge, Theres a Way Out
description: To the Editor:

title: In App Land, Lots of Ways to Get a Ride
description: In Mondays Times, Brian X. Chen writes about the legal struggles of Uber, whose app connects users with car service drivers. Uber has captured the fancy of many riders but faces opposition from regulators and the taxi industry. While the company is perhaps the most prominent tech start-up looking to shake up the car service and taxi industries, it is not alone. Here is a quick look at the approaches being pursued by various companies.

title: Knightly Activity
description: The one-l lama, hes a priest;The TWO-L llama, hes a beast.And I will bet a silk pajamaThere isnt any three-l lllama. Ogden Nash

title: A Spate of Rebranding for Spanish-Language TV
description: Its a race to be the best of the second best. On Monday, Univision, the dominant Spanish-language network in the United States, will announce a new name and look for its second-largest network, TeleFutura. The move is a direct shot at Telemundo, a rival for second place among domestic Spanish-speaking viewers.

title: A Cleveland Newspaper Takes Steps to Prevent Cuts
description: While workers at many newspapers owned by Advance Publications have tried to brace themselves for what seems to be the inevitable  layoffs and the end of a daily print product  reporters and editors at The Plain Dealer in Cleveland are fighting back in an unusual way: they are taking their case directly to the public.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include ISM manufacturing index for November and construction spending for October (Monday), ADP employment for November; revised third-quarter productivity, ISM service index for November and factory orders for October (Wednesday), weekly jobless claims (Thursday) and unemployment for November, Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for December and consumer credit for October (Friday).

title: A Stalwart of Time Inc. Packs Up
description: In the decade Ive covered John Huey, Id never once been to his magisterial office on the 34th floor of the Time & Life building. It is large and imposing in a way its occupant is not, an unlikely landing spot for an old newspaper hack. On the wall is a photograph of William Faulkner, the patron saint of all hard-drinking Southern writers, as Mr. Huey, a native of Atlanta, describes him.

title: Chinese Media Retreat After Reports of Unexpected Black Jail Verdict
description: BEIJING  A brief news article published on Sunday by a score of state-run news media outlets offered an account of an unexpected judicial verdict: a Beijing municipal court had sentenced 10 people to jail for illegally detaining and assaulting a group of citizens who had come to the capital to lodge complaints about official malfeasance in their hometown in Chinas central Henan Province.

title: From Before
description: Photos of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater in Garth Fagans work.

title: Some Analysts Doubt Dire Predictions on Tax Increase Fallout
description: As anxious investors assess their portfolios in light of expected tax increases on investment income, hedge fund manager Douglas Kass has a simple message: Relax.

title: Chris Stamp, a Manager and Discoverer of the Who, Dies at 70
description: Chris Stamp, who as a cockney kid from East London aspired to make a documentary film about the rise of British rock in the 1960s and ended up helping to discover and manage a raucous working-class quartet called the Who, died on Nov. 24 in Manhattan. He was 70.

title: A New Wildlife Magazine Aimed at the Very Young
description: After 50 years of guiding children through wildlife and ecology on his own, Ranger Rick is getting a helping hand in the form of a younger sibling.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Lies! Murder! Lexicography!
description: HERES a tip: if you see the words dictionary and scandal in a sensational headline, prepare to be disappointed.

title: Being There
description: IN a smart, disheartening piece in The New York Times Magazine last month, Robert Worth surveyed the frustration of American diplomats who signed up to engage the world  even dreamed of changing it  and now find themselves encumbered by the safeguards and protocols of a risk-averse Washington. It is hard to change the world when you live in a fortress and travel in an armored motorcade.

title: Do Filibusters Stall the Senate or Give It Purpose?
Partnership Offers Support for Media Entrepreneurs
description: Can the nascent entrepreneurial ideas bouncing around Silicon Valley help reinvent public media?

title: Rick Majerus, College Basketball Coach, Dies at 64
description: Rick Majerus, who never headed the elite programs in college basketball but who became a leading coach, winning more than 500 major-college games, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 64.

title: Book by 2 From Google Takes a Deep Look at the Web
description: The Internet is the largest experiment involving anarchy in history, begins a new book written by two top Google executives, which aims to explain how this experiment will play out in politics, business and even personal lives.

title: Displaced Residents Grapple With Hurdles of Going Home
description: MAMPUJN, Colombia  The jungle owns Mampujn, this once-prosperous farming town near the Caribbean coast that has become a symbol of Colombias descent into lawlessness  and now its efforts to turn things around.

title: Mondays Matchup: Giants at Redskins
description: Giants (7-4) at Redskins (5-6)8:30 p.m., ESPNLine: Giants by 3

title: Ford Redoubles Effort to Reawaken Its Sleepy Lincoln Brand
description: DEARBORN, Mich.  In the fiercely competitive world of luxury cars, the Ford Motor Companys Lincoln brand has long been stuck in the slow lane, with stodgy models, older buyers and a distinct lack of pizazz.

title: Lines Blur as Texas Gives Industries a Bonanza
description: DALLAS  The Preston Hollow neighborhood has been home to many of Texas rich and powerful  George and Laura Bush, Mark Cuban, T. Boone Pickens, Ross Perot. So it is hardly surprising that a recent political fund-raiser was held there on the back terrace of a 20,000-square-foot home overlooking lush gardens with life-size bronze statues of the hosts daughters.

title: A Feisty Start-Up Is Met With Regulatory Snarl
description: WASHINGTON  Summoning a taxi or car service with your smartphone feels like the future. City governments around the world can agree on that. But many of them are proposing new rules that would run Uber, one of the most prominent ride-requesting apps, off the road.

title: Frances Floating Generation
description: As youth unemployment hits 22 percent, many young people cannot find jobs that get them on the path to being taxpaying, property-owning adults.

title: A Troubling Portrait of Domestic Work
description: If workplaces were fairer, domestic workers would be protected by minimum-wage and antidiscrimination laws and by unemployment insurance. They would also have things most employees take for granted, like meal breaks. But too many nannies, caregivers and housecleaners have none of these things. A new study confirms what advocacy groups have struggled to convey: that domestic workers, a vital but invisible sector of the economy, are suffering the predictable consequences of toiling behind closed doors in an unregulated industry.

title: Young, Educated and Jobless in France
description: LILLE, France  Justine Forriez wakes up early to go onto the computer to look for a job. She calls university friends and contacts; she goes to the unemployment office every week, though mostly for the companionship, and has taken a course in job hunting. She has met with 10 different recruiters since May and sent out 200 rsums.

title: Shattering Records in the Giant Slalom, Ligety Leaves His Rivals Marveling
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo.  Ted Ligety of the United States charged to victory down the Birds of Prey giant slalom track Sunday with a combined time of 2 minutes 25.59 seconds. After setting a course record for margin of victory, beating Marcel Hirscher of Austria by 1.76 seconds, Ligety bowed and kissed the snow in the finish area.

title: Perfidious Prosecutors
description: In an egregious case of bad judgment, two federal prosecutors in the United States attorneys office in New Orleans surreptitiously posted hostile comments on a public news site about defendants in cases the office was pursuing and then lied about it. That conduct now jeopardizes important criminal convictions and has resulted in a judges call for an independent investigation of the office.

title: Promises on AIDS Are Not Enough
description: Experts know how to control the global spread of the AIDS virus. Whats missing is enough money and political will to apply proven tactics widely enough to change the course of the epidemic.

title: DVR Use One Factor in Networks Low Ratings
description: If you ask several of the top programmers in network television what is going wrong with their ratings this season, they offer a litany of answers: jarring schedule disruptions from debates, election night and Hurricane Sandy, for instance, as well as the ever-increasing defections toward delayed viewing and away from the nightly schedules that have defined network prime time since the days of radio.

title: Amid Euphoria Over U.N. Vote, Palestinians Still Face Familiar Challenges
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Now we have become a state! Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, announced Sunday to a crowd of thousands in the courtyard of his headquarters in this Palestinian city.

title: A Georgia Main Street Paved in Red Carpet
description: SENOIA, Ga.  Unlike so many recession-weary towns, Senoia has a bustling Main Street. Dozens of new stores have opened, including a sushi bar, an antiques vendor and an Irish pub. City Hall has been repainted with money from the soaring tax revenues.

title: Marine Life on a Warming Planet
description: Since the beginning of the industrial era, humans have pumped increasing amounts of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. This has led not only to a warmer climate but also to significant changes in the chemistry of the oceans, which have long acted as a sink for carbon emissions but are being asked to absorb more than they can handle. The result is ocean acidification: increasingly corrosive seawater that has already ruined many coral reefs and over time could threaten the entire marine food chain.

title: The Big Budget Mumble
description: In the ongoing battle of the budget, President Obama has done something very cruel. Declaring that this time he wont negotiate with himself, he has refused to lay out a proposal reflecting what he thinks Republicans want. Instead, he has demanded that Republicans themselves say, explicitly, what they want. And guess what: They cant or wont do it.

title: Chief of News Corp. Unit in Britain Is Resigning
description: Tom Mockridge, a longtime News Corporation official who served as chief executive of the companys British newspapers in the aftermath of a phone hacking scandal, will step down.

title: Collaboration in Gaza Leads to Grisly Fate
description: RAFAH, Gaza Strip  When Fadel Shaloufs family went to pick up his body at the morgue the day after he was executed on a busy Gaza street corner, they found his hands still cuffed behind his back. Hamas, the militant faction that rules Gaza, did not provide a van to carry the body to burial, so they laid him on two mens laps in the back of a sedan.

title: Delta, Seeking London Access, Ponders a Stake in Virgin Atlantic
description: Delta Air Lines is in talks to buy Singapore Airlines 49 percent stake in Virgin Atlantic Airways, in an effort to bolster its international operations, particularly flights between New York and London, a person briefed on the matter said on Sunday.

title: Young Immigrant Activists Cast a Wider Net
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  After a boisterous three-day congress here, more than 600 leaders of a national movement of young immigrants living in the country without legal papers voted to expand beyond their past demands for citizenship for young people, and to mobilize in support of a bill to legalize 11 million illegal immigrants in the United States.

title: Pushing for Greater Immigration Reform
description: The United We Dream networks platform calling for an inclusive pathway to citizenship, will increase pressure on President Obama and lawmakers to pass a comprehensive overhaul.

title: A Forlorn Shuttle Points to Progress in the Rockaways
description: The travelers duck through a widened slit in a chain-link fence, a makeshift portal to a makeshift train ride above the ruins of the Rockaways. Doctors appointments await. So do school days. A grocery store with power. An A.T.M. And so they take their seats to travel through neighborhoods that are still missing many things. But not a subway, anymore. For two weeks now, a so-called H train has been running through a stretch of the Rockaways devastated by Hurricane Sandy, making stops at a limited number of the peninsulas stations with the help of a connection called the Hammels Wye, which is not ordinarily used by passenger trains.

title: Vietnam Veterans, Discharged Under Cloud, File Suit Saying Trauma Was Cause
description: NEW HAVEN  In the summer of 1968, John Shepherd Jr. enlisted in the Army, figuring that the draft would get him anyway. By January 1969, he was in the Mekong Delta, fighting with the Ninth Infantry Division.

title: Jets Defense Gives Offense Plenty of Do-Overs
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  No matter how mightily the Jets struggled to score before Greg McElroy replaced Mark Sanchez at quarterback Sunday, members of the defense said their mind-set never changed. They were determined to get off the field on third down and give their offense the ball as often as possible, believing someone would eventually figure out what to do with it.

title: Criticized as Weak in Past Talks, Obama Takes Harder Line
description: WASHINGTON  Amid demands from Republicans that President Obama propose detailed new spending cuts to avert the year-end fiscal crisis, his answer boils down to this: you first.

title: Batch Helps the Steelers Look Like the Steelers
description: BALTIMORE  Charlie Batch hugged each teammate he encountered long and hard as the Pittsburgh Steelers streamed off the field, as if he knew this was his valedictory.

title: Syria Moves Its Chemical Weapons, and U.S. and Allies Cautiously Take Note
description: WASHINGTON  The Syrian militarys movement of chemical weapons in recent days has prompted the United States and several allies to repeat their warning to President Bashar al-Assad that he would be held accountable if his forces used the weapons against the rebels fighting his government.

title: Giant Is Full-Time Kicker and Part-Time Cobbler
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Most of the attributes that make the Giants Lawrence Tynes one of the best kickers in the N.F.L. are not surprising: A strong foot. An unshakable confidence. A short memory.

title: Lottery Numbers
Reports on Alleged Fraud by 1-800-Flowers.com
description: The Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation, and the New York State Attorney Generals office have both investigated the role of 1-800-Flowers.com in an alleged fraud.

title: David Oliver Relin, Adventurous Journalist, Dies at 49
description: David Oliver Relin, a journalist and adventurer who achieved acclaim as co-author of the best seller Three Cups of Tea (2006) and then suffered emotionally and financially as basic facts in the book were called into question, died Nov. 15 in Multnomah County, Ore. He was 49.

title: A Mets Owner and Claims of Consumer Fraud
description: This article is by  Steve Eder,  Richard Sandomir and  Alison Leigh Cowan.

title: Morgan Stanley Trader Faces Inquiry on Possible Manipulation
description: On paper, Glenn Hadden seemed to be the ideal person to run a large bond trading operation at Morgan Stanley when he was hired in early 2011. Mr. Hadden, a former Goldman partner, was one of the most profitable bond traders on Wall Street.

title: Theater Prize Awarded
description: Amy Herzog has won the 2012 New York Times Outstanding Playwright Award for After the Revolution, her Off Broadway play about a politically radical family. The award, which comes with a $5,000 prize, was created in 2009 to support an American playwright whose work recently received its professional debut in New York. Ms. Herzog dedicated the award to her extended family, which inspired the characters in After the Revolution. The work was produced by Playwrights Horizons in 2010. Previous recipients include Kristoffer Diaz for The Elaborate Entrance of Chad Deity, Tarell Alvin McCraney for The Brothers Size and Dan LeFranc for Sixty Miles to Silver Lake. The selection committee included the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwrights Edward Albee, James Lapine and Lynn Nottage; the Pulitzer finalist Richard Greenberg; and current and former editors for The Times.

title: War of Wills, Vocabularies and Virtues
description: They sure talk fancy in the clink these days.

title: UBS Is Reported to Be Near a Deal on Rate Rigging
description: UBS, the Swiss banking giant, is close to reaching settlements with American and British authorities over the manipulation of interest rates, the latest case in a multiyear investigation that has rattled the financial industry and spurred a public outcry for broad reform.

title: A Boulevard in Harlem Undergoes a Resurgence
description: It was not that long ago, Leon Ellis remembered as he stared from the window of his latest restaurant, when no one wanted any part of this section of Harlem, when cabdrivers would not stop here. The farthest taxis would venture uptown was 110th Street, a boundary that fractured the neighborhood from the rest of Manhattan.

title: Spain Rodriguez, Artist of Underground Comics, Dies at 72
description: Spain Rodriguez, a cartoonist whose radical politics and hyperbolic macho imagery, all presented with sly humor, were influential elements in the rise of underground comics, died on Wednesday at his home in San Francisco. He was 72.

title: A Day After Tragedy, a Bouquet on the Steps and an Unworn Jersey in a Locker
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  There was a single bouquet of flowers on the front steps of the pale green house at the end of the street. Ten minutes from Arrowhead Stadium, the house on the corner, with the wreath on the door and a stone on the stoop that reads Dream, looked routine, like the others on Crysler Avenue. If not for the flowers.

title: Seahawks Wilson Shows He Belongs Near Head of Rookie Class
description: CHICAGO  Russell Wilson walked to the microphone shortly after Seattles 23-17 overtime win dressed in a sharp gray suit, crisp white shirt and dark tie. His trademark eye black was washed from his face.

title: Gang Said to Have Been Vanquished in 80s Makes Cameo in Extortion Case
description: When federal prosecutors accused three men of a loan-sharking scheme last week, the authorities vividly described how the men used threats of violence to ensure that they would be repaid.

title: Homeless Man Is Grateful for Officers Gift of Boots. But He Again Is Barefoot.
description: After Officer Lawrence DePrimo knelt beside a barefoot man on a bitterly cold November night in Times Square, giving him a pair of boots, a photo of his random act of good will quickly took on a life of its own  becoming a symbol for a million acts of kindness that go unnoticed every day and a reminder that even in this tough, often anonymous city, people can still look out for one another.

title: McElroy Shines in Place of Sanchez
description: A capsule look at the Jets 7-6 win over the Cardinals:

title: Reviewing Week 13 in the N.F.L.
description: DAYS BEST

title: McDowell Takes His Second World Challenge Title
description: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif.  After winning at Sherwood Country Club for the second time in his past two visits, Graeme McDowell joked that maybe he should invest in a membership and a lot.

title: Liquor Barons Death Opens Market in Uttar Pradesh
description: Just hours after the politically connected businessman Gurdeep Singh Chadha was killed in a shootout in a Delhi farmhouse this month, thousands of liquor stores in Uttar Pradesh shut down, as did half a dozen movie theaters he owned.

title: Fighting Hidden Illness Whose Draining Effects Are Noticed Every Day
description: On the surface, Salvatore Costanzos home life seems fairly normal.

title: N.F.L. Replay: Week 13
description: Tears in Kansas City, along with a few touchdowns and plenty of tackling.

title: Behind a Call That Kept Nursing Home Patients in Storms Path
description: Hurricane Sandy was swirling northward, four days before landfall, and at the Sea Crest Health Care Center, a nursing home overlooking the Coney Island Boardwalk in Brooklyn, workers were gathering medicines and other supplies as they prepared to evacuate.

title: Jets Beat Cardinals
description: Action from the Jets 7-6 victory over the Arizona Cardinals at MetLife Stadium, as Greg McElroy, replacing Mark Sanchez, threw a touchdown pass in his N.F.L. debut.

title: Ballet, Rock, the Blues and Acting Share Honors
description: WASHINGTON  As an Academy Award-winning actor heralded for redefining Hollywoods conception of the leading man, Dustin Hoffman doesnt focus on his legacy.

title: Corrections: December 3, 2012
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

title: Cashmans Next Challenge: Taking a Patient Approach to Fixing the Yankees Offense
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  It has become a holiday tradition: on the eve of baseballs winter meetings, the man in charge of the Yankees fluctuating roster, General Manager Brian Cashman, puts on an elf suit and rappels from the roof of the Landmark Building in Stamford, Conn.

title: Dickey and Mets Enter Key Period for Contract Talks
description: NASHVILLE  R. A. Dickey is not officially the host of baseballs winter meetings in his hometown, but he might as well be.

title: Pentagons Top Technologist Joins I.B.M.
description: Last Friday afternoon, a half-hour after he said his goodbyes at the Pentagon, where he was assistant secretary of defense for research and engineering, Zachary Lemnios was discussing why his new job made sense as the next step in his career. Exactly the right thing to do at the right time, he said.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, Dec. 3
description: Its like we are in a shed of cows, waiting their turn for slaughtering. After what happened with my sons, I hate all the people; I even hate myself.

title: Living With a Sound You Cant Turn Off
description: Shortly after my 70th birthday, a high-pitched hum began in my left ear. I noticed it only during quiet times but soon realized that it never went away.

title: Images of Brain Injuries in Athletes
description: Images of athletes brains illustrate the deterioration that can be caused by repeated mild head traumas.

title: Study Bolsters Link Between Routine Hits and Brain Disease
description: The growing evidence of a link between head trauma and long-term, degenerative brain disease was amplified in an extensive study of athletes, military veterans and others who absorbed repeated hits to the head, according to new findings published in the scientific journal Brain.

title: Word of the Day | relic
description: relic \re-lik\ noun

title: School Districts in 5 States Will Lengthen Their Calendars
description: The school day and year are about to get longer in 10 school districts in five states, where schools will add up to 300 hours to their calendars starting next fall.

title: Parsi Money, Not Bodies, Key to Vulture Survival, Expert Says
description: Ask the director of the Bombay Natural History Society about vultures, and he will discuss the issue endlessly. Ask him about Parsis and their corpse disposal practices, and he will roll his eyes.

title: Symbolism and Numerology in North Korean Rocketry
description: HONG KONG  North Korea has announced it will make another attempt to launch a long-range rocket, and speculation is rife on the peninsula about the when and the whys of this latest effort.

title: News Quiz | December 3, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Will Guardiolas Message Translate Outside Barcelona?
description: It is somewhat odd that while club owners across Europe desperately woo Pep Guardiola, he has been passed over for the one job in which he explicitly expressed an interest.

title: A Eulogy for Remus
description: Dear Diary:

title: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 3
description: NEWS Despite solid credentials, college graduates cannot find permanent jobs that gets them on the path to the taxpaying, property-owning French ideal that was once the norm. Steven Erlanger reports from Lille, France.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Dec. 3, 2012
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article With Stickers, a Petition and Even a Middle Name, Secession Fever Hits Texas.

title: A Conversation With: Indias Chief Climate Change Negotiator
description: DOHA, Qatar  With one week left for the U.N. climate change talks to conclude, developed and developing countries remain at odds on how to solve the crisis being linked to the recent spate of extreme weather events that have claimed lives and destroyed property worth billions of dollar.

title: An Act of Kindness Goes Viral
description: In Photo of Officer Giving Boots to Barefoot Man Warms Hearts Online, and City Shows Gratitude After Gift by an Officer,J. David Goodman writes about a good Samaritan. In a Dec. 3 follow-up, Times reporters find that Homeless Man Is Grateful for Officers Gift of Boots. But He Again Is Barefoot,

title: Taking Photos, and Action, in Indonesia
description: In a region of Indonesia that is blessed with gold, copper and timber, the people who have lived there for centuries are cursed with poverty. The indigenous Papuans of the countrys two easternmost provinces have suffered, as they watched migrants come from other parts of the country to set up profitable businesses or get better-paying jobs.

title: Are Digital Photographs Too Plentiful to Be Meaningful?
description: How often do you and your friends take photos? How many do you post on social media? Are there any photos, from your past or present, that are especially meaningful to you? Are those images digital only or have they been printed?

title: The Early Word: No Mercy
description: Todays Times

title: Part 1: College Students Answer Readers Questions About Admissions and Campus Life
description: The Choice has invited two of our former student bloggers of The Envelope, Please series to stop by our virtual Guidance Office and answer reader questions about the admissions process and what college life is like after youve made your choice.

title: Did Costas Choose Right Forum for Gun Control Remarks?
description: Bob Costas and NBC angered a lot of people Sunday night, and it had nothing to do with tape-delayed Olympic results.

title: December College Checklist for Seniors
description: This week, The Choice is publishing our monthly Counselors Calendar, which is designed to keep students on track during the college admissions process.

title: The Debt Limit Is the Real Fiscal Cliff
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: How Will Aging Baby Boomers Affect Crash Rates?
description: While the number of older drivers is growing, it is not likely that these graying baby boomers will cause greater carnage on Americas roads, according to a new study by the Highway Loss Data Institute, which is affiliated with the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. Both are financed by the insurance industry.

title: What the Doha Climate Talks Could Do for Sustainable Development
description: While participants at last years climate meeting in Durban, South Africa, agreed on an extension of the troubled Kyoto Protocol, it is at this years meeting in Doha, Qatar, that policy makers have to agree on the pesky details, including long-term emission reduction goals.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Nathaniel Rich on Falling in Love With a Jellyfish
description: Nathaniel Rich wrote this weeks cover story about a Japanese scientist who studies jellyfish that regenerate themselves. Rich is the author of the novel The Mayors Tongue; Farrar, Straus & Giroux will publishhis second novelthis spring. His last article for the magazine was about the Lower Ninth Ward in New Orleans.

title: Terms of Greek Bond Buyback Top Expectations
description: LONDON  In a bold bid to reduce its debt burden, Greece offered on Monday to spend as much as 10 billion euros to buy back 30 billion euros of its bonds from investors and banks.

title: British Lawmakers Accuse Multinationals of Immorally Avoiding Taxes
description: The British government announced plans on Monday to crack down on tax dodgers as a parliamentary report criticized United States companies for what it described as tax avoidance.

title: Malaria or Mars?
description: Alexander Kumar, a physician and researcher at Concordia Station, writes from Antarctica, where he conducts scientific experiments for the European Space Agencys human spaceflight program.

title: Q&A: Opening a New Page in a Browser Tab
description: Q.

title: Fill-In | Saying No to College
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first eight paragraphs of the article Saying No to College by Alex Williams.

description: I wrote last week about the poor choices facing patients, most very old and within six months of death, who need nursing home care after a hospitalization.

description: When is not scoring a touchdown the right thing to do?

description: Update: Dec. 4, 2012
