description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: On Our Radar: Mislabeled Seafood
description: A year after a Boston Globe investigation, a new round of DNA testing shows that restaurants and stores across Massachusetts are still mislabeling the fish they are selling. [The Boston Globe]

title: Week 13 Quick Hits: Colts Luck Plays Like Big Ben
description: Andy Benoit takes a quick tour of Sundays Week 13 games. Share your thoughts.

title: Opinion Report: Promises on AIDS
description: From the editorial page

title: Choosing Between McElroy and Sanchez
description: Its not a quarterback controversy on the order of Alex Smith versus Colin Kaepernick, but the Jets have at least injected some life into the leadup to the Jaguars game  just as Greg McElroy gave some life to the Jets on Sunday in a victory over Arizona.

title: Cantor Fitzgerald to Buy Irish Brokerage Firm
description: LONDON  Cantor Fitzgerald agreed on Monday to acquire the Irish firm Dolmen Stockbrokers as part of its expansion into global markets.

title: Winner Lose All
description: MADRID  The results of last weeks regional elections in Catalonia arent what they seem.

title: What Ails You, Putin?
description: MOSCOW  If you type Putin on Yandex, the most popular search engine in the Russian language, a drop-down list appears: Putin, Vladimir Vladimirovich, Putin stroke, Putin Wikipedia, Putin biography and Putin is ill. In other words, the top five options include two regarding the Russian presidents rumored ill health. Even Putins ostensible longtime mistress is only No. 7 on this list of things that Russians want to know. The big question now is, Whats wrong with the president?

title: UBS Approaches Deal on Rate Rigging
description: The Swiss bank UBS is close to reaching settlements with American and British authorities over the manipulation of interest rates, DealBooks Ben Protess and Mark Scott report. UBS is expected to pay more than $450 million to settle claims that some employees reported false rates to increase the banks profit, according to officials briefed on the matter who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the talks were private.

title: Malaysia Urged to Protect Domestic Workers
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Malaysia must punish the recruitment agents accused of forcing more than 100 foreign women to work as domestic help without pay and enforce laws to protect migrant workers, the Indonesian Embassy in Kuala Lumpur and a migrant workers support group said on Monday.

title: Archer Daniels Raises Bid for GrainCorp
description: The Archer Daniels Midland Company raised its offer for GrainCorp of Australia on Monday, valuing the grain processor at about $2.9 billion, as A.D.M. pressed ahead with its unsolicited takeover bid.

title: Monday Reading: Test-Flying the 787 Dreamliner
Asked & Answered | Aby Rosen
description: The German-born real estate mogul and prolific art collector Aby Rosen is Art Basel Miami Beachs poster boy for parties, hosting A-list, superprivate dinners that bring together top art collectors, connoisseurs and the requisite fashion crowd.

title: Designer to the Stars Takes a Stroll Down the Catwalk
description: LONDON  When I see them, I remember every single dress, says Valentino, as he walks down the runway, looking at chair labels in the audience reading Jennifer Lopez or Carla Bruni. The designer points to dresses worn by the famous to the Oscars  or, in the case of Jacqueline Kennedy, for her 1968 Greek island wedding to Aristotle Onassis.

title: New York Times Seeks Buyouts From 30 in Newsroom
description: Aiming to cut costs in an increasingly troubled advertising environment, The New York Times announced on Monday morning that it would offer buyout packages to newsroom employees. While the primary goal of the buyout program is to trim managers and other nonunion employees from its books, the company is offering employees represented by the Newspaper Guild the chance to volunteer for buyout packages as well.

title: Saputo to Buy Morningstar Unit of Dean Foods for $1.45 Billion
description: Saputo, a Canadian dairy processor, agreed on Monday to buy the Morningstar division of Dean Foods for about $1.45 billion in cash to help expand its presence in the United States.

title: Trump Takes On a Farmer, and the Farmer Wins
description: New Yorks bloviator-in-chief has landed ignobly on the losing end of a couple of recent elections. Yes, as you have probably figured out, the reference is to Donald J. Trump.

title: News Corp. Gives Details on Its Corporate Split
description: 8:15 p.m. | Updated A phone hacking scandal and restless shareholders may have forced Rupert Murdoch to split News Corporation into two companies, but on Monday he celebrated the decision by pouring Veuve Clicquot Champagne over the head of his newest editor.

title: New Glimpses of the Twin Towers Past
description: Anthony W. Robins did not set out to amass one of the most important surviving archives of the original World Trade Center. Though he is an architectural historian devoted to the buildings of New York City, Mr. Robins didnt even set out to study the twin towers.

title: Pete Wells, Restaurant Critic, Answers Readers Questions
description: Pete Wells, the chief restaurant critic of The New York Times, answered selected readers questions Monday and Tuesday.

title: After Years of Indies, Will Studios Triumph?
description: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences handed out its Governors Awards on Saturday night. The honorees were the stuntman Hal Needham, the documentarian D. A. Pennebaker and the film advocate George Stevens Jr. But the celebratory feel in the Ray Dolby Ballroom in Hollywood had as much to do with past achievements as with the Oscar season ahead.

title: What Were Reading
description: Smithsonian: The strange, sweet stench of the durian fruit, explained.  Julia Moskin

title: A Couple at a Crossroads: How to Build?
description: My wife, Julia, and I are fast approaching the end of an internship that involves building a straw bale house in Moab, Utah, with the nonprofit Community Rebuilds. We took this four-month volunteer position to gain experience in constructing someone elses affordable green home before beginning to build our own on land Julias family owns near Woodstock, N.Y.

title: Refuge for Healing Veterans
description: The Veterans Sanctuary in Trumansburg, N.Y., provides a holistic wellness program and rehabilitation center for veterans, with a focus on those returning from Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Network TVs Struggles, and the Pope to Add Followers on Twitter
description: Other than at NBC, prime time ratings of network television are down this fall  in the case of Fox and CBS, sharply down, Bill Carter writes. Programmers can come up with a number of reasons why it has been hard for the networks to grab audience attention, what with all the big news distractions of an election and Hurricane Sandy. But, still, these executives concede, the shows themselves have failed to entice: the only new series to crack the top 30 among 18- to 49-year-olds is the NBC drama Revolution. Lately, cable has been doing a better job of making the kind of programs that can break through.

title: Healing Veterans Find Solace in Community and the Arts
description: The Veterans Sanctuary in Trumansburg, N.Y., provides a holistic wellness program and rehabilitation center for veterans, with a focus on those returning from Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: This Week in the Global Arts Guide
description: Images of People, at the Museum Frieder Burda in Baden-Baden, Germany, is a themed approach to Mr. Burdas collection of modern and contemporary art. Human emotions are the recurring motif expressed in a variety of styles in the paintings of Gerhard Richter, Sigmar Polke and Georg Baselitz (with his trademark upside-down scenes). The younger generation is not forgotten: Tim Eitel paints lonely people after photographs he took himself but insists on calling them fictions; Susanne Khn, while creating narrative works that blend interiors, landscapes and figuration, favors space, color and structure over meaning; and Simon Pasieka uses a dreamy palette to paint young people living on the margins of society. Through Jan. 6.

title: Howard Stern to Return to Americas Got Talent
description: Howard Stern will return to NBC as a judge on its summer talent competition Americas Got Talent, the network announced Monday morning.

title: Old Vic Announces 2013 Season
description: Vanessa Redgrave, 75, and James Earl Jones, 81, seen together not long ago on Broadway and the West End in Driving Miss Daisy, will team up again as an unusually well-seasoned version of the lovers Beatrice and Benedick in Shakespeares Much Ado About Nothing, at a production next September at the Old Vic in London, directed by Mark Rylance.

title: A Diplomatic Red Line
description: TimesCast: The United States warns Syria over its chemical weapons. | To be young, educated and unemployed in France. | Tax deals create a war between New York and New Jersey.

title: The Giving Spree | John Derian
description: Who: The store owner and designer John Derian, whose home renovation was documented in T in The Makeunder.

title: Daily Report: Car-Service App Tangles With Regulators
description: Summoning a taxi or car service with your smartphone feels like the future. City governments around the world can agree on that. But as Brian X. Chen reports in Mondays New York Times, many of them are proposing new rules that would stop Uber, one of the most prominent ride-requesting apps.

title: Watching the Entrepreneurial Flame Flicker
description: Every successful company I know shares a common ingredient: a leader who is an entrepreneur and who is irrationally committed to the companys success. These people will duck, dive, dodge, twist and turn to live to fight another day and make their dreams and visions come true.

title: Dallas Museum Volunteers to Return Mosaic to Turkey
description: The Dallas Museum of Art voluntarily returned an ancient marble mosaic in its collection to Turkey on Monday, after determining that the work  which dates from A.D. 194 and shows Orpheus taming animals with his lyre  was probably stolen years ago from a Turkish archaeological site.

title:
Initial Deficit Cuts Are Sticking Point in
Negotiations
description: WASHINGTON  For all the growing angst over the state of negotiations to head off a fiscal crisis in January, the parties are farthest apart on a relatively small part of the overall deficit reduction program  the down payment.

title: Dell Shares Leap After Analyst Muses About a Buyout
description: Shares of Dell rose sharply on Monday after an analyst at Goldman Sachs upgraded the stock  and mused about the (distant!) possibility of a leveraged buyout in the computer makers future.

title: For Holiday Party Fare, Try a Pure
description: Heres a new concept: view the holiday party season as an opportunity to eat more vegetables and legumes. I spent a week making Mediterranean vegetable and bean pures that we spread on toasted bread and devoured for lunch and dinner every day. My son and I managed to consume nearly a pound each of fresh spinach, carrots, and winter squash. Liam is admittedly a very hungry, athletic teenager, but this was a great indication that something healthy and delicious (and pretty, too!) on a canap is just as likely to be gobbled up as something not-so-healthy.

title: How Much Homework Does It Take to Educate a Nation?
description: Finland and South Koreas school systems are practically polar opposites.

title: A Financial Plan for Misbehaving Lottery Winners
description: Carl Richards is a financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

title: Amour Gains a Euro Prize, and Perhaps Momentum
description: The European Film Awards  a polling of 2,500 professional across the continent  were handed down over the weekend, and it was a near-sweep for Michael Haneckes Amour, named the best feature. The tale of an elderly Parisian dealing with his wifes dementia, it also won top prizes for its stars, Jean-Louis Trintignant and Emmanuelle Riva, and best director for Mr. Haneke, the Austrian filmmaker and frequent Cannes champion best known for The White Ribbon and other cinematic tragedies. Amour is, as our colleague Larry Rohter wrote, the front-runner for the best foreign-language Oscar.

title: South African Company to Build U.S. Plant to Convert Gas to Liquid Fuels
description: WESTLAKE, La.  In an ambitious bet that the glut of cheap natural gas in the United States will last for many years, a South African energy company announced on Monday that it would build Americas first commercial plant to convert natural gas to diesel and other liquid fuels.

title: Obama to Ask Wasserman Schultz to Stay On as D.N.C. Chief
description: President Obama will ask Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz to serve another term as chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee and preside over the party as it heads into the next election cycle.

title: Chaplin to Close Next Month
description: Chaplin: The Musical, starring Rob McClure as the Little Tramp, will have its final Broadway performance on Jan. 6, the producers announced on Monday. When the show closes at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, it will have played 24 previews and 136 regular performances.

title: Science Times Podcast
description: This week: the doctor versus the computer and your life after cancer.

title: Image of the Day: Dec. 3
Exploring Humanitys Evolving Global Brain
description: Over the last several years, Ive become familiar with the work of Thomas W. Malone and the Center for Collective Intelligence, the lab he directs at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The center is studying, and trying to make the most of, the human species fast-growing capacity to think outside the box  with the box in this case being an individuals skull and cerebral cortex.

title: Street Style: Metallics
description: The best of readers photos from the week of Nov. 26.

title: Twitter Has a New User: The Pope
description: VATICAN CITY  Now trending on Twitter: Pope Benedict XVI.

title: Leading Off: For the Chiefs, a Day of Sorrow and Inspiration
description: From very far away, the Kansas City Chiefs win Sundays game over Carolina in the wake of the unthinkable murder-suicide perpetrated by Chiefs linebacker Jovan Belcher could have been tied up with a little sports bow. In footballs usual make-believe world, the kind often spun out of whole cloth by television types, the Chiefs rallied together, inspired one another, started to heal and move on and go ahead and fill in more of the clichs designed to make sports and athletes so heroic.

title: For Rodriguez, First One Hip, Now the Other
description: 10:32 p.m. | Updated

title: E.P.A. Updates a Decades-Old Water Quality Standard
description: Last week the Environmental Protection Agency issued a new set of water quality guidelines for monitoring bacterial outbreaks in inland and coastal waters used frequently by recreational swimmers. The standard was last updated in 1986. The move was prompted by a federal court order and a requirement of the Beaches Environmental Assessment and Coastal Health Act of 2000.

title: Dont Rush the Critics Circle (People Have Tried)
description: The New York Film Critics Circle, one of the countrys pre-eminent critics groups, knows how to build anticipation: its releasing its choices for the years best cinema one by one on Twitter today, leaving the awards blogosphere alternately panting with me-firstness and grumbling with me-lastness.

title: Close Encounters With the Lincoln Brand
description: Dip into most news outlets this week and it will be almost impossible not to encounter the Lincoln, Ford Motor Companys luxury brand.

title: Steven Strogatz and The Joy of x, Part 2
description: This week we offer a second puzzle from  The Joy of x,  the recently-released book by mathematician Steven Strogatz based on his popular New York Times Opinionator Series The Elements of Math. If you happened to enjoy The Elements of Math, youll love The Joy of x.

title: Copelands Strides Give Knicks a New, Improved Look
description: The most obvious difference between this Knicks season and any of the last dozen years are the high expectations. The Knicks are 12-4, second in the Eastern Conference and fifth overall. For the first time in more than a decade, the Knicks could be considered title contenders.

title: Man Trying to Rescue Cat Dies in Fall From Tree
description: Updated, 5:45 p.m. | A 53-year-old man fell out of a tree and died while trying to rescue a cat in the Bronx late Sunday night or early Monday morning, the police said.

title: The Rock Hall of Fame Names a New Frontman
description: The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame has a new frontman. Greg S. Harris, who before coming to the rock hall was a top official at the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum, will take over as the president and chief executive on Jan. 1, when the current chief executive, Terry Stewart, steps down.

title: You Can Use the Slick Stuff to Clean Your Face
description: Tight, dull and parched skin can be a nagging problem come winter. Oil-based cleansers are frequently touted as powerful hydrators suitable for all skin types, including oily complexions. Below are some of the newest.

title: College Freshmen Home for Winter Break: Independence vs. House Rules?
description: Are you a college freshman who will be heading home for winter break? My colleague Jan Hoffman would like to write about your first homecoming:

title: Removing Sacrifice From Gluten-Free
description: I WAS gluten-free before it was cool to be. In 2000, a doctor told me I was allergic to wheat, barley and rye, and said that avoiding gluten was the only way to end my stomach pains and chronic lethargy. So I had to give up tagliatelle, Belgian-style ale, granola and  I feared  cooking for friends.

title: Lawyer Says Trader Did Not Manipulate Market
description: A lawyer for a high-profile trader under investigation over his trading in Treasury futures said his client did not engage in any manipulative activity.

title: Everythings Great in China
description: HONG KONGSome two weeks after Chinas once-in-a-decade leadership change brought intense scrutiny from the rest of the world, mainland government officials and sundry representatives vetted to speak with American journalists are fiercely, defensively optimistic: Everythings swell, the countrys on the up and up, and any problems are really just glitches, easily surmountable.

title: Monday Motorsports: Keselowski Collects $5 Million as Nascar Champion
description: LAS VEGAS  Brad Keselowski was officially crowned Sprint Cup champion on Friday at Nascars annual awards banquet here.Keselowski, a first-time winner, accepted a trophy, a diamond-studded champions ring from the Nascar president, Brian France, and a check for more than $5 million.

title: Sex, Drugs, Rock n Roll and More Sex?
description: For our most recent Ask the Expert feature, we invited readers to send us questions about female sexuality and aging. There was such a strong response that our expert, Susan Kellogg, a professor of obstetrics and gynecology, will be answering a second round of questions on Wednesday.

title: The Get | Chris Benzs Rhoda Dress for Anthropologie
description: Welcome Anthropologies latest Made in Kind designer partner: New Yorks Chris Benz. Its a little something fun to spice up ladies wardrobes before the holidays, says Benz of the capsule collection, which goes on sale today. Casual separates, like oversize tees, blouses with big off-the-shoulder bows, and floor-sweeping mermaid skirts, complement the collections dresses: ruffled, printed and peplumed, all perfect for a party. Our intent was to bring unique pieces that embody my aesthetic  rich in color and print, Benz says. Standing out is the print, which appears here on the knot-neck Rhoda dress ($348) and which Benz says, incorporates the idea of a cameo but almost resembles a piece of precious jewelry.

title: Tax Battle in the Northeast
description: Bettina Damiani of Good Jobs New York, and Jonathan Gouveia of the N.Y.C. Economic Development Corporation, discuss the issue of pro-business tax incentives in New York and New Jersey.

title: Dont Encourage Students to Skip College
description: Kobe Bryant and LeBron James didnt go to college at all. Carmelo Anthony attended Syracuse University, but for only a year. All three are now superstars in the N.B.A., earning tens of millions of dollars. So does this mean that we should encourage our 14-year-old hoops-loving son to take a shot at a similar path and see if he can make it as a professional basketball player?

title: Stevie Wonder Drops Out of Benefit for Israeli Soldiers
description: Stevie Wonder has pulled out of a concert in Los Angeles benefiting Friends of the Israel Defense Forces, citing the current tensions in the Middle East.

title: Most New Yorkers Think Climate Change Caused Hurricane, Poll Finds
description: New York State voters overwhelmingly say they believe that Hurricane Sandy demonstrated the effects of climate change, according to a poll released Monday by Siena College.

title: Walkabout  12/3: Airbnb Hosts Busted for Subletting; Delta Eyes Singapore Airlines
description: Airbnb Hosts Beware Renters who sublet their apartments through Airbnb may not be aware theyre breaking city ordinances. Some believe the site ought to do a better job at informing their users. (New York Times)

title: New Faces at the N.H.L. Negotiating Table
description: The outcome of two meetings this week could decide whether the N.H.L. season will be salvaged or lost to a lockout for the second time in nine years.

title: 5 European Nations Summon Envoys of Israel
description: JERUSALEM  Britain, France, Spain, Sweden and Denmark summoned the Israeli ambassadors to their countries on Monday to protest Israels plans for increased settlement construction, an unusually sharp diplomatic step that reflected the growing frustration abroad with Israels policies on the Palestinian issue.

title: Have an N.F.L. Question? Judy Battista Has Answers
description: How (and when) will the Eagles soap opera end? How good (or not) are the Bears right now? How will the Niners resolve their quarterback situation? And the Jets? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The New York Times, will answer questions from readers this week. Use the comment field below for your questions. Answers will appear Friday on The Fifth Down.

title: Spate of Harsh Weather in New England Shifts Sentiment on Trees
description: WILBRAHAM, Mass.  First came the tornado, which felled five big trees and sent them crashing down on half their house, forcing Heather Mercier and Ellie Tobiasz to move into a mobile home on their property while the house was being repaired.

title: Its Health Care Costs, Stupid
description: Busy day, so not much blogging. But a further thought on budget issues.

title: More Goodbyes (and One Good Riddance) for Philip Roth
description: Philip Roths recent announcement that he was retiring from fiction prompted headlines around the world. It has also prompted a chorus of envy, skepticism and at least one finally! from three dozen writers recently canvassed by Flavorwire.com.

title: Cuomo Travels to Washington to Press for Disaster Aid
description: WASHINGTON  It was an unusual role for a politician who is accustomed to being in complete charge.

title: After Re-election, Missouri Republican Decides to Leave Congress
description: The longest-serving member of Missouris Congressional delegation is leaving the Capitol and is headed to K Street.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Barrie Berg, chief executive for the Americas at What If Innovation, New York, was named to a new post, global chief executive. She succeeds Sal Pajwani, who will take a post that involves working with what the agency described as its largest and most global clients.

title: Man Pushed to Death on Subway Tracks
description: Updated, 9:47 p.m. | A 58-year-old subway passenger was killed on Monday after he was pushed onto the tracks of an onrushing train in Manhattan by a man who had been mumbling to himself as he walked along the platform, the police said.

title: Telling the Story of PHL (Also Known as Philadelphia)
description: An agency that promotes the City of Brotherly Love would love to share its assets, the better to raise the profile of Philadelphia around the world as a place to do business, visit, hold meetings and attend college.

title: For Planes, a Climate Antidote: Bypass the Arctic
description: This year Arctic sea ice reached a historic low, breaking a record set in 2007 by a whopping 18 percent. Researchers suggest that the ice could disappear entirely in as little as two or three decades. That would accelerate the warming of the planet, given that dark solar-energy-absorbing ocean water would replace a surface of bright white ice, which reflects sunlight back into space.

title: String of Insider Trading Cases Shows Prosecutors Casting a Wider Net
description: The end of November included a veritable rush of insider trading prosecutions, belying the notion that the government goes on hiatus at the end of the year.

title: For Second Opinion, Consult a Computer?
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The man on stage had his audience of 600 mesmerized. Over the course of 45 minutes, the tension grew. Finally, the moment of truth arrived, and the room was silent with anticipation.

title: Tom Cruise, On Screen and in Person
description: For those who feel the need for speed and others who are looking to be completed, the Film Society of Lincoln Center will present a retrospective of the work of Tom Cruise this month, as well as a live talk with the star.

title: A Rise in Injuries on Inflatable Bouncers
description: A new study has found that in the past two decades more than 64,000 children under 17 have been injured using inflatable bouncers at home or at public recreation facilities.

title: Aspirin Tied to Reduced Risk of Liver Cancer
description: In a large prospective study, researchers have found an association between aspirin use and a reduced risk of liver cancer.

title: Tree Power
description: Q. My family owns a 40-acre woodlot of relatively mature deciduous trees. How many pounds of carbon dioxide does such a forest absorb in a typical year? And how many pounds of oxygen are emitted?

title: S.E.C. Charges 5 Firms Over Audits in China
description: 9:06 p.m. | Updated

title: Cicely Tyson to Star in Trip to Bountiful on Broadway
description: The Academy Award-nominated actress Cicely Tyson will return to Broadway for the first time in 30 years to star in a revival of Horton Footes 1953 drama The Trip to Bountiful, directed by Michael Wilson, the shows producers announced on Monday. The 14-week run is to begin previews on March 31 at the Stephen Sondheim Theater, with opening night scheduled for April 23.

title: The Les Miz Folks, Singing Even After Production Wraps
description: The campaign for Les Misrables, an expected juggernaut in the making, continued apace this weekend. On Sunday Universal, the studio behind Tom Hoopers big-budget musical adaptation, held another invite-only screening, complete with the now de rigueur applause breaks after musical numbers. (Anne Hathaways rendition of I Dreamed a Dream typically brings down the house.)

title: Students Seize Cooper Union Room to Protest Possible Tuition
description: Updated, 3:57 p.m. | Twelve students barricaded themselves inside an eighth-floor room at the top of the Cooper Union Foundation Building at noon on Monday to urge the school not to begin charging tuition to undergraduates.

title: Newspapers Continue to Struggle
description: TimesCast Media+Tech: The latest shake-ups at newspaper companies. | Marketing to single aunts. | Networks fail to produce fall television hits.

title: Royal Baby a Delight, Especially to Britains Tabloids
description: LONDON  The speculation began virtually the moment Kate Middleton said I will to Prince William in April 2011, leaving an industry of tabloid newspapers and gossip magazines with a big black hole where their wedding coverage used to be.

title: Trust Women Conference: The Biggest Issues in Womens Rights
description: Activists from around the world introduced the most pressing issues of law and rights facing women at the first session of the two-day Trust Women Conference on Dec. 4, hosted by the International Herald Tribune and ThomsonReuters Foundation.

title: In Lab Lit, Fiction Meets Science of the Real World
description: In Barbara Kingsolvers new novel, Flight Behavior, a central character is an entomologist tracking the effects of global climate change on monarch butterflies. The scientist, Ovid Byron, shows up at the Appalachian farm of Dellarobia Turnbow after she discovers a vast immigration of monarchs, displaced from their Mexican wintering spot by floods caused by global warming.

title: TimesCast Media+Tech: Newspapers Continue to Struggle
description: The latest shake-ups at newspaper companies. Marketing to single aunts. Networks fail to produce fall television hits.

title: Go See | Little Things: A Flneurs Finds
description: When the graphic designer JP Williams appeared on The Martha Stewart Show a few years ago with his collection of vintage twine balls, the famed hostess marveled over the fact that he viewed them as art, not just utilitarian objects. Now, for his exhibition Little Things: A Flneurs Finds at Tribecas Mondo Cane gallery, hes transformed them into art that anyone can appreciate: a family of small cast bronze sculptures that also includes facsimiles of doorstops, dried banana peels and 10 other curiosities from his extensive personal archive. Each item was picked from off my shelves or out of my drawers because I thought other people might want to hold or touch it, says Williams, who was a founder of the esteemed design firm MW in 1993. While his first bronze made its debut last year at the now-shuttered NoHo shop Partners & Spade, the Mondo Cane exhibition is the first time hes stepped away from client work to properly showcase his own creations. Theyre all about form for me, and seeing that form transcend whatever it was before, he explains. Thats what art is really about, isnt it?

title: Pharmaceuticals: GlaxoSmithKline Retains Top Ranking Measuring Outreach to Poor Countries
description: GlaxoSmithKline hung on to its perennial top spot in the new Access to Medicines Index released last week, but its competitors are closing in.

title: From All Sides, Fiscal Plans Fall Far Short of Whats Needed
description: We dont yet know whether our economy will take the icy plunge off the fiscal cliff, but do we know this: At present course and speed, any budget deal that emerges from the intense brinkmanship now under way would fall short of every sensible ambition for fiscal reform.

title: The Trust Women Conference
description: In London, two Nobel Peace Prize laureates  Shirin Ebadi from Iran, and, by video from Myanmar, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi  will kick off the first Trust Women conference held by the International Herald Tribune and ThomsonReuters Foundation. The aim of the two-day gathering is to examine how law can be used to further the empowerment of women and enhance gender diversity. Lawyers, aid organizations and government officials from all over will meet representatives of women from all over who need either the existing laws of their countries to be enforced in their favor, or to get laws passed that will bolster the advancement of women.

title: Teenagers and the Morning-After Pill
description: When a teenager goes in for a checkup, the pediatrician often asks the parent to step outside so the doctor can talk to the youngster one-on-one about sensitive topics, like whether she is using drugs or is sexually active.

title: At Loft Conversion, City Stop Work Order Failed to Stop It for Long
description: The old brick factory building on Banker Street and Meserole Avenue in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, is just blocks from Williamsburgs bustling Bedford Avenue, McCarren Park and the East River. There is exposed brick. There are stainless steel appliances. There is a jaw-dropping panoramic view of the Manhattan skyline from the expansive roof terrace, the perfect party space.

title: A Repeat Win for Kathryn Bigelow, Plus a Few Surprises From New York Film Critics Circle
description: Its a busy day for pop culture news and a slow-drip day for movie news: All afternoon the New York Film Critics Circle has been revealing its year-end winners on Twitter. For its surprises, at least, the Bagger will say it was worth the wait.

title: Filling In at Safety, a Giant Breaks Out by Forcing Turnovers
description: When Stevie Brown was asked to move from safety, a position he had played with distinction, to linebacker as a senior at Michigan, he viewed the switch as a chance to improve his tackling. He made the transition without complaint.

title: Tourists Increase Share of Broadway Ticket Sales
description: Tourists accounted for nearly two-thirds of the tickets sold for Broadway shows last season, according to the Broadway Leagues annual demographics report, released on Monday.

title: Nordstrom and GE Capital Block Mint.com Users
description: Nordstrom, the retailer widely known for its excellent customer service, recently caused a ruckus among some of its credit card holders by terminating access to their accounts by Mint.com, the online money-management site.

title: Marketing to Single Aunts
description: A look at a potentially lucrative demographic: the PANK, or Professional Aunt, No Kids.

title: Really? Some Herbal Remedies Can Be Useful During Pregnancy
description: THE FACTS

title: Taking His Fight Against H.P. to the Web
description: Mike Lynch, the founder of the British software company Autonomy, is not about to walk away from his fight with Hewlett-Packard over the technology giants claims of accounting fraud.

title: The Stroke Remains, but Not the Desire
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  As he has on countless weekends over the last decade, Andy Roddick awoke Saturday in a city not his own, ready to work. His preparation was typically thorough because, appearances notwithstanding, it is not an easy job to entertain people.

title: Border Agents Power to Search Devices Is Facing Increasing Challenges in Court
description: The government has historically had broad power to search travelers and their property at the border. But that prerogative is being challenged as more people travel with extensive personal and business information on devices that would typically require a warrant to examine.

title: British Business Leaders Stay Silent on E.U. Exit
description: LONDON  The chairman of the London Stock Exchange, Chris Gibson-Smith, simply does not have the time to speak. Christopher North, the boss of Amazon in Britain, is too busy as well. And Charles Dunstone, the founder of the mobile phone retailer Carphone Warehouse, also has an exceptionally full agenda.

title: Republicans Make Counteroffer in Fiscal Talks
description: WASHINGTON  Republican Congressional leaders on Monday countered President Obamas deficit reduction proposal with a plan of their own that is far heavier on spending cuts but embraces $800 billion in new taxes over the next 10 years.

title: Mars Rover Discovery Revealed
description: Last Updated, 4:55 p.m. SAN FRANCISCO  In a sand drift on Mars, NASAs Curiosity rover discovered  sand.

title: Bahrains Embrace of Kim Kardashian
description: Bahrains continuing attempt to change the subject of international conversation about the kingdom away from its crackdown on dissent took an awkward turn over the weekend, when the nations foreign minister posted a message on Twitter thanking Kim Kardashian for saying nice things about the country during a brief visit to open a milkshake shop.

title: Doubts on Treatment for Urinary Infection
description: A study of urinary tract infection treatments in men suggests that a longer course of antibiotics may do more harm than good.

title: U.S. Warns Syria on Chemical Weapons
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama warned Syria on Monday not to use chemical weapons against its own people, vowing to hold accountable anyone who did, even as American intelligence officials picked up signs that such arms might be deployed in the fighting there.

title: Elizabeth Price, Video Artist, Wins Turner Prize
description: The video artist Elizabeth Price, whose work splices together images, sounds and texts dealing with subjects as disparate as 1960s girl bands and a tragic chain-store fire in the late 1970s, won this years coveted Turner Prize.

title: Insomnia Is Linked to Trouble Breathing
description: Subtle breathing problems during sleep may play a larger role in causing insomnia than the usual suspects, like stress and the need for a bathroom, a small study of poor sleepers suggests.

title: Acrobatic Blue Whales Can Sneak Up on Krill
description: To capture enough food for their enormous bodies, blue whales use an extreme technique called lunge feeding: they take enormous gulps of water, then let it pass through comb-like mouth filters called baleen, keeping krill behind for consumption.

title: Discussing Washington Square, by Henry James
description: Thanks to all of you who participated in tonights discussion of Washington Square. It was one of our liveliest to date. Feel free to comment and raise additional questions this week. Ill be checking in from time to time. Our next book club selection will be announced shortly.

title: Choosing Sides on Regulating the Press
description: LONDON  When the final report of the nine-month Leveson inquiry into the ways of the British press was published last week, it came as a boxed set  four chunky volumes totaling just shy of 2,000 pages encased in brown cardboard and tipping the scales at about the same weight as a good-sized Thanksgiving turkey. (Read the 48-page executive summary.)

title: Vietnam Veterans, Discharged Under Cloud, File Suit Saying Trauma Was Cause
description: The New York Times James Dao wrote about Vietnam War veteran John Shepherd Jr., who is part of a class-action lawsuit against the armed forces arguing that he and other Vietnam veterans had post-traumatic stress disorder when they were issued less-than-honorable-discharges.

title: Ben Brantley Takes Readers Questions
description: Have questions about what Broadway show to see? Want to know whats happening Off Broadway? Ben Brantley, the chief theater critic for The New York Times, is taking readers questions about whats happening in the New York theater scene. You can submit your questions in the comment space below. Look for his answers on ArtsBeat later this week.

title: Red Bulls Acquire Three Players and Begin Remake
description: The Red Bulls on Monday began to remodel their roster with the acquisition of three proven players in Major League Soccer.

title: Bid to Preserve Manhattan Project Sites in a Park Stirs Debate
description: A plan now before Congress would create a national park spread over three states to protect the aging remnants of the atomic bomb project from World War II, including an isolated cabin where grim findings threw the secretive effort into a panic.

title: Orthodox Leader Deepens Progressive Stance on Environment
description: At a conference near Istanbul last June, the chimpanzee expert Jane Goodall spoke about the endangered habitat of what she called our closest relatives. Underlining the evolutionary link, she described her encounter with a senior male ape who had a beautiful white beard.

title: Jumping Insects Can Push Off Waters Surface
description: Pygmy mole crickets are tiny insects that live in burrows near fresh water in warm places like Florida and South Africa. (They are not actually crickets but more closely related to grasshoppers.) On land they are expert jumpers, using the skill to escape the clutches of tiger beetles and other predators.

title: A Royal Spotlight on a Rare Condition
description: News that the Duchess of Cambridge, the former Kate Middleton, is pregnant spurred headlines and excitement around the world on Monday, but the exuberance was tempered by word that the mother-to-be has been hospitalized with a rare form of severe morning sickness.

title: Mediterranean Settlers Had Little Taste for Fish
description: Sicilian cuisine is famous for the bounty of the Mediterranean: fish, clams, mussels, shrimp. But 20,000 years ago, around the time of the last ice age, the first modern humans who arrived in the region ate very little seafood, researchers report after studying the remains of human skeletons.

title: Theater Talkback: A Hot Ticket on Broadway, and a Cold Shoulder to Reviewers
description: Al Pacino is back on Broadway, or so I hear. I wouldnt know from firsthand experience. Unlike the many thousands of theatergoers who have seen Mr. Pacino in the revival of David Mamets Glengarry Glen Ross, making it the highest-grossing straight play currently on Broadway, critics have not been invited to attend until later this week, more than six weeks after the show began previews.

title: Hospital in Brooklyn Files for Bankruptcy Protection
description: A Brooklyn hospital, Interfaith Medical Center, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization, listing the federal and state governments and several malpractice plaintiffs among its largest creditors.

title: Kate Middletons Morning Sickness: How Bad Can It Get?
description: An entire world watching. Morning sickness so bad it requires a trip to the hospital. Kate Middleton, Duchess of Cambridge, has embarked on a version of pregnancy that few would envy.

title: For Buffett, the Long Run Still Trumps the Quick Return
description: If somebody bought Berkshire Hathaway in 1965 and they held it, they made a great investment  and their broker would have starved to death.

title: Science in Sign
description: Several groups have been working to develop standardized signs for common terms in chemistry, physics, biology and other sciences.

title: Pushing Sciences Limits in Sign Language Lexicon
description: Imagine trying to learn biology without ever using the word organism. Or studying to become a botanist when the only way of referring to photosynthesis is to spell the word out, letter by painstaking letter.

title: Table Talk | The Acorn in Vancouver
description: Really, its just about celebrating vegetables, says Shira Blustein, a co-owner of the Acorn, a charming new restaurant on Main Street in Vancouver. Within months of opening, Blustein and the co-owner and head chef Brian Skinner, childhood friends and devoted vegetarians, have gracefully dodged the common pitfalls and stereotypes associated with meatless eaters, forging a hot spot for even the most carnivorous diners.

title: Remembering Bonni Benrubi, Curator of Images
description: The magazine lost a friend and colleague last week when Bonni Benrubi, the founder and director of the Bonni Benrubi Gallery died on Thursday. Benrubi opened her gallery in 1987, at a time when photography was still claiming its place within the world of art collecting. She represented an amazing group of photographers, several of whom have had a close working relationship with the magazine over the past 25 years. Benrubi had a special love for magazine photography and was as likely to be seduced by the storytelling in an image as by its visual beauty. She was a major force in our field, someone who brought tremendous energy and passion to the community, as well as a fine curatorial eye.

title: As Concertos Fly by, a Rollicking Bach Time Is Had by All
description: Though performing a substantive program of challenging music is hard work, it should also be fun. But should performers have quite as much fun as the pianist Jeremy Denk and an ensemble of 11 string players from the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center had on Sunday afternoon, when they performed six of Bachs seven keyboard concertos at Alice Tully Hall?

title: A Cabaret in Its Final Days Cheers Up With Gershwin
description: Its a pretty safe bet that no one knows more or cares more about the songwriting legacy of George and Ira Gershwin than Michael Feinstein. Thats why his new show, A Gershwin Holiday at Feinsteins at Loews Regency, has a focused emotional intensity not usually associated with this traditional crooner, pianist, musical archivist and outspoken champion of the American songbook.

title: Recruiting Young Talent in China to Find the Next Big Idea
description: BEIJING  As he discusses technology, Stephen Bell, with his shaved head, glasses and dark Levis, channels Apples co-founder, Steven P. Jobs.

description: A collection of author interviews published on ArtsBeat.

title: Deltas Talks Over Virgin Stake Raise Questions About Bransons Holdings
description: As Delta Air Lines holds talks to buy some or all of Singapore Airlines 49 percent stake in Virgin Atlantic Airways, one question has arisen.

title: Learning to Accept, and Master, a $110,000 Mechanical Arm
description: Cpl. Sebastian Gallegos of the Marines, who lost his arm to an explosive device in Afghanistan, is part of a small group of military amputees who are benefiting from new advances in upper limb technology, wrote James Dao of The New York Times last week.

title: Academy Unveils Documentary Shortlist
description: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences released the shortlist of 15 films eligible for the Oscar for best documentary. They are:

title: The Week Ahead in Fiscal Talks
description: The Times looks at what is coming up in this weeks congressional talks on the fiscal cliff, from Republican counter-proposals to the potential effect of Fridays jobs numbers.

title: A Little Peace, Just Off Times Square
description: During the holiday season many public spaces become an aural purgatory, with hapless listeners subjected to a relentless torrent of Christmas jingles. But on Saturday night in the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, just steps away from the cacophony of Times Square, the Tallis Scholars, the superb English a cappella ensemble, offered respite from the ubiquitous noise with a program of works for double choir by Renaissance and contemporary composers.

title: The Hospital Revolving Door (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Gilbert and Sullivan Made Jokes About Costco and Smartphones? Who Knew?
description: Midway through a New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players performance of The Sorcerer on Saturday night at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater of John Jay College, the conjurer of the title boasted that he could predict the Maya apocalypse and upgrade features of the iPhone 6. Jarring? Hardly. Timely embellishment is part of the Gilbert and Sullivan tradition, of which Albert Bergeret, the Players artistic director and conductor, is a steadfast conservator.

title: Television Thats Worth Dissecting
description: In his first session with Dr. Melfi, Tony Soprano says: Its good to be in something from the ground floor. I came too late for that, I know. But lately, Im getting the feeling that I came in at the end. The best is over.

title: Cases Where Justice Was All Too Blind
description: Vindicated, beginning on Tuesday night on BET, is a television series about people sent to prison for crimes they didnt commit. Like TV Ones Find Our Missing, a series about missing-persons cases that begins its second season on Jan. 9, its both a typical docu-reality program and a quiet, matter-of-fact cri de coeur. Without making a big point of it, the series are here to remind us that these things happen, disproportionately and with depressing regularity, to black Americans.

title: There Is No Playbook for What the Chiefs Face
description: Perhaps the most striking thing about the horror of last weekends events in Kansas City was how quickly the N.F.L. seemed to move past it Sunday. Not in Kansas City itself, of course, where the players and coaches remain stricken, where there will be funerals to attend, tributes to consider and questions of how the Chiefs should be represented at them. Staff members and teammates may be haunted for years by what they saw unfold in a parking lot on Saturday morning  and ultimately, by what they did not see in Jovan Belcher.

title: Is Law School a Good Investment?
description: To the Editor:

title: Flip Side to Her Wild Side
description: Keshas not dangerous. She plays at being a terrible influence  drinking, sex, swearing, hard nights at the club  but the furtive surprise at the center of her project is sweetness, as it always was.

title: New Meaning and Drive in Life After Cancer
description: When people hear the words You have cancer, life is suddenly divided into distinct parts. There was their life before cancer, and then there is life after cancer.

title: It Was The New Yorker With Hot Sauce
description: The new issue of The Oxford American, that estimable and disorderly Southern literary quarterly, flopped onto my porch the other day. I stared at it for a while before picking it up. The magazine had been on my mind.

title: Romney Campaign Manager Says He Regrets Immigration Stance
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Mitt Romney and his team are not eager to dwell on regrets.

title: No Time Like the Present to Take Flight
description: For the first few years after the works composition, the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter had exclusive rights to perform In Tempus Praesens (In the Present Time), a violin concerto written for her by Sofia Gubaidulina. After her period of championing the work, Ms. Mutter once said, My colleagues will take it and fly with it, and I have to let go.

title: At Sundance, a Starry Lineup of Premieres
description: LOS ANGELES  In recent years, the Sundance Film Festivals noncompetition lineup has looked increasingly like  its competition lineup. The out-of-competition section, called Premieres, had become a little artier and less commercial; films from well-established indie directors were few.

title: Emotional Currents Captured in Physical Forms
description: According to the program for the double bill at Dance New Amsterdam, Elke Luytens Studies of Inertia is supposed to follow Kendra Portiers Beautiful Weather for an Air Raid. But at the start of Fridays performance, it quickly became apparent  after, say, the fifth or sixth consecutive time that one woman walked the theaters perimeter in silence  that the studies were preceding the weather.

title: Capturing the Vibes of the Past Right Now
description: When Ballet Hispanico played the Apollo Theater last December, it was the troupes debut there. Its return uptown for a one-night-only event on Saturday felt like a tradition in the making. Three premieres, live music and an enthusiastic audience combined with the theaters historic vibrations for a sense of special occasion.

title: Porsche Pavilions First Christmas at Autostadt
description: This is the time of year when clever lighting makes the big smokestacks of the Volkswagen factory in Wolfsburg look like huge holiday candles. A Christmas market has opened in the Autostadt theme park next door, with the scent of cinnamon, vanilla, cloves and fir mingling together.

title: Ruling Is Victory for Drug Companies in Promoting Medicine for Other Uses
description: In a case that could have broad ramifications for the pharmaceutical industry, a federal appeals court on Monday threw out the conviction of a sales representative who sold a drug for uses not approved by the Food and Drug Administration. The judges said that the ban on so-called off-label marketing violated the representatives freedom of speech.

title: Fleetwood Mac Will Tour in 2013
description: Fleetwood Mac is coming back. The pop-rock giants from the 1970s announced Monday they would do another reunion tour next spring, starting with a concert in Columbus, Ohio, on April 4, Rolling Stone reported. It has been three years since the group last toured.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Expanding Twitter Ads Reach, and Y Combinator Cuts
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Hurricane Helps to Lift Auto Sales to 4-Year High
description: DETROIT  Automakers said on Monday that new-vehicle sales in the United States rose 15 percent in November, as the replacement of cars and trucks damaged in Hurricane Sandy contributed to the industrys best monthly sales rate in four years.

title: Republicans Who Have Opposed Leadership See Committee Assignments Stripped
description: Perhaps presaging a year in which revolts by rank-and-file members will be less tolerated, Republican leaders on Monday removed members with obstinate voting patterns from key committees.

title: Rick Santorum Is Afraid, Very Afraid
description: The Senate is set to vote Tuesday on whether to ratify the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons With Disabilities. In a more reasonable political atmosphere, this would be an easy call. The United States should have no trouble being party to a well-meaning, innocuous global treaty that makes countries promise not to discriminate against people with disabilities and diseases like AIDS, especially since President George H.W. Bush enacted a civil-rights law for disabled people in 1990 that was so comprehensive and far-sighted that much of the rest of the world has spent the last 20 years just trying to catch up.

title: Judge Approves $110 Million El Paso Corp. Settlement
description: WILMINGTON, Del.  A judge approved a $110 million settlement on Monday between the El Paso Corporation and its shareholders, who sought last year to block the sale of the companys pipeline business to Kinder Morgan for $21.1 billion citing potential conflicts of interest.

title: Brothel Owner Raises Profile With Election Victory
description: SPARKS, Nev.  Sex for sale aside, brothels here tend to be modest businesses: shoddy buildings kept out of sight in rural areas, on the outskirts of town or camouflaged in a thicket of cottonwood trees.

title: Activists Tackle Sexual Harassment in Tahrir
description: Now that Egypts opposition has returned to the streets, activists are making a renewed effort to confront the problem of sexual harassment and assaults against women who take part in demonstrations.

title: E.P.A. Rule Complicates Runoff Case for Justices
description: WASHINGTON  Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. did not seem happy during a Supreme Court argument on Monday about whether the Clean Water Act applies to runoff from logging roads. The source of his frustration was a last-minute action from the Environmental Protection Agency that was expressly calculated to address the legal issues before the court.

title: No Hollywood Ending in Old Car Town
description: A movie studio that arose from the ruins of a General Motors complex in Pontiac, Mich., did not lead to job creation and economic improvement.

description: Washington
