description: Through 1943 and the early months of 1944 Allied bombers roamed more and more freely above Germanys industrial centers. The spring of 1943 marked sharp intensification of the bombing. The eleventh attack on Stuttgart came on September 6, 1943, when the U.S. Army Air Force made its first daytime bombing run over the industrial center, location of the Daimler-Benz aircraft-engine factory. Nevertheless the home base of the Porsche team remained at Stuttgart-Zuffenhausen  even though many other firms with important wartime missions had already been dispersed, either underground or to strategically less important regions.

title: Historys Greatest Automotive Mysteries, Myths and Rumors Revealed
description: The more automobile design has changed, the more it has remained the same. A century after the Model T Ford debuted, the vast majority of the cars on the road still feature steel bodies, chassis suspended on four wheels and four-stroke internal combustion engines. Not that would-be revolutionaries havent tried to improve the automobile with a host of innovations: Bodies made of carbon-fiber. Bodies fitted with wings. Bodies that float on water. Three-wheelers. Six-wheelers. Steam engines. Jet turbines. For a while, there was even talk of nuclear power.

title: Fast Girl
description: Enter the racetrack. Its not exactly yoga, my friends, and its not a day at the spa. Its very, very loud. Its stinky. The gear is uncomfortable. The helmet is heavy and restrictive and looks stupid. The seat belts are uncomfortably tight. The gloves are hot. If Im not sweating like a pig while marinating on the hot tarmac then Im freezing my [expletive] off. And above all else, screaming down a straight at 135 miles per hour is not relaxing. Adrenaline is having a house party in my nervous system. My heart is thudding. My brain is calculating wildly as my sensory input approaches maximum overload. My palms are sweating. Every nerve in my body is thrumming with the effort of keeping up, and the lizard part of my brain is just repeating and repeating: Youre gonna die, youre gonna die, youre gonna die. And yet I find this mental activity to be so therapeutic, so beneficial, so seductively desirable that I go back again and again for the brain fix. Why?

title: Corvette Sixty Years
description: Born in 1910 to Russian-Jewish parents, Zachary (Zora) Arkuss grew up in St. Petersburg, where he witnessed the February 1917 Bolshevik revolution. Eventually his parents divorced and Zoras mother Rachel remarried a man named Josef Duntov. In the early 1920s, they relocated to Germany. Enthralled with cars, racing, and high performance, he became a friend of Alfred Neubauer, head of Mercedes- Benz racing.

title: For Baby No. 2 or 3, No Shower but a Sprinkle
description: WHEN Tori Males was pregnant with her first child more than three years ago, friends and family helped her celebrate the impending arrival with three elaborate baby showers. So when Ms. Males, a 31-year-old loan administrator from Woodstock, Ill., was due again earlier this year, she didnt want or expect another fete.

title: A Big Business in Getting High
description: THE artwork for Rihannas hit single Diamonds features a black-and-white image of the singers manicured hands rolling a joint made of diamonds. For the songs music video, she takes a bedazzled puff.

title: Prank Call Seeking Royal Family Secrets Takes Horrifying Turn
description: LONDON  As pranks go, this one appeared outrageous and obnoxious rather than malicious: after convincing a hospital nurse who answered the phone this week that they were Queen Elizabeth and Prince Charles, two Australian radio hosts then tricked another nurse into disclosing medical information about the pregnant Duchess of Cambridge, who had been admitted with acute morning sickness.

title: An Art World Gathering, Divided by Money
description: MIAMI  Mera Rubell was taking time out from greeting the hundreds of visitors at her familys sprawling contemporary art center here to vent.

title: College Boosters
description: To the Editor:

title: Rice in Limbo as Nomination Remains Uncertain
description: WASHINGTON  It did not take long for Susan E. Rice and her champions at the White House to realize that the Republican furor over the Benghazi attack was not going away after the presidential campaign ended.

title: Justices to Take Up Generic Drug Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court said on Friday that it would decide whether a pharmaceutical company should be allowed to pay a competitor millions of dollars to keep a generic copy of a best-selling drug off the market.

title: Joes Junk Yard
description: When I was growing up in Southeastern Pennsylvania, my father ran an automotive junkyard, and my mother ran a series of small antique shops. I was surrounded by junk. My mom routinely dragged us out of bed at sunrise to go to the flea markets and yard sales, in search of treasure  a painting by a famous artist, a valuable piece of pottery, or an important document or cash stowed in the backing of a frame. My dad helped run the family business, and started a motorcycle department to tap into his other interest besides cars: Harley Davidsons. He built one of his bikes from the ground up, using parts he acquired in the business. I was shaped by the idea that one mans trash is another mans treasure.

title: Automotive Diversions of the Non-Driving Kind
description: This weekends Automobiles section offers six brief reviews of recent books that readers may want to consider as holiday gifts or as additions to their own bookshelves. Covering a broad range of interests  pop culture, famous racers and marque histories are among the selections  they are evidence of a healthy ecosystem in the realm of automotive literature.

title: A Lifetime of Work Destroyed at Westbeth
description: Al Cooke, 81, had a few hours on Friday to save what remained of his lifes work. A metal sculptor, he slowly carried heavy sheets of aluminum up to his studios loft. Walking back down the stairs, however, the pain shooting through his knees made him hesitate with every step.

title: Storm Sirens Last Wail
description: TILLAMOOK, Ore.  The tsunami sirens of Tillamook County, posted along the rocky beachfront on this stretch of the earthquake-prone Pacific coast, are a reassuring presence to many residents and visitors. The 30-odd pole-mounted speakers, simple and dated in their 1960s technology of transistors and circuit boards, carry an echo of cold war civil defense, suggesting that people have a kind of handle on responding to the earths potential violence from a killer wave.

title: Pacquiao, Like All Boxers, Is in Fight Against Time
description: LAS VEGAS  When Manny Pacquiao climbs inside the ring Saturday to face his longtime nemesis Juan Manuel Marquez for the fourth time, his every movement will be scrutinized, analyzed, picked apart for signs of decline. His legs. His reflexes. His willingness to attack.

title: Whipping Up Confections, With Expert Help
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J.  Jonell Copeland, one of the 16 students in a holiday cookie class at the Sur La Table store here last Sunday, had carefully considered reasons for spending two hours learning to make gingerbread and sugar cookies, lemon-thyme wreaths and other treats.

title: Pornography Curbs Ordered
description: The Air Force has ordered inspections of its facilities for public displays of pornographic or misogynistic materials after complaints from female personnel. The order from the Air Force chief of staff, Gen. Mark Welsh, follows a report in The New York Times about the case of a technical sergeant, Jennifer Smith, who has served in the Air Force for 17 years. She filed a complaint with the service saying that she had been the victim of sexual assault and harassment, and that she had also been forced to endure a hostile work environment because of widespread and open displays of graphic materials that were demeaning toward women.

title: All That Sparkles
description: When Louisa and Alex Hargrave pioneered the Hargrave Vineyard (now Castello di Borghese) in Cutchogue in 1973, they made only still wines. First-rate sparkling wines from East End producers lay years in the future.

title: The Best Gift Ideas for the Best-Dressed Global Traveler
description: Times are harder than they used to be for pretty much everybody. But that doesnt change the professional imperative to look good or the personal desire to travel well. Indeed, in tougher economic times standing taller than the rest can be even more crucial at the office. And that means looking good, as the I.H.T. explains in our fashion special report:

title: Rebel Groups in Syria Make Framework for Military
description: ANTALYA, Turkey  Military commanders of the main Free Syrian Army units from all over Syria agreed Friday to a unified command structure, bowing to intense pressure from Qatar and Saudi Arabia, who the fighters said promised more advanced weapons once a central military council was in place.

title: A Killer Ends Half-Told Tale of His Crimes With Suicide
description: ANCHORAGE  In a conversation with homicide investigators before his suicide in jail this week, Israel Keyes said he had lived much of his life thinking that people only pretended to be nice. But then, Mr. Keyes told one of the interrogators, he realized that perhaps it was only him.

title: Safety Agency Proposing Mandatory Event Data Recorders
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said on Friday that it was proposing a new standard that would require light passenger vehicles built on or after Sept. 1, 2014, to have event data recorders, or E.D.R.s, an earthbound and much less complex version of the black boxes long seen in airplanes. The rule will not apply to vehicles weighing more than 8,500 pounds.

title: Corporate Money Allowed for Inaugural Donations
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will accept unlimited donations from corporations  but no money from lobbyists or political action committees  to finance his 2013 inaugural festivities, a spokeswoman for his inaugural committee said Friday.

title: Aiming Beyond the Diner Dcor
description: It is safe to say no one is coming to Fancy Lee Asian Bistro n Sushi for the dcor. The restaurant, which opened early last year in Babylon, resembles neither a sedate traditional-style Japanese restaurant nor an ornate Pan-Asian palace. Instead, it looks like the diner that the building once was.

title: Japanese Quake Stirs On-Air Alarm, but No Damage to Nuclear Plants Is Reported
description: TOKYO  It was perhaps the surest sign that Japan remains unnerved by last years devastating earthquake and tsunami. After a large quake on Friday hit near the same area stricken last year, broadcasters on the public television network NHK threw aside their usual reserve to repeatedly issue worried warnings about tsunamis, with one host frantically urging people to flee now to save your life!

title: Jobs Report Becomes Fodder in Fiscal Debate
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats and Republicans seized on Novembers job numbers on Friday to press for a compromise on a deficit deal, as Speaker John A. Boehner opened the door slightly to tax rate increases as part of a broad fiscal package.

title: Tacos Every Which Way, and Beer From the Can
description: The newest of three tequilacentric restaurants, offshoots of the popular Barcelona tapas bars based in Fairfield County, Bartaco occupies a prime slot in West Hartford Center. The place has a brash and sunny feel, with high ceilings, whitewashed barn-wood walls, gleaming oak booths and a central three-sided bar where silver citrus juicers stand sentinel at every corner. The walls display colossal photos of tropical beaches, bikini-clad goddesses and bearded outdoorsmen conquering Alpine peaks.

title: Hoping to Wake Up Against Saints, Giants Revisit a Nightmare
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants season-long quest to return to the defensive heights that carried them to last seasons Super Bowl triumph may revolve around motivation drawn from watching one of the worst performances in their 88-year history.

title: An Enemy of Brussels, and Not Afraid to Say So
description: STRASBOURG, France

title: Bill Cunningham | Men First
description: On the Street: The male fashion peacock is out of the cage.

title: A Pizza for Dessert? Naturally. With Smores.
description: IT has been years since going to a restaurant in a hotel typically meant suffering through mediocre fare designed mainly for the convenience of those staying there. Still, I cringed a little upon entering the Hilton Westchester in Rye Brook to go to its new restaurant, Hrth, despite an attractive renovation that has opened up the space and made it more inviting. I smelled the chlorine of the indoor pool, saw the hotels generic welcome desk and thought, this isnt promising.

title: Holiday Boxes on Stoops Bring Reports of Thefts
description: A pair of brown leather boots was snatched last week from a doorstep in the suburbs of Chicago. A computer disappeared from a front porch in Fort Worth last month, and an iPad case was stolen outside a Long Island home this week.

title: Strapped District Plans to Add Online Classes
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Budget cuts have eliminated about 95 full-time teachers from the school district here over the past year, swelling class sizes and prompting parents to cry foul.

title: Harlem to Say Goodbye to an Art Deco Haven of Jazz
description: The Lenox Lounge, where Billie Holiday had a table, Dizzy Gillespie played his trumpet, and James Baldwin soaked up the scene, where the burgundy leather couches, Art Deco light fixtures and zebra-print wallpaper stir up memories of other eras, and where, even now, everybody knows everybody, will close on Dec. 31.

title: A True Story of Hate and Redemption
description: I buy the idea of Driving Miss Daisy: A grouchy Southern Jewish white widow and her soft-spoken black chauffeur defy tradition and become close friends as the civil rights movement changes the world around them. But a Ku Klux Klan leader and an African-American woman who become pals? In the 1970s?

title: Twenty and Counting
description: You may have heard that there are going to be 20 women in the Senate next year. Ive been trying to figure out what that means.

title: Canada Clears $15 Billion Chinese Takeover of an Energy Company
description: MONTREAL  Canada on Friday allowed a Chinese state-run oil giant to move forward with $15 billion takeover of a domestic energy company, but the government indicated that such deals might not pass muster in the future.

title: Cheaper Money
description: Americas money is too expensive. Thats essentially what the Government Accountability Office stressed last week to a House subcommittee examining possible changes in Americas currency. Paper dollar bills wear out after four or five years, and replacing them with a sturdier coin could save $4.4 billion over the next 30 years. Pennies were not mentioned, but they, too, should get some reconsideration, on cost grounds alone: a single penny costs the government two pennies to make.

title: Some Thieves at Citys Jails Lurk Outside
description: From a thiefs point of view, the place had a lot of potential.

title: Bid to Write New Rules for Funds Gains Ally
description: A type of mutual fund could lose its trademark stable value of $1 a share after a crucial government official voiced his support for controversial efforts to overhaul the $2.6 trillion money market fund industry.

title: Mavericks Succeeding Without Their Coach
description: MANKATO, Minn.  Football practice ended early, in the twilight, at Minnesota State University on Wednesday. As has been the case since mid-August, the Mavericks crossed Stadium Road to their locker room, cleats clacking on the asphalt. As they have all season, they made the walk without their coach.

title: In WikiLeaks Case, Defense Puts the Jailers on Trial
description: FORT MEADE, Md.  In a half-empty courtroom here, with a crew of fervent supporters in attendance, Pfc. Bradley Manning and his lawyer have spent the last two weeks turning the tables on the government.

title: Its Hard to Be a Hero
description: On a crisp January day in 2007, a 50-year-old construction worker named Wesley Autrey became a New York hero when he rescued a man who had fallen onto the subway tracks.

title: Certified Safe, a Factory in Karachi Still Quickly Burned
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  The century-old Central Jail here, a gritty repository of criminals, jihadists and sectarian killers, has a reputation for overcrowding and prisoner riots. But for Arshad and Shahid Bhaila, the industrialist brothers whose factory burned to the ground in September, killing at least 262 workers, there are some comforts.

title: Scrooge. The Grinch. Congress.
description: Hurricane Sandy didnt suppress job growth in November by as much as economists had expected. But the jobs report, released on Friday, offers plenty of bad signs, and no reason to believe the picture will improve unless Congress starts dealing with high unemployment and the needs of those already out of work for months.

title: Beyond the Fiscal Cliff
description: As Congress waits for negotiators to resolve the budget standoff, there is other worthy business that could be accomplished, particularly in political ethics.

title: After Stroke, Living in a Home Filled With Bickering, and Love
description: A conversation between two roommates, Marianela Toro and Ana Ventura, on a recent afternoon consisted of disparaging comments soaked in sarcasm and exasperated sighs that were soon chased with laughter. There was even a weapon brandished: Ms. Ventura, 43, threatened Ms. Toro, 46, with a pillow.

title: Next Civil Rights Landmark
description: Fifty-eight years after it banned discrimination in public education, the Supreme Court has set the stage for the defining civil rights decision of this era  agreeing to hear two cases challenging laws that define marriage to exclude couples of the same sex. To us, and a growing number of Americans, the right course seems clear: that the justices continue the march toward real equality.

title: Lottery Numbers
Ytterbiums Atomic Number
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  SEVENTY. The answer is SEVENTY.

title: Dinosaurs and Denial
description: Finally, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida  a Tea Party darling and possible 2016 presidential candidate  admits that dinosaurs and humans didnt co-exist.

title: Bill on Russia Trade Ties Sets Off New Acrimony
description: WASHINGTON  In theory, the action by Congress this week to make Russia a full trading partner  finally doing away with a 38-year ban that once punished the Soviet Union over its restrictive emigration rules  could have begun a new era of happier ties between former cold war rivals.

title: Jon Kest, Advocate for Low-Wage Workers in New York, Dies at 57
description: Jon Kest, a founder of the Working Families Party and a longtime community advocate in New York, who organized the recent strike by the citys fast-food workers, among many other initiatives, died on Wednesday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 57.

title: Jets Focus Returns to Ground Game
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  All of the attention paid to Mark Sanchez this week overlooks a simple point: the quarterback is not supposed to be the focal point of the Jets offense.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Dec. 8, 2012
description: If we see any rockets and missiles, it will probably be the ones fired at us.

title: Subverting the Standard Survey
description: An impressive selection of 79 artworks dating from the 1700s to the present makes up Artists in America: Highlights of the Collection From the New Britain Museum of American Art at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor. But while the museums Web site says the exhibition surveys 300 years of great American painting, the show isnt arranged as a historical survey at all. Instead, it reflects recent curatorial trends, which lean toward mash-up or collage aesthetics, with paintings hung in pairs or groupings that consciously disrupt the flow of linear history.

title: Marty Reisman, 82, a Wizard of Table Tennis, Dies
description: Marty Reisman, a wizard at table tennis, the sport in which he captured national championships, won and lost fortunes on wagers and moved crowds to laughter  sometimes using a frying pan as a paddle  as an opening act for the Harlem Globetrotters, died Friday in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: Point Guards Past and Present Send Nets to Third Straight Loss
description: As the Warriors bus pulled up to Barclays Center on Friday, Coach Mark Jackson imagined for a moment what effect the glittery new arena and the rebranded Nets franchise would have on young point guards in New York.

title: Small-Scale Works That Surprise at Every Turn
description: Steel that bends like a palm frond. Porcelain that mimics paper. And paper that flows like a river. The famed British sculptor Anthony Caro, still at work at 88, is a kind of alchemist, transmuting a range of materials and playing with our perceptions. These tricks of his can be contemplated at intimate range in the strong, lively small-scale works  most from private collections  that make up Caro: Close Up, at the Yale Center for British Art.

title: Russia: Prosecutors Investigate After Exhibition Draws Complaints
description: Prosecutors in St. Petersburg are investigating an exhibition at the State Hermitage Museum by the British artists Jake and Dinos Chapman for possible violations of a law on inciting religious hatred. The exhibition, which opened in October, is called The End of Fun and addresses themes of violence and fascism in a series of installations resembling a chamber of horrors. A statement posted Friday on the Web site of the St. Petersburg prosecutors office said that numerous citizens had complained that the exhibition offends the feelings of Orthodox believers and contains actions directed at degrading the dignity of citizens who profess Christianity. The installations include a figure of the McDonalds clown mascot, Ronald McDonald. crucified on a cross. Mikhail Piotrovsky, the Hermitages director, said the investigation of the exhibition was a sign of the cultural degradation of our society, according to the Interfax news agency. Members of the band Pussy Riot were tried and convicted in a similar case this year.

title: In This Show, the Abstract Is Here and Now
description: RYE, N.Y.  Abstraction is often defined as what it is not: it is not representational, not objective, not figurative, not realistic, not narrative. From Where I Stand: 12 Contemporary Abstract Artists, an exhibition of 40 paintings and prints at the Rye Arts Center, aims to enlighten gallerygoers about what abstract art is and to present an assortment of methods and aesthetics at play in the genre.

title: Congo: Peace Talks Delayed
description: Peace talks between rebels and the government of the Democratic Republic of Congo in Uganda were delayed Friday as negotiators failed to arrive on schedule, Congolese and rebel officials said.

title: Quinn Backs Expansion of Campaign Spending
description: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker and an expected candidate for mayor next year, is supporting a change to New York Citys campaign finance rules that would significantly expand the ability of unions, corporations and advocacy groups to spend money on behalf of local candidates.

title: Hot Chocolate Under Stuffed Moose
description: The big stuffed moose peers down in amusement at the midweek crowd gathered on the Hudson Hotels terrace, newly tented in for the winter. Other assorted taxidermy, twinkling lights, sleds, skis, wooden tables and couches draped in fur throw rugs create the full-on incongruity of an urban ski lodge on West 58th Street. In lieu of expensive lift tickets, customers at the Hudson Lodge open their wallets for spiked and steaming drinks and gooey foodstuffs like fondue, cookies and smore grilled cheese sandwiches. Manufactured snow shoots into the air nightly after 8, drawing tequila-induced squeals and melting into soap suds on the pates of prematurely balding men in suits. As D.J. tunes bounce in the 1,500-square-foot tent, spillovers from holiday parties mingle with couples on second dates cozying on benches, enjoying the marshmallow ambience after a hard day on the office slopes.

title: Convictions in 95 Killing of Cabdriver to Be Vacated
description: The Bronx district attorney said Friday that the murder convictions of five people found guilty in the 1995 shooting of a livery-cab driver must be thrown out.

title: Women on the Margins
description: Q. There used to be a group of institutions for pregnant girls called Florence Crittenton Homes. Who was Florence Crittenton?

title: Corrections: December 8, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: In the Ashes in Karachi, Evidence of Oversight Failures
description: A fire at a factory that was certified as safe killed at least 262 workers, highlighting monitoring flaws.

title: Daring to Take the Long Way Home
description: The point of a mapping app is to move you efficiently from one place to another. But Wanderous, a free iPhone app released this fall, turns that idea on its head. A user enters start and end points, and the app comes up with a meandering path to travel between them. Exploring the city has always been a popular subject for New York-based  apps,  and Wanderous is one of several that aim to make strolling around the city feel like a game.

title: Uganda: Oil Industry Regulations Passed
description: Lawmakers passed legislation on Friday intended to regulate Ugandas nascent oil industry, but critics say it gives too much authority over the industry to the nations energy minister.

title: Knicks Are Bombarding Their Opponents With 3-Pointers
description: CHICAGO  Shooting 3-pointers successfully in the N.B.A. is a skill that needs to be practiced over and over again. During training camp and after practice, many members of the Knicks did not lift weights or head to the treadmill. Instead, they looked for a ball and the 3-point line.

title: Dance Is Never Far From His Mind
description: Last year, Robert Battle became the third person to head the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater since the company was founded in 1958. During the troupes season in New York, which runs through Dec. 30 at City Center, Mr. Battle attends both the matinee and evening performances. At other times, the day is more relaxing (though he also cant seem to stay away from Aileys Midtown studios). Mr. Battle, 40, has for the past 14 years shared his Upper West Side apartment with Nina Miller, a voice teacher, who he says has become like family.

title: The Maestro of Flushing
description: Youre eating up my energy, roared Maurice Peress, 82, as he rushed around his Manhattan apartment on Wednesday evening. He was preparing for a rehearsal but kept getting sidetracked by questions about his 60 years as an orchestra conductor, the last 30 at the Queens College Aaron Copland School of Music.

title: A Neighborhood Through Time
description: For many decades, Danny Stein has photographed the dwindling Orthodox Jewish community on the Lower East Side, from its people and celebrations to its rapidly gentrifying streets.

title: Eyes of the Soccer World Turn to Manchester
description: With just one swish of his right foot, Sergio Aguero changed the landscape of English soccer forever. His stoppage-time goal against Queens Park Rangers on the final day of the Premier League season in May clinched Manchester Citys first league title in 44 years and confirmed Manchester United was no longer the only soccer superpower in the northwest of England.

title: Are the Knicks This Good?
description: The Knicks stand atop the Eastern Conference with a 14-4 record and have already demolished the Miami Heat on two occasions, including a 112-92 rout Thursday night in which Carmelo Anthony, the Knicks best player, did not suit up. The Knicks were expected to be a competitive team this season, but no one can really say he saw this kind of basketball coming.

title: No Fehr? No Deal, Say the N.H.L. Players
description: The lockout is in its 84th day, and there will be no resolution, according to the players, without the union head Donald Fehr being part of the negotiations.

title: East Village Shrine to Riots and Radicals
description: FOUR days before the opening of the Museum of Reclaimed Urban Space on Avenue C, near 10th Street, Bill DiPaola told the volunteer staff about the suggestion box. Though the group was supposed to make all decisions collectively, on this he acted alone.

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (Showtime) WAR HORSE (2011) Steven Spielbergs sweeping adaptation of the popular stage spectacle follows Joey, a fleet-footed headstrong half-thoroughbred who has formed an unbreakable bond with a strapping lad, Albert (Jeremy Irvine, above), on his parents tenant farm in England. Across the English Channel, on the battlefields and in the trenches of Flanders and France, Joey and Albert endure parallel experiences, including harrowing escapes, the loss of friends, terror and deprivation. Peter Mullan and Emily Watson play Alberts parents, and David Thewlis is their landlord in this story written by Lee Hall and Richard Curtis, based on the novel by Michael Morpurgo. Like most movies with an antiwar message, War Horse cannot help but be enthralled by the epic scale and transformative power of military conflict, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times.  The war has taken everything from everyone  the truth of this reckoning, uttered more than once by characters on screen, is self-evident, but it is complicated by the visceral charge and cathartic relief that an effective war movie gives to its audience. Still, The extreme violence of the slaughter in World War I is implied rather than graphically depicted, he added. Mr. Spielberg steps back from the bloody, chaotic naturalism of Saving Private Ryan  this is an animal fable for children, after all, with echoes of E. T. and Carroll Ballards Black Stallion  but his ability to infuse action sequences with emotional gravity has hardly diminished.

title: Shooting Lessons
description: Few people criticize the quality of the training that New York Citys recruits and police officers receive, but some say the officers need more gun training in real-life scenarios.

title: Ready, Aim, Ready?
description: Armed with cap guns and the usual apprehension, two recruits from the New York Police Academy knocked on the door of a set in the Bronx meant to resemble a down-at-the-heels apartment. They had just received a radio assignment from an instructor: 911 had taken a complaint about an E.D.P.  an emotionally disturbed person  in their sector. They were told to report to the location and advise.

title: The Great Divide, Now in the Toy Aisle
description: Earlier this year, at the 109th Annual American International Toy Fair, held at the Javits Convention Center as one of the cultures most convincing cases for childlessness, a former investment banker named Jill Todd displayed The Tuneables, an interactive DVD series she had created through her company, the Music Intelligence Project. The daughter of two musicologists, Ms. Todd developed the project in conjunction with her parents as an instructional system in melody, rhythm and tone  the fundamentals of music leveraged as a means to enhance cognitive function. Nearby, but easily obscured by the acres of primary-color plastic, was a booth for a company called Fat Brain Toys, whose games and puzzles in logic and sequencing came with an impressive lineage, some of them designed by the celebrated inventor Ivan Moscovich, a Holocaust survivor.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 8
description: NEWS Germanys economy is slowing and will probably stagnate in 2013, the countrys central bank said Friday, sharply cutting its forecast for growth. Considering the difficult economic situation in some euro area countries and widespread uncertainty, economic growth will be lower than previously assumed, said the Bundesbank, which now expects G.D.P. to expand by just 0.4 percent next year. David Jolly reports.

title: A Case for Forgiving Tiki Barber
description: Greg Hanlon of CapitalNewYork.com knows its a hard sell.

title: The Weekend Word: Marriage
description: Todays Times

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: In the legislative council elections held this week for four seats under the quota for panchayats, or village councils  the first such polls in 38 years  the governing coalition of National Conference and Indian National Congress won, Kashmir Live reported.The voters comprised 33,540 elected village council members and heads from the Jammu region and Kashmir Valley, according to an IANS report on the IBNLive Web site.

title: Backing Off Added Powers, Egypts Leader Presses Vote
description: CAIRO  Struggling to quell violent protests that have threatened to derail a referendum on an Islamist-backed draft constitution, President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt moved Saturday to appease his opponents with a package of concessions hours after state news media reported that he was moving toward imposing a form of martial law to secure the streets and allow the vote.

title: Rise of the Robots
description: Catherine Rampell and Nick Wingfield write about the growing evidence for reshoring of manufacturing to the United States. They cite several reasons: rising wages in Asia; lower energy costs here; higher transportation costs. In a followup piece, however, Rampell cites another factor: robots.

title: Romany Were European 500 Years Earlier Than Previously Thought
description: LONDON  The Romany people constitute Europes largest and, arguably, now its most persecuted minority.

title: A Welcome Reality Checker Amid Appeals to Fear and Utopia
description: I thought it worth revisiting my 2009 Perimeter Institute conversation with Vaclav Smil, someone I consider a vital touchstone in a world of distorted risk assessments, after noticing some of his recent columns. Heres my relevant Twitter note, followed by some links:

title:
Leader Celebrates
Founding of Hamas
With Defiant Speech
description: GAZA CITY  Khaled Meshal, the political leader of Hamas, gave a defiant speech on Saturday, vowing to build an Islamic Palestinian state on all the land of Israel, the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

title: For Afghan Officials, Facing Prospect of Death Is in the Job Description
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  There are so many ways for an Afghan official to die: car bombs, suicide attacks, a volley of bullets or, in the case of one particularly enterprising assassin, a handgun hidden in the sole of a shoe.

title: Helmet? Check. Shoulder Pads? Check. Cup? No Thanks.
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Protection is a perpetual buzzword in the N.F.L.

title: Variety: Spiral
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Spirals are a lot of fun, particularly if you subscribe to what I like to call the Hokey Pokey method of solving: You put an Inward answer in, you put an Outward answer in, you put another In, and then you  well, you get the idea.

title: Climate Talks Yield Commitment to Ambitious, but Unclear, Actions
description: DOHA, Qatar  The annual United Nations climate change negotiations concluded here late Saturday after the customary all-night negotiating session and recriminations over who must bear the costs and burdens of a warming planet.

title: Chris Corbould
description: Chris Corbould is a British special-effects expert known for his work on James Bond films, including the latest, Skyfall. He also oversaw the breathtaking blasts and crashes in Inception and the Batman films, most recently The Dark Knight Rises.

title: For Corporate Donors, Inauguration Details
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas finance team is offering corporations and other institutions that contribute $1 million exclusive access to an array of inaugural festivities, including tickets to a benefactors reception, a childrens concert, a candlelight celebration at the National Building Museum, two reserved parade bleacher seats and four tickets to the presidents official inaugural ball.

title: Sharp-Elbowed Rebounder Gives Nets an Edge
description: Consider Reggie Evanss basketball career as a play in three acts, three intimate conversations staged against three distinct backdrops: an enormous arena in Seattle, a small gymnasium in Kansas, a county jail in Pensacola, Fla.

title: Deck the Malls
description: A short impressionistic video captures the holiday shopping bustle at Macys flagship department store in New York.

title: Haitis Silenced Victims
description: A TEXT MESSAGE was the first sign that something was wrong. In the week after Hurricane Sandy hit Haiti, our research team was assessing post-disaster crime, food security and service provision. The message came from a Haitian researcher in our group, an enthusiastic and talented graduate student whom well call Wendy. She had been walking alone a few blocks from our hotel when she was forced into a house and brutally raped.

title: Suffer. Spend. Repeat.
description: IN these final weeks before Christmas, it may strike you that retailers have gone out of their way to make holiday shopping as unpleasant an experience as possible. The odd truth is that they probably have. And theres a reason for that: evidence suggests that the less comfortable you are during the seasonal shopping spree, the more money youll spend.

title: The Full Israeli Experience
description: Tel Aviv

title: A Tepid Welcome Back for Spanish Jews
description: PARIS

title: An Empty Seat in the Courtroom
description: THE lawyer David Coombs rarely speaks publicly outside the courtroom. He says that his client, Bradley Manning, the Army private accused of leaking secret documents to WikiLeaks, prefers it that way.

title: Presidential Inauguration Donor Packages
description: A list of inaugural events and giving levels for prospective donors.

title: An Unexpected Journey: Hobbits in the Heartland
description: Thirty years and 300 leagues separate me from that wintry day and place, yet how well I remember. Wearing a blue goose-down jerkin over my doublet, and boots, I descended the stairs to a library chamber and beheld with my own eyes the grave and thrilling history of Middle-earth, in its earliest form  page after page of the words, runes and drawings of J. R. R. Tolkien, the original texts, with corrections and annotations in his own spidery hand. How long I tarried there I do not know, yet even a scant minute would have justified my long journey across barren prairies to the city of men beside the Great Lake where the precious hoard had come to rest.

title: What Compassionate Release?
description: Federal sentencing law has been indefensibly harsh for a generation, but in theory it has contained a safety valve called compassionate release. The 1984 Sentencing Reform Act gives federal courts the power to reduce sentences of federal prisoners for extraordinary and compelling reasons, like a terminal illness.

title: Karzai Implicates Pakistan in Suicide Bombing That Hurt Afghan Spy Chief
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The suicide bomber who tried to assassinate Afghanistans powerful new intelligence chief came from Pakistan and the attack was organized with the help of a sophisticated foreign intelligence service, President Hamid Karzai said Saturday.

title: After Two Contenders Rebuild, the Thunder Look Stronger
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Entering their game Friday in Oklahoma City, it was the Los Angeles Lakers  not the still very-young Thunder  in search of a statement win. It was the Lakers  the 16-time N.B.A. champions  who were looking to weigh themselves against the Thunder, the class of the Western Conference.

title: A Step Toward E-Mail Privacy
description: The growth of the Internet, social networking and mobile technologies has transformed how Americans communicate and exchange information, but Congress has lagged in updating federal privacy laws to safeguard digital communications from inappropriate prying. Late last month, the Senate Judiciary Committee made some serious progress in the right direction.

title: Schoolhouse to Courthouse
description: KENNETH screwed up. The 11th grader made a crude joke about the police officers in his Bronx high school  and an officer overheard.

title: Bin Laden, Torture and Hollywood
description: IM betting that Dick Cheney will love the new movie Zero Dark Thirty.

title: A Vault for Taking Charge of Your Online Life
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif.

title: The Years of Senator DeMint
description: IN November 2008, just after John McCain was routed by Barack Obama, Jim DeMint addressed a Myrtle Beach conference on the future of the Republican Party. The first-term South Carolina senator was there to reassure his audience: Republicans might have lost an election, but conservatism hadnt lost the country.

title: Worry Tempers Joy Over Gay Marriages Moment in Court
description: LOS ANGELES  Within moments of the announcement on Friday that the Supreme Court would hear two cases relating to same-sex marriage, gay activists rejoiced, heralding the decision as a major advancement for their movement.

title: N.H.L. Void Has Networks Scrambling
description: DETROIT  Usually at this time of year, hockey fans would plant themselves in front of their televisions and watch players like Sidney Crosby, Alexander Ovechkin and Marian Hossa command the ice.

title: Those Crazy Indemnity Forms We All Sign
description: IN order for one of my boys to play indoor lacrosse this winter, I was asked to sign a release indemnifying the sports dome and a long list of its business associates, volunteers, advertisers and (presumably) their family pets against any possible claim filed on behalf of my son.

title: The Jokes on Whom?
description: Ive pranked several thousand people, although I never favored that term. Much of my career was spent doing hidden-camera stunts on Candid Camera, following a path charted for decades by my father, Allen Funt. We always worried about what might go wrong, particularly involving the physical and emotional health of unsuspecting subjects. Our gags were relatively tame, and we sought to find greater social meaning in each sequence. Our track record was pretty good. Still, we had our share of critics.

title: A Lost Civilization
description: WASHINGTON

title: The Cracks in the Nations Foundation
description: Across the coasts of New York and New Jersey, hundreds of millions of gallons of raw and partially treated sewage are spilling into waterways and the ocean. The immediate cause is equipment damage from Hurricane Sandy, but as Michael Schwirtz recently reported in The Times, aging plants like one in Nassau County on Long Island were leaking long before the storm, flooding neighborhood streets with sewage during downpours.

title: Seeking to Qualify but Also to Inspire
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  It was crunch time last Sunday in the last round of the L.P.G.A.s final qualifying tournament, and history and milestones were not the top priority for two young golfers trying to earn playing status for the 2013 tour.

title: Censoring Myself for Success
description: HERE is a story about fame. I heard it first as a fable in Somalia, before living it out in America.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Medicating for A.D.H.D.
description: Parents, patients and care providers discuss treatment options.

title: Getting the Cold Shoulder
description: Tilburg, the Netherlands

title: The Childs Menagerie
description: Tucson

title: Epic Battle of Opposites: Irish vs. Tide in 1973
description: Protecting a 24-23 lead in the final minutes of the 1973 Sugar Bowl against Alabama, underdog Notre Dame faced a pivotal third-and-8 at its 3-yard line.

title: A Bittersweet Reunion in Guatemala
description: Amy and Rob Carr of Reno, Nev., are among the 4,000 Americans who found themselves stuck in limbo when Guatemala shut down its international adoption program in 2008.

title: A Simple Way to Create Suspense
description: How do you create suspense? Im asked that question often, and it seems that every writers symposium has a class with that title. Its an important technical issue, and not just for so-called suspense novels. Every novel needs a narrative engine, a reason for people to keep reading to the end, whatever the subject, style, genre or approach.

title: Splash!
description: Arsenals Santi Cazorla drew a penalty on what certainly looked like a blatant dive Saturday against West Bromwich.

title: A Good Mentor Never Tramples on Big Dreams
description: This interview with  Tony Tjan, chief executive of Cue Ball, a venture capital firm based in Boston, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: After Radio Prank, Hospital Chairman Condemns Australian Network
description: Last Updated, 3:28 p.m. A day after a nurse at a London hospital was found dead after falling victim to a prank call seeking medical information about the pregnant Duchess of Cambridge, the hospitals chairman issued a scathing indictment of the Australian network that broadcast the hoax.

title: Chevron Aims at an Activist Shareholder
description: PUBLIC corporations routinely tell shareholders that their views matter. The Chevron Corporation, for example, said in its 2012 proxy statement: Your board welcomes dialogue on the topics presented in the stockholder proposals on the following pages. So it might seem odd that last month Chevron subpoenaed one of its investors, Trillium Asset Management, which has sponsored numerous shareholder proposals at Chevron over the years. The oil company demanded documents related to those proposals. The subpoena also asked for records of discussions Trillium had about these proposals with the media.

title: Big Money Bets on a Housing Rebound
description: DAVID N. MILLER, a master of bailouts, steps to the dais and coolly explains how the financial world went crazy.

title: Tebow Divided Hometown Without Even Taking a Snap
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  This was the first night of the 2010 N.F.L. draft, the draft that contained the player who could deliver excitement and relevancy, if not necessarily victories, to Raef Godwins beloved Jacksonville Jaguars.

title: The Outsourcing  of Human Resources
description: To the Editor:

title: A Game-Changer for Nintendo
description: To the Editor:

title: Heritage, Chicago, and the Fiscal Cliff
description: Menzie Chinn has some fun pointing out that if the doctrine Heritage was pushing to oppose fiscal stimulus were true  namely, that government borrowing always crowds out an equal amount of private spending  then the fiscal cliff could not be a problem. Hey, the government is going to borrow less, which will automatically and necessarily lead to an equal rise in private borrowing, so total demand cant be affected, right?

title: Cubas Free-Market Farm Experiment Yields a Meager Crop
description: HAVANA  Cubas liveliest experiment with capitalism unfolds every night in a dirt lot on the edge of the capital, where Truman-era trucks lugging fresh produce meet up with hundreds of buyers on creaking bicycle carts clutching wads of cash.

title: Cuban Agriculture Struggles Under Creaky Infrastructure
description: More Cubans are farming, but because of waste, poor management, policy constraints and other problems, many are actually seeing less food at new private markets.

title: A Tumultuous Trip to Mobile App Transparency
description: MOBILE apps are the Trojan horses of our smartphones.

title: Billion-Dollar Flop: Air Force Stumbles on Software Plan
description: IN policy circles, problems that are mind-bogglingly difficult or impossible to solve, like global warming, are formally termed wicked.

title: No Longer Overlooked
description: Like a fallen leaf, the question lingered silently for decades near the doorstep of the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: In Talks, G.O.P. May Have to Just Say Yes
description: IN their book, Getting to Yes, Roger Fisher and William Ury introduce what may be the most important concept in the theory of negotiations: the best alternative to a negotiated agreement, or Batna. Knowing your true Batna  and your adversarys  is critical in bargaining. A vivid example from the entertainment world illustrates the concept and offers some useful hints about how the current fiscal negotiations in Washington are likely to unfold.

title: Tax Arithmetic Shows Top Rate Is Just a Starter
description: WASHINGTON  Despite hints in recent days that President Obama and House Speaker John A. Boehner might compromise on the tax rate to be paid by top earners, a host of other knotty tax questions could still derail a deal to avert a fiscal crisis in January.

title: The Next Move for the Fed
description: TIME is running out for Operation Twist, the Federal Reserve stimulus program named for that hip-swiveling dance from the 1960s.

title: 30 Seconds With Kenny Smith
description: Kenny Smith explains how to play NBA Baller Beats, a new Xbox 360 Kinect-controlled game.

title: A Switch at Midlife, to Make a Difference
description: I CAN pinpoint the time in my career when I started to question what I was doing with my life.

title: Hamas Leader Delivers Defiant Speech at Anniversary Celebration
description: Khaled Meshal delivered a fiery speech at a celebration for the 25th anniversary of Hamas in Gaza on Saturday.

title: Out of Vietnam, and Back
description: MY father, Quang Lam, was a captain in the South Vietnamese Army. He was a helicopter pilot who had been trained in Texas. On April 30, 1975, when Saigon fell, he was able to escape Vietnam and reached the United States. But he was not able to let us know what had happened to him until a year later.

title: Racetrack Drugs Put Europe Off U.S. Horse Meat
description: PARIS  For decades, American horses, many of them retired or damaged racehorses, have been shipped to Canada and Mexico, where it is legal to slaughter horses, and then processed and sold for consumption in Europe and beyond.

title: A Fringe Politician Moves to Japans National Stage
description: TOKYO  Shintaro Ishihara has been a rare, flamboyant presence in Japans otherwise drab political world for four decades. A novelist turned right-wing firebrand, he has long held celebrity status on the political margins, where he was known for dramatic flourish. He once signed a pact in blood to oppose diplomatic ties with China because of its communist government, and he published a book at the height of Japans economic power that lectured his countrymen on the need to end what he considered its postwar servility to the United States.

title: Celtics Take Long View on Draft Picks
description: When the Boston Celtics ended up with back-to-back picks in the first round of the 2012 N.B.A. draft, they had a rare opportunity to draft a player who was ready to contribute right away and one who was more of a project. They did exactly that, selecting Jared Sullinger with the 21st pick and Fab Melo with the 22nd, a pick they acquired in a trade in 2011.

title: Variations on Obamas Tax Plan
description: President Obama has offered a tax plan that would raise $1.4 trillion in revenue over 10 years by increasing taxes on top earners. How different variations on the plan could affect how much money is raised:

title: Marijuana Legalization and States Rights
description: As the Obama administration weighs its response to the legalization of the recreational use of marijuana in Washington and Colorado, a new YouGov poll has found that a slim majority of adults believe the federal government should not enforce federal laws  under which marijuana use is still illegal  in those states.

title: New Taxes to Take Effect to Fund Health Care Law
description: WASHINGTON  For more than a year, politicians have been fighting over whether to raise taxes on high-income people. They rarely mention that affluent Americans will soon be hit with new taxes adopted as part of the 2010 health care law.

title: Matchup: Saints (5-7) at Giants (7-5)
description: 4:25 p.m. Eastern, Fox

title: Rumblings for Change in Sudans Governing Party
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  When the Sudanese government announced late last month that it had disrupted a plot of sabotage and had arrested 13 people, including senior members of the armed forces and the security services, it shed light on what was already an open secret: the growing discontent within its ranks.

title: Matchup: Jets (5-7) at Jaguars (2-10)
description: 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

title: Russia Announces Barriers on Imports of U.S. Meat
description: MOSCOW  Russian health regulators announced formidable new barriers to the import of meat from the United States late on Friday, in a move some analysts saw as retaliation for American legislation punishing Russian officials linked to human rights violations.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Dec. 9
description: With all eyes on Washington as the fiscal deadline looms, the Sunday shows are focusing on the status of negotiations.Alan K. Simpson and Erskine B. Bowles, who served as co-chairmen of President Obamas deficit reduction commission two years ago and are still promoting their proposal, will appear on CBSs Face the Nation to weigh in.

title: Last Name First
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  The nice thing about the Sunday New York Times crossword puzzles is that they run with a title. According to some solvers, the not-so-nice thing about the Sunday New York Times crosswords is that they run with a title.

title: Previewing the Fourth Quarter of the N.F.L. Season
description: Has your team clinched a playoff spot, leaving you wondering what to pay attention to with a month to go in the N.F.L. regular season? In an unusually top-heavy and familiar season  it is possible that only 2 of the 12 playoff teams will be different from last season  you have plenty of company. Three divisions have been settled and two more could be this weekend, but the playoff picture is still spectacularly scintillating. Colts-Broncos in the Peyton Bowl? Sign us up. But subplots  and no shortage of firings, benchings and questionable decisions  abound to tide us over until January. Put down the holiday catalogs and keep this guide handy.

title: A Family, for a Few Days a Year
description: GUATEMALA CITY  The little boy flies like an airplane through the hotel, his arms outstretched. Then he leaps like a superhero, beaming as the red lights on his new sneakers flash and flicker, while the American couple he is with dissolve in laughter.

title: Giving an Old Brewery a New Life, and Cuisine
description: Nearly 12 years ago, the Pearl Brewing Company in downtown San Antonio emptied its tanks and moved the production of its beer to Fort Worth. It left behind a historic but derelict 22-acre complex, anchored by a towering brew house. It looked like the property was destined to be razed.

title: Contributions Blackout Serves Many Functions
description: Ladies and gentlemen, close your checkbooks. Sunday starts the blackout on campaign contributions to Texas state officeholders,  a period of pecuniary protection that will last until after the legislative session that begins in a month.

title: Proposed Rules on Fracking Gain Cautious Praise
description: Hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, the controversial process of shooting water, sand and chemicals underground to retrieve oil or natural gas trapped in shale rock, has made plenty of headlines in recent years. But the drilling process involves many other steps beyond breaking up rock  and several opportunities for things to go wrong.

title: Italys Prime Minister to Quit After Losing Party Support
description: ROME  Prime Minister Mario Monti said he intended to resign after losing the backing of former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconis party, according to a statement issued late Saturday by the presidents office.

title: Syrian Rebels Tied to Al Qaeda Play Key Role in War
description: BAGHDAD  The lone Syrian rebel group with an explicit stamp of approval from Al Qaeda has become one of the uprisings most effective fighting forces, posing a stark challenge to the United States and other countries that want to support the rebels but not Islamic extremists.

title: Perry Helps Advisers Take a Big Next Step
description: Career coach is not listed on Gov. Rick Perrys rsum, but it might as well be.

title: Land Routes Blocked, Smuggling Rises Sharply on California Coast
description: LOS ANGELES  The small, open-hull fishing boats head north from Baja Mexico, traveling at night, their navigation lights off. It is an old smuggling route, popular with tequila runners during Prohibition in the 1920s and then little used for nearly a century.

title: North Korea Cites Rocket Problems
description: HONG KONG  North Korea said Sunday that it might have to postpone a rocket launching it had previously said would take place as early as Monday, citing unspecified problems encountered by its technicians.

title: Famous Wolf Is Killed Outside Yellowstone
description: Yellowstone National Parks best-known wolf, beloved by many tourists and valued by scientists who tracked its movements, was shot and killed on Thursday outside the parks boundaries, Wyoming wildlife officials reported.

title: Clintons Countless Choices Hinge on One: 2016
description: Youre one of the most famous women on earth, and youre jobless for the first time in decades. Youd like to make money, but you dont want to rule out running for president. So what do you do all day?

title: New Art District in Miami
description: The newfound allure of Wynwood is the latest testament to how art can sprinkle its metaphysical magic and transform even the bleakest places.

title: Breathing Life, and Art, Into a Downtrodden Neighborhood
description: MIAMI  Ski, a New York graffiti artist, swirled a can of spray paint, blasting a riot of neon in this once-forlorn slab of Miami called Wynwood. A few doors down, in a pop-up store, another artist, Asif Farooq, was selling an array of firearms  actually cardboard replicas for those who like everything about a gun except the shooting.

title: Anthony Will Sit for a Second Straight Game
description: CHICAGO  Carmelo Anthony will miss his second consecutive game Saturday night, sitting out as the Knicks play the Chicago Bulls. Anthony, who sustained a deep cut on his left middle finger during Wednesdays victory in Charlotte and received five stitches, had the final say to sit out.

title: Duke Shows Krzyzewski a Quality He Values
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Year after year, Duke seems to manufacture championship-caliber basketball teams as if on an assembly line. Coach Mike Krzyzewskis recipe for success is no secret. It starts with recruiting fundamentally sound players, preaching unselfish play and finding chemistry.

title: Even the Best Can Bungle, and Then It Gets Exciting
description: The highest-ranked men are sometimes accused of shying away from risk in their game play. That was certainly not true last week, when there were several games filled with bold moves and mistakes. They were a lot of fun to watch.

title: Army Batters Navy, but Bid to End Streak Slips From Its Grasp
description: PHILADELPHIA  The game was over, and the Army football team glumly walked up the sideline Saturday and turned to face seven sections filled with gray-coated members of the Corps of Cadets. Only a few players sang the United States Military Academys alma mater, and their classmates were not exactly in the mood to sing, either.

title: From Street Hustler to Family Man Eager to Cook
description: James Glover was a product of a very different New York.

title: Rally Protests Coalition in New York State Senate
description: Civil rights leaders and black lawmakers, worried that minority communities would be robbed of influence in Albany, on Saturday denounced a plan by Republicans and a group of dissident Democrats to join together to preside over the State Senate.

title: Peter Johnson, Crusader Against Corruption, Dies at 91
description: Peter Johnson was 17 when his father, James, a longshoreman on the Manhattan docks, died. James was owed pay that the family needed for his burial. Peter had to beg the corrupt longshoremens union to get it.

title: Manziel, in His First Season, Achieves a Heisman First
description: Johnny Manziel spent his 20th birthday Thursday, with what little time he had, playing nine holes of golf with his family. That night, he accepted the Davey OBrien Award as the nations top quarterback. That left no time for birthday gifts.

title: Robert Lescher, Editor and Literary Agent, Dies at 83
description: Robert Lescher, a literary agent and steward to the works of a wide array of distinguished 20th-century authors, including Robert Frost, Isaac Bashevis Singer and Alice B. Toklas, died on Nov. 28 in New Milford, Conn. He was 83.

title: Fugue for Wrung-Out Tinhorns
description: The fight has gone out of the once-robust boys from Glengarry Glen Ross, David Mamets 1984 Pulitzer Prize-winning drama of sharks in a small pond. Sure, they still curse and rant and beat up on the furniture in the production that formally opened at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater on Saturday night, after an indecently extended preview period.

title: Corrections: December 9, 2012
description: NATIONAL

title: Lottery Numbers
Adoption Limbo
description: American families are struggling with long adoption delays in Guatemala.

title: A Maestro in Queens
description: Maurice Peress, a protege of Leonard Bernstein and former associate of Duke Ellington, leads the Queens College Orchestra like a big-time philharmonic.

title: Chvez Says His Cancer Has Returned and Names His Successor
description: ORURO, Bolivia  President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela announced Saturday in Caracas that he would have to undergo another operation for cancer, and he designated his vice president, Nicols Maduro, as his successor if he should prove unable to continue to lead the country.

title: Knicks Fall Apart vs. Bulls Defense
description: CHICAGO  The pace was so slow, so tedious at times that the loudest noise inside United Center was often the bounce of the ball and the squeak of sneakers. Or it was the clang of the ball bouncing off the rim, which happened a lot in the Knicks game Saturday against the Bulls. Coaches Mike Woodson of the Knicks and Tom Thibodeau of the Bulls frequently raised their arms in bewilderment. Sure, the Knicks and the Bulls played solid defense, but they were inefficient on offense.

title: Feeding the People in Cuba
description: Last year, President Ral Castro legalized small agricultural businesses as part of an effort to revive the economy.

title: Dodgers Are Said to Land Greinke
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers reached a record contract Saturday with starter Zack Greinke, agreeing to a six-year, $147 million deal. The $24.5 million average annual value is the highest ever for a pitcher on a multiyear contract, surpassing C. C. Sabathias $24.4 million average annual salary with the Yankees.

title: Army vs. Navy Replay
description: A recovered fumble in the fourth quarter dashed any hope the Army had for ending Navys win streak.

title: Fragile Australian Radio Hosts Get Counseling After Nurses Death
description: HONG KONG  Anger and outrage continued to grow over the weekend after two Australian radio hosts made a prank call to the London hospital where the Duchess of Cambridge, Kate Middleton, was being treated for acute morning sickness.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, Dec. 9
description: Theres this hope in you that doesnt want to die. In my heart, hes my son.

title: Meghan Kelly, Jason Gefaell
description: Meghan Boyle Kelly and Jason William Gefaell were married Saturday in Westerly, R.I. The Rev. James R. Bocchino performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church, where he is the interim rector, with the Rev. Richard Ryscavage, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: Stephanie Hacker, Jonathan Krieger
description: Stephanie Alexandra Hacker and Jonathan Brett Krieger are to be married Sunday, with Rabbi Gerald L. Zelizer officiating at Clarks Landing, a catering hall in Point Pleasant, N.J.

title: Harlan Bratcher, Toby Usnik
description: Harlan Ray Bratcher and William Louis Usnik Jr. were married Thursday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Damaris Acosta, a deputy city clerk at the New York City Clerks Office, officiated.

title: Abigail Eustis, Geoffrey Sprague
description: Abigail Elisabeth Eustis, a daughter of Barbara Simmons Eustis and James R. Eustis Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Geoffrey Owen Sprague, the son of Margaret Wunderlich Sprague and Stephen Owen Sprague of Boston. The Rev. Dr. Richard J. Lichti, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church of Bronxville.

title: Lindsay Hymson, Jason Schechter
description: Lindsay Sarah Hymson and Jason Robert Schechter were married Saturday evening at Temple Israel in Lawrence, N.Y. Rabbi Ian J. Silverman officiated.

title: Vanessa Kramer and Joseph Hallett III
description: Vanessa Brie Kramer and Joseph Jacob Hallett III were married Saturday in Brooklyn. Rabbi Benjamin J. Zeidman officiated at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Laura Fine, Benjamin Liebman
description: Laura Bailey Fine and Benjamin Isaac Liebman were married Saturday evening at Cook Commons, an event space in Baltimore. Rabbi Daniel Cotzin Burg officiated.

title: Alexis Steil and Bradley Burwell
description: Alexis Ingham Steil, the daughter of Janice M. Steil and M. Peter Steil Jr. of New York, was married Saturday evening to Bradley William Burwell, a son of Judith A. Burwell of Vashon Island, Wash., and William E. Burwell of Aspen, Colo. The Rev. Lynn Sanders, an Episcopal priest, officiated at St. Bartholomews Church in New York.

title: Alison Cool, Willing Davidson
description: Alison Collier Cool and Homer Willing Davidson were married Friday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell, an employee of the New York City Clerks Office, officiated.

title: Jill Grabel, Andrew Kirby
description: Jill Patricia Grabel and Andrew Justin Kirby were married Saturday at the Raphael vineyard in Peconic, N.Y. The Rev. Marie April Gismondi, a minister of the Church of Ancient Ways, officiated.

title: Catherine Dwyer, Adam Brinch
description: Catherine Elizabeth Dwyer and Adam Soren Brinch were married Saturday at the Second Congregational Meeting House Society on Nantucket Island in Massachusetts. The Rev. David M. Horst, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Mara Opperman, Scott Maness
description: Mara Rachel Opperman and Scott Russell Maness were married Saturday evening at the Pleasantdale Chateau, an event space in West Orange, N.J. Cantor Hal Rifkin officiated.

title: Leigh Aidner and Micah Brill
description: Leigh Ryan Aidner, the daughter of Sandye Berger of New York and Donald A. Aidner of Los Angeles, was married Saturday evening to Micah Levy Brill, the son of Ralph Brill of North Adams, Mass., and the late Gail J. Koff, who lived in New York. Rabbi Jordan Millstein officiated at Cipriani 42nd Street, an event space in New York.

title: Parisa Arash and Rudrabhishek Sahay
description: Parisa Arash and Rudrabhishek Sahay were married Saturday at the Acqualina Resort and Spa in Sunny Isles Beach, Fla. The Rev. Milan R. Kralik, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

title: Erin Moughon and David Smith
description: Erin Nicole Moughon and David Paul Smith were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. Gary Wiley, an evangelical minister, performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Christian Church.

title: Kerry Nordling, David Mayurnik
description: Kerry Catherine Nordling and David Paul Mayurnik were married Saturday evening at Meadow Wood Manor, an event space in Randolph, N.J. The Rev. Carroll J. Mrowicki, a minister affiliated with CITI Ministries, performed the ceremony.

title: Sonya Hebert and Jon-Bernard Schwartz
description: Sonya Natasha Hebert and Jon-Bernard Schwartz are to be married Sunday at the Carnegie Institute for Science in Washington. Rabbi Stan Levin is to officiate.

title: Pacquiao Stunned in Sixth Round
description: LAS VEGAS  Manny Pacquiao never saw it coming. He never saw the punch that snapped his head back Saturday and dropped him to the canvas and left him sprawled there momentarily, face down, while his wife sobbed uncontrollably and the packed crowd at MGMs Grand Garden Arena rose to its feet in shock.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: An article in Open magazine titled The Villain Nobody Knows looks at the beginnings of the Babri Masjid controversy. The idea that eventually changed the politics of India emerged for the first time among three friends, write the authors, who trace its origins to Maharaja Pateshwari Prasad Singh, head of the princely state of Balrampur, Mahant Digvijai Nath, politician and religious leader, and KKK Nair, an Indian Civil Service officer, whose friendship was formed over a shared interest in Hindu communalism (and tennis).

title: Like the Band They Follow, Stones Fans Are Grayer but Still Spry
description: After 50 years in the rock music business, the Rolling Stones have an average age of 68, higher than the average age of the justices on the United States Supreme Court. By all accounts, they are aging well, as have their songs.

title: Reindeer Games in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  Hong Kong has one of the most expensive and crowded property markets in the world, and CBRE, the commercial real estate services firm with offices here, can be highly imaginative when illustrating that point.

title: Well-Worn Sound, With Unrelenting Swagger
description: In a filmed montage of celebrity adoration before the start of the Rolling Stones show on Saturday night at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, Iggy Pop had a good line. He was remembering seeing the band play in the late 60s, and he said, approvingly, that hearing Keith Richardss guitar sound back then felt like being hit with a dead mackerel.

title: Ignoring Planetary Peril, a Profound Disconnect Between Science and Doha
description: In one of the most poignant moments of the Doha climate talks, the Philippine climate change commissioner, Naderev M. Sano, appealed to his fellow negotiators at a session deciding the contours of the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol.

title: Afghan and Coalition Forces Rescue American Doctor Who Was Kidnapped by Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An American doctor kidnapped by the Taliban was rescued Sunday by Afghan and coalition forces in eastern Afghanistan, officials said. At least six people were killed, including a member of a U.S. special forces Navy SEAL team. Two Taliban leaders were arrested during the rescue.

title: All He Wants for Hanukkah Are In-App Purchases
description: In-app purchases, my son said when I asked him what he wanted for Hanukkah. I was dismayed. He wanted to buy the $0.99 and up shortcuts that let him level up in his iPod games. Its a cash cow for video game developers, a freemium business strategy that allows you to download apps for free but which hits you up for cash later in exchange for slogging through hours of gameplay and unlocking content fast.

title: Stephanopoulizing
description: Whoops  forgot to post about this. My head talks on This Week this morning; posting from the Green Room now.

title: Manchester Derby: City 2, United 3
description: Robin van Persie is unlikely to forget his first Manchester derby.

title: Disruptions: How My Smartphone Emptied My Pockets
description: Growing up, I noticed that something happened to my father as he aged: his wallet expanded with each passing year.

title: Tom Wolfe Would Hardly Recognize The Bronx Today
description: Two white people, one of them a young woman decked out in a royal-blue Avenue Foch jacket with shoulders out to here . . . enough matched luggage in the back seat for a trip to China . . . a $48,000 Mercedes roadster . . . in the middle of the South Bronx . . .Miraculous!

title: Romanians Vote in Parliamentary Elections
description: PARIS  Romanians went to the polls on Sunday in parliamentary elections that have threatened to push the country further into political upheaval and acrimony.

title: On Our Radar: The Doha Denouement
description: John M. Broders summary of the slim achievements at the United Nations climate change conference in Doha, Qatar. [The New York Times]

title: Mortgage Crisis Presents a New Reckoning to Banks
description: The nations largest banks are facing a fresh torrent of lawsuits asserting that they sold shoddy mortgage securities that imploded during the financial crisis, potentially adding significantly to the tens of billions of dollars the banks have already paid to settle other cases.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (ABC) CHRISTMAS WITH HOLLY (2012) Mark Nagle (Sean Faris) is the uncle and guardian, along with his two brothers, of 6-year-old Holly (Lucy and Josie Gallina), who hasnt spoken a word since her mother died unexpectedly. He also owns a coffee shop in Friday Harbor, Wash., where Maggie Conway (Eloise Mumford, above with Mr. Faris) has moved after her fianc left her at the altar. Maggies dream, quickly fulfilled: to open a toy store in this town, where she spent her summers as a girl. During the holiday retail crunch, she cant help but be drawn to Holly each time she comes in. Alex Paxton-Beesley plays Marks girlfriend, who may or may not be what keeps Mark and Maggie from getting to know each other in this Hallmark Hall of Fame production.

title: Telecoms Merger in Austria Could Open Door to Further Consolidation
description: BERLIN  For nearly a decade, financial analysts have expected a wave of mergers and acquisitions to sweep Europes fragmented telecommunications sector, consolidating the regions 102 mobile operators and creating a more efficient market.

title: James Bond Wont Die at the Box Office Either
description: Skyfall climbed back to No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend after more than a month in release  an extremely difficult box-office stunt to pull off, even for James Bond. Skyfall took in an estimated $11 million between Friday and Sunday, lifting its domestic total to $261.6 million and putting a $1 billion global gross within reach for Sony and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

title: Obama and Boehner Talk Deficits at the White House
description: WASHINGTON  With just three weeks left for lawmakers to avert a fiscal crisis, President Obama and Speaker John A. Boehner met privately at the White House on Sunday as a top Republican senator suggested that his party should perhaps accede to Mr. Obamas demand to raise the top tax rates so that the attention can shift to making serious cuts in benefit programs like Medicare and Medicaid.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 8 P.M. (ABC) EXTREME MAKEOVER: HOME EDITION While on patrol in Iraq in February 2007, Staff Sgt. Shilo Harris received burns to more than 40 percent of his body after an roadside bomb struck the truck that he was traveling in. But he refused medical treatment until he had been assured that his troops were safe. During the months of surgeries that followed, Mr. Harris and his wife, Kathreyn (above, with their children), found their calling: to help those undergoing the same anguished ordeal. Mr. Harris became a motivational speaker, and Ms. Harris started working for the Army Wounded Warrior Project. In this two-hour episode Ty Pennington and his crew renovate their home in Smithville, Tex., with the help of the actor J. R. Martinez and the country singer Lee Greenwood.

title: U.S. Drone Strike Kills a Commander for Al Qaeda in Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A senior commander for Al Qaeda has been killed in an American drone strike in North Waziristan, the restive tribal area along the border with Afghanistan, Pakistani security officials said Sunday.

title: A Day for the Reds in the Manchester Derby
description: Manchesters derby, City versus United, has grown into a game for all nations. The players now come from all over the world, and Sundays version was broadcast live to 212 countries. It was a tumultuous affair, settled by a winning goal in stoppage time that gave United a 3-2 victory on Citys turf.

title:
Fighting Drives an
Old Sense of Peace
From Damascus
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  Business has been terrible for Abu Tareq, a taxi driver, so last week, without telling his wife, he agreed to drive a man to the Damascus airport for 10 times the usual rate. But, he said later, he will not be doing that again.

title: Technology or Monopoly Power?
description: More on robots and all that: first, heres the chart from the BLS (pdf), which focused on nonfarm business:

title: Broadway on the Elbe
description: HAMBURG, Germany  An eight-hour production of Goethes Faust may be the highbrow hit of the fall at the grand Thalia state theater here, but it is an altogether different blockbuster  the Disney musical Tarzan  that exemplifies why modern Hamburg has become that rare thing in the theater world: a reliable profit center for producers outside of their two biggest markets, New York and London.

title: Nets Evans, Knowing Focus Is on Him, Tries to Stay on His Feet
description: Reggie Evans is a brawny, feisty rebounding machine who loves a good collision. It takes a lot to make him cringe. A brief exchange with Commissioner David Stern might have done it.

title: Opponents of Egypts Leader Call for Boycott of Charter Vote
description: CAIRO  The political crisis over Egypts draft constitution hardened on both sides on Sunday, as President Mohamed Morsi prepared to deploy the army to safeguard balloting in a planned referendum on the new charter and his opponents called for more protests and a boycott to undermine the vote.

title: Next Act in Italian Drama: Exit Monti the Technocrat, Enter Monti the Politician?
description: ROME  For months, he had flirted with the idea of staying out of politics, but in the end former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi just could not resist. His statement on Saturday that he would seek office again out of a sense of responsibility for Italy effectively ended the mandate of Prime Minister Mario Monti, who said he would step down after Parliament passes a budget bill this month.

title: Protest of Peace Prize for E.U. Turns Local
