description: OSLO  After braving a blizzard of denunciation from China from afar over its decision two years ago to honor a jailed Chinese dissident, the Norwegian Nobel Committee faced anger in its own backyard Sunday on the eve of a ceremony awarding this years Nobel Peace Prize to the European Union.

title: The Lure of the Writers Cabin
description: Much has been written about the writers cabin. Among the most notable recent books on the topic are Heideggers Hut by Adam Sharr and A Place of My Own: The Architecture of Daydreams, Michael Pollans account of imagining and then actually constructing his own writing space. A standard Internet search can quickly yield images of the writing rooms (cabins, huts, sheds) of legendary scriveners: Dylan Thomas, Virginia Woolf, Ludwig Wittgenstein, Roald Dahl, Carl Jung, Henry Thoreau and  a writer of a markedly different sort Ted Kaczynski, to name a few. And Jill Krementzs 1999 collection of photographs The Writers Desk gives us tantalizing glimpses of writers sitting at their desks. But why the interest? Have these places somehow become secular sites of the sacred?

title: As Jets Stand by Sanchez, They Run Past Jaguars
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  It may not look like it sometimes, but the Jets want to win. Honest, they do. That desire to win consumes their lives, week after week after week, and guides their decisions  decisions like their call to start Mark Sanchez on Sunday against the Jacksonville Jaguars, a week after he was removed with a bruised ego.

title: Channeling Bach, With Intensity and Dexterity as Tools
description: Piotr Anderszewski hurried onto the stage of Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening with the awkward impatience of a stagehand who had left behind a tool and now had to retrieve it in front of an auditorium packed with expectant faces. Without a glance at the audience he sat down at the piano, lightly hunched his shoulders and began to play the first notes of Bachs French Suite No. 5 in G.

title: Fall Nationals in San Francisco
description: Quick  when you are nonvulnerable, which scores more: six spades redoubled and made with an overtrick, or seven spades doubled and made? What if you are vulnerable?

title: Awakenings in a Kooky Wonderland
description: It begins with a little white mouse. The opening of Alexei Ratmanskys Nutcracker, performed by American Ballet Theater, is flawless: Hiding under a table in the bustling Stahlbaum kitchen is an adorably droll rodent with twiggy legs and bony knees. After devouring a piece of cheese, he gives his beer belly a pat and waves off a couple of horrified maids. Was The Nutcracker missing a rogue all along?

title: Top-of-the Lungs Welcome for Young Top-40 Favorites
description: The Z-100 Jingle Ball 2012 was not the apotheosis of the sublime or the terrifying, but only the massive  as in British slang, as in, Massive thank you to Z-100!, a phrase the audience became accustomed to.

title: Florida May Reduce Tuition for Select Majors
description: MIAMI  Rick Scott, businessman turned politician, campaigned for governor in 2010 with promises to run Florida like a successful business  more efficiency, lower costs, less hand-wringing and measurable results.

title: Messis Mark Leaves a Goal Yet to Achieve
description: If Lionel Messi had been born three hours from Barcelona, rather than from Buenos Aires, there would be little doubt today about his place in soccer history.

title: In Girls Last Hope, Altered Immune Cells Beat Leukemia
description: PHILIPSBURG, Pa.  Emma Whitehead has been bounding around the house lately, practicing somersaults and rugby-style tumbles that make her parents wince.

title: Time Passes, but a Songs Time Doesnt
description: Leonard Cohen spent years struggling with his song Hallelujah. He recalls being in a New York hotel room in his underwear, banging my head on the floor and saying, I cant finish this song. He wrote perhaps as many as 80 verses before paring the song down and recording it on the 1984 album Various Positions. Then his label, CBS Records, refused to release Various Positions, not realizing that Hallelujah would become one of the most haunting, mutable and oft-performed songs in American musical history.

title: Patrick Moore, Eccentric Astronomer and TV Host, Dies at 89
description: Patrick Moore, an eccentric and accomplished astronomer, television show host and author of popular science books who once wrote an astronomy book with the guitarist from the band Queen, died on Sunday at his home in Selsey, England. He was 89.

title: Humor at High Altitudes
description: There are no clowns and no lions (or any live animals for that matter). So unless youre afraid of daring Australians who fly through the air  or men in tutus sprinkling fairy dust  you have no reason to fear Circus Oz. This Melbourne groups fast and furious show From the Ground Up is the New Victory Theaters holiday offering, and its a good one: a little naughty, a little nice, a little death defying.

title: The Sexual Duel in an Eyebrow-Raising Ballet
description: Jiri Kylians Petite Mort is predictably a dance of duets. It takes two, as they say in another sexual euphemism, to tango.

title: An Experimental Treatment for Leukemia
description: Seven-year-old Emma Whitehead has been in remission since May, after an experimental treatment for leukemia at Childrens Hospital of Philadelphia.

title: Complex Geometry and Sinuous Moves
description: The idea that ballet is like a cult is a truism. And as expressed by the choreographer Jillian Pea in The Guiding Light it remains a truism.

title: Browser Wars Flare Again, on Little Screens
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When Google took a video camera to Times Square in 2009 and asked passers-by what a browser is, most of the answers were hilariously incorrect, from a search engine to broadband to Yahoo.

title: Where to Find Coaches
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Michael David made his New York Times debut last April and hes back with a very clever Monday theme.

title: Tradition, on a Fresh Note
description: Since its founding in 1985 the World Music Institute has enriched New Yorks cultural ecosphere with events featuring accomplished practitioners of classical and folkloric traditions from around the globe. Recently the institute has begun to sprinkle among its grander offerings a handful of more casual affairs. Global Salon, a new series in the Leonard Nimoy Thalia at Symphony Space, is meant to illuminate its participants creative paths, mixing music and conversation in an intimate, stripped-down setting.

title: Japans Plutonium Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: At Art Basel Miami Beach, Around-the-Clock Offerings
description: The daily start time is noon for the main art fair at Art Basel Miami Beach that was wrapping up on Sunday, but art was available  with food and drink  at all hours. On Saturday morning, for example, Cricket and Martin Taplin welcomed an estimated 2,000 guests for an annual art brunch at their hotel, the Sagamore, on Collins Avenue. An ebullient Ms. Taplin, who has been hosting the brunch since 2001, said the art was mostly from her personal collection. It s an extension of our home, she said.

title: Julian Rachlin and Itamar Golan
description: 92nd Street Y

title: When Hospitals Buy Doctor Practices
description: To the Editor:

title: Happy With Broadband
description: To the Editor:

title: Inon Barnatan
description: 92nd Street Y

title: Oceans in Trouble
description: To the Editor:

title: Olga Neuwirth
description: Miller Theater

title: Petite Mort
description: Images of Jiri Kylians piece at City Center.

title: Lower Manhattan Residents and Businesses Still Grapple With Recovery
description: In the streets that surround the New York Stock Exchange, the air is filled with the odor of generator fuel and frustration over the slogging recovery from Hurricane Sandy.

title: Tracking the Violence in Damascus
description: Maps of violent episodes between the Syrian government and opposition groups near Damascus since November 2011.

title: Circus Oz
description: Scenes from the troupes show From the Ground Up at the New Victory Theater.

title: Mobile Video Calling Creates a New Frontier
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  The next competition in technology is your face  anywhere, anytime.

title: Three Dozen Private-College Presidents Earned Over $1 Million in 2010, Study Finds
description: WASHINGTON  Three dozen private-college presidents earned more than $1 million in total compensation in 2010, the same number as in the previous year, according to The Chronicle of Higher Educations analysis of federal tax documents.

title: Fed Is Likely to Sustain Its Stimulus Program
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve is widely expected to announce on Wednesday that it will continue buying Treasury securities to stimulate growth in the new year.

title: The Walking Dead Wins a Video Game Honor
description: The undying popularity of Robert Kirkmans zombie property, The Walking Dead, continues to spread  first from comic books, then to television and now to video games. The Walking Dead: The Game (above) was selected as the game of the year at the 10th annual Spike Video Game Awards on Friday in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. Developed by Telltale Games, this downloadable game was released in five parts, reflecting the episodic nature of the comic book and the television series. Other winners included Borderlands 2 (Gearbox Software) for best shooter and multiplayer game and Journey (thatgamecompany) for best independent game.

title: Jingle Ball 2012
description: Photos from the concert at Madison Square Garden.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data scheduled to be released include the trade deficit for October and wholesale trade for October (Monday); import prices for November (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, retail sales for November, the Producer Price Index for November and business inventories for October (Thursday); and the Consumer Price Index for November and industrial production for November (Friday).

title: Lets Gang Up on Killer Bugs
description: I hope you never have this experience: a loved one is hospitalized. Her doctors tell you her infection is resistant to antibiotics. She dies. More than 60,000 American families go through that experience each year  and the number is almost certain to rise.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Susan Rice and Africas Despots
description: Tampa, Fla.

title: For Iran, Unrest in Syria Is Noise, Not Brutal War
description: TEHRAN  When Syrias agricultural minister, Subhi Ahmad al-Abdullah, arrived in the Iranian capital for a visit last week, everybody involved stuck to a well-worn script.

title: In Beyonc Deal, Pepsi Focuses on Collaboration
description: FOR its campaign with Beyonc next year, Pepsi doesnt just want to sign up the telegenic pop star for another TV commercial. It also wants to get into the Beyonc business.

title: Who Will Hold Colleges Accountable?
description: Washington

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Water Piped to Denver Could Ease Stress on River
description: The federal government has come up with dozens of ways to enhance the diminishing flow of the Colorado River, which has long struggled to keep seven states and roughly 25 million people hydrated.

title: With a Breakout Game From Wilson, Giants Topple Saints
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  David Wilsons trademark is the back flip and once, on a particularly energetic day in college, the Giants backup running back performed 21 back flips in a row in a YouTube classic. So far this year, it only feels as if the Giants season has had that many.

title: WMVY-FM Aims to Shift to Web Streaming as a Nonprofit
description: The radio station WMVY-FM in Marthas Vineyard in Massachusetts is beloved by many listeners for its eclectic alternative programming and local news and sports, but since 2008, that affection has not translated into enough advertisers to keep it profitable.

title: NBC Rides The Voice From Worst to First Place
description: Could it still be true that even the worst performing television network is only one hit away from a turnaround?

title: John Silva, Father of Helicopter Journalism, Dies at 92
description: Helicopter news footage is common today. But until myriad problems in sending live pictures from a moving aircraft were solved, television broadcasters could not show an eagles-eye view of a forest fire, or contemplate aerial coverage of, say, a famous man fleeing the police in a white Ford Bronco.

title: A.I.G. to Sell Most of Leasing Unit to Chinese Investors
description: 8:04 a.m. | Updated

title: Robots and Robber Barons
description: The American economy is still, by most measures, deeply depressed. But corporate profits are at a record high. How is that possible? Its simple: profits have surged as a share of national income, while wages and other labor compensation are down. The pie isnt growing the way it should  but capital is doing fine by grabbing an ever-larger slice, at labors expense.

title: Before More Cancer Surgery, Chvez Had Some Political Fences to Mend at Home
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia  President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela has flown repeatedly to Cuba this year for cancer treatments, but the flight that took him back to Caracas on Friday may have been the most meaningful of all.

title: Birger Stromsheim, Hero on Skis in an Anti-Nazi Raid, Dies at 101
description: There was no Google Earth, no Gore-Tex and only a modest measure of hope on the February night in 1943 when six Norwegians parachuted into the remote and frigid Telemark region of their home country for an outdoor challenge like few others.

title: Is This the Right Blueprint for the Jets?
description: A capsule look at the Jets 17-10 victory over the Jaguars:

title: Checking the Costs of Homeland Security
description: It was no surprise that a fierce budget hawk like Senator Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, pounced on ridiculous grants doled out by the Department of Homeland Security supposedly to help local police and fire departments prepare for terrorist attacks. Mr. Coburns recent report on the departments decade-long, $7 billion program, called the Urban Areas Security Initiative, offers many depressing examples of locally misspent money.

title: Tebow Returns Home but Seems to Belong Nowhere
description: Jacksonville, Fla.

title: For The Journal, Leadership at a Crossroads
description: Betting against Rupert Murdoch hasnt gone very well for many people, including me. When he bought The Wall Street Journal in 2007 and brought in a trusted associate, Robert Thomson from The Times of London, I said that he might ruin one of the countrys most important newspapers.

title: A Question of Honor, Fairness and PTSD
description: Veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq wars have benefited from a growing, if still incomplete, understanding of post-traumatic stress disorder. The government has gotten better at recognizing the affliction and giving them the medical care and benefits they deserve. Vietnam veterans are not always so lucky.

title: Signals of a More Open Economy in China
description: BEIJING  In a strong signal of support for greater market-oriented economic policies, Xi Jinping, the new head of the Communist Party, made a visit over the weekend to the special economic zone of Shenzhen in south China, which has stood as a symbol of the nations embrace of a state-led form of capitalism since its growth over the last three decades from a fishing enclave to an industrial metropolis.

title: In Pursuit of McAfee, Media Are Part of Story
description: Late last month, the editor in chief of Vice magazine, Rocco Castoro, joined by a photographer, Robert King, managed to secure a plum exclusive: an invitation to travel along with the fugitive tech millionaire John McAfee.

title: Despite Knockout, Fight Leaves Much Unanswered
description: LAS VEGAS

title: Fire Safety in Garment Factories
description: The deaths of about 400 workers in two recent fires at Asian garment factories that made clothes for American and European brands should outrage consumers and become a rallying cry for higher safety standards. Just as the 1911 fire at the Triangle shirtwaist factory in New York ushered in a sweeping overhaul of industrial regulations in this country, these tragedies should lead to comprehensive changes in developing countries that have become the biggest suppliers of clothes to the Western world.

title: Robotic Gadgets for Household Chores
description: BERLIN  Joseph Schlesinger, an engineer living near Boston, thinks robotic toys are too expensive, the result of extravagant designs, expensive components and a poor understanding of consumer tastes. So this year, Mr. Schlesinger, 23, began to manufacture an affordable robot, one he is selling for $250 to holiday shoppers.

title: Divining the Weather, With Methods Old and New
description: EMMITSBURG, Md.

title: Redskins Rally, Exhale, Then Hold Their Breath
description: LANDOVER, Md.  Robert Griffin III walked slowly, haltingly down the Washington Redskins sideline, clapping his hands and glancing at the celebration happening on the field a few yards away without him. In that moment, the Redskins craziest dream and worst nightmare unfolded as one, a thrilling 31-28 overtime victory over the Baltimore Ravens keeping the Redskins alive for a playoff spot while the player who has made them competitive and compelling again hobbled away on a sprained right knee.

title: Mexican-American Singing Star Is Feared to Have Died in Plane Crash Near Monterrey
description: A plane carrying the Mexican-American singer and television star Jenni Rivera crashed early Sunday morning, Mexican officials said, adding that they feared there were no survivors.

title: Focusing on the Children, Not the Illness
description: To keep her secret, Jessica Rivera used to tell anyone who inquired about her wobbling legs and lack of balance that she was drunk. She preferred a ruse to divulging the truth: that she had multiple sclerosis.

title: Bloomberg Weighs Making Bid for The Financial Times
description: Not long ago, The Financial Times would have been the crown jewel of any media company, instantly conferring prestige and influence on its owner. Now, given the likely bidders, one of the worlds most respected and distinctive financial newspapers could end up as a trophy to help sell more computer terminals.

title: Same-Sex Issue Pushes Justices Into Overdrive
description: WASHINGTON  Life moves fast these days, and so does the law.

title: Chinese Firm Wins Bid for Auto Battery Maker
description: DETROIT  Wanxiang Group, a large Chinese auto parts maker, won a high-stakes auction on Sunday for assets of A123 Systems, the bankrupt American battery maker that was a centerpiece of the Obama administrations loan program for electric vehicles.

title: In Bid for Sports Dominance, Yahoo and NBC Make Web Deal
description: Yahoo Sports and NBC Sports are tying their Web sites loosely together in an arrangement meant to give NBC more traffic online and Yahoo more promotion on television.

title: For Nets, Any Adjective Suits if It Means Bad
description: In their best moments Sunday night, the Nets were clumsy and unfortunate. The rest of the time, they were inexplicably inept, disjointed and in disarray.

title: U.N. Ambassador Questioned on U.S. Role in Congo Violence
description: WASHINGTON  Almost two decades after the Clinton administration failed to intervene in the genocide in Rwanda, the United States is coming under harsh criticism for not moving forcefully in another African crisis marked by atrocities and brutal killings, this time in Rwandas neighbor, the Democratic Republic of Congo.

title: Where Theory and Research Meet to Jam About the Mind
description: Backed by his Zombie Blues band, David Chalmers is a vision of primordial rock n roll: a growling, howling menace with wild hair and a leather jacket. But the lyrics he shouts are inside references to debates about the nature of consciousness, and the audience that gathers for the performance is in on all the jokes.

title: 113th Congress: This Time, Its Out With the New
description: WASHINGTON  As a fund-raiser for a local college scholarship program, Rick Nolan understands how much it costs to send children in northern Minnesota to technical school. Having run a sawmill, he can speak like a logger.

title: Grappling With Italian Steel Plant That Provides and Pollutes
description: TARANTO, Italy  Every morning, Graziella Lumino cleans the black soot from her kitchen window, which looks out on the hulking Ilva steel plant where her husband, Giuseppe Corisi, worked for 30 years.

title: Senators Propose Tax Breaks for Storm Cleanup
description: Senators Charles E. Schumer of New York and Robert Menendez of New Jersey are proposing billions of dollars in tax breaks to help individuals and businesses rebuild in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy.

title: Reviewing Week 14 in the N.F.L.
description: DAYS BEST

title: City Is No Longer Reporting the Costs of Its Settlements of Federal Cases
description: The New York City Law Department has quietly adopted a practice of withholding from public filings how much it pays to settle most federal court cases filed against the city or its employees.

title: An Enforcer on the Ice and at the Negotiating Table
description: Kevin Westgarth is well suited to be on the negotiating team for the N.H.L. Players Association. He is a 6-foot-4 enforcer for the Los Angeles Kings, little used but with his name on the Stanley Cup. He also has a psychology degree from Princeton. And he has been present for almost every bargaining session since before the N.H.L. lockout began Sept. 16.

title: Ingersoll Details a Spinoff and Other Shake-Ups
description: 9:13 a.m. | Updated Ingersoll-Rand confirmed the details of its plan on Monday.

title: Sectarian Conflict Kills at Least 17 in Northern Lebanon in Spillover of Syrian Civil War
description: TRIPOLI, Lebanon  Clashes between Sunni Muslim and Alawite militias have killed at least 17 people here recently in perhaps the worst spillover of violence from the civil war in neighboring Syria.

title: Housing Agencys Flaws Revealed by Storm
description: Three weeks after Hurricane Sandy, fresh teams of federal disaster recovery workers rushed to Coney Island to solve a troubling mystery: few people were signing up for federal financial aid. The workers trooped into the citys public housing towers, climbing up darkened stairwells, shouting FEMA, knocking on doors.

title: Inventing Democracy
description: JOHANNESBURG

title: Stevie Brown Picks Up Giants
description: A capsule look at the Giants 52-27 victory over the Saints:

title: Understanding Immigration Reform
Timeline of the New York City Housing Authoritys Response
description: Saturday, Oct. 27 As Hurricane Sandy approaches, the New York City Housing Authority contacts tenant associations in its 26 developments in Zone A, with more than 45,000 residents, to review the evacuation plan. It begins shutting down elevators, boilers and electrical systems.

title: Jets Defeat Jaguars
description: The Jets have found a formula for success.

title: Karl Praises Change in Anthonys Game
description: George Karl has seen it before in the N.B.A.: the superstar who compiles impressive statistics while losing important games and finally adjusts his priorities. Karl went down the list of stars: Michael Jordan, Kobe Bryant and even Ray Allen.

title: Pitcher Looking to Head to U.S. Decides to Play in Japan
description: 10:11 a.m. | Updated Apparently, the trans-Pacific leap was too big to make for Shohei Otani, at least for now.

title: N.F.L. Replay: Week 14
description: The Bears are losing and the Browns are winning as the season winds down.

title: Detectives in Queens Kill Man Pointing a Pellet Gun
description: Two plainclothes detectives fatally shot a man on a darkened Queens corner after he came at them  pointing what appeared to be a semiautomatic pistol, the police said Sunday.

title: Lottery Numbers
After Sandy, Failing to Help Those in Need
description: While the New York City Housing Authority moved aggressively before the storm to encourage residents to leave, it was woefully unprepared to helps its residents in Hurricane Sandys aftermath.

title: Rival to Merkel Is Officially Seeking Her Job
description: BERLIN  As if it werent challenging enough to run against a chancellor viewed as Europes most powerful leader, Angela Merkels main rival in next years national election has come under fire since his nomination for the nearly $1.7 million he earned from speaking fees in the past three years.

title: Garlands and Mud for New Nobel Laureate from China
description: HONG KONG  The novelist Mo Yan will formally receive the Nobel Prize in Literature on Monday, a first for China, but after a particularly nasty backlash over his selection, its understandable if some members of the Swedish Academy might be having some buyers remorse.

title: Giants Replay: Week 14
description: Action from the Giants 52-27 victory over the New Orleans Saints at MetLife Stadium, as the rookie David Wilson scored three touchdowns, helping the Giants keep their lead in the N.F.C. East.

title: Anthony Helps Knicks Stay Perfect at Home
description: The Denver Nuggets were not the ideal opponent for the Knicks on Sunday, not after a late flight from Chicago the night before, wrapping up a three-game trip and a stretch of five games in seven nights.

title: Mexican-American Superstar Jenni Rivera
description: Ms. Rivera, who sold more than 15 million albums worldwide and appeared in her own reality show, was killed in a plane crash outside of Monterrey, Mexico.

title: Big Plays on Defense, but Still Room for Improvement
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Safety Antrel Rolle said last week that the Giants defense needed to become nastier. Defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul echoed the criticism by saying the unit had been soft.

title: When Daily Stress Gets in the Way of Life
description: I was about to give an hourlong talk to hundreds of people when one of the organizers of the event asked, Do you get nervous when you give speeches? My response: Who, me? No. Of course not.

title: Major Renter to Students to Pay Millions for Civil Fraud
description: The founder of a nonprofit group that has rented affordable apartments to a generation of New York City college students siphoned millions of dollars from the agency through a shell company, using the groups money to fly back and forth to a second home in Aspen, Colo., and to pay for a luxury penthouse in Brooklyn, an investigation by the state attorney generals office has found.

title: Poor Schools Struggling to Meet State Standards, Years After Critical Ruling
description: Six years after a landmark court ruling required New York State to increase spending on public education, many schools in poor districts lack basic resources, and some do not even meet minimum state standards in certain areas, according to a report to be released on Monday by researchers affiliated with Teachers College at Columbia University.

title: Corrections: December 10, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Homeless Rates in U.S. Held Level Amid Recession, Study Says, but Big Gains Are Elusive
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government has made big strides in reducing the ranks of the chronically homeless and of veterans who are homeless, but it probably will not reach its goal of ending homelessness among those two populations by 2015, according to a government report to be released on Monday.

title: Young and Homeless
description: The Timess Susan Saulny reports from Seattle where she talks with young adults who are struggling with homelessness as a result of the recession.

title: Word of the Day | parry
description: parry \per-e, pa-re\ verb and noun

title: China Reports a 2.9% Rise in Exports for November
description: HONG KONG  Exports from China edged up 2.9 percent in November, far less than analysts had expected, highlighting the crucial role that homegrown stimulus and reforms will play in the renewal of Chinas acceleration while the trajectory of global demand remains highly uncertain.

title: Letters Show Millers Desire to Be Taken Seriously
description: For Marvin Miller to revolutionize labor history, he first had to sell himself to the baseball players union. He was still an economist for the United Steelworkers union in December 1965, when he was interviewed by Robin Roberts, Harvey Kuenn and Jim Bunning to be the executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, Dec. 10
description: We are at a major turning point in the arc of gay and lesbian rights. The cases are moving fast, and the country is as well.

title: Messi: 86 (and Counting) in 2012
description: Lionel Messi scored twice in Barcelonas league victory at Real Betis on Sunday. Normally that information would be met with a shrug; Messis scoring is not exactly a piece of big news anymore, and the goals themselves were not particularly memorable. But they were the latest two in Messis incredible haul of 86 this year  Got 10 minutes? Some enterprising YouTuber has compiled them all in the video above  and that broke the record for goals in a calendar year set by Germanys Gerd Mller in 1972.

title: News Quiz | December 10, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 10
description: NEWS Cerebral, bespectacled and more at home at a seminar than in the bear pit of Italian politics, Prime Minister Mario Monti for the last year has quietly restored Italys weight in European diplomacy while helping mend its battered credibility with the financial markets. So Mr. Montis announcement over the weekend that he intended to stand down from his job running the euro zones third-largest economy posed a worrying question: Is Italy about to go back to its bad old ways? Stephen Castle and Jack Ewing report.

title: A Conversation With: Human Rights Activist Binayak Sen
description: Binayak Sen, 62, is no ordinary doctor. Few doctors, after all, spend three decades working in a region threatened by what Prime Minister Manmohan Singh called the single biggest internal security challenge ever faced by the country. And that was before Dr. Sen was jailed on charges of waging a war against the state, which prompted a group of Nobel laureates to petition for his release.

title: Near Aisle Rage at Gristedes
description: Dear Diary:

title: Technical Issues Delay Rocket Launching, North Korea Says
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said on Monday that a technical issue had been found in the rocket it had planned to launch as early as this week to put a satellite in orbit, but that it still planned to try the launching by the end of the month.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Dec. 10, 2012
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article Scientists See Promise in Deep-Learning Programs.

description: WHAT do participants in a competition like a Tough Mudder experience as they complete the course?

title: What Are Your Tips for Enjoying the Holiday Season?
description: Hanukkah is here, Christmas and Kwanzaa are about two weeks away, and everyone seems to be busy with holiday plans.

title: Polaroids Instant Karma
description: The road to instant imagery began with a question familiar to any parent on vacation: Are we there yet?

title: Anxiety Over Italys Future Devalues Its Bonds, and Spains
description: ROME  Italian stock and bond prices fell on Monday after a weekend of political turmoil in Italy gave rise to fears that the country was headed for renewed instability.

title: Week 14 Quick Hits: Redskins Rising
description: Andy Benoit take a quick tour through Sundays Week 14 games. Share your thoughts.

title: Romania Faces Upheaval as Center-Left Wins Vote
description: PARIS  Romanias parliamentary elections have left the country poised for Round 2 of a political standoff that has destabilized one of the European Unions newest and poorest members.

title: Several Are Killed in Attack on Pakistan Police Post
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Taliban suicide bombers attacked a police station in northwestern Pakistan on Monday, killing at least eight people, including three police officers, officials said.

title: Whats in a Name? In This Family, College Is the Accomplishment
description: I could run off a list of my favorite colleges and I would be met with blank stares at family reunions.

title: The Early Word: Double Negatives
description: Todays Times

title: Capitalism and the Kids
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. She recently edited and contributed to For Love and Money: Care Provision in the United States.

title: Congress Party Craters in Gujarat
description: KESHOD, Gujarat The prospects of the Indian National Congress party in the battleground state of Gujarat are dwindling by the day, analysts and potential voters say, a situation that could ultimately advance Gujarat chief minister Narendra Modis bid to become prime minister.

title: Behind the Cover Story: A. O. Scott on Women, Girls and the Standout Female Performances of the Year
description: A.O. Scott, a chief film critic for The Times, wrote this weeks cover article about the state of women in movies and exceptional female performances in 2012. His essay accompanies a photo portfolio by Tierney Gearon.

title: Fill-In | More Dads Buy the Toys, So Barbie, and Stores, Get Makeovers
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first seven paragraphs of the article More Dads Buy the Toys, So Barbie, and Stores, Get Makeovers by Stephanie Clifford.

title: Jets Need a Receiver; What About Braylon Edwards?
Opel Confirms End of Car Production at a Key German Plant
description: FRANKFURT  Opel, the unprofitable European unit of General Motors, confirmed Monday that it would stop producing cars at its plant in Bochum, Germany, in 2016, a sign that even the Continents most powerful economy cannot escape the effects of the euro zone crisis.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | Dec. 10, 2012
description: Update: Dec. 12: Scroll to the bottom of this post to find the caption, related story and comments from the photographer.

title: This Week in Small Business: The Popes on Twitter (Are You?)
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: Subject Appears Anxious
description: Year: 2007

title: Crowdsourcing Your Commute
description: THE HAGUE  In an article in our Smart Cities series, my colleague Choe Sang-Hun reported on how citizens of Seoul are able to connect to a city information system to receive real-time traffic information or mass transit updates.

title: Training Needed for Home Care Is Lacking
description: H from Chicago, I heard you when you joined a lively discussion over hospice at home here a couple of weeks ago and asked, where can family members get the training to do all the nursing tasks?

title: Mourning an Alpha Female
description: As I reported on Sunday in The Times, Yellowstone National Parks best-known wolf was shot and killed last week outside the parks borders. A large gray alpha female known as 832F, she had been fitted by researchers with a GPS collar that allowed them to track her movements.

title: RIT Capital to Take Stake in British Financial Start-Up
description: LONDON  RIT Capital Partners, the investment firm chaired by Jacob Rothschild, said on Monday that it had acquired a stake in a British crowdfunding company, Zopa.

title: And Now, Round 3 in the Medea Sing-Off
description: ParisOn Monday evening Cherubinis Mde takes to the stage of the Thtre des Champs-lyses as the third and final work of a mini-festival this fall of operas about Greek mythologys most famous woman spurned. On the podium, will be Christophe Rousset, whose sterling credentials as a harpsichordist and Baroque specialist might suggest hed be more at home with Marc-Antoine Charpentiers Mde, the first in the series (Medea by the composer Pascal Dusapin was the second).

title: The Math Bowl: Carolinas Win Against Atlanta
description: The Atlanta-Carolina game was a mini-mathematics bowl for some in the statistical community.

title: Study Predicts Future for U.S. as No. 2 Economy, but Energy Independent
description: WASHINGTON  A new intelligence assessment of global trends projects that China will outstrip the United States as the leading economic power before 2030, but that America will remain an indispensable world leader, bolstered in part by an era of energy independence.

title: Q&A: Borrowing E-Books from the Library
description: Q.

title: Monday Reading: Deep Powder, Without Deep Pockets
Opinion Report: Factory Fires
description: From the editorial page

title: Getting His Goat
description: MOSCOW  Should the prime minister have referred to Russian detectives as goats? It can be a derogatory term in Russian, just like that word in English that can mean either donkey or derriere.

title: Kickoffs Help Giants, but Future of Kickoffs Is Uncertain
description: The Giants needed kickoff returns by David Wilson to turn the momentum against the Saints on Sunday.

title: Philosophy, or Plumbing: How Well Is Academia Preparing Students for the Real World?
description: A report being released Monday by the McKinsey Center for Government shows a big disconnect between new grads looking for work and the employers looking to hire them. Both sides have acknowledged that something is amiss: Only 42 percent of employers felt that new hires were adequately prepared by their education or formal training. Similarly, only 45 percent of graduates felt they were adequately prepared for even entry-level positions in their field.

title: Banks Rising Legal Bills
description: The mortgage crisis continues to haunt banks, which face an onslaught of lawsuits, Jessica Silver-Greenberg writes in The New York Times. Estimates of potential costs from these cases vary widely, but some in the banking industry fear they could reach $300 billion if the institutions lose all of the litigation. Depending on the final price tag, the costs could lower profits and slow the economic recovery by weakening the banks ability to lend just as the housing market is showing signs of life. The banks are fighting prosecutors, regulators and investors. We are at an all-time high for this mortgage litigation, said Christopher J. Willis, a lawyer with Ballard Spahr, which handles securities and consumer litigation.

title: Daily Report: The Browser Wars Are Back
description: Many consumers are not so sure what a Web browser is. But these programs have become a crucial business for tech companies like Google and Microsoft, Claire Cain Miller reports in Mondays New York Times. That is because they are now the entry point not just to the Web but to everything stored online, like Web apps, documents and photos.

title: Japanese Manufacturers Help Save Chip Maker Renesas
description: TOKYO  When a magnitude 9 earthquake knocked out a chip-making factory at Renesas Electronics, Toyota Motor and other manufacturers dispatched hundreds of workers to help get the plant in northeastern Japan running again.

title: Vain Glorious | The Shampage at Pierre Michel
description: To ease the stress of the impending holiday rush, the Pierre Michel salon has introduced a service called the shampage (shampoo plus massage). I was cynical, but its a winner: a 30-minute hair wash that also focuses on pressure points to release stress. Masseuse/stylists (lets call them masstylists) apply gentle fingertip pressure on both sides of your nose to clear sinuses. Why every stylist doesnt do this everywhere all year round is another story (they should!). The service at Pierre Michel does not cost extra, and its not required, either. A regular blow-out is $65 and includes the shampage if your schedule permits.

title: Huawei to Open Research Center in Finland
description: PARIS  Huawei Technologies, a Chinese maker of telecommunications equipment, said on Monday that it planned to open a research and development center in Helsinki next year, accelerating its investments in Europe, where its business is expanding rapidly.

title: Not Silenced, 33 Years After Her Own Subway Nightmare
description: On the second night of Hanukkah, Renee Katz lit the menorah candles Sunday evening at her home in Queens, using her right hand a bit tentatively. Hanukkah candles are slender. They are not easy for Ms. Katz to grasp with the right hand. I dont have great dexterity, she said. Anything that requires fine motor skills is hard.

title: Windows 8s Clarity Problem
description: A modest suggestion to Microsoft: Next time, more verbs.

title: Vast Land Deal Divides Detroit
description: John Hantz says he has a dream: to purchase 140 acres of derelict land in the heart of Detroit and turn it into the worlds largest urban farm.

title: Chanel's Scottish Touch Warms Up the Scottish Highlands
description: EDINBURGH  The ghost of the doomed Mary, Queen of Scots, might have been swirling in the (fake) mist above the ruined castle where she was born five centuries ago; and the plaintive bagpipes could have been in honor of Gabrielle (Coco) Chanel, when the young French woman was in love with both the Duke of Westminster and the Highlands of Scotland.

title: Family Treasures and the Secrets They Unlock
description: PARIS  Sometimes there are family treasures that unlock the dramas of generations, revealing stories far larger than ever imagined.

title: Amgen to Acquire the Gene-Hunting Firm deCODE
description: In a bid to bolster its drug discovery efforts, the biotechnology giant Amgen said on Monday that it would pay $415 million to acquire deCODE Genetics, a gene-hunting business known for its headline-grabbing discoveries linking genetic variations to disease.

title: Ask Alex Gansa and Howard Gordon About Homeland
description: Dec. 14 | Updated  Answers are published here.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Bloomberg and The Financial Times, and the First Telecopter
description: The stars are aligning, perhaps, for the purchase of The Financial Times by Bloomberg L.P., the media company whose shares are 90 percent controlled by New Yorks mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, Amy Chozick and Michael Barbaro write. The departure of two top executives at Pearson, the owner of The Financial Times, has made the sale of the newspaper seem a possibility. Bloomberg, which makes its money primarily from desktop terminals, would have to weigh the business advantages of going backward technologically to print; one advantage would be to gain a well-respected daily platform for Bloomberg content. (Thomson Reuters is also said to be likely to bid on the newspaper.)

title: Critics Groups in Los Angeles, New York and Boston Get Serious
description: The films that, at years end, critics (and sometimes audiences) love are beginning to take shape and lets call it, well, whatever form gravitas takes. The Los Angeles Film Critics Association announced its choices over the weekend, and it gave the top prize to Michael Hanekes Amour, the story of an elderly French couple dealing with dementia and death.

title: What Were Reading
description: LA Weekly: Apples as art.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Standard Chartered Agrees to Settle Iran Money Transfer Claims
description: The British bank Standard Chartered reached a deal with federal and state prosecutors on Monday over accusations that it had illegally funneled money for Iranian banks and corporations.

title: Man Groups Chief  to Step Down
description: LONDON  The Man Group, the worlds largest publicly traded hedge fund management firm, said on Monday that Peter Clarke would retire as chief executive at the end of February after almost 20 years with the firm.

title: More Time For Investors To Sell Back Greek Debt
description: LONDON  Greece, on the verge of completing a crucial plan to reduce its debt burden, extended the deadline on Monday for foreign investors and Greek banks to sell their deeply discounted bonds back to the government.

title: Moroccans Fear That Flickers of Democracy Are Fading
description: TANGIER, Morocco  Until recently, politics in Morocco involved red carpets and speeches in high Arabic that the average citizen could not understand. But on a campaign swing this fall through a working-class area of this port city, Prime Minister Abdelilah Benkirane stood on a makeshift podium in a muddy vacant lot.

title: HSBC Names Head of Financial Crime Compliance
description: LONDON  The British bank HSBC on Monday appointed Robert W. Werner, a former United States Treasury official, to direct financial crime compliance, a newly established role.

title: Something in My Last Post Didnt Add Up
description: Well, commenters to my last post quickly revealed why I am not a wealthy and successful businessman.

title: Apps for Children Fall Short on Disclosure to Parents, Report Says
description: Several hundred of the most popular educational and gaming mobile apps for children fail to give parents basic explanations about what kinds of personal information the apps collect from children, who can see that data and what they use it for, a new federal report says.

title: A Girls Soundtrack Album Is On the Way
description: Anyone who feels their approximation of the life of 20-something Brooklyn ladies is incomplete without a musical accompaniment can ready their headphones. The HBO series Girls will have an official soundtrack, released by the label Fueled by Ramen on Jan. 8, just before the second seasons premiere. Contributors include a whos who of pop acts and the contemporary indie scene like Fun., Icona Pop, Fleet Foxes, Robyn (whose Dancing on My Own helped fuel a plot point in an early episode), and Sleigh Bells. A track by Santigold  called Girls is the lead single.

title: Memo from Miami | Fun in the Sun
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Where Neighborly Agreement Is Scarce, Finding Consensus on Art in the Lobby
description: The spaces are often teeny and the prices are generally enormous, but perhaps the most irritating feature of living in New York City condominiums and co-ops lies past the wallet and outside the apartment door: collective decision-making among dozens, even hundreds, of neighbors.

title: U.S. Agricultural Research Is Faltering, Report Warns
description: A blue-ribbon panel of scientific and technology advisers to President Obama warns that the nation risks losing its longstanding supremacy in food production because research in agriculture has not kept up with new challenges like climate change, depleted land and water resources and emerging pests, pathogens and invasive plants.

title: Zero Dark Thirty Catches Even Cast Members by Surprise
description: 11:51 a.m. | Updated  With this seasons compressed schedule for Oscar voting comes a glut of screenings, Q&As and other appearances intended to endear movies and their stars and filmmakers to Academy voters. In New York that also means luncheons  often masterminded by the publicity maven Peggy Siegal  that are stocked with Academy members who dont mind a free meal in exchange for a few hours in the company of colleagues and celebrities.

title: Dueling Protests Continue in Cairo
description: The Timess Cairo bureau chief, David Kirkpatrick, explains the ongoing political crisis over Egypts draft constitution.

title: Everyones a Critic: Turkish Lawmaker Joins Prime Minister in Attack on Soap Opera
description: The culture clash between a steamy Turkish soap opera and the countrys conservative governing party shows little sign of abating.

title: Street Style: Black and White
description: The best of readers photographs from the week of Dec. 3.

title: Image of the Day: Dec.10
Obama, With Blue-Collar Backdrop, Pushes for Higher Taxes on the Richest
description: REDFORD, Mich.  Using a German-owned truck factory as a grease-stained backdrop, President Obama on Monday pressed his case for higher tax rates for the richest Americans, declaring that his economic program would cut the deficit without crimping the job market.

title: Alice in Math Wonderland
description: The Museum of Mathematics (MoMath) will open to the public on Saturday at 11 East 26th Street in Manhattan. The museum features innovative hands-on exhibits that emphasize the fun of mathematics. To celebrate the occasion, todays Numberplay and the one next week will feature puzzles that are based on exhibits at the museum.

title: Mourning a Banda Star
description: TimesCast: Mexican-American singer Jenni Rivera is feared to have died in a plane crash. | Cubas agricultural experiment with capitalism. | Egypts constitutional standoff continues.

title: Feeling the Heat, Yoga Chain Bows to Bikram, Despite Federal Ruling
description: Updated, 4:25 p.m. | A popular New York-based chain of yoga studios accused by Bikram Yoga of copyright infringement has decided to let go, despite a Copyright Office ruling that supported its position.

title: Jenni Rivera, Mexican-American Singer, Dies at 43
description: Jenni Rivera, the Mexican-American singer and reality television star known as the Diva of Banda, died early Sunday when the plane in which she was traveling crashed outside Monterrey, Mexico, after a performance there. She was 43.

title: When Giving a Used Gift Is O.K.
description: Would you give someone a pre-owned gift for the holidays or a birthday?

title: An Adoptive Parent Wont Take the Blame
description: Im the adoptive mother to a daughter and a son, ages 10 and 8, both born in Guatemala. Three years after my daughter came home, in November 2006, The New York Times ran an article blasting Guatemalas adoption system, calling the country a virtual baby farm.

title: Did the Mainstream Press Really Bungle the Campaigns  Single Biggest Story?
description: In one of the most fascinating media-related pieces Ive read in a while, Dan Froomkin interviews Thomas Mann and Norman Ornstein, two longtime Washington observers who wrote a book together and soon after, they say, found themselves near pariahs in a city that didnt want to hear what they had to say.

title: Single Rides and Monthly Passes to Cost More in M.T.A. Plan
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authoritys board appears poised to consider a proposal that would increase base fares on subways and buses by a quarter, to $2.50, and raise the cost of a 30-day pass by $8, to $112.

title: Amid Highlights, Grief Returns to N.F.L. Sideline
description: Death was again a presence on an N.F.L. sideline on Sunday. A week after Jovan Belcher of the Kansas City Chiefs committed suicide in front of Coach Romeo Crennel and General Manager Scott Pioli after murdering his girlfriend Kasandra Perkins, the Dallas Cowboys paid tribute to Jerry Brown, who died after a car in which he was a passenger spun out of control on Saturday. The driver was a teammate, Josh Brent, who was jailed and charged with intoxication manslaughter.

title: The Connection Between Europes Nobel and Afghanistan
description: The European Union received the Nobel Peace Prize on Monday in recognition of the blocs commitment to peace and human rights.

title: Springsteen, Lady Gaga and the Black Keys to Join the Stones
description: Bruce Springsteen, Lady Gaga and the Black Keys will be guest artists when the Rolling Stones play on Saturday at the Prudential Center in Newark, the last scheduled concert in a mini-tour to celebrate the bands 50th anniversary.

title: 7 Score and 7 Years Ago, a Similar Albany
description: New Yorks capital city cant seem to catch a break. A string of corruption and sex scandals and byzantine power struggles have frustrated would-be reformers; the State Senate is so divided that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said last week that I expect the leadership situation to be fluid and subject to influence for some time.

title: Baryshnikov Arts Center Announces 2013 Season
description: The Baryshnikov Arts Center has announced its spring 2013 season lineup, a schedule of performance and dance that will focus on new works by choreographers relatively new to the New York scene.

title: Masta Killa on The Master
description: The Los Angeles Film Critics Association fell hard for The Master, awarding Paul Thomas Anderson best director and also smiling on Joaquin Phoenix and Amy Adams for their performances. Theyre professionals and all, but few of them  as far as we know  actually take the title Master.

title: Look of The Moment | Pharrell Williams
description: The Look: Army Grade. Black tie on top with street-sport shorts on the bottom and an allover military camo is a perfect fashion mash-up.

title: Charles Rosen, Scholar-Musician Who Untangled Classical Works, Dies at 85
description: Charles Rosen, the pianist, polymath and author whose National Book Award-winning volume The Classical Style illuminated the enduring language of Haydn, Mozart and Beethoven, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 85.

title: A New Twist on a Hanukkah Staple
description: Im glad that nutritionists have changed their view of fats. The data tells them that when it comes to negative health outcomes like deaths from diabetes and heart disease, fats, at least of the polyunsaturated and monounsaturated variety, are not the big bad culprits. Simple carbohydrates appear to play a much more pernicious role.

title: Changes at The Wine Advocate Signal a Shift in the Market
description: For many wine lovers, the news that Robert M. Parker Jr. is planning to sell a portion of his influential newsletter, The Wine Advocate, to a group of Asian investors and step down as editor in chief does not so much signal an end of an era as acknowledges changes that have been under way for a decade.

title: Video Shows Man Mugging 85-Year-Old Woman in Elevator
description: The police are looking for a man who was captured on video knocking down an 85-year-old woman in the elevator of her West Village apartment building and stealing her bag. The man is at least six feet tall and weighs at least 200 pounds, the police said.

title: Sweet Potato and Apple Latkes With Ginger and Sweet Spices
description: I found that the best way to make these so they cook through without burning is to make small latkes, using about 2 tablespoons of the mixture for each one. You can also finish them in the oven.

title: Homer R. Warner, a Pioneer of Using Computers in Patient Care, Dies at 90
description: Homer R. Warner, a physiologist whose research fusing engineering and medicine helped introduce computer analysis to diagnosing illnesses, died on Nov. 30 in Salt Lake City. He was 90.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Bottlerocket Marketing Group, New York and Foxborough, Mass., was acquired by Brand Connections, New York. Financial terms were not disclosed. The acquisition is the second in a month for Brand Connections, coming after a deal to acquire Pie Advertising, New York.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Environment: Mapping Hot Spots of Lead Contamination Could Safeguard Children in Mining Towns
description: Using a hand-held scanner to map hot spots where the soil is full of lead could protect children in mining towns against brain damage, scientists at Columbia University concluded in a new study.

title: Playing the Talk About Giving Game With Your Family
description: In this past weekends Your Money column, I mentioned the Talk About Giving game. Its a $13 offering (including shipping and handling) from the Central Carolina Community Foundation, and you pick cards from a deck and use the questions as a way to begin a family discussion about values and philanthropy.

title: In the Heights Coming to the Heights
description: In the Heights will finally be coming to the Heights. The rap-salsa-pop musical by Lin-Manuel Miranda, which won the 2008 best musical Tony for its jaunty exploration of the lives of Dominican-American characters living in Washington Heights, will be restaged in the form of a one-night-only concert Feb. 11 at the United Palace of Cultural Arts at 175th Street and Broadway.

title: A Rising Tide of Noise Is Now Easy to See
description: When a hurricane forced the Nautilus to dive in Jules Vernes Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea, Captain Nemo took the submarine down to a depth of 25 fathoms, or 150 feet. There, to the amazement of the novels protagonist, Prof. Pierre Aronnax, no whisper of the howling turmoil could be heard.

title: The Mayor Menino Blues
description: A blues tune recorded by the mayor of Boston, Thomas M. Menino, is featured on the Samaritans suicide prevention Web site.

title: David Ortiz Sings the Blues
description: A blues tune recorded by David Ortiz of the Boston Red Sox can be found on the Samaritans suicide prevention Web site.

title: Effort to Fight Suicide Focuses on the Help and the Hope
description: There has been quite a vogue in recent years for what are called random acts of kindness. A new campaign is adding some planning to the mix.

title: Cuomo Rejects Criticism for Avoiding Senate Leadership Dispute
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, criticized by black lawmakers for not objecting to a proposed governing coalition in the State Senate between Republicans and a group of dissident Democrats, insisted on Monday that it was not his place to get involved in what he called a schism within the Democrats in the chamber.

title: Your Modern Family Questions Answered
description: Steven Levitan and Christopher Lloyd, the co-creators of the hit ABC comedy Modern Family, answered questions posed by Times readers. (Alex Gansa and Howard Gordon, the creators of Showtimes Homeland, are taking queries now.)

title: For the Baseball Classic, the Fan Cave Will Be International
description: The M.L.B.s popular Fan Cave is taking a road trip, sort of.

title: Technology and Wages, the Analytics (Wonkish)
description: Obviously Im getting a lot of reaction to my stuff on robots and all that. (My copy editor, last night: Thank God, its not about the fiscal cliff!) My sense is, however, that a lot of the reaction, both positive and negative, involves misunderstanding the economic logic, with some readers believing that technological progress can never hurt workers, others believing that rapid productivity growth always hurts workers; neither is true. So heres an attempt to explain whats going on in the theory; cognoscenti will recognize it as nothing more than an exposition of J.R, Hickss analysis of the whole thing in his 1932 Theory of Wages (pdf).

title: Westgarth Says Pension Plan Would Be a Gain
description: Below, excerpts from an hourlong conversation over the weekend with Los Angeles forward Kevin Westgarth, a member of the N.H.L. Players Association negotiating committee. (You can read a profile here.) In that conversation, he discusses what was achieved by last weeks talks in New York, why the owners seem to be dodging mediation, why they dislike Donald Fehr, what really happened in the reported shouting match between Jeremy Jacobs and Ryan Miller, and where the two sides stand on key issues as new talks loom in the 12-week-old N.H.L. lockout.

title: Want to Live Longer? Breathe Clean Air
description: Continuing declines in air pollution are linked to increasing life expectancy, a national study has found.

title: Gmail Goes Down, Frustrating Office Workers
description: Some Gmail users had trouble starting the work week on Monday.

title: Really? On a Cloudy Day, Your Eyes Can Be Sunburned
description: THE FACTS

title: Fried Shallots
description: Mark Bittman prepares a simple garnish with a mandoline.

title: A Winters Cornucopia in Wales
description: THE predicament I found myself in was also an opportunity, and not unlike the puzzle that faces C.S.A. participants each week: I had a pile of vegetables and I had to figure out what to do with it. (A C.S.A.  for community supported agriculture  is a scheme in which participants share in a farmers risk and bounty, putting money down upfront and getting a periodic share of the crop in exchange.)

title: Campaign Finance API: Were Deprecating Individual Donor Search
description: One of the earliest features of our Campaign Finance API allows users to search individual contributions to presidential candidates from 2008 and 2012 by name and/or ZIP code. But this data is offered in many other places, several of which have better search interfaces and also include contributions to other campaigns. (The individual search responses are also among the least requested by users of our Campaign Finance API.)

title: Man Fatally Shot on Midtown Street
description: Updated, Tuesday, 6:51 a.m. | Gunfire cut through the bustling noise of Monday afternoon in Midtown Manhattan, a sound instantly recognizable to passers-by on a packed corner a block from Central Park.

title: TimesOpen 2012 Hack Day Wrap-Up
description: 10:12 a.m. | Updated Added Tumblist Times to the list of hacks (we were waiting for permission to post the details).

title: A Brief Note on Mary Matalin
description: The briefer the better, Id say. But anyway, yesterday on This Week she attacked me for being a polemicist; whats interesting is the context. I was trying to correct a claim she was making that was factually wrong. She threw out a number  $1.7 trillion from capping deductions  as evidence that the G.O.P. claim that it can raise lots of revenue from high-income Americans without raising tax rates is true.

title: Egyptian President Tries to Clarify Military Order
description: CAIRO  A day after President Mohamed Morsi formally directed the military to help keep public order and authorized soldiers to arrest civilians, a spokesman on Monday sought to draw distinctions between the order and the forms of martial law that the Egyptian Army had previously imposed.

title: European Officials Accept Unions Nobel Peace Prize
description: OSLO  Besieged by economic woes and insistent questions about its future, the European Union accepted the Nobel Peace Prize on Monday with calls for further integration and a plea to remember the words of Abraham Lincoln as he addressed a divided nation at Gettysburg.

title: At Home on Mars
description: Q. Could Mars be made suitable for human life by raising plants to produce oxygen?

title: Facing a Defining Sunday After a Deflating One
description: Days like last Sunday happen occasionally in the N.F.L.  usually at least once a season  and when they do, it feels as if a shift has taken place. Next Sundays schedule is loaded with critical matchups and will be perhaps the best viewing day of the season, with at least eight games freighted with postseason implications.

title: The Next Big Thing in Motorcycles: Going Small
description: LONG BEACH, Calif.  Boomers who were long the motorcycle industrys primary focus could be less important to product planners if the new, smaller bikes presented last weekend at the Progressive International Motorcycle Show are indeed the future.

title: Concussion Liability Costs May Rise, and Not Just for N.F.L.
description: As the N.F.L. confronts a raft of lawsuits brought by thousands of former players who accuse the league of hiding information about the dangers of concussions, a less visible battle that may have a more widespread effect in the sport is unfolding between the league and 32 of its current and former insurers.

title: Ford Fixing Leak Problem With Software Upgrade
description: Ford says that next week it will send dealers a software upgrade that will solve a fire concern that required the recall of 65,000 2013 Escapes and almost 15,800 2013 Ford Fusions in the United States.

title: Concern Over Apps for Kids
description: TimesCast Media+Tech: An update in the battle over childrens privacy online. | Deb Perelman of Smitten Kitchen. | Bloomberg weighs bidding on Financial Times.

title: Britains Departing Central Banker Is Troubled by Trade Imbalance
description: Mervyn A. King, the outgoing governor of the Bank of England, expressed confidence in his successor and discussed economic challenges facing Britain and the United States in their approaches to monetary policy and financial regulation in a speech Monday at the Economic Club of New York.

title: N.H.L. Drops Games Through Dec. 30
description: In a move expected after last weeks failed labor talks, the N.H.L. canceled another 16 days of games Monday. The move extended the cancellations from Dec. 15 through Dec. 30, bringing the total number of regular-season games lost in the lockout to 526, or 42.8 percent of the schedule.

title: Mapping Ocean Noise
description: A project to document and map man-made noise in the ocean estimated average annual underwater noise across a range of frequencies.

title: The Budding Health Care Costs of Climate Change
description: Images of physical damage have been prominent in the news coverage of Hurricane Sandy  the charred frames of houses in Breezy Point, Queens, for example, or a roller coaster submerged in the Atlantic City breakers. Far less conspicuous are long-term health effects, from increased rates of tetanus and respiratory disease to post-traumatic stress disorder.

title: Hotel Worker Settles Claim Strauss-Kahn Forced Sex
description: The former French politician Dominique Strauss-Kahn and the hotel housekeeper who accused him of sexually assaulting her last year have agreed to settle her lawsuit stemming from their encounter, a judge said on Monday.

title: Abuse Verdict Topples a Hasidic Wall of Secrecy
description: Sexual abuse in the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community has long been hidden. Victims who came forward were intimidated into silence; their families were shunned; cases were dropped for a lack of cooperation.

title: Week Ahead in Fiscal Talks
description: The Timess Annie Lowrey reports on how some Republicans are considering concessions on taxes in order to shift the debate to entitlements.

title: The Fine Line Between Legal, and Illegal, Insider Trading
description: The steady drumbeat of insider trading cases brought by the government has continued, and corporate officers have not avoided scrutiny.

title: Batman, Not Bond, and Other Film Institute Notes
description: 1:35 p.m. | Updated  It was good news for fans of one British series, and bad news for diehards of another today, as the American Film Institute announced its picks for the years best films. The Dark Knight Rises  helmed by a British director, Christopher Nolan, with stars, like Christian Bale and Michael Caine, from all over the United Kingdom  was on the list; Skyfall was not. (Sorry to disappoint, Bond aficionados and Bagger readers!) Robert Zemeckiss Flight, still an Oscar contender for Denzel Washingtons performance, was also not chosen as one of the cream of the crop; latecomer Django Unchained was.

title: Holiday Shopping on the Fly
description: Airport shopping used to be mainly for the desperate or bored. But as airports seek to generate more revenue, they have been expanding their offerings of stores and other services, and some time-constrained business travelers now say they find gift-worthy items before their flights.

title: Science Times Podcast
description: This week: cacophony in the ocean deep, parasites and zombies, and building empathy in children.

title: In Performance: Shuler Hensley
description: Shuler Hensley in a scene from The Whale, Samuel D. Hunters play about a morbidly obese man.

title: The Earliest Dinosaur, or Maybe Its Closest Kin
description: Researchers may have discovered the earliest dinosaur yet, or at least its closest relative.

title: Scene City: Last Stop at Art Basel Miami Beach
description: A roundup of some Art Basel Miami Beach parties held over the weekend, including a party held at the former Versace mansion and Monclers 60th anniversary.

title: South Street Seaport Museum to Reopen Friday
description: The waterlogged South Street Seaport Museum has dried out and is coming back to life. Having been closed by Hurricane Sandy, the museum will reopen on Friday, officials announced Monday.

title: Walkabout  12/10: What Berlins Delayed Airport Means, and Our Travel Sections Cameo on The Simpsons
description: Up in the Air Willy Brandt International Airportwas supposed to be Berlins gateway to the world, but has turned into a symbol of its provincialism. (International Herald Tribune)

title: In China, New Leadership and New Style
description: Xi Jinping visited Shenzhen over the weekend in a move seen by some as a sign of his commitment to further economic reforms. The choice of this city as the destination for his first domestic trip as general secretary is seen as a strong signal that Mr. Xi is hitching himself to Deng Xiaopings legacy and style and is serious about reinvigorating reforms.

title: The Giving Spree | Liu Wen
description: Who: The Chinese model Liu Wen, who appeared on the cover of Ts spring travel issue. Her journey from Hunan province, where she was born, to the New York runways is documented in Christina Larsons The Liu Wen Express.

title: A Tense Compromise on Defining Disorders
description: They plotted a revolution, fell to debating among themselves, and in the end overturned very little except their own expectations.

title: Notable Opinion Art from 2012
description: A selection of illustrations that reflects on the issues of 2012 using exemplary wit, incisiveness, beauty and provocation.

title: Republican Party Looks to Learn From 2012 Electoral Losses
description: The Republican National Committee is studying how to improve the partys image, expand its appeal to voters and improve how campaigns are conducted, a move that signals a direct acknowledgment that party leaders are intent on trying to heed lessons from the 2012 election cycle.

title: China Detains Two Tibetans in Self-Immolation Protests
description: BEIJING  Chinese police officials have detained a Tibetan monk and his nephew and accused them of playing a role in a series of self-immolations, according to Xinhua, the state news agency. The move appeared to be part of a campaign to prosecute Tibetans who are accused of aiding others who set fire to themselves in protest of Chinese rule.

title: Opportunity, a Mars Rover Past Its Best-By Date, Keeps Going
description: SAN FRANCISCO  While many obsessed over speculation that NASAs newest Mars rover, Curiosity, had dug up signs of life  it had not  it is the agencys older, smaller jalopy, Opportunity, that has been exploring a more intriguing plot of Martian real estate.

title: HSBC to Pay $1.92 Billion to Settle Charges of Money Laundering
description: 4:37 a.m. | Updated

title: Jettisoning the Aircraft Leasing Business
description: Robert H. Benmosche is making American International Group more aerodynamic  at a price.

title: When Hiding Their Food, Eurasian Jays Keep Quiet
description: The Eurasian jay, a member of the crow family, hides acorns and other food in several thousand locations every year, to be retrieved when food is scarce.

title: Life After Escaping an Indian Brothel
description: Minati, 19, was never meant to be rescued from a brothel here in the red light district of Kolkata, India. When Nick Kristof accompanied the International Justice Mission and the police on a raid in a brothel in the Songachi district last year, they were looking for a girl much younger than Minati.

title: Fearing a Mile-High Punkd Prank
description: NEVER in a million years did I think that I was going to be the guy who hops on a plane and gets to go and do something he enjoys so much  being the Subway guy. Im a good flier, but Im also lucky that most of my flights have been pretty uneventful.

title: Pogues 12 Days of Gadgets: CardNinja Cellphone Case
description: On the third day of gadgets, my true love gave to me  another budget-conscious tech gift, as part of Pogues 12 Days of Gadgets!

title: S.C. Governor Rules Out a Placeholder Appointment to Replace DeMint
description: South CarolinaGov. Nikki Haley said Monday that she would not appoint a placeholder to fill temporarily the Senate seat made vacant by the retirement of Senator Jim DeMint.

title: Coating on Aspirin Sets Off a Debate
description: Millions of Americans take low-dose aspirin every day to prevent heart attacks and strokes. But a study published last week challenges some cherished beliefs about the familiar remedy, leaving some consumers to wonder if they should throw out their coated pills and others concerned that they unnecessarily may be taking expensive substitutes.

title: Recalling Lives Altered, in Ways Vivid and Untidy
description: Alice Munro, one of the foremost short-story writers of her generation, creates tales that have the scope and amplitude of novels: whole lives are condensed into a handful of pages, the progress of love is charted over the years as passion gives way to restlessness or deeper commitment or something more ambiguous.

title: A Dark and Stormy Fall Season for Broadway
description: The fall theater season on Broadway has been one of the weakest in recent memory, to judge by box office receipts and critics reviews, with only a handful of potential hits among the new shows. Indeed, the two best-reviewed shows of the fall have emerged as two of the worst sellers on Broadway.

title: Gridlock Reform
description: With Harry Reid apparently determined to alter Senate filibuster rules, Republicans John McCain, Lamar Alexander, Jon Kyl and Lindsey Graham have commenced back-channel talks with Democrats.

title: Efficacy of Tobacco Taxes Tied to Gene Type
description: Tobacco use has declined sharply since the 1960s, but for the past 20 years about 20 percent of the population has continued to smoke. The imposition of steep tobacco taxes in many states has not lowered the smoking rate.

title: Lower Bone Density for Girls Who Smoke
description: Smoking in teenage girls is associated with slower development of bone mineral density, a new study reports.

title: Fighting the Resource Curse, Part 2
description: The World Bank has announced efforts to create a $50 million trust fund for use by African countries negotiating mineral, oil and gas contracts. The money would be spent on securing advice from lawyers and from technical advisers like engineers and chemists during negotiations with energy and kining companies.

title: Genomic Study Traces Roma to Northern India
description: The Roma people of Europe, often called Gypsies, are long thought to have originated in India because of similarities between Roma and Indian languages. But historical records are scanty.

title: Afghan Womens Affairs Aide Shot Months After Killing of Predecessor
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The acting head of womens affairs in Laghman Province in eastern Afghanistan was shot to death in daylight on Monday as she was traveling to work.

title: Understanding How Children Develop Empathy
description: The mother was trying to hold the baby still, and I was pulling gently on the ear, angling for a better look at the infants eardrum. The wriggling baby didnt like any of it, and her whimpering quickly turned to full-fledged wails.

title: Trying to Give Voice to Unparalleled Purity
description: Have you seen but a bright lily grow, a Ben Jonson poem asks, before rude hands had touchd it?

title: Growth of Sign Language (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Turkey, New York and India.

title: Sopranos Song Recital Makes Room for Solo Turns by Its Accompanist
description: It is rarely in question who the star of a song recital is.

title: Bailout Over, U.S. Treasury Plans to Sell A.I.G. Shares
description: 9:01 p.m. | Updated

title: A Successful Diagnosis (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Coping With Tinnitus (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Alternative to Antibiotics
description: To the Editor:

title: College Search Is Not a Quest for Value
description: Maimuna Abdi Yussuf, a Somali student at African Leadership Academy in Johannesburg, is trying not to get caught up in the rat race that is the college application process.

title: Frances McDormand, Voice of Sanity
description: One of the Baggers favorite people to encounter on the awards circuit is Frances McDormand  like Bill Murray, she is a rare sighting, and youll never know what shell say.

title: Obesity in Young Is Seen as Falling in Several Cities
description: PHILADELPHIA  After decades of rising childhood obesity rates, several American cities are reporting their first declines.

title: The Wind at Her Back, a Writers Buzz Gets Louder
description: The interview ended a bit later than expected, so Ayana Mathiss nails were going to have to make it to Chicago without a manicure. And she still had to scurry to clean her one-bedroom apartment and fill it with fresh flowers for a photo shoot. But at least a car was scheduled to whisk this first-time novelist to La Guardia Airport.

title: A Rich, Aging Man Dupes Three Greedy Heirs ...
description: In 1955 Orson Welles hatched a characteristically ambitious plan to stage the tragedy King Lear with Ben Jonsons Volpone, a contemporaneous comedy.

title: David Pogues 12 Days of Gadgets
description: One offbeat tech gift idea a day  and nothing over $100.

title: History of Fredericksburg in 21 Objects
description: A pipe, a stencil, a cup, a button  common objects rendered remarkable by the events of December 1862.

title: As One-Acts, Operas Find Solidarity
description: One-act operas can seem to exist via reputation and recordings only, with staged presentations few and far between. Even the very best works in the genre tend to languish, often for the most prosaic reason: if an opera is too short to sustain a full program, what can it be paired with, profitably and sympathetically? The Italian red-sauce tandem Pagliacci and Cavalleria Rusticana is an example of an unusually successful coupling, bonded by blood and big tunes.

title: Ennobling Many Forms of Work and Creation
description: There is late seating in Adrienne Truscotts ... Too Freedom ... . But beware: You may find yourself led onstage for a brief detour before being ushered to your seat. Spotlights may also be involved.

title: A Stamp on the Outside, Intimacy on the Inside
description: NEW HAVEN  I seem to spend my life missing you, Robert Lowell wrote to Elizabeth Bishop, many years after the long and intimate friendship between these two great American poets began. In another letter he sadly observed, We seem attached to each other by some stiff piece of wire, so that each time one moves, the other moves in another direction.

title: Goat Farmer With a Side Project in Advertising Wins Amazing Race
