description: Remember in the theme song of the CBS sitcom Green Acres how Eva Gabor, as Lisa Douglas, bade goodbye to city life? That also seems to be the fate of a winner of a CBS reality series.

title: Celebrating Renee Robinson
description: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater feted the retiring dancer at City Center Theater on Sunday evening.

title: As He Saves a Fallen Woman, a Monk Plays With Fire
description: Mditation, the interlude for solo violin from Massenets opera Thas, has developed a life of its own on the concert stage, but the opera itself is not often performed. Marked Andante religioso, the Mditation is played as the title character ponders giving up her life as a courtesan to enter a convent. Her night of soul-searching is heralded by remarkably sensual, passionate music, fit for a hedonist converted by a lustful monk.

title: Nikolai V. Zlobin: Selected Quotations
description: The political analyst Nikolai V. Zlobin documents meticulously everyday American life for an uncomprehending Russian readership. It seems strange that ordinary Russians would still be hungry for details about how ordinary Americans eat, pay mortgages and hire teenage baby sitters. But to Mr. Zlobins surprise, his book  published this year and marketed as a guide to Russians considering a move abroad  is already in its fifth print run, and his publisher has commissioned a second volume. The following are selected quotes from his 400-page book, America  What a Life!

title: Can You Be Creative in Berlin?
description: In his Riff in the magazines Nov. 25 issue, Robert F. Coleman writes about his stint as a musician in Berlin. Instead of flourishing in a city many consider a creative mecca, he became one of the many people who flock to Berlin to pursue their art, only to realize months later that they havent produced a single piece of work. This motivated several of our readers to respond in disagreement, saying that it is possible to be a productive artist in Berlin and avoid all the partying  and laziness  associated with so-called creative tourists.

title: A Hunger for Tales of Life in the American Cul-de-Sac
description: MOSCOW  After 20 years of opining on weighty bilateral issues like NATO expansion and ballistic missile defense, the political analyst Nikolai V. Zlobin recently found himself trying to explain, for an uncomprehending Russian readership, the American phenomenon of the teenage baby sitter.

title: Drought and Economy Plague Sheep Farmers
description: SEVERANCE, Colo.  Since he was a boy in western Colorado, John Bartmann seemed destined to become a sheep man. He raised lambs with the local 4-H club and sheared them for elderly German farmers. His office is lined with paintings of sheep and a plaque honoring him for promoting culinary excellence in lambs.

title: A Compelling Salute to Posterity
description: Renee Robinson gave the farewell performance every dancer would love to give at City Center Theater on Sunday evening. After more than 30 years of professional dancing, she was still a compelling image of style, moving with verve and lan at the heart of two of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theaters classic works. Any dancer in any company could learn from her about focus, projection and ardor; she danced as if she had not only the equipment to carry on much longer but the hunger for it too.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,146 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Quick Defense in Insider Trading Trial of 2 Hedge Fund Managers
description: Defense lawyers for two former hedge fund managers called two witnesses before resting their case, a surprise decision that will send the insider trading trial to the jury as soon as Tuesday.

title: Swagger With a Bit of Angst
description: Big Boi starts his second solo album, Vicious Lies and Dangerous Rumors (Def Jam), reminding listeners that hes one-half of the mind of Outkast, the hip-hop duo (with Andr 3000) from Atlanta that released its last album, Idlewild, in 2006. Memories probably arent that short. And once Big Bois solo career got moving  his 2010 album, Sir Lucious Left Foot: The Son of Chico Dusty, was delayed by record-company conflicts  it was clear that he was keeping what made Outkast so memorable: fast-talking rhymes alongside full-fledged tunes that might draw on funk, new wave, club beats or hip-hop. Pop choruses didnt mean the songs were trivial.

title: Police Commissioner Hits the Street to Help Open an Applebees
description: It was meant to be a quick appearance for the police commissioner, a ribbon-cutting at a new Harlem outpost of Applebees.

title: Hawking and CERN Teams Win Prizes From Russian Billionaire
description: MEYRIN, Switzerland  Its been a good year to be a physicist.

title: The State of Tap: A Survey Course
description: WASHINGTON  Though the Kennedy Center has honored many tap dancers, this most officially American of theaters rarely presents the American art of tap on its main stages. In fact, JUBA! Masters of Tap and Percussive Dance, the variety show here on Friday, was the first of its kind.

title: TimesCast Media+Tech: Concern Over Apps for Kids
description: An update in the battle over childrens privacy online. Deb Perelman of Smitten Kitchen. Bloomberg weighs bidding on Financial Times.

title: Swans, Dragons and Other Bold Images Cast Spells on the Melodies
description: During a performance of Somei Satohs Shu (Spells) for six players at Japan Society on Saturday evening, images of elaborate dragons roiled across an overhead screen as the music became increasingly turbulent. An elusive cello melody unfurled to delicately meshed pictures of swans and other white birds.

title: Memo From Miami | The Wrap-Up
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Quick, What Is Time?
description: Last year, Alan Alda, the actor, asked, What is a flame? and more than 800 people answered.

title: Boom in Mongolia Deflates After Deal That Started It Is Threatened
description: ULAN BATOR, Mongolia  The concept of a blue sky country has become almost a clich in presentations about Mongolia, the worlds fastest-growing economy last year. The phrase, which evokes the Montana-like landscape of the steppe, paints a picture of sunny investment horizons in this frontier democracy rich in coal, copper and gold.

title: Putin Restores Worker Award of Soviet Era
description: MOSCOW  When secretaries, financial analysts and the like spilled onto the streets of Moscow in antigovernment protests last winter, Vladimir V. Putin took one look and dismissed them as a crowd of office plankton.

title: Trains Fill the Gaps in Airline Schedules
description: NOT long ago, I wrote about all the problems I encountered in trying to get from Tucson to Houston on short notice on a weekend. A nonstop flight would have taken less than two hours.

title: Colleges and Climate
description: To the Editor:

title: McCain Wants Committee Job With Influence on Foreign Affairs
description: As President Obama mulls whether to nominate Susan E. Rice, the United Nations ambassador, to replace Hillary Rodham Clinton as secretary of state, one of Ms. Rices biggest critics, Senator John McCain of Arizona, said he would seek a seat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: A Scrapbook of Our Relationship With the Universe
description: In her excellent 2011 collection, Life on Mars, the poet Tracy K. Smith writes of seeing the high beams of a million galaxies flick on at twilight. Thats the kind of wonder I felt as Michael Bensons Planetfall carried me away.

title: A Scrapbook of Our Relationship With the Universe
description: Planetfall is a collection of breathtaking images of our solar system taken by NASA and European Space Agency missions from 2000 to 2012.

title: Anger and an Arrest as a Leader of Egypts Muslim Brotherhood Visits Brooklyn
description: The tension that has gripped Egypt in recent weeks over a draft constitution written by Islamists briefly erupted on a New York street on Saturday night, with the arrest of a protester who disrupted a discussion of the document by Essam El-Erian, a leader of the Muslim Brotherhood.

title: What if, You Say, the Seinfeld Gang Were Still Around?
description: Further proof that nothing does indeed live forever has arrived in the form of the SeinfeldToday Twitter feed, which imagines 21st-century scenarios for the 20th-century quartet and has accumulated more than 50,000 followers since its start on Sunday.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: IPhone 5S Alert, and Googles Bermuda Money
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Dickey Has at Least One More Assignment With Mets
description: Unless theres a Scrooge inside the Mets front office, R. A. Dickey should remain a member of the organization at least through Tuesday morning.

title: Cooper Union Students End Occupation of Suite After a Week
description: Just before noon on Monday, a group of Cooper Union students picked up their blankets and sleeping bags and left the Peter Cooper Suite on the eighth floor of the institutions Foundation Building, where they had barricaded themselves a week earlier to protest the possibility of undergraduates being charged tuition for the first time in at least 110 years.

title: The Diversity Inside a Childrens Book
A Tribute to Brubeck
description: To the Editor:

title: Humans and Dinosaurs
description: To the Editor:

title: When Low-Income Tenants Face Eviction
description: To the Editor:

title: Citys Economic Development Corporation Agrees to More Openness
description: The Bloomberg administrations main agency for economic development has pledged to make its operations more transparent, thanks to a new agreement with the city comptroller, John C. Liu.

title: Analysis of an Interception: Drew Brees and the Giants
description: Jonathan Bales breaks down a big play each week at The Fifth Down:

title: Gay and Immigrant Rights Groups Join Forces on Marriage Issue
description: In a letter on Monday to the White House, more than 50 gay rights and immigrant advocacy groups asked President Obama to put a hold on immigration cases involving Americans seeking legal residency visas for foreign-born spouses of the same sex, until the Supreme Court issues a significant ruling on gay marriage next year.

title: The Rules of the Prank-Call Game
description: OTTAWA  Until last week, Pierre Brassard was the worlds most famous royal prankster, thanks to a 14-minute conversation he had with Queen Elizabeth back in 1995. But last Friday, while preparing to record his weekly news quiz radio program in a Montreal radio studio, Mr. Brassard learned about the death of Jacintha Saldanha, the nurse in Britain who accepted a call from an Australian broadcaster pretending to be the queen.

title: BlackBerry Phones Get Free Calls Over Wi-Fi
description: By using Research In Motions exclusive data network, the BlackBerry Messenger service, or BBM, has long allowed its users to avoid texting charges from their wireless carriers. On Monday, RIM added dodging voice charges to BBMs list of features.

title: Euro-Skeptics Turn Up Heat on Cameron
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain faced more pressure over his countrys fraught relationship with the European Union on Monday when an influential former cabinet minister said Britain should threaten to quit the bloc if it cannot negotiate much looser ties.

title: 55 Years After Girls Death, Her Killer Gets a Life Term
description: It was the coldest of cold cases  a crime so old that when the director of the F.B.I. requested regular updates on the investigation, it was J. Edgar Hoover who did the asking.

title: For Marriage Equality, the Works Not Just in Court
description: PROPONENTS of same-sex marriage had good reason to celebrate last week; the Supreme Court announced that it could restore the freedom to marry in California and end federal discrimination against the marriages celebrated by same-sex couples in the nine states (along with the District of Columbia) that have the freedom to marry.

title: U.S. Places Militant Syrian Rebel Group on List of Terrorist Organizations
description: WASHINGTON  The United States has formally designated the Al Nusra Front, the militant Syrian rebel group, as a foreign terrorist organization.

title: Could the Farm Bill Devastate Americas Birds?
description: Washington

title: At 20, Holocaust Museum Plans a Call to Action
description: INTERNET users who type ThirdReich.com into an address bar land in what may be the last place they would expect to: the Web site for the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum. The museum, which is near the National Mall in Washington secured the domain name not just to foil people who may be looking for anti-Semitic material, but also to educate them.

title: California: 25 Arrested Off Coast in Suspected Smuggling Case
description: In a joint operation, federal law enforcement officials on Monday morning arrested 25 people suspected of human smuggling on a fishing boat off the coast of Southern California, the authorities announced. The United States Coast Guard was notified by Border Patrol agents of a vessel approaching the shore near Rancho Palos Verdes in Los Angeles County around 5 a.m. The type of vessel seized, known as a panga, has been increasingly used by smugglers to move drugs along the California coast; last week, a member of the Coast Guard was killed while trying to board a similar vessel.

title: Massachusetts: A Dean at Harvard Is Chosen to Lead Smith College
description: Kathleen McCartney, the dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Education, will be the next president of Smith College, effective July 1. Dr. McCartney, an expert in early childhood education, has degrees from Yale and Tufts, where she is a trustee, and is the Harvard representative on the founding board of edX, an online consortium. Under her leadership, the Harvard education school began a doctoral program in education leadership, a three-year tuition-free program designed in collaboration with the faculty from the Harvard Business School and the Harvard Kennedy School. She will succeed Carol T. Christ, who has led Smith since 2002.

title: Even in a Blowout, Disturbing Signs for the Giants Defense
description: Sometimes, it can be difficult to take N.F.L. players and coaches seriously. In a league that is often teeming with undeserved bravado  the Jets come to mind  there is also an overwhelming amount of self-flagellation. Occasionally, it can feel as if no one who is actually good ever wants to admit it.

title: Twitter Adds Photo Filters in Battle With Instagram
description: So many filters, so little time.

title: The God Glut
description: Bob Kerreys political career spanned four years as the governor of Nebraska and another 12 as a United States senator from that state, during which he made a serious bid for the Democratic presidential nomination. In all that time, to the best of his memory, he never uttered what has become a routine postscript to political remarks: God bless America.

title: Delay Sought for Visa Cases That Involve Same-Sex Spouses
description: In a letter to the White House on Monday, more than 50 gay rights and immigrant advocacy groups asked President Obama to delay immigration cases involving Americans who are seeking legal residency visas, known as green cards, for their foreign-born spouses of the same sex until the Supreme Court issues a ruling on same-sex marriage next year. Under the federal Defense of Marriage Act, a same-sex marriage cannot be a valid basis for federal benefits, including immigration documents. Administration officials have been denying applications for green cards for foreign-born same-sex spouses of American citizens. On Friday, the Supreme Court agreed to hear two cases involving same-sex marriages, including a direct challenge to the federal law. The groups are asking the administration to postpone decisions on green card applications from gay couples until the court rules.

title: Montana: Wolf Hunts Are Banned in Areas Bordering Yellowstone
description: Montana wildlife commissioners on Monday shut down all wolf hunts and prohibited trapping in areas of the state that border the northwest corner of Yellowstone National Park. The decision was made after the eighth Yellowstone wolf wearing a tracking collar for research was killed this season. Bob Ream, the chairman of the Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks Commission, said the scientific study played a role in the decision. We recognize they put a lot of time and money and effort into collaring wolves, and we want to see that research continue, he said. Doug Smith, a senior wildlife biologist for the park, praised the decision as a moderate one that addresses some of the issues as far as the science.

title: Cairo Filmmakers Screen Images of Revolt on the Presidents Wall
description: Activists from Mosireen, a Cairo film collective dedicated to documenting the continuing Egyptian revolution, set up a projector outside the presidential palace on Sunday night and showed video shot at the same location last week during street battles between opposition protesters and Islamist supporters of President Mohamed Morsi.

title: New Problems With Boeing 787 Revive Concerns
description: After years of delays in producing its much-anticipated 787 aircraft, Boeing seemed in recent months to be turning a corner, streamlining production and increasing the pace of deliveries.

title: Chvez in Cuba for Cancer Surgery
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela arrived in Cuba early Monday to have surgery for what appears to be an aggressive form of cancer, leaving behind a nation hanging on the outcome of his treatment.

title: El Salvador: Court Orders Investigation of 1981 Massacre
description: The Inter-American Court of Human Rights has ruled that a 20-year-old amnesty law does not cover war crimes committed during El Salvadors long civil war. The ruling, which was announced Monday, ordered the government to investigate the massacre in the region of El Mozote 31 years ago and to prosecute and punish those hold responsible. More than 800 civilians, many of them children, were killed by the military in the worst massacre of the war, which began in 1979 and ended in 1992. But Salvadoran courts have refused to investigate the killings, citing a 1993 amnesty law. The regional courts ruling means that El Salvador will have to secure truth and justice for the crimes committed during this massacre, said Viviana Krsticevic, executive director for the Center for Justice and International Law in Washington, which joined with the human rights office of the San Salvador archdiocese to take the case to the regional court.

title: Taking Aim at Michigans Middle Class
description: The decline of the middle class in this country has paralleled that of the labor movement, which has been battered by the relentless efforts of business groups and Republicans to drive down wages, boost corporate profits and inflate executive salaries and bonuses. Now that campaign is on the verge of a devastating victory in Michigan, home of the modern labor movement, which could transform the states economy for the worse.

title: Some Devils Find Playing Time on A.H.L. Team
description: TROY, N.Y.  The Times Union Center was occupied by Carrie Underwood and the Siena mens basketball team last week, so the Albany Devils practiced at their backup rink, the Knickerbacker Ice Arena, up Interstate 787 and across the Hudson.

title: Social Science Palooza III
description: Elections come and go, but social science marches on. Here are some recent research findings that struck my fancy.

title: A Cooperative Approach on Too Big to Fail Banks
description: It is one of the thorniest problems hanging over the financial system: how should authorities deal with the collapse of a sprawling global bank to protect the financial system at large?

title: Town Mourns a Mayor Who Had Staying Power
description: RICHMOND, Tex.  The mayor of this town southwest of Houston never had a desk or an office at City Hall. In fact, even though a life-size bronze statue of Mayor Hilmar G. Moore was erected outside City Hall, the mayor himself refused to accept a key to the place, although his tenure leading this town of 12,000 was certainly unusual and, in the era of term-limited politicians, nearly unbelievable.

title: Higher Educations Future: Discuss!
description: I saw the poster in the window of one of the New School buildings. The Future of Higher Education: A Panel Discussion, Monday, December 3, 6:30  8. To say that I have heard the topic discussed before would be an understatement (maybe 50 times), but I cant resist the (unlikely) possibility that someone will say the magic word. At the very least I went in with a certain anthropological curiosity. What are they going to say this time?

title: The American Way of Learning
Documents Reveal New Details About Walmarts Connection to Tazreen Factory Fire
description: Documents uncovered at the Tazreen garment factory in Bangladesh where 112 workers died in a fire two weeks ago indicate that not one but two American apparel makers supplying goods for Walmart were using the factory around the time of the fire.

title: Ray of Hope in Lopez, but Nets Are Cautious
description: It is too soon for a crisis and too soon for saviors, but there was Brook Lopez, standing tall and pain-free on the Nets practice court Monday, looking strong and spry enough to steady a listing ship, and not a moment too soon.

title: In Talks, House Majority Weighs Loyalty to Voters
description: WASHINGTON  As their leaders inch toward agreeing to higher tax rates, dozens of House Republicans find themselves caught between the will of a larger American public that favors higher taxes on the rich and the wishes of constituents who re-elected them overwhelmingly to oppose the Obama agenda at every turn.

title: Obama Approves Health Insurance Marketplaces in 6 States
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration gave conditional approval on Monday to health insurance marketplaces being set up by six states led by Democratic governors eager to carry out President Obamas health care overhaul.

title: Royals Trade the Future for Now
description: Dayton Moore stood between two practice fields one morning last March in Surprise, Ariz., prospects fanned out to either side. They performed the same drills and wore their pants the same way, showing plenty of socks, like the old-timers. To an outsider, the aspiring Kansas City Royals looked mostly the same.

title: Saul P. Steinberg, Icon of the Corporate Takeover, Dies at 73
description: Saul Steinberg, a swashbuckling corporate raider who for more than three decades so terrified companies with attacks on their stock that some paid him millions just to go away, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 73.

title: Morsis Opponents Describe Abuse by Presidents Allies
description: CAIRO  Islamist supporters of President Mohamed Morsi captured, detained and beat dozens of his political opponents last week, holding them for hours with their hands bound on the pavement outside the presidential palace while pressuring them to confess that they had accepted money to use violence in protests against him.

title: Minnesotas Williams, at No. 2, Falls Short of the Hype, but Lives Up to a Trend
description: Being an early pick in any draft comes with oversized and, occasionally, unrealistic expectations. The Minnesota Timberwolves Derrick Williams is the latest to experience the growing pains of the N.B.A..

title: The Jets, at 6-7, Gain Unexpected Playoff Hopes Amid the Usual Drama
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  It has been quite a two weeks for the Jets. Their offensive line coach went rogue. A linebacker blasted their fans. Their self-appointed mascot resigned from his self-appointed post. There also may have been something about a quarterback benching  a controversy or some such.

title: Show Me the Money
description: The annual IMG Intercollegiate Athletics Forum, held last week in Midtown Manhattan, is the kind of meeting where football games are routinely described as product, television networks are distribution channels, and rooting for State U. is an example of brand loyalty. The university presidents, conference commissioners, athletic directors and corporate marketers who attend spend very little time mouthing the usual pieties about how the student-athlete comes first. Rather, they gather each year to talk bluntly about making money.

title: Jenni Rivera, American Diva
description: As news of the death of Jenni Rivera, in a plane crash in Mexico, spread on Twitter on Sunday, a divide opened up between the distraught and the bewildered. Those who vowed never to forget her were matched by those who said: Jenni who? The short version is that she was a superstar in the border-straddling world of Mexican regional music, an immigrants daughter from a musical dynasty who sold millions of albums, became a TV celebrity and led a personal life straight out of a telenovela.

title: When a Hurricane Strands Those in Need
description: For the most part, New York Citys bureaucracy responded quickly to the challenges presented by Hurricane Sandy. But it did not do nearly as well with respect to the most vulnerable citizens who live in public housing. As documented by Eric Lipton and Michael Moss in The Times on Monday, the city made insufficient efforts to remove them from harms way before the hurricane struck and moved too slowly to help them afterward.

title: Al Qaeda in Syria
description: The presence of rebel fighters in Syria that were trained and supported by Al Qaeda poses a serious problem for the United States and Western allies. The Nusra Front, an offshoot of Al Qaeda in Iraq, has become one of the most effective forces fighting against President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Michigan Labor Fight Cleaves a Union Bulwark
description: LANSING, Mich.  With Democratic furor escalating and party leaders warning that Michigan was about to be plunged into lasting political discord, the states Republican-led Legislature was on the verge of approving new limits to unions here in the birthplace of the modern labor movement.

title: Libyan Reluctance Hampers U.S. Investigation Into Deadly Benghazi Assault
description: WASHINGTON  An unarmed American military surveillance drone now flies virtually every day over Benghazi, gathering information and poised to respond at a moments notice if any of the suspects believed to be behind the attacks last Sept. 11 on the American Mission in the Libyan city are located.

title: Cecilia Chang: A Sordid Life in Documents
description: Papers from Dr. Changs files show how she leveraged relationships with powerful people, like Gov. Frank H. Murkowski.

title: James D. Hodgson,  Labor Secretary and Ambassador, Dies at 96
description: James D. Hodgson, who as President Richard M. Nixons secretary of labor in the early 1970s promoted jobs for minority workers in the building trades and safer American workplaces, died on Nov. 28 at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 96.

title: Fallen Deans Life, Contradictory to Its Grisly End
description: She sat in her regular beauty salon, strikingly optimistic, eyeing in the mirror not a defendant but a woman whose fortunes would surely turn the next day.

title: Good as Done
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  You can always tell when were getting closer to Christmas. It starts with the Jingle Bell Rock that gets piped relentlessly into stores the minute the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade wraps up, and the festivities continue through the New Year, which is also known in the retail industry as Holiday Present Returns Season.

title: Corrections: December 11, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Pentagon Says Afghan Forces Still Need Assistance
description: WASHINGTON  As President Obama considers how quickly to withdraw the remaining 68,000 American troops in Afghanistan and turn over the war to Afghan security forces, a bleak new Pentagon report has found that only one of the Afghan National Armys 23 brigades is able to operate independently without air or other military support from the United States and NATO partners.

title: Even Anthony Likes Offense to Go Through Kidd
description: The moment said a lot about Carmelo Anthony and Jason Kidd.

title: Suzuki and Yankees Expect to Get a Deal Done
description: Ichiro Suzuki made a strong impression on Yankee fans in the second half of 2012, and it is starting to look as if they will have a chance to watch him for a full season in 2013.

title: Governor Nominates 2 for New Jerseys Top Court
description: After his first nominees were rejected, Gov. Chris Christie made another attempt to fill the longstanding vacancies on the New Jersey Supreme Court on Monday, nominating two men he said would meet the State Senates demands for diversity.

title: Navy SEAL Team Member Dies Saving Kidnapped Doctor
description: The Navy SEAL who died during the daring rescue of an American physician in Afghanistan has been identified as Petty Officer First Class Nicolas D. Checque. He was 28 years old and lived in Virginia Beach.

title: Gateway Recreation Area Faces Long Recovery After Storms Battering
description: The usually advantageous geography of Gateway National Recreation Area, with its salt-sprayed parks, beaches and historic sites at the edge of New York City and New Jersey, put the federal lands in the bulls-eye of Hurricane Sandy. Six weeks after the storm pummeled the region, most of the recreation area remains closed, as the National Park Service continues to clean up and restore essential elements like drinking water and sewage treatment.

title: Brooklyn: Something to Lean On
description: A portion of John Forts song, Brooklyn: Something to Lean On, is played before every game as part of the Nets elaborate player introductions.

title: Italys Premier Refuses to Commit to Running
description: ROME  While Prime Minister Mario Montis decision over the weekend to resign this month rattled Milans stock market and worried European leaders, Italian centrists stepped up their efforts on Monday to persuade him to join their political movements.

title: A Boy Full of Quirks Learns to Curb His Aggression
description: When Jaren Aponte, 4, wants to show someone affection, he seeks out an ear.

title: Lottery Numbers
Chinese Leader Offers Policy Hints
description: The state news media confirmed Monday that Xi Jinping, the new Communist Party chief, visited Guangdong Province over the weekend, a trip first reported by Hong Kong news organizations. Mr. Xi chose Guangdong and the special economic zone of Shenzhen for his first tour outside of Beijing as party chief, signaling that he might favor more market-oriented economic policies. Xinhua, the state news agency, reported Monday that Mr. Xi met with business executives in Guangzhou and talked about tax reform, support for exports, aid for small businesses and land use. We need both a firm confidence in victory and a stronger sense of peril, he said, and added that officials should carry out deeper reform, improve the mechanisms of the market economic system and strengthen the rule of law.

title: Creating an Anthem for a Borough
description: On Tuesday night, when the Nets take on the Knicks for the second time this season at Barclays Center, a good chunk of the capacity crowd will be looking to let loose with its newly established chant of Broooo-klyn! Broooo-klyn! It will be loud  unless the Nets are being drastically outplayed  it will be impressive and it will be just as John Fort envisioned it would be.

title: Reveling in Her Supreme Court Moment
description: People move to New York for many complicated reasons  personal, professional, spiritual, gravitational  some quite clear, some unknowable. Edith Windsor came 60 years ago for a very simple one.

title: Gloria Davy, First African-American to Sing Aida at the Met, Dies at 81
description: Gloria Davy, a Brooklyn-born soprano who was the first African-American to sing Aida with the Metropolitan Opera, died on Nov. 28 in Geneva. She was 81.

title: A World of Corruption
description: HONG KONG  Corruption can be a somewhat elastic concept, whether its an American homeowner slipping the cable guy $20 for free HBO or a Chinese police chief setting up his twin-sister mistresses in a free apartment.

title: Sports Replay: Dec. 10
description: The day in sports, including a big game in the N.F.L and a Womens Euro 2012 Handball Championship match.

title: Contra N.B.A.: Orchestra Executive Moves from Brooklyn to New Jersey
description: The basketball Nets moved from New Jersey to Brooklyn. Richard Dare, an entrepreneur turned orchestra executive, is making the opposite journey. Mr. Dare, the chief executive and managing director of the Brooklyn Philharmonic, will become president and chief executive of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra in January, the symphony is expected to announce on Tuesday.

title: A Start-Up Sees an Opportunity in Diabetes Prevention
description: There is no doubt that diabetes is a national health crisis  and a costly one.

title: Word of the Day | aberrant
description: aberrant \a-ber-nt, -, -be-rnt;a-b-rnt, -ber-nt, -be-rnt\ adjective and noun

title: Study Finds Seafood Is Often Mislabeled in New York
description: Its the eternal question when ordering fish, whether at the sushi bar or the fried-fish shack: is this really the fish I ordered, and would it matter if it wasnt?

title: Tests Say Mislabeled Fish Is a Widespread Problem
description: Fish is frequently misidentified on menus and grocery store counters in New York City, even at expensive restaurants and specialty shops, DNA testing for a new study found. National supermarket chains had the best record for accuracy in seafood labeling, the researchers reported.

title: Indias Real Estate Developers Predict New Construction Boom
description: The sight of a construction crane looming on the horizon has become ubiquitous in most large cities across India  and may become even more so in the near future.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 10:30 P.M. (Discovery) AMISH MAFIA Beyond the buggies, bonnets and simple lives of the Amish in Lancaster, Pa., is a group of men responsible for keeping the peace. Led by the gun-toting Lebanon Levi, who was never baptized in the Amish church, the vigilantes work beyond cultural codes to prevent outside forces from wreaking havoc while keeping Amish principles and morality in check. This new series, which has a sneak peek here and its official premiere on Wednesday night at 9, examines misdeeds within the community through eyewitness accounts and re-enactments, and the workings of Mr. Levis team (above)  a group that the church says does not exist, according to the shows producers.

title: News Quiz | December 11, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 11
description: NEWS Besieged by economic woes and insistent questions about its future, the European Union accepted the Nobel Peace Prize on Monday with calls for further integration and a plea to remember the words of Abraham Lincoln as he addressed a divided nation at Gettysburg.  Andrew Higgins reports from Oslo.

title: U.S. Students Still Lag Globally in Math and Science, Tests Show
description: Fourth- and eighth-grade students in the United States continue to lag behind students in several East Asian countries and some European nations in math and science, although American fourth graders are closer to the top performers in reading, according to test results released on Tuesday.

title: A Rare View Inside Delhis Royal Court
description: With her thinly arched eyebrows, flowing mane of black hair and polished English, the journalist Tavleen Singh looks very much the part of the upper-class New Delhi socialite, a set into which she was born and in which she moves with ease.

title: Test Yourself | English, Dec. 11, 2012
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article An American in Paris, Again.

title: Diageo Ends Talks to Buy Jose Cuervo Brand
description: 8:07 p.m. | Updated

title: Same-Sex Marriage and the Supreme Court
description: On WHAT topic (one of the most important social controversies of the day) has the Supreme Court recently agreed to hear cases?WHAT is the Defense of Marriage Act?WHAT is the eight-state solution?

title: Capturing the Accelerating Change in Tibet
description: We highly recommend viewing this slideshow in full-screen mode.

title: Welcome to Saudi Albany?
description: The people who run U.S. Steel have not had much reason to celebrate in a long time. Once the icon of American manufacturing, the company became shorthand for the countrys industrial decline. For decades, it ignored innovation and was undercut by cheaper Asian producers and outflanked by U.S. start-ups. Its brief glory in the mid-2000s turned out to be fueled by housing-bubble excess; and its stock price has dropped nearly 90 percent since late 2008. A few months ago, John P. Surma, the companys chairman and C.E.O., addressed a Steel Hall of Fame event at which all the inductees were either long dead or retired. He noted that, given the business climate, his own generation of steel C.E.O.s might have trouble getting the big prize themselves.

title: How Stressed Are You?
description: Anxiety is a fact of life. Ive yet to meet anyone, no matter how upbeat, who has escaped anxious moments, days, even weeks, writes the Times health columnist Jane Brody.

title: Mandela Is Hospitalized With a Lung Infection
description: JOHANNESBURG  Former President Nelson Mandela, who has been hospitalized since Saturday, has had a recurrence of a lung infection and is responding to treatment, the office of South Africas current president, Jacob Zuma, announced Tuesday.

title: Malis Prime Minister Resigns After Arrest, Muddling Plans to Retake North
description: BAMAKO, Mali  Soldiers carried out a late-night arrest of Malis prime minister at his home here, forcing his resignation early Tuesday and casting new doubt on plans to chase out radical Islamists who control much of this troubled West African nation.

title: Dear Rafiki, You Are Not Your SAT Score
description: Most people would agree that numbers are a measure of value; this is true in regard to assets and investments. But do the same rules apply to human beings?

title: Oxymorons of Sustainable Overfishing
description: GENERAL SANTOS, Philippines  Fishtocrats from three dozen nations just met in Manila to protect imperiled Pacific tuna, but they barely budged the status quo. So I flew down to Mindanao to hobnob with fishermen. It looks as if we had best develop a taste for tofu tartar and seaweed sushi.

title: The Real Long-Term Budget Challenge
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: The Early Word: Michigan
description: Todays Times

title: Defensive Player of the Year? See the Class of 2011
description: Chase Stuart writes about the historical and statistical side of football at his site, FootballPerspective.com

title: A New Ad Agency for Lincoln
description: Physically, the new Hudson Rouge advertising agency resides in a hip Manhattan neighborhood a short crosstown ride from one of its namesake rivers. Spiritually, Hudson Rouge hugs the River Rouge and the Ford plant near Detroit; thoroughly appropriate for an agency charged with reinventing the Lincoln automobile brand.

title: Mr. Adams and His Save the World Club
description: In 2005, I visited the main public library in my hometown of Quincy, Mass., south of Boston. I was there to speak about my new novel for middle school students. After my presentation, a man approached the podium trailed by a half dozen boys and girls. He said he was Ron Adams and that he taught 100 extraordinary students at Broad Meadows Middle School.

title: North Korea Plans Rocket Launch
description: Technical issues have delayed a rocket launch in North Korea, the country said, but it still plans to launch by the end of Dec.

title: Brandon Jacobs, Stuck in San Francisco
Is It Really This Hard to Buy a Phone System?
description: Our loan-brokerage business is almost three years old. Weve been running our phone system in the cloud on a service called Onebox that makes us look and feel like a big company. A recorded voice answers our calls and then tracks us down on our cellphones, wherever we may be.

title: Treasury Earns $7.6 Billion From Sale of Last Shares in A.I.G.
description: The Treasury Department said on Tuesday that it had sold its remaining stake in the American International Group, earning about $7.6 billion from the sale.

title: Spectra Energy to Buy Pipeline Network for $1.25 Billion
description: The Spectra Energy Corporation agreed on Tuesday to buy an oil pipeline network for $1.25 billion, the latest in a flurry of acquisitions as companies position themselves to profit from the energy sector.

title: Declared Loser Proposes New Election Within French Party
description: PARIS  Three weeks into an impasse over who won a leadership vote in Frances center-right opposition party, Franois Fillon  who was declared the loser, though he has refused to concede  proposed on Tuesday that a new election be held next spring in which he most likely would not run.

title: Newspapers Can Argue to Open Records in Fracking Suit
description: Advocates for greater openness for Pennsylvanias natural gas industry are heartened by a state appeals courts decision to allow two newspapers to press for the unsealing of records in a lawsuit brought against the industry by a western Pennsylvania couple.

title: In Performance: Shuler Hensley of The Whale
description: This week well be featuring two videos as part of In Performance, our new theater series in which actors perform excerpts from their new shows.

title: Tangled in Punctuation
description: As weve noted before, dashes and colons can cause problems if used carelessly. And a profusion of such punctuation may suggest that a sentence is overstuffed or undercooked.

title: Opinion Report: Right to Work Laws
description: From the editorial page

title: Rhino Horn as Club Drug and Other Tales from Safari Talk
description: [Dec. 12 12:24 p.m. | News note | Immense Cache of Smuggled Ivory Is Seized in Malaysia. More from Traffic.org.]

title: The Importance of Being Finished
description: BEIJING  How does one eat a banana gracefully? With a knife and fork, slicing it into thin slivers  of course! At least that is what we are told during a three-hour etiquette training course held in one of Beijings priciest hotels.

title: Tuesday Reading: Youth Obesity Falls in Several Cities
Daily Report: Apps for Children Fall Short on Disclosure to Parents, Report Says
description: Natasha Singer reports in The New York Times about a new federal report that says hundreds of the most popular educational and game mobile apps for children fail to give parents basic explanations about what kinds of personal information the apps collect from children, who can see that data and what they use it for.

title: To Add Flights to Heathrow, Delta Buys 49% Stake in Virgin Atlantic
description: 7:39 p.m. | Updated

title: At Barclays Center, No Bottle Caps for You
description: Dear Diary:

title: Activists Conviction Upheld in Test of Pledges by Bahrain
description: CAIRO  A court in Bahrain on Tuesday mainly upheld the conviction and prison sentence of a prominent human rights activist in a case that exposed the government to international criticism and was seen as a crucial test of the monarchys repeated pledges to allow greater political freedom.

title: Cabinet Diversity Poses a Question for Obama
description: It has been 15 years since a white man served as secretary of state or secretary of labor.

title: You Did It, A.I.G. Chief Tells Workers
description: Since signing on as chief executive of the American International Group, Robert H. Benmosche has made one goal clear: repaying American taxpayers in full for bailing out the insurer during the depths of the financial crisis.

title: The Giving Spree | Tom Delavan
description: Who: The designer and creative director of Gilt Home Tom Delavan, whose Greenwich Village home was featured in Ts spring design issue.

title: A Pocket Guide to Lobbying in the United States
description: That Wal-Mart Stores spent $25 million on lobbying in the United States over the past four years on such issues as whether India would open its own retail markets to the global behemoth should surprise no one, much less shut down Indias parliament, as it did Tuesday.

title: Indian Firms No Strangers to Lobbying in the United States
description: Who has taken the money? one parliamentarian shouted.

title: Restaurant Inspections Pushed Back Again in Neighborhoods Affected by Sandy
description: The New York City Department of Health will not send out restaurant inspectors to perform letter-grade inspections in city neighborhoods affected by Hurricane Sandy until Jan. 2, according to the department, pushing back their schedules once again.

title: Human Versus Physical Capital
description: One more entry in the robots and all that discussion, just to stress how much recent trends require a new storyline.

title: After Petraeus and Broadwell, Considering the Ethics of Biographies
description: Lets start with an eminently reasonable suggestion from the ethicists: Preferred behavior for biographers does not include sleeping with the people they write about. So much for that business between David H. Petraeus and his chronicler, Paula Broadwell.

title: Bleeding Europe
description: Europe has surprised me with its political resilience  the willingness of debtor nations to endure seemingly endless pain, the ability of the ECB to do just enough, at the very last minute, to calm markets when the financial situation seems ready to explode. But the economics of austerity have played out exactly according to script  the Keynesian script, that is, not the austerian script. Again and again, responsible technocrats induce their nations to accept the bitter austerity medicine; again and again, they fail to deliver results. The latest case in point is Italy, where Mario Monti  a good guy, deeply sincere  is leaving early, ultimately because his policies are delivering Italy into depression. (And yes, for the record, this means that Italy wont get the full Monti.)

title: Coming Back: A Good Foundation
description: Mike Pedano, a contractor, was two weeks from finishing his familys vacation home in Ortley Beach, N.J.,  when Hurricane Sandy hit.

title: Coming Back: Ortley Beach
description: Residents of the town, which is still vacated, are waiting for the demolition and assessments that will allow them to rebuild in earnest.

title: In Shore Community, Small Steps Toward Renewal
description: ORTLEY BEACH, N.J.  Gone is the smell of gas from fractured pipes that hung eerily in the air when rescue workers first arrived. But what you see now is not much better  the buildings knocked down or ripped open like stage sets, the endless mounds of junked refrigerators, soaked insulation and shattered glass.

title: Prime Ministers Ousting Complicates Strategy to Curb Malis Islamists
description: LONDON  Slow-moving international efforts to confront an Islamist takeover of northern Mali, described at the United Nations this week as one of the potentially most explosive corners of the world, just got more complicated.

title: In Kuwait, Panetta Affirms U.S. Commitment to Middle East
description: KUWAIT  Despite Washingtons renewed focus on the Asia-Pacific region, the United States remains fully committed to deterring security threats in the Persian Gulf and across the Middle East, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said as he began an official visit Tuesday to Kuwait.

title: Limits on Unions Pass in Michigan, Once a Mainstay
description: LANSING, Mich.  With Democrats and labor leaders vowing retribution at the ballot box and beyond, the Republican-dominated Michigan Legislature on Tuesday approved sweeping, statewide changes to the way unions will be financed, substantially reducing their power in a state that has long been a symbol of union might and an incubator for the American labor movement.

title: Religious Monument Gets a Sidekick: Bill of Rights
description: PHOENIX  It started as a joke about 10 years ago. Chris Bliss, a juggler and stand-up comedian of Internet fame,  had been scanning the headlines for inspiration and discovered the controversy over a granite monument to the Ten Commandments in the rotunda of Alabamas state judicial building.

title: On Our Radar: A Python Hunting Contest
description: Florida plans to open a Burmese python hunting contest next month to slow the spread of the snake, an invasive nonnative species. The state Fish and Wildlife Commission will award $1,500 to the hunter who harvests the most pythons and $1,000 to the hunter who catches the longest one. The snakes are thought to have been released into the wild by people who bought them as exotic pets; the biggest captured so far in Florida was 17 feet long. [The Jacksonville Oserver]

title: HSBC in Record Settlement
description: HSBC has agreed to pay $1.92 billion to settle accusations that it laundered billions of dollars. But state and federal authorities decided not to indict the bank over concerns that criminal charges could jeopardize one of the worlds largest banks and ultimately destabilize the global financial system, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report in DealBook.

title: Should a Gay Uncle Boycott His Straight Nieces Wedding?
description: Every other Tuesday,  Steven Petrow, the author of Steven Petrows Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners, (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience.  Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

title: For Best Score, a Long Shortlist
description: The Academy released the list of the 104 films whose scores are eligible to be Oscar-nominated, and right at the top is the movie you went to see for its jaunty tunes: Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter.

title: In Euro Zone, Challenging London as the Continents Financial Capital
description: LONDON  For two centuries, London has reigned as the financial capital of Europe. Now, that supremacy is being challenged by European politicians who question why so much business and trading in the euro is done in a country that does not even use the currency.

title: What Were Reading
description: United Press International: Orange food rules: new research on foods that contain carotenoids  in such fruits and vegetables as carrots, mangoes, apricots, squash, papaya and sweet potatoes  shows that women with the highest level of carotenoids in their blood have the lowest risk of breast cancer.  Glenn Collins

title: Federal Regulators Stay on the Full-Court Press
description: It has become the era of the star prosecutor in white-collar crime.

title: For Chinas Great Renewal, 8 Trends to Keep an Eye On
description: BEIJING  The Bo Xilai scandal, an economic downturn and the leadership switch from Hu Jintao to Xi Jinping made 2012 one of Chinas most eventful years. It is hard to imagine that next year will be as exciting, but there will be change.

title: After Storm Work, a Nights Rest on Water
description: Andrew Baas, 32, a federal employee sent to New York as part of a recovery team, told the folks back home in Everett, Pa., that he was helping Hurricane Sandy victims in south Brooklyn and sleeping on a ship docked at the base of a bridge in the Bronx.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Dec. 11, 2012
description: Its been nothing but bad news for 30 years, so the fact that we have any good news is a big story.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Whats Tracked in Apps for Children, and America  What a Life!
description: A report from the Federal Trade Commission found that hundreds of the most popular educational and game mobile apps for children failed to inform parents about the information the apps gathered during use, Natasha Singer reports. That information can be used to track children as they use different apps and browse the Internet. The report did not disclose the names of the apps that were studied, because, in the words of Jessica Rich, an official at the commission, the point was to emphasize that parents could not navigate the system themselves, thinking if they avoid certain apps, they are home free. The commission is preparing stronger rules on parental notification.

title: Is There a Toy-Class Divide?
description: Are children whose parents shop primarily at big-box stores and mass-market retailers cut off from the toys most clearly designed to promote creativity and learning?

title: 3 Unorthodox Ways to Solve Europes Debt Crisis
description: In Europe, they dont like to talk about Plan Bs.

title: Why Hillary Clinton Would Be Strong in 2016 (Its Not Her Favorability Ratings)
description: Lets start by stating the obvious: Hillary Rodham Clinton would be a formidable presidential candidate in 2016.

title: Finding Big Start-Up Ideas, Even in Small Cities
description: Rick DeVos could not wait to leave Grand Rapids, Mich. After high school, he made a beeline to Pepperdine University near Los Angeles and spent a year studying in London, but eventually returned home to finish his degree at Calvin College. My family has deep roots in Grand Rapids, he said. I missed the grounding and humility of the Midwest.

title: An Architect of Wall Street Reform Prepares for Life After Politics
description: When a new Congress convenes next month, Wall Street will lose a longtime foe. Representative Barney Frank, the Massachusetts Democrat who helped lead a regulatory crackdown after the financial crisis, is retiring after more than 30 years on Capitol Hill.

title: Motorsports: New Racing Industry Trade Show Emerges Under SEMA Banner
description: The International Motorsports Industry Show, formed three years ago to provide hard-core racing companies a venue to exhibit their wares in racing-intense Indianapolis, celebrated not only a packed house last week at the Indiana Convention Center, but also a new ownership structure for the show.

title: Good News in Obesity Epidemic
description: TimesCast: Childhood obesity is seen as falling in some cities. | Edith Windsor revels in her day in court. | Why Silicon Valley is embracing the Stoics.

title: Will Northwestern Finally Win a Bowl Game?
description: EVANSTON, Ill.  Northwestern plays host to two infamous streaks and it would undoubtedly like to rid itself of both.

title: Pogues 12 Days of Gadgets: Pop Bluetooth Handset
description: Hark the herald angels sing  its the fourth day of Pogues 12 Days of Gadgets!

title: Swashbucklers Transformed, and Now Much Tamer
description: After the last year, one thing is clear about the worlds largest private equity firms: nothing is private about them anymore.

title: A Warning About That Guy Who Is Beating the Market
description: Carl Richards is a financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

title: Forecasting Wall Street With a Finger in the Wind
description: The consensus outlook on Wall Street is gloomy for the immediate future, with glimmers of optimism for the longer term. This forecast might have been borrowed from Al Sleet, the Hippy dippy weatherman created by George Carlin.

title: Bo Bice Is Broadway Bound in Pump Boys and Dinettes
description: The Broadway revival of Pump Boys and Dinettes will begin preview performances March 19 at Circle in the Square Theater, the producers announced on Tuesday, and the ensemble of six actors will include Bo Bice, who was runner-up to Carrie Underwood on the fourth season of American Idol.

title: A Regional Oddball, Resurrected for Chilliest of Days
description: DICKENSIAN trappings like wassail, flaming punch or mulled wine didnt figure at all in the Christmases of my Wisconsin childhood. But at some point during the day, the adults would all hoist a hot mug of Anglo-American nostalgia: a Tom and Jerry.

title: Holiday Nostalgia, Served Warm
description: I AM a Dutch-German-Hungarian-Polish-Russian-Jewish-American woman. Yet every December, I turn into a 19th-century British gentleman.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Imagine a New Party
description: To the Editor:

title: Image of the Day: Dec. 11
Hugh Jackman, All Muscles and Fake Teeth
description: 12:16 p.m. | Updated  Two sides to Hugh Jackman were on view recently:

title: Wallflowers of Silicon Valley Get Asked to Dance
description: SAN FRANCISCO  After years of being wallflowers at Silicon Valleys hottest tech conferences and Sean Parkers after-parties, enterprise technology firms are now part of the in crowd.

title: Melee at the Opera: Catcalls for Paris Mde
description: Audiences fed up with a radical directors take on an opera usually save their rage till the final curtain calls. Monday night at the Thtre des Champs-lyses, in the first of four performances of Cherubinis Mde, the audience couldnt wait and interrupted the performance. There are limits, it would seem, on just how far a director can go, and for many those limits were breached.

title: In New Brand of Philanthropy, Nonprofits Invest in For-Profits
description: When the W. K. Kellogg Foundation set aside $100 million in 2007 to invest in companies that could produce both social and financial benefits, it was considered revolutionary. Historically, major foundations had used mainly stocks, bonds, real estate and other traditional asset classes to build their endowments.

title: Thats Demi, Not Semi
description: EVER since her split with the much-younger Ashton Kutcher (and reports that she is distressed over his new relationship with Mila Kunis), Demi Moore has been keeping a relatively low profile. That all changed last week, with the actresss here-there-and-everywhere appearances at Art Basel Miami Beach. Whether it was hanging out with her rumored boy toy, the 26-year-old art dealer Vito Schnabel (who reportedly broke up with her by weeks end), or partying with Lenny Kravitz and Stacy Keibler, or bringing a stray kitten as her date to a Chanel-hosted dinner party, Ms. Moore provided plenty of material for anyone with access to Twitter.

title: Finalists Named for Kennedy Theater Prize
description: Two recent Off Broadway plays and two works produced at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival are among the five finalists for the new $100,000 theater award established to honor Senator Edward M. Kennedy and his interest in American history, the Columbia University Libraries announced on Tuesday. The winner of the annual prize, to be chosen by a jury of writers and academics, will be announced on Feb. 22, Mr. Kennedys birthday. The finalists are:

title: Using Technology, M.L.S. Looks South
description: Professional soccer players in Central and South America beware: M.L.S. is watching you.

title: Embattled German Steel Maker Reports a Huge Loss
description: FRANKFURT  The German steel maker ThyssenKrupp, battered by slow economic growth and a series of corruption scandals, reported the biggest loss in its history late Monday and confirmed that three top executives would leave the company.

title: Galina Vishnevskaya, Soprano and Dissident, Dies at 86
description: Galina Vishnevskaya, an electrifying soprano who endured repression and exile as one of the postwar Soviet Unions most prominent political dissidents, died on Tuesday in Moscow. She was 86.

title: Poverty and Perverse Incentives
description: My colleague Nick Kristof has earned some deserved praise from conservatives for using his Sunday column to reflect on the perverse incentives that welfare programs can sometimes create for their beneficiaries. Heres his arresting opening example:

title: Suspect in Midtown Shooting
description: New York City Police released this surveillance video showing the suspect in the Dec. 10, 2012 killing of Brandon Woodard, recorded 10 minutes before the crime.

title: Corcoran Gallery of Art Will Stay Put
description: After the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington alarmed fans of its spectacular Beaux-Arts home near the White House by announcing this summer that it was considering a relocation, the board said on Monday that its members had decided against a move. According to a news release, the board voted on Dec. 5 to now focus only on approaches that keep the museum in the building, including the possibility of a collaboration with another like-minded institution.

title: Reshaping the Future of Cocoa in Africa
description: Seventy percent of the worlds cocoa now comes from West Africa, where family-run farms have proliferated across the landscape in recent decades. Yet in a paradox, the spread of these nonnative cocoa trees often contributes to deforestation. Rather than planting cacao trees under a forest canopy that shades them, which is the traditional method in Latin America, farmers in Ivory Coast, Cameroon and Ghana often clear forest so they can plant more trees and achieve higher yields.

title: Not All Companies Would Welcome a Lower Tax Rate
description: Tax Assessment

title: Wall Street Titans Toast Philanthropy at UJA-Federation Dinner
description: The hedge fund manager Boaz Weinstein, who is worth millions today, harked back to his younger years when he recalled the consternation by his schools rabbi over his underachievement.

title: PBS Names Beth Hoppe as Programming Chief
description: PBS has a new head of programming.

title: Evidence of Torture by Egyptian Islamists
description: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports from Cairo, Islamist supporters of President Mohamed Morsi captured, detained and beat dozens of his political opponents last week, holding them for hours with their hands bound on the pavement outside the presidential palace while pressuring them to confess that they had accepted money to use violence in protests against him.

title: Butternut Squash and Sage Latkes
description: Winter squash and sage is one of my favorite flavor combinations. Make sure to squeeze as much juice out of the onion as you can before you add it to the other ingredients.

title: Tracing a Victims Path in Life to a Brazen Killing in Midtown
description: A single bullet. A nickel-plated gun. Two suspects, lying in wait in the light drizzle of a Monday afternoon in Midtown, stalking their victim for nearly 30 minutes.

title: Broadcast Critics Unveil Their Nominations, Starting With Lincoln
description: The Broadcast Film Critics Association, the group behind the Critics Choice awards, has narrowed its picks somewhat, offering a lengthy list of nominations today led by Lincoln, with 13. Here are the main categories:

title: Why Everyone Is So Certain About Hillary 2016
description: NEW YORK  The Hillary-in-2016 buzz has hit overdrive, and the political speculation game has gone viral. By ten oclock Monday, Id watched a variety of commentators on three cable news programs speculate, guess, opine and bet on the real and imaginary future of Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Water Pollution and the Farm Economy
description: As many people know, the astounding increase in agricultural output that marked the latter half of the 20th century came at a high environmental price. Agriculture is a major contributor to global warming, and runoff from farm fields helps pollute rivers and streams.

title: New York Areas Offer $10 Lift Tickets, for a Day
description: Ski resorts have in recent years been selling multiresort passes that promise so many potential slopes that their names alone (Epic, Mountain Collective, Yeti) get your adrenaline pumping. New York State ski areas havent come up with a catchy name yet but they do have a catchy promotion: $10 a lift ticket on Jan. 10.

title: Agency Under Scrutiny for Oversight of Highway Money
description: The Department of Transportations inspector general is investigating whether the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has been checking on whether $601 million it gave to states for highway safety has been properly used.

title: Red Cabbage, Carrot and Broccoli Stem Latkes With Caraway and Sesame
description: I love finding things to do with broccoli stems. I find that allowing the cabbage mixture to sit for 10 to 15 minutes before forming the latkes allows the cabbage to soften a bit, and the latkes hold together better.

title: Judge Keeps Curbs on Travel for Defendant in Martin Case
description: MIAMI  The judge in the Trayvon Martin murder case on Tuesday rejected a request that the defendant, George Zimmerman, be allowed to remove his monitoring device and travel around the state.

title: Contract Impasse Darkens Mood of Mets Dickey
description: Christmas melodies floated above the chatter of schoolchildren and filtered through a dining lounge at Citi Field, where the Mets on Tuesday morning hosted their annual holiday party. But there was talk of baseball business, too, providing some unexpected discordant notes.

title: Zosia Mamets Winter Plans: On Girls and Off Broadway
description: The actress Zosia Mamet will be playing two characters this winter who, apart from being lovelorn, could not be more different temperamentally. Just as she is returning to the HBO series Girls in January as the bubbly naf Shoshanna Shapiro, Ms. Mamet will also make her Off Broadway debut as the downbeat, enigmatic Leigh in Paul Downs Colaizzos Really Really, a drama about sexual politics and culture clashes among college students. The MCC Theater production will be staged by David Cromer, the Obie-winning director of the recent Off Broadway productions Our Town and Tribes.

title: Study Finds Weakness in Googles Android Security Service
description: 5:09 p.m. | Updated Adding comment from Google.

title: Messis Brilliance Transcends His Numbers
description: It was Pep Guardiola, the former manager of Barcelona, who once suggested that Lionel Messi should be observed instead of dissected. He is, after all, widely considered the worlds greatest soccer player, not a biology project.

title: Feeling For | Cole Haan and Fragment Designs LunarGrand Loafer
description: Cole Haans partnership with Nike last year, when the former incorporated the latters Lunarlon foam cushioning into the soles of its shoes, resulted in LunarGrand, a collection of sportier wingtips and chukka boots that Cole Haan then expanded upon in a collaboration with Fragment Designs Hiroshi Fujiwara. That partnerships pop-preppy shoes were an instant hit, achieving cult status among dandy-cool fashion folk  a pair of the spectator wingtips with neon pink soles are currently on eBay for almost four times their original retail price. Which is precisely why the latest shoe from this collaboration  a loafer with a white Lunarlon sole  is so exciting. We wanted to explore a modern yet authentic reimagination of this iconic style, says Gareth Lewis, Cole Haans mens footwear design director. Completing this new series, which will be available tomorrow, are two spectator-like wingtips in brown and white with a neon orange sole or black and white with black sole. Its a subtle but bold reinterpretation of a timeless classic, Lewis adds.

title: Kidd Finds a Home Beyond the Arc
description: When the Nets play the Knicks on Tuesday night, they will have their hands full keeping the Knicks from scoring. The Knicks have had the N.B.A.s second-best offense for most of the season, as measured by offensive efficiency.

title: Beauty Spots
description: In a glittering season, copper is the beauty industrys latest salvo against aging. The metal, best known for its presence in pennies, also has been mentioned in claims that it helps prevent collagen loss, for firmer and more radiant skin. But forget the pennies: the new products featuring it arent exactly cheap.

title: Deconstructing Dodd-Frank
description: Wall Street has found a common enemy: the Dodd-Frank Act. After the industrys aggressive risk-taking nearly toppled the financial system and the broader economy, Congress ushered in Dodd-Frank, the most significant regulatory overhaul since the Great Depression. Since the law was passed in 2010, banks and other financial institutions have sought to tone down the most onerous aspects of the law, fearful of the threat to their businesses and their bottom line.

title: Slow Gains in Justice for Afghan Women
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Women who are victims of violence in Afghanistan are often afraid to report abuses to government authorities and rarely see their cases taken to trial, though prosecutors regularly obtain convictions when cases do go forward, according to a report released Tuesday by the United Nations office here.

title: Plenty of Footage (and Headaches) on the Zero Dark Thirty Shoot
description: The Baggers pals over at Vulture have a lengthy examination of how Kathryn Bigelow and Mark Boal came to make Zero Dark Thirty, from Mr. Boals abandonment of his original script, which he spent two years on (about the failed hunt for Osama bin Laden in Tora Bora) to the tough working conditions on their six-month shoot in India and Jordan. Not that it put a dent in Ms. Bigelows directorial vision: she shot two million feet of footage. The average is probably half of that, Megan Ellison, a producer of the film, told the Bagger at a recent lunch at the 21 Club.

title: Shia LaBeouf to Star Opposite Alec Baldwin in Orphans on Broadway
description: Shia LaBeouf is better known for performing high intensity heroics (the Transformers movies, the last Indiana Jones picture) than limning cold fury, but his new career move will give him a chance to play a bad boy  a very bad boy.

title: Airlines Waive Change Fees Because of  Hurricane Sandy
description: We all grumble about airlines and their increasingly creative fees. But some airlines are doing something nice for families and teachers affected by Hurricane Sandy.

title: Russia to Close Radar Station in Azerbaijan
description: MOSCOW  The Russian government said Tuesday that it would shut down operations at a major radar station in Gabala, Azerbaijan, that can detect missile launchings throughout the Middle East, after failing to reach an agreement on a new lease with the Azeri government.

title: Tagliabue Lifts Suspensions but Not Blame in Bounty Case
description: Paul Tagliabue, in a surprising rebuke of his successor as N.F.L. commissioner, Roger Goodell, vacated the suspensions of four players involved in a bounty scandal that has roiled the New Orleans Saints for more than nine months.

title: Loopholes to Some, Lifelines to Others
description: If there is one idea that everybody seems to agree on while peering over the fiscal cliff, it is that we should close the loopholes that riddle the tax code. It is offered as a painless way to raise money, like fixing a leak or ending some unfair privilege.

title: Student Crossword | The Cold War
description: Play our crossword (PDF) to see what you know about the cold war. You can find the answers here.

title: Teaching the Cold War With The New York Times
description: What was the cold war? How did it shape history? How are we still seeing its echoes today?

title: Molding Himself to the Moment
description: If the Brill Building were still the songwriting hub it once was, Bruno Mars would be both guarding the entrance and occupying the penthouse suite. Not only is he probably the best pop-oriented traditionalist songwriter of the past five years, but hes also the one whos been most successful at preserving that practice in the mainstream. Others are more daring, their songs taking unanticipated left turns or staying in the high-minded conceptual clouds. But no one brings it home quite like Mr. Mars, a model of concision who always knows where the trigger is, and always, always pulls it.

title: Storm-Tested Menorah, Off to the White House
description: A 90-year-old menorah from a temple on Long Island that was ravaged by Hurricane Sandy will be displayed at a Hanukkah party hosted by President Obama as a symbol of perseverance and hope for the holidays.

title: The Fighting Irish Brigade
description: When the Civil War broke out, thousands of Irish-born men in both the North and the South volunteered for military service. Some 140,000 served in the Union Army, and they dominated at least 20 regiments. The most famous belonged to Thomas F. Meaghers Irish Brigade. Meagher (pronounced Mar) was an Irish native whom the British had banished to Tasmania after he became involved in Irelands 1848 uprising. After escaping from the island, he made his way to America, where he became a popular lecturer on Irish independence.

title: HSBC to Pay Record Fine to Settle Money-Laundering Charges
description: Federal and state authorities secured a record $1.92 billion payment from HSBC on Tuesday to settle charges that the banking giant transferred billions of dollars for nations under United States sanctions, enabled Mexican drug cartels to launder tainted money through the American financial system, and worked closely with Saudi Arabian banks linked to terrorist organizations.

title: The Latest on the Fiscal Negotiations
description: TimesCast Politics: For Obama and Boehner, 20 days left to make a deal. | Tim Kaine, Virginias next senator, lays out his agenda. | Looking ahead to an immigration overhaul.

title: Greece Buys Back Debt, Clearing Way for More Aid
description: LONDON  Debt-weary Greece, after a frantic two days of cajoling and arm-twisting, finally persuaded local banks and foreign investors to sell back to the government about 32 billion euros worth of discounted bonds, bankers close to the buyback program said on Tuesday.

title: Rush, Public Enemy and Heart to Join Rock Hall of Fame
description: Dec. 12 | Updated

title: You Dont Need to Tweet to Submit to the #mehlist
description: For the past few months, we at The One-Page Magazine have been asking readers to submit suggestions for the Meh List, a weekly roll call of things that are not hot, not not, just meh.So far, weve received some pretty inspired ideas via the hashtag#mehliston Twitter: drum solos, French pedicures, Toms of Maine. Possums.

title: When Looking at Job Numbers, Add In a Changing America
description: For decades, the American labor force grew at a rapid rate, helping to spur strong economic growth.

title: Hedge Funds Stride the Stage of World Affairs
description: Argentinas president, Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner, was re-elected with a huge margin last year, leaving her political opponents fractured and demoralized. But in recent months, she has found herself locked in battle with a determined adversary who may outmaneuver her.

title: Wall Street Is Bracing for the Dodd-Frank Rules to Kick In
description: Wall Street lobbyists, the influential power brokers railing against regulation, may soon pass the mantle to more unassuming colleagues: bank compliance officers.

title: Holly Hunter Withdraws From The Vandal Off Broadway
description: The Oscar winner Holly Hunter has withdrawn from the Flea Theaters production of the new play The Vandal, citing scheduling conflicts, and will be replaced by the admired theater actress Deirdre OConnell (Magic/Bird, In the Wake), the theater announced on Tuesday. No further details about Ms. Hunter were provided.

title: Fiscal Cliff and Global Troubles Create a Fog for Deal-Making
description: Wall Street has always been more concept than place. By the late 18th century, a couple of blocks in Lower Manhattan had already become synonymous with stock trading. Later, they became shorthand for the entire American financial system.

title: Europe Reaches Agreement on System for Patents
description: BRUSSELS  It took only four decades of wrangling.

title: Shopping Snapshots: Dec. 13
description: What Sophia Webster, the British accessory designer, wore; Charlotte Neuville, former fashion designer, now makes cakes; and Public School and Black Apple designers create Knicks gear.

title: Tim Kaine Joins the Senate
description: Times reporter Michael D. Shear sits down with Tim Kaine, the senator-elect from Virginia, to talk about his upcoming term.

title: Deb Perelman on Smitten Kitchen
description: Deb Perelman sits down with the reporter Leslie Kaufman to discuss how her popular food blog led to a best-selling cookbook.

title: Bookshelf | The White Review
description: Londons better-known literary publications tend to look after their own. Not unwisely, the London Review of Books et al repeatedly turn to a well-worn roster of credential-heavy big hitters for contributions  a default position that suits authors like Colm Tibn, Jenny Diski and John Lanchester but which leaves emerging talent somewhat out in the literary cold. Small titles with lofty ambitions to break the trend have come and gone in Britain, but The White Review, a sumptuous, cream-colored journal that mixes interviews, essays, fiction and artwork by up-and-coming writers and artists, might just contain the youthful wherewithal to stick it out.

title: Delusions of Wisdom
description: Both Jonathan Chait and Charles Pierce  have a field day with a Politico piece titled, without a hint of irony, Crafting a boom economy. In said piece they talk to various Very Serious People, and divine the insider consensus on What Must Be Done  which mainly seems to involve, naturally, cutting Social Security and Medicare while reducing corporate tax rates.

title: Small-Business Optimism Plunges
description: The Small Business Optimism Index is starting to look misnamed.

title: SCOTUSblog and SCOTUS
description: The website SCOTUSblog is applying, once again, for credentials to cover SCOTUS, the Supreme Court of the United States. Its already been turned down twice. But the Senate Press Gallery, which is in charge of such things, should relent this time around. At least, that is, if the site completes the transformation it started about seven years ago, from what was essentially a promotional website for a legal practice, to a fully independent journalistic venture.

title: America Today at the Met
description: An animated rendering of how Thomas Hart Bentons mural will appear when it is installed in 2015.

title: America Today
description: The 10-panel Thomas Hart Benton mural has been donated to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Thomas Hart Benton Masterwork Goes to Met
description: On New Years Day 1931, a new and radically different building opened amid the town houses of West 12th Street: Joseph Urbans International-Style New School for Social Research, with one room in particular as a star attraction.
