Thomas Hart Benton, the American realist painter, had lined the third-floor boardroom with nine panels of what would be a 10-panel mural, America Today, depicting a panoply of pre-Depression American types, from flappers to farmers, steel workers to stock market tycoons. Lloyd Goodrich, a prominent art historian, pronounced it a breakthrough that heralded a new approach to mural painting, of actually taking reality and making mural art directly out of it.

title: Detainee Was Held Longer for Rejecting Voluntary Iris Scan, Suit Claims
description: Updated, 6:26 p.m. | An Occupy Wall Street protester who said she had been held in custody by the police longer than was normal because she did not allow officers to photograph the irises of her eyes, filed a lawsuit on Tuesday, claiming her constitutional rights had been violated.

title: Penguin to Publish 2012 Campaign Book From Authors of Game Change
description: 5:14 p.m. | Updated Mark Halperin and John Heilemann, the political journalists behind the best seller Game Change, about the 2008 presidential campaign, will publish a book about the just-concluded election under the title Double Down: Game Change 2012, Penguin Press announced on Tuesday.

title: At a New Bar, Its Not Just the Drinks That Will Be on Ice
description: Global warming wont matter once you step into the Minus5 Ice Bar, coming this spring to the New York Hilton, 1335 Avenue of the Americas (54th Street).

title: Ed Cassidy, Drummer for the Experimental Group Spirit, Dies at 89
description: Way back when rock n roll was countercultural  before the members of the Rolling Stones were anywhere close to 50 years old, much less celebrating their 50th anniversary together  the genre tended to emphasize rather than bridge generational divides.

title: Excerpt: 'Bare'
description: Taylor Trensch and Jason Hite in a scene from the musical at New World Stages.

title: Solar Installations Surge on Lower Costs and Government Support
description: The number of solar installations grew strongly in the nations residential, commercial and utility sectors in the third quarter, largely as a result of falling costs, a federal investment tax credit and state programs that support renewable energies, the solar industrys main trade group reported on Tuesday.

title: Cuomo Names Commissioners to Tax-Reform Panel
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Tuesday named a former state comptroller, H. Carl McCall, and an investment banker, Peter J. Solomon, to lead a new panel charged with proposing reforms to the states tax code.

title: Cato: Rome's Last Citizen
description: An interview with Jimmy Soni and Rob Goodman, authors of a new book on Cato, the ancient Roman stoic.

title: Steven B. Tanger
description: Mr. Tanger, 63, is the president and chief executive of Tanger Factory Outlet Centers, a publicly traded real estate investment trust based in Greensboro, N.C.

title: The Spirit That Shook (or Stirred) the World
description: The best part of The Book of Gin, a new survey of the history of this most clever and lively of spirits, arrives at the very end, in an appendix.

title: Kazakh Border Guard Gets Life Term in Killings of Soldiers
description: MOSCOW  A military court in a remote city in eastern Kazakhstan sentenced a 20-year-old border guard to life in prison on Tuesday over the killings of 15 people, in a case that has drawn widespread skepticism of the authorities in the former Soviet state.

title: In Cairo, Effort to Broaden Support for Charter
description: CAIRO  President Mohamed Morsis advisers struggled Tuesday to work with a panel of politicians and intellectuals in an effort to work out last-minute proposals that might broaden support for an Islamist-backed draft constitution that is set to go before Egypts voters on Saturday, participants said.

title: Making Gin: Do It Yourself
description: A new kit allows you to make your own bathtub gin  without the bathtub or the moonshine. Start with good vodka, and use the kits juniper, mixed spices and botanicals to create a gin tinged with amber and perfumed with juniper and lavender; there are also spice, sandalwood and green cardamom notes in the flavor. That makes it better served on the rocks with a spritz of fresh lime or in a French 75 with Champagne than in a classic martini, which demands the clean, persistent whisper of juniper. The kit also contains two empty bottles, a fine-mesh strainer and a funnel. Its a fitting gift for an amateur mixologist.

title: How the Broadcast Critics Help Academy Voters
description: The wonky schedule for this years Oscar race means the nominations will be unveiled the same day as the Critics Choice awards are bestowed. If youre snubbed by the Academy in the morning, will you turn up to potentially be snubbed again at a televised award show that night? Seat fillers all over Los Angeles are hoping the answer is no.

title: From Their Goats to Your Caramels
description: There is nothing  I repeat, nothing  at all odd about goat milk caramels. After all, cajeta, the Mexican cousin to dulce de leche, is made from goat milk. And so in Townshend, Vt., Lucas Farrell and Louisa Conrad, who produce cave-aged goat cheese, have begun turning the rich milk from their herd into hand-wrapped caramels. The candies are simple and irresistible, with only a chai flavor and long caramel sticks straying from the theme.

title: A New Generation of Italian Cheeses
description: Renato Brancaleoni learned the craft of aging cheese from his father, who started in Italy in 1937, but he has taken the techniques in new directions. Mr. Brancaleoni (at right) is from Roncofreddo, in the Emilia-Romagna region. He buys young cheeses, often pecorino, and carefully ages them in caves or in huge terra cotta containers. But instead of sticking only to cheeses made nearby, as tradition dictates, he brings them in from elsewhere, often the high Dolomites. They may be coated with olive oil and ashes or wrapped in walnut leaves. Or he might enclose them in hay, chestnut leaves or even crushed blackberries or beeswax. Each of his cheeses has a different aroma, flavor and texture but offers a balance of richness and acidity. A new one, a majestic cylinder wrapped in hay, leaves and mushrooms and called Merlino, was an experiment that has made him very happy.

title: Royal Seafood Restaurant
description: Inside the Chinatown restaurant on Mott Street, where everybody is ordering lobster.

title: Kaine Says He Is Optimistic About Immigration Overhaul
description: Tim Kaine, Virginias newest senator, said he was eager to be a vote for immigration reform that would require those in the country to pay a fine in exchange for permanent legal status.

title: Gifts for the Frugal Traveler
description: Looking for budget-friendly items that make travel better? Here are nine ideas.

title: The Bean Curd of Desire
description: EVERYBODY was having lobster.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Egypt, Bahrain, Syria and the Philippines.

title: Ill-Fated Gay Love and Hormonal Tempests on a School Stage
description: Like a high school counselor with a bucket load of empathy but too few concrete solutions to problems, the director Stafford Arima appears to be specializing in taking troubled teen-angst musicals and trying to smooth out their kinks. Following his valiant bid this year to salvage Carrie from the junkyard of cult infamy, hes now taking a crack at Bare, a pop-rock chronicle of ill-fated gay love at a coed Roman Catholic boarding school.

title: Your Frugal Holiday Gift Ideas
Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: South Carolina Governor Closing In on Replacement for DeMint
description: Nikki Haley, the Republican governor of South Carolina, is narrowing her search to a handful of men and women  current lawmakers and political novices both  to fill the seat of Senator Jim DeMint, who announced last week that he would leave the Senate in January. Republican officials in South Carolina expect her to announce her pick within the next week.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Hurricane Sandy Relief

title: Scalias Domino Theory
description: At Princeton on Monday a freshman asked Antonin Scalia to explain his legal writings comparing sodomy bans with laws prohibiting bestiality and murder.

title: Noted Pairing Blends Into Duet
description: The George London Foundation Awards Competition has been a trustworthy talent scout over the years, having supported an impressive list of notable singers early in their careers. In addition to cash prizes, the foundation presents singers in recital, most notably in a series at the Morgan Library & Museum that pairs emerging and established artists.

title: Holiday Tops Lawson in Early Contract Returns
description: When Denver and Philadelphia met on opening night, the ink had barely dried on a pair of four-year, $40-plus million dollar extensions signed by the teams point guards, the Nuggets Ty Lawson and the 76ers Jrue Holiday.

title: The Dirty Work for the Clean
description: Like a bully who can spot his next victim, reality television has set its beady eyes on the Amish. High ratings for Breaking Amish on TLC  a show that brought young men and women to New York for a taste of bikinis, mechanical bulls and lap dances  have paved the way for Amish Mafia, beginning Wednesday on Discovery.

title: Gifting | One-Stop Online Shops
description: Theres nothing quite like walking into a shop with your holiday gift list and finding something for everyone (or at least several of the giftees on your list) in that one place. That is, if its not one of those stores going out of its way to make your buying experience as irritating as possible. This year, try browsing online boutiques that offer one-stop gratification, whether you want to cross each recipient off in a single visit or cover perhaps at least all the tweens or pet-lovers in your life in a few clicks. Here are some of Ts favorites, from the gift-centric to green-thumbed and more.

title: New Concerns Over Apps for Children
description: The developer behind Mobbles, a popular freegame app for children, temporarily pulled the product from the Apple App store and Google Play store on Tuesday after learning that it was the subject of a complaint to federal authorities by childrens advocates.

title: Microsoft Will Expand Distribution of Surface Tablet
description: Microsoft said Tuesday that it planned to expand sales of its Surface tablet beyond Microsoft-owned retail stores.

title: Proof of Citys Wholesomeness: New Yorkers Live Longer
description: New Yorkers continue to live longer than Americans as a whole by an increasingly wide margin, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Tuesday.

title: Low-Level Striver Reaching for Utopia
description: The real name of the title character in Robert Askinss play P. S. Jones and the Frozen City cannot be published here, but his job description should clue you in: P. S. spends his days shoveling pig manure in the postapocalyptic landscape of this comic-book-inspired comedy. (Or is the more aesthetically correct term graphic-novel-inspired comedy?)

title: Health Centers Find Opportunity in Brownfields
description: PHILADELPHIA  The community health center rising on a derelict corner here in West Philadelphia never would have broken ground if not for the asbestos inside the building that was demolished to make way for it. Because of the contamination, Spectrum Health Services received a $2 million federal cleanup grant, the first piece of a $14 million construction financing puzzle.

title: Men Add Juice to Sugar Plums
description: Only a few productions of The Nutcracker feature a character called the Snow Boy (or sometimes the Snow Prince). Usually his function is to add a powerful dash of virtuosity to the snow scene that ends Act I; sometimes hes a junior member of a Snow royal family. But Ive always found the role trite  until Saturday afternoon, when Dances Patrelle performed The Yorkville Nutcracker, and a 15-year-old dancer named Alexandros Pappajohn suddenly flooded the stage with style, charm and fantasy.

title: Back Where the Music, and a Band, Grew Up
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.  The victory of the three musicians in Yo La Tengo  Ira Kaplan, James McNew and Georgia Hubley  has been in part the victory of their broad enthusiasms. With rock n roll from the mid-1960s to the mid-80s, theyre ninjas of secondary-source material; though theyre not always covering songs outright, theyre building something greater than the sum of their references.

title: Marquez Headed to Len, Report Says
description: If reports in the Mexican news media are to believed, the Red Bulls long nightmare  ah, make that the Red Bulls fans long nightmare  is close to an end.

title: If You Like Otis Redding. . .
Childhood Obesity Rates Falling
description: The Times's Sabrina Tavernise discusses how childhood obesity rates have fallen in some American cities.

title: Don Imus Signs a 3-Year Extension for His Radio Show
description: On his syndicated radio show, Imus in the Morning, the 72-year-old Don Imus sometimes talks about retiring to his ranch in New Mexico. And maybe he will someday, but not for at least three years.

title: A Show Giveth, a Show Taketh
description: You can tell a lot about a society from its game shows, and by that standard, boy, have we traveled a dismaying arc in the last three months. We have gone from rewarding contestants for knowing their Bible to rewarding them for knowing that a computerized stock-car-racing simulator is worth more than an 18-foot speedboat.

title: In Queens Mexican Communities, Mourning a Voice Gone Silent
description: It was only after her death in a plane crash that Jenni Rivera attracted significant attention in the English-language news media, introducing her to a broad audience that may have known little about her.

title: A Nutcracker Tour
description: Dances Patrelle and New York Theater Ballet are among the companies with Nutcracker productions this season.

title: Monserrate Gets 2 Years in Prison for Misusing City Funds
description: Hiram Monserrate, a former New York City councilman and state senator who acknowledged misusing about $100,000 in city money to help pay for one of his Senate campaigns, was sentenced on Tuesday to two years in prison.

title: Obama Says U.S. Will Recognize Syrian Rebels
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Tuesday that the United States would formally recognize a coalition of Syrian opposition groups as that countrys legitimate representative, intensifying the pressure on President Bashar al-Assad to give up his bloody struggle to stay in power.

title: Bausch & Lomb Said to Hire Goldman to Explore a Sale
description: Bausch & Lomb, the eye care products maker, has hired Goldman Sachs to explore a sale of the company, a person briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

title: U.S. Will Grant Recognition to Syrian Rebels, Obama Says
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Tuesday that the United States would formally recognize a coalition of Syrian opposition groups as that countrys legitimate representative, in an attempt to intensify the pressure on President Bashar al-Assad to give up his nearly two-year bloody struggle to stay in power.

title: Teenager Charged in Opossums Beating Death
description: An 18-year-old was arrested in connection with a fatal attack on an opossum in a park in Queens, the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals announced on Tuesday.

title: Union Members Protest at Vote on Michigan Labor Law
description: Thousands of union protesters from around the country  descended  on Michigans Capitol building on Tuesday to voice opposition to legislation limiting the power of organized labor to raise dues and gain members.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Big Brother Buses and a Facebook Mystery
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Bones in the Woods, Family Secrets in the Heart
description: Consuming Spirits, an animated feature by Chris Sullivan, is a defiant  or maybe, even better, an oblivious  exception to the rules and patterns of contemporary cartoon entertainment. At a time when animation is expected to be computer-generated, three-dimensional and relentlessly upbeat, Mr. Sullivans film is flat, handmade and melancholy, a dark and painful fantasy for grown-ups.

title: Rather Than Recasting, Evita Will Close on Jan. 26
description: The Broadway revival of Evita will close on Jan. 26 with the departure of Ricky Martin and his two co-stars, the producers announced on Tuesday, reversing their plans to re-cast the musical and continue running. Whether the producers will be able to earn back their investors money with such a short run  10-and-a-half months of performances when Evita closes  remains to be seen.

title: In Netflix Case, a Chance to Re-examine Old Rules
description: Netflix is in the Securities and Exchange Commissions sights over a post on Facebook by Reed Hastings, its chief executive, saying that the video streaming companys monthly viewing had reached a billion hours. Yet, the case is more convincing as an illustration of how the regulator clings to outdated notions of how markets work.

title: Some Charges Dropped Against Masked Protesters
description: The Manhattan district attorneys office dismissed some charges Tuesday against three women who were arrested in August while wearing masks during a demonstration outside of the Russian Consulate on the Upper East Side.

title: Yankees Are Set to Add Youkilis, Symbol of Rivalry
description: In October 1996, horrified Red Sox fans recoiled at the sight of Wade Boggs riding a police horse around Yankee Stadium to celebrate a World Series championship, something he never did in Boston. Three years later, those fans were sickened to see Roger Clemens standing on the dugout roof spraying Champagne on Yankees fans to celebrate that years title.

title: Immense Cache of Smuggled Ivory Is Seized in Malaysia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Malaysian authorities said Tuesday that they had uncovered more than 1,000 smuggled elephant tusks hidden in secret compartments in two shipments of mahogany, a staggeringly large seizure that several conservationists said was the biggest in history.

title: American Tariffs, Bangladeshi Deaths
description: Berkeley, Calif.

title: Early Kickoff for Marketers at Super Bowl
description: ADVERTISERS got an early start this year on Christmas, as holiday ads began appearing in mid-October. The front-running is continuing, for another big advertising occasion: the Super Bowl.

title: New Thirst for Urban Living, and Few Detroit Rentals
description: Abandoned houses with overgrown yards may be the image most people associate with Detroit, but the citys downtown and midtown neighborhoods have the opposite problem: a shortage of rental apartments to meet a growing demand for an urban lifestyle.

title: Bill to Extend Deposit Insurance Program Moves Forward in the Senate
description: WASHINGTON  A bill extending a federal program guaranteeing deposits in noninterest-bearing accounts at federally insured banks easily cleared a procedural hurdle on Tuesday, setting it up for a vote on final passage later this week.

title: Co-op Laws in Cuba Are Seen as Progress
description: MEXICO CITY  The Cuban government authorized a wide range of co-ops on Tuesday, allowing workers to collectively open new businesses or take over existing state-run businesses in construction, transportation and other industries.

title: The 2,000-Year-Old Wonder Drug
description: Los Angeles

title: Mexican Team Seeks Marquez
description: Carlos Slim Hel, the richest man in the world, has his son working on a deal that will send Rafael Marquez from the Red Bulls to Len in the Mexican league. He would provide a lot of experience, leadership and quality in the team too, Slims son, Arturo Elias Ayub, told Periodico.am. Marquez, a Mexican international who joined the Red Bulls from Barcelona, has a year to go on his $4.6 million designated player contract. Since joining the Red Bulls in 2010, he has appeared in only 44 regular-season games as he dealt with injuries and assorted suspensions. More at nytimes.com/goal.

title: Pesticides: Now More Than  Ever
description: How quickly we forget.

title: Solo, Piano - N.Y.C.
description: A lone piano stands curbside in New York City, and a short documentary chronicles the interactions of passers-by as the piano awaits its fate.

title: Solo, Piano  N.Y.C.
description: Making this film was pure serendipity. After a January snowstorm in New York City, I decided to do some work on another film, in my home in Washington Heights. But as I approached my desk, I thought I heard a piano plinking. I looked out the window and saw a piano on the curb below. I was mesmerized by the pattern that emerged. Passers-by would slow, stop and play. Some played well. All day long they collected and dispersed, and into the night they measured, shoved and deliberated the pianos fate. (If it stayed on the sidewalk, the city could have issued a fine.) I was riveted. Pianos have histories. No one who stopped seemed eager to leave it behind. Their thoughts were obvious: Can we take it? Who abandons a piano? Is it worth anything?

title: Dysfunctional Business Model Puts the N.H.L. in Peril, Experts Say
description: During the last 20 years, the N.H.L. has lost nearly 10 percent of its scheduled games to labor disruptions, a rate of cancellation more than three times greater than any other major sports league in North America.

title: Chafin v. Chafin
description: An international treaty called The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction sets rules about where child custody disputes should be resolved when the parents are in different countries. The treaty puts a premium on swift resolution, but a speedy ruling by a trial court to let one parent take the child overseas without an opportunity for the other parent to appeal can mean a mistaken ruling stands unfairly.

title: For Vegas Weddings, a Date With a Built-In Reminder
description: LAS VEGAS  Wendy Wampach has been dating Rick Schroeder for about four years, but neither one can remember when their romance started. So when they decided a couple of months ago to get married, the date they chose was an obvious one: 12/12/12.

title: When a Winning Record Trumps a Checkered Past
description: At a restaurant near the campus of Western Kentucky University in Bowling Green, Eric Bain-Selbo sat down with a group of philosophy students on Monday. They talked about football.

title: North Koreans Launch Rocket in Defiant Act
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea launched a long-range rocket on Wednesday morning that appeared to reach as far as the Philippines, an apparent success for the countrys young and untested new leader, Kim Jong-un, and a step toward the nations goal of mastering the technology needed to build an intercontinental ballistic missile.

title: Too Big to Indict
description: It is a dark day for the rule of law. Federal and state authorities have chosen not to indict HSBC, the London-based bank, on charges of vast and prolonged money laundering, for fear that criminal prosecution would topple the bank and, in the process, endanger the financial system. They also have not charged any top HSBC banker in the case, though it boggles the mind that a bank could launder money as HSBC did without anyone in a position of authority making culpable decisions.

title: Detroit Narrowly Approves Vast  Land Sale
description: In a 5-4 vote, the Detroit City Council on Tuesday approved a controversial land sale of more than 140 acres of land to an entrepreneur by a 5-4 vote.

title: Rate Inquiry Accelerates With Arrests In London
description: 9 p.m. | Updated

title: Can God Save Egypt?
description: Cairo

title: Chemical Thrown at Rabbi Who Aided Victims of Abuse
description: An outspoken advocate for child sexual abuse victims in the Satmar Hasidic community was injured by a chemical he believed to be bleach that was thrown in his face as he walked down the street in his Williamsburg, Brooklyn, neighborhood on Tuesday.

title: Privacy and the Apps You Download
Transgender Bias
description: To the Editor:

title: Trees and the Storm
description: To the Editor:

title: WikiLeaks Case Lawyer Chides Marine Jailers on Mannings Treatment
description: FORT MEADE, Md.  Supervisors at the Marines Quantico brig imprisoned Pfc. Bradley Manning, who is accused of leaking hundreds of thousands of secret government documents to WikiLeaks, in unduly harsh and restrictive conditions over nearly nine months for no legitimate nonpunitive reason, his lawyer argued on Tuesday at the conclusion of a pretrial hearing.

title: Appointment at Fredericksburg
description: When Gen. Ambrose Burnside took over the Army of the Potomac in November 1862, the Republicans had suffered major losses in the mid-term elections, and the pressure was on to strike the Confederacy hard and end the rebellion. But Burnside took over a command as divided as the Union itself: many soldiers, particularly in the lower ranks, were angry over the recent dismissal of their beloved but controversial leader, Gen. George B. McClellan, and had serious doubts about both Burnsides competence and the Norths shifting war aims.

title: Despite Dig on Twitter, Edwards Rejoins Jets
description: Braylon Edwards called the Jets front office idiots on Twitter last week. On Tuesday, Edwards and the Jets reunited.

title: Justice in Williamsburg
description: The sexual abuse conviction in a State Supreme Court in Brooklyn of a prominent member of the Satmar Hasidic community sends a strong and overdue message to Williamsburgs tightly knit ultra-Orthodox Jewish neighborhood, which has shielded such abusers from legal scrutiny.

title: Mr. Berlusconis Shameless Return
description: Silvio Berlusconis announcement last week that he plans to run for a fourth term as prime minister is lamentable news for Italian politics and its economic reforms. Though it may sound like a bad joke given his failures to reform or revive the economy and his sex scandals, Mr. Berlusconis return could do a lot of serious damage.

title: A Tale of Two Women
description: WASHINGTON

title: Alabama: Two Accused of Terror Plot
description: Two men from Mobile were charged on Tuesday with plotting a terrorist attack in West Africa. F.B.I. agents arrested the suspects, one at an airport and one at a bus terminal in Georgia, where they were beginning journeys to Mauritania. They were accused of planning to wage violent jihad there or in a neighboring country. The men, Mohammad Abdul Rahman Abukhdair and Randy Wilson, both 25 and American citizens, were charged with plotting to provide material support to terrorists. Prosecutors say Mr. Wilson is a close friend and former roommate of Omar Hammami, an Alabama native who was recently added to the F.B.I.s list of most-wanted terror suspects.

title: China Woos Overseas Companies, Looking for Deals
description: HONG KONG  Even as Wall Street deal makers await a revival of the moribund merger market, Chinese companies are shopping abroad with their wallets out.

title: SolarCity Is Said to Delay Its I.P.O.
description: SolarCity, a prominent solar power energy company, has delayed its initial public offering by at least a day as it struggles to price its stock sale, a person briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

title: Power of Unions Curbed in Michigan
description: The Michigan Legislature approved sweeping legislation on Tuesday that vastly reduces the power of organized labor.

title: Tour of Dioramas (Source: Jihad Museum)
description: The museum in Herat, Afghanistan is a temple to the mujahedeen heroes who battled the Soviets in the 1970s and 1980s, and a portrayal of a likely future.

title: Attorney General Seeks to Force Disclosure of More Political Donors
description: The New York attorney general announced a a far-reaching draft regulation on Wednesday that would force broad public disclosure of millions of dollars in loosely regulated spending on elections and ballot measures in New York.

title: Where War Still Echoes, Recalling Earlier Battles
description: HERAT, Afghanistan  For a country disfigured by decades of conflict, it seems fitting that Afghanistan should have a place set aside for reflecting on war.

title: Off the Wall
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  This month is the 50th anniversary of the release of LAWRENCE of Arabia, the 1962 film directed by DAVID LEAN and starring PETER OTOOLE.

title: In Brooklyn, Taking Pride in No. 42
description: History and sentimentality collided outside Barclays Center on Tuesday, but for Jerry Stackhouse, the moment was about more than a relocated flagpole or any imagined link between todays Brooklyn Nets and yesterdays Brooklyn Dodgers.

title: Court Rules Gang Crime Falls Short of Terrorism
description: New York States highest court on Tuesday ruled that the Bronx district attorneys office erred in trying to use a state terrorism charge to prosecute street gangs.

title: Lawyer Posits Justification in Fatal Push in Subway
description: A lawyer for the man charged with pushing a Queens man onto a subway track in front of an approaching Q train last week said Tuesday that his clients actions might have been justified because the man who died had been drinking and was harassing him.

title: Armenians Fleeing Anew as Syria Erupts in Battle
description: YEREVAN, Armenia  At the newly opened Cilician School in this former Soviet republic, the textbooks are in Arabic, photocopied from a single set flown out of war-torn Syria. The curriculum is Syrian, the flag on the principals desk is Syrian, and the teachers and students are all Syrians.

title: As Fiscal Talks Heat Up, Questions on Whether Boehner Can Get the Votes
description: WASHINGTON  With negotiations quickening on Tuesday to prevent a year-end fiscal crisis, White House officials once again are confronting a vexing question: Can Speaker John A. Boehner deliver enough Republican votes for whatever deficit-reduction plan he and President Obama might decide?

title: Officials Announce Pact on Jail in Louisiana
description: The Orleans Parish sheriff, United States Justice Department officials and lawyers from the Southern Poverty Law Center announced Tuesday that a wide-ranging agreement had been reached to overhaul the troubled Orleans Parish Prison, long criticized as a place of violence, sexual assault and abuse.

title: Unlikely Backers in a Battle Over Taxes
description: A broad swath of the nations leading chief executives dropped its opposition to tax increases on the wealthiest Americans on Tuesday, while the White House quietly pressed Wall Street titans for their support as well.

title: New Model for Albany Looks Familiar
description: Every so often, a politician from Long Island named Dean G. Skelos triumphantly declares the dawn of a new day in New York State politics, proclaiming that an Athenian moment has arrived. As it happens, these are times when Mr. Skelos, a Republican, has managed to inveigle state senators from the other side of the aisle to leave their party, shift the balance of power and make Mr. Skelos the boss of the State Senate.

title: Making Low-Income Housing a Priority
description: To the Editor:

title: Cayman Islands Premier Arrested in Corruption Investigation
description: MEXICO CITY  The premier of the Cayman Islands, the Caribbeans offshore financial center, was arrested Tuesday as part of a corruption investigation that might involve illegally imported explosives, the Royal Cayman Islands Police Service said.

title: Anthony Has 45, and Kidds 3-Pointer Wins It
description: Jason Kidd planted himself 26 feet from the basket and Jerry Stackhouse charged  two gray-bearded basketball veterans on a collision course, with a game hanging in the balance and 17,732 New Yorkers of various stripes screeching in various octaves.

title: For Lesser Crimes, Rethinking Life Behind Bars
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  Stephanie George and Judge Roger Vinson had quite different opinions about the lockbox seized by the police from her home in Pensacola. She insisted she had no idea that a former boyfriend had hidden it in her attic. Judge Vinson considered the lockbox, containing a half-kilogram of cocaine, to be evidence of her guilt.

title: That Crush at Kosovos Business Door? The Return of U.S. Heroes
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo  Prime Minister Hashim Thaci is in a bind. His countrys largest and most lucrative enterprise, the state telecommunications company, is up for sale. The jostling among buyers is intense. Narrowing the bidders has hardly helped.

title: Corrections: December 12, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: A Trash-Talking Rivalry Gaining History
description: Ethan Schorr and Barak Taub stood next to one another at Barclays Center as close friends, separated by allegiance. Schorr, 17, wore a black Nets cap and jersey. Taub, 21, was clad in a blue and orange Knicks T-shirt.

title: Drug Executive Faces Manslaughter Charges
description: A French court brought manslaughter and injury charges on Tuesday against a drug executive and six companies in a case involving a diabetes and weight-loss drug that caused cardiovascular damage, the Paris public prosecutors office said.

title: Lottery Numbers
Courting Merit Scholars Opens Door to Questions
description: NORMAN, Okla.  An introductory course here in American government offers the kind of intimate, interactive learning that scholars prize: just 20 students, most of them freshmen, debating the merits of the Senate filibuster one recent morning, and parrying pointed questions from a professor who knew their names.

title: Quinn Delays Hearing on Campaign Bill
description: Christine C. Quinn, the speaker of the City Council, has delayed action on a bill that would loosen regulations on spending by unions and advocacy groups in New York City elections, as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg denounced the measure as a terrible idea and really not good for democracy.

title: Sports Replay: Dec. 11
description: The day in sports, including a farewell victory for a Brazilian goalkeeper and the I.P.C. Disabled Alpine Skiing Nor-Am Cup.

title: Two Colleges Put on Notice By Commission Over Inquiries
description: An accrediting commission placed Florida A&M University on probation on Tuesday, 13 months after a marching band member died after a brutal hazing ritual.

title: Adults in Jail or Prison
description: Incarceration rates have more than tripled in the past 30 years.

title: G.O.P.s Full Control in Long-Moderate North Carolina May Leave Lasting Stamp
description: With a Republican newly elected as governor and a Republican-controlled legislature, North Carolina, long a politically moderate player in the South, will soon have its most conservative government in a century.

title: Reinhold Weege, Creator of Night Court, Dies at 62
description: Reinhold Weege, who created the hit NBC sitcom Night Court, which won a handful of Emmys by wringing humor from a Manhattan courtrooms night shift, died on Dec. 1 at his home in San Diego. He was 62.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Dec. 12, 2012
description: Mandatory sentences breed injustice.

title: Can This Man Defeat England?
description: After a pathetic performance in the last two tests against England, the Indian cricket team is pinning its hopes on the gifted Saurashtra all-rounder Ravindra Jadeja to even the four-match series, whose final test starts Thursday in Nagpur.

title: Why Afternoon May Be the Best Time to Exercise
description: Does exercise influence the bodys internal clock? Few of us may be conscious of it, but our bodies, and in turn our health, are ruled by rhythms. The heart, the liver, the brain  all are controlled by an endogenous circadian rhythm, says Christopher Colwell, a professor of psychiatry at the University of California, Los Angeless Brain Research Institute, who led a series of new experiments on how exercise affects the bodys internal clock. The studies were conducted in mice, but the findings suggest that exercise does affect our circadian rhythms, and the effect may be most beneficial if the exercise is undertaken midday.

title: British Plan for Gay Marriage Would Exclude Anglican Church
description: The governments plan to legalize same-sex marriages before a general election in 2015 took an unexpected turn on Tuesday with an announcement that the Church of England, Englands most populous faith, will be forbidden by the new law from marrying same-sex partners, while other religious groups that favor the change, including Quakers, Unitarians and liberal Jews, will be allowed to opt in to the practice. By specifically excluding Anglicans, the government of Prime Minister David Cameron appeared to have taken a major step back from a change that gay and lesbian groups have hailed as a watershed. Maria Miller, the culture minister, said the aim was to guarantee the Anglican churches that they could not be forced to hold same-sex marriages if litigants went to British and European courts demanding the rights that members of other faiths would enjoy. That possibility helped opponents of the change muster support from a substantial bloc of Conservative lawmakers.

title: Word of the Day | veer
description: veer \vir\ verb

title: Venezuela: Surgery on Chvez Is Successful, Government Says
description: President Hugo Chvez was recovering after undergoing cancer surgery in Cuba on Tuesday, Vice President Nicols Maduro said. Speaking on television, he said the operation was successful and lasted more than six hours. It has been a complex operation, he said. We have been through complex moments of tension, but fortunately our commanders gigantic humanity once again demonstrates its fortitude. He also addressed Mr. Chvez directly, saying: You have to come back. And we wait for you here, your children. Mr. Maduro did not characterize Mr. Chvezs condition. The operation was at least the third for Mr. Chvez since his illness was discovered in June 2011. He has refused to say what type of cancer he has or where in his body it occurred.

title: After a Partners Death, Still Focused on the Children
description: Hours after learning of the death of her childrens father, Simone McCray said, she called his cellphone, thinking he might answer.

title: 3 Dead, Including Gunman, in Shooting at Oregon Mall
description: A gunman opened fire in a shopping mall in suburban Portland, Ore., on Tuesday, killing at least two people and severely injuring another before killing himself. About 3:30 p.m., the police said they received calls about a shooting in progress at the Clackamas Town Center in Happy Valley.

title: Ravi Shankar, Sitarist Who Introduced Indian Music to the West, Dies at 92
description: Ravi Shankar, the sitar virtuoso and composer who died on Tuesday at 92, created a passion among Western audiences for the rhythmically vital, melodically flowing ragas of classical Indian music  a fascination that had expanded by the mid-1970s into a flourishing market for world music of all kinds.

title: Woman Is Killed Outside a Hospital
description: A 31-year-old woman was fatally shot outside a Brooklyn hospital on Tuesday after briefly leaving the bedside of her sick daughter, the police said.

title: Life Without Parole: Four Inmates Stories
description: Of the 140,000 prisoners serving life sentences in the United States, about 41,000 have no chance at parole, a result of laws that eliminated parole in the federal system and for many state prisoners. These rules, along with the mandatory sentences decreed for some crimes and some repeat offenders, were intended to make punishment both stricter and fairer, but judges complain that the rigid formulas too often result in injustice. Here are four prisoners sentenced to life without parole by judges who did not believe the punishment fit the crime.

title: Firm Is Accused of Monopolizing Double-Decker Bus Trade
description: The federal and New York State governments sued the joint venture that operates New York Citys popular hop-on, hop-off tour bus service on Tuesday, accusing it of being a monopoly and using its dominant position to overcharge customers.

title: West Bank: Israeli Military Raids 3 Palestinian Organizations
description: Israeli soldiers raided three Palestinian nongovernmental organizations in Ramallah before dawn on Tuesday, seizing computers and other equipment from two of them: Addameer, which supports Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails, and the Union of Palestinian Women Committees. The offices of the Palestinian NGO Network, an umbrella group that assists dozens of local organizations working in fields like health, agriculture and human rights, located in the same building as Addameer, were also ransacked. An Israeli military spokesman said the offices were searched because they were affiliated with the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a leftist militant group that Israel and others classify as a terrorist organization. A spokesman for Addameer strongly denied any such links.

title: Shooting Star Picks Right Time to Pass
description: With every basket he scored, baskets that pulled his team out from a 17-point deficit, Carmelo Anthony impressed everyone  his teammates, the divided capacity crowd and even the Nets  at Barclays Center.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 7:30 P.M. (AMC, Bio, Bloomberg, Cooking, Encore, Epix, Fuse, HBO, IFC, MSG, Showtime 2, VH1 Classic); 8 P.M. (G4, 13, 21, 50) 12.12.12 THE CONCERT FOR SANDY RELIEF Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band, Billy Joel, Eric Clapton, Kanye West, Jon Bon Jovi, Alicia Keys, Chris Martin, Paul McCartney, the Rolling Stones (with Mick Jagger, above), the Who, Roger Waters, Eddie Vedder and Dave Grohl perform at Madison Square Garden in support of victims of Hurricane Sandy. The event will also be shown in movie theaters, broadcast on radio and streamed online. For a list of channels, Web sites, radio stations and movie theaters, go to 121212concert.org.

title: Sitar Maestro Ravi Shankar Dies at 92
description: Ravi Shankar, the Indian sitarist and composer, died Tuesday in a hospital near his home in Southern California. He was 92.

title: News Quiz | December 12, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 12
description: NEWS North Korea launched a long-range rocket on Wednesday morning that appeared to reach as far as the Philippines, an apparent success for the countrys young and untested new leader, Kim Jong-un, and a step toward the nations goal of mastering the technology needed to build an intercontinental ballistic missile. Choe Sang-hun reports from Seoul, and David E. Sanger from Washington.

title: Fandango Tries an Oscar Gambit of Its Own
description: LOS ANGELES  Art and money. Boil down everything Oscar  the televised ceremony, the cocktail parties, the pundits  and thats what sits at the bottom of the pot. So why not just be open about it?

title: Outside India, Shankar Fascinated Generations of Fans
description: Ravi Shankars career was followed closely in the pages of The New York Times for more than 50 years. The classical Indian musician, who died on Tuesday at age 92, spent much of his adult life outside India, earning generations of fans in the United States and Europe, where he inspired musicians, sparked movements and won adulation.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Dec. 12, 2012
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the article New H.I.V. Cases Falling in Some Poor Nations, but Treatment Still Lags.

title: Parasites Control the Brains of Zombie Hosts
description: WHAT is the strange and ghoulish habit of Anelosimus octavius, a spider species that lives in Costa Rica?WHAT examples in this article about zombies in nature are most vivid and interesting to you?

title: After Rocket Launching, a Call for New Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON  The United States and its Asian allies began an effort on Wednesday to impose additional sanctions on North Korea after its largely successful rocket launching, but this time Washington added a warning to China: Failure to rein in Kim Jong-un, the Norths new leader, will result in an even greater American military presence in the Pacific.

title: Sugars Bittersweet Legacy
description: With the holidays upon us, the Great Sugar Rush is on: were gorging ourselves on sugar-dusted cookies, nibbling at peanut brittle and devouring plump chocolates oozing with caramel or raspberry liqueur.

title: The Gift of Reading
description: This is the year of the tablet, David Pogue of The Times has told us, and that may be good news for seniors who open holiday wrappings to find one tucked inside. They see better with tablets adjustable type size, new research shows. Reading becomes easier again.

title: Should Engineers Pay Less for College Than English Majors?
description: Should students majoring in engineering, science, health care or technology  all fields in demand in the job market  have to pay less for college than those majoring in history, philosophy, anthropology or English? The governor of Florida says he thinks so, at least at Floridas 12 state universities.

title: Syria Uses Scud Missiles in New Effort to Push Back Rebels
description: WASHINGTON  President Bashar al-Assads forces have resorted to firing ballistic missiles at rebel fighters inside Syria, Obama administration officials said Wednesday, escalating a nearly two-year-old civil war as the government struggles to slow the momentum of a gaining insurgency.

title: Ravi Shankars Death Mourned in India
description: Pandit Ravi Shankar, the sitar virtuoso and music composer, who died Tuesday in Southern California, leaves behind bereaved fans around the world, thanks to his role as the unofficial ambassador of Indian classical music. Back home in India, his death is being mourned as a national loss by national leaders and the fraternity of artists.

title: Panetta Visits Afghanistan to Discuss Troop Levels
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta made an unannounced visit to Afghanistan on Wednesday to meet with senior commanders and discuss proposals for future troop levels that he said would be presented for President Obamas consideration over the next few weeks.

title: 50 Years of Fascination With Ravi Shankar
description: Ravi Shankar, who died on Tuesday at age 92, spent much of his adult life outside India, earning generations of fans in the United States and Europe, where he inspired musicians, sparked movements and won adulation.

title: College Decision Beckoning to Be Unveiled? Please, Let It Wait Until You Get Home.
description: Marie Bigham is the director of college counseling at Greenhill School in Addison, Tex.

title: Honda Recalling 807,000 S.U.V.s and Minivans
description: Honda is recalling 807,000 utility vehicles and minivans because of a defect that could allow the vehicles to roll away, the automaker said in a news release.

title: The Early Word: Labor
description: Todays Times

title: New York Voters Open to Coalition Leadership of State Senate
description: About half of New York State voters would prefer that a coalition of Democrats and Republicans share control of the State Senate rather than one party, according to a new poll released Wednesday.

title: The Microeconomics of Poverty Since 2007
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: Rejecting Boycott, Egyptian Opposition Urges Vote Against Disputed Charter
description: CAIRO  Egyptians living abroad began casting ballots on Wednesday in a bitterly divisive referendum on an Islamist-backed draft constitution, the start of a vote that has become a test of the countrys nascent democracy.

title: China Reportedly Strips Shanghai Bishop of His Title
description: BEIJING  A Roman Catholic bishop who stunned congregants and Communist Party officials last July when he renounced his government position during his consecration has been stripped of his religious title, according to two Catholic Web sites that cited contacts in the Chinese church.

title: The Museum of Everything, an Alternative to the Art World You Know
description: PARISAfter traveling through Russia, setting up shop at Tate Modern in London and welcoming more than 350,000 visitors since its creation in 2009, the Museum of Everything is parked in Paris for the winter, at the end of a dark alleyway in St Germain des Prs in what used to be a catholic seminary.

title: Gay Marriage Fight Intensifies in Britain and France
description: LONDON  The pragmatic Dutch should be forgiven for wondering what all the fuss is about.

title: Taking On Cancer Again, This Time With the Wisdom of Age
description: After I finished eight months of treatment for testicular cancer in my mid-20s, my psychologist said, Well, that was like having five years of therapy all at once. What he meant was that you learn a lot about yourself in weekly talk sessions, but during a life-threatening illness, the issues come at you nonstop. I relished the slow unfolding of myself in the first, but I resented  no, hated  every step of the second. Nearly two decades later, when confronted with the same diagnosis, I finally understood the benefits of that earlier trial by fire, much as I did the wisdom of Ralph Waldo Emerson when he wrote, The years teach much which the days never knew.

title: A Win for Small Businesses in a Bank Fraud Case
description: In June, we published an article advising small-business owners to guard against hackers who use malicious software, or malware, to raid business bank accounts. Computer security specialists say these crimes, called corporate account takeovers, have become increasingly common, and small businesses are especially easy prey because many lack firewalls and monitoring systems.

title: Live Blog: DealBooks Post-Election Conference
description: 5:32 p.m. | Updated

title: Dear Friends: Pope Takes to Twitter, With an Assist
description: ROME  After struggling with the touch screen of an iPad, Pope Benedict XVI dispatched his first Twitter message on Wednesday. Dear friends, it read, I am pleased to get in touch with you through Twitter. Thank you for your generous response. I bless all of you from my heart.

title: Coffee Break
description: LONDON  A slim young man in a green wool jacket sipped from his tall red cup of coffee and watched the protest. He had just left the Starbucks opposite Londons Angel underground station, having squeezed past around 50 protesters accusing the coffee chain of tax evasion, hypocrisy and hating women.

title: Textile Makers in Taiwan Create a High-Tech Niche
description: TAIPEI  Jason Chen knows what it feels like for globalization to threaten his family business.

title: Most Pakistani Leaders Dont File Returns, Study Finds
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Fewer than a third of Parliament members in Pakistan file annual tax returns, according to a report published on Wednesday, lending new focus to longstanding complaints from foreign donors and ordinary Pakistanis about tax evasion at the highest levels of society.

title: On Our Radar: Onetime Japanese Ship Joins Effort Against Whaling
description: In what it calls as a coup, the conservation group Sea Shepherd says it has purchased a ship previously owned by the Japanese government, one of the groups biggest antagonists, and will deploy it for antiwhaling activity. The vessel  named the Sam Simon, after the founder of The Simpsons, a benefactor  will join three other ships that are to sail to the Southern Ocean this month to chase the Japanese whaling fleet. [The Guardian, Sea Shepherd]

title: Barclays Names Former British Regulator as Head of Compliance
description: LONDON  Barclays appointed Hector Sants, Britains former top financial regulator, as head of compliance on Wednesday, as part of an effort to repair the banks image after a rate-rigging scandal.

title: Secrets, Stories and Soul Baring
description: 1. TIM BERNE Snakeoil (ECM) A gorgeous, brooding statement from an alto saxophonist and composer of granite conviction, unveiling a deftly chamberlike quartet with Oscar Noriega on clarinets, Matt Mitchell on piano and Ches Smith on drums. Recorded with haunting clarity, this is an album that encourages full immersion while refusing to give up its secrets.

title: Rap or Rock or Folk-Jazz, Theyve Got Soul
description: 1. FRANK OCEAN Channel Orange (Def Jam) The moody introspection of a soul-ballad man fuses with the metaphor-making skills of a rapper in the sparse, aching songs that fill Frank Oceans official debut album. Even with some resemblances to Prince and R. Kelly, hes an unusual character for R&B: estranged but observant, admitting an attraction to a man, finding emptiness where others find material or emotional comfort. And in their sound as well as their lyrics, his songs create hollow spaces that they can only sometimes fill. As the tracks make eerie, restless dissolves between instruments and electronics, the songs melt down and recast themselves, again and again.

title: Asking Questions and Raising Stakes
description: 1. DAVID VIRELLES  This young Cuban pianists new album, Continuum (Pi Recordings), moves backward, forward and sideways through history. Intuitive and original, its equally of the American experimental jazz tradition, Afro-Cuban religious culture and modern nonjazz composition. Its got nerve and soul and memory.

title: Bright Colors, Grown-Up Concerns and Bruises
description: 1. EMELI SAND Our Version of Events (Capitol) Its mostly the voice: clarion clear and full of judiciously doled-out power. This British soul singers unerringly beautiful debut album is all bright colors and bold shapes, loud as a sunrise.

title: Moving Forward in Tough Times
description: Welcome to the second annual Fixes holiday season retrospective! Almost every week, over the past two years, weve covered a response to a social problem thats noteworthy, usually because its producing better than expected results. We highlight these positive deviants because 1) theyre under-reported; 2) they show society not just whats going wrong but how it might improve; and 3) theyre inherently interesting, like a good puzzle or whodunit. Because we get more leads than we can cover, we typically focus on initiatives that have a track record, evidence of effectiveness and potential for broader impact.

title: Wednesday Reading: Why Afternoon Exercise May Be Best
Cairo Court Sentences Man to 3 Years for Insulting Religion
description: CAIRO  A Cairo court sentenced an atheist from a Christian family on Wednesday to three years in prison for insulting religion, firing up fears about the future of freedom of expression here just as Egyptians prepare to vote on an Islamist-backed draft constitution denounced by secular groups as failing to protect such rights.

title: Opinion Report: Berlusconi Returns
description: From the editorial page

title: View From New Orleans on Tagliabues Saints Bounty Ruling
description: An opportunity here for readers to comment on the former commissioner Paul Tagliabues verdict on the Saints bounty appeal, in which he vacated player suspensions. But first a look at how the decision was covered in New Orleans:

title: In Bank Settlements, Fines but No Accountability
description: The global banking giant HSBC reached a settlement on Tuesday with the Justice Department and other federal agencies that requires the bank to pay about $1.9 billion and beef up its compliance measures.

title: Toyota to Repair 700,000 Lexus Trunk Releases, Consumer Reports Says
description: 11:20 a.m. | Updated Consumer Reports magazine says it expects Toyota in January to announce plans to repair about 700,000 Lexus automobiles because the emergency trunk release can break, trapping an occupant inside.

title: Saving a Life at the Stage Deli
description: Dear Diary:

title: Wall Streets Expanding Scope
description: With new regulations, weak growth and fiscal concerns, the financial industry increasingly finds itself at the center of the economic debate. DealBook reports on the changing face of Wall Street and the broader corporate community in our special section. Business Between Worlds looks at the various forces driving the discussion.

title: Another Asterisk for Asset Purchases
description: Federal Reserve officials have complained for years that the rest of the government is impeding the effectiveness of monetary policy. The Fed keeps making it cheaper to borrow, but the nations favorite kind of borrowing is the mortgage loan, and the mortgage market  well, lets just say its a little broken.

title: Daily Report: Wallflowers of Silicon Valley Get Asked to Dance
description: After years of being wallflowers at Silicon Valleys hottest tech conferences and Sean Parkers after-parties, enterprise technology firms are now part of the in crowd.

title: The Yes, Minister Theory of the Medicare Age
description: Aaron Carroll cant believe that were still talking about raising the age for Medicare eligibility; his disbelief is easy to understand. It is, after all, a truly terrible idea, for reasons he details in the linked post; it would inflict vast hardship on the most vulnerable, while saving the federal government remarkably little money, and would actually raise overall health spending, basically because private insurers have much higher administrative costs and much less bargaining power than Medicare, so shifting seniors out of the program ends up costing a lot of money.

title: People Watching | Carina Seth Andersson
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Screen Actors Guild Spreads Nominations Around
description: Les Misrables, Lincoln and Silver Linings Playbook shared in the bounty today at the Screen Actors Guild nominations, a key step on the path to awards season. Those films each received four nominations, with Argo, The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel, The Sessions and Skyfall getting two apiece.

title: Chicago Architect Wins $200,000 Prize From Notre Dame
description: Thomas H. Beeby, one of the Chicago Seven architects who challenged modernist orthodoxy in the 1970s and 80s, has received the 2013 Richard H. Driehaus Prize from the University of Notre Dame.

title: Series of Turning Points Limited Death Toll at Oregon Mall
description: CLACKAMAS, Ore.  Law enforcement officials here expressed a kind of bleak gratitude on Wednesday that a masked 22-year-old gunman armed with a semiautomatic rifle and extra magazines of ammunition did not kill or wound more people in an attack at a suburban mall filled with holiday shoppers on Tuesday afternoon.

title: What Were Reading
description: OC Weekly: Were getting close to the date of that Mayan prophecy about the end of the world, so maybe now is the right time to get acquainted with dishes like papadzules and tikin xic.  Jeff Gordinier

title: U.S. Ad Spending Rose in Quarter, Nielsen Reports
description: There was a relatively strong increase in advertising spending in the United States during the third quarter, according to data to be released on Wednesday morning by Nielsen.

title: OPEC Leaves Production Quotas in Place
description: Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries left their 30 million-barrel-per-day quota for oil production intact Wednesday, indicating the cartels satisfaction with current crude prices and its reluctance to do anything to further weaken the world economy.

title: Worth a Look
description: At itsbest, childrens picture book illustrationis an art form unto itself. It can give a dull story life, add oomph to the merely O.K. or elevate a good story onto the bookshelf of enduring classics. Sometimes, it simply carries the book on its own.

title: Chinese Court Sentences 3 Uighurs to Death
description: BEIJING  A Chinese court in the northwest region of Xinjiang has sentenced to death three men who were convicted of trying to blow up a commercial airliner in June in what the state media described as an act of religious-inspired extremism.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Tribune Looking for Buyers, and Imus Stays Put
description: The Tribune Company, owner of The Los Angeles Times and The Chicago Tribune, is looking for bankers to help sell some of its papers after it emerges from bankruptcy on Dec. 31, according to a Bloomberg News report. Rupert Murdoch has been reported to be interested at least in the Chicago and Los Angeles papers for his new publishing-focused News Corporation.

title: Facebook Changes Privacy Settings, Again
description: Stop me if youve heard this one before: Facebook is making changes to its privacy settings.

title: Calling All Kids: Submit Your Escaped Zebra Drawings
description: There is still time to send in your submissions for our latest Kids Draw the News assignment, Runaway Zebra (and Pony).

title: An Online Tool for Calculating Flood Risk
description: After Hurricane Sandy struck this fall, many home and business owners who had not previously gauged their flood risks turned to the government-run Web site FloodSmart. Run by the National Flood Insurance Program, which is overseen by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, FloodSmart offers users information about flooding, helps them estimate what their costs might amount to after a flood and points them to 88 agents that are accredited by the insurance program.

title: A Ritz Ups the Ante in Puerto Rico
description: TO reach Ritz-Carltons newest and most opulent resort, you drive through a forest of coconut palms, swamp bloodwoods and flame of the woods flowering shrubs until the road ends at a wall of water. Its a fountain of a sort, and behind its soft gurgle stretches Dorado Beach, a $342 million hotel built along three miles of toasty Caribbean sand. At the center of the resort, which opened Wednesday, guests will find a labyrinthine infinity pool with a bubble bed in its center, a four-bedroom villa that rents for $30,000 a night and a spa composed of 22 buildings that sprawl across five acres and includes treatment platforms built into treetops.

title: Hotel Review: Basecamp in South Lake Tahoe, Calif.
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Let My People Come to Bare Itself in New York Again
description: One of the most sexually explicit musicals ever to play Broadway, the flesh-flaunting Let My People Come, is being updated by composer Earl Wilson Jr., for a comeback this winter at the Underground, a bar and lounge on the Upper West Side, the shows producer said on Tuesday.

title: The Venerable Bridge Cafe Struggles to Reopen After Sandy
description: Even in the calculus of disaster, respect must be paid. If dozens of restaurants and bars have been devastated in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy, the Bridge Cafe at 279 Water Street in Manhattan is surely one of the most venerable to have been closed by the storm. It dates back to 1794, according to the Encyclopedia of New York City, and is believed to be the oldest continually operating drinking establishment in New York City.

title: BrightScope Lists Its Top 401(k) Plans
description: The financial research firm BrightScope on Tuesday released its annual list of the 30 top 401(k) plans and found that target-date funds are making inroads in highly rated plans.

title: Thursday Matchup: Bengals at Eagles
description: Bengals (7-6) at Eagles (4-9)

title: Cory Michael Smith to Star in Breakfast at Tiffanys
description: With two well-regarded performances Off Broadway this year, in The Whale and Cockfight Play, the young actor Cory Michael Smith has landed a new role on a much bigger stage. He will play Fred, the narrator and Southern writer in the Broadway production of Truman Capotes Breakfast at Tiffanys, which is to begin preview performances on March 4 at the Cort Theater and officially open on March 20.

title: A Big Year for Conservatives on Twitter, if Not at the Ballot Box
description: In 2012, the Tea Party had a banner year.

title: A Boost for Best Exotic Marigold and Other Surprises
description: The retired residents of The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel may soon be going back to work, on the awards circuit. The film, a sleeper hit for Fox Searchlight  its grossed $46 million domestically ($134 million worldwide) at the box office, on a production budget of about $10 million  nabbed a best-ensemble nomination from the Screen Actors Guild, displacing other projected favorites like Zero Dark Thirty and Django Unchained. (Django was finished so late that many guild members may not have had a chance to see it, and the nonunion stars of Beasts of the Southern Wild were not eligible for the awards.) Maggie Smith also grabbed a best-supporting-actress spot.

title: 17 Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of The Economists The World in 2013 Issue
description: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9KJSnd8VzQw

title: A Defiant Rocket Launch
description: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan explains his stance on unions. | Why President Obama recognized Syrian opposition groups. | North Korea appears to put a satellite into orbit.

title: Facebook Profile of Gunman in Oregon Shopping Mall Shooting
description: 6:05 p.m. | Updated  About 10,000 people were inside the Clackamas Town Center mall in suburban Portland, Ore., on Tuesday when a gunman, identified on Wednesday as 22-year-old Jacob Tyler Roberts, began shooting in the food court around 3:30 p.m.

title: Simple Tools Help Owners Sift Data for Eager Customers
description: Velvet Palate sells artisanal wines that are made in small quantities around the world and typically not stocked in stores. Selling online, said Kim Kooren, a co-founder, has allowed the company to zero in on a niche of geographically diverse customers.

title: Experimental Alzheimers Drug Will Get More Study at Eli Lilly
description: The drug maker Eli Lilly & Company said on Wednesday that it planned an additional study of an experimental Alzheimers drug that failed to improve the condition of people with the disease, saying that it remained hopeful about the drugs prospects.

title: How Are You Using Data Analysis to Improve Sales?
description: A small-business guide weve just published highlights a Web site, Velvet Palate, that sells artisanal wines that are made in small quantities around the world and typically not stocked in stores. Written by Julie Weed, the guide explains how Kim Kooren, co-founder of Velvet Palate, is employing sophisticated data collection and analysis to improve sales of those wines.

title: Clip: 'Magic Mike'
description: A performance of "It's Raining Men" in "Magic Mike."

title: Image of the Day: Dec. 12
Allure of the Backcountry
Finding Their Friends
Video: Marc Andreessen on the Triumph of Software
description: Marc Andreessen, a partner in the venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz and a co-founder of the first major Web browser, Netscape Navigator, discussed software, unions, the fiscal negotiations in Washington and the notion of a tech bubble with Andrew Ross Sorkin at DealBooks post-election conference.

title: Like Kate Middleton, Pregnant but Thin
description: So youre due, what  next week?Whoa  you having twins?

title: Time for National Voting Standards?
description: It should be obvious to anyone who paid attention on Nov. 6 that the election system is broken. Not just election financing but election mechanics: How Americans register to vote, and cast ballots. President Obama even saw fit to mention the inexcusably long lines in his acceptance speech.

title: In China, Fears Ours Would Be a One-Week Puppy
description: BEIJING  China has many genuine pet lovers who care well for their dogs, but also many owners who dont. The dog trade is virtually unsupervised and selling sick animals to unsuspecting customers is common. Animal shelters are full. The pet scene is tough. Buying a dog, which I write about in my latest Letter from China, can be a risky business.

title: Bilbo Baggins, by Way of the Meerkat
description: The Les Miz folks were preoccupied with the teeth of their singing cast, but on the New Zealand set of The Hobbit, it was feet that got the actors in character. Martin Freeman, who plays the diminutive Bilbo Baggins, wore prosthetic Hobbit feet as he moved around the Shire, which entirely changed his gait.

title: At the Paris Opera, a Carmen in Search of Catharsis
description: PARIS  Three years ago the mezzo-soprano Anna Caterina Antonacci scored a major success as Carmen at the Opra Comique here, so when the Paris Opra decided on a new production of Bizets opera at Opra Bastille, it was only natural for her to reprise the title role. Unfortunately, while in some respects Ms. Antonaccis portrayal is as arresting as ever, the new production by Yves Beaunesne fails to bring out the best in her or, indeed, to do much for the opera.

title: Rising Temperatures Threaten Fundamental Change for Ski Slopes
description: NEWBURY, N.H.  Helena Williams had a great day of skiing here at Mount Sunapee shortly after the resort opened at the end of November, but when she came back the next day, the temperatures had warmed and turned patches of the trails from white to brown.

title: Room for The Whale
description: Mimi Lien talks about her set design for the play The Whale, at Playwrights Horizons.

title: Former Bank of England Official Criticizes British Policies
description: LONDON  Adam S. Posen, the former Bank of England policy maker, is breaking his silence to criticize the British governments austerity plan, and he is not mincing words.

title: Happy Whatever-This-Is, From the Staff of City Room
Jinks Aplenty, More Low Than High, and Gleefully So
description: How do you hold an audience of the young and hip captive, let alone keep them laughing, wolf-whistling and hooting with delight through a three-and-a-half-hour evening fashioned from the dusty bones of 17th-century popular theater? Ed Sylvanus Iskanders raucous production of Amy Freeds anachronism-flaunting Restoration Comedy at the Flea Theater answers that question.

title: Michigan's Governor on Union Limits
description: In an interview, Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan talks about recently passed legislation in his state that changes the way unions will be financed, substantially reducing their power.

title: Top Deutsche Bank Executives Caught Up in Tax Evasion Inquiry
description: FRANKFURT  After a raid at Deutsche Banks headquarters, the company disclosed Wednesday that two of its highest-ranking executives were a focus of a tax evasion investigation, dealing a fresh blow to the German institutions already battered reputation.

title: Campus Divestment Fight Resonates in the East
description: For apartheid, it was universities in the West and Midwest that got the ball rolling. On the issue of Sudan and Darfur, the cause caught fire earliest at Ivy League schools. But for the latest college divestment movement, most of the action is unfolding at schools like Middlebury, the University of Vermont, Bowdoin, the University of New Hampshire, Tufts, Vassar and Swarthmore.

title: Fed Ties Rates to Joblessness, With Target of 6.5%
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve made it plain on Wednesday that job creation had become its primary focus, announcing that it planned to continue suppressing interest rates so long as the unemployment rate remained above 6.5 percent.

title: More Arrested Development Is On the Way
description: The television comedy Arrested Development will not have an arrested season. Deadline Hollywood reports that Netflix has allowed the shows creator, Mitch Hurwitz, to produce more than the originally scheduled 10 episodes. At this time, we are not confirming or announcing the final episode count but we are sure fans will be thrilled when we do, a Netflix spokeswoman said, according to Deadline Hollywood.

title: G.O.P. Balks at Plan to Add Airwaves for Mobile Internet and Wi-Fi
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans warned the Federal Communications Commission on Wednesday against giving away scarce airwaves that they said could produce up to $19 billion in proceeds if they were instead auctioned to telecommunications companies for use in mobile broadband networks.

title: Two Haunting Images, but Why Criticism for Only One?
description: Updated 3:06 p.m. | The two photos, taken a week apart, though hardly identical, have much in common: a man seconds away from sudden public death, the instrument of his demise closing in on him.

title: How The Times Covered 12-12-12. In 1912, That Is.
description: The last time the date rolled around, The Times was looking ahead.

title: North Korea Launches Rocket
description: The Times's David E. Sanger discusses Pyongyang's apparently successful attempt to put a satellite into orbit, the timing of which caught the United States by surprise.

title: Obama to Recognize Syrian Rebels
description: The Times's Michael R. Gordon on President Obama's announcement that the United States will formally recognize a coalition of Syrian opposition groups as the country's legitimate representatives.

title: Court Convicts a Bosnian Serb General of Genocide
description: PARIS  A former senior commander of the Bosnian Serb Army, Zdravko Tolimir, was convicted of genocide on Wednesday and sentenced to life in prison for his role in the killings of thousands of prisoners near the Bosnian town of Srebrenica in July 1995.

title: Airbnb Adds Experience As a Rental Filter Choice
description: Airbnb, which started as a vacation rental site, has sought to expand its mission with add-ons like meetups, activities meant to broaden its appeal to an audience just as interested in a curated travel experience as they are in bargain accommodations.

title: Political Predictions, Holiday Edition
description: Gail Collins: Happy holidays, David! I can tell were in the Christmas season because the tree sellers have returned from Quebec and set up shop on my corner. I always enjoy getting off the subway and walking through what seems to be a small forest populated by people speaking French and brandishing hatchets.

title: Claims of Looting Shadow Expert in Khmer Art
description: BANGKOK  For decades Douglas A. J. Latchford, an 81-year-old British art collector, has built a reputation as one of the worlds great experts in Khmer antiquities, one whose generous return of treasures to Cambodia garnered him knighthood there in 2008.

title: The Knicks Have a New Number: 3
description: The New York Knicks final, game-winning shot against the Brooklyn Nets Tuesday night was, appropriately, a Jason Kidd 3-pointer. The Knicks, who lead the Eastern Conference, are averaging 29.4 3-point shots per game, which puts them on pace to shoot more 3-pointers than any team in N.B.A. history.

title: Knicks-Lakers: Compare and Contrast
description: Carmelo Anthony of the Knicks had a season-high 45 points. Thirty-nine-year-old Jason Kidd hit the game-winning 3-pointer. The Nets had an early lead of 17 points, and led by 10 in the third quarter. The Knicks won, 100-97, evening the season series at a game apiece.

title: In Performance: Michael Learned
description: The actress in a scene from Bruce Grahams family drama The Outgoing Tide.

title: A Warm-and-Fuzzy Look That Leaves You Cold
description: YOU see them all the time lately, grown women who look as if they dressed for work and then walked out of the house and forgot their shoes. On the A train at 42nd Street, a woman in a business suit stood reading the business reports on her iPad, on her feet fur slippers as big as plates.

title: Why Not in My Backyard?
Deadline Nears for Free Holiday Shipping
description: If youre planning on shipping holiday gifts at no charge, its time to start paying attention  that is, if you want them to arrive before Christmas Day. Time is running out for free shipping.

title: In London, a Sanctum for Single Malts
description: Signature cocktails need to go. And no one seems to feel this sentiment as acutely as the whiskey aficionados and connoisseurs who belong to Londons new Soho Whisky Club. Besides its fabulous whiskey, the clubs finest quality is its semisecret location in a lofty annex above one of Londons oldest and finest single-malt retailers, the Vintage House on Old Compton Street. This downstairs shop carries over 1,800 pours and is the envy of single-malt collectors, offering hard-to-find tipples like a 70-year-old Mortlach (just $30,400). The attitude of the upstairs whiskey club seems to be along the lines of: Why read a description of our whiskies when you can have them in a glass? And for a $320 annual membership fee, members enjoy privacy, free monthly tastings and a choice from over 300 single malts, from the delightfully drinkable to the rare reserves. Among the special 2012 bottles the club currently recommends are the Port Ellen 32 year old ($956), a peppery pour with an almost muddy coal finish, and Auchroisk 30 year ($367), which tastes of banana, charred fruitcake and orange peel.

title: Homes for $2.9 Million
description: Properties in Ballard, Calif., Golden, Colo., and Chicago.

title: What You Get for ... $2.9 Million
description: BALLARD, CALIF.

title: How Boulder Grew Into a Hub for Start-Ups
description: After selling his Boston start-up in 1995, Brad Feld, then 29, moved to Colorado with his wife, Amy.

title: Below the Line: Designing the Costumes for Magic Mike
description: This summer, when Christopher Peterson would meet people and tell them he designed the costumes for Steven Soderberghs stripper drama Magic Mike, he would often hear the same question: What costumes were there?

title: A Three-Bedroom House in an Old Sugar Mill on Nevis
description: Vervain Mill, converted in 1980 and renovated in the 1990s, is on the market for $1.95 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Nevis
description: A THREE-BEDROOM HOME IN A CONVERTED SUGAR MILL ON NEVIS

title: Book Titles With That Indie-Rock Feel
description: When Douglas Coupland, born in 1961, called a novel Girlfriend in a Coma, after the song by the Smiths, it made perfect generational sense. The song was released when Mr. Coupland was 25. But certain bands  the Smiths, R.E.M., the Cure  continue to hold a special place for bookish listeners of new generations, and to influence writers looking for titles.

title: The Hottest Tickets of the Year
description: WHOS AFRAID OF VIRGINIA WOOLF? Half a century after it exploded onto the American cultural scene, Edward Albees biting examination of marriage as a grueling emotional battleground was revitalized yet again, making for the years best show on Broadway. The Steppenwolf Theater production, directed by Pam MacKinnon, stars a revelatory Tracy Letts as the most commanding George Ive seen, and Amy Morton as the most woundingly human Martha. Fight the fight for good theater on Broadway by making a visit to Virginia Woolf a priority. Trust me, youve never seen it like this before.

title: Charles Isherwoods Best of 2012
description: Photos of The Piano Lesson, Detroit and other shows.
