description: GAZA CITY  Hamas has been riding high of late, after its professed victory in the recent conflict with Israel and the overthrow last year of Egypts president, Hosni Mubarak, an avowed enemy.

title: Controversial Group Plans More Ads in Subway Stations
description: The group behind a recent spate of inflammatory advertisements throughout the transit system said this week that it planned to make its biggest purchase yet: the space beside each of the roughly 220 clocks hanging in New York Citys subway stations.

title: Fields and Picnic Area Open in Brooklyn Park
description: Brooklyn Bridge Park, an 85-acre work-in-progress that stretches along the East River waterfront, took a significant step toward completion on Thursday with the opening of three new athletic fields, two playgrounds and a picnic area on Pier 5.

title: Confession Only Adds to Mystery in Patz Case
description: There are no secrets in this case, the lawyer Harvey Fishbein wrote in papers he filed in court Wednesday.

title: As the Mets Sit Quietly, Trade Speculation Swirls
description: A month and a half has passed since the conclusion of the baseball season, and the Mets have made no player acquisitions of any significance. Instead, it has been a winter defined by departures.

title: Moodys Downgrade Deepens Puerto Ricos Economic Problems
description: Moodys Investors Service downgraded the debt of Puerto Rico to just above junk status on Thursday, putting pressure on the governor-elect, Alejandro Garca-Padilla, to show credible plans for staving off a crisis.

title: Dempster Is Set to Join Red Sox
description: The Boston Red Sox reached an agreement on a two-year, $26.5 million contract with the right-hander Ryan Dempster, adding a veteran starter to a thin rotation. The agreement was confirmed by a baseball official. The deal will not be announced until Dempster, 35, passes a physical. He was 12-8 with a 3.34 earned run average last season for the Chicago Cubs and the Texas Rangers. Dempster is the fifth player, but the first pitcher, to reach a two- or three-year contract agreement with the Red Sox this off-season. Burned in past years by long-term commitments, the Red Sox have been thriftier this time, signing Dempster, Jonny Gomes, Mike Napoli, David Ross and Shane Victorino to short-term deals. Napolis contract has not been finalized.

title: Hoping for a Senate Seat, the Friendliest of Rivals
description: WASHINGTON  Representatives Trey Gowdy and Tim Scott, first-term Republicans from South Carolina, are both in the running to replace Senator Jim DeMint when the conservative leaves office next month. But they say they know the best man for the job: the other guy.

title: Senate Panel Approves Findings Critical of Detainee Interrogations
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate Intelligence Committee on Thursday approved a highly critical, classified report on the Central Intelligence Agencys detention and interrogation program, the most comprehensive review of the brutal treatment of Qaeda prisoners in the years after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

title: Hope of a Better Future Fades in Boulaq
description: Everywhere, people tell stories about the Egyptian governments failures, suggesting that the new leaders had turned out no better than the old ones.

title: Rices Blunt Style Endeared Her to President, but Not All
description: WASHINGTON  For President Obama, the decision to forgo the fight to make Susan E. Rice his secretary of state was a deeply painful one. It required publicly abandoning one of his most loyal aides, who had broken with the Democratic foreign policy establishment early to side with his improbable candidacy, and whose blunt-speaking style  which helped cost her the job  had always been, for Mr. Obama, a part of her appeal.

title: Judge in North Carolina Voids 3 Death Sentences
description: A judge in North Carolina on Thursday ruled that race had played a significant role in the sentencing of three convicted murderers to death, and changed their sentences to life in prison without possibility of parole. It was the second such decision under the states Racial Justice Act and the first since the act was amended by the state legislature.

title: Outcry Brings Down Murals in Atlanta Art Project
description: ATLANTA  Two murals intended to spruce up blighted neighborhoods in Atlanta have been painted over after some residents complained that they were confusing at best, demonic at worst.

title: Church Opens Arms to Muslim Group, and Is Taken to Task
description: When the Muslim Public Affairs Council arranged to hold its annual convention at All Saints Church in Pasadena, Calif., this Saturday, leaders of both organizations believed it would be a bold demonstration of progress in interfaith relations.

title: After Fast Start, Anthony Limps Off and Knicks Hold On
description: Carmelo Anthony looked up at the shot clock, put his head down and drove the lane. Mike DAntoni, his former coach, stood a few feet away as Anthony was fouled hard by Dwight Howard. Anthonys left knee and ankle were caught under his body when he hit the court in a violent crash.

title: The End of 'Ebb' and 'Flow'
description: An animation released by NASA shows the proposed crash landing of two lunar-orbiting spacecraft, called Ebb and Flow, into the moon's surface.

title: Two Space Probes to Crash, Intentionally, on Dark Side of Moon
description: NASAs latest Moon mission will end on Monday  not with a whimper, but a splat.

title: Word of the Day | filibuster
description: filibuster \fi-l-bs-tr\ noun and verb

title: As State Budgets Rebound, Federal Cuts Could Pose Danger
description: After years of budget cuts and sluggish recovery, states expect to see their revenues climb back to prerecession levels this year for the first time since the financial crisis hit. But even as some states hope to restore some of the deep spending cuts they have made, they face a new threat.

title: National Governors Association Fiscal Survey of States
description: States collected more taxes this year than in 2008, the last fiscal year before the recession. But the news is not as good as it initially appears.

title: A Mother Fought to End a Destructive Path and Reunite Her Family
description: Getting through to troubled teenagers should not be difficult, says Julie Rodriguez, who aspires to be a counselor after surviving some tough decades of violence and drug abuse.

title: Bryants Frustration Grows as Free Fall Continues
description: Kobe Bryant tried making the most of his off day in New York City on Wednesday.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 9 P.M. (Sundance) RESTLESS In the conclusion of this two-part drama written by William Boyd, Ruth Gilmartin (Michelle Dockery), a Cambridge graduate student in 1970s England, continues to uncover the past of her mother, Sally (Charlotte Rampling, above), who she has recently discovered is actually Eva Delectorskaya (Hayley Atwell plays the young Eva), a Russian exile who worked as a British spy during World War II. Now the former spy thinks someone is out to kill her, which is why shes buying a rifle and ammunition strong enough to take down a charging elephant. We all have secrets, she admonishes her disbelieving daughter. No one even knows half the truth about someone else. Rufus Sewell and Michael Gambon share the role of Lucas Romer, a spymaster and Sallys former lover, who may be the only one who can save her. Devout fans of the British espionage thriller or the British cozy mystery may find themselves perfectly happy with Restless, Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. Mr. Boyds understated script is free of hackneyed dialogue or florid emotion (no surprise), and there are niceties of language  strategically repeated phrases, Ruths wavering forms of address to her mother  that you dont expect in a mini-series. And Ms. Dockery and Ms. Rampling, in their relatively short screen time together, have an astringent rapport that brings to life the complicated relationship of Ruth and Eva, as well as Mr. Boyds themes of the forging and cracking of identity under pressure, in a way that goes beyond words on a page.

title: News Quiz | December 14, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: At a Busy Gurgaon Call Center, Putting the Phones on Hold for Family Day
description: On a recent Friday, amid the corporate sprawl of modern Gurgaon, Genpact, one of Indias largest business process and technology outsourcing centers, transformed an otherwise nondescript conference room into a festive reception hall with bright balloons, waiters passing out candy and a stage set up for the occasion. Employees trickled in, some new to the company, others veterans with years of experience, to slowly fill the 100-odd chairs in the room. But this afternoon, instead of the notepads and pens they would bring to regular team meeting, these workers have got their families in tow.

title: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 14
description: NEWS European leaders gathering on Thursday for their year-end summit meeting hailed an agreement to place euro zone banks under a single supervisor, calling it a concrete measure to maintain the viability of the currency as well as a step in laying the groundwork for a broader economic union. James Kanter reports from Brussels.

title: Russia Steps Back From Envoys Comments on Syria
description: MOSCOW  The Russian Foreign Ministry distanced itself on Friday from comments by its Middle East envoy, who was widely quoted a day earlier as saying that rebels in Syria may defeat the forces of President Bashar al-Assad, and said Russias insistence on a political solution to the Syrian crisis will never change.

title: Test Yourself | Critical Thinking, Dec. 14, 2012
description: This question was written by Katherine Schulten from a recent Op-Ed column by Charles M. Blow.

title: Musicians Rock for Sandy Relief
description: In Wave After Wave of the Right Tunes, Jon Pareles reports on the Hurricane Sandy relief concert that took place on Wednesday night.

title: Art, Elevated: Henry Chalfants Archives
description: We encourage viewing this slideshow in full-screen mode.

title: The Color of War
description: A new view of an old conflict in Congo.

title: Should You Care About the Health and Safety of Those Making Your Clothing?
description: Recent factory fires killed more than 400 workers in Bangladesh and Pakistan. Unsafe conditions, like locked exits and barred windows, made the death tolls much higher. In the United States, more than a century of activism and legislation has drastically improved factory safety at home, but so much of our clothing is now manufactured overseas where workers do not have the same protections. American consumers benefit from lower prices, but at what cost?

title: Panetta Orders Deployment of U.S. Antimissile Units in Turkey
description: INCIRLIK AIR BASE, Turkey  Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta signed an official deployment order on Friday to send 400 American military personnel and two Patriot air defense batteries to Turkey as its tensions intensify with neighboring Syria, where government forces have increasingly resorted to aerial attacks, including the use of ballistic missiles, to fight a spreading insurgency.

title: PPG Industries to Buy Paint Unit for $1.05 Billion
description: LONDON  The specialty chemical company PPG Industries agreed on Friday to buy part of the North American operations of a Dutch rival, AkzoNobel, for $1.05 billion.

title: Taking on Merkel
description: HANOVER, Germany  Peer Steinbrck is a name the world will be hearing a lot more often in the New Year. On Sunday, Germanys Social Democratic Party nominated the former finance minister to challenge Angela Merkel for the job of chancellor next year.

title: Hospital Alarms Fail to Prevent Injury, Study Finds
description: When it comes to protecting older people from falls, it can take a long time to figure out what helps and sometimes an even longer time to take action against things that were supposed to help but dont.

title: The Trade-Off Between Economic Growth and Deficit Reduction
description: Laura DAndrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and served as chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Bill Clinton.

title: Week 15 Matchups: No Need to Flip
description: Giants (8-5) at Falcons (11-2)

title: When All Else Fails, Try the Supreme Court
description: The workload of Indias highest court is swelling, possibly because people are losing faith in the countrys lower courts, according to a report released Friday.

title: If College Admissions Were Like Tetris, Everything Would Fall in Line
description: When I close my eyes, a game of Tetris appears. The blocks fall flawlessly. Each one perfectly fits into the contour created by the previous blocks. The structure has no lapses.

title: In Kerala, a Distinctly Indian Art Fair With International Appeal
description: KOCHI  In a dank, musty loft at Moidus Heritage, an unused warehouse in Fort Kochi, Kerala, the Brazilian artist Ernesto Neto stood precariously on a stool.

title: A Start-Up Finds Traction Through E-Mail Marketing
description: When the last of Carol OLearys six children graduated from high school, she was eager to start a new career.I was 55, she said. I needed to do something to fill my time and maybe make a few bucks.

title: British Regulator Says Banks Too Big to Prosecute
description: Andrew Bailey, the future chief of the Prudential Regulation Authority, a newly created British regulator, believes that some banks have become too big to prosecute.

title: Q. and A.: Jeremy Irons and Trashed
description: Just in time for the holidays, a new documentary about the ultimate fate of just about everything we lug home from the mall opens on Friday in limited release in the United States. Trashed, directed by Candida Brady and starring Jeremy Irons, delves into the less festive side of consumerism and waste disposal  overflowing landfills in England, a toxic trash incinerator in Iceland, a hospital for children with birth defects in Vietnam.(Jeannette Catsoulis briefly reviews the film in Fridays Times.)

title: Friday Reading: Tackling Medical School Debt
Daily Report: N. Joseph Woodland, Inventor of the Bar Code, Dies at 91
description: In The New York Times on Friday, Margalit Fox reports on the life of N. Joseph Woodland, who invented the bar code, and who died last Sunday at age 91.

title: Kirchner Stumbles Again
description: BUENOS AIRES  It wasnt the celebration President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner had planned. For months, her government had billed Dec. 7 as the date in which the Clarn Group, the countrys largest media conglomerate, would finally be left with no choice but to dismantle in accordance with a 2009 media law that curtails how many broadcast licenses one company can own. For months, the government billed the date, which it christened as 7D in copious state advertising, as the dawn of a new day in Argentina.

title: Can You Be English if You Dont Speak English?
description: LONDON  Should immigrants be obliged to learn the language of their adopted country?

title: Opinion Report: The Sequester
description: From the editorial page

title: Common Core Practice | Team Anthems, Humanities Majors and Murals
description: Brooklyn: Something to Lean On, the Brooklyn Nets new anthem.

title: Guilty Plea Expected for UBS Unit in Rate-Rigging Case
description: GUILTY PLEA EXPECTED FOR UBS UNIT IN RATE-RIGGING CASE | UBS is in final negotiations with American, British and Swiss authorities to settle accusations that its employees reported false rates, a deal in which the banks Japanese unit is expected to plead guilty to a criminal charge, DealBook reports. In addition, UBS could face about $1 billion in fines and regulatory sanctions, according to people briefed on the matter who spoke of private discussions on the condition of anonymity.

title: Ending a Life, and a Part of Yourself, for the First Time
description: Two hundred meters was all that separated me from an insurgent carrying an AK-47. I sat in a dilapidated brown leather chair, recessed in the shadows of a second-story room in the government complex of Falluja, Iraq. My sights were perfectly centered as I perched my elbows on the desk in front of me. The clear tip traced the center of his chest. He crept around a corner of a mud wall and slowly moved toward our position. Fear built inside me. I hesitantly began to pull the trigger of my M-16.

title: Discovery Strikes 2 Deals in Bid for International Growth
description: Discovery Communications struck two deals on Friday aimed at expanding its reach in Europe, including buying the Nordic arm of the German broadcaster ProSiebenSat.1.

title: The Happy Holiday | Party Perfect Clutches
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: How Big Is the Budget Hole?
description: Something Ive been meaning to write: get into a discussion of matters fiscal, especially with conservatives, and youre bound to have somebody declaring that we have a ONE TRILLION DOLLAR deficit, which means that what Americans want from their government is far more than we can pay for, so we must slash the welfare state, etc.. Also, that the hole is so big that taxing the rich cant possibly make any real difference (although somehow savaging the poor supposedly will).

title: Bleeding the Patient: A Drama
description: The Irish Economy has the script, lifted from comments on a piece about the ECB still defending austerity; reposted here after the jump.

title: Syrian Rebel Lays Out Hostage Demands, as Case Sullies a Cause
description: BAB AL-SALAM, Syria  When Syrian rebels stopped two buses of Lebanese travelers in the spring and took 11 passengers hostage, they set off a cascade of fallout: riots at the Beirut airport, retaliation kidnappings against Syrians in Lebanon and a deepening of the sectarian character of the war.

title: An Encounter With a Red-tailed Hawk
description: Dear Diary:

title: Coming Back: Up and Running Again
description: As it recovers from flooding after Hurricane Sandy, the Red Hook Lobster Pound makes a triumphant comeback to the first place where they ever sold lobster rolls.

title: Merchants Quandary: Rebuild Quickly, or Improve?
description: Susan Povich wanted to fry. Ever since she and her husband, Ralph Gorham, opened the Red Hook Lobster Pound nearly four years ago, customers have invariably asked if they could have fries with their lobster rolls. To which the owners, not in possession of a deep fryer, could only reply, No.

title: Tax Plan Is Popular, but Not Quite Fair
description: Mitt Romney may have lost in November, but the ghost of the Republican presidential candidate lives on in the debate over tax reform and the fiscal cliff.

title: Forum for New Diplomacy
description: Irina Bokova, Director General of Unesco, in conversation with Serge Schmemann, Editorial Page Editor of the International Herald Tribune.

title: Can You Have Holidays Without God?
description: Can you do the gifts without the God?

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Golden Globes Lift Django, and Introducing Kanyes Kilt
description: The Golden Globe nominations were announced on Thursday, with Lincoln leading the way with seven nominations, Brooks Barnes reported. But true to form, he writes, the awards from the Hollywood Foreign Press Association were spread about quite evenly, with Argo and Django Unchained close behind with five nominations apiece; Zero Dark Thirty, Les Misrables and Silver Linings Playbook each received four. The Globes will be handed out on Jan. 13, with Amy Poehler and Tina Fey as co-hosts of the telecast, a role recently filled by Ricky Gervais.

title: A Director Who Prefers Working With Kids (Well, One in Particular)
description: Early in her career, the Swiss-French director Ursula Meier, 41, worked as an assistant to Alain Tanner, whose directorial credits include acclaimed films like The Salamander and Jonah Who Will Be 25 in the Year 2000. Ms. Meier has so far made only two feature-length films on her own, but both, Home in 2008 and now Sister, ended up being submitted by Switzerland as that countrys candidate for the Oscar for best foreign-language film.

title: What Were Reading
description: Time: The small-plates trend finally filters down to fast-food restaurants, where the little dishes are called snacks.  Patrick Farrell

title: Syrian Rebels Claim to Shoot Down Warplane
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian rebels claimed on Friday to have shot down a government warplane that had been attacking insurgent positions near the Damascus international airport, reflecting the continuing and stubborn battle between the authorities and adversaries seeking to secure positions on the approaches to the capital.

title: British Authorities Charge Hedge Fund Founder
description: LONDON  The founder of Weavering Capital, one of Britains oldest hedge funds, has been charged with fraud, fraudulent trading and false accounting.

title: Keeping Up With the Dodgers
description: If there is one thing the Angels owner Arte Moreno definitely has, its a sense of place. There is a reason they are the Los Angeles Angels now and not the bourgeois Anaheim ones. Moreno wanted in on Hollywood, wanted to own and operate a slice of show business. So, in Hollywood, when the Dodgers go flashy by signing Zack Greinke and trading for Adrian Gonzalez and Josh Beckett, the Angels have to throw $125 million at Josh Hamilton.

title: A Redesigned Museum
description: Images from the renovated Yale University Art Gallery.

title: A Critics Tour of Literary Manhattan
description: A FEW years ago, the novelist Gary Shteyngart, whose books are very funny and very sad, gave an interview to a magazine called Modern Drunkard. (Yes, this magazine actually exists.) Its the funniest and saddest interview Ive ever read.

title: New York, Chapter and Verse
description: Do poetry slams still exist? What about good bookstores? Some answers in a tour of literary Manhattan.

title: More Safety Features for Amarnath Pilgrims
description: Alarmed by the number of Hindu pilgrims who die each year while visiting the holy Shri Amarnath cave in the Himalayas, Indias Supreme Court on Thursday ordered the Jammu and Kashmir government and the shrines administrator to improve road safety and provide basic facilities like medical shelters.

title: Google Introduces a New Mobile Ad to Combat Fat Fingers
description: The fat finger effect  the theory that people accidentally click on mobile ads because cellphone screens are so small  is one reason mobile ads generally earn less money than ads shown on desktop computers.

title: Miss Manners on the Best Holiday Visits
description: WITH the holidays upon us, families are crisscrossing the country to visit one another. The likelihood of all this family togetherness devolving into discord is so great its become a Hollywood trope. Judith Martin, the arbiter of etiquette known as Miss Manners, dispenses words of advice on how to avoid such scenarios. Below are edited excerpts from a conversation with her on how to be a gracious host and a well-mannered house guest.

title: Chasing Anchovies on Turkeys Black Sea Coast
description: SO youre here for anchovies, said the bartender at Sehrazade, a shadowy spot in Unye, Turkey, a smile playing at the corners of his mouth.

title: Skiing to a Remote Retreat in the Canadian Rockies
description: IN a secluded valley deep in the Canadian Rockies, miles from any road and even farther from the nearest chairlift, sits a luxurious cabin. Inside theres a sauna, a crackling fire and two chefs laboring in a fully stocked kitchen; outside, trackless powder stretches to the glacier-capped horizons.

title: Restaurant Report: Le Bec Fin in Philadelphia
description: In 1970, a Frenchman named Georges Perrier opened an opulent little jewel box of a restaurant just off Rittenhouse Square in Philadelphia and astutely named it Le Bec Fin, a French expression that literally translates as the Fine Beak, but that also means the Fine Palate. He quickly seduced the citys frequently Francophile establishment, and, more important, tutored them in Gallic gastronomy like a stern but conditionally charming headmaster. For almost 40 years, Bec Fin was considered the best restaurant in Philadelphia, and one of the finest French tables in the United States.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Virginias Northern Neck

title: Best Buy Gives Founder More Time to Make a Bid
description: 4:20 p.m. | Updated

title: This Weeks Movies: Dec. 14
description: This week, Times critics look at the drama Any Day Now with Alan Cumming, The Girl featuring Abbie Cornish, and the new film adaptation of The Hobbit. Find all of this weeks reviews here.

title: A Womans Final Wish, Denied by the Church That She Loved
description: Carmen Villegass last wish was to lie in repose for just one hour inside Our Lady Queen of Angels. The modest brick church on East 113th Street in East Harlem had been the center of her life since childhood. When the Archdiocese of New York closed it in 2007, she led a group of the faithful in weekly services on the sidewalk, hoping their prayerful protest would persuade the hierarchy to reopen the sanctuary.

title: European Leaders Back Common Banking Rules
description: BRUSSELS  European Union leaders pledged on Friday to take further steps to set up common banking rules for the bloc, but they delayed plans for a shared budget for the euro zone nations as pressure appeared to be easing on the single currency.

title: Tina Fey and Amy Poehler, Fancy-Talking Hosts
description: When both Tina Fey and Amy Poehler were nominated for best comedic actress at the Golden Globes on Thursday, the Bagger got excited thinking how these old friends  who are hosts of the telecast on Jan. 13  might handle their extra spotlights. After all, they have a history  of doing the award shows best bits:

title: At the Panels Edge
description: Ellen Forneys greatest strength as a cartoonist is her gift for explanation  getting information across with vigor, wit and visual inventiveness. That inspiration may have come at an awful cost, she suggests in MARBLES: Mania, Depression, Michelangelo, and Me (Gotham, paper, $20), a memoir of her long tango, or wrestling match, with bipolar disorder. As she explains, her frantic, volatile high moods seemed to fuel her art; her crushing lows made it nearly impossible for her to make it, or do anything else; and the desperately inexact science of medication, she once feared, might rob her of the creativity she cherished. The bulk of Marbles documents her wobbly progress toward stability, with interpolated drawings from her journals and occasional side trips into the history of crazy artists. Its not exactly focused, but its mostly delightful: Forney switches up the style and layout of her artwork every page or two, and shes got enough perspective on herself to find some kind of comedy even in painful experiences.

title: Ewan McGregor: Star Wars
description: Part 10: The actor discusses his time on the Star Wars films, why he took the role of Obi-Wan, and what it was like to play a young Alec Guinness.

title: Ewan McGregor: A Good Growing-Up Year
description: Part 4: The actor reminisces about his drama school days and formative experiences as a young actor.

title: TimesTalks | Ewan McGregor: Preview
description: The actor talks Trainspotting, Star Wars, Beginners and other milestones in his already-accomplished film career.

title: Ewan McGregor: Beginners
description: Part 11: The actor talks about working with the director Mike Mills, the actor Christopher Plummer and two dogs in 2011s Beginners.

title: Ewan McGregor: Intro
description: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the actor Ewan McGregor.

title: Ewan McGregor: The Impossible
description: Part 5: The actor explains why he wanted the part in The Impossible and talks about what it was like working primarily with child actors in the film.

title: Ewan McGregor: Pulling Focus
description: Part 7: The actor discusses the unique challenge of getting emotions to show up on camera.

title: Ewan McGregor: Highlights and Regrets
description: Part 13: The actor talks about which directors have taught him the most and who he wishes he couldve worked with.

title: Ewan McGregor: I Was Embarrassed
description: Part 6: The actor talks about why The Impossible isnt a disaster movie, and describes why he felt guilty about taking a role in the film.

title: Ewan McGregor: Trainspotting
description: Part 9: The actor recalls what it was like to be in London when Trainspotting came out, and reflects on the abrupt end of his relationship with the director Danny Boyle.

title: Ewan McGregor: Long Way Round
description: Part 12: The actor recalls what it was like to arrive in New York City on the final day of his 19,000-mile motorcycle trip around the world.

title: Ewan McGregor: Action Movie Acting
description: Part 8: The actor reveals why he thinks action movies present a bigger dramatic challenge for an actor than smaller-scale film roles.

title: Ewan McGregor: Broad Comedy
description: Part 3: The actor talks about how he prepares for his roles, and describes working with the director Lasse Hallstrom on Salmon Fishing in the Yemen.

title: Ewan McGregor: Lightsaber Battles
description: Part 15: The actor reveals what it was really like to film the lightsaber fights in the Star Wars films, and reflects on what he wants to achieve with the rest of his career.

title: Ewan McGregor: Woody Allen
description: Part 14: The actor tells three stories from his time on a Woody Allen film, and explains why he didnt want to play James Bond.

title: Ewan McGregor: The Best Kind of Acting
description: Part 2: The actor explains what made his film Salmon Fishing in the Yemen such a fun project to shoot.

title: Reading the Fine Print
description: In the Dec. 10 issue Nicole Krauss reviews The River of Consciousness, a collection of essays by Oliver Sacks. Three years before his death,Sacks wrote about the complex and deeply personal act of readingfor the Book Review.

title: Editors Choice
description: SASHA AND EMMA: The Anarchist Odyssey of Alexander Berkman and Emma Goldman,  by Paul Avrich and Karen Avrich. (Belknap/Harvard University, $35.) Even when their affair ended, their comradeship lasted for the rest of their remarkable lives.

title: Paperback Row
description: [SIC]: A Memoir,  by Joshua Cody. (Norton, $15.95.) This sprightly, manic cancer memoir sidesteps sentimentality by mocking it, in prose our reviewer, Gregory Cowles, called bright and jazzy and meandering. Drawing from journals he kept during his treatment, Cody, a young composer in New York, combines the story of his illness  and his attempts to find refuge in sex and drugs  with meditations on family and the relationship between art and life.

title: Sweeping Torture Under the Rug
description: In Strasbourg, France, a 17-judge panel of the European Court of Human Rights ruled unanimously on Thursday that U.S. intelligence did in fact kidnap a German citizen in Macedonia. The court said he was locked in a hotel room for 23 days, then handed over to a C.I.A. rendition team at an airport, where he was severely beaten, sodomized, shackled and hooded. Later he was sent to Afghanistan and illegally detained for months. The German citizen, Khaled el-Masri, had no connection to terrorism, unless you count the fact that U.S. officials were seeking an Al Qaeda operative with a similar name. The court ordered Macedonia to pay Mr. Masri $78,000 in damages.

title: Empresses of Fantasy
description: As the lowly assistant crouched on the floor, arranging purple snakeskin shoes for a photo shoot, the imperious editor swept into the room, flinging her Mainbocher coat at the young woman. Without thinking, the assistant chucked it right back. Was the underling fired for insubordination? No. Did she turn her experience into a blockbuster movie? Yes. But not in the way you might suppose, and not when you might suppose. That assistant wasnt Lauren Weisberger, who parlayed her first job  answering the phones for Anna Wintour, editor of the American edition of Vogue  into the roman  clef, and then film, The Devil Wears Prada (a disgracefully disloyal thing to do, Vogues creative director, the amusingly blunt Grace Coddington, remarks in her understatedly dishy memoir, Grace). Far from it: the office dogsbody was the future film star Ali MacGraw, then an assistant to Wintours legendary predecessor, Diana Vreeland.

title: Death of an Author
description: For over 30 years, the Argentine expatriate Alberto Manguel has championed the cause of literature and reading in his polyhistoric anthologies and essays. His latest novel, All Men Are Liars, translated by Miranda France, advances this concern under the guise of a cross-continental literary mystery.

title: Outside the Ring
description: Eduardo Halfon is the author of 11 books, but The Polish Boxer is his first to be translated into English, by, as it happens, five translators. This seems less a testament to the difficulty of the novel than a playful nod to one of its central preoccupations: how translation is a form of writing and writing is a form of translation. It is the sort of concern that can easily become ponderous in the wrong hands; in Halfons, it is funny and revelatory.

title: Rocking the Cradle
description: Although in the same league with George Gershwin and Aaron Copland, subjects of two earlier biographies by Howard Pollack, Marc Blitzstein is relatively unfamiliar for a variety of reasons, among them his leftist politics and his openly gay sexuality in an era when both were disdained. Three years after Blitzsteins death from what was evidently a gay-bashing in Martinique in 1964, Copland said, It is disheartening to realize how little the present generation knows who he was or what he accomplished, and Leonard Bernstein expressed dismay in 1976 at the rapidity with which his names been forgotten, calling him the greatest master of the setting of the American language to music.

title: Bookworms and Apples
description: In life and fiction, technology obsolesces the moment we acquire it. In Stieg Larssons novel The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, Lisbeth Salander is a hacker. Her superpower is an ability to uncover anything about anyone using her Powerbook, a laptop produced by Apple from 1991 to 2006. When Larsson wrote the novel, Powerbooks were advanced. Today, they are relics. Larsson spends an inordinate amount of time detailing hardware specifications, but this information doesnt have the desired effect. Our smartphones have more computing power than Salanders Powerbook. The way to write about technology does not reside in exhaustive technical description.

title: The Trial
description: In 1971, Franois Bizot, a French ethnologist studying Buddhism in Cambodia, was captured and held for three months in a Khmer Rouge detention camp, where he was interrogated (though apparently not physically tortured) by Kaing Guek Eav, a young revolutionary better known as Duch. Captor and captive developed a rapport, and ultimately, Bizot became the only Westerner to be released from Khmer Rouge captivity. Duch, meanwhile, went on to oversee the torture and murder of thousands of Cambodians at the notorious Tuol Sleng prison and in 2010 was the first person convicted by Cambodias war crimes tribunal. Bizot returned to Cambodia to testify at the trial. Facing the Torturer is his attempt to come to terms with this part of his ordeal (a previous account, The Gate, published in the United States in 2003, chronicled his earlier experiences in Cambodia).

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: BY LOVE POSSESSED  Stories.  By Lorna Goodison.  Amistad/HarperCollins, paper, $14.99.

title: Nation Reels After Gunman Massacres 20 Children at School in Connecticut
description: A 20-year-old man wearing combat gear and armed with semiautomatic pistols and a semiautomatic rifle killed 26 people  20 of them children  in an attack in an elementary school in central Connecticut on Friday. Witnesses and officials described a horrific scene as the gunman, with brutal efficiency, chose his victims in two classrooms while other students dove under desks and hid in closets.

title: This Means War
description: It was a rainy afternoon. Two 4-year-old girls played on the kitchen floor, coloring either end of a long accordion of paper. Glorious pastels and autumn tones materialized on the adjoining rectangles until they came together in the middle. The two girls held up their joint creation with glee. Until, that is, one mother arrived to pick up her daughter, who refused to budge without her half of the book. She asked for scissors, but her host, who happens to be my daughter, shook her head no and crawled under the kitchen table. One wailed for her half; the other wailed to keep the whole book.

title: Midnight Caller
description: In the 1970s, most Americans still had rotary phones. CB radios were a new craze. Students learned math using slide rules. Mark Zuckerberg had not yet arrived on the planet, and teenagers didnt obsessively fashion aspirational online identities.

title: In His Own Time
description: Will Sparrow was a liar and a thief, and hungry begins Karen Cushmans latest novel. One of her recurring themes is that with enough pluck and mulishness, children will play through the bad hand fate deals them  once theyve glimpsed a reason to do so. I care for no one but myself, the boy starts out saying, and nothing but my belly! while stealing a cold rabbit pie. By the end of Will Sparrows Road, when the boys conscience blossoms as he envisions a different life, we will have traveled with him through a lively and amusing parade of the late 16th century and through the heros own personal journey.

title: The World Below
description: No matter how fervently children cling to the belief that fairies yet linger in the backyard, fireflies are really fallen stars and stuffed animals can talk, absolutely, the adult world (with its tedium, stresses and need for matched socks) will slowly encroach on theirs. But the stubborn and lucky few who refuse ever to believe they are too old for imagination are also those who wisely come to understand that sometimes there was great truth in made-up stories.

title: Bookshelf: Penguins
description: Baby Penguins Everywhere!, Penguin and Pinecone, and more.

title: Bookshelf: Penguins
description: BABY PENGUINS EVERYWHERE!  Written and illustrated by Melissa Guion.  32 pp. Philomel. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 5)

title: Inside the List
description: MAKING A LIST: This is the season when a columnists thoughts turn to sugarplums and shopping, and begging other people to do his job for him. What books will best-selling authors be giving  or craving  for the holidays this year? Lets ask them!

title: Image of the Day: Dec. 14
Dec. 14 Updates on Connecticut School Shooting
description: On Friday night, hundreds of people turned out for prayer vigils and services in Newtown, Conn. and across the country in the aftermath of one of the deadliest school shootings in U.S. history. As our colleagues report a gunman killed 26 people, including 20 children, then killed himself at the Sandy Hook Elementary School. The gunmans 54-year-old mother was found dead at the home they shared in Newtown. Read all related coverage on the Lede

title: Generator of Dreams
description: First, let me dispel the curse of the two-book review. These ambitious works of cultural history are in no way a forced pairing. Both The Entertainer and The Noir Forties examine political and sociological shifts in America at large, viewing Hollywood as a generator of dreams that at once mirrors and shapes the collective unconscious  as well as a company town run by despotic bosses.

title: Caroline Sylvester and Charles Maddock
description: ON the surface, Charles Maddock could be seen as one of those privileged young men who develops a sense of noblesse oblige as he dances between the raindrops while everyone else gets wet.

title: Pin Your Best Recipes for Holiday Sweets
description: What is your foolproof holiday dessert recipe, the secret weapon in your December arsenal, the dazzler at the party or the beauty at the end of the meal? Or, if youre trying something new this year, what is the recipe youre most enticed by?

title: 25 Favorites From a Year When 10 Arent Enough
description: IF you spent a lot of time this year reading and writing about movies  as opposed to watching them, which is more fun  you might have detected recurrent notes of anxiety, trepidation, even dread. Television is better than movies; audience levels are in a state of permanent decline; the Hollywood studios have given up on grown-ups; and digital, a force so powerful that it is both adjective and noun, is destroying cinema as we know it. These are among the tenets of a pessimistic conventional wisdom.

title: NATO Sends Anti-Missile Units to Turkey
description: TimesCast: The United States and its allies come to Turkeys defense.  | Examining Susan E. Rices blunt style. | Building a showcase campus, on a foundation of debt.

title: Your Homeland Questions Answered
description: The second season of the Showtime thriller Homeland has been as suspenseful as its acclaimed first run but somewhat more polarizing. With the finale coming up on Sunday, the creators of Homeland  Alex Gansa, the show runner and executive producer, and Howard Gordon, an executive producer  agreed to answer questions from Times readers about the show.

title: Nothing Staid About Royal Academys Art Gift to the Queen
description: Queen Elizabeth IIs art collection just got a little bigger and  at least by the work represented  a lot more adventurous. To commemorate the queens diamond jubilee marking the 60th anniversary of her ascension to the throne, the Royal Academy of Arts has given her 97 works on paper by some of Britains most esteemed and also most polarizing artists.

title: A Proliferation of Ways to Use a Tax Break as Its End Nears
description: HOLIDAY shoppers and tax filers are known for procrastinating. This year, theyre joined by the wealthy who have still not decided whether to make a gift under a generous gift tax exemption that may soon disappear.

title: Safety First, Then Mistletoe, Is Byword for the Holidays
description: LAST Thanksgiving, I learned a valuable safety tip: be careful when using a foil roasting pan. It can puncture and fat can drip in the oven, resulting in a fire.

title: Against the Odds, Smart Films Thrive at the Box Office
description: SEEN any good movies lately? How could you not? This has been a bumper year for movies big and small, imported and domestic, some made for hundreds of millions of dollars and others made for about the price of a grande soy latte. As has been the case in recent years, the top box office movies in America were mostly formulaic corporate entertainments, including the superhero comic-book fantasies like Marvels The Avengers that make some critics despair. Even amid the usual selection of big-screen cartoons and testosterone, though, it was nice to see female-driven stories like The Hunger Games  and all the female viewers its box office represents  muscling into the mix.

title: Thank You for the Tissue Graft
description: FOR weeks I had been reading the sample thank-you letter I got from the hospital. In June I underwent A.C.L. replacement surgery, which means that one of the major ligaments in my knee  the one that holds the knee in place  was removed, and in its place doctors screwed in an anonymous cadavers Achilles tendon. Along with the tendon, I got a folder filled with recovery instructions for taking a shower and protecting the stitches and a piece of paper on how to write a thank-you note to the family of the donor. Every few days Id pick up the paper and my eyes would fill with tears as I was reminded that my gain was someone elses heartbreaking loss.

title: Week 15 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
description: Jason and Justin Sablich provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy.

title: Perpetual Motion
description: THE fall 2013 fashion season begins on the worn-down heels of fall 12. Stores are marking down the stuff they couldnt sell as designers present their new duds. There is no time to mourn in fashion, and apparently no room for a guilty conscience about the glut of clothes, since it keeps right on growing like a berserk house plant.

title: Hard-Line Israeli Foreign Minister Resigns
description: JERUSALEM  Facing indictment for breach of trust and fraud, Israels foreign minister, Avigdor Lieberman, resigned his post Friday afternoon amid mounting political pressure, upending the campaign landscape five weeks before national elections.

title: Ristretto | Books for the Coffee Lover
description: The annual annual avalanche of cookbooks, food memoirs and single-ingredient investigations has largely passed by coffee. For some reason, the publishing industry hasnt been that interested in what you drink every morning.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Molly Haskell discusses two new books about old Hollywood; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Liesl Schillinger on three books about the world of high fashion; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: The Year of the Body Vulnerable
description: SO many of the years best films have broken ground in their depiction of the realities of war, disability, aging, illness and death that I would call 2012 the year of the body. Not the body beautiful, which Hollywood has exalted for decades, but the body vulnerable. Even the male strippers in Magic Mike, Steven Soderberghs unsexy beefcake parade, are tarnished deities with feet of clay.

title: Educating Students From Cultures That See Work as Exploitation
description: NEW YORK  Traveling through this citys warren of subways, you see them everywhere: advertisements promoting community colleges  and in so many cases, emphasizing their flexibility as a principal selling point.

title: Lebanese Captives in Syria Speak Out
description: C.J. Chivers, a correspondent for The New York Times, spoke with two Lebanese men held captive in Syria for seven months. Syrian rebels accuse them and seven others of being members of Hezbollah.

title: E.P.A. Sets a Lower Limit for Soot Particles in the Air
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency announced a new standard for soot pollution on Friday that will force industry, utilities and local governments to find ways to reduce emissions of particles that are linked to thousands of cases of disease and death each year.

title: I Was A Teenage Cyclist, Part 2: The Scourge of the Lethal Ghost Riders
description: Back in March 2011, John Cassidy of The New Yorker wrote a much-discussed and highly instructive blog post in which he made a case against bike lanes in New York  much-discussed in that many people disagreed with him (including me) and instructive insofar as it conveniently collected nearly all the tropes of the burgeoning anti-bike genre.

title: Book Review Podcast: Old Hollywood
description: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Molly Haskell reviews two new books about old Hollywood: The Noir Forties: The American People From Victory to Cold War, by Richard Lingeman, and The Entertainer, in which Margaret Talbot writes about the career of her father, the actor Lyle Talbot. Ms. Haskell writes about Ms. Talbots book:

title: Off the Charts: A Wide Open Bond Market
description: Bond issuance in the United States and in emerging markets has risen to record levels in 2012.

title: Dancing With Jamie Foxx and Quentin Tarantino
description: Even before the strong showing for Django Unchained at the Golden Globe nominations on Thursday, Harvey Weinstein was in a good mood. At the films premiere, hosted by the Cinema Society on Wednesday night, he stood at the front of the Ziegfeld Theater and crowed about the honors that this Weinstein Company release had already garnered: a host of nominations from the NAACP Image Awards.

title: ESPN to Use Twitter to Send Instant Replays of College Football
description: For the holidays this year, college football fans are getting the gift of portable instant replay.

title: Manohla Dargiss Top Films of 2012
description: Images of the critics top picks.

title: Journalists Punched by Israeli Officers After Fatal Shooting at West Bank Checkpoint
description: Two Palestinian journalists working for Reuters were punched, hit with rifle butts and forced to strip by Israeli soldiers on Wednesday as they tried to reach the scene of a fatal shooting at a West Bank checkpoint, the news agency reports. The soldiers then confiscated the crews camera and gas masks before letting off a tear-gas canister which forced one of the men to seek medical treatment.

title: The Best Albums of 2012
description: The New York Times critics Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Nate Chinen and Ben Ratliff discuss their pop music top-ten album lists of 2012.

title: Rices Withdrawal From Contention
description: After Susan E. Rice pulled her name from the race for secretary of state, The Times looks at her record and other possible nominees for the position.

title: Lopez Hopes to Play Friday Night
description: Nets center Brook Lopez said he is hopeful to return from a sprained right foot on Friday against Detroit, after missing the last seven games.

title: The 12.2.12 Issue
description: SUPERHERO OF THE SEA

title: Why I Keep the Dearly Departed in My Address Book
description: Heading into my golden years, I have one bad knee, two good daughters and 836 names in my iPhone address book. Of the latter, 246 are people I have not seen or spoken to in at least 10 years. Thirty-nine are a total mystery to me  I have no idea who they are.

title: Willie Nelson, the Silver-Headed Stranger
description: In your new book, Roll Me Up and Smoke Me When I Die, you write about enjoying bumblebee fights in Texas as a child. What is that exactly?  Abbott, where I grew up, is a small farm town, and you knew all the farmers. They would come in on weekends to do their shopping and talk about bumblebees nests that they had run into while they were out plowing their fields. They would tell us kids where the bumblebees were, and wed go out on Sunday afternoons and fight bumblebees.

title: Cat Custody
description: A neighbor recently posted on a neighborhood forum that after several years, her lost cat returned home. The cat was a kitten when it went astray. Naturally, the neighbors did the usual things you do when you lose a cat; searched endlessly, put food out and posted on community boards, electronic and otherwise. The family was naturally relieved when the cat returned. However, someone has clearly cared for the cat. It is healthy and has been neutered. But theres no indication of ownership. My neighbors dilemma is a question of obligation to the temporary family and whether she can take ownership of the cat. CRAIG FIELD, AUSTIN, TEX.

title: Let My Tebow Go
description: What will Tim Tebow be doing by the time you read this? Will he be leading the Jets to an improbable victory, perhaps even a miraculous playoff berth? Will he be publicly demanding a trade to somewhere like Jacksonville? Or will he be exactly where he was when we last saw him  injured and wasting away on the Jets bench, weathering nasty cheap shots from teammates, like the one who sneered to The Daily News: Were depending on miracles? You cant play that way?

title: Feast in a Day
description: Last month, Sam Sifton and I took up the job of cooking for 15 people at a friends home in Brooklyn. The idea was to feed and impress friends, family members and colleagues without driving ourselves nuts. Its possible. And to do so, we decided not to spend more than eight hours obsessing over, shopping for and preparing the meal. We bought all our ingredients in the morning and then cooked through the afternoon. Dinner was called for 6 p.m.

title: Who Made Those 3-D Glasses?
description: One morning in 1915, curiosity-seekers filed into the Astor Theater in New York for a new cinematic spectacle. As two film projectors rattled to life, the audience was immersed in a wonderland. Hills, valleys, houses, the figures on a country road, wrote Lynde Denig, a reporter who attended the screening, the effect is marvelously real.

title: The Sweet Spot | Music Sharing
description: Remember 8-track? A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about the various ways we find, and listen to, our favorite tunes  like Gangnam Style.

title: Examining the Hazards of Older Parenthood
description: Older parenthood, proposes Judith Shulevitz in The New Republic, will upend American society. Parenthood over the last century has undergone a change so simple yet so profound we are only beginning to grasp the enormity of its implications, she writes. In short, we have our children much later than we used to.

title: Salutes to the Pros, From a Winded Amateur
description: OH, how the arts love awards! Here at Classical Music World News Headquarters we issue our own at the end of random years. We do not give them cute anthropomorphic names (Bessie, Emmy, Tony); they have no monetary value, no statuette and, in fact, no real importance. But here they are anyway, a means of recalling some of the years highs and lows.

title: Risk Creeps Up in Long-Term Bonds
description: THE Federal Reserve Boards Open Market Committee this week gave the first hint of what would cause it to allow interest rates to rise. It promised to maintain low rates until the unemployment rate  at 7.7 percent last month  fell to 6.5 percent, so long as inflation also remained quiet.

title: The Sweet Spot: Dec. 14
description: Remember 8-track? A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about the more modern ways in which we find, and listen to, our favorite tunes  like Gangnam Style.

title: How to Cook a Feast in 8 Hours or Less
description: A timeline in photos.

title: This Look Wont Insult Her
description: LISA LAMPANELLI, 51, a former journalist, is best known for the insult comedy that has earned her the nickname the Queen of Mean. Ms. Lampanelli, who was born in Trumbull, Conn., now lives on the Upper West Side of Manhattan with her husband, Jimmy (Canno) Cannizzaro, her road manager. She is scheduled to perform at the Apollo Theater on Jan. 30.

title: Denise and Jeff Austin, Blessed With Enthusiasm
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: Travel Is Educational In a Year of the Move
description: THE links among dance, geography and social anthropology are complex and profound. Sooner or later much  by no means all  of the worlds best dance comes to New York; some of it even blooms brighter here. Yet dance grows in meaning when we see it within its culture. Two trips I made this year opened my eyes and mind in life-enhancing ways.

title: Sights in New York Like No Others
description: IN her terrific new book, A Choreographic Mind, Susan Rethorst discusses the difficulties of sticking to your artistic guns in the face of forces like the market, the feedback of colleagues and the ever-changing fashions of the field. How on earth, she asks, do you keep your compass?

title: Russia Opens New Inquiry Targeting an Activist
description: MOSCOW  The police opened a new criminal investigation on Friday against Aleksei Navalny, the street protest leader and anticorruption activist, who is already being questioned in two other cases.

title: Quirks of the Game: Should the N.F.L. Kill the Kickoff?
description: Talk about bad timing.

title: Making the Most Of Their Moments
description: THIS was the year of the dancer. Ingrained in my memory is a treasure chest of afterimages: the most vivid are Hee Seo, Nicole Mannarino and Thibault Lac. Ms. Seo, a newly promoted principal dancer at American Ballet Theater, is a dramatic ballerina of profound depth, as she proved with her savagely beautiful Tatiana in Onegin at the Metropolitan Opera. Ms. Mannarinos spellbinding performances in Sarah Michelsons dances at both the Whitney Biennial and at the Museum of Modern Art have cemented her as a cherished muse and, in turn, transported an experimental choreographers work to a new level. And Mr. Lac, a contemporary dancer based in Europe, moves like a slippery piece of silk. One of the great pleasures of this past year has been watching his lanky frame navigate the places where voguing meets postmodern dance in Trajal Harrells excellent series Twenty Looks or Paris Is Burning at the Judson Church.

title: Karl Roves Social Welfare Organization
description: From June 2010 until Dec. 2011, leading up to the presidential election season, Karl Roves Crossroads GPS spent $64.7 million, according to ProPublica. Of that money, a grand total of $1.4 million, or 2 percent, was spent on what Crossroads identified as research.

title: The Angel of Maryes Heights
description: All through the night of Dec. 13, 1862, the ambulance corps of the Unions Army of the Potomac labored to remove their wounded brethren from the killing grounds at Fredericksburg. Compared with earlier battles  especially the twin debacles at Bull Run  the stretcher-bearers and hospital stewards did an exemplary job.

title: Curtain Falls, But Operas Reverberate
description: AS I look back over the concerts, productions and developments that made an impact in 2012, two operas loom largest in my estimation. One, Einstein on the Beach, by Philip Glass and Robert Wilson, must have felt like the death and rebirth of the art form when it first appeared in 1976. (Hard for me to say, not having been there.) The other, Dog Days, by David T. Little and Royce Vavrek, received its premiere this year. Compared with Einstein it was defiantly traditional.

title: Worth Hearing And Rehearing
description: HERE are the performances that have stuck with me through the year:

title: Fat Dad: Hanukkah With My Grandmothers
description: When I lived in Chicago, Jewish holidays were spent either at my Grandma Beautys house or my Bubbe Marys house. My two grandmothers lived near each other on the North Side of Chicago. However, I saw my grandmother Beauty every weekend, but I would only see my grandmother Bubbe Mary, my fathers mother, on occasional holidays. While my two grandmothers had a lot in common  they were both amazing cooks  they were also very different.

title: Ancient Roots, Twisting Together in Easy Harmony
description: WE spent a good part of 2012 celebrating the bridge builders in music: institutions like Georg Soltis World Orchestra for Peace and Daniel Barenboims West-Eastern Divan, which bring together players from different cultures, or the Venezuelan Sistema, which narrows the gap between low income and high art. All worthy and good. But what drew my attention was the archaeological work of musicians who quietly reveal the common foundations and tangled roots among cultures that have been there all along.

title: Titans Outpaced by Little Guys
description: THE six years leading up to this one were blessed with an extraordinary bounty of video games. Every year brought new creations that expanded our sense of the mediums possibilities. Among them  and I could go with a score of different titles  were BioShock, Grand Theft Auto IV, Portal, Red Dead Redemption and Rock Band. The run of games since the release of the Xbox 360 in late 2005 (followed the next year by the PlayStation 3 and Nintendo Wii) has been so remarkable that sometimes it feels as if 2012 has broken the streak, that well-turned games like Borderlands 2, Dishonored and XCOM: Enemy Unknown dont quite belong in the same genre-expanding class as their predecessors.

title: Moments Taut, Tawdry or Unscripted
description: THE lure of the unexpected drew mass television audiences to the London Olympics and the presidential debates. But what keeps viewers returning to regular shows week after week (or hour after hour on an iPad) is a more delicate blend of familiarity and surprise. Its a balance that is easily upset by overblown expectations. And even some of the best shows of the year battled the weight of excessive appreciation:

title: Pleasures of Unexpected Programming
description: ADVENTUROUS programming has proved one of the most effective tools artists have to shake classical music out of its staid concert protocols. The Israeli pianist David Greilsammer has been particularly innovative at devising programs that juxtapose old and new works in dynamic ways. He showed this vividly in a solo recital at the Mostly Mozart Festival in August at the Kaplan Penthouse, part of the popular Little Night Music series of late-night programs. If the ambience was informal, the music making was exhilarating.

title: Still Going Strong: Detectives, Killers and Bill Moyers
description: 1. SHERLOCK (PBS) We get only three episodes of this BBC series a year, but each one packs an amazing amount of intelligence, mystery, action, brittle emotion and sheer entertainment into its 90 minutes. Benedict Cumberbatch and Martin Freeman, as the contemporary Holmes and Watson, give very different but perfectly complementary performances, and each is wonderful.

title: Violinist With Flag, Film With Diva, Allegory of Aging
description: HERE, in chronological order, are the 10 performances that excited me most this year:

title: Popcast: The Best Albums of 2012
description: This week, the critics Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Nate Chinen and Ben Ratliff emerge from seclusion, deliberation and rigorous inventory to discuss their pop music top-ten album lists of 2012.

title: Dubious Ideas, and Hybrids That Got Away
description: MOST year-end lists involving the arts try to impose order on an impossibly unwieldy subject or theme: the Most Memorable Broadway Performances among hundreds; the Best Indie Films That Nobody Saw among a countless number of indie films that nobody saw. But in the case of television this insistence on tidy systematization runs counter to what the medium has become; namely, the very definition of chaotic.

title: Mercedes-Benz Recalling 5,800 Vehicles for Fuel Leak
description: Mercedes-Benz is recalling about 5,800 vehicles because of a possible fuel leak, the automaker has told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Wild Horses Are Running Out of Room, On and Off Range
description: CAON CITY, Colo.  The herd of wild horses clopped cautiously toward the strangers in their pen. A chestnut mustang leaned in for a closer look, sniffing and snorting curiously. Another inched backward, her black eyes flashing with fear.

title: Dempsters Deal With Red Sox Should Interest Dickey
description: Just how much is R.A. Dickey, the Mets 38-year-old Cy Young Award-winning knuckleballer, worth?

title: A. O. Scotts Top Film Picks
description: Images from the critics top picks from the year.

title: Dec. 16  22
description: WHEN THE CLOCK  Christian Marclays universally adored video installation  was playing at Lincoln Center this past summer, 18,000 people came to see it. But those who missed it have another chance. From Friday through Jan. 21 it will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art. The 24-hour montage of clips from the last hundred years of movies and television that depict particular minutes in the day, synchronized with the moment they are shown, has become one of those classics that movie buffs relish seeing over and over again.

title: A Sleepy Cosette and a Hungover Fantine
description: Musical interludes have been a big theme this week, as studios and consultants pull out all the stops before the cutoff date for razzle-dazzling voters, on Jan. 10, when the Oscar nominees are revealed.

title: Morgan Stanley Names New Regional Chiefs for Mergers Unit
description: Morgan Stanley named new heads of mergers and acquisitions for the Americas and for Europe on Friday after a management reshuffling brought on by the impending departure of a senior deal maker, Paul Taubman.

title: On Our Radar: Atlantic Panel Limits Catch of Crucial Fish
description: In a compromise, a regulatory panel approves a 20 percent cut in the annual harvest of the menhaden, a vital fish in the mid-Atlantic food chain. [The Baltimore Sun]

title: ESPN Suspends Commentator Over Racial Comments About Quarterback
description: ESPN announced on Friday that it had suspended Rob Parker, a commentator on the networks program First Take, because of his racially oriented comments about the rookie quarterback for the Washington Redskins, Robert Griffin III.

title: This Duck Doesnt Need a Label on It
description: IF the word stew conjures up less-than-positive memories, perhaps you should consider saying braise instead. It is really just a question of semantics, but your dining companions may react differently if you tell them there are red-wine braised duck legs on the menu, rather than calling the dish duck stew.

title: Murder Charges Upgraded in Florida Killing of Youth
description: The man accused of shooting and killing a Jacksonville, Fla., youth after an argument over loud music is now being charged with first-degree murder.

title: The Giving Spree | Olivier Theyskens
description: Who: The designer for Theory and Theyskens Theory, Olivier Theyskens, who turned the city of New York into our signature initial for Ts spring mens issue.

title: Mining Scandal for Ratings
description: On the ABC drama Scandal, Kerry Washington plays Olivia Pope, the best consultant in Washington, but even that character would have to be impressed with the marketing savvy that is pushing the series to new heights in the ratings.

title: Rialto Bridge in Venice to Be Restored With Corporate Money
description: ROME  The city of Venice announced Friday that the fashion entrepreneur Renzo Rosso, the founder of the OTB holding company  whose brands include Diesel, Viktor & Rolf and Martin Margiela  had donated 5 million euros (about $6.5 million) through the company to restore the Rialto Bridge in the city.

title: The Debt Ceiling, Then and Now
description: The Timess Annie Lowrey reports on how the 2011 debt ceiling negotiations have informed the current back-and-forth.

title: The Slaughter of Schoolchildren
description: It is a sad reflection of the human capacity for violence that Wikipedia has a sub-category, under rampage killers, for rampage killers: school massacres. David Brooks July column on rampage killings and a related piece by the psychiatrist David Archer in Psychology Today, provide valuable data and insights on such killings, if little comfort on a very dark day.

title: For Student Borrowers, Relief Now May Mean a Big Tax Bill Later
description: Those breathing a sigh of relief that their student loan payments are now in line with their income may want to re-examine the rules that set the payment in the first place. There could be a tax time bomb looming, slowly ticking away. And defusing it is not a big part of the policy discussion in Washington at the moment.

title: Should You Have to Pay Taxes on Forgiven Student Loan Debt?
description: I generally try to stay away from policy debates in my work, but this weekends Your Money column begs a tax policy question that will probably affect millions of people someday: If youre enrolled in the income-based repayment program, where any remaining federal student loan debt gets forgiven after a certain number of years, should you have to pay income taxes on the loan balance that the government dismisses?

title: Spurs Mystery: Where Is Matt Bonner?
description: Ever since the San Antonio Spurs and Coach Gregg Popovich decided to go all-in on a fast-tempo offense that emphasizes the 3-pointer, the offense has hummed along at incredible efficiency. The one clinking noise ratting around in the otherwise smooth offensive machine has been the dilemma of what to do with the second front court spot. That is, the one not occupied by future hall of famer Tim Duncan.

title: Q&A: Moving Playlists to the iPod in iTunes 11
description: Q.

title: Trading Up Can Be Hard to Do
description: EVEN with a hefty down payment, a perfect credit score and a top-notch broker, many New Yorkers who want to move to bigger and better apartments are having no luck. Stymied by a scarcity of listings and a tight credit market, even the most qualified buyers are being outbid, turned down for loans or simply cant find what theyre looking for. As a result they are being forced to sit on the sidelines.

title: A Young Star, Team Player
description: When you are a young pianist appearing with a given orchestra for the first time, you dont want to seem presumptuous. You want to be a team player, literally.

title: The Language of Uptalk
description: THE BIG PROFILEBy Dave Itzkoff

title: Pews Tirelessly Restored, and an Immigrant Redeemed
description: On a Sunday morning last summer, Fabian Cervantes walked through the doors of Our Lady of Refuge, the Roman Catholic church in Brooklyn that he had lost hope of ever seeing again. His arms were pale from seven months in jail. His clothes hung limply because he had lost 25 pounds. His sallow eyes attested to scores of sleepless nights.

title: Message, if Murky, From U.S. to the World
description: DUBAI

title: Carney Addresses School Shooting During White House Briefing
description: For the last week, the White House daily briefing has been consumed by often prosaic questions about the budget talks between President Obama and Republicans on Capitol Hill.

title: Joy Behars Rooms With a View
description: Co-owner: Joy BeharDomain: Upper West Side apartment

title: Render That Duck Fat
description: For the braise featured in this weeks City Kitchen column, I bought four large, meaty Muscovy duck legs, weighing about a pound apiece. They were untrimmed, which meant they came with a generous coating of fat.

title: The Gift Tax and Other Tax Worries
description: With the tax talks in Washington seemingly at an impasse, no one knows for sure what will happen to the now-generous gift tax exemption. But the tax lawyers and advisers Paul Sullivan spoke to for his Wealth Matters column this week said the wealthy have been scrambling in recent weeks to make gifts before the exemption  now at $5.12 million a person  expires at the end of the year.

title: A Contrarian Spin on the Next Big Climate Report
description: Some Green readers have probably heard by now that a draft of the next big United Nations report on climate change has leaked.

title: Judge Dismisses Case Against Harlem Wizards
description: The Harlem Ambassadors and Harlem Wizards, two of the best-known show basketball teams in the country, have at least one thing in common: They both claim to play a Harlem brand of basketball.

title: Simpler Ways to Enjoy the Holidays
description: Readers of Booming and of Real Simple recently submitted questions to Kristin van Ogtrop, the managing editor of Real Simple, about ways to simplify life this holiday season. Ms. van Ogtrop, who has spent her career at magazines, also oversees Adventures in Chaos, a blog where she writes about life as a working mother. She is author of Just Let Me Lie Down: Necessary Terms for the Half-Insane Working Mom, published by Little Brown in 2010.

title: Should Students Be Trained for School Shootings?
description: The images of the children leaving their elementary school in Newtown, Conn., after the shootings at Sandy Hook Elementary School leave me with the same chill of disbelief that I think all of us share. They brought to mind, too, a program that Nancy Rappaport, associate professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School and director of school-based programs for the Cambridge Health Alliance, drew to my attention last week: ALICE, for alert, lockdown, inform, counter, evacuate.

title: U.S. Open Officially Changes Schedule
description: The United States Tennis Association made official the schedule change that has been discussed for months: moving the United States Open mens singles final to Monday and the womens final to Sunday, ending the Super Saturday format that featured the mens semifinals and womens final on the same day.

title: Film Based on Rushdie Novel Survives Indias Censors
description: A movie adaptation of Salman Rushdies 1980 novel, Midnights Children,  whose magical-realist exploration of the partition of British India was highly praised but also generated a libel suit by Indira Gandhi that Mr. Rushdie lost  will be shown in India without any cuts from the countrys film review board, the BBC reported.

title: The Case of Cinematic Dj Vu
description: Movies titled Safe, The Deep Blue Sea and Bully were all released in 2012  and in 1995, 1999 and 2001, respectively. This kind of cinematic dj vu, involving identical or near-identical titles, has happened before: whether with Crash (1996 and 2004) or Kicking and Screaming (the 1995 Noah Baumbach ode to slackers and the 2005 Will Ferrell ode to soccer dads). But the past year seemed especially packed with new movies recycling old names.

title: Obama on Connecticut School Shooting
description: President Obama delivers an emotional statement on the massacre at an elementary school in Newtown, Conn.

title: Keeping It Cool and Familiar, Even When Life Gets Messiest, in Love and War
description: The contemporary repertory company Les Ballets Jazz de Montral finally made it to New York, opening at the Joyce Theater on Thursday night after its November engagement was canceled in the wake of Hurricane Sandy. It was an evening of pomp: Premier Pauline Marois of Quebec attended, flanked by an entourage and a security detail. Her announced presence drew applause, and eventually the dancers received their own rousing ovation.

title: Tips for Talking to Children About the Shooting
description: First, find out what they have heard.

title: Death in Connecticut
description: Each slaughter of innocents seems to get more appalling. A high school. A college campus. A movie theater. People meeting their congresswoman. A shopping mall in Oregon, just this Tuesday. On Friday, an elementary school classroom.

title: Met Opera Raises $100 Million in Bond Sale
description: The Metropolitan Opera successfully sold $100 million worth of taxable bonds on Thursday, according to The Wall Street Journal, and plans to use about two-thirds of the proceeds to pay off a bank loan and to pay down a line of credit. The rest of the money will go toward operating expenses and renovations, said Peter Gelb, the Mets general manager.

title: German Lawmakers Seek to Ban Far-Right Party
description: BERLIN  Nearly a decade after the German government embarrassingly failed in an attempt to ban the countrys leading extreme-right political party, the upper house of Parliament on Friday voted overwhelmingly to launch a new effort to have the National Democratic Party deemed unconstitutional.

title: Week in Review: Rate-Rigging Scandal Keeps Growing
description: The rate inquiry escalated. | Chinese companies shopped abroad. | The Deal Professor called for the S.E.C. to re-examine old regulations. | DealBooks special section examined business between worlds. | HSBC agreed to pay nearly $2 billion to settle charges over money laundering. | Mongolias investment prospects dimmed. | The Treasury Department sold its A.I.G. shares. | Amgen said it would buy a firm working on gene links to diseases.

title: Q & A
description: Rules for Checking Buyers Finances

title: A Smart Breakaway for Big East Basketball Schools
description: A variety of reports suggest that the seven Big East schools that do not compete in high-level football may split off to form their own basketball-centric athletic conference.

title: Pictures of the Day: Connecticut and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Connecticut, Egypt, North Korea and West Bank.

title: Lots of Latkes
description: Here at the Well blog we have learned not to mess with the latke. Readers love the traditional dish just as it is. But as Martha Rose Shulman discovered in this weeks Recipes for Health, it can also be exciting to experiment with the recipe and develop new flavors so that latkes can be enjoyed every day of the year.

title: D.J.s Hiding After Threats Over Prank, Report Says
description: LONDON  The repercussions from last weeks suicide of the nurse who answered a prank telephone call at the hospital treating the pregnant Duchess of Cambridge were felt again on Friday with reports that the D.J.s who made the call had received so many threats that they had been forced into hiding.

title: Pogues 12 Days of Gadgets: Tagg Pet Tracker
description: Silent nightall is calm, all is bright because your dog ran away!

title: Doha: Weirdly Tame and Dispirited
description: The annual United Nations climate change negotiations this year in Doha, which wrapped up on Dec. 8, seemed weirdly tame and dispirited. There was minimal press coverage and, as Jennifer Haverkamp of the Environmental Defense Fund observed, there were no people in polar bear suits, no passionate youth doing skits, no melting ice sculpturesno real infusion of energy. There was also no solid agreement on how to confront the threat of global warming by slowing the seemingly inexorable rise of heat-trapping emissions or by helping poor nations mitigate the inevitable damage or, preferably, both.That was not weird. These conferences have not produced a binding document since the Kyoto Protocol of 1997, which was itself flawed because it asked nothing of big developing nations, and, partly for that reason, was never ratified by the United States Congress.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Facebook Gift Swap and Social 2nd Thoughts
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $11.5 Million
description: A well-preserved brick town house in the West Village that was built for a sea captain in 1842 and had been owned since 1987 by the publishing magnate Timothy C. Forbes, a son of Malcolm S. Forbes, sold for $11.5 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: The Week in New York Region Pictures, Dec. 14
description: Subjects include the auction of a piano from Casablanca, a settlement in the Dominique Strauss-Kahn case and a peek behind the scenes at The Nutcracker.

title: A Wedding Date Thats a Cinch to Remember
description: KATE VAL and Gleb Bukin fell in love quickly and deeply.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Dec. 14
description: Events from this week included performances by Mick Jagger, the New York City Ballet and Circus Oz.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Dec. 14
description: More Photographs

title: Newtown, Conn., and Guns in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinas Communist Party Chief Acts to Bolster Military
