Many headed for relative safety in Lebanon, a day after Syrian forces attacked that neighborhood with airstrikes for the first time in the civil war.

title: Vain Glorious | Elena Rubin Skincare
description: Elena Rubin had been working as a Wall Street analyst for several years before she admitted to herself that she was miserable. Not only did she sit in the bath and cry every night but her high-powered career had saddled her with autoimmune disorders and skin problems. After successfully seeking holistic treatment, she reassessed her life. I came to the conclusion that all I wanted to do was spend time at the spa, she says. So I decided to open one. Thanks to New York State law, which requires that at least one owner of a spa have a cosmetology license, Rubin enrolled in beauty school, which she attended with the same sort of dedication she had given to her Harvard M.B.A. The teachers really liked me, she says wryly. I never missed a class and I was all about critical thinking and scientifically backed facts.

title: Risks: Coffee Linked to Fewer Oral Cancer Deaths
description: A large study has found that drinking coffee is associated with a reduced risk of death from oral cancer.

title: The Automat May Be Long Gone, But Its Recipes Are in Demand
description: It is a century since the first Automat opened in New York, and 21 years since the chain closed in Manhattan, but people still crave the recipes for its food served up from little glass doors at the drop of a few coins.

title: Oscar Voters, the Polls Are Open
description: The countdown clock has officially started for the 282 films that are eligible for the Academy Awards. Voting begins today, weeks earlier than normal, a schedule that has thrown the entire awards calendar into overdrive, as pundits and consultants do their best to spin for anyone with even a glimmer of hope for a nomination. (For your consideration: best production assistant! Best directors niece who interns in the art department! Best anyone that had anything to do with a movie, at all, ever!)

title: Americas Gun Stockpile
description: In 1993 Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan argued that gun control was near pointless. Even a strict and comprehensive ban on the sale of new guns would do nothing to diminish the existing supply, which he estimated would last 200 years. These mostly simple machines last forever, Mr. Moynihan said.

title: How Did Your Childrens School Handle the Newtown Shootings?
description: As our children begin to come home from their school days, many may be describing how their schools did, or didnt, address the tragedy in Newtown, Conn. A number of parents have forwarded to me their schools stated plans. In one Catholic school, the principal attended morning meetings for the younger grades in case of questions (there werent any), while the older grades (fifth and up) held a vigil for peace.

title: When Anxiety Interrupts a Childs Life
description: Is it any wonder so many children are anxious? As the recent horror in Connecticut demonstrates, children today may be confronted with unthinkable realities, events that their parents and grandparents could never have conceived.

title: After Tragedy, Partisanship May Cool a Bit
description: WASHINGTON  To the extent that Americans have diverted their attention since Friday from the horror in Connecticut toward their capital, it has been to wonder whether the school shooting would provoke the first serious gun control debate in years. But the tragedy could have an impact on another crucial legislative issue: the contest over taxes and spending.

title: G.E. Said to Be Close to Buying Avio for $4 Billion
description: General Electric is expected to strike a deal to buy the Italian aerospace company Avio for $4 billion or more, in a bid to bolster its commercial jet engine business.

title: As Europe Presses Google on Antitrust, U.S. Backs Away
description: BRUSSELS  Google seems on its way to coming through a major antitrust investigation in the United States essentially unscathed. But the outlook is not as bright for Google here, as the European Unions top antitrust regulator prepares to meet on Tuesday with Eric E. Schmidt, Googles executive chairman.

title: Participant Media Plans Its Own Cable Channel
description: Participant Media, the production company behind films like An Inconvenient Truth, Food, Inc. and Waiting for Superman, said Monday that it planned to start a cable channel of its own by combining the assets of two obscure channels, the Documentary Channel and Halogen TV.

title: Pogues 12 Days of Gadgets: Prank Packs
description: Joy to the world  its Day 8 of Pogues 12 Days of Gadgets! (All offbeat tech products, all under $100.)

title: Poland Finds Its Not Immune to Euro Crisis
description: WARSAW  The Fiat factory in Tychy, Poland, has long been considered one of the most productive auto plants in Europe, often singled out for praise by the Italian companys demanding chief executive, Sergio Marchionne.

title: Changing Chinas Growth Model
description: Chinas Central Economic Work Conference concluded Sunday. The annual meeting sets economic goals for the year ahead and usually includes a grab bag of policy prescriptions.

title: An Odometer Moment on a Warming Planet
description: For those who might be keeping score, we just passed the 333rd consecutive month of global temperatures above the 20th-century average.

title: For Jets Offense Built for Run After Run, Powell Provides a Second Wind
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets have slogged into what Tony Sparano, their first-year offensive coordinator, calls the deep end of the pool there, schedule-wise, in which teams desperately seek bursts of energy to reach the wall at the other side.

title: Debut Poetry Collection Coming From James Franco
description: Perhaps the only way that James Franco could surprise us now with his unpredictable creative pursuits is if he simply chucked them all to spend time splitting rocks at his local quarry. And yet Mr. Franco, the artist, author and actor (whose films include Milk and 127 Hours), continues to add to his eclectic rsum, announcing plans on Monday to publish his first book of poetry.

title: Really? Losing Sleep Reduces Your Pain Tolerance
description: THE FACTS

title: How Social Media Affect the News
description: TimesCast Media+Tech: Three days after the shootings at a Connecticut elementary school, Jeff Jarvis and Neda Soltani talk about the effect of social media on the news cycle.

title: Bangladesh Finds Gross Negligence in Factory Fire
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  Criminal charges for unpardonable negligence should be brought against the owner of the Bangladesh garment factory where a fire killed 112 people last month, according to a preliminary report from a government inquiry submitted Monday.

title: Participant Media Plans New Cable Channel
description: Participant Media, the production company behind films like An Inconvenient Truth, Food, Inc. and Waiting for Superman, said on Monday that it planned to start a cable channel of its own by combining the assets of two obscure channels, The Documentary Channel and Halogen TV.

title: Recipe for Resentment: Claims of Running Prowess
description: From the moment it appeared online last month, an editorial in the journal Heart became a Rorschach test for opinions about runners.

title: TimesCast Media+Tech: Mistaken Identity in Breaking News
description: Three days after the shootings at a Connecticut elementary school, Jeff Jarvis and Neda Soltani talk about the effect of social media on the news cycle.

title: Would You Leave Your Country Over Taxes?
description: Grard Depardieu, one of the most recognizable faces of French cinema, after more than forty years playing French historical figures, has bought a new house in Belgium, for 800,000 according to Le Monde, or a little more than $1 million. Its only 2 kilometers, a little less than a mile and a quarter, over the border from his beloved France.

title: Hard Times in Spain Force Feuding Couples to Delay Divorce
description: SABADELL, Spain  Esther Fernndez, 45, was desperate for a divorce. A hairdresser, she had fallen in love with another man.

title: Massachusetts Fines Morgan Stanley Over Facebook I.P.O.
description: 10:48 a.m. | Updated Morgan Stanley is paying for its role in the troubled stock market debut of Facebook.

title: Depardieus Cri de Coeur, Translated into English
description: Pathetic. Pathetic, you say? It is, indeed, pathetic.

title: Studying Ethical Questions as the Brains Black Box Is Unlocked
description: In a world of proliferating professions, S. Matthew Liao has a singular title: neuroethicist. Dr. Liao, 40, the director of the bioethics program at New York University, deploys the tools of philosophy, history, psychology, religion and ethics to understand the impact of neuroscientific breakthroughs.

title: Beyond the Kiss, Mistletoe Helps Feed Forests, Study Suggests
description: For years, mistletoe has suffered from a split reputation: either the decorative prelude to a sweet Christmas kiss or the tree-killing parasite that must be mercilessly excised for the good of the forests.

title: Photo Replay: Dec. 17
description: A view of the day in sports, including Santa at the slalom, Jeremy Lins return to New York and a hat trick in the English Premier League.

title: Zinc Found Effective Against Jellyfish Venom
description: Years ago, Angel Yanagihara had a painful encounter with Hawaiian box jellyfish while swimming in Waikiki. So began a quest to identify the toxins in the creatures venom and to develop a possible remedy.

title: The Case For More Cops
description: Theres nothing inherently wrong with politicizing tragedies; indeed, many tragedies cry out for a political response. But human nature being what it is, the politicking and policymaking that happens amid grief and outrage tends to be  well, problematic would be the kindest way of putting it.

title: Girding for Zombies
description: Thank goodness well all be wiped out by the Maya doomsday by weeks end. That will spare us the discomfort of having to go through the impending zombie apocalypse.

title: Fossils of New Species Discovered in England
description: A tiny, fossilized crustacean that lived 425 million years ago has been discovered, remarkably intact, in a rock formation in Herefordshire, England. Paleontologists say it represents a new genus and species, belonging to a class of shrimplike marine creatures called ostracods.

title: Dinner-Party Tips From Famous People!
description: Sundays issue included a package by Mark Bittman and Sam Sifton on how to make a feast in 8 hours. But you dont have to take their word for it. Here are more dinner-party tips, from people who will probably never invite you to their dinner parties, as told to Spencer Bailey.

title: The Giving Spree | Matt Abramcyk
description: Who: Matt Abramcyk, a co-owner of Tinys and Super Linda in TriBeCa, who invited T to a brunch party he and his wife, Nadine Ferber, hosted this summer.

title: Urban Roots
description: Q. When large deciduous trees were felled intact by recent storms, I was surprised to see only a small disk of surface roots and a thin plate of soil. What happened to the root balls and deep taproots?

title: What Instagrams New Terms of Service Mean for You
description: Instagram released an updated version of its privacy policy and terms of service on Monday, and they include lengthy stipulations on how photographs uploaded by users may be used by Instagram and its parent company, Facebook.

title: A Christmas Story Climbs the Broadway Box Office Charts
description: The new Broadway musical A Christmas Story, based on the 1983 movie, jumped at the box office to become the fourth-most-popular Broadway show last week, behind the traditional blockbusters Wicked, The Lion King and The Book of Mormon, according to ticket sale data released on Monday. Its $1,377,131 gross put A Christmas Story ahead of two shows that beat it the prior week  the Al Pacino-led Glengarry Glen Ross and the super-hero spectacle Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark. The high gross for Christmas Story was partly the result of its producers adding a ninth performance last week; most other shows had only the usual eight.

title: Scroogewala, a Deli Worker, Looks for Love in New Land
description: He works in a deli. She wants to be a writer like Jhumpa Lahiri. Hes an immigrant from Mumbai. Shes what he calls an ABCD  American-born confused desi (or Indian). When they meet, sparks dont fly. Still, Bumbug the Musical would have us believe theyre in love.

title: Facebook and Google Benefit From Mobile Ad Surge
description: Making big money from advertisements on a small screen has been a challenge for many media companies, including Facebook and Google. But mobile ad spending grew significantly this past year, according to a new report.

title: Safety: Beware Walking and Texting
description: People who cross the street while using mobile devices are dangerously distracted from the task at hand: getting across quickly and safely.

title: An Evening of Haydn and Bartok and an Extra Viola
description: The opening of the third-movement Adagio in Mozarts String Quintet in G minor (K. 516) is a particularly lovely moment, featuring a somber melody that evolves into a potent dialogue. The Brentano String Quartet played it beautifully during its concert on Saturday evening in the huge auditorium at the High School of Fashion Industries.

title: 2 Former Hedge Fund Managers Found Guilty in Insider Trading Case
description: Two former hedge fund managers were found guilty on Monday of fraud and conspiracy, the latest convictions in the governments campaign to eliminate illegal conduct on Wall Street trading floors.

title: Rumors of a Deal
description: It sounds as if Ezra Klein is hearing more or less the same things Im hearing: Republicans willing to give up a lot more on tax rates, although not fully undoing the Bush tax cuts in the 250-400 range; additional tax hikes via deduction limits in a form that hits the wealthy, not the upper middle class (28 percent and all that); unemployment extension and infrastructure spending; but chained CPI for Social Security, which is a benefit cut.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Afghanistan, Iraq, Egypt and Connecticut.

title: The Songs Left Behind
description: The Mexican-American singer Jenni Rivera died on Dec. 9 in a plane crash, two days before the release of her new compilation album La Misma Gran Seora. Obviously, the album was never intended as a valedictory.

title: A Quest for Speedier and Smarter Airport Security
description: As 15 million people in the United States head to airports this holiday season  slightly fewer than last year  some travelers will find welcome changes to security screening procedures.

title: Children Can Usually Recover From Emotional Trauma
description: Perhaps the most remarkable part of her story is that today she sleeps just fine.

title: Looking for a Taxi? Try Enlisting Some Angels
description: At the end of the Manhattan Youth Ballets Knickerbocker Suite six tiny angels pull a 2-D yellow cab onto the stage, and the ballets young hero and heroine, who have discovered love and adventure in New York (at least in the heroines dream), prepare to depart in it. At the end of the Pennsylvania Ballet production of George Balanchines The Nutcracker the young hero and heroine leave the Kingdom of Sweets not in the flying sleigh seen in New York City Ballets staging of the same Balanchine classic, but in a flying sailboat, a tiny yacht just made for two, which lifts off into the air.

title: The Grimms Catalog, Revisited and Told Anew
description: Philip Pullman, a writer known for his originality and command of suspense, has written a new book almost entirely devoid of either. That hardly sounds like praise  but suspense and originality are not the only literary virtues. Mr. Pullmans Fairy Tales From the Brothers Grimm transports us to the opposite pole of storytelling pleasure: the domain of the fixed, the communal and the familiar.

title: This Is America Now
description: Anyone who has seen Ayad Akhtars drama Disgraced, at the Claire Tow Theater at Lincoln Center knows the Big Scene: an explosive dinner party featuring a rainbow of character types  a Muslim, a white woman, a Jewish man, his African-American wife  whose verbal combat can make even starving audience members lose their appetite. At the center of the action is Aasif Mandvi as Amir, a successful Pakistani-American lawyer whose ethnic background has suddenly caused problems at work.

title: Looking Up at the New Whitney
description: The final beam was lofted into place on Monday atop the Renzo Piano-designed building in the meatpacking district that will serve as the new home of the Whitney Museum. The museum is leaving the Upper East Side for the downtown location in 2015. The top of the structure included an American flag, which was flown at half-staff to honor the victims of the Newtown, Conn., school shooting.

title: Intrepid on the Set, but Rattled by Frail Planes
description: WHEN I was a teenager, I was a competitive martial artist. I participated in a lot of tournaments, so flying isnt new to me. After serving in the Marines from 1989 to 1994, I moved to Vancouver and joined a martial arts school.

title: How a Former Landfill Helped Absorb Hurricanes Surge
description: I encourage you to read Michael Kimmelmans post on the ArtsBeat blog about how the former Fresh Kills Landfill helped limit flood damage in Staten Island when the remains of Hurricane Sandy struck the region. Heres the video report, a blog excerpt and link to the rest:

title: Efficient Ceramic Indoor Stoves Fail to Reduce Risk of Pneumonia in Children
description: Small ceramic indoor stoves, such as those sold by women in AIDS self-help groups in Africa, do save fuel and cut down on eye-irritating smoke, a new study has found  but they do not save children from pneumonia.

title: By Any Means Necessary
description: There is a crucial scene in Zero Dark Thirty  Kathryn Bigelows brilliantly directed fictionalized account about the search for Osama bin Laden  in which three Central Intelligence Agency officers stop talking and look at a television. On the screen Barack Obama is speaking with a correspondent on 60 Minutes. Its Nov. 16, 2008. I have said repeatedly, Mr. Obama asserts, that America doesnt torture. The three look at the screen without a word, and then Ms. Bigelow cuts to a close-up of one, Maya (Jessica Chastain). The analysts face is a blank. This is, Mr. Obama continues, part of an effort to regain Americas moral stature in the world.

title: Well, Everyone Has to Pay Taxes
description: It should come as no surprise to any New Yorker that Dunkin Donuts and the Subway sandwich chains have continued to spread throughout the city. But Liberty Tax Service?

title: A Changed Fire Island
description: Hurricane Sandy reshaped beaches and dunes on Fire Island.

title: In Islands Shifted Sands, Signs of a Hurricanes Power
description: FIRE ISLAND, N.Y.  Starting at the waters edge, B. J. Reynolds had rolled his surveying pole about 200 feet inland across the beach, the GPS receiver on top producing continuous elevation data that was recorded in a computer in his backpack.

title: In Tappan Zee Replacement, Location Adds to the Cost
description: If this were a docudrama, it might be called A Bridge Too Far. If it were a television game show, it would be The $4 Billion Question. Instead, its a timely real-life, stranger-than-fiction answer to a decades-old anomaly: Why did New York State build the Tappan Zee Bridge at one of the wider points on the Hudson River?

title: No Big Hits, but Bookshops Say Theyre Thriving
description: Last year, there was a clear winner among books for the holiday gift of choice: Steve Jobs, by Walter Isaacson. This year, despite a lineup of offerings from literary heavyweights, many of whom have commanded strong sales in the past, there has not been a breakout hit for the holiday season, booksellers say.

title: Apatow, Mann & Rudd: Bennifer Theory
description: Part 4: The director and actors discuss what its like to work professionally with family.

title: Apatow, Mann & Rudd: American Boy
description: Part 10: Judd Apatow explains where the idea for The 40-Year-Old Virgin came from.

title: Apatow, Mann & Rudd: Gern Blanston
description: Part 14: Judd Apatow reveals his favorite Freaks and Geeks character.

title: Apatow, Mann & Rudd: Tom Petty Box Set
description: Part 3: The director and actors discuss what This Is 40 gets right in its portrayal of marriage.

title: Apatow, Mann & Rudd: Rhoda and Frasier
description: Part 7: Judd Apatow talks about why he wanted to revisit the characters of Pete and Debbie from Knocked Up.

title: Apatow, Mann & Rudd: Girl Island
description: Part 6: The director and actors reflect on the most challenging thing about being in a relationship.

title: TimesTalks | Apatow, Mann, Rudd: Preview
description: The director and actors talk about their film This Is 40, and explore their family lives on screen and off.

title: Apatow, Mann & Rudd: Respectfully Tense
description: Part 12: Judd Apatow and Leslie Mann talk about bringing their personal fights as a couple to the set.

title: Apatow, Mann & Rudd: Boring People
description: Part 8: The director and actors reflect on how having children changes marriage, and talk about how being creative professionals affects their style of parenting.

title: Apatow, Mann & Rudd: Intro
description: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the writer and director Judd Apatow and the actors Leslie Mann and Paul Rudd.

title: Apatow, Mann & Rudd: What Is This?
description: Part 9: Paul Rudd talks about shooting a challenging scene in This Is 40.

title: Apatow, Mann & Rudd: A Fort
description: Part 5: Judd Apatow reflects on directing his daughters, and explains why his movies keep returning to the theme of growing up.

title: Apatow, Mann & Rudd: Fart Snobs
description: Part 11: Judd Apatow describes his process of using improvisation to refine and guide a scripted scene as he shoots it.

title: Apatow, Mann & Rudd: Poison Cupcakes
description: Part 13: Judd Apatow explains why its a bad idea to shoot scenes under the influence.

title: Apatow, Mann & Rudd: Fat Rudd
description: Part 2: Judd Apatow explains why he always asks Paul Rudd to gain weight for his films.

title: Grapefruit Is a Culprit in More Drug Reactions
description: The patient didnt overdose on medication. She overdosed on grapefruit juice.

title: Wal-Mart Comes to Teotihuacn
description: A New York Times investigation found that Wal-Mart paid bribes as it sought to build in the shadow of one of Mexicos most revered cultural landmarks, the pyramids of Teotihuacn.

title: The Mommy Penalty, Around the World
description: Around the developed world, women earn less than men by a sizable margin: as of 2010, about 16 percent less when employed in similar full-time jobs. Women with children, though, experience a far larger wage gap, a phenomenon known as the mommy penalty.

title: In Gun Debate, a Misguided Focus on Mental Illness
description: In the wake of the terrible shooting at an elementary school in Newtown, Conn., national attention has turned again to the complex links between violence, mental illness and gun control.

title: SpongeBob Game Removed From App Store After Complaints
description: SpongeBob Diner Dash, a free game app for children featuring the popular yellow cartoon character loved by millions of youngsters, disappeared from the Apple App Store on Monday after an advocacy group complained that the app violated federal privacy protections for children online.

title: Ancient Bones That Tell a Story of Compassion
description: While it is a painful truism that brutality and violence are at least as old as humanity, so, it seems, is caring for the sick and disabled.

title: How to Use the Rule (or Suggestion) of Thirds in Photos
description: Bryan Peterson, photographer and author, doesnt like to stifle creativity. So in his new book, Understanding Composition, when he describes the rule of thirds, a classic composition strategy, he prefers to call it the suggestion of thirds.

title: Is the New T-Mobile Pricing a Good Deal?
description: T-Mobile has said it will start selling Apple products in 2013, but will stop underwriting the cost of phones with its contracts. That most likely means paying the full $650 for an iPhone.

title: Scientists See Promise for People and Nature in Peak Farmland
description: Jesse H. Ausubel of Rockefeller University has long been one of my core go to analysts of global resource issues and trends.

title: Federal Initiative Aims to Raise Number of Minority Scientists
description: Few blacks enter biomedical research, and those who do often encounter obstacles in their career paths.

title: Infiniti Plans to Q Up Its Nomenclature
description: New traffic alert on Sesame Street!: Infiniti automobiles are now brought to you by the letter Q.

title: Daniel Inouye, Hawaiis Quiet Voice of Conscience in Senate, Dies at 88
description: Senator Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii, who went to Washington at the birth of his state in 1959, dominated public life in the Hawaiian islands for more than 50 years and became a quiet voice of national conscience during the Watergate scandal and the Iran-contra affair, died on Monday in Bethesda, Md. He was 88.

title: 5 Rare Turtle Hatchlings Progressing at Healthy, Slow Pace
description: The Bronx Zoo has taken a slow and steady step toward victory in a race to save a gravely endangered turtle from extinction.

title: Poll Conducted After Shooting Shows More Support for Stricter Gun Laws
description: A CBS News poll conducted in the aftermath of the shootings at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., finds a significant increase in the number of Americans supporting stricter gun control laws.

title: Journal Offers Dose of Fun for Holiday
description: LONDON  Dutch and Norwegian scientists say they have solved a glowing mystery: why Rudolph the reindeers nose is red.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Pinterest Apocalypse and Tornado Energy
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Uniteds Top Flier of 2012 Has Eye on Global Title
description: LIKE many frequent fliers, Tom Stuker is reflecting on his past year of accumulating miles in the air. Unlike many of us, he reflects on the fact that as of last week he had flown more than a million miles so far in 2012, all on United Airlines.

title: Wal-Mart and the Pyramids
description: In 2004, Wal-Mart de Mexico built a supermarket within a mile of the pyramids of Teotihuacn, an important cultural landmark in Mexico. Some residents, upset with Wal-Marts proximity to the pyramids, staged hunger strikes and blocked construction sites in protest.

title: A Leader in Protests Against Wal-Mart
description: When Wal-Mart de Mexico began building near the pyramids of Teotihuacan, Emma Ortega, a spiritual healer, lead hunger strikes, blockades, and protest marches to stop the project.

title: Safety Worry Leads to End of a Popular Toy Magnet
description: The maker of the magnetic toys called Buckyballs announced on Monday that it would stop selling them this week because of a legal and public relations dispute with federal regulators.

title: Dont Blame Autism for Newtown
description: LAST Wednesday night I listened to Andrew Solomon, the author of the extraordinary new book Far From the Tree, talk about the frequency of filicide in families affected by autism. Two days later, I watched the news media attempt to explain a matricide and a horrific mass murder in terms of the killers supposed autism.

title: What Drives Suicidal Mass Killers
description: Tuscaloosa, Ala.

title: Mining Executive Receives Payout of $100 Million, Russias Largest Ever
description: MOSCOW  He once worked for an agency that arrested speculators.

title: Having Hope, but Needing a Consistent Manning
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Banks Seek a Shield in Mortgage Rules
description: As regulators complete new mortgage rules, banks are about to get a significant advantage: protection against homeowner lawsuits.

title: Our Live College Application Help Line Returns to Facebook This Week
description: If youre a college-bound senior who is scrambling to finish your college applications  or trying to make sense of your early admission decisions  The Choice has lined up some expert guidance.

title: Reading the City
description: I was in Barcelona last month for a conference on smart cities (more specifically, on how technology can make cities smarter). There were some intriguing presentations and a lot of cool-looking smart trucks and electric bikes. I could have spent a lot more time interfacing with all the technology housed in Fira de Barcelona convention center (which, starchitect hotel by Toyo Ito notwithstanding, is definitely a textbook case of bad urbanism).

title: How Wal-Mart Used Payoffs to Get Its Way in Mexico
description: SAN JUAN TEOTIHUACN, Mexico  Wal-Mart longed to build in Elda Pinedas alfalfa field. It was an ideal location, just off this towns bustling main entrance and barely a mile from its ancient pyramids, which draw tourists from around the world. With its usual precision, Wal-Mart calculated it would attract 250 customers an hour if only it could put a store in Mrs. Pinedas field.

title: Deal Signed to Overhaul Juvenile Justice in Tennessee
description: For teenagers, especially African-Americans, getting in trouble in Shelby County, Tenn., has long been a particularly bad idea.

title: Wal-Mart Abroad
description: How a retail giant fueled growth with bribes

title: Questions That Require a Super Bowl to Settle
description: Statement Sunday, the somewhat grandiose nickname attached to Week 15 of the N.F.L. season, was supposed to answer more questions than it created.

title: The Bullets Legacy
description: Hillside, N.J.

title: Finding an Audience, for a Cause
description: DOCUMENTARY films are notoriously difficult to finance, with filmmakers often spending more time scrounging up money to make a film than actually producing it. Unlike big Hollywood films, where having the presence of a marquee name can attract dollars, documentary filmmakers often must try to explain how a niche idea can succeed at the box office.

title: Need a Few More Clues? Fedora. Bullwhip. Archaeology.
description: The mystery of The Raiders of the Lost Ark and the University of Chicago admissions office has been solved.

title: South Korea Vote Will Change Policy Toward North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  No matter who wins South Koreas presidential election on Wednesday, the end is near for the hard-line policy on North Korea promoted by the departing president: the two top candidates both agree on a more moderate approach.

title: Bring On the Fiscal Cliff
description: Washington

title: Premiere of Violent Tarantino Film Is Canceled Because of School Massacre
description: LOS ANGELES  Citing the mourning and emotional distress resulting from the Connecticut school massacre, the Weinstein Company late Monday canceled a premiere for its violent film Django Unchained.

title: Arbitration Clauses
description: To the Editor:

title: A National Commission
description: To the Editor:

title: Mourning, Outrage and Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Lockheed Profit on F-35 Jets Will Rise With New Contract
description: Lockheed Martin expects to earn a profit in the high single digits under a new contract signed last week for the fifth batch of its radar-evading F-35 fighter planes, company officials said.

title: Gossip Girl Secret: Dont Google It
description: Monday nights mystery is whether Gossip Girl, in the series finale, will finally reveal the identity of Gossip Girl herself. Less of a mystery is what kind of device she probably uses to send her scandalous blasts.

title: West Bank Land, Empty but Full of Meaning
description: AL ZAYYEM, West Bank  They buried Rabi al-Essawy 14 months ago on land his family owns not far from this village, between East Jerusalem and the large Israeli settlement of Maale Adumim. Mr. Essawy, 65, was a member of an important clan, and thousands attended his funeral.

title: Fears That Lack of Money Will Weaken Malaria Battle
description: The world has made great progress against malaria in the last decade, but the fight is stalling for lack of funds, the World Health Organizations annual report on malaria concluded on Monday. The amount spent on the disease by all countries rose to $1.8 billion last year, compared with $100 million in 2000, and, as a result, about one million childrens lives were probably spared over that time, the report said. But it would take $5 billion a year to get nets, insecticide spraying, diagnostic kits, effective drugs and hospital treatment to everyone needing them, and donor contributions, especially to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, have been nearly flat since 2010. Last year, the number of new nets purchased fell sharply, to 66 million from 145 million two years ago. Since nets wear out in three years and children are always being born, large numbers of infants and toddlers will soon be unprotected if more money does not come in, the report warned. The W.H.O. estimated that there were 219 million malaria cases in the world in 2010, with 660,00 deaths.

title: Not-Too-Sweet Wok-Popped Coconut Kettle Corn
description: Im usually not a big fan of sweet kettle corn, but I wanted to make a moderately sweet version because some people love it and it is nice to be able to offer a sweet snack for the holidays. I realized after testing this recipe that I do like kettle corn if it isnt too sweet. The trick to not burning the sugar when you make kettle corn is to add the sugar off the heat at the end of popping. The wok will be hot enough to caramelize it.

title: Healthy Holiday Snacks
description: This weeks recipes come in response to requests from readers for ideas for snacks to have around the house during the end-of-the-year holidays: something to replace the candy bowls and cookies that are usually there and easy to nosh on. Commercial snacks that are healthy (or healthier  read the labels closely) are available including vegetable chips and pita crisps, seaweed snacks, nuts, dried fruit and trail mix. But some of these have a lot of salt and they can be pricy.

title: France: Multinational Military Force Expected for Mali
description: France expects that the United Nations Security Council will authorize the deployment of a multinational African military force in Mali in the coming days, but operations to regain control of the countrys north would begin no earlier than August or September, a French diplomat said Monday. Northern Mali is controlled by several violent Islamist and separatist groups, including Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb.

title: Symbol of Pride, Inverted, Is Now Symbol of Political Dismay
description: GENOA, Ill.  Jim Harris expected vandalism, angry calls, maybe even a violent attack.

title: Iraq: 30 Die in Bombings and Gunfire in Several Cities
description: A wave of attacks across Iraq on Monday killed at least 30 people and wounded dozens more. The attacks, involving suicide and car bombings as well as shootings, occurred in Baghdad, Mosul, Samarra and other cities.

title: Mexico: New Leader Outlines Shift in Antidrug Policy
description: President Enrique Pea Nieto promised on Monday to modify the strategy, spearheaded by his predecessor, Felipe Caldern, of unleashing the military on narcotics organizations. Mr. Pea Nieto proposed a six-point program, which involves alleviating addiction, establishing a new paramilitary police force with 10,000 recruits, folding the Federal Police into the Interior Department and reclaiming public spaces like parks. Mr. Pea Nieto did not say when the plan would go into effect. During a meeting of the National Security Council, Interior Secretary Miguel ngel Osorio Chong criticized Mr. Calderns strategy, which focused on the arrest of drug cartel leaders and depended largely on heavily armed security forces. Security resources more than doubled, but, unfortunately, crime has increased, he said.

title: Reason to Hope After the Newtown Rampage
description: This is a country that has a history of facing tragedy and becoming better for it. It is a country that recoiled in horror at the Triangle shirtwaist factory and took steps to protect the lives of factory workers. It is a country able to rethink deeply seated beliefs  as it did with discrimination against blacks and women and is now doing with antigay discrimination.

title: Personal Guns and the Second Amendment
description: When the Supreme Court struck down a ban on handguns by the District of Columbia in 2008, ruling that there is a constitutional right to keep a loaded handgun at home for self-defense, the decision was enormously controversial in the legal world. But the courts conclusion has generally been accepted in the real world because the ruling was in tune with popular opinion  favoring Americans rights to own guns but also control of gun ownership.

title: Obamas New Offer on Fiscal Crisis Could Lead to Deal
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama delivered to Speaker John A. Boehner a new offer on Monday to resolve the pending fiscal crisis, a deal that would raise revenues by $1.2 trillion over the next decade but keep in place the Bush-era tax rates for any household with earnings below $400,000.

title: Ohio States Monitoring of Athletes Spending Raises Concerns
description: At Ohio State, one slice of an ambitious universitywide compliance department overhaul fostered something of a national debate last week on oversight in college sports. It did not involve study habits, training habits or dietary habits.

title: Egypt: Chief Public Prosecutor Quits After One Month
description: The chief public prosecutor appointed last month by President Mohamed Morsi stepped down Monday after a demonstration by district prosecutors accusing him of political bias. The district prosecutors accused the new chief, Talaat Ibrahim Abdullah, of pressing one of their peers to file charges against a group of opposition protesters accused of receiving money to use violence. Mr. Morsi had said that appointing Mr. Abdullah as chief prosecutor was one of the main goals of the Nov. 22 presidential decree granting himself temporary power above the courts, which set off weeks of protests here.

title: Hearing Reveals Details of Spys Life, but Motive for Death Is Still a Mystery
description: LONDON  It is now more than six years since Alexander V. Litvinenko, whistle-blower and former K.G.B. officer, died a slow, agonizing and much-chronicled death, reflecting the shadowy world in which he maneuvered to tilt against the Kremlin  the font, as he depicted it, of Russian organized crime.

title: Mets Pelfrey, Coming Off Surgery, Signs Deal With Twins
description: When the Mets selected pitcher Mike Pelfrey with the ninth pick of the 2005 draft, they expected an ace who could lead the starting rotation for several years. On Monday, Pelfreys tenure with the team ended without much fanfare when he signed a one-year $4 million deal with the Minnesota Twins, according to a source close to the negotiations.

title: Emotional Times for McHale and Lin
description: Disbelief was etched all over Kevin McHales face and was punctuated by shakes of the head. Even a man who last month buried a 23-year-old daughter could not fathom the violent and senseless loss of someone elses child at 6 or 7.

title: In Sign of Normalization, Pentagon to Reimburse Pakistan $688 Million
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon quietly notified Congress this month that it would reimburse Pakistan nearly $700 million for the cost of stationing 140,000 troops on the border with Afghanistan, an effort to normalize support for the Pakistani military after nearly two years of crises and mutual retaliation.

title: Three Rs of Narrative Nonfiction
description: Late on a Friday in Montreal, 1974, Art Williams, a National League umpire, is pacing the floor of his hotel room, sleepless and worried. During a game that evening, a player had pushed him, and Mr. Williams had pushed back  inappropriate behavior for those charged with enforcing the rules. It was personally troublesome for Mr. Williams, who, as the first black umpire in the National League, felt extra pressure to perform.

title: With the Why Elusive, Two Boys, Two Burials
description: NEWTOWN, Conn.  Noah Pozner loved tacos, so much so that he talked of wanting to be the manager of a taco factory when he grew up; that way, he would be able to eat a taco whenever he wanted. He had a way of charming his elders and loved his siblings, including a twin sister who was in another classroom that day.

title: Lets Get M.A.D.D. About Guns
description: On May 3, 1980, a 13-year-old girl named Cari Lightner was killed by a drunken driver. A terrible alcoholic, the man had three prior drunken driving convictions. He had just come from a bar, on the back end of a three-day binge.

title: How to Sell a U.S. Tax Increase Back Home: Make Sure to Cut Spending, Too
description: ZEELAND, Mich.  The people who live here on the western edge of Michigans midsection like to say they inherited their Dutch forefathers thriftiness.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Dec. 18, 2012
description: I used to do everything with him. We liked to wrestle. We played Wii. We just played all the time. I cant believe Im never going to see him again.

title: Seeking Comfort in Song Amid the Whiz of Bullets
description: The second graders had just finished their yoga poses and jumping jacks when the gunshots began.

title: Unable to Lock Up Dickey, Mets Capitalize on Value
description: The Mets always wanted to keep R. A. Dickey, General Manager Sandy Alderson said Monday night, shortly after a deal to send Dickey, a 38-year-old Cy Young winner, to the Toronto Blue Jays was made official by the clubs.

title: Diamond Feat
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  When the theme of a puzzle doesnt make itself clear right away, especially so early in the week, thats your clue to look through the clues for a hint to several different entries in the puzzle type of payoff. At least thats what I do.

title: Corrections: December 18, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Pro-Gun Democrats Signaling Openness to Limits
description: WASHINGTON  Demonstrating rapidly shifting attitudes toward gun control in the aftermath of a massacre in a Connecticut school, many pro-gun Congressional Democrats  including Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader and a longstanding gun rights supporter  signaled an openness Monday to new restrictions on guns.

title: A Pristine Afghan Prison Faces a Murky Future
description: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan  The first thing one notices about the new prison here is the smell, or rather the absence of it. Helmand Central Prison does not reek of sewage or sweat or old clothes or rancid cooking oil, the typical odors of an Afghan lockup. The air smells, dare one say, fresh.

title: Silent Since Shootings, N.R.A. Could Face Challenge to Political Power
description: Until recently, Debra Maggart considered the National Rifle Association an ally. As chairwoman of the Republican caucus in the Tennessee House of Representatives, she was a lifetime N.R.A. member and steadfastly supported its agenda, even voting for a bill that allowed guns in bars.

title: Connecticuts Rules for Purchasing This Gun
description: Police say that Adam Lanza used an AR-15 style rifle on Dec. 14 to kill 26 people in Newtown, Conn. Here are the steps to purchase a similar weapon.

title: Wall Street, Invested in Firearms, Is Unlikely to Push for Reform
description: 5:25 a.m. | Updated

title: Misfiring Williams Takes Shot at the Nets System
description: Deron Williams became a Net because the Utah Jazz traded him, because they feared he would leave anyway and because Williams himself could not guarantee otherwise.

title: In Colorado, Getting Down to Business of Marijuana
description: GOLDEN, Colo.  It has been a little over a month since Coloradans approved a groundbreaking law legalizing small amounts of marijuana for recreational use.

title: New Forms of Assistance Benefit Homeowners in Storm-Torn Areas
description: New York and New Jersey homeowners hit hard by Hurricane Sandy are receiving an unusually generous array of federal financial assistance, even as some safeguards were initially relaxed to speed distribution.

title: Report Cites Bias by Police in Killings in Canada
description: OTTAWA  Robert W. Pickton, a pig farmer, managed to murder 49 women before his arrest in 2002 largely because of systemic bias by the police against the victims, the commissioner who investigated the actions of the police said Monday.

title: Amgen Expected to Plead Guilty in U.S. Case
description: The biotechnology giant Amgen is expected to plead guilty Tuesday to illegally marketing its drugs, people close to the investigation said Monday.

title: Incoming Leaders Plan: Not Repeating His Errors
description: TOKYO  Shinzo Abe, set to return as Japans prime minister after his partys landslide victory on Sunday, means it when he says he knows what it feels like to hit rock bottom. His last term in office was marred by political financing scandals, a nationalist agenda that seemed off the mark and rumors  later confirmed  that he had resigned over an intestinal ailment, an ignominious exit that prompted snide jokes about his condition.

title: In Other Countries, Laws Are Strict and Work
description: Like other shootings before it, the Newtown, Conn., tragedy has reawakened America to its national fixation with firearms. No country in the world has more guns per capita, with some 300 million civilian firearms now in circulation, or nearly one for every adult.

title: Obama's Speech in Newtown
description: President Obama speaks at a vigil for victims of the massacre at an elementary school in Newtown, Conn., on Sunday.

title: In Return, Lin Plays as if He Never Left
description: For one night this season, a new version of Linsanity was the featured event at Madison Square Garden. Jeremy Lin, wearing his red and silver Houston Rockets jersey, was cheered during pregame introductions, but there were no visible Linsanity signs in the arena  a far cry from last February, when he went from benchwarmer to global phenomenon.

title: Burial No. 9, Americas Prisons and Fruit-Drug Interactions
description: This week: a strange case of Stone Age care; a new series on the incarceration capital of the world; and grapefruits surprising health dangers.

title: U.S. Envoy Optimistic About Ties With China
description: Gary F. Locke, the United States ambassador to China for the past 16 months and the first American of Chinese descent to hold that post, spoke optimistically on Monday about the deepening relationship between the United States and China despite differences over issues including North Korea, human rights abuses and Chinas growing military assertiveness in Asia.

title: Audit Finds Lax Oversight of Preschool Special Education
description: New York spends around $2 billion a year on preschool for children with disabilities, yet the State Education Department has not visited and audited a single contractor involved in the program since 2007, the state comptrollers office has found.

title: Senate Democrats Vote to Oust Their Leader
description: Democrats in the State Senate, smarting over their inability to take control of the chamber despite winning a numerical majority, on Monday ousted their leader, John L. Sampson of Brooklyn, and replaced him with Andrea Stewart-Cousins of Westchester County.

title: In New York, Lin Craze Is Out of Fashion
description: In the back northeast corner of the basement level of a sporting goods store in Times Square, a rack of Jeremy Lin jerseys hung unsold and unnoticed on Monday. They were Houston Rockets red.

title: Man Pleads Guilty to Defrauding Education Department
description: A Pennsylvania man pleaded guilty on Monday to defrauding New York Citys Education Department of $2.7 million that was intended for children with special needs, according to federal prosecutors.

title: Army Officer Reaches Deal in the Suicide of a Private
description: The only officer to be implicated in the death of Pvt. Danny Chen, the Chinese-American infantryman from New York City who killed himself last year while he was deployed in Afghanistan, will avoid a trial but be thrown out of the military under a deal with prosecutors, the Army said Monday.

title: Lottery Numbers
Snapshot of Storm Aid
description: In addition to Hurricane Sandy assistance for individuals, the federal government will distribute billions of dollars more to local and state governments.

title: Former Landfill, a Park to Be, Proves a Savior in the Hurricane
description: During Hurricane Sandy, the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island absorbed a critical part of the storm surge. Its hills and waterways spared nearby neighborhoods like Travis, Bulls Head, New Springville and Arden Heights much worse flooding. The 2,200-acre site, which closed a decade ago and is being turned into a park, was also temporarily reopened as a transfer station, helping officials and relief agencies clear debris from around the city.

title: World Religious Groups
description: A new study on religious adherence has found that about one-sixth of the world population has no particular religious affiliation.

title: Study Finds One in 6 Follows No Religion
description: A global study of religious adherence released on Tuesday by the Pew Research Center found that about one of every six people worldwide has no religious affiliation. This makes the unaffiliated, as the study calls them, the third-largest group worldwide, with 16 percent of the global population  about equal to Catholics.

title: Laying the Children to Rest
description: Funerals were held Monday in Newtown, Conn., for two young shooting victims.

title: No Euro, but European
description: The Polish economy has begun to slow in response to the downturn in the euro zone.

title: In Philippines, a Turning Point on Contraception
description: HONG KONG  There was both recrimination and celebration after the passage of a landmark bill in the Philippines on Monday, a measure that codifies sex education in schools and broadens access to condoms and birth control pills in poor and rural areas.

title: Word of the Day | sarcasm
description: sarcasm \sr-ka-zm\ noun

title: For Prosecutor in Sexual Abuse Case, Muted Praise From One Corner
description: Charles J. Hynes, who served as Brooklyn district attorney for more than two decades before he decided to take a close look at the scourge of sexual molesting among the Hasidim, talked tough a few weeks ago.

title: Fearing a Stigma for People With Autism
description: Amid reports from neighbors and classmates that the gunman in the shooting rampage in, Newtown, Conn., had an autism variant known as Asperger syndrome, adults with the condition and parents of children with the diagnosis are fighting what they fear may be a growing impression that it is associated with premeditated violence.

title: With Playoff Hopes on Line, Jets Put Ball on Turf
description: NASHVILLE  The Jets season began on a warm and sunny afternoon, and after a comprehensive victory, all things seemed possible. It ended on a crisp and windy night, and after another embarrassing defeat, all things seem possible once more.

title: His Source of Comfort: Visits With the Departed
description: Throughout Mikhail Lekhners Brooklyn apartment one can still feel the presence of his wife, Zinaida, who died from brain cancer six years ago.

title: Jets Replay: Week 15
description: The Jets saw their playoff hopes come to an end in a sloppy loss to the Titans.

title: Party Identity in a Gun Cabinet
description: An American child grows up in a married household in the suburbs. What are the chances that his family keeps a gun in their home?

title: Agony of the Jets, on Twitter
description: Well have more coverage in the morning, but heres a place to comment (or commiserate) as the Jets were eliminated from the playoffs in what was a fitting ending: an awful interception by Mark Sanchez (one of four), followed by a reprieve as the Titans went three-and-out and shanked a punt, followed by a low snap that was fumbled by Sanchez.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (13) FIRST FREEDOM: THE FIGHT FOR RELIGIOUS LIBERTY This 90-minute documentary uses re-enactments, expert commentary and the founding fathers own words to tell the story of how colonial Americans, including Thomas Jefferson, Benjamin Franklin and George Washington, above, raised the ideal of religious freedom to the level of a fundamental human right protected by law. Offering perspective are the historian Douglas Brinkley, who wrote the films script; the Rev. Forrest Church of the Unitarian Church of All Souls in Manhattan, who died in 2009; John Hope Franklin, the author of From Slavery to Freedom: A History of Negro Americans, who also died in 2009; Jon Meacham, the former Newsweek editor now at Random House; and Cokie Roberts, a contributor to NPR News.

title: Mary Griggs Burke, Japanese Art Connoisseur, Dies at 96
description: Mary Griggs Burke, who amassed the most comprehensive private collection of Japanese art outside Japan with a meticulousness, deliberation and incisive eye that befit her subject, died on Dec. 8 at her home in Manhattan. She was 96.

title: Portraits From the Kochi Biennale: Multimedia Artist Ahmed Mater
description: At the Kochi-Muziris Biennale in the Kerala State city of Kochi, India Ink interviewed several exhibiting artists about their work, their expectations for the biennale and the politics of art. The fair will continue until March 13.

title: News Quiz | December 18, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 18
description: NEWS Shinzo Abe, Japans presumptive new prime minister, whose earlier term ended in failure in 2007, is in many ways a changed man, shifting his focus from nationalism to the economy. Hiroko Tabuchi reports from Tokyo.

title: For Late-Night Hosts, a Struggle to Confront the News
description: The school shooting in Newtown, Conn., made for an awkward subject for the usually topical comedy of late-night television, but two hosts did try to engage the subject Monday night, though not in any way that resembled their conventional approach to commenting on the news.

title: Test Yourself | English, Dec. 18, 2012
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Wild Horses Are Running Out of Room, On and Off Range.

title: Home for the Holidays, or Not: Tell Us Your Stories
description: There is plenty of allure, challenge and excitement to living abroad, but those with a proclivity for homesickness can find themselves awash in it during the holiday season. Have you spent your holidays overseas, on assignment or by choice? Where did you go? How did you celebrate? Here is my story; tell us yours. Well post our favorites during these last weeks of 2012.

title: New Extreme Sport: Tandem BASE Jumping
description: In BASE Jumpers Double the Dare, John Branch reports on the new sport of tandem BASE jumping.

title: The Opportunity, or Not, to Be American
description: When Jon Lowenstein first came to Chicago 20 years ago, he was torn between pursuing a career as a photographer and devoting his life to teaching English as a second language to Spanish speakers.

title: Soledad OBrien Is Betting on Jeff Zucker
description: Your memoir made your experience growing up in Smithtown, a largely white town on Long Island, sound like a huge drag.  It really wasnt. It is truly not fun to be the family that sticks out in an all-white community. On the other side, I have five brothers and sisters, we all look exactly the same and were very, very tight. The lessons about race were not pleasant, but there are things that I loved about my childhood. In the book, I didnt want to be the tragic mulatto.

title: Crowds Are Not People, My Friend
description: We have all been to a church or a concert without merging with the rest of the audience into some sort of hive mind. Likewise, we all know from experience that Internet message boards arent Borg-like mind-melding machines that multiply users brain power. So why, then, do we insist on treating crowds, real or virtual, like sentient beings? Weve long believed that physical crowds are emotional, irrational and prone to violence. Over the last decade, weve come to think of virtual crowds as sources of wisdom that cant be found in individuals. Both these ideas treat crowds as entities, rather than groups of people  an idea that has its origins in 19th-century sociology, which, according to scientists studying crowd behavior today, is deeply flawed.

title: How Should We Prevent Future Mass Shootings?
description: In the wake of the shootings at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., that left 20 children and 6 school staff members dead, President Obama stated that were going to have to come together and take meaningful action to prevent more tragedies like this, regardless of the politics. However, he did not provide any detailed proposals for what meaningful action should look like. So, were asking you:

title: Church Officials Call on Filipinos to Campaign Against Birth Control Law
description: MANILA  After losing a battle to stop the passage of a contentious birth control law, Roman Catholic Church officials on Tuesday dug in and instructed their millions of followers to campaign against the measure in communities, schools and homes.

title: What to Do if You Are Deferred to the Regular Decision Pool
description: Brennan Barnard is the director of college counseling at the Derryfield School in Manchester, N.H.

title: In Unusual Move, Cerberus to Sell Gun Company
description: Sitting in their offices high above Park Avenue late on Monday, the private equity executives who own the countrys largest gun company received a phone call from one of their most influential investors.

title: Breaking Down Roethlisbergers Overtime Interception
description: Jonathan Bales analyzes a big play each week.

title: The Early Word: Deal?
description: Todays Times

title: The True Burden of Government
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Richard Engel of NBC Is Freed in Syria
description: Richard Engel, the chief foreign correspondent for NBC News, and his crew had sneaked into Syria before. They knew where to go, where not to go; what to say, what not to say. But last Thursday, in a demonstration of the perils of reporting from the war-torn country, Mr. Engels crew was taken hostage by an unknown group and told they would be used to secure the release of hostages being held by Syrian rebels.

title: In the Middle: Helping Unhappy Couples
description: A post on Monday discussed the forces that can make an older couples good marriage suddenly go bad  an array of subtle, and often-misunderstood, mental, physical and emotional factors that can upset the equilibrium of even the happiest marriages.

title: Hands Off Germanys Neo-Nazi Party
description: BERLIN  Last Friday appeared to be a good day for German democracy. The Bundesrat, or upper house of Parliament, voted to ban the extreme-right National Democratic Party for trying to undermine the countrys constitutional order with its anti-Semitic, racist and xenophobic stance. The party, known by its German initials N.P.D., regrets the Nazis defeat in World War II, wants to take Germany out of NATO and agitates to send immigrants home.

title: After the Massacre in Connecticut
description: After the shootings in Newtown, Conn., President Obama repeated his call to take meaningful action to prevent more tragedies like this.

title: Why Im Looking for a New Bank
description: It started with little annoyances, the kind of stuff that you overlook when you are truly committed to a relationship. But lately Im having a hard time pretending that things are O.K. Certain behaviors stick in my mind for weeks at a time  some of them blatant, some half-hidden and even more worrisome. But the most recent incident was the last straw.

title: Out With Tennis Injury, Tolkien Wrote Hobbit
description: Tennis has been a passion of writers since long before the birth of the professional game, with scribes ranging from Russian Vladimir Nabokov (1899-1977) to American David Foster Wallace (1962-2008) wielding rackets with as much intensity as their pens, and even incorporating the sport in their work occasionally.

title: Indians Outraged Over Rape on Moving Bus in New Delhi
description: The police said the men were looking for some fun. They had been drinking, having a party, and decided to go on a joy ride. They began circling the capital in a private bus, the police said, when they spotted a couple looking for a ride home. They waved the man and woman onboard and charged them each 36 cents.

title: For Start-Ups, the Final Round
description: When Silicon Valley heard that Bravo was filming a reality show about tech start-ups, it reacted with the sort of disdain it usually reserves for government inquiries about data privacy policies. The general response to the show seemed along the lines of, Were serious people here working seriously hard to improve the world, and we resent any depictions that might undermine that.

title: Nielsen to Buy Arbitron for $1.26 Billion
description: Nielsen Holdings said on Tuesday that it had agreed to acquire Arbitron, the radio ratings company, for $1.26 billion.

title: Come January, Another Try on Nuclear Waste
description: The incoming chairman of the Senate Energy Committee suggests that the Energy Department should stop billing utilities more in waste disposal fees than the department is actually spending on addressing nuclear wastes. And he wants the department to pay for moving some of the wastes out of spent fuel pools at the nations highest-risk reactors and into dry casks.

title: Iraqi President Is Said to Be in a Coma
description: BAGHDAD  Jalal Talabani, the president of Iraq, whose influence in mediating disputes among the countrys many political factions has far outweighed the limited powers of the office he occupies, suffered a stroke and was in grave health on Tuesday in a Baghdad hospital.

title: Gay Mom Struggles With In-Laws Favoritism
description: Steven Petrow, the author of Steven Petrows Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners, (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience.  Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

title: Rex Ryans Fatal Attraction to Mark Sanchez
description: How do you explain your fatal attraction to Mark Sanchez?

title: In Performance: Jackie Hoffman of A Chanukah Charol
description: In a scene from her solo show A Chanukah Charol, inspired by Patrick Stewarts Christmas Carol, Jackie Hoffman impersonates several family members during a particularly kvetchy holiday dinner. Performances of the show continue on Friday and Saturday evenings through Dec. 29 at New World Stages.

title: When Spell-Check Cant Help, Again
description: [PLEASE NOTE: After Deadline will take a holiday break next week and will return on Tuesday, Jan. 1.]

title: Cerberus to Sell Gun Maker Amid Public Pressure
description: CERBERUS TO SELL STAKE IN GUN MAKER | The private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management said on Tuesday that it would immediately sell its controlling stake in the Freedom Group, the company that makes the rifle that was used to kill 20 schoolchildren in Newtown, Conn., on Friday. It is apparent that the Sandy Hook tragedy was a watershed event that has raised the national debate on gun control to an unprecedented level, Cerberus said in a statement.

title: Opinion Report: Guns
description: From the editorial page

title: Daily Report: Massachusetts Fines Morgan Stanley Over Facebook I.P.O.
description: Morgan Stanley is paying for its role in the troubled stock market debut of Facebook, report Susanne Craig and Ben Protess on Tuesday in The New York Times.

title: Tuesday Reading: Beware of Walking and Texting
Gunmen in Pakistan Kill Women Who Were Giving Children Polio Vaccines
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Gunmen shot dead five female health workers who were immunizing children against polio on Tuesday, causing the Pakistani government to suspend vaccinations in two cities and dealing a fresh setback to an eradication campaign dogged by Taliban resistance in a country that is one of the diseases last global strongholds.

title: A Bungalow, Destroyed by Sandy
description: Dear Diary:

title: Energy Agency Sees Global Coal Boom Unabated, Europes Binge Temporary
description: The International Energy Agencys Medium-Term Coal Market Report, issued today in Paris, is essential reading for anyone wishing to maintain a reality-based view of global trends in fuel use. While many energy forecasts end up wrong, on short time scales like this, thats less true. [Dec. 19, 7:34 a.m. | Insert | Tom Zeller Jr. has written a useful analysis of the report for Huffington.]

title: African National Congress Chooses Tycoon as the Partys Deputy President
description: BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa  In South Africa, a nation where the gap between the rich and poor yawns wider than just about anywhere in the world, Cyril Ramaphosa might seem an unlikely savior to a political party whose base is the poor. His fortune is estimated to top $500 million. He sits on the board of the mining company whose 34 workers were killed in a harsh police crackdown on an illegal strike protesting low pay and miserable living conditions.

title: Feeling For | Sebastian Bergnes Brussels Sprouts Wrap
description: The once-lowly Brussels sprout has become the darling of many a restaurant side-dish menu, but who would have expected it to be the inspiration for wrapping paper? Just in time for the holidays, the London designer Sebastian Bergne offers us the very tasty Brussels Sprouts Wrap, his ode to a vegetable that he thinks many people in the U.K. still love to hate. Like many born-again Brussels sprout fans, Bergne understands that its all about the cooking, and has printed his favorite recipe  which includes bacon and chestnuts  on the paper itself.

title: Alex Smith Can Still Win Passer Rating Crown
description: Keep an eye on what San Francisco does with Alex Smith over the next two weeks.

title: Reaction to Newtown Shootings Spreads to Corporate America
description: 4:43 p.m. | Updated

title: A Growing List of Gun Victims, and the Mayors Demand for a Plan
description: On the same day as the school massacre in Newtown, Conn., another madman attacked little children outside a primary school many thousands of miles away.

title: Rape Suspects Captured in Record Time, Delhi Police Say
description: Four men have been arrested in the rape of a woman and the beating of her male friend, after the police tracked down the bus in which the assaults took place, Delhis police chief said Tuesday.

title: No Monkey Business: Woman Behind Botched Fresco Restoration Sells Painting on eBay
description: You may not appreciate the handiwork of Celia Gimnez, the 80-year-old woman whose unauthorized restoration of a religious fresco turned the face of Jesus into something resembling, say, a monkey in a shearling coat. But like it or not, she is now a professional artist: The Associated Press reported that an original painting by Ms. Gimnez, depicting only a rustic scene and no holy figures or primates, had been sold on eBay for about $1,400.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Nielsen Buys Arbitron, and Instagrams New Ad-Friendly Rules
description: Nielsen Holdings announced Tuesday morning that it would be acquiring Arbitron, the radio ratings company, for $1.26 billion, Michael de la Merced reported. The acquisition price amounts to $48 a share in cash for each outstanding share of Arbitron, or a 26 percent premium to Arbitrons closing price on Monday. The deal was described by Nielsen as part of its effort to track how people view and listen to media programs, which can be delivered in an increasing array of formats.

title: The Deal Dilemma
description: First things first: cutting Social Security benefits is a cruel, stupid policy  just not nearly as cruel and stupid as raising the Medicare eligibility age. But sometimes you have to accept bad things in pursuit of a larger goal: health reform should have included a public option  heck, it should have gone straight to single-payer  but a flawed route to universal coverage was better than none at all.

title: No Shortage of Contenders  for Next Oscar Season
description: Oscar voting began on Monday but with more than two months left in the season, you may already be tired of hearing about the debate over the torture in Zero Dark Thirty or the historical accuracy of Lincoln.

title: N.F.L. Playoff Field Will Look Familiar
description: Chase Stuart writes about the historical and statistical side of football at his site, FootballPerspective.com

title: What Were Reading
description: Bright Cove: In this weeks video treat, Pascaline Lepeltier, sommelier at Rouge Tomate in New York and friend of the wine panel, demonstrates how to lop off the head of a Champagne bottle using no more than a spoon.  Eric Asimov

title: Toyota to Pay Record $17.35 Million Fine for Delaying Recall
description: For the fourth time, Toyota has agreed to pay a fine to settle allegations by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration that the automaker delayed a safety recall.

title: On Our Radar: A Global Coal Boom
description: Coal will come close to surpassing oil as the worlds top energy source by 2017, the International Energy Agency predicts. Demand for coal will increase in every region of the world except the United States, where the fuel is being pushed out by natural gas, the agency says. [International Energy Agency]

title: How to Read Like a Master of Meh
description: Samantha Henig is the magazines online editor and writes The Meh List section of The One-Page Magazine..

title: Peter Kenen, R.I.P.
description: Oh, my  I just got word that my colleague and friend Peter Kenen has died. Ill try to write more later, but I did write an essay for his festschrift, The Practical Theorist, a number of years back. Sad to say, I dont have an electronic copy; but I can lift the opening from Google Books:

title: For Potvin, and Rangers Fans, the Chant Endures
description: N.H.L. hockey at Madison Square Garden may seem like a far-off memory now, with more than six months gone since the last time it was played. But the fact remains: the chant is as much a part of the Garden hockey experience as anything.

title: Musical Moments, Part 6
description: Anthony Tommasini performs favorite classical music moments sent in by readers.

title: NBC Reporter Describes Captivity in Syria
description: Last Updated, 11:00 p.m. Richard Engel, the chief foreign correspondent for NBC News, and four colleagues were freed on Monday after five days in captivity in Syria, as my colleagues Brian Stelter and Bill Carter report.

title: Love Em While You Can
description: It takes special people to run a bad sports franchise these days, people with superhuman powers of persuasion. During the season, these fine managers must convincingly beg fans: please love our players, invest your emotions  and large chunks of your paychecks  in those wonderful humans wearing our uniform. Please forget that our franchise has not won a championship since, oh, we forget when. Please shell out large sums for tickets and jerseys and the privilege of being associated with us.

title: France Opens the Door to a Right to Die, but Not Now
description: LONDON  France may become the latest European country to grant a right to die to the terminally ill, after a government-commissioned report on Tuesday opened the door to legalizing assisted suicide.

title: Obama and Biden to Attend National Prayer Service
description: President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will go to the Washington National Cathedral on Jan. 22, the day after their second inaugural ceremony, to participate in the National Prayer Service, held every four years to commemorate the inauguration of the president.

title: In Shooting Aftermath, Axelrod Says Focus Should Also Be on Video Games
description: While much of Washington has focused on what to do about guns in the aftermath of the school shooting in Connecticut, at least one adviser to President Obama also wants the country to think about what to do about violent video games.

title: Musical Moments, Part VI: Clair de Lune
description: What constitutes a moment in music? Some readers cited fairly long passages, even whole movements of pieces, as favorite moments. But BAM (to use the name readers gave for their posts), from Farmington, Conn., pointed to a precise moment toward the end of Debussys popular piano piece Clair de Lune when a single note is introduced to a chord, resulting in a subtle change of harmony, like the instant of recognizing first love on a moonlit night. In this video I discuss that moment.

title: Wal-Mart's Aggressive Corruption
description: TimesCast: President Barack Obama offers a deal over fiscal crisis. | Young adults struggle with homelessness while jobless or underemployed. | David Barstow on how Wal-Mart used payoffs in Mexico.

title: War of the Words
description: MADRID  A tart pun appeared on a protesters sign along a Barcelona street last week: Franco ha Werto. The idea was that the former dictator General Francisco Franco, who died (ha muerto) in 1975, is being recast as Spains current education minister, Jos Ignacio Wert.

title: Ang Lees 3-D Vision
description: With few bankable stars in his new film, the director Ang Lee has been doing many of the press rounds himself for Life of Pi, traversing the globe to promote his 3-D story of a boy, a boat and a tiger. We caught up with Mr. Lee recently at the Apple store in SoHo, where he was due for a Q. & A. He had been traveling with the film since its premiere at the New York Film Festival in September, when he admitted to some fatigue. I thought I was going to get sick, he said, but I didnt have time.

title: An Arrest in the Vandalism of Soldera Wine
description: A former employee of Case Basse di Soldera, the great Brunello di Montalcino estate, has been arrested on charges of destroying more than 60,000 liters of wine, the Italian daily Corriere della Sera reported.

title: Web Sites Offer Free Credit Monitoring
description: Credit Sesame, a Web site that helps people manage their credit, has begun offering its users free credit monitoring, a service that big credit bureaus offer for a fee.

title: Vice Purchases i-D, the British Style Magazine
description: Vice, the multimedia company known for its in-your-face journalistic style, is expanding into fashion coverage by buying the British style publication i-D magazine.

title: Top 10 Movies for Grown-Ups, AARP Edition
description: Call me a dinosaur, but I still watch movies in theaters. When I walk into the theater I feel like a kid  because even at the age of 60, Im the youngest person there. Part of that is, younger people dont have the emotional ties to movie theaters that my generation does. Theyre at home watching on Netflix, or in the case of my kids, on their laptops. And part is selection  I have yet to see a movie with a vampire in a leading role.

title: The Ethics of Aesthetics
description: Suzy Menkes of the I.H.T. talks to Livia Firth about the Green Carpet Challenge and fashions impact on the environment and social justice.

title: Jefferies Posts $71.6 Million Profit in 4th Quarter
description: The Jefferies Group is ending its life as an independent firm on a pleasant note: with a solid quarterly profit.

title: Arbitron Deal Would Extend Nielsens Reach Into Consumer Habits
description: 7:54 p.m. | Updated Consumers today are gleaners of information, moving swiftly from cellphones to newspapers, tablets to radio and social media to television. The question for advertisers is how to reach them across a fragmented environment.

title: Williams, Johnson Play Down Rift over Nets Offense
description: 4:49 p.m. | Updated For a few minutes at least, Deron Williams and Avery Johnson found common ground regarding the Nets playbook on Tuesday.

title: Varied Snacks Nudge Children Toward Healthier Eating
description: Brian Wansink and his colleagues at the Food and Brand Lab at Cornell University are known for their targeted research into what nudges us to eat less food. (Wansink is the author of Mindless Eating: Why We Eat More Than We Think and the researcher who led the infamous bottomless soup bowl experiment.)

title: For Young Disabled Athletes, a Chance to Glide, and Compete, on the Ice
description: The players arrived at Lasker Rink in Central Park on Saturday morning with the help of wheelchairs, walkers and crutches. Many had to be helped into their pads and then lifted into the bucket seats of narrow aluminum sleds with skate-blades on the bottom.

title: Manhattan Theater Club and Ars Nova Announce Recipients of Inaugural Commissions
description: Two prominent New York theaters, Manhattan Theater Club and Ars Nova, announced on Tuesday that they have chosen five playwrights as the first recipients of their new Writers Room commissions. The commissions are worth between $5,000 and $10,000 a piece and are geared to developing works for possible Off Broadway productions at the theaters. The inaugural commissions will go to Thomas Bradshaw (Job), Samuel D. Hunter (The Whale), and Sharyn Rothstein (The Invested); a fourth commission will be shared by Adam Bock (A Small Fire) and Justin Levine (Bonfire Night), who are developing a new musical.

title: Our Sons Are Not Future Killers
description: The Aspergers stereotype before the shootings in Newtown, Conn., was relatively harmless if inaccurate  that of a quirky, brilliant male unable to read subtle social cues or navigate the world of non-autistic people. Think Sheldon on The Big Bang Theory or Abed on Community.

title: Hospitals Fear Theyll Bear Brunt of Medicare Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  As President Obama and Congress try to thrash out a budget deal, the question is not whether they will squeeze money out of Medicare, but how much and who will bear the brunt of the cuts.

title: Image of the Day: Dec. 18
Dec. 18 Updates on Connecticut Shooting Aftermath
description: Four days after the school shooting in Connecticut took the lives of 20 children and 6 staff members, classes resumed at most Newtown schools on Tuesday and the National Rifle Association broke its silence. The N.R.A. is prepared to offer meaningful contributions to help make sure this never happens again, it said in a statement.
