description: To the Editor:

title: Yemeni Leader Tries to Centralize a Divided Military
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi of Yemen ordered a sweeping restructuring of the countrys divided and weak military on Wednesday, moving to replace or sideline commanders who were loyal to his predecessor and whose competing agendas had fed the countrys persistent insecurity.

title: Leniency Denied, UBS Unit Admits Guilt in Rate Case
description: UBS on Wednesday became the first big global bank in more than two decades to have a subsidiary plead guilty to fraud.

title: Behind the Scenes in Congress; Out in Front at Home
description: FAIRFAX CITY, Va.  With Washington gripped by the usual gridlock and partisanship, Steve Stombres, the chief of staff to Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the House majority leader, slipped into a back room for a closed-door meeting one evening last week.

title: Citing Logistics, F.T.C. Pushes Antitrust Inquiry Against Google Into January
description: WASHINGTON  Google was prepared to start the holidays early this week, by settling its antitrust dispute with federal regulators without a harsh punishment.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, Dec. 20, 2012
description: This time, the words need to lead to action.

title: Lebanons Shiites and Sunnis Battle in Syria, but Not at Home
description: ARSAL, Lebanon  The patchwork of Sunni Muslim and Shiite villages arrayed along the northern border with Syria are heavily embroiled in the protracted struggle there, but with a distinctive twist.

title: Pretty, Pretty Please
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Back in the day, young constructor Caleb Madison took on the admirable task of teaching a group of senior citizens attending a class at the Jewish Association of Services for the Aged (J.A.S.A.) how to make a crossword puzzle.

title: Corrections: December 20, 2012
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Many Owners Say Semiautomatic Weapons Are Just Another Hobby
description: Anyone seeking to limit the sale of assault weapons must reckon with the fact that millions of Americans own guns that might be classified as one, and for many it is no more exotic than, say, a motorcycle or sports car, from which they derive a similar satisfaction.

title: Thomas Hired by NBA TV as an Analyst
description: Isiah Thomas is back in the N.B.A., or at least in proximity to it.

title: Knicks Demonstrate Distance to Brooklyn
description: In the beginning, there was intrigue  catchy slogans, competing chants and visions of a basketball rivalry that would split New York. It was interesting, for a moment or two.

title: Some Answers on Benghazi
description: An independent inquiry into the attacks in Benghazi, Libya, that killed four Americans, including Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens, has finally provided some real facts and expert assessments about that tragic night. It offers this country a better chance of understanding what went wrong and what correctives are needed than the reckless Republican mudslinging that for weeks dominated public discourse in the aftermath of the calamity.

title: A Queens High Rise Where Fear, Death and Myth Collided
description: On Nov. 7, little more than a week after Hurricane Sandy battered New York, a filmmaker, Kate Balandina, navigated the dark hallways and staircases of 7-11 Seagirt Avenue, four hulking towers with more than 900 apartments along the beach in Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: Senators Say Torture Scenes in Movie on Bin Laden Hunt Are Misleading
description: WASHINGTON  In an unusual Congressional critique of Hollywood moviemaking, three United States senators on Wednesday lambasted Zero Dark Thirty, the new fictionalized film about the hunt for Osama bin Laden, calling it grossly inaccurate and misleading in its suggestion that torture resulted in information that led to the location of the terrorist leader.

title: On Guns, America Stands Out
description: Sometimes I think the best argument is raw data. This is one of those times.

title: A Helium Shortage Leads to Fewer Balloons in the Sky
description: AMARILLO, Tex.  One chain of party supply stores in Texas and Oklahoma was forced to make a cut worthy of Scrooge: no more balloons donated to charity events. A gated community on Lake Erie in Ohio that had handed out balloons to children at a Fourth of July parade for decades did not give out a single balloon this year. And a longtime tradition at University of Nebraska home football games  releasing up to 5,000 red balloons after the Huskers score their first touchdown  was downsized this season to a modest 2,000.

title: Agency Will Pay $1.7 Million for False Job Placement Claims
description: A nonprofit agency that once was among Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs favorite contractors has agreed to pay $1.725 million to the federal government for falsely claiming to place 1,400 New Yorkers in jobs.

title: In Tough Times, French Economy Loses Ground
description: Charts show key factors contributing to the falling the French economy.

title: Senate Republicans Plan Smaller Storm-Aid Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans in the Senate, seeking to substantially trim a Hurricane Sandy aid package being sought by Democrats, are planning to unveil a $23.8 billion emergency spending plan to finance the recovery efforts of states devastated by the storm.

title: Arrests in a Freshmans Drinking Death Reflect a Tougher Approach
description: DeKALB, Ill.  All it took was two hours.

title: Pleased by Ridership, City Looks for Bids to Bolster East River Ferry Success
description: New York Citys experiment in subsidizing ferry service on the East River has been such a smashing success that city officials are preparing to continue it for at least five more years.

title: A Policy Shift in Programs for the Gifted Is Abandoned
description: In a reversal, New York City school officials on Wednesday said they would continue their sibling-preference policy for gifted and talented programs that have more eligible students than seats.

title: Chaplain With Traumatic Brain Injury Finds the Tables Turned
description: Lt. Col. Richard Brunk, a former Army chaplain, suffered from two major blasts in Iraq in 2005 that traumatically injured his brain.

title: Lockdown Drill Surprises Some, Scaring a School in East Harlem
description: Police officers raced to the school. Some students trembled as they crouched in corners trying to hide. A few staff members began to pray.

title: Where Have All the Primary Care Doctors Gone?
description: More and more, my family and friends are asking for my help in finding a primary care doctor. That they would be having trouble finding one doesnt surprise me. Weve all been reading warnings about an impending doctor shortage for several years now.

title: Word of the Day | ashen
description: ashen \a-shn\ adjective

title: Guilty Plea in Grade-Fixing at Baruch
description: He was the kind of school administrator some college students might have considered themselves lucky to encounter, someone who was willing to raise grades issued by professors when the students marks fell short of graduation requirements.

title: Midsize Cars Fare Better Than Luxury Models in Newest Crash Test
description: In a challenging measure of frontal crash safety called the small overlap test, a group of 18 moderately priced midsize cars did better than a group of similar-size luxury and near-luxury models that the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety tested earlier this year.

title: Amnon Lipkin-Shahak, Israeli Military Leader and Peace Negotiator, Dies at 68
description: JERUSALEM  Amnon Lipkin-Shahak, a former chief of staff of the Israeli military and a cabinet minister who was deeply involved in peace talks with the Palestinians, died here on Wednesday. He was 68.

title: Reservations Bill Hits Hurdles in Parliament
description: A proposed constitutional amendment that would make it easier for the government to promote employees from lower castes encountered stiff resistance Wednesday in the lower houseof Parliament, which had to adjourn for the day after lawmakers opposing the bill repeatedly disrupted the session.

title: A New Start for the Koreas (or Not)
description: HONG KONG  All the countries involved in talks to wind down North Koreas nuclear program have chosen leaders this year  Park Geun-hye won the presidency in South Korea on Wednesday  and there has been some optimism among experts in the region that a chance might be at hand to revive the moribund six-party process.

title: Things I Saw  No. 48
description: Suggestions for what youd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

title: Frustrating Game, Week and Month
description: As the New York Knicks turned Wednesdays game against the Brooklyn Nets into a blowout, one fan stood up from his seat high above Madison Square Garden, beer in hand, and hurled this ruthless insult at the visiting team: Go back to New Jersey! It was unclear if he was a Knicks fan poking fun at a crosstown rival or a Nets fan fed up with the way the season is going.

title: Struggling to Go On After a Sons Death
description: To enter the apartment of Kendrick Moore and Carol Bowman-Moore in the Alphabet City neighborhood in Lower Manhattan is to be greeted by a ghost. Not far from the doorway is a table adorned with dozens of photos that preserve Shytik Bowman, killed last year, as he will always be remembered: a charismatic young man a few weeks shy of 18 with more than a passing resemblance to the singer Chris Brown.

title: Whats On Thursday
description: 8 P.M. (NBC) A WHITE HOUSE CHRISTMAS: FIRST FAMILIES REMEMBER First ladies present and past  Michelle Obama, Laura Bush, Hillary Rodham Clinton, Barbara Bush and Rosalynn Carter  reminisce with Meredith Vieira about their Christmases in the White House. The former first children Barbara Bush, Jenna Bush Hager, Chelsea Clinton, Dorothy Bush Koch, Michael Reagan, Amy Carter, Susan Ford Bales, Tricia Nixon Cox, Julie Nixon Eisenhower, Lynda Johnson Robb and Luci Baines Johnson share their holiday memories as well. Ms. Vieira also trails along with staff members and volunteers, above, at the White House as they plan the dcor around this years theme, Joy to All, with more than 50 trees and elaborate gingerbread creations.

title: Lottery Numbers
Congress Poised to Wrestle Himachal Pradesh From B.J.P.
description: Himachal Pradesh, a small, hilly state in northern India, seems poised to oust its Bharatiya Janata Party government, with its main challenger, the Congress party, leading in more than half of the states 68 constituencies.

title: News Quiz | December 20, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 20
description: NEWS With the election of Park Geun-hye as president on Wednesday, South Korea extended the tenure of its staunchly pro-American governing party and handed power to the daughter of South Koreas longest-ruling dictator, the first woman to win the post in a deeply patriarchal part of Asia. Choe Sang-Hun reports from Seoul.

title: Bank of Japan Will Talk About Inflation Target
description: TOKYO  The Bank of Japan said on Thursday that it would expand asset buying and lending and hinted at a review of its target of 1 percent inflation in the face of pressure from the incoming prime minister, Shinzo Abe, who wants bolder action against deflation.

title: Modis Magic Number
description: That Narendra Modi, the chief minister of Gujarat, is close to winning state elections Thursday does not come as much of a surprise. The Congress Partys campaign has been badly out-flanked by Mr. Modi and his supporters, earning derision even from its own voters.

title: Home for the Holidays: When Your Native Country Is the One That Feels Foreign
description: Have you had a memorable holiday away from home? Tell us your stories. Well post our favorites on IHT Rendezvous during these last weeks of 2012. Here is one:

title: Iraqi President Is Flown to Germany for Treatment After Stroke
description: BERLIN  Jalal Talabani, the president of Iraq, was flown to Germany on Thursday for medical treatment for a stroke suffered this week, his spokesman said. The president, 79, was said to be in stable condition, and the decision to move him was announced after medical specialists from abroad were dispatched to Iraq to assess the possibility of sending him out of the country for further treatment.

title: South Korean President-Elect Calls for Reconciliation After Tight Race
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Koreas president-elect, Park Geun-hye, called for national reconciliation on Thursday, a day after she was elected as the countrys first female leader in a close contest that reflected generational divides and growing unease over North Koreas military threat.

title: Why Do Groups of Men Attack Lone Women?
description: The psychologist David Lisak is an expert on violent crime, including murder and rape. He taught courses on the subject at the University of Massachusetts for 22 years, while working as a forensic consultant to universities, the U.S. military and law enforcement officials. He has worked on hundreds of criminal cases.

title: What They Said: The Gujarat and Himachal Pradesh Elections
description: According to the state assembly election tally posted on the Election Commission Web site at 2:05 p.m., the Bharatiya Janata Party is headed for a victory in Gujarat, while in Himachal Pradesh the Congress party has surged ahead.

title: Test Yourself | English, Dec. 20, 2012
description: This question was written by Jessica Lahey. It comes from the Sunday Magazine article Robert De Niro: In Conversation.

title: More Young Adults Forced to Sleep on Streets
description: In After Recession, More Young Adults Are Living on Street, Susan Saulny writes about the growing problem of homelessness for the nations young adults.

title: Modi Inches Closer to Indias Capital
description: NEW DELHI  Gujarats polarizing state leader, Narendra Modi, inched closer Thursday to becoming the leading political challenger to Indias dominant Gandhi family.

title: Last-Ditch Attempt to Derail Volcker Rule
description: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: Images of Emancipation
description: The portrait for the carte-de-visite of Sojourner Truth, the African-American abolitionist and womens rights advocate, was taken in Battle Creek, Mich., in the 1860s (Slide 5). She wears an elegant silk dress and shawl. With one hand resting on her hip, the other on the arm of the chair, her pose is majestic and determined. She stares resolutely into the camera.

title: How Will You Spend the Holiday Break?
description: All of us spend the holidays in different ways. Some of us have family traditions involving meals, gift giving or religious ceremonies. For others, the holiday break means traveling to be with family or for a getaway vacation. For others, the holidays fall short of what theyre supposed to be &#8212 for one reason or another.

title: Week 15 Film Review, Including Giants-Falcons
description: Andy Benoit takes a closer look at some of Sundays Week 15 matchups, with the benefit of film review:

title: Putin Evasive on Banning Adoptions by Americans
description: MOSCOW  He seemed to wince a bit as he sauntered on stage  a twinge no doubt from a lingering back injury  but as he took his seat before scores of cameras in a hall packed with more than 1,000 journalists on Thursday, President Vladimir V. Putin was clearly in his element: under the bright lights, jaunty and confident, arriving to theme music befitting an action hero.

title: Putin Defends Stand on Syria and Chastises U.S. on Libya Outcome
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday strongly defended Russias implacable opposition to military intervention in Syria and sharply chastised the United States for its role in toppling Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya, describing that outcome as a mistake that created chaos and ultimately led to the death of Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens in Benghazi.

title: Chinese Companies Head for the Exit
description: HONG KONGFed up with slumping share prices, prickly regulators and aggressive short sellers, Chinese companies listed on American stock exchanges are increasingly heading for the exits.

title: The Early Word: Gun Violence
description: In Todays Times:

title: After Storm, Friends Rescue a Caregiver
description: Tales of Hurricane Sandy survival will likely emerge for years  particularly about the sick and elderly who were trapped in their homes or forced to evacuate under harrowing circumstances. Many of those stories have happy endings, like this one of social media and neighborliness I recently heard.

title: In London for the Holidays? Theatrical Gifts for Everyone on Your List
description: So who needs more possessions? The holidays afford the chance to give the gift of theatergoing, the kind of present that will be remembered (one hopes) throughout the year. With that in mind, what follows is a handful of London theater suggestions for the festive season.Enjoy, and curtain up!

title: Guns N Poses
description: LONDON  My father once owned a rifle, a little .22, with which he occasionally shot rabbits. He had inherited it from my grandfather, who in turn had inherited it from my great-great-uncle. It was in a small way a family heirloom and might have one day come to me. Except it didnt.

title: Ericsson Writes Down a Chip-Making Venture
description: BERLIN  Ericsson, the worlds biggest maker of mobile network equipment, said on Thursday that it would take a sizable charge against earnings to write down the value of ST-Ericsson, an unprofitable venture that makes cellphone components.

title: Scenes From Rajkot, Gujarat on Election Day
description: It seemed as if the people of Rajkot, a large and politically charged city in western Gujarat, were all talking about the same thing on Thursday morning: the Bharatiya Janata Partys near-certain victory in the state elections.

title: Week 16 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: The Case for Carolina
description: There are some great matchups this week to write about, but Im going to choose to feature perhaps the least important one. The Raiders visit the Panthers, a forgettable game in almost all respects. Both teams have losing records and have been eliminated from the playoffs. There are no records to be broken or rivalry to be fought. But there is one quirk.

title: Giving Lamb Legs
description: The gleaming, massive lamb shank on these pages, impressive though it may be, is not the most effective way to serve what amounts to the shin and ankle of a lamb.

title: Jerry Seinfeld Intends to Die Standing Up
description: Jerry Seinfeld began his commute after dinner, in no particular hurry. Around quarter to 8 on a drizzly Tuesday, he left his Manhattan home  a palatial duplex apartment with picture windows and a broad terrace overlooking Central Park  and made for a nearby garage. Due to tell jokes at a comedy club downtown, he decided to drive what he calls his city car: a 1998 Porsche 911 Carrera 4S. Stepping into the garage, he tugged a thick fabric cover from the car. The interior was a pristine matte black, and the paint job was a startlingly luminous azure. Its called Mexico blue  a very traditional Porsche color, Seinfeld said. In the 70s it looked normal, but now it looks insane.

title: The End of the World
description: According to some interpretations of the Mayan calendar, the world is scheduled to end on December 21.

title: A Merrier Christmas
description: KYOTO  Spend any time in Japan these days, and you cant help but notice: This country may be less than 1 percent Christian, but its 100 percent Christmas. Hearing the carols blaring from sidewalk loudspeakers in this overwhelmingly Buddhist and Shinto country, you wonder, how did Japan buy into such a foreign tradition?

title: Jerry Seinfeld: How to Write a Joke
description: The comedian describes the anatomy of his Pop-Tart joke, still a work in progress, and shows his longhand writing process.

title: On Our Radar: Twelve Quaggas Clogging
description: An expert on invasive species adjusts the Twelve Days of Christmas lyrics to educate people about threats and prevention in the Great Lakes. [The Journal Sentinel]

title: Might Makes Him Mr. Right
description: Who are you, Mister? a young woman asks Jack Reacher (Tom Cruise), and its a question that recurs, not always quite so politely, throughout the movie that bears Reachers name. He may be an elusive individual with a sketchy background  ex-military, no fixed address, a single shirt to his name  but as an archetype he is easy enough to recognize. He is a cousin of Shane and Caine (from the old Kung Fu television series) and Clint Eastwoods Man With No Name: a paladin without portfolio who travels from town to town, dispensing righteous violence and hard-boiled aphorisms.

title: Snapshots of the Instagram Debate, Through the Lens of Professionals
description: During Hurricane Sandy, I was on assignment in Arizona. At the hotel where I was staying, they had really bad cable. The best way I could follow what was going on with the storm was by seeing the photos being posted to Instagram. It was amazing.

title: Opinion Report: Ending Gun Violence
description: From the editorial page

title: The Deal for N.Y.S.E.
description: N.Y.S.E IN MERGER TALKS | The owner of the New York Stock Exchange is in talks to be acquired by the IntercontinentalExchange, an upstart commodities and derivatives trading platform, in an $8 billion deal, people briefed on the matter tell DealBooks Michael J. de la Merced. IntercontinentalExchange, known as ICE, is expected to offer about $33 a share, with two-thirds of that in stock, according to one of these people. That would be a 37 percent premium to NYSE Euronexts closing price on Wednesday.

title: Thursday Reading: Where Donated Cars May End Up
Bus Company Involved in Recent Rape Banned From Delhis Roads
description: Yadav Travels, the company that owned the bus in which a woman was raped Sunday evening in Delhi, has been banned from operating in Indias capital region, transportation officials have told India Ink.

title: Upstart Market Operator Clinches $8.2 Billion Deal for N.Y.S.E.
description: 8:39 a.m. | Updated

title: Champions League Draw
description: It is the dream matchup: Cristiano Ronaldo vs. Wayne Rooney. Alex Ferguson vs. Jos Mourinho. Manchester United vs. Real Madrid.

title: Ristretto | Scaling Up for the Holidays
description: Ive been good this year, which must be why I already have the V60 Drip Scale from Hario. A slim device with the footprint of an iPad Mini, its a step up for coffee scales. Actually, as far as I know its the only digital scale designed expressly for coffee. The engineers at Hario not only put a timer next to the readout screen, but added a couple of hidden features that address the specific needs of brewing coffee.

title: John Goodman in the Crescent City
description: On a balcony overlooking his New Orleans neighborhood, John Goodman discusses movies with Melena Ryzik.

title: It May Not Be the End of the World, but Its Bad News for Transit Riders
description: Optimism being our default position, lets begin with the good news:

title: At Benghazi Hearing, State Dept. Concedes Errors
description: WASHINGTON  State Department officials promised on Thursday to carry out quickly the recommendations of a review board to beef up security for the foreign service and urged Congress to provide more money to protect American diplomats.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Senators Criticize Zero Dark Thirty, and Filming Assange
description: Three prominent United States senators on Wednesday joined critics of the film Zero Dark Thirty over its depiction of C.I.A. interrogations in the ultimately successful hunt for Osama bin Laden, Scott Shane writes. In a letter to Michael Lynton, chairman and chief executive of Sony Pictures Entertainment, which is releasing the film, the senators called the film grossly inaccurate and misleading in its suggestion that torture resulted in information that led to the location of Bin Laden. The three  Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California; Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan; and John McCain, Republican of Arizona  called on Sony to consider correcting the impression that the C.I.A.s use of coercive interrogation techniques led to the operation against Bin Laden, but they do not explain exactly how that could be done.

title: An Apology for the Oxford English Dictionarys Ill-Timed Word of the Day
description: Oxford University Press, the publisher of the Oxford English Dictionary, has apologized for what it called a coincidence of the worst kind after the dictionarys Web site named bloodbath as its word of the day on Tuesday, after last weeks deadly shootings in Newtown, Conn.

title: High-Speed Trade Giants to Merge
description: The merger of two computer-driven trading firms is set to create a new company that market analysts say would most likely be the single largest player in the trading of American stocks, and a dominant force in several other markets.

title: What Were Reading
description: Momofuku Long Play: An early-80s-tinged video of the influential London chef Marco Pierre White. Mario Batali worked as his sous-chef, and his unrepentant memoir, White Heat, was Bourdain before Bourdain.  Julia Moskin

title: Daily Report: F.T.C. Broadens Rules on Childrens Online Privacy
description: In a move intended to give parents greater control over data collected about their children online, federal regulators on Wednesday broadened longstanding privacy safeguards covering childrens mobile apps and Web sites, Natasha Singer reports in Thursdays New York Times. Members of the Federal Trade Commission said they updated the rules to keep pace with the growing use of mobile phones and tablets by children.

title: Dec. 20 Updates on Connecticut Shooting Aftermath
description: Funerals or wakes were to be held on Thursday for at least six victims of Fridays school shooting in Newtown, Conn., as Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. prepared to visit Newtown in the afternoon to meet with investigators and first responders. In Washington, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is meeting with law enforcement officials to discuss gun restrictions after President Obama asked him to lead the administrations response.

title: Video: John Goodman in the Crescent City
description: In his 30-year career, John Goodman has never been nominated for an Oscar, and though he was up seven times for an Emmy for his work in the sitcom Roseanne, he never won for that show either. He did finally win the TV honor for a guest performance on Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip, but as he tells the Bagger in the video above, Im used to losing.

title: Camry Gets Rating of Poor in a New Crash Test
description: The Toyota Camry, the best-selling car in the United States, did not do well in the Insurance Institute for Highway Safetys new frontal crash test of 18 moderately priced cars.

title: Q&A: Customizing Word Keyboard Shortcuts
description: Q.

title: Marathon Organizers Offer Refund or Future Race
description: Nearly two months after it canceled the New York City Marathon in the days after Hurricane Sandy, New York Road Runners announced Thursday that runners who registered for the 2012 race could get either a full refund or entry into the race in one of the next three years.

title: The Ultimate Threat
description: Dear Diary:

title: Female Vaccination Workers, Essential in Pakistan, Become Prey
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  The front-line heroes of Pakistans war on polio are its volunteers: young women who tread fearlessly from door to door, in slums and highland villages, administering precious drops of vaccine to children in places where their immunization campaign is often viewed with suspicion.

title: As Dogs Waste Away, Owners Seek Answers
description: A few years ago, Michele Danielss puppy, Jackie, suddenly became sick with constant, messy stomach problems. As Jackie, a 9-month-old German shepherd, rapidly lost 20 pounds, Ms. Daniels, who lives in Point Pleasant, N.J., spent many sleepless nights caring for her dog and worrying.

title: Joke About Child Murder Remains in This Is 40
description: Judd Apatows child-murder joke will remain in This Is 40 when the film arrives in theaters on Friday.

title: The Eighteenth Brumaire of Barack Obama
description: These days, political events occur, as it were, twice  the first time as near-tragedy, the second time as farce*.

title: Lee Child: By the Book
description: The author, whose lead character makes his film debut this weekend in Jack Reacher, would like to ask Shakespeare, Why did you make Richard III so damn long?

title: Being French Means Never Having to Say
description: LONDON  President Franois Hollande on Thursday acknowledged the sufferings inflicted on Algeria during more than a century of French colonial rule in a statement that fell short of an apology.

title: Health Workers in the Cross Hairs
description: TimesCast: The campaign against polio faces fear and violence in Pakistan. | Buddhism in Thailand becomes increasingly commercial. | At UBS, a rare admission of fraud from a major bank.

title: On Not Seeing the Forest for the Equations
description: So, Noah Smith weighs in on the state of macro and argues that there really isnt that much disagreement in the field, because both saltwater and freshwater macro use the same set of techniques. (For newbies: saltwater is the kind of macro practiced at MIT, some of Harvard, Princeton, etc., macro that still finds Keynesian ideas useful and argues that monetary and fiscal policy can be effective; freshwater is Chicago, Minnesota, etc. insisting that business cycles are optimal responses to real shocks).

title: Big Moments, Not Always in the Script
description: WOULD Rebecca have been unforgettable? We may never know, though the drama surrounding the seasons ill-fated Broadway production certainly was. The revelation that the shows last-minute investor didnt exist was among the theater years most galvanizing moments. Here are others, on stages big and small:

title: The Years Most Galvanizing Moments
description: A look at scenes on stages big and small.

title: Limited Blogging for A Bit
description: Travel day tomorrow, and I have to do a lot of preparation today (oh, and write a column for tomorrows paper). I might weigh in if something important happens AND I find myself in a place with internet access; otherwise, a bit of a break coming.

title: For Supporting Actor, Who Would Get Your Vote?
description: This seasons supporting-actor hopefuls are a mix of cinema legends and newcomers, performers stretching and playing just beyond their comfort spots. Its a tight race, which we examine in depth here.

title: Musical Moments, Part VIII: Mozart
description: Several readers wrote in to say that one of their favorite moments in music comes near the end of the fourth and final act of Mozarts Marriage of Figaro, when the philandering Count Almaviva, having been caught and humiliated, asks his wife for forgiveness. But that melody is hinted at in Act III, during the counts seductive duet with Susanna, his wifes maid, as I point out in this video.

title: The Giving Spree | Will Self
description: Who: The writer Will Self, who profiled Emma Watson for Ts fall womens fashion issue, and who more recently wrote about Londons cabbie shelters in Fare Grounds.

title: Caribou and Oil Companies to Share Alaska Petroleum Reserve
description: An Interior Department plan for the National Petroleum Reserve  Alaska calls for half of its 23 million acres to be set aside for wildlife conservation, wilderness and recreation and for the rest to be opened to potential oil and gas development.

title: Booker Studies Bid for Senate, Not Governor
description: Despite pressure from party leaders, Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark will not challenge Gov. Chris Christie for re-election next year in New Jersey, deciding instead to focus on making a bid for a Senate seat in two years.

title: Fewer Americans Say Their Actions Can Slow Climate Change
description: Americans may be buying more compact fluorescent light bulbs these days, but they are less likely to set their thermostats low during the winter than they were four years ago and have less confidence that their actions will help to curb global warming, according to a new survey.

title: The Christmas Frog
description: Last winter, on Christmas Eve, I found a frog in my lettuce. The lettuce was not even organic, and I was sure it came from Mexico. I had purchased it at the Pathmark grocery store under the Manhattan Bridge, and it had been in the fridge for days. The frog hopped out of the bag and perched on a plate, looking uncannily like a food-related item.

title: A Tough Season to Be a Nets or Jets Fan
description: You are not alone if todays sports news starts to feel a lot like your last-minute Christmas shopping. You start out with such high hopes (playoffs, baby!), everything looked so much nicer in the ads (or pregame shows) and you suddenly find yourself staring at some of the weird mens gifts of the season and wondering where everything went so wrong. I mean, when did those ballyhooed, whoopee-were-big-in-Brooklyn Nets turn into the N.B.A. equivalent of ice-scraper mittens?

title: The N.R.A.s Blockade on Science
description: In the wake of the school massacre in Newtown, Conn., and the resulting renewed debate on gun control in the United States, The Stone will publish a series of essays this week that examine the ethical, social and humanitarian implications of the use, possession and regulation of weapons. Other articles in the series can be found here.

title: In Performance: Tracee Chimo of Bad Jews
description: In Joshua Harmons comedy Bad Jews, Tracee Chimo plays Daphna Feygenbaum, a Vassar senior who is less than thrilled to be staying with relatives on the Upper West Side when in town for her grandfathers funeral. In this scene Daphna complains to her cousin about another cousin who ate a cookie during Passover. The show runs through Dec. 30 at the Roundabout Undergrounds Black Box Theater.

title: Hiding in Plain Sight, a Japanese Pub
description: From the street, youd never know it was there. Walking toward the elevator and staircase, both at the end of a narrow hallway in what passes for a lobby, youre not entirely sure you have the correct address.

title: Moonrise Kingdoms Magical, Nerve-Racking Moment
description: When Wes Anderson started working on the script that eventually became Moonrise Kingdom, he had a direction in mind, a few ideas, 11 or so pages of notes and a feeling  the memory of a fantasy, as he put it.

title: The 12.9.12 Issue
description: HOLLYWOODS YEAR OF HEROINE WORSHIP

title: Poetry Pairing | The Oxen
description: In anticipation of Christmas, this weeks Poetry Pairing matches The Oxen by Thomas Hardy with two articles: The Christmas Maniac, and from 2011, A Lively Nativity Scene With Roots in Italy.

title: A Top Deal Maker at Sony Will Join Warner Music
description: Robert S. Wiesenthal, a top deal maker at Sony for the last decade, is leaving the company to become chief operating officer of the Warner Music Group, the company announced on Thursday. The move could help Warner expand through acquisitions and compete more handily against the music worlds two corporate giants, Universal and Sony.

title: Modi Victory Speech Comes With Apology
description: Addressing a large crowd of cheering supporters Thursday evening after the Bharatiya Janata Party won a decisive victory in the state elections in Gujarat, its polarizing leader Narendra Modi thanked the states voters for coming out in large numbers, even as he appeared to reach out to Indians all over the country.

title: Preposterous Explanations for Newtown
description: Beyond the abstraction of evil, we may never know why Adam Lanza shot and killed 20 children, six school officials and then himself in Newtown last Friday. And there can never be a satisfactory answer to the question how could this happen? (Although all-too-easy access to guns is certainly part of the answer. As Mayor Bloomberg put it, Its so unbelievable and it only happens in America. And it happens again and again.).

title: Image of the Day: Dec. 20
Long After War, Moral Questions Linger
description: Its hard for a New York team to maintain fan loyalty when it is playing erratic football. But the front office deserves a lot of credit when the green and white colors are displayed alongside members of the military at the opening ceremonies of every game.

title: Syria Fires More Scud Missiles at Rebels, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON  Forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria have resumed firing Scud ballistic missiles against rebel positions in recent days, American officials said on Thursday.

title: Living With Cancer: Dancing With N.E.D.
description: The vocalist begins her song with people shocked by a diagnosis they cannot accept, women not yet ready to admit they have cancer.

title: Charlie Rose Show Agrees to Pay Up to $250,000 to Settle Interns Lawsuit
description: 9:09 p.m. | Updated  Charlie Rose and his production company have agreed to pay as much as $250,000 to settle a class-action lawsuit brought by a former unpaid intern who claimed minimum-wage violations.

title: Merck Says Niacin Drug Has Failed Large Trial
description: The drug maker Merck announced on Thursday that a combination of niacin and another medicine failed to protect against heart attacks and strokes in a large clinical trial, and that the company would no longer pursue approval of the combination drug in the United States.

title: Frank Beardsley, 97, Storied Father of 20
description: Stacks of discount-price childrens shoes lined the walls of a large closet at the Beardsley home in Carmel, Calif., in the 1960s and 70s  size after size in three types: oxfords for school, patent-leather dress-ups for church and tennis shoes for play.

title: A Holiday Built on Presence, Not Presents
description: MY three vegetarian, activist, urban, multi-degreed, agnostic, adult children have rejected Christmas as a consumerist sham of a holiday, one in which they will not be participating. Oh, theyll take the day off and drink organic wine, but they wont be buying presents, putting up a tree, baking cookies, lighting candles or decking any halls. There will be no taking of a family picture for their card and no sending of that card or any other.

title: Culture and Cuisine in Queens
description: A jazz legends home, a museum that honors the moving image and tastes from around the world are all part of the Queens experience.

title: 36 Hours in Queens, N.Y.
description: REMEMBER old New York, where immigrants strived, cultures collided, grit outshined glamour and ethnic restaurants were filled with ethnic crowds, not Instagramming foodies? Before Manhattan commerce was diluted with H&M and Starbucks, and Brooklyn became half hipster playground, half suburb substitute? That city lives on in Queens, where the forces of gentrification have barely nipped at the edges of the citys most expansive borough, home to 2.2 million people, from (it seems) 2.2 million backgrounds. Though its coastal areas have only just begun to recover from the destruction of Hurricane Sandy, most of the boroughs vast territory was untouched by the storm, and is full of sights and sounds unlike anything youll find a short subway ride away in The City.

title: A Hit Parade of Small Labels and Upstarts
description: Fiscal cliffs are nothing new in the classical record industry. As became increasingly apparent when the classical music critics of The New York Times set about the annual ritual of choosing records of the year, the larger economy could perhaps learn a thing or two from certain classical cliff dwellers who have managed to tailor supply to demand while maintaining a zest for innovation and continuing to lead and expand taste.

title: 36 Hours? In Queens, Enough Frugal Options for a Week
description: This week, the New York Times Travel section is publishing its first ever 36 Hours itinerary for Queens, N.Y. As a Queens resident, I heartily endorse the weekend romp through its unique museums, wildly eclectic restaurants, energetic night life and extraordinarily affordable foot massages. As the articles author, I must add that my feet have never felt more relaxed.

title: Reading (and Composing) Wanderlists With an App
description: Browsing through Afar.com, the user-generated online travel guide, is like chatting with a group of well-traveled friends. Users post such passionate descriptions and beautiful photos of destinations that you want to follow in their footsteps.

title: For a Big Exchange Merger, Platoons of Advisers
description: Putting two of the biggest market operators in the world together requires a fair amount of work. In the case of the IntercontinentalExchanges $8.2 billion takeover of NYSE Euronext, that fell on 18  yes, 18  advisers. (To be fair, NYSE Euronexts failed tie-up with Deutsche Brse relied on an even bigger group of 20 firms.)

title: Empathy as a Path to Climate (and Energy) Progress
description: Dec. 21, 8:33 a.m. | Updated below |David Roberts at Grist yesterday posted a deeply moving essay about using empathy as a means to take on tough issues. He built the piece around President Obamas heartfelt reaction and response to the Connecticut elementary school massacre and, followed by Joe Romm, noted the lack of any such response from the president or society on the greenhouse buildup despite the risk posed by human-driven climate change. (Current and past greenhouse-gas emissions will affect the climate for generations, actually millenniums, to come).

title: Princelings
description: A series that looks at how relatives of top Chinese officials have amassed vast wealth through businesses closely entwined with the state.

title: Carrie Nation at the New Yorker
description: Heres Adam Gopniks thought experiment on guns:

title: Last-Second Gift Suggestion From the Magazine (and Jerry Seinfeld, Sort Of)
description: Its Dec. 20. You have five days before Christmas, and we can assure you that for the entirety of that time, navigating any stores that sell anything vaguely gifty is going to be disastrously unpleasant. Have no fear. If the person you need a last-second gift for is a New Yorker, an aspiring writer, a fan of comedy and/or an observer of pop-culture phenomena, then we have a gift idea for you!

title: Common Core Practice | Serendipitous Discovery
description: Were never quite certain where The Times will take us when we walk through our classroom door, write Sarah Gross and Jonathan Olsen, the teachers with whom weve been collaborating for our Friday Common Core Practice postings.

title: Polio Campaign Crisis in Pakistan
description: Times health reporter Donald G. McNeil Jr. speaks about the killing of polio vaccine workers.

title: In Defense of the $100 Christmas Tree
description: In our household, the fake versus live Christmas tree debate was long ago resolved in my favor. I prefer live trees because thats what I grew up with, and I think theyre ultimately better for the environment. And they just plain smell nice.

title: Happy Birthday, You Miserable Achievers
description: Whats going on with Pete and Debbie? First of all: You remember Pete and Debbie, dont you? They were the designated grown-ups played by Paul Rudd and Leslie Mann in Knocked Up, a movie about the accidental conception and hilarious gestation of their niece. If you want an update on that child, who would be in kindergarten by now, you wont find it in This Is 40, Judd Apatows sort-of sequel to the earlier movie and the fourth feature film he has directed. (The babys parents were played by Katherine Heigl and Seth Rogen, who have moved on to other things.)

title: E-Reader Market Shrinks Faster Than Many Predicted
description: Nearly three years after the first iPad was introduced, the tablet has come a long way. Now there are plenty of smaller, cheaper tablets that are pretty powerful. So why buy a more primitive e-book reader?

title: Obama, Fan of Lincoln (and Beasts, Too)
description: When Time magazine announced Barack Obama as its person of the year, bet you didnt think it would include a dive into his movie tastes. But granted an audience with the president, the magazines managing editor, Richard Stengel, asked him about watching Lincoln.

title: Newsies Recoups Initial Investment
description: The Broadway musical Newsies, a David-vs.-Goliath story about the 1899 strike of New York City newsboys, has recouped its $5 million capitalization, becoming the fastest of any Disney musical on Broadway to turn a profit, the shows producers said on Thursday.

title: UBS Settlement Minimizes Impact of Guilty Plea
description: The Swiss banking giant UBS paid a fairly stiff price to settle the rate-rigging case. In addition to approximately $1.5 billion in penalties and disgorgement, the banks Japanese securities subsidiary pleaded guilty to a charge of felony wire fraud.

title: Questions Remain About New Plan on Too Big to Fail
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Bank of England recently put out a new paper on how they might work together to aid a major financial institution that gets into trouble.

title: Insurance Institute Announces Its New Top Safety Pick+ Award
description: Now that the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety has added a new frontal crash test to its portfolio, it announced on Thursday that it will add a new safety award to recognize vehicles that do even better than those that receive its Top Safety Pick award.

title: Asked & Answered | Pascal Barbot
description: The arrival of a new cookbook dedicated to a hotshot chef and his destination restaurant is usually met with the realization that the volume is more advanced than our brains can fathom, although it will look lovely on a coffee table or impressive on a shelf. You might expect more of the same from Astrance: A Cooks Book (ditions du Chne, $95), the new tome from the 12-year-old, 25-seat Michelin-starred Parisian restaurant that was recently ranked 18th in the world. Astrances chef Pascal Barbot is a master, after all. But Astrance, which was written by Chihiro Masui and Barbots business partner Christophe Rohat, who is responsible for everything that goes on in the front of house, is an entirely unorthodox, or as Masui might say, unnatural, cookbook. In it, what Barbot calls spoken recipes reveal more about the chefs process and approach than the traditional combination of head notes and directions do.

title: Media Baubles: A Just-in-the-Click-of-Time Gift Guide
description: Not that long ago, someone here, we wont say who, came up with the bright idea of doing a media-centric gift guide. There was a fair amount of skepticism, but when the list was produced, it settled everything. Some of the best editorial minds in the hemisphere  well, actually, the dark overlords of the media kingdom at The New York Times  judged it to be ill-considered, dumb, awkwardly executed and full of log-rolling.

title: Ackman Outlines Bet Against Herbalife
description: From the perspective of Herbalifes executives, the company is built on a sound model that benefits its participants.

title: Recommended Reading: Journo-Code Commit Messages
description: New York Times interactive news developer Tyson Evans wrote this fantastic article thats sure to fill you with holiday cheer: Updated horse parser: The year in journo-code commit messages at NiemanLab.org.

title: Boehner Cancels Tax Vote in Face of G.O.P. Revolt
description: WASHINGTON  Speaker John A. Boehners effort to pass fallback legislation to avert a fiscal crisis in less than two weeks collapsed Thursday night in an embarrassing defeat after conservative Republicans refused to support legislation that would allow taxes to rise on the most affluent households in the country.

title: Shorter Stairway to Heaven: Rock Stars Die Younger, Study Finds
description: A new study confirms what music fans have long suspected: rock and pop musicians die prematurely more often than the general population.

title: A Brief History of the New York Stock Exchange
description: The New York Stock Exchange, with its opening bell and floor traders, has been the public image of a stock market for two centuries

title: Why Renters Use More Electricity
description: Why do people buy inefficient refrigerators and clothes washers when spending a little more for an efficient one would save them money over time through lower electricity or water bills? There are a variety of reasons, but one that is persistently cited is that people are not necessarily buying these appliances for themselves. Often the buyer is a landlord, and the user is a tenant who does not make the choice but faces the consequences because he receives the energy bill.

title: Shell Be Thankful for the Memory
description: FLASH memory drives come in many odd forms  disguised as plastic sushi pieces, Swiss Army knives and Hello Kitty figures. Now, a contender for the oddest: a vibrator.

title: Russian Ban on U.S. Adoptions Moves Forward
description: A law that would prohibit adoptions of Russian children by United States citizens passed Russias lower house of Parliament on Wednesday. The bill (in retaliation for a new United States law that seeks to punish Russian citizens who are accused of violating human rights) still faces two more legislative votes, and President Vladimir V. Putin has evaded the question of whether or not he would sign it.

title: The View from Notre Dame: Russells Twist of Fate
description: In December 2011, KeiVarae Russell traded in his childhood dream of suiting up for Southern California for a new one of playing for Notre Dame. One year later, Russell, a freshman cornerback, can realize the biggest dream of all: a national championship.

title: Bistro SK in City Island
description: At night, City Island is left to its residents, who have welcomed Bistro SK as if positively starved for coq au vin and bavette, hanger steak with red wine-shallot sauce.

title: Making It Easier to Estimate Libor Losses
description: The potential victims of the Libor scandal are starting to estimate the costs to their bottom lines.

title: A Bistro in the Bronx With a Warm Welcome
description: FOR all the restaurants in New York City claiming the name bistro, it is rare to find one with the most crucial ingredient. Its not duck confit; its a dining room where everyone is welcomed and waited on by the owner, who may also be (or be married to) the chef.

title: Q&A: Easing the Pain of Computing
description: Q.

title: Forget the East-West Divide; Its Berlin vs. Munich
description: For the German director Christian Petzold, the subject of his latest film, Barbara  a character study of an East German doctor torn between her sense of professional responsibility and a desire to escape to the West with her lover  is one that hits close to home. He was born in West Germany to parents who had fled together from East Germany, but as a child and adolescent, he would return with them to East Germany each summer, to enjoy the warmth and affection of the many relatives who had remained behind while also experiencing what he now describes as an atmosphere that was very, very mistrustful in the larger society.

title: Nearly 30,000 Jobs Lost Because of Hurricane Sandy
description: Hurricane Sandy wiped out nearly 30,000 jobs in and around New York City last month, the New York State Labor Department said on Thursday.

title: Hoping for a Silent Night
description: My wife and I raised our boys (twins, 6, and their brother, 1) to believe in Santa. My sister decided against it with her little ones (6, 4, 2 and 1). We will be together for a day around Christmas, and she wrote that if Santa comes up, her oldest will spill the beans, causing confusion and possibly heartbreak. She suggested we tell our children not to mention Santa, and asked what I thought. What do you think?

title: $1,200 a Pound, Truffles Suffer in the Heat
description: PARIS  Just about everything in Eduardo Manzanaress shop, Truffes Folies, is made with truffles. Sausage, cheese, spaghetti  even popcorn.

title: NYSE Euronexts Decent Deal for Its Suffering Shareholders
description: At least Duncan Niederauer, the NYSE Euronext chief executive, isnt blind to the inevitable. He has agreed to sell the Big Board to IntercontinentalExchange for $8.2 billion.

title: Cash and Debit Prevail This Holiday Season
description: The holiday season is one time when my credit card gets a heavy workout, and this year is no different. But Im apparently an outlier, according to a survey of holiday consumer spending.

title: Cardinal Finds a Biblical Parallel in a School Aides Selfless Life and Death
description: KATONAH, N.Y.  To those who know what aides do for the disabled children in their care, it was no surprise that after a gunman invaded the Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., the body of Anne Marie Murphy was found slumped protectively over at least one of her charges, a 6-year-old boy named Dylan Hockley.

title: Whos to Blame for the Fiscal Cliff Impasse?
description: Republicans are trying to blame the apparent impasse in fiscal cliff negotiations on President Obama and the Democrats.

title: Sale of Wright House Assures Its Preservation
description: PHOENIX  A house designed by Frank Lloyd Wright here for his son was sold on Thursday, guaranteeing its preservation after it had been threatened for months with demolition by its owners, who had planned to replace it with new homes.

title: Internet Meme Goes Analog
description: The viral 8-bit meme Nyan Cat has inspired a pop-up store in New York City.

title: Syrian Television Journalist Announces Defection
description: In a telephone interview shown on Thursday by the Saudi news channel Al Arabiya, a man who identified himself as Ahmad Fakhouri, a prominent Syrian state television anchor, announced his defection.

title: Should Felton Be Shooting So Much?
description: Because the Knicks offense has been so strong under the direction of Raymond Felton, there is a sense that his passing has led to the eye-popping production. After all, part of the thinking behind letting Jeremy Lin leave was that the Knicks, with Carmelo Anthony as the teams centerpiece, needed a more traditional point guard at the controls.

title: Snow Fall: The Avalanche at Tunnel Creek
description: The snow burst through the trees with no warning but a last-second whoosh of sound, a two-story wall of white and Chris Rudolphs piercing cry: Avalanche! Elyse!

title: Milan Fashion House to Join the Diesel Empire
description: LONDON  Renzo Rosso, the Italian executive who has turned cool style into big bucks, is expanding his empire.

title: The Avalanche at Tunnel Creek
description: Fresh powder beckoned 16 expert skiers and snowboarders into the backcountry. Then a slab of snow cracked and swept violently down the mountain. No one knew how many were caught.

title: UBS Unit Admits Guilt in Rate Case
description: Peter Eavis and David Gillen of The New York Times discuss UBS, which became the first big global bank in more than two decades to have a subsidiary plead guilty to fraud.

title: Former Top Banker Testifies in Spain Behind Closed Doors
description: MADRID  Rodrigo Rato, a former top banking official in Spain and a former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, on Thursday became the most prominent banker to appear in a Spanish court since the start of the countrys financial crisis.

title: Pogues 12 Days of Gadgets: The Touchfire iPad Keyboard
description: Thumpity thump-thump  thats the sound your fingers make on an iPad screen when they try to type. Its not an efficient process. You sort of have to keep looking down at the glass to see where your fingers are. In short, typing is not, ahem, the iPads shining moment.

title: Brian McGrory Rises From Boston Globe Paperboy to Become the Papers Next Editor
description: 8:44 p.m. | Updated The Boston Globe announced on Thursday that Brian McGrory, a columnist and former metro editor at the newspaper and a Boston native with deep roots in the area, would be its next editor. The appointment is effective immediately.

title: Web Service Raises $7 Million to Automate Your Life
description: IFTTT, the nifty Web service that offers a way to automate tasks online, just got a nice holiday present: a significant chunk of change from the venture capital firms Andreessen Horowitz, NEA and Lerer Ventures.

title: Inventing Abstraction
description: A look at the new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: For All His Flaws, an Influential Ceramist
description: The British ceramist Michael Cardew carefully recorded his anxieties and failures. From his 1920s apprenticeships until his death in 1983, he traveled worldwide, proselytizing for traditional, handmade ceramics and writing confessional diary entries and letters to his family. He detailed his nightmares about misfortunes befalling his wife and three sons during his long absences, and his frustrating efforts to set up self-sufficient potteries in Ghana and Nigeria.

title: When the Future Became Now
description: In the second decade of the 20th century, abstraction became the holy grail of modern art. It was pursued with feverish intent by all kinds of creative types in Europe, Russia and elsewhere, responding to assorted spurs: Cubism and other deviations from old-fashioned realism, the beautiful whiteness of the blank page, communion with nature, spiritual aspirations, modern machines and everyday noise.

title: Two Inaugural Balls to Honor Obama Guests and Military Families
description: President Obama will hold just two official inaugural balls  one for guests of his choosing, with some limited tickets for the public, and the other to honor military families  after he takes the oath of office to begin his second term, inaugural planners said Thursday.

title: Egypts Chief Prosecutor Retracts His Resignation
description: CAIRO  Egypts chief prosecutor withdrew his resignation on Thursday, just days after submitting it. The move was the latest bizarre turn in a complicated three-way struggle among the new Islamist president, the institutions of the old government and the presidents opposition in the streets.

title: The Push for Gun Control
description: TimesCast Politics: The history and future of gun-control legislation. | The upcoming challenges for the Democratic Party. | The sharp divide on the fiscal talks.

title: Hollande Uses Softer Tone on Delicate Visit to Algeria
description: PARIS  On a delicate and closely watched visit to Algeria, President Franois Hollande of France on Thursday acknowledged the profoundly unjust and brutal nature of Frances colonial rule, a statement seen in both countries as heralding a change of tone. But Mr. Hollande did not make an apology for Frances conduct, although Algeria has long pressed for one.

title: The Giving Spree | Tiina Laakkonen
description: Who: The fashion stylist and new store owner Tiina Laakkonen, whose Amagansett home was featured in Ts Design and Living issue.

title: Boomers and Millennials Feel a Need to Care for One Another
description: Last summer there was a media frenzy about a supposed war between greedy baby boomers who are sucking up the nations resources, and young adults, the millennials, doomed to a bleak financial future. Are Millennials the Screwed Generation? asked the Daily Beast, which never lets itself get bogged down by nuances.

title: Where Is Jack Goldstein?
description: Venus Over Manhattan

title: Rackstraw Downes
description: Betty Cuningham Gallery

title: Terry Allen: Ghosts: Works From Dugout/ Ghost Ship Rodez/ and Others
description: Nyehaus

title: Cellblock I and Cellblock II
description: Andrea Rosen Gallery

title: Alicja Kwade: The Heavy Weight of Light
description: Harris Lieberman

title: Gooding, Williams, Rashad Join Trip to Bountiful Cast
description: The Oscar winner Cuba Gooding Jr., and the Tony nominees Vanessa Williams and Condola Rashad will join Cicely Tyson in The Trip To Bountiful on Broadway, the producers said on Thursday.

title: A Tokyo Ramen Innovator Eyes the Lower East Side
description: There has been a lot of buzz about Ivan Orkin, the American chef who took the Frank Sinatra route  his way  with ramen in Tokyo. He is now in New York and plans to open a version of his popular ramen restaurants on the Lower East Side.

title: Iron Curtain Exhibition at Hebrew Home
description: A perk of living in a city brimming with artists and art lovers is that there tends be a lot of stuff around. Having a surplus means that terrific work can end up in unexpected places. Many of those places are fun to seek out.

title: Pushed and Pulled, a Doctor Wants a Way Out
description: Barbara is a film about the old Germany from one of the best directors working in the new: Christian Petzold. For more than a decade Mr. Petzold has been making his mark on the international cinema scene with smart, tense films that resemble psychological thrillers, but are distinguished by their strange story turns, moral thorns, visual beauty and filmmaking intelligence. His latest to open in the United States, Barbara, begins in 1980 with an East German doctor from Berlin (Nina Hoss) who, after an unspecified offense, has been recently banished to the boonies. There, in between hospital rounds and harassment from the secret police, she waits and she burns.

title: Applicants Continue to Flock to Early Admission Programs
The Caucus: Paying Final Respects
A Bronzino Portrait Heads to Auction
description: Agnolo Bronzino was the go-to guy for power portraits in 16th-century Florence. They were generally commissioned by wealthy people to convey a certain swagger and confidence, said Nicholas Hall, head of Christies international department of old master paintings.

title: In Japan, a Test of Inflation Targets
description: Under a paper-money system, a determined government can always generate higher spending and, hence, positive inflation.

title: Bloomberg, Incensed by Shooting, Vows Stiffer Fight to Rework Gun Laws
description: It is a moment when Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs heart races and his breath gets caught in his throat: the ringing of a bedside telephone in the middle of the night.

title: Fewer First-Time Buyers
description: TWO recent national surveys of real estate agents suggest that first-time buyers are on the decline, their access to the housing market blocked by tight credit and eager investors.

title: Memorials, Along With Some Mischief
description: The New York solo debut of the Berlin-based artist and writer Hito Steyerl at e-flux is one of the best gallery shows of the season. Ms. Steyerl works primarily in video, but defines the medium broadly to include documentary, staged history, what look like found film images and the near-equivalent of home movies.

title: The Nervous Leading the Blind to the End
description: Praising the virtues of the radio dramas from his childhood, Stephen King once noted that the perfect monster is the one you make in your mind.

title: White House Asks Police for Help in Shaping Gun Control Policy
description: The White House recruited national law enforcement leaders on Thursday to help shape a response to last weeks school shootings in Connecticut, hoping to use the credibility of Americas police officers to build support for measures curbing the spread of assault weapons.

title: An Interview With Patrick Gaspard
description: The Timess Jeff Zeleny interviews Patrick Gaspard, the executive director of the Democratic National Committee, about some upcoming challenges his party faces.

title: Awaiting the End in a Small Turkish Town
description: ISTANBUL  Despite assurances from leading Islamic and Christian clerics and the global skepticism based on scientific facts, as many as 10,000 people are expected to descend on a small Turkish town in the Aegean region in hopes of being among the few to survive the Dec. 21, 2012, doomsday supposedly predicted by the Mayan calendar.

title: Theater Listings for Dec. 21-27
description: Theater

title: Sense of Restraint About Zinfandels
description: THE wine panel generally explores a particular region, genre or vintage in all its manifestations. We might examine the 2007 Barolos, for example, or survey recent Mosel kabinett rieslings or Mendocino pinot noirs. Our tasting coordinator, Bernard Kirsch, always shops retail and puts together a representative sampling.

title: Start Your Engines!
description: Indoor karting lets you meet your need for speed in cavernous warehouse-size buildings that accommodate multiple tracks for racers of all ages.

title: Ladies, Gentlemen and Kids, Start Your Engines!
description: Drivers in New York have two choices: slow bumper-to-bumper traffic and fast bumper-to-bumper traffic. Everyone knows Option 1. It is an existential condition in the city.

title: CNN, Planning New Programming, Hires Jake Tapper From ABC
description: 8:57 p.m. | Updated CNN said on Thursday that it had hired Jake Tapper, the senior White House correspondent for ABC News, as new programming for the cable news channel was announced.

title: Souffled Horseradish Oysters
description: 6 tablespoons crme frache

title: Why Does Everyone Have a Grandma and Grandpa Except Me?
description: Why does everyone have a grandma and grandpa except me? my 4-year-old daughter asked me a couple of weeks ago as we snuggled on the couch. I answered her the way I have answered my 8-year-old son over the past five years: Grandma and Grandpa are in heaven, so even though you cant see them, they are watching you all the time.

title: Citys Incarceration Rate Plummets as Nations Climbs
description: Even as the prison population across the country continues to grow, New York City officials said on Thursday that they had recorded a large drop in the citys rate of incarceration.

title: Vain Glorious | Dr. Philippe Allouche on the Bio-Lift Facial
description: A facial massage that feels more like an annual checkup  assessing hydration, elasticity and epidermal water loss  is an intriguing way to start a spa treatment. Dr. Philippe Allouche of the French skin care line Biologique Recherche has been practicing medical beauty since the early 1990s. His clinical, holistic Bio-Lift facial at the Peninsula Spa in New York professes to reshape the face. T spoke to Dr. Allouche about the virtues of electrical currents, the healing power of the hand and his golden rule: never, ever do steam extractions.

title: Venison and Zinfandel Wines
description: The weather and the wine demanded a plate of robust food. Ourzinfandels had class, soI chose venison, sophisticated and festive. And when I discovered that DArtagnan, the meat and luxury food purveyor, offered venison osso buco, I decided that was the ticket. Venison is leaner than veal, but braising made it rich and tender. (Boneless venison stew meat could be used instead.) Cranberries, red wine, sweet parsnips and a heady whiff of allspice rounded out the dish. Broad noodles or grits alongside would welcome a pool of the abundant sauce. And remember to provide small forks for the lagniappe, the bone marrow. FLORENCE FABRICANT

title: Comedy Listings for Dec. 21-27
description: Comedy

title: When the Auto Moved In
description: IN the no-holds-barred luxury residential market, its a constant battle to find something to offer picky millionaires. Among the most unusual lures are the super-handy parking spaces in the 19-story Sky Garage at 11th Avenue and 24th Street, where sales began in 2007 and ended this year. The architect Annabelle Selldorf gave 14 apartments there separate elevators so that residents could park their cars within 10 feet of their living rooms. This amenity is not without a precedent: the town-house garage of the early 1900s.

title: Best Songs of 2012
description: This week, the Times pop critics Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Nate Chinen and Ben Ratliff discuss their favorite songs of 2012.

description: Movies

description: Pop

title: U.S. Makes Arrest in Olympus Scandal
description: Federal agents arrested a former bank executive in Los Angeles on Thursday in connection with the accounting scandal that erupted last year at Olympus, the Japanese camera and medical equipment maker.

title: Transcript of The Choice Blogs College Application Help Line
description: On Wednesday, The Choice hosted a live, hourlong College Application Help Line on Facebook, in an effort to help high school seniors and their families navigate this pivotal period of the admissions process with confidence.

title: The Good News in the Fare Increases, Relatively Speaking
description: There was one relatively good piece of good news arising from the subway and bus fare increase announced Wednesday, relatively being the key word. Under the new fare structure, the break-even point for a 30-day unlimited MetroCard  that is, the point at which the unlimited card becomes a better deal than the pay-per-ride card  comes sooner, at 48 rides instead of 50.

title: TimesCast Politics: The Push for Gun Control
description: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times

title: Brooklyns Mayans Pretty Sure World Wont End Friday
description: If the world is ending Friday, as many earthlings say the ancient Mayans predicted, there were no signs of panic, prophesying or much else out of the ordinary on Thursday on the streets of New Yorks most densely Mayan neighborhood, Bath Beach in Brooklyn.

description: Jazz

title: When the Manners Police Knock
description: WE are self-appointed, and we wear the badge of moral righteousness. Some of us police the waterfront, and some of us, the mountaintop.

title: Peter Madoff Is Sentenced to 10 Years for His Role in Fraud
description: 8:48 p.m. | Updated

description: Classical

title: Dance Listings for Dec. 21-27
description: Dance

title: Once Banished, Never Silenced
description: Outstanding artworks in the Vietnam-era department of my personal mental museum include: James Rosenquists F-111; Peter Sauls hallucinatory paintings of rape and carnage in Vietnam; Claes Oldenburgs monumental sculpture of a giant lipstick standing vertically on military tank tracks; and Judith Bernsteins mural-scale, charcoal drawings of enormous phallic screws. All of these have in common a more or less explicit metaphorical conflation of war and sexual violence.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Robot Pack Mule and Potato People
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: The Just-Do-It Apartment
description: FOR more than a dozen years, ever since his divorce, Richard Carbone had rented a two-bedroom apartment in Suffolk County on Long Island. It was near his business, Tech Steel and Materials, a seller of specialty metals. His rent was around $2,000 a month.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Dec. 21-27
description: Art

title: Boston Radio Station Switches to Electronic Dance Format
description: Dance music just doesnt work on the air.

title: Pictures of the Day: Russia and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Russia, Turkey, Pakistan and Sri Lanka.

title: A Continents Art on a Long American Journey
description: Its easy to take for granted just how quickly art travels today, whether by JPEG or shipping crate. For a sense of how slow things were just a century ago, and how much could get lost en route from one continent to another, visit African Art, New York, and the Avant-Garde, a small but highly compelling show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Its one of several exhibitions timed to the centennial of the Armory Show of 1913, where many New Yorkers caught their first glimpse of Modern art from Europe (much of it influenced by African sculpture).

title: Spare Times for Children for Dec. 21-27
description: CHRISTMAS CAROLS: A SCROOGE MASH-UP

title: Thrill-Seeking Beats Take the Scenic Route
description: First the good news: America the Beautiful has rarely looked more ripe for exploration than it does in On the Road, a noble attempt by the Brazilian director Walter Salles (The Motorcycle Diaries, Central Station) to capture literary lightning in a bottle. With spacious skies stretching endlessly over open, uncongested roads bordered by amber waves of grain, and purple mountains beckoning in the distance, the movie resurrects a perennial frontier dream and invites you to barrel into the unknown with its Beat Generation legends.

title: Hints of Mischief Waft in Spirit of the Season
description: Wonder and innocence, gaudiness and cheer: can it be any surprise that the jazz drummer Matt Wilson thrives around the holidays? His Christmas Tree-O, which released a scrappy and endearing album on Palmetto two years ago, does more or less what youd expect, batting around holiday standards with a mischievous but sentimental air.

title: Spare Times for Dec. 21-27
description: Around Town

title: A Bunch of Drummers and Friends, Thinking About Home and John Cage
description: If you have followed the exploits of So Percussion, you will probably recognize that Where (we) Live, the new show that the group has mounted at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Harvey Theater, is a project its members have been working toward for some time now. If not, you will probably be perplexed, if pleasantly so. You may even wonder what the goings-on have to do with contemporary classical music, the sphere from which So Percussion emerged.

title: A Debut With a Proustian Touch
description: The violinist Paul Huangs Francophile New York recital debut on Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall had an unlikely literary connection.

title: Gil Friesen, Entertainment Executive, Dies at 75
description: Gil Friesen, who achieved success in films and television but was best known for helping to establish A&M Records as an artists haven for an eclectic stable of performers that included Carole King, the Police, Barry White and the Carpenters, died on Dec. 13 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 75.

title: A Mad Dash to Avoid a Bigger Tax Bite
description: NOT that anybody needs more stress during the holiday season, but sellers and their brokers and lawyers across the country have been scrambling to close deals and avoid January tax increases that will eat into their profits.

title: Super Bowl, Tebow, Saints: Answers to Readers Questions
description: Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, answers questions from readers.

title: The Formidable Co-op Approval Process
description: NO matter how wealthy you are, or how much money you spend on a co-op apartment in New York City, what you have to go through to get approved by the buildings board of directors is a level of scrutiny that no one is spared.

title: Oh, Humbug, Magoo, Youve Done It Again
description: ITS that time of year.

title: German Health Care Attracts Foreign Patients
description: BERLIN  When Jalal Talabani, the president of Iraq, needed advanced medical care for a stroke suffered this week, he flew not to the United States or Britain but to Germany, for treatment here in the capital.

title: Assange Addresses Dozens in London
description: As my colleague Michael Cieply reports, six months after Julian Assange stepped into the small Ecuadorean Embassy in London, seeking political asylum, several Hollywood filmmakers are at work on dramatic treatments of the WikiLeaks story.

title: Police Dept. to Use Internet to Try to Stop Mass Shootings
description: Top intelligence officials in the New York Police Department met on Thursday to examine ways to search the Internet to identify potential deranged gunmen before they strike, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said.

title: Talking Turkey About Real Estate
description: WHEN it comes to playing the real estate game, the period between Thanksgiving and New Years Day is traditionally a dead zone, thanks to unpredictable weather, relentless family obligations and brimming to-do lists. But this time of year, seeds are often planted that propel housing decisions down the line.

title: Wall St. Downsizes Holiday Parties
description: In the year of Hurricane Sandy, looming fiscal austerity and global scrutiny of banks, Wall Street is just not in a celebratory mood.

title: Playing With the Band When the Music Meant Everything
description: There is plenty of hope but little glory in Not Fade Away, David Chases sympathetic, acutely drawn portrait of a young Italian-American musician in New Jersey chasing 1960s rock n roll dreams. That character, Douglas Damiano (the perfectly cast John Magaro), is not a baby Bruce Springsteen or Jon Bon Jovi surrogate ascending to the pantheon while the whole world cheers. Near the beginning of the movie, a voice-over narrator, Douglass younger sister Evelyn (Meg Guzulescu), remarks, Like most bands, youve never heard of them.

title: A Pile of Debt, for Colleges and Students Alike
description: To the Editor:

title: The Envelope, Please: Will Walker
description: Will Walker, a student at University School in Hunting Valley, Ohio, undergoes the worst day in my life as he awaits his early admissions fate.

title: Neighborhood Joint: Juggling as a Business
description: Brian Dube spent so much time juggling as a youth that he dropped out of college to spend more time at it. At 61, hes still at it, operating Dube Juggling Equipment in Manhattan.

title: Patersons Radio Show Is Being Dropped
description: ALBANY  Former Gov. David A. Patersons career as a radio host on WOR-AM (710) lasted little more than a year.

title: Childrens Online Privacy Rules: Winners and Losers
description: Now that the Federal Trade Commission has published its updated privacy protections for children online, Facebook may finally open its site to children under 13, industry analysts say.

title: Applicants Continue to Flock to Early Admission Programs
Almost Like Being in Vegas
description: For me, Cirque du Soleil will always be associated with the movie Knocked Up, in which the characters played by Seth Rogen and Paul Rudd take in a performance of Mystre under the influence of hallucinogenic mushrooms. If such a trip is not to your taste, or if a trip to Las Vegas is not on your calendar, you might opt for the relatively inexpensive, mildly mind-blowing Cirque du Soleil: Worlds Away, a new 3-D movie directed by Andrew Adamson.

title: Where Things Forever Seem Up in the Air
description: WEIGHTY questions get tossed around at Dube Juggling Equipment, a third-floor shop in SoHo where visitors can get caught in a debate about local unicycling laws or a discourse on the mathematician Claude Shannons juggling theorem.

title: Rebounding in Pittsburgh
description: A lively stretch of Penn Avenue in once-blighted Garfield offers evidence of an area in transition.

title: Paranoia From Both Left and Right
description: Like one of those optical illusions that can be viewed as two completely different things, Patrea Patricks American Empire will give you whiplash.
