At first glance this eye-rollingly melodramatic documentary seems to be a left-wing attack on unbounded corporate power. Just squint a little, however, and youll see a right-wing conspiracy rant whose attacks on the Federal Reserve would make Ron Paul thrill.

title: Proposal Would Force Bank Loan Write-Downs
description: An accounting rule that would often force banks to take loan write-downs well before loans actually go bad was preliminarily proposed on Thursday by the Financial Accounting Standards Board, which sets American accounting rules.

title: France: Budget Proposal Approved
description: The Parliament on Thursday approved the Socialist governments 2013 budget proposal, a rigorous and contested plan to drop the deficit to 3 percent of the gross domestic product with $26 billion in increased taxes on individuals and businesses and savings of $13 billion through a freeze in public spending. Members of the opposition called the tax increases unfair, citing, for instance, a 75 percent rate applied to income over $1.3 million and $13 billion in additional taxes on corporations already worried about high labor costs. Some on the left said the spending cuts were out of step with President Franois Hollandes promises to promote growth and avoid austerity measures. The budget was based on growth projections of 0.8 percent for 2013, a figure some economists said was too optimistic.

title: Canada: Court Seeks a Balance on Veils
description: The Supreme Court of Canada ruled Thursday that witnesses could cover their faces for religious reasons while testifying in court under some circumstances. A Muslim woman, who cannot be named under a court order, asked to wear a niqab, a full-face veil, for religious reasons when testifying in an Ontario court against two men whom she has accused of sexual assault. The Supreme Court did not specifically rule on her request. But it provided trial judges with a four-part process for analyzing such requests to maintain a balance between religious freedoms and the right to a fair trial. The defendants lawyers argued that the faces of witnesses provided clues about the truthfulness of their testimony. Canadas immigration minister recently barred women from wearing a niqab when taking the citizenship oath.

title: OSHA Says It Is Investigating Garage Employees Drowning
description: Federal agents have opened an investigation into the death of a man who drowned during Hurricane Sandy at the underground garage in Manhattan where he worked.

title: Use of Death Sentences Continues to Fall in U.S.
description: Thirty-six years after the Supreme Court reinstated the death penalty, its use is waning, with prosecutors and juries preferring to sentence convicted murderers to life in prison without parole. New data for 2012 show that nine states executed inmates this year, the fewest in two decades, and the number of death sentences handed down this year  80  was about a third of the total in 2000.

title: Not a Happy Homecoming
description: It would be interesting to know whether Antonio Mndez Esparza had a Mexican audience or an American one in mind when he made Aqu y All (Here and There), a bare-bones film about what happens when a man named Pedro returns to his Mexican village after working for several years in the United States.

title: A Million Users Desert BlackBerry, and Revenue Falls 48%
description: OTTAWA  Research in Motion said on Thursday that it lost a million BlackBerry owners worldwide during the companys last financial quarter, the first such decline in the devices history.

title: Palestinian Premier Calls for Boycott of Israeli Goods
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Israels refusal this month to transfer tax revenue to the West Bank has undermined the Palestinian Authoritys already dire finances, prompting the prime minister, Salam Fayyad, to call for a boycott of Israeli goods.

title: Tearing Down After Sandy
description: On Dec. 20, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers began demolishing houses severely damaged by Hurricane Sandy.

title: Instagram Does an About-Face
description: 11:14 p.m. | Updated SAN FRANCISCO  In the aftermath of the uproar over changes to Instagrams privacy policy and terms of service earlier this week, the company did an about-face late Thursday.

title: Marijuana, Not Yet Legal for Californians, Might as Well Be
description: LOS ANGELES  Let Colorado and Washington be the marijuana trailblazers. Let them struggle with the messy details of what it means to actually legalize the drug. Marijuana is, as a practical matter, already legal in much of California.

title: A Stickler for Order Finds Chaos as Usual
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Several Giants players have recently become fond of saying they have been here before, repeating a company line that has grown more prominent as the team deals with another late-season stumble and the pressure of needing to win the last two games to guarantee a spot in the playoffs.

title: Georgia: A Stalinist Restoration
description: A municipal assembly in Gori on Thursday voted to restore a monument of Stalin, the Soviet leader who died in 1953. It was a rebuke to President Mikheil Saakashvili, who has tried to clear Georgia of all vestiges of Soviet symbolism. A monument of Stalin stood for 48 years in the central square in Gori, his birthplace, until June 2010, when the authorities removed it. Mr. Saakashvilis party was defeated in October by an opposition coalition led by Bidzina Ivanishvili. Some members of Mr. Ivanishvilis coalition promised to restore monuments to Stalin in Gori and other cities. Zviad Khmaladze, the leader of Goris district assembly, said that $15,000 would be allocated to set up the monument near the small house where Stalin was born.

title: Borking Before Bork
description: THE death on Wednesday of Robert H. Bork, the conservative judge whose Supreme Court nomination was rejected by the Senate in 1987, has prompted a flood of commentaries describing his confirmation battle as a historic turning point. By opposing Mr. Bork for his right-wing views, it is alleged, Senate Democrats engaged in an unprecedented act of brazen partisanship against Ronald Reagans nominee, politicizing a once deferential process.

title: Labs, Washed Away
description: BEDPAN ALLEY is the affectionate name given to a stretch of First Avenue in Manhattan that is packed with more hospitals than many cities possess. This stretch also happened to be right in the flood zone during Hurricane Sandy. Water damage and power failures closed down all three of the New York University teaching hospitals  Bellevue Hospital, Tisch Hospital and the Manhattan V.A. Two months later, they are still not admitting patients, though two are on schedule to begin doing so shortly.

title: Preparing Students for a Newtown-like Disaster
description: IN the hours after the massacre in Newtown, Conn., parents kept asking if they should discuss the horrific events with young children who might otherwise not realize their schools were similarly vulnerable.

title: Possible Defense Nominee Faulted for Record on Gays
description: WASHINGTON  Chuck Hagel, the former Nebraska senator on President Obamas short list for defense secretary, came under fire again on Thursday, this time for his record on gay rights and remarks he made 14 years ago about an openly gay nominee for a diplomatic post.

title: Quaker Oats Prepares to Court Younger, More Diverse Moms
description: THE Quaker Oats Company, in its quest to refresh the companys 135-year-old image, could borrow the phrase everything old is new again for a new campaign that makes subtle tweaks to the companys tried and true marketing approach in hopes of appealing to modern mothers, a new target for the brand.

title: Another Questionable Bank Settlement
description: The Department of Justice would like you to believe it has finally gotten tough with a too-big-to-fail bank. As part of the global investigation into interest-rate-rigging at the worlds biggest banks, it has extracted a guilty plea for felony wire fraud from UBS Securities Japan, a subsidiary of UBS, the Swiss bank.

title: N.H.L. Moves Closer to Canceling Season
description: The N.H.L. may have reached the brink of canceling the 2012-13 season, with an announcement Thursday that it had scratched another two weeks worth of games, through Jan. 14.

title: A Tax Credit Worth Preserving
description: Lawmakers interested in simplifying the corporate tax code must take care to protect the low-income housing tax credit, which allows corporations to reduce their tax liabilities by investing in affordable housing. Without it, affordable-housing construction, which already falls far short of the need, would quickly grind to a halt.

title: Real or Not, Worlds End Is Trouble for Schools
description: Predictions of doomsday have come and gone repeatedly without coming true. But the latest prophecy, tethered to the Mayan calendar and forecasting that the world will self-destruct on Friday, has prompted many rumors of violence, with a particular focus on school shootings or bomb threats.

title: Playing Taxes Hold Em
description: A few years back, there was a boom in poker television  shows in which you got to watch the betting and bluffing of expert card players. Since then, however, viewers seem to have lost interest. But I have a suggestion: Instead of featuring poker experts, why not have a show featuring poker incompetents  people who fold when they have a strong hand or dont know how to quit while theyre ahead?

title: ICE Deal for N.Y.S.E. Creates Global Powerhouse
description: It was the temple of commerce, the symbol of New Yorks status as the nations  and for many decades, the worlds  financial center.

title: Swept Away and Torn Apart in a Sea of Despair
description: The Asian tsunami of Dec. 26, 2004, killed almost a quarter-million people in 14 countries. The scale and speed of the devastation defy comprehension, and no movie could be expected to convey the full measure of the horror. But disaster, real and imagined, is a staple of the modern cinematic imagination, and an event like the tsunami presents itself to an ambitious filmmaker as both a technical challenge and a moral risk.

title: Paper Tigers and Glass-jawed Bullies
description: On Friday, after a week of hiding, the National Rifle Association will attempt to explain why it has spent more than two decades trying to ensure that weapons of mass murder are accessible to madmen. They will probably make pious remarks about the children slaughtered one week ago, divert attention to the moral rot of Hollywood and secular society, and throw out other distractions as part of their promised contribution to solving a uniquely American pathology.

title: Former Olympian Cites Depression for Taking Job as Escort
description: Suzy Favor Hamilton was a top American middle-distance runner from the early 1990s to 2000, a three-time Olympian after becoming a nine-time N.C.A.A. champion at Wisconsin. She was so accomplished that the Big Ten Conference named the award given to its female athlete of the year in her honor.

title: Strangers in the Night
description: Its always amazing how little Democrats and Republicans know about each other. Democrats, for example, are mystified that we havent already gotten a deal on the fiscal cliff. On Monday, the two sides seemed close. Both made serious counteroffers, and a deal seemed a day away.

title: Tensions Between Japan and South Korea Complicate Picture for U.S.
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The sighs of relief in Washington have almost been audible. As the United States forges ahead with efforts to counter Chinas influence in Asia, Japan and South Korea this week both elected conservative, pro-American leaders, raising hopes that the United States and its two closest Asian allies can work together on the vexing security issues roiling this economically vibrant region.

title: Resounding Victory in Indian Vote Nudges Polarizing Figure Closer to a Larger Race
description: NEW DELHI  The polarizing leader of the western state of Gujarat, Narendra Modi, inched closer on Thursday to becoming the leading political challenger to Indias dominant Gandhi family by winning a resounding re-election as chief minister.

title: Ex-Officer Loses His Bid to Delay Serving Jail Term
description: A federal judge on Thursday told a former New York City police officer who had been accused of raping a drunken woman he was called to assist that the officer had committed a final act of chutzpah in seeking to further delay serving his jail sentence.

title: Return of a Savior Presents Only Problems
description: Sometime soon, perhaps next week, perhaps even in Phoenix, the city of his greatest basketball exploits, Amare Stoudemire will tuck in that familiar No. 1 jersey, adjust his goggles and take a leap into the great unknown.

title: A Reminder of What Midwest Winters Are About
description: CHICAGO  Snow, absent for so long in much of the Midwest that people seemed to have forgotten all about it, returned with a fury on Thursday. High winds whipped the region, near whiteout conditions left motorists stranded and holiday travel slowed to an inch-by-inch trudge as people abruptly, and in some cases miserably, remembered what winter is about.

title: At the Big Board, Seeking Rejuvenation in Consolidation
description: When the chief executive of IntercontinentalExchange approached his counterpart at NYSE Euronext about a merger in late September, they quickly came to terms, hashing out a deal in only three months.

title: The Fading Mideast Peace Dream
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahus aggressive new push to expand settlements in the West Bank and Jerusalem further isolates Israel while diminishing fading hopes for a two-state solution with the Palestinians.

title: U.N. Council Votes to Help Malis Army Oust Islamists
description: The United Nations Security Council unanimously approved a resolution on Thursday that will send thousands of African troops into the desert nation of Mali to help oust Islamist extremists who have turned its northern half into a vast Qaeda enclave and training ground, menacing the stability of neighboring states and posing a potent new international terrorism threat.

title: National Rifle (Selling) Association
description: The National Rifle Association is scheduled to hold a news conference on Friday where it says it plans to provide details about its promise of meaningful contributions to prevent another a massacre like the one in Newtown, Conn.

title: Russian Speakers Become Prey in Syrian Conflict
description: MOSCOW  Late last month, a Ukrainian blogger and journalist, Anhar Kochneva, sat on a couch in the place where she was being held by a Syrian rebel group and, as one of her captors filmed her, confessed to working at the behest of Russian intelligence services.

title: Mets Seeking New Sponsor In Florida
description: By trading one of their two most prominent players for prospects and by acquiring no free agents this off-season who have any major league stature, the Mets seem likely to go into the 2013 season with a very modest profile and little chance for success. Appropriately enough, the Mets also seem likely to play their spring training games in a stadium with no name.

title: One Boys Death Moves State to Action to Prevent Others
description: Prompted by the death of a 12-year-old Queens boy in April, New York health officials are poised to make their state the first in the nation to require that hospitals aggressively look for sepsis in patients so treatment can begin sooner. Under the regulations, which are now being drafted, the hospitals will also have to publicly report the results of their efforts.

title: For Scott Brown, a Third Round in the Battle Against Partisan Gravity
description: 8:35 p.m. | Updated  An updated version of this blog post can be found here.

title: Attack on Police Complex in Benghazi Kills Four
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  At least four people were killed after militants attacked a security headquarters here on Thursday night, signaling a sharp escalation in a continuing battle between armed Islamist militants in the city and government forces who have been struggling to assert their authority.

title: McElroy Has History of Moving Past Tebow
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Rex Ryan has repeatedly referred to Greg McElroys reputation as a winner as he defends his decision to choose McElroy as the Jets starting quarterback for Sundays game against the San Diego Chargers.

title: Exchange Sale Reflects New Realities of Trading
description: On a warm day in Boca Raton, Fla., the host of a reception for an annual financial conference was not a big bank or a powerful exchange as in years past, but a young firm based in Atlanta.

title: High Energy Is Part of the Package
description: TRACY ANDERSON, the tiny blond fitness guru perhaps best known as Gwyneth Paltrows trainer and business partner, is as bright and sparkly as the Swarovski crystal-encrusted iPhone case she was admiring one recent Thursday.

title: This Weeks Movies | Dec. 21, 2012
description: The New York Times critics on Zero Dark Thirty, Amour, and The Guilt Trip.

title: With Farm Bill Stalled, Consumers May Face Soaring Milk Prices
description: WASHINGTON  Forget the fiscal crisis and the automatic budget cuts. Come Jan. 1, there is a threat that milk prices could rise to $6 to $8 a gallon if Congress does not pass a new farm bill that amends farm policy dating back to the Truman presidency.

title: Kerry Suggests Military Role in Diplomats Security
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John Kerry said Thursday that the United States needed to re-examine how the military might play a greater role in protecting diplomats in dangerous regions in the wake of the attack on the mission in Benghazi, Libya, on Sept. 11 that led to the death of four Americans.

title: How Should Children Learn to Shop?
Regulating Health Habits
description: To the Editor:

title: Torture and the Hunt for Bin Laden
description: To the Editor:

title: After a Massacre, Toughening Laws on Gun Sales
description: To the Editor:

title: Known for Faith as Well as His Play, a Top Recruit Picks Duke, Not B.Y.U.
description: CHICAGO  With a deep breath and a smile, Jabari Parker held up a blue T-shirt with a bright, white D on it. All around the Simeon Career Academy gym on the South Side here, cameras flashed and TV cameras rolled as the country learned that Parker would play college basketball at Duke.

title: N.R.A. Leader, Facing Challenge in Wake of Shooting, Rarely Shies From Fight
description: WASHINGTON  David Keene  big-game hunter, minence grise to conservatives, and now head of the National Rifle Association  was explaining last month why people are buying more guns these days.

title: Roaming Far Afield, Liu Talks of Wages and Sick Pay
description: New Yorks comptroller, John C. Liu, bellowed that the hourly minimum wage should be raised to $11.50. He vowed to crack down on corporate welfare while endorsing tax cuts for small businesses. And he offered a ringing endorsement of mandatory paid sick leave to help the working poor climb out of poverty.

title: Corrections: December 21, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Gaps in F.B.I. Data Undercut Background Checks for Guns
description: CLARKSBURG, W.Va.  Nearly two decades after lawmakers began requiring background checks for gun buyers, significant gaps in the F.B.I.s database of criminal and mental health records allow thousands of people to buy firearms every year who should be barred from doing so.

title: Beats Decisively
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  As someone who loves a good crossword theme, I only begrudgingly started solving the themeless puzzles at the end of the week because it was part of the job. Over time, Ive come to love them for the challenge and fresh entries, but in a sense theres a part of me that still wants that theme. A Friday themeless has to have some really good stuff in it and some dazzling wordplay to impress me now.

title: Suit on Police Stops Is Reinstated
description: In a further blow to the Police Departments database of stop-and-frisk interactions, a state appellate court on Thursday reinstated a lawsuit challenging the polices authority to retain information about people who were arrested after a street stop, but later cleared of criminal charges.

title: Instagrams Loss Is a Gain for Its Rivals
description: One apps loss is another apps gain.

title: Most States Lag on Submitting Mental-Health Records to the F.B.I.
description: Despite a federal push after the 2007 shootings at Virginia Tech, many states have failed to submit more than a handful of mental-health records to the F.B.I.s background-check database. The records are used to prevent the mentally ill from owning guns.

title: A Hockey Anomaly
description: As N.H.L. negotiations stall, the United States is gearing up for the world junior championships. One of its biggest stars, Seth Jones, is an African-American teen with serious skating skill.

title: A Rising Hockey Star With N.B.A. DNA
description: Seth Jones probably should have wound up a basketball player. He is tall, with a great vertical leap, and his father is Popeye Jones, who played 11 years in the N.B.A. and is now an assistant coach with the Nets.

title: Cluster Bombs Used on Civilians in Syria
description: A closer look at the use of cluster bombs by President Bashar al-Assads government.

title: Service Held for Mother of Connecticut Gunman
description: KINGSTON, N.H.  Nancy Lanza, the first victim in the killing spree by her son Adam that left 26 children and staff members dead at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., was mourned on Thursday at a private memorial at the home of a relative in this small New Hampshire town.

title: Syria Unleashes Cluster Bombs on Town, Punishing Civilians
description: MAREA, Syria  The plane came in from the southeast late in the afternoon, releasing its weapons in a single pass. Within seconds, scores of finned bomblets struck and exploded on the homes and narrow streets of this small Syrian town.

title: Princeton Review to Pay Millions After Forging Records
description: The owner of the Princeton Review will pay the government up to $10 million after admitting it falsified attendance records to bill for thousands of hours of taxpayer-financed tutoring services it never provided, federal prosecutors said on Thursday.

title: Restriction Lifted, Sea Otters Can Roam Freely
description: SAN FRANCISCO  California sea otters, hunted to near extinction and more recently denied the chance to roam freely in the southern part of their coastal range, may now swim wherever they choose under a new policy announced by the federal Fish and Wildlife Service.

title: Tensions Rise in Baghdad With Raid on Official
description: WASHINGTON  Iraqi security forces raided the office and home of a leading Sunni official in Baghdad on Thursday, prompting fears that Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki is cracking down on political opponents.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Dec. 21, 2012
description: Until it has all the records of people out there in the country who have been deemed too dangerous to own a firearm, the background check system still looks like Swiss cheese.

title: Amid Bangs and Crunches, an Owners Heart Breaks
description: The wait was over, the machines were in position and there was only one thing left to do. As workers and bystanders fell silent on Thursday afternoon, the excavators giant arm jerked upward then slammed its steel jaws into the roof of the house on Staten Islands eastern shore, tearing out a chunk of shingles and wood.

title: New Scenery for Breaking the Ice With the Taliban
description: PARIS  A year that began with hopes that the Taliban were ready to start talking peace is ending with a final initiative  informal talks outside Paris among Afghanistans competing factions, including militants  that, if anything, exemplifies how little progress has been made in 2012 toward opening negotiations to end the war.

title: Cuomo Says Hell Outline Gun Proposal Next Month
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Thursday that he had started discussions with leaders of the State Legislature about new gun control measures, and that he planned to propose a package of gun legislation in his State of the State address on Jan. 9.

title: Panel Finds Lawmaker Broke Ethics Rules
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Shelley Berkley, Democrat of Nevada, violated House ethics rules when her office repeatedly intervened with federal officials to try to speed payments to her husbands medical practice, the House Ethics Committee has found.

title: Smaller, But Growing Fast
description: The IntercontinentalExchange, started in 2000, agreed to buy the 220-year-old parent of the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday.

title: Fighting Sepsis
description: At the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System, nurses practice sepsis detection on robot patients.

title: U.S. Reopens Waters Off New England for Fishing
description: Regulators on Thursday voted to reopen about 5,000 square miles of protected waters off the coast of New England to new applications from commercial fishing interests. The move drew concern from environmental advocates and praise from fishermen who hope access to the waters will boost the ailing industry.

title: Religion: Rabbis Oppose Israeli Plan in Disputed Area
description: More than 500 American rabbis and cantors have released an open letter to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel asking him not to build settlements in the contested E1 area of the West Bank, saying it would bifurcate a potential Palestinian state and be the final blow to a two-state solution. They said building would also violate commitments Israel has made to the United States, damaging relations between the countries. The United States and many other countries have urged Israel not to proceed with the plans. The letter was sponsored by Rabbis for Human Rights  North America, J-Street and Americans for Peace Now. A spokesman for the Israeli Embassy in Washington said the proposed building is in an area that will remain part of Israel in a future peace agreement with the Palestinians, and will in no way prevent the emergence of a territorially viable Palestinian state.

title: Mother Gathers the Will to Set Examples for Her Children
description: To get back on her feet and return to the work force after making one of the boldest decisions of her life, Angela Washington had to rely not only on wits and tenacity but also on the synergistic efforts of various organizations.

title: Lottery Numbers
Man Shot to Death in Queens Bodega
description: A bodega worker was shot in the head and killed on Thursday evening in what was reported as a robbery on Onderdonk Avenue in Ridgewood, Queens, the police said.

title: Word of the Day | equinox
description: equinox \e-kw-nks, e-\ noun

title: Spencer Cox, AIDS Activist, Dies at 44
description: Spencer Cox, an AIDS activist whose work with a cadre of lay scientists helped push innovative antiretroviral drugs to market, creating the first effective drug protocols to combat the syndrome, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 44.

title: Session Could Prove Awkward for Perry
description: Gov. Rick Perry was at the height of his power in 2011 when the most Republican Texas Legislature in modern times enacted deep spending cuts and handed him one victory after another.

title: Arming More Citizens to Fight Gun Violence in a Gun-Loving State
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Legislature Prepares to Take on Water Projects
description: When the 83rd legislative session begins in January, Texas lawmakers will return to a city of brown lawns and low lakes. Austin has withered, getting just 3 percent of its normal rainfall for the past two months, and Lake Travis has fallen to 37 feet below normal. Most of the rest of the state is also still struggling through a severe drought.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 9 P.M. (ABC) BACK TO THE BEGINNING WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR Using the Old Testament as a guidebook, Ms. Amanpour (above with Zahi Hawass, an Egyptian archaeologist), travels to the lands of the Bible to explore the roots of Judaism, Christianity and Islam, and the stories that not only inspire their followers but also unite all three religions. She also considers the ways that these tales have helped form essential human values. This two-part program concludes next Friday at 9.

title: News Quiz | December 21, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 21
description: NEWS In a deal spanning Wall Street, Atlanta and financial centers in Europe, the owner of the New York Stock Exchange agreed on Thursday to an $8.2 billion deal that would give control of the symbolic cradle of American capitalism to an upstart competitor, IntercontinentalExchange. The takeover illustrates how trading in commodities and derivatives has become much more lucrative than trading in the shares of companies. Ben Protess and Nathaniel Popper report from New York.

title: Test Yourself | Critical Thinking, Dec. 21, 2012
description: This question was written by Jessica Lahey. It comes from the Op-Ed The Emperor of All Identities.

title: Ornaments and Memories
description: In Tree of Life, Joyce Wadler writes about one womans collection of Christmas ornaments  and her memories for each.

title: Putin Puts More Distance Between Russia and Assad
description: BRUSSELS  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Friday added to recent signals that Moscow is slowly distancing itself from the regime of Syrias president, Bashar al-Assad, its longstanding but now severely weakened ally.

title: A Conversation With: Suman Nalwa, head of Delhi Polices Unit for Women
description: Delhi has been shaken by the gang rape last weekend of a 23-year-old woman on a moving bus. Demonstrations have been taking place across the capital, and much of the publics anger has been directed at the police.

title: The Fading Glory of Bihars Sonepur Cattle Mela
description: For centuries, the Sonepur cattle fair in the Saran district of Bihar was one of the largest of its kind on the continent, with traders coming from as far as central Asia each year to buy and sell all kinds of animals, including elephants and horses.

title: Clashes Kill Dozens in Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  About 40 people, many of them children, were killed and scores of others were seriously injured on Friday in renewed attacks along the coastal Tana River delta, Kenyan police officials said.

title: Week 16 Matchups: Different Motivations, Same Goal
description: Falcons (12-2) at Lions (4-10)

title: Medicare Spending Isnt Out of Control
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: The Early Word: Setback
description: In Todays Times:

title: A Plea From the Admissions Office to Go for the Dangerous Essay
description: Daniel Grayson is the associate director of undergraduate admissions at Tufts University in Medford, Mass.

title: Home for the Holidays, or Not: Minnesota, Land of Pink Tinsel  and Doodads
description: Have you had a memorable holiday away from home? Tell us your stories in the comment space here. Well post our favorites on IHT Rendezvous during these last weeks of 2012.

title: North Korea Says It Detained American Over Hostile Acts
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said on Friday that it had charged an American citizen detained there with committing hostile acts against the republic, a crime punishable by years in prison, at a time when the United States is pushing for new sanctions against the reclusive country for a recent rocket launching.

title: Obama Asks Supporters to Push Congress on Gun Control
description: President Obama sought on Friday to enlist supporters to mount a public lobbying campaign on behalf of gun control in the wake of the mass killings in Newtown, Conn., suggesting that Congress would listen only if forced to by a populist backlash to gun violence.

title: Georgian Soldier Disappears in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A soldier from Georgia belonging to the NATO-led mission in Afghanistan has been missing since Wednesday in the southwest of the country, the coalition said on Friday.

title: How Was Your Doomsday?
description: LONDON  One of the most alarming things to have emerged from the hullabaloo over the so-called Mayan doomsday prophecy is how many people in the world actually believed it.

title: Is the Cure for Cancer Inside You?
description: Claudia Steinman saw her husbands BlackBerry blinking in the dark. It had gone untouched for several days, in a bowl beside his keys, the last thing on anybodys mind. But about an hour before sunrise, she got up to get a glass of water and, while padding toward the kitchen, found an e-mail time-stamped early that morning  Sent: Monday, Oct. 3, 2011, 5:23 a.m. Subject: Nobel Prize. Message: Dear Dr. Steinman, I have good news for you. The Nobel Assembly has today decided to award you the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for 2011. Before she finished reading, Claudia was hollering at her daughter to wake up. Dad got the Nobel! she cried. Alexis, still half-asleep, told her she was crazy. Her father had been dead for three days.

title: In a Lime Plaster Job, a Leonardo Moment
description: What do the Sistine Chapel, the Brooklyn Bridge, the Appian Way and the outside of the straw bale house weve been building have in common?

title: Week 16 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
description: Jason and Justin Sablich provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy.

title: Happy Holidays
description: What are you doing over the holidays?

title: A Man of Many Parts Wants More
description: FOR T. I., the rapper, actor, novelist, reality-television star and former resident of the Forrest City Federal Correctional Complex in Arkansas, existential accountings are routine and often occur in the oddest of places. So he seemed unfazed to find himself, on a recent Wednesday afternoon in Hells Kitchen on the set of Current TVs Joy Behar: Say Anything!, amiably fielding questions about federal weapons charges, the emotional veracity of his familys VH1 show, T. I. & Tiny: The Family Hustle, and the long-term romantic prospects of his fellow pop stars Chris Brown and Rihanna.

title: General Electric to Buy Avio for $4.3 Billion
description: LONDON  General Electric agreed on Friday to buy the Italian aerospace company Avio for $4.3 billion, acquiring a long-time partner in its jet engine business.

title: Girl Shot by Taliban Asks That College Not Bear Her Name
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistani teenager who was shot in the head by a Taliban gunman in October has asked a provincial government to reverse its decision to name a college after her, an official said on Friday. But her request was not immediately granted.

title: The Japan-China Bout
description: Preparing for the next round in the Japan-China bout.

title: Changing Face of Finance
description: CHANGING FACE OF FINANCE | The $8.2 billion deal for the New York Stock Exchange showed how the power base in finance has shifted. Once seen as the cradle of American capitalism, the stock exchange has suffered from declining trading volumes and razor-thin margins. Meanwhile, its acquirer, the Atlanta-based IntercontinentalExchange, or ICE, has bolstered its position as trading in commodities and derivatives has become much more lucrative than trading in the shares of companies, DealBooks Ben Protess and Nathaniel Popper write.

title: Opinion Report: Gun Money
description: From the editorial page

title: Friday Reading: Frugal Travel Options in Queens
British Commission Says Bank Reforms Dont Go Far Enough
description: LONDON  Regulators in Britain should have the power to completely split up banks, a government-commissioned report concluded Friday, adding that changes being currently proposed do not go far enough to prevent a future crisis.

title: A Song for the Girl in the White Jacket
description: Dear Diary:

title: Updates on Connecticut Shooting Aftermath
description: A week after the school shooting  in Newtown, Conn., people around the world observed a moment of silence at 9:30 a.m. Church bells rang 26 times for each of the victims who died inside Sandy Hook Elementary School. At least five more victims from the shooting, including three children, were buried on Friday. After a weeklong silence, the National Rifle Association made a case this morning for armed police officers to be stationed at every school. Click to read Thursdays updates.

title: The Civilian Toll of Cluster Munitions
description: C. J. Chivers reports from Marea, Syria, on the governments use of cluster munitions in 2012 against civilians in what appears to be collective punishment.

title: App Smart Extra: More Holiday Apps
description: As befits the date, this weeks App Smart column was about Christmas-related apps. We talked about a variety of them, like photo effects or storytelling ones.

title: The Boardwalk of Lagos
description: LAGOS  For the first time, Monopoly, the American board game, has been customized for Lagos, Nigerias commercial capital. The counsel on the box: Stay sharp  because theres only room at the top for one. For everyone else, theres bankruptcy.

title: Pinnacle to Buy Ameristar Casinos for $869 Million
description: Pinnacle Entertainment agreed on Friday to buy Ameristar Casinos for $869 million in cash, in a deal that would more than double its size.

title: Daily Report: A Million Users Desert BlackBerry, and Revenue Falls 48%
description: Research in Motion said on Thursday that it lost a million BlackBerry owners worldwide during the companys last financial quarter, the first such decline in the devices history, Ian Austen reported on Friday in The New York Times.

title: The Giving Spree | Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby
description: Who: Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby, the British designers responsible for 2012s Olympic torch, for which they earned a spot in Ts Twelve for 12.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Instagram in Retreat, and Jersey Shore Signs Off
description: The photo-sharing app Instagram on Thursday completed a full retreat from its proposed new terms of service that led to instant outcry from users, Nicole Perlroth and Jenna Wortham reported. The question, however, was whether the move came too late from Instagram, which was acquired this year by Facebook and is under the same pressure as its parent company to generate advertising revenue. The proposed changes included a clause that suggested Instagram would share users data  like their favorite places, bands, restaurants and hobbies  with Facebook and its advertisers to direct ads more precisely. In the interim, other services, including Flickr, which coincidentally has just introduced a new app, appeared to be gaining followers.

title: Debt Ceiling Rises Again as Threat for the U.S.
description: The three major ratings agencies shrugged off this weeks breakdown in talks aimed at ending the fiscal impasse in Washington by Jan. 1, saying their outlook for Americas sovereign debt was already negative and would not immediately change.

title: Passing the Bar: Ireland to Get Its Own Version of Cheers
description: Sometimes you want to go where everybody knows your name, and other times you want to go where your name is pronounced with a rich Irish brogue. Ireland, a nation which we understand has its own longstanding tradition of people gathering together in establishments that serve alcohol, will be getting a remade version of the NBC sitcom Cheers that transports its familiar cast of characters from a Boston bar to a rural Irish pub.

title: Apollo Unit to Buy Avivas U.S. Unit for $1.8 Billion
description: A unit of Apollo Global Management agreed on Friday to buy the American operations of Aviva, the British insurer, for about $1.8 billion in cash.

title: What Were Reading
description: BBC: Well, they should have plenty of leftovers. Survivalists, calling themselves preppers, have been storing food for Fridays apocalypse, which may or may not have been predicted by the ancient Mayans.  Glenn Collins

title: Obama Presses Stripped-Down Plan to Limit Tax Increase
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, conceding that a grand bargain for deficit reduction with Speaker John A. Boehner is unlikely, called Friday for Congress to approve a stripped-down measure by years end to prevent a tax increase for all but the richest taxpayers and to extend aid for two million unemployed Americans.

title: Interpretive Freedom
description: In Americas Unwritten Constitution, Akhil Reed Amar, a commendably unorthodox and, in some ways, iconoclastic constitutional scholar at Yale Law School, bucks dominant opinions on both sides of the political spectrum. He contends that the written Constitution points to an unwritten one, and he argues that we can interpret with both intellectual honesty and analytical rigor. Aware that the idea of an unwritten constitution has been abused by judges and scholars on both the left and right, Amar insists that the idea itself is sound  indeed indispensable to the cause of constitutional fidelity  and needs rescuing from its abusers.

title: When You Need a Stand-in for Champagne
description: PARISIn a recent column, my colleague at The New York Times, Eric Asimov, looked at holiday alternatives to Champagne. Some people in Champagne would argue, with some justification, that there is no such thing, but there are certainly a lot of other wines with bubbles.

title: Kerry Named for the Role of a Lifetime
description: WASHINGTON  With a patrician bearing, nearly three decades of service on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, a highly decorated combat career in the Vietnam War, even a father who was a diplomat, John Kerry is the very picture of a secretary of state.

title: Happy Birthday, Larry Eisenberg
description: The name Larry Eisenberg should sound familiar to Times readers. Mr. Eisenberg is among the more active members of our online community, and perhaps the most distinctive. For whenever he comments, he does so in verse. Specifically, in limerick form. Hes the closest thing this paper has to a poet in residence.

title: Kesha Reverses Herself on Die Young Lyrics
description: The massacre of school children in Newtown, Conn., has had reverberations in the radio world, as lyrics that seemed within the bounds of good taste two weeks ago suddenly seem to hit a sour note.

title: Amour Leads Foreign-Language Oscar Shortlist
description: The Academy winnowed down 71 films to a shortlist of 9 today that is heavy on European entries. The films vying for five spots on the ballot are:

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Robert P. George discusses Americas Unwritten Constitution; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Jonathan Mahler talks about the fate of Detroit; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: The Art of Getting Bloomberg Super PAC Money
description: Are you a politician looking for a bit of cash from Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs super PAC?

title: Hanging Around
description: Synchronized spins in Torontos skies.

title: Who Made That Champagne Cork?
description: According to legend, a French monk named Dom Prignon realized that a cork could seal in the fizz and flavor of Champagne after he saw Spanish travelers using tree bark to plug their water gourds. But George Taber, author of To Cork or Not to Cork, and other historians dispute this story. Taber cites evidence of Champagne corks on the Duke of Bedfords household inventory list from 1665  several years before Dom Prignon took charge of the vineyards at the abbey of Hautvillers. Still, Prignon and his name remain indelibly associated with Champagne.

title: Laptop Prop?
description: Im alternately amused and annoyed by the proximity of laptop computers on anchors desks during televised news broadcasts and other public-affairs programming. While Id like to believe its there for the news readers reference as she tracks breaking news, or to look up momentarily forgotten facts like the capital of Estonia, I am more disposed to believe they are just props situated to convey the impression of a (phony) up to the minute information capacity. Does a news program have an ethical responsibility to avoid misrepresenting how current its reporters information is likely to be? Whats more, isnt positioning the laptop to continuously display its manufacturers logo a form of advertising inappropriate for a news organization? JACK KENNY, BUFFALO

title: Our Family Christmas, Rescinded
description: Several years ago, my mother announced that she was spending Christmas in Egypt with friends. I flew home anyway, alone, and spent two days making homemade pierogies and sauerkraut and bread for the traditional Carpatho-Rusyn meal we always have on Christmas Eve. At 10 p.m., my sister had an hour off from her rounds at the hospital. She came home and we ate. Then she left, and I did the dishes.

title: This Weeks Movies: Dec. 21
description: This week, Times critics look at the Kathryn Bigelow drama Zero Dark Thirty, the Michael Haneke film Amour, and Seth Rogen and Barbra Streisand in The Guilt Trip. See all of this weeks reviews here.

title: Snack Time
description: Its hard not to snack at holiday time, but this week Martha Rose Shulman offers some healthful  and economical  alternatives to assuage the guilt.

title: Plains of Blood
description: The Iliad is the goriest of ancient poems. Homer doesnt sugarcoat the death of a hero, or even that of some insignificant Myrmidon. Hes an anatomist of death, a forensic pathologist of the bronze spear and the bronze sword. The Greek and Trojan warriors meet their fates in ways violent, bloody and graphic  had Greek battlefield surgeons existed, they could have used the Iliad as a textbook. Hollywoods violence is merely a weak imitation of what the Greeks recited for centuries.

title: Boehner Again Finds the Speakers Chair Can be Lonely
description: WASHINGTON  Less than 24 hours after failing to advance his plan to avert a fiscal crisis and telling his Republican colleagues to head home for the holidays, Speaker John A. Boehner walked silently into a news conference Friday on Capitol Hill, where reporters then pressured him to explain how he would manage to keep his job.

title: Metaphors, Take Flight
description: Literary critics occasionally practice an aphoristic little art form without a name, one that captures in vivid analogies the distinctive architecture or choreography of a writers sentences. Sometimes critics (or reviewers) celebrate the authors distinctive style, sometimes they mimic it, sometimes they skewer it. Whatever the case, these figurative sketches are always illuminating, and they provide a small literary pleasure of their own along the way.

title: Back From Madness
description: In the vast and growing literature of affliction there is essentially one story: how the writer and her loved ones made it through. From a literary point of view, everything depends on the sensibility of the narrator, her comportment both as the teller and as the main character in her own tale. The readers resistance to these stories can be strong. Severe illness, by its nature, narrows the focus; the palette of experience both intensifies and shrinks; we crawl into the bush, figuratively speaking, and wait out our fate, fighting to survive. There is little suspense: the existence of the memoir is testament to the fact that the author has lived to tell the tale. But what hard-won nugget of wisdom has she brought back from her brief descent into a hell that most of us, for now, have been lucky enough to avoid? Can she give her ordeal meaning beyond the brute fact of the thing itself?

title: Why Am I a Safer Driver?
description: You may not be a shrunken figure perched behind the steering wheel with a homburg on your head and a Gen Yer gritting his teeth in the car behind as you lumber along in the passing lane (at least, not yet) but the fact is you probably dont drive the way you used to.

title: We Shall Go On to the End
description: The second volume of William Manchesters best-selling life of Winston Churchill, published in 1988, left the newly appointed British prime minister in May 1940 standing on the verge of his finest hour. Manchester began work on the third and final volume, but the project was halted in 1998 when he suffered two strokes. Language for me came as easily as breathing for 50 years, he said, and I cant do it anymore.

title: Fraternity of Men
description: The intricate challenge that brothers pose for each other, aptly characterized by the playwright Athol Fugard as a blood knot, is right up there with the most intense, frustrating, rewarding and self-defining of social bonds. If I speak from experience, having one brother, think how much more is George Howe Colt, with three  an older, Harry, and two younger, Ned and Mark  authorized to expatiate on the subject. Anyone whos had the pleasure of reading Colts previous, National Book Award-nominated work, The Big House (2003), will know his delicate, detailed, ironically self-mocking way with prose, and his lucid, affectionate fair-mindedness. That book dealt mainly with the generational fortunes of his Boston/Cape Cod WASP clan; the present one, Brothers, is more a meditation on himself and his contemporaries, seen through the fraternal lens.

title: Where Credit Is Due
description: Mothers and daughters. Lets consider them  not because were intrigued by the eccentricities of women like Big and Little Edie Beale of Grey Gardens or the connection between Mary Wollstonecraft and Mary Shelley, but because fathers and daughters have taken up so much space. A case in point is Louisa May Alcott and her several dads, as Eve LaPlante reasonably argues. Was Louisa really descended solely from the legendary likes of Emerson, Hawthorne and Thoreau, never mind the transcendentally feckless Bronson Alcott? Didnt she have a mother?

title: 40 Days and 40 Nights
description: Antoine Wilsons first novel, The Interloper (2007), had a brilliant conceit. Seeking vengeance against the man who murdered his wifes brother  a crime that has crippled her with depression  Owen Patterson decides to write the killer in jail using a female pseudonym. The convict, Owen muses, would fall in love with his correspondent and then, when she had wholly gained his affection . . . break his heart.

title: Bearing Arms
description: Despite the movie theater massacre in Aurora, Colo., in July  to say nothing of smaller mass shootings elsewhere in the United States this year  the issue of gun control was conspicuously absent from the 2012 presidential campaign. It wasnt until mid-October that Barack Obama and Mitt Romney felt compelled to address the problem of gun violence  and then only because an undecided voter asked them about it at the town-hall presidential debate. As Stephen Colbert joked afterward: Now is not the time to discuss gun control. We havent had a mass shooting in almost 49 days. A mere four days after Colberts quip, another mass shooting left three people dead and four injured at a Wisconsin day spa. Which, of course, did nothing to inject the issue of gun control into the presidential race.

title: Element of Surprise
description: Subtle is an inadequate word for Ruth Rendell. So are crafty, cunning, clever and sly. Although these are accurate descriptions of her confounding technique, a better word would be surprising. Whatever it is you might think Rendell is up to, especially when shes writing as Barbara Vine  thats not it.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: MY BRILLIANT FRIEND  Book One: Childhood, Adolescence.  By Elena Ferrante.  Europa Editions, paper, $17.

title: A Man and an Island
description: This gleaming novel tells the story of a Ceylonese Odysseus born poor in 1899. Through his protagonists long and eventful life, Randy Boyagoda explores themes of shifting identity, of the diamond-hard determination to evade ones destiny and of the inner landscapes of an island that itself undergoes a dramatic transformation. Boyagodas hero lives a long century, accruing wealth and sophistication, but his village is always there, as home always is, and the juxtaposition between the stinking piled-up old ways and the turning world beyond gives Beggars Feast much of its narrative tension.

title: Remains to Be Seen
description: Back in 2009, when the American auto industry was in free-fall, Mark Binelli joined the great migration of newspaper reporters and magazine writers  myself among them  heading to Detroit. We were all looking for a fresh angle on what was essentially the same story: What happens to the city that theyve been (barely) supporting when the Big Three, like the wobbly legs of a rickety old stool, finally give way?

title: Paperback Row
description: A MAN OF PARTS,  by David Lodge. (Penguin, $17.) Once called the man who invented tomorrow, H. G. Wells (1866-1946) wrote in a range of forms and genres: from science fiction to gritty working-class realism and Wikipedia-like history. (An autodidact of deep intellectual curiosity, he also immersed himself in socialist politics and free love.) Lodges smart novel reimagines Wellss life and his many tormented relationships with women, including Rebecca West.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE ENTERTAINER: Movies, Magic, and My Fathers Twentieth Century,  by Margaret Talbot. (Riverhead, $28.95.) Talbot shrewdly examines the career of her father, the actor Lyle Talbot, which illuminates the first 60 years of the last century.

title: Inside the List
description: CATS AND DOGGEREL: Serious poetry almost never shows up on the best-seller lists, but the unserious kind does make an occasional appearance. Witness for instance Calvin Trillins Dogfight, a collection of satirical verse about the 2012 presidential campaign, still bouncing around the extended hardcover nonfiction list after climbing as high as No. 12 last week. (Sample lines: Reveal himself? No, Mitt would not be forced; / The humanizing had to be outsourced.) Meanwhile, Francesco Marciuliano has spent six weeks on the hardcover advice, how-to and miscellaneous list with I Could Pee on This: And Other Poems by Cats, currently at No. 13 on the extended list. In a recent phone interview, Marciuliano told me he wrote the book while mourning his two cats, Boris and Natasha (named after the characters in Rocky and Bullwinkle,  he clarified, not War and Peace ), who had lived with him for some 17 years. When you spend any real time with cats, he said, you eventually try to figure out what on earth is going on in their brains. Dogs wear everything on their sleeves  or flanks?  but cats are very poised and reserved, very serious about the job of being a cat.

title: Book Review Podcast: Americas Unwritten Constitution
description: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Robert P. George reviews Americas Unwritten Constitution. Mr. George writes:

title: Musical Moments, Part IX: Strauss
description: A few readers also agreed about another overwhelming moment in music, the passage toward the end of Strausss opera Der Rosenkavalier when the Marschallin sings a resigned Ja, Ja as she walks out of the life of her much younger lover, Octavian, and out of the opera. Here is my take on it.

title: On Our Radar: Bigger Marine Sanctuaries
description: In a move that would permanently ban oil drilling along more than 50 miles of rugged coastline, the Obama administration plans to significantly expand two marine sanctuaries in Northern California. [The Santa Cruz Sentinel]

title: Leading Off: Were the Mayans Just Predicting the End of the N.H.L.?
description: We have finally made sense of the N.H.L. lockout. After a season of staring at this sorry spectacle and concluding that N.H.L. owners are the adult equivalent of children who light things on fire just because they like to watch them burn, there is a glimmer of reason in all of this.

title: Candy Cane Scrooge
description: Im considering getting the windows on my family S.U.V. tinted.

title: G.M. Recalling 119,000 Pickups for Missing Hood Latch
description: General Motors is recalling almost 119,000 of its 2010-12 Chevrolet Colorado and GMC Canyon pickups because the hoods may fly open, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Volunteers Helped to Tell an Asteroids Story
description: On April 22, a fast-moving fireball flew through the sky over Nevada and California and exploded. Some people witnessed the event, others snapped photos, and a security camera near Lake Tahoe caught it on video.

title: The More Guns Argument
description: Of the many specious arguments against gun control, perhaps the most ridiculous is that what we really need is the opposite: more guns, in the hands of more people, in more places. If people were packing heat in the movies, at workplaces, in shopping malls and in schools, they could just pop up and shoot the assailant.

title: Feeling For | Gargyles New Bags
description: Gargyle, the multibrand boutique that started online and turned brick-and-mortar with a New York City outpost in 2010, has just released a debut collection of womens handbags. We wanted to start with familiar shapes but then add frill and details and stuff that would be instantly recognizable as a Gargyle bag, says Nhung Nguyan, who founded the shop with her husband, Don Vu. Made of dark textured leather, the made-in-New York collection is a trio of beloved styles  the circle (called the Elwood, shown here), the bucket (Omaha) and the satchel (Smarty Jones)  finished with subtle but effective embellishments, like zigzag trimming and custom hardware. Theyre really sort of masculine looking, Nguyen says. Masculine but in feminine shapes.

title: A Magical Day at Disney
description: Having visited Walt Disney World more than two dozen times, Ive learned how to make my own magic. Heres my idea of a perfect day.

title: Inside Disneys New Fantasyland
description: YOU have a great gig, I said to the mermaid as I sat down beside her in the giant clamshell. You dont have to schlep around.

title: Manifest Fantasy
description: Take a spin around Disneys New Fantasyland, the largest expansion in the history of the Magic Kingdom.

title: Your Disney Questions
description: For the Dec. 23 issue of the Travel section, I wrote about the grand opening of New Fantasyland at Walt Disney World Resort in Florida. Yet it was hardly unfamiliar territory. Ive visited Walt Disney World more than two dozen times (and counting), which makes me something of an expert.

title: N.R.A. Envisions a Good Guy With a Gun in Every School
description: WASHINGTON  After a weeklong silence, the National Rifle Association announced Friday that it wants to arm security officers at every school in the country. It pointed the finger at violent video games, the news media and lax law enforcement  not guns  as culprits in the recent rash of mass shootings.

title: For Quick Success, Be Flexible
description: THE members of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater arent interchangeable, but some rise to the top faster than others. The elegant Jacqueline Green is everywhere this season, dancing lead roles in Kyle Abrahams Another Night and Jiri Kylians Petite Mort as well as  and even she can hardly believe this  carrying the umbrella in the Wade in the Water section of Aileys 1960 masterpiece Revelations.

title: New Spaces for the Revolution
description: JUDSON DANCE THEATER, a group of experimental artists who masterminded a series of performances from 1962 to 1964, altered the course of dance history. This wave of choreographers, inspired by composition workshops taught by Robert Ellis Dunn at Merce Cunninghams studio, approached Judson Memorial Church as a space to show the pieces developed in the class after being turned down by the 92nd Street Y.

title: Breakup Fees in NYSEs Deal With ICE Show Lessons From Past
description: After its attempted merger with Deutsche Brse collapsed, NYSE Euronexts board grew a little wary of jumping into another major deal that could fall apart on antitrust grounds.

title: Colorblind Casting Widens Operas Options
description: COLORBLIND casting has become commonplace in opera. In most instances to mention a singers race in a review would be not just irrelevant but in questionable taste. If a white Italian baritone portraying the title role of Verdis Rigoletto were to be greeted onstage by a black American soprano as Rigolettos daughter Gilda, that they are of different races would be a nonissue. What would matter is what always matters: the singing, the acting, the overall effectiveness of the performance and the production.

title: With Kerrys Exit Expected, Hopefuls Wait in the Wings
description: President Obamas decision to pluck John Kerry of Massachusetts from the Senate to be his new secretary of state sets the stage for a comeback by the departing Senator Scott P. Brown, a Republican, even before he leaves office early next month.

title: With Nomination, Kerry Has Chance to Reshape Rsum
description: Senator John Kerrys nomination to be secretary of state makes him something of a throwback. He is an unsuccessful nominee for president who appears set to ascend to a major new political position following his loss.

title: In Toledo, Layers of Spanish History
description: THE rain and morning fog had left the cobblestones of the old bridge too slippery to jog on. I had to get to the other side of the Tagus River to get a real view. I turned and looked.

title: Behind the Veil of the Forest in India
description: THE rutted road, part paved, part dirt, was a border between two worlds. To the left, a patchwork of villages, farms and fields covered the fertile plains between the Ganges and Yamuna Rivers. To the right rose the rugged, forested wilderness of the Shivalik Hills. Dehradun, the bustling capital of the northern state of Uttarakhand, was just 20 miles away, but felt much, much farther.

title: Restaurant Report: Ammo in Hong Kong
description: Not far from the ceaseless thrum of Hong Kongs busy Admiralty district, down a narrow footpath and through a thicket of lush greenery and wizened banyan trees, youll find a shimmering glass box. Peer in and youll see a well-heeled clientele perched in plush banquettes, hoisting glasses and passing around small plates.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Where the Slopes Are

title: The Right Time to Say Goodbye
description: IN this seasons opening episodes of Gossip Girl the gang was once again on the trail of a missing Serena. (Shes disappeared before.) She was keeping secret the fact that she had slept with a boyfriend of Blairs (not the first time); the two women werent on speaking terms (as usual). Dan was writing a tell-all (again). And Rufus was making waffles. (Its what he does.) If it seems as if the show had visited this territory before, it had.

title: Traveling Paths of Their Making
description: Melissa Aldana

title: Off the Charts: Germany Perks Up
description: German job and export growth are slowing and industrial production is declining. But business sentiment has turned up and stocks have been strong.

title: Struggling Red Hook Businesses Feed a Cookbook
description: In used bookstores and flea markets, I can never resist flipping through community cookbooks put together by churches, ladies clubs and such. Youve seen them  theyre typically typewritten, with hand-drawn paper covers, and theyre bound with a wire spiral or a curled plastic comb.

title: Simon de Pury Steps Down from Helm of Phillips de Pury
description: Just as the art world is disappearing for the holidays, Phillips de Pury & Company, the struggling boutique auction house, released an announcement that Simon de Pury  its chairman, principal auctioneer and the face of the company for the last 12 years  is stepping down. In a separate e-mail his wife, Michaela, who has been a senior director there, announced her departure too.

title: 40 Years Without a Word
description: While my inner grump tried to scoff at Mummenschanz, my inner kid seldom stopped grinning. Sure, this Swiss mime troupe, which goes by the same name as its production, has been producing similar shows for 40 years. But its longevity is well earned, and in an age of ceaseless special effects, its low-tech feel is unexpectedly energizing.

title: Dec. 23  29
description: ITS that time of the year again: jam-band convergence, when New York Citys rock halls fill with bands playing marathon sets, settling in on their way to New Years Eve.

title: A Hip-Hop Rant, With Epiphanies and Caricatures Included
description: Ingenious Nature, a theatrical mixtape now at SoHo Playhouse, is the white Canadian rapper Baba Brinkmans latest foray into educational hip-hop theater.

title: Two London Councils Battle Over Henry Moore Sculpture
description: Who really owns Old Flo?

title: Weekend Fare
description: Known for its over-the-top weekend brunches, Beaumarchais, 409 West 13th Street, in the meatpacking district, brings its penchant for parties with an End of the World soiree Friday night. The French restaurant will be in a festive mood with Mayan dcor, costumes, a special menu and music. For reservations, e-mail reservations@beaumarchais.com or call (212) 675-2400.

title: A Legislative Revolt
description: TimesCast: Speaker John A. Boehner faces dissension in the ranks over fiscal deal. | Syria uses cluster bombs against civilians. | Tearing down after Sandy. | A hockey anomaly.

title: Argo and the Workaday C.I.A. Officer
description: John Goodman may not have done much research for his part in Argo but his castmate and director, Ben Affleck, sure did, from meeting with the real-life C.I.A. operative he plays, Tony Mendez, to scouring old news footage.

title: Q&A: Setting AutoSave Times In Microsoft Office
description: Q.

title: France Suspects Islamists in a Kidnapping
description: PARIS  The men responsible for the kidnapping Wednesday of a French citizen in northern Nigeria are believed to be linked to Al Qaedas North African affiliate or other radical Islamist groups in northern Mali, French officials said Friday.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Django Unchained
description: Quentin Tarantino, the writer and director of Django Unchained, narrates a scene from his movie.

title: Beyond Wizards and Vampires, to Sex
description: Vampire and wizard fans are apparently ready for characters who shed their robes and show a little more skin.

title: A Crowd Service Gives Tips on Cloud Service
description: If you are looking for a cloud service, 50,000 friends would like to help you out.

title: House Speaker on Canceled Vote
description: House Speaker John A. Boehner failed to win support for his latest proposal to avert the fiscal cliff, and said he would still be willing to negotiate with President Obama.

title: Outside the Box: Eight No-Wrap Gift Ideas
description: Consume, consume, consume. That message is about as easy to ignore this time of year as the sight of a plump, red-suited man tromping over a crest of new-fallen snow.

title: Making an Argument for a Narrower Focus In Charitable Donations
description: THIS is a time of year when solicitations for donations are coming at you from every direction, and for good reason: the end of the year is when people make most of their gifts to charity.

title: Text of the N.R.A. Speech
description: The prepared remarks delivered by Wayne LaPierre, executive vice president of the National Rifle Association, on Friday.

title: Vain Glorious | Barber & Supply Comes to Williamsburg
description: After having colonized downtown Manhattan, the boys behind F.S.C. Barber have finally opened their first outpost in Williamsburg to cater to Brooklyns hirsute hipster class. Barber & Supply, the new salon that opens tomorrow, features old-school Belmont barber chairs (with custom built-in ash trays), oak and nickel cabinetry, and a pop-up apothecary, which will rotate every three months, showcasing different purveyors. (Malin+Goetz is first up.) Since the Brooklyn shop allowed for more space, the founder Sam Buffa decided to build a large, Grand Central Terminal-style communal bench so clients can hang around in a more gentlemanly fashion. Now if they only they did shoeshines.

title: Walking Dead Gains a New Season But Its Show Runner Becomes Latest Casualty
description: The Walking Dead, AMCs hit drama series about the survivors of a zombie apocalypse, will continue for another season, but not all the members of its creative team will continue on to fight the undead hordes: the cable channel said on Friday that its show runner, Glen Mazzara, was leaving the series.

title: The Ultimate Amenity: Grandparents
description: THE unlikely new custodians of the nuclear family are young, urban and inextricably caught up in their careers: Do not expect them to flee the city for the suburban lawns and balms of their wonder years. They dont want to go home again, not even if or when their lives start to be accessorized by cradles, strollers, pacifiers, pediatrician appointments and nannies. They prefer to customize the complexities of the city to fit their needs, not escape the city for simpler climes.

title: Russia Moves a Step Closer to Banning Adoptions by U.S. Citizens
description: MOSCOW  The lower house of Parliament gave its final approval on Friday to a proposed ban on the adoption of Russian children by American citizens, drawing a sharp response from the United States, which urged officials not to play politics with the lives of orphans.

title: The Sweet Spot | Pondering Lincoln
description: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about Steven Spielbergs latest offering, and whether moviegoers prefer rollicking tales or history lessons.

title: Each Wed in 1980, Three Sisters and Their Spouses Look Back
description: BACK in 1980, three sisters  Susan, Carol and Beth Driscoll  were married in three separate ceremonies. Thirty-two years later, they are all still married. Susan, the eldest of the three, married John Devlin on June 14; now both 59, they live in Oxford, Md., where she is executive director of a nonprofit and he is a management consultant. Carol, 57, married James Kagdis, 55, on Aug. 2; they live in Fairfield, Conn., where she is a medical director and he a business acquisitions manager for an aircraft company. Last in line was Beth, who married Samuel Kinney on Oct. 4. Beth, 55, is a director of community services; Samuel, 57, is an insurance broker and they live Summit, N.J.

title: After His Home Was Flooded and His Music Lost, the Maestro Returns
description: Irwin Meyer was never afraid of the sea. He joined the Navy and was on a combat-crippled destroyer off Omaha Beach on D-Day for the invasion of Normandy, and on three subsequent invasions in Europe.

title: On Television, Holiday Specials Draw Plenty of Eyeballs
description: In keeping with a long-standing holiday tradition, the television networks filled the airwaves with Christmas-themed specials and movies this year. While some classics, like Its a Wonderful Life and A Christmas Story will not be broadcast until Monday, viewers have had plenty of holiday programming to choose from throughout the month.

title: Weighing the Consequences of a Money Fund Overhaul
description: Anyone know what to do with $2.6 trillion?

title: Even in Disarray, G.O.P. Has Power to Constrain Obama
description: WASHINGTON  Its been 45 days since voters reaffirmed their faith in President Obama and heartily endorsed his policy agenda for the next four years.

title: No Lip-Syncing for the Wretched of Paris
description: London

title: N.R.A. Calls for Armed Guards in Schools
description: Wayne LaPierre of the National Rifle Association announces the creation of the National School Shield Program and calls on government to put armed security officers in every school in the nation.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Django Unchained
description: In the middle of Django Unchained, Quentin Tarantinos energetic mashup of spaghetti westerns and blacksploitation movies, comes a quiet and important scene. Its a moment involving Djangos wife, the slave Broomhilda, played by Kerry Washington. The scene finds Django (Jamie Foxx) and his partner, Dr. King Schultz (Christoph Waltz), on a mission to rescue Broomhilda from a plantation. In the video above, Mr. Tarantino narrates a closer look at the scene, discussing his choice of Ennio Morricone music, the delicate lighting and the subtle ways the actors play the moment.

title: Re-emerging BMG Buys Rights to 80s Hits From Culture Club and the Like
description: 2:51 p.m. | Updated BMG Rights Management, which in just four years has become a major music-publishing company, has expanded once again with a $90 million deal for some 30,000 songs, including a slew of 1980s hits by Culture Club, Tears for Fears and the Human League.

title: Kremlin Statements Move Farther Away From Syrias Leader
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin said Friday that Russias main goal in the Syrian conflict was to avoid chaos, the latest in a series of remarks that have served to distance Moscow from the government of President Bashar al-Assad and shift the focus to a controlled political transition.

title: A Trove of Tablets for Young Hands
description: The Times's Children's tech critic reviews 21 tablets for children.

title: Hagel Apologizes About Remarks Against Gay Diplomat
description: Chuck Hagel, a candidate for secretary of defense whose record on gay-rights issues has come under fire in recent days, apologized on Friday for remarks he made as a senator that an openly gay man nominated for a diplomatic post should not represent the United States.

title: Mexico Frees American in Case That Drew Criticism
description: MEXICO CITY  An American Marine veteran who spent the past four months in a Mexican prison for crossing the border with a shotgun was released on Friday, according to his family and lawmakers who came to his aid, ending an ordeal that had raised tensions between the two governments.

title: Fiscal Cliff Looms
description: The Timess Binyamin Appelbaum and Peter Lattman talk about the G.O.P. revolt following Speaker John A. Boehners effort at a compromise during fiscal cliff negotiations with President Obama.

title: In Filing, News Corp. Says Publishing Business Showed $2.1 Billion Loss
description: Potential investors got a glimpse of the financial challenges that Rupert Murdochs soon-to-be spun-off publishing company could face. In a regulatory filing, News Corporation said its publishing businesses lost $2.1 billion in the fiscal year that ended June 30.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Pogo Possum and Friends
description: Volume two of Pogo, by Walt Kelly, which continues the deluxe reprinting of the newspaper strip starring Pogo Possum and set in the Okefenokee Swamp, is at No. 4 on the graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week. This volume introduces some cool characters: Tammanany the Tiger, Uncle Antler the bull moose, and three bats named Bewitched, Bothered and Bemildred. Carolyn Kelly, the cartoonists daughter, designed and edited the book, as well as restoring some of the strips. This volume also features annotations and commentary by the comic historians R.C. Harvey and Mark Evanier.

title: Voting From the Heart (Once the Online Snags Were Solved)
description: 11:42 a.m. | Updated  Oscar voting has been live online for a week, and almost from the first, there were problems.

title: The Sweet Spot: Dec. 21
description: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about Steven Spielbergs latest offering, and whether moviegoers prefer rollicking tales or history lessons.

title: Liberating Pleats
description: SMALL costume exhibits are finding a home at the Queen Sofa Spanish Institute. The cultural center, on Park Avenue near 68th Street, was host to an impressive Balenciaga exhibition in 2010 and now one devoted to the Venetian textile maven Mariano Fortuny. The exhibition spaces are not generous, and they are on separate floors, but on a weekday morning a visitor might find the place to herself, and thats pretty rare. Also, for Fortuny: An Artistic Legacy, the set designer Stefan Beckman (he does Marc Jacobss shows, among other presentations) has created a spare but powerful design that helps illuminate the multiple talents and paradoxical nature of Mariano Fortuny y Madrazo.

title: 12 Days of Gadgets: Necomimi Brain-Powered Cat Ears
description: On the 12th day of Christmas, my true love gave to methe last gift idea for gadget lovers who dont really merit spending over $100 on.

title: Explosion of Brands and Erosion of Soul
description: Now that the college football bowl season has kicked off  four games down, a mere 31 to go  we should all pause, put down our Bud Lights and reflect on what this annual ritual reveals about our nations soul.

title: The Flip Is Dead. Long Live the Touchdown Celebration.
description: To flip or not to flip, that was one of the biggest questions leading up to the Giants game against Atlanta on Sunday.

title: E.P.A. Issues Standards on Air Pollution for Boilers
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency on Friday issued long-delayed new air pollution standards for industrial boilers, incinerators and cement kilns. The rules provide significant concessions to industry and allow several additional years for full compliance in an effort to minimize job and economic impacts, officials said.

title: Engineered Fish Moves a Step Closer to Approval
description: Government regulators moved a big step closer on Friday to allowing the first genetically engineered animal  a fast-growing salmon  to enter the nations food supply.

title: Knicks Lose Their Taste for Turnovers
description: Though the grind of the N.B.A. season makes them rare, Knicks practices this year have begun with an amusing refrain: the coaching staff, including Mike Woodson, runs baseline-to-baseline laps, one for each turnover under 13 the Knicks committed in the last game.

title: In Varied Housing Size, Diversity Insurance
description: IN 1974, Nora and Al Galland, their two young sons in tow, packed up their belongings and traded in a cramped one-bedroom apartment in Brooklyn Heights for a five-bedroom colonial in Hastings-on-Hudson, in southern Westchester.

title: Living In | Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.
description: A village in southern Westchester has a diverse housing stock that includes Tudors, colonials, contemporaries and apartments, in many price ranges.

title: Image of the Day: Dec. 21
Revisiting Apple, NBC and Gay Marriage
description: After Apple introduced its iPhone 5 in China last week, Apples chief executive, Tim Cook, hailed the rollout as the companys most successful ever, with two million handsets sold the first weekend. Its the kind of news that in the past has sent Apple stock soaring.

title: For the Holidays, a Nostalgia Trip on a Bus Like Ralph Kramdens
