description: As word spread last week that a house of the Russian Parliament had voted to prohibit adoptions of Russian children by American parents, Russian adoptees in the United States made appeals to President Vladimir V. Putin, asking Russia not to hold needy children hostage to international politics.

title: Giving Moms Book Five Stars? Amazon May Cull Your Review
description: Giving raves to family members is no longer acceptable. Neither is writers reviewing other writers. But showering five stars on a book you admittedly have not read is fine.

title: Bywords
description: I weep for ADONAIS  he is dead!Oh, weep for ADONAIS! though our tearsThaw not the frost which binds so dear a head!  Percy Bysshe Shelley

title: Sharing the Bounty of California
description: The Farm to Family program, run by the California Association of Food Banks, taps surplus produce from growers and packers and channels it to food pantries.

title: Taliban Hint at Softer Line in Talks With Afghan Leaders
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  After years of deriding Afghanistans government and army as corrupt tools of Western occupiers, the Taliban have begun publicly airing a softer vision for the countrys future, with senior insurgent leaders saying the militants are willing to govern alongside other Afghan factions and even to adopt the current American-financed army as their own.

title: Affluent Students Have an Advantage and the Gap Is Widening
description: Low-income students with above-average scores on eighth grade tests have a college graduation rate of 26 percent  lower than more affluent students with worse test scores.

title: For Poor, Leap to College Often Ends in a Hard Fall
description: GALVESTON, Tex.  Angelica Gonzales marched through high school in Goth armor  black boots, chains and cargo pants  but undermined her pose of alienation with a place on the honor roll. She nicknamed herself after a metal band and vowed to become the first in her family to earn a college degree.

title: A Bleak Procession of Funerals for Shooting Victims Ends in Newtown
description: NEWTOWN, Conn.  This community laid to rest on Saturday the last of the children killed in a schoolhouse massacre.

title: Express Train Derails on Upper West Side
description: The last car of a southbound train on the A express line jumped the tracks while passing through the Upper West Side of Manhattan on Saturday morning, transit officials said. No one was hurt, but hundreds of passengers were temporarily stranded.

title: Thieves Target Volunteers Aiding Staten Island
description: Days after powerful waves created by Hurricane Sandy washed over parts of Staten Island and left devastation behind, a group of people from other states arrived in New York City saying they wanted to help.

title: How Party of Budget Restraint Shifted to No New Taxes, Ever
description: WASHINGTON  On a Saturday afternoon in October 1990, Senator Pete V. Domenici turned from a conversation on the Senate floor, caught the eye of a clerk by raising his right hand and voted in favor of a huge and contentious bill to reduce federal deficits. Then he put his hand back into his pocket and returned to the conversation.

title: Big Rich Texas Becomes an Unlikely Reality-TV Hit
description: In a cosmetic surgeons office in the Uptown neighborhood of Dallas, a mother sat in on a consultation with her 16-year-old daughter. Her explanation for their visit?

title: Latina Liberals Vie for Senate Seat Left by Gallegoss Death
description: The recent death of a veteran state legislator from Houston has set the stage for an unexpected election that includes two members of a growing demographic in Texas, the progressive Latina woman.

title: Turning to Outsiders to Finance Water Deals
description: Developers say the site for the proposed Lake Columbia reservoir in East Texas is not much to look at right now.

title: The Diploma Divide
description: Angelica Gonzales graduated at the top of her high school class and headed off to one of the nations top universities. Four years later she is back home, without a degree.

title: School Lawsuits Serve a Purpose, as Easy Outs
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: At a Sacred Site, a Fight Over Women and Prayer
description: JERUSALEM  The face-off at the security gate outside the Western Wall one Friday this month was familiar: for more than two decades, women have been making a monthly pilgrimage to pray at one of Judaisms holiest sites in a manner traditionally preserved for men, and the police have stopped them in the name of maintaining public order.

title: Lee Dorman, Bass Guitarist, Dies at 70
description: Lee Dorman, a bass guitarist for the psychedelic rock band Iron Butterfly, who played on one of the genres most recognizable songs, In-a-Gadda-da-Vida, died on Friday in Laguna Niguel, Calif. He was 70.

title: Midge Turk Richardson, Ex-Nun and Editor, Dies at 82
description: Midge Turk Richardson, who spent 18 years as a nun before spending 18 years as the editor of Seventeen magazine, a redoubt of worldly concerns like clothes, makeup and dating, died last weekend at her home in Manhattan. She was 82.

title: Jimmy McCracklin, R&B Singer and Songwriter, Dies at 91
description: Jimmy McCracklin, a blues singer and pianist who by his count composed nearly a thousand songs and recorded hundreds, including the 1950s hit The Walk, died on Thursday in San Pablo, Calif. He was 91.

title: When Games Can Take Years to Complete
description: Ron Langeveld of the Netherlands did not receive a lot of attention when he won the World Correspondence Chess Championship in October. Computers have removed much of the titles luster.

title: Women at the Western Wall
description: Jodi Rudoren, The Timess Jerusalem bureau chief, reports on Jewish women fighting Orthodox restrictions on how and where they can pray at the Western Wall in Jerusalem.

title: Corrections: December 23, 2012
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, Dec. 23
description: Its becoming increasingly unlikely that a low-income student, no matter how intrinsically bright, moves up the socioeconomic ladder. What were talking about is a threat to the American dream.

title: Amanda Steren, Marc Garfinkle
description: Amanda Jean Steren and Marc Evan Garfinkle were married Saturday evening at Old Oaks Country Club in Purchase, N.Y. Rabbi Seth M. Limmer officiated.

title: Kathleen OConnell, Stephen Marsh
description: Kathleen Cook OConnell and Stephen Ingram Marsh were married Saturday at a private home in Malibu, Calif., that was rented for the occasion. Jennifer Robinson, a friend of the couple who was temporarily appointed a deputy commissioner of civil marriages by Los Angeles County, officiated.

title: James Mulkin Jr. and Michael Robertson II
description: James Edward Mulkin Jr. and Michael Eugene Robertson II were married Wednesday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell, an assistant administrator in the City Clerks office, officiated.

title: Marcela Schaefer, Jeffrey Weber
description: Marcela Elizabeth Schaefer and Jeffrey Robert Weber were married Tuesday. James Mitchell, an assistant administrator in the City Clerks office, officiated at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau.

title: Alona Simon, Gabriel Erbst
description: Alona Judith Simon, the daughter of Nadine S. Simon and Zvi A. Simon of Westbury, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Gabriel Alexander Erbst, a son of Jeannette R. Erbst and Les Erbst of Long Branch, N.J. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert officiated at the Liberty Warehouse in Brooklyn.

title: Joyce De Leon and Joshua Stein
description: Joyce De Leon and Joshua Michelangelo Stein were married Saturday. The Rev. Angel Castro performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels in Los Angeles.

title: Claire Friedman and Maximillian Feldman
description: Claire Gillian Friedman and Maximillian Louis Feldman were married Saturday night at the Metropolitan Club in New York. Rabbi Jill Hausman officiated.

title: Mercedeh Namei, John Back Jr.
description: Mercedeh Namei and John Edward Back Jr. were married Saturday at Memorial Hall, an event space in Cincinnati. The Rev. Al Hirt, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Nicole Parent and Philip Haughey Jr.
description: Nicole Marie Parent and Philip Carberry Haughey Jr. were married Saturday in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. David J. Cavanagh performed the ceremony at St. Paul Roman Catholic Church, with the Rev. Michael E. Drea, another Roman Catholic priest and the pastor of the church, taking part.

title: Jordan Kraemer and Channing Moore
description: Jordan Harriet Kraemer and Richard Channing Moore III were married Monday at City Hall in San Francisco. Robin Wirthlin, a deputy marriage commissioner of San Francisco County, officiated.

title: Windsong Hollis and Ronald Gottlieb
description: Dr. Windsong Emily Hollis was married Saturday to Ronald Joseph Gottlieb in Washington. Judge Delissa A. Ridgway of the United States Court of International Trade in Manhattan officiated at the Cosmos Club. The Rev. John P. Goodloe Sr., a Pentecostal minister, offered a blessing.

title: Police Crackdown in Delhi Sunday After Protests Over Rape
description: A week of growing anger about a recent rape in Delhi ended in violence Saturday after police and protestors clashed near the India Gate monument.

title: Adding More Bricks to the Great Firewall of China
description: HONG KONG  China appears to have reinforced its Internet firewall in recent days, blocking some of the leading services that allow people on the mainland to access forbidden sites like Twitter, Facebook and YouTube.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: Gujarats divisive chief minister Narendra Modi surprised no one when he won a resounding victory in the recent state elections, inching closer, some say, to fulfilling his ambitions of becoming a national leader, perhaps even prime minister. But what remains surprising and even inscrutable to some is the fervent support the right-wing politician enjoys on his home turf and elsewhere.

title: Home for the Holidays, or Not: An Expat Christmas in New York
description: NEW YORK  I am American and I live abroad right here in New York. I know it doesnt seem to make sense but it is true. Well thats because I am French-American to be precise. Ive lived and worked in New York for almost twenty years and I call it home  except at Christmas time.

title: Egypt Opposition Gears Up After Constitution Passes
description: CAIRO  Egyptians approved an Islamist-backed constitution, state news media said Sunday, and the headlines made clear that the political brawl about it has only begun.

title: A 50-50 Game and Season for the Giants
description: A few links to consider before the Week 16 games begin:According to NFL-Forecast.com, the Giants have a 51 percent chance of making the playoffs.

title: North Korean Missile Said to Have Military Purpose
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korean technicians scrutinizing the debris of the North Korean rocket launched this month have found evidence suggesting the rockets military purposes and the Norths technological ties with Iran in its efforts to develop an intercontinental ballistic missile, South Korean officials said Sunday.

title: Protests Over Rape Turn Violent in Delhi
description: NEW DELHI Protests over a recent gang rape quickly gained force over the weekend, tapping into longstanding fury against entrenched corruption and lopsided justice, and leading to clashes with the police.

title: India Reacts to Tendulkars Retirement from One-Day Cricket
description: The Indian batsman Sachin Tendulkar said Sunday that he was retiring from One Day International cricket.

title: From Corn Dogs to Bche de Nol, and Onward
description: My parents lived in France for a year in the early 1970s on my fathers Fulbright scholarship, and they returned to the United States with opinions on fromage. They changed the way they ate and cooked and thought about food, and my mother started making bche de Nol.  translated into English, that means Christmas log cake. (Proving that everything sounds better in French.)

title: Sunday Morning Music: Winter Wonderland
description: Over at Washington Monthly, Kathleen Geier has been featuring Christmas music that isnt terrible  and this morning mentions the Roches album, which Id forgotten about. Heres my favorite, Winter Wonderland done as it should be, in a full Brooklyn (prounounced Bvwooklyun) accent:

title: Syrian Airstrike Is Said to Kill Dozens in a Bread Line
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Bombs that antigovernment activists said were dropped by a Syrian warplane on Sunday killed dozens of people at a bakery in the west-central town of Halfaya where residents had lined up for bread after the town received its first flour delivery in days.

title: Ibanez Is Going to Mariners, and Swisher to the Indians
description: General Manager Brian Cashman recently lauded the Yankees uncanny ability to pull off important and unheralded moves late in the off-season, weeks after other notable free agents had signed.

title: Buying Back Greek Debt Rewarded Hedge Funds
description: LONDON  Last month, the European Commissions top economic official in Brussels, Olli Rehn, received an intriguing e-mail.

title: Scientists Report Faster Warming in Antarctica
description: West Antarctica has warmed much more than scientists had thought over the last half century, new research suggests, an ominous finding given that the huge ice sheet there may be vulnerable to long-term collapse, with potentially drastic effects on sea levels.

title: N.R.A. Leaders Stand Firm Against Gun Restrictions
description: Leaders of the National Rifle Association said Sunday that they would fight any new gun restrictions introduced in Congress, and they made clear that they were not interested in working with President Obama to help develop a broad response to the Connecticut school massacre.

title: The Hobbit Stays No. 1 at the Box Office
description: The weekend before Christmas is typically a weird one for Hollywood. It is one of the only periods all year when a movies performance over its first three days does not necessarily signal how good (or bad) total ticket sales will be; ticket buyers may still materialize in significant numbers over the holiday week.

title: Stoudemire Not Quite Ready to Return
description: Coach Mike Woodson said Amare Stoudemire would not play his first game of the season Sunday when the Knicks host the Minnesota Timberwolves.

title: Cargo Continues Moving on the Mississippi River, but Perhaps Not for Long
description: The Mississippi River is still open for business  for now. January is another story.

title: Italian Premier Wont Run in New Elections but Keeps Options Open
description: ROME  After weeks of speculation, Italys caretaker prime minister, Mario Monti, said Sunday that he would not run as a candidate in national elections that are expected in February, but was open to leading the government if parties that endorsed his pro-Europe, pro-reform agenda asked.

title: Why Is This Museum Shaped Like a Tub?
description: AMSTERDAM  Offhand I cant recall seeing a more ridiculous looking building than the new Stedelijk Museum, which recently opened here. Shaped like a bathtub, of all things, it arrives years behind schedule at the tail end of the money-fueled, headline-hungry, erratically ingenious era of indulgent museum design that began to peter out with the global economy. Compared with no-frills, cost-effective, almost penitential, post-meltdown designs like Herzog & de Meurons stylish Parrish Art Museum in the Hamptons, its a throwback.

title: For the Holidays, Hong Kong Decks Its Skyscrapers in Lights
description: HONG KONG  For the past few weeks, Santa Claus, looking cheerful and surrounded by twinkling stars and ornaments, has been dancing on the sides of skyscrapers.

title: Let the 2012 Presidential Campaign Books Begin
description: Here come the quickie journalistic accounts of the 2012 campaign.

title: Make Music Winter
description: Images from the festival in New York.

title: Jets Try Something New but End Up With a Similar Result
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  With nothing at stake in the Jets game Sunday against the San Diego Chargers, it had an experimental feeling at the start. Out of the playoffs, the Jets loosened the restraints on their playbook a bit.

title: Surmounting Struggles in Life and Onstage
description: NEWARK  Fred Hammond walked onstage after a technical delay: a big man in jeans, a dark blazer and rectangular glasses moving uncharismatically, stiffly, maybe wearily.

title: No Sales Pop for a New Version of Windows
description: BELLEVUE, Wash.  It used to be that a new version of the Windows operating system was enough to get people excited about buying a new computer, giving sales a nice pop.

title: SportAccord World Mind Games in Beijing
description: At the second SportAccord World Mind Games in Beijing this month the United States open team (Curtis Cheek, Joe Grue, John Hurd, Joel Wooldridge, Ralph Katz and Howard Weinstein) played against Sweden (Peter Bertheau, Per-Ola Cullin, Fredrik Nystrom, Johan Upmark, Johan Sylvan and Frederic Wrang) in the battle for third place. The first four Swedes, along with Krister Ahlesved and Jonas Petersson, won the World Mind Sports Games open team title in Lille, France, last August.

title: The Freedom of Faith: A Christmas Sermon
description: In an essay in The Times Sunday Book Review this week the writer Paul Elie asks the intriguing question: Has fiction lost its faith? As we are gathered here today, let us consider one of the most oddly faithful of all fiction writers, Fyodor Dostoevsky. More specifically, Id like focus pretty intensely on what some consider to be the key moment in his greatest novel  arguably one of the greatest of all time  The Brothers Karamazov. (Elie himself notes the 1880 masterpiece as an example of the truly faith-engaged fiction of yore.) I speak in particular of the Grand Inquisitor scene, a sort of fiction within a fiction that draws on something powerful from the New Testament  Jesuss refusal of Satans three temptations  and in doing so digs at the meaning of faith, freedom, happiness and the diabolic satisfaction of our desires.

title: Topics to Make Brazil Squirm
description: Francisco Buarque de Hollanda, known professionally as Chico Buarque, has had a curiously bifurcated artistic career. In his homeland, Brazil, he is considered the greatest songwriter of the past 50 years, a kind of Cole Porter crossed with Bob Dylan whose elegant compositions, written alone or with partners like Antnio Carlos Jobim, Vinicius de Moraes and Caetano Veloso, have become standards in the Great Brazilian Songbook.

title: Four Seasons Gets New Spin
description: Reconstructing staples of the classical repertory through a contemporary prism has long tempted artists of wide-ranging aesthetics. The music of Bach has proved particularly irresistible, luring jazz performers like Uri Caine, Jacques Loussier and Dave Brubeck. The rapper Ludacris poached the Dies irae of Mozarts Requiem for his song Coming 2 America.

title: Two Cast Changes For Metropolitan Opera
description: The Metropolitan Opera announced on Saturday two casting changes for coming performances. The first will be on Wednesday, when the tenor Bryan Hymel is scheduled to make his Met debut in Berliozs Troyens. Mr. Hymel will step in for the tenor Marcello Giordani as Aeneas for the final four performances of Les Troyens, including the Live in HD global transmission on Jan. 5. The second change is for the production of Rossinis Comte Ory, which will now feature the debut of Pretty Yende, the South African soprano who won first prize in Plcido Domingos Operalia competition in 2011. She will play Countess Adle. Le Comte Ory is scheduled to open on Jan. 17.

title: How I Met Your Mother Nears an Extension
description: Television viewers who have been waiting seven-and-a-half years to learn the identity of the titular mother in the CBS comedy How I Met Your Mother may have to wait a little longer. CBS is close to finishing new contracts with the shows creators and cast to extend the series and bring it back for a ninth season, according to Entertainment Weeklys Web site. Jason Segel, who has built an impressive film rsum while also starring in How I Met Your Mother, was reported to be reluctant to return but is said to have signed on. The show has been a solid ratings performer in recent years, reaching a series high in total viewers last season, with an average of 9.7 million. It has been averaging 8.2 million viewers during its eighth season.

title: A Kesha Reversal On Die Young Lyrics
description: The Newtown, Conn., school shootings have had reverberations in the radio world, as lyrics that seemed within the bounds of good taste two weeks ago are suddenly hitting a flat note. A case in point is Keshas recent hit Die Young, a lightweight party tune about living for the moment. Though the theme of the song is carpe diem, it contains the chorus: Lets make the most of the night like were gonna die young/Were gonna die young/Were gonna die young. Program directors at pop stations in Connecticut and around the country took the song out of their rotations in the days after the Dec. 14 shootings. Another song receiving very few spins these days is Pumped Up Kicks, last years Foster the People hit, which tells the story of a student shooting his classmates. The airplay for Keshas song dropped 19 percent on the Billboard Radio Songs chart this week, and the song has dipped to No. 4 from No. 3 on the Hot 100 single chart. Several program directors said the drop-off in airplay would be temporary, Billboard reported. In a string of Twitter posts last week, Kesha, below, apologized and asserted that she had objected to the lyrics but was forced to sing them. I did NOT want to sing those lyrics and I was FORCED TO, she wrote, in a post that was later taken down. She later posted a message on her Web site trying to clarify: After such a tragic event I was feeling a lot of emotion and sadness when I said I was forced to sing some of the lyrics to Die Young. Forced is not the right word. I did have some concerns about the phrase die young in the chorus when we were writing the lyrics especially because so many of my fans are young and thats one reason why I wrote so many versions of this song. But the point of the song is the importance of living every day to the fullest and staying young at heart, and these are things I truly believe. Kesha is one of several songwriters on Die Young. The list includes Lukasz Gottwald (known as Dr. Luke), Benny Blanco, Cirkut and the group Fun.s frontman, Nate Ruess.

title: Just a Little Off the Top for Rossinis Old Barber
description: It was illuminating, at intermission during the Metropolitan Operas opening-night presentation of Rossinis Barber of Seville on Tuesday, to scroll through comments about the performance posted on Twitter. The staging, by Bartlett Sher, was the busy, buzzy, slightly daffy one that has mostly earned approval since its 2006 debut. The cast was filled with promising up-and-comers and reliable company players.

title: The Illustrious and Twisted Paths to Secretary of State
description: WASHINGTON  My latest Letter From Washington details why Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts is an excellent choice to be secretary of state.

title: On a Solstice, Music Can Pop Up Anywhere
description: New York became an outdoor concert hall on Friday, when Make Music Winter organized events in public spaces in the city for the winter solstice. The next event? The next solstice: June 21, 2013.

title: Present-Tense Movement, With Memory
description: PHILADELPHIA  The dances choreographed by Merce Cunningham abound in solos. Because these solos deal purely with steps and movements, with no evident characterization or narrative gesture, its easy to miss the ways in which they operate as drama. Alone, a Cunningham dancer investigates movement, space and time with a quality of contemplation that often turns dance into a stream-of-consciousness soliloquy. A dancer may return to a step like a default position or a habit of thought; may suddenly  and frequently  change direction and tempo as if changing the subject; may change position in midair as if meeting a challenge. The focus of the eyes plays a crucial role.

title: Coveting a Childrens Garden of Zs
description: Few preschoolers who watch the Sprout channels brilliant Snooze-a-Thon on Christmas Eve are likely to appreciate its startling genius as a piece of filmmaking. This is neo-neo-neorealism at its finest, boldly pushing the envelope to places where even radical iconoclasts rarely go.

title: The OReilly Factory
description: Abe would have liked this book, the Fox News television host Bill OReilly said confidently of his blockbuster best-seller Killing Lincoln: The Shocking Assassination That Changed America Forever. Even the ending?

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday. Bond markets will close early on Monday at 2 p.m. and will be closed on Tuesday in observance of Christmas Day.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: Data to be released this week includes the Standard & Poors/Case-Shiller housing price index (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, new home sales for November and consumer confidence for December (Thursday); and the Chicago purchasing managers index for December and pending home sales for November (Friday).

title: The Trouble With Truffles
description: PARIS  Dec. 24, as I recently wrote, is typically the biggest truffle-eating night of the year in France. But Prigord black truffles, the Rolls Royce of truffles, seem to be suffering from a climatic trend toward hotter and drier summers in their native habitats of southwestern France and Spain.

title: Upper West Side Store Is Hurt by Staten Island Flooding
description: 1:48 p.m. Monday | Updated On first hearing, it simply did not make sense. How could Stationery and Toy, a cherished, packed daughter-and-pop store at 125 West 72nd Street, have lost almost all of its inventory during Hurricane Sandy? After all, the Upper West Side was barely discommoded by the storm. Most residents suffered from nothing much more serious than survivors guilt.

title: Big Laughs
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Im convinced of it now. I wasnt before, but now I am. Michael Sharp is hitting for the cycle. And hes almost there.

title: Behind in Math and Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Little Sign of a Predicted E-Book Price War
description: Right about now, just as millions of e-readers and tablets are being slipped under Christmas trees, there was supposed to be a ferocious price war over e-books.

title: In a Land of Austerity, Christmas Is Reinvented as a Season of Thrift
description: MADRID  This is the season when barren stone plazas and broad sidewalks here fill with Christmas markets peddling sweets, candles, holiday decorations and crafts. But alongside the festive stalls this year, another kind of market has sprung up in response to Spains hard times.

title: Albert Hirschman, Optimistic Economist, Dies at 97
description: Albert O. Hirschman, who in his youth helped rescue thousands of artists and intellectuals from Nazi-occupied France and went on to become an influential economist known for his optimism, died on Dec. 10 in Ewing Township, N.J. He was 97.

title: Philippine Law Forbids Abductions by Military
description: MANILA  The Philippines has enacted a law aimed at stopping the military and police officers from abducting people suspected of antigovernment activity, one of the ugly legacies of years of dictatorship.

title: New Lineup Without Humphries Has a Surging Start
description: The Nets joined the N.B.A.s small-ball revolution and rode a new starting lineup to a 95-92 win over the 76ers on Sunday, narrowly escaping a late run by Philadelphia. With the recently stagnant team suddenly showing some life, Kris Humphries may have a new role for himself on the bench.

title: Hollywood Rebounds at the Box Office
description: LOS ANGELES  Some blockbuster new characters  Katniss Everdeen, Ted the foul-mouthed bear  joined some familiar ones (Batman, Bond, Baggins) to deliver a lift to moviegoing in North America in 2012, increasing attendance by 5.6 percent after two years of declines.

title: A TV Voice Rang True in Clamor of Shooting
description: On the day of the school shooting in Newtown, Conn., reporters were struggling and failing to get their arms around a story too horrible to fathom. At our house, we stared at the incremental television coverage and came to realize that no one really knew anything.

title: China Takes Chilling Look at Security in Its Schools
description: BEIJING  The attackers first young target, a girl with a pink backpack, falls at the school gates as she tries to race away. She gets up, but stumbles again inside the gates as the man slashes at her with a meat cleaver. Two minutes later, dozens of students race out of the gates as the man rampages through the school, eventually wounding 23 children.

title: Ceremony in Honolulu Remembers Senator
description: HONOLULU  They chartered a plane from Washington to bid a final farewell to their old friend.

title: The Hell of Online Shopping
description: A FEW days ago, I got an e-mail from my sister Amy in Los Angeles saying she and her husband had received boxes from J. Crew. Christmas presents from me, she assumed, since I had ordered them online and told her to expect them.

title: Official Killed in Bombing Is Mourned in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A senior politician killed in a suicide attack claimed by the Pakistani Taliban was buried Sunday in the northwestern city of Peshawar amid renewed calls for unity in the fight against terrorism and militancy.

title: Stabilization Wont Save Us
description: THE fiscal cliff is not really a cliff; the entire country wont fall into the ocean if we hit it. Some automatic tax cuts will expire; the government will be forced to cut some expenditures. The cliff is really just a red herring.

title: The Moral Animal
description: London

title: When Medias Decision in the Face of Events Is to Say Nothing About Them
description: With less than two weeks to go until the presidential election, Lloyd Grove had had enough.

title: When Prophecy Fails
description: Back in the 1950s three social psychologists joined a cult that was predicting the imminent end of the world. Their purpose was to observe the cultists response when the world did not, in fact, end on schedule. What they discovered, and described in their classic book, When Prophecy Fails, is that the irrefutable failure of a prophecy does not cause true believers  people who have committed themselves to a belief both emotionally and by their life choices  to reconsider. On the contrary, they become even more fervent, and proselytize even harder.

title: Another Rout, and Giants Playoff Hopes Are Teetering
description: BALTIMORE  The emotional spectrum was wide in the Giants locker room late Sunday as a humbled group of men snatched at oversize suits and half-knotted ties before stalking toward the door. Many seemed to be moving quicker than they had all day, and their haste made it appear as if they were, understandably, trying to run from their humiliation as fast as possible.

title: All the Worlds a Game, and Business Is a Player
description: Congratulations. Reading the first paragraph of this article has earned you a badge.

title: Why Aren't People Happier During the Holidays?
The Adventures of Lightning Ellsworth
description: In December 1862, Gen. Braxton Bragg, commander of the Confederate Army of Tennessee, was encamped around Murfreesboro, Tenn. Nearby, poised to attack him, was Union major general William S. Rosecranss Army of the Cumberland, headquartered just 35 miles away in Nashville.

title: A Look Back, and Beyond
description: Every day until Dec. 31, reporters and editors from The New York Times will recall the people, teams and moments that made the last year memorable, and in some cases look ahead to 2013.

title: N.Y.U. and Other Medical Schools Offer Shorter Course in Training, for Less Tuition
description: Training to become a doctor takes so long that just the time invested has become, to many, emblematic of the gravity and prestige of the profession.

title: A Campaign on U.S. Debt Gains Steam
description: WASHINGTON  Maya MacGuineas has been ringing alarms about the nations growing debt for 15 years, imagining a day when a president and a Congress might finally work together to curb deficit spending. After watching President Obama and Speaker John A. Boehner once again come close to agreeing on a plan, only to see a deal slip away, she is troubled but undeterred.

title: A Tradition Meant to Be Broken, Then Eaten and Passed Around
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  At Christmas, horses in this historic racing city take a back seat to another celebrated creature, its legs designed to be somewhat fragile and far stubbier.

title: Anthonys Closing Run Gives Knicks a Close One
description: This game, and the circumstances surrounding it, offered the right combination for a Knicks letdown.

title: The Peppermint Pig, a Holiday Tradition
description: As the candy is passed around the dinner table, each person shares good fortune from the past year, with hopes of good luck for the next.

title: Sneaky Apps That Track Cellphones
description: A perversion of smartphone technology called stalking apps  precise, secretive trackings of the movements of cellphone users  is increasingly a matter of national concern, particularly for domestic abuse victims. No less threatening is the routine monitoring of childrens locales and phone habits for commercial purposes while parents are kept in the dark. Stealth apps even stoop to cyber-leering through the now notorious app called Girls Around Me, which allows men to search out women, unbeknown to them, by cross-matching GPS technology with information and photo sites like Facebook.

title: A Breakthrough for the Bengals; Another Breakdown for the Steelers
description: PITTSBURGH  When the football split the uprights, the Cincinnati Bengals spilled onto the field. They leapt and they hugged and they pumped their fists, savoring the sweet sound of silence at Heinz Field.

title: For Patsy Clines Hometown, an Embrace That Took Decades
description: WINCHESTER, Va.

title: Promoting Made in U.S.A., but Very Carefully
description: BRANDS reviving the Made in the U.S.A. slogan to attract buyers for American-produced goods are relying less on patriotism and more on data that shows consumers are willing to pay a premium for better quality, quicker availability and product safety.

title: Division Title in Reach for Redskins
description: PHILADELPHIA  The quarterback was limited, the defense was shaky, and Washington was on the ropes. Less than two months ago, the Redskins would probably have lost a game like the one they played against the Philadelphia Eagles on Sunday, a game in which they could not put an inferior opponent away despite holding a two-touchdown lead early in the fourth quarter, in which the defense allowed the opponent to drive with ease.

title: Search for Way Through Fiscal Impasse Turns to the Senate
description: WASHINGTON  With little more than a week for lawmakers to avert huge tax increases and spending cuts, attention is turning from the gridlocked House to the Senate, where some Republicans on Sunday endorsed President Obamas call for a partial deal to insulate most Americans from the tax increases but defer a resolution on spending.

title: Gun Makers Use Home Leverage in Connecticut
description: Gun owners packed a hearing room in the Connecticut capital, vowing to oppose a bill that would require new markers on guns so that they are easier to trace.

title: Shortchanging Ex-Offenders
description: The Federal Interagency Re-entry Council, whose purpose is to help released inmates become productive citizens, is rightly pushing the states to help ex-offenders find jobs, housing, drug treatment, training and the other tools that will give them a reasonable chance of staying out of prison. But the federally financed halfway houses that are supposed to smooth this transition appear to be failing to keep their end of the bargain.

title: Illinois Clergy Members Support Same-Sex Marriage in Letter Signed by 260
description: More than 250 religious leaders in Illinois have signed an open letter in support of same-sex marriage, which the legislature is likely to take up in January.

title: Out in Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG

title: Generous Defense Is the Cure for What Ails the Ravens
description: BALTIMORE  In the final, furious games of last season, opponents came to dread the sight of the Giants defense. Quarterbacks wanted to look away when they stared at what had evolved into a game-changing front four. On the rare occasion when they had time to peer downfield, they found receivers blanketed.

title: Could A.I.G. Happen Again?
description: The United States government recently sold the last of its shares in the American International Group, more than four years after it bailed out the insurance giant with a package of assistance that eventually totaled $180 billion. In announcing the sale, the Treasury Department also said that the government had a positive return of $22.7 billion  a sum that fails to take into account tax breaks A.I.G. received as a ward of the state. But whether the government profited from the bailout is not important. The truly vital issue is this: Could this happen again? Unfortunately, the troubling answer is yes.

title: Retiree Lost His Savings to Thieves Lie About a Prize
description: It was a mess, something he had not witnessed in his near century of living, and even with it settled, he gets wound up talking about it. The nerve! Fouling up his life!

title: Larry Morris, 63 Title Game Star, Dies at 79
description: Larry Morris, the Chicago Bears star linebacker who was named the most valuable player of the 1963 National Football League championship game, in which he stymied Giants quarterback Y. A. Tittle to help give the Bears their first league title in 17 years, died on Wednesday in Austell, Ga., outside Atlanta. He was 79.

title: U.N. Says South Sudan Threatens Its Peacekeeping Mission
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  The United Nations said Sunday that the shooting down of one of its helicopters in South Sudan last week was just the latest in a series of attacks or threats against its peacekeeping mission by South Sudans military.

title: Rebuilding in Haiti Lags After Billions in Post-Quake Aid
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  A few days after the Jan. 12, 2010, earthquake, Reginald Boulos opened the gates of his destroyed car dealership to some 14,000 displaced people who settled on the expansive property. Seven months later, eager to rebuild his business, he paid the families $400 each to leave Camp Boulos and return to their devastated neighborhoods.

description: A fire badly damaged a Romanesque Episcopal church in Brooklyn early Sunday, and investigators were looking into the possibility that the blaze was the work of an arsonist.

title: On School Stage, Learning Harlems Past and Narrowing a Generational Gulf

In Need, French Museums Turn to Masses, Chapeaux in Hand

description: The Giants loss to the Ravens in Baltimore left them with only slim playoff hopes.

title: Running a Fast Break From Brooklyn to the Garden
description: In Manhattan, Madison Square Garden was dark, and the Knicks were in the process of being introduced to a capacity crowd. title: Staying Independent in Old Age, With a Little Help
description: My 92-year-old aunt, who is cognitively impaired and requires a walker or wheelchair to get around, still lives in her own apartment, where round-the-clock home health aides help her get to and from the bathroom, bathe, dress and undress, and go outside each day for some fresh air. The aides shop, prepare and serve meals, do light housekeeping and make sure she takes her medications on time.

title: Woman Is Killed and Boy Is Critically Injured in Newark Stabbings
description: A young woman was killed and a 9-year-old boy was in critical condition in stabbings in Newark over the weekendthat the authorities wereinvestigatingas related crimes, the police and prosecutors said on Sunday.

title: China Assails U.S. Over Alliance With Japan and Possible F-16 Sales to Taiwan
description: HONG KONG  The nomination of Senator John Kerry as the new U.S. secretary of state has been warmly received by China, but the state-run news media on the mainland has sharply attacked the passage of a new military spending bill that is awaiting President Obamas signature.

title: In Golds Own Country
description: Lord Padmanabha, the presiding deity of Thiruvananthapuram, also known as Trivandrum, the capital of Kerala, who is depicted as reclining on a gigantic snake, Anantha, suddenly went up in the estimation of his devotees recently, when it was discovered that he has an inestimable treasure of gold in his custody.

title: A Minifig Christmas
description: A stopmotion Christmas wish from the minifigs of Motherlode.

title: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh Appeals for Peace and Calm
description: On Monday morning Prime Minister Manmohan Singh addressed the nation and appealed for peace and calm in the wake of the protests that broke out in New Delhi following the gang rape of a 23-year old woman last Sunday. He spoke for the first time on national television after the incident, and assured that perpetrators of the crime would be punished and measures would be taken to ensure safety of women across India.

title: A Chocolate Hater Offers Holiday Cheer
description: Dear Diary:

title: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 24
description: NEWS An Islamist-backed constitution was approved by voters in Egypt, propelling deeply split political factions into a new phase in the battle over the countrys future. David Kirkpatrick and Mayy El Sheikh report from Cairo.

title: U.S. Civilian Is Killed at Police Post in Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A police sergeant shot and killed an American civilian adviser at police headquarters in Kabul on Monday, Afghan police officials said, breaking a relative lull in the so-called insider killings that have strained the relationship between Americans and Afghans here.

title: An Education City Takes Shape
description: HONG KONG  Malaysia is working on turning an area of gritty industrial towns and villages into EduCity, a massive new education complex that will include the branches of 10 foreign schools, including several universities, business and sports institutes, and two private prep schools.

title: What Will You Do With All That Gift Wrap?
description: Paris  With the season of  exuberant gift giving, joyful excess and artificial Christmas trees at hand, activists, academics and filmmakers are warning of growing landfills and environmental pollution fed by our unsustainable consumption cycle.

title: In Western China, Steep Highs and Steep Lows
description: The high-rises of Chongqing, in western China, are built on hills; it is a city of steep ups and downs.

title: The Betrayal of Russian Orphans
description: MOSCOW  Last week was a terrible week to be a Russian and a great week to be a journalist. From my point of view as a journalist, there was drama, suspense and even a bit of comedy. From my point of view as a Russian, there was nothing but tragedy and shame.

title: Austerity for Posterity
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. She recently edited and contributed to For Love and Money: Care Provision in the United States.

title: Feelings of Ecstasy, and Guilt, About Getting In
description: When I woke up on the morning of Dec. 13, I felt like death.

title: Fudging the Facts, for Peace of Mind
description: Lou, my beloved grandfather, lived almost 101 years and obsessively worried every single day of his adult life  probably because his adult life began before it should have. As a child in Russia, he watched helplessly as his mother and sister were killed during a vicious pogrom in their village.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Jonah Weiner on Jerry Seinfelds Perfectionism
description: Jonah Weiner is the author ofthis weeks cover story about the comedian Jerry Seinfeld. Weiner, a contributing editor at Rolling Stone, wrote about the artist David Shrigley for the magazine earlier this year.

title: What Giants Need to Make the Playoffs
description: The answer is they need a lot. Lets take a closer look.

title: Parliaments Winter Session: A Report Card
description: NEW DELHIAfter its monsoon session collapsed without a single law being passed, Indias Parliament managed to approve a few landmark bills in its just-concluded winter session, but not without wasting most of its time.

title: Protected Tigers, Burning Bright
description: Tigers have delivered a bit of holiday cheer: populations are on the upswing, it turns out, in some protected areas in India and Thailand. In a field often dominated by news of felled forests and population declines, wildlife conservationists have taken heart from this development, while noting that tigers have a long, long way to go if they are to claw their way off the endangered species list.

title: Q&A: Finding a Simplified Smartphone
description: Q.

title: Creams for When Its Cold
description: Chilly winter weather isnt exactly the ideal environment for a radiant and soft complexion: The low temperatures can make skin look lackluster and feel dehydrated. But there are an army of new beauty products promising to combat the effects of the cold.

title: Monday Reading: Inside Disneys New Fantasyland
Week 16 Quick Hits: Ravens Up, Giants Down
description: Andy Benoit takes a quick tour through Sundays Week 16 games. Share your thoughts.

title: Envoy Meets With Assad as Russia Seeks Distance
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Lakhdar Brahimi, the special envoy seeking an end to the Syria crisis, held an urgent meeting with President Bashar al-Assad in Damascus on Monday as new signs emerged that Russia, Mr. Assads most important foreign backer, was moving forward with plans to evacuate Russian diplomats and other expatriates.

title: On Issues Like Climate Change, Can Urgency and Patience Coexist?
description: Here are some end-of-year thoughts on ways to fit human aspirations on a finite planet, expressed during a recent short interview taped while I was participating in this years Business for Social Responsibility (aka BSR) conference (more interviews and talks are here). One is that addressing humanitys entwined energy and climate challenges requires an unlikely mix of urgency and patience:

title: Daily Report: Making Everything in Life a Game
description: Many businesses are using games to try to get people hooked on their products and services  and it is working, thanks to smartphones and the Internet, reports Nick Wingfield on Monday in The New York Times.

title: An E-Book Price War Is Slow in Coming
description: Right about now, just as millions of e-readers and tablets are being slipped under Christmas trees, there is supposed to be a ferocious price war over e-books, reports David Streitfeld on Monday in The New York Times. But it has not happened quite like that.

title: Windows 8 Sales Disappoint in Shaky PC Market
description: It used to be that a new version of the Windows operating system was enough to get people excited about buying a new computer, giving sales a nice pop, reports Nick Wingfield on Monday in Thew New York Times. Not this time.

title: Urs Fischer Hits the Beach
description: Call it domestic spectacle: the way the Swiss artist Urs Fischer blends statuary, household furniture and a Photoshopped mishmash of Americana. In what is sure to be one of the last gallery openings of 2012, his show Tables, Heads and Arms will make its debut three days after Christmas at Eden Rock on the island of St. Barts. For a 2011 show at Gavin Browns Enterprise, Fischer made 300 tabletops, only two-thirds of which were ever displayed in New York. Twenty-one from the remaining lot will go on view in St. Barts, along with an assortment of found objects (chairs, vases, lamps), a new sculpture cast from Fischers forearms and several hand-painted figurines. The pop culture references here run the gamut from Tom Hanks in Da Vinci Code mode to E.P.A. warning signs to Big Bird, who rather solemnly graces the announcement card. But before reading political subtext into the Sesame Street characters appearance, its worth remembering that Fischer titled a 2010 exhibition Oscar the Grouch and that he has a 3-year-old daughter, Lotti, with the artist Cassandra MacLeod. All three are expected to attend his year-end Caribbean vernissage.

title: A Tuesday Like Any Other Day, a Holiday, for an Exonerated Woman
description: Letter by letter, Cathy Watkins removed her name from a roster it should never have been on. This was a list of two dozen prison inmates, their names entered on a board maintained by Centurion Ministries in Princeton, N.J. Centurion advocates on behalf of men and women like those on that board, people it believes were locked up for crimes they did not commit. People like Cathy Watkins.

title: Game of Thrones Is Named Years Most Pirated Show
description: Some fans of the HBO series Game of Thrones may not be willing to pay a premium-cable subscription fee to watch it, but short of besieging a fleet of ships with a magical explosive chemical theyll do just about anything else to get their hands on it. Game of Thrones, the HBO fantasy drama adapted from George R. R. Martins Song of Ice and Fire novels, was the years most pirated show, according to the Web site TorrentFreak. TorrentFreak said that an individual episode of Game of Thrones had been illegally downloaded some 4.28 million times according to data compiled from BitTorrent peer-to-peer file-sharing services and other sources (the particular episode that drew this many downloads was not specified).

title: Intersection:Dandies in the West Village
description: We hear Kai Shaw explain how mens wear is shaping fashion, while other West Village locals gave us tips on holiday dressing.

title: A Gaming Laptop Thats Quick and Costly
description: The word extreme may be overused in describing male-dominated activities like the X Games or the cinnamon challenge, but it fits the bill when it comes to the Razer Blade gaming laptop.

title: Holiday Greens: Spinach for Christmas
description: When I lived in Paris I used to eat Christmas Eve dinner every year at a brasserie. I would always order salmon and a side of spinach, which they cooked very simply and served up in copious amounts. There must have been one low-level guy on the kitchen brigade who did nothing but wash, stem and blanch spinach all day, so much of it did the popular side dishes require. (For every cup of cooked spinach you need 3 pounds of bunch spinach or 1 1/2 pounds of baby spinach.) That is a lot of beta keratin, vitamin K, iron, vitamins A and C, manganese, folate, magnesium, calcium, potassium, vitamins B2 and B6, tryptophan and dietary fiber for Christmas.

title: Penne With Mushroom Ragout and Spinach
description: Mushrooms and spinach together is always a match made in heaven. I use a mix of wild and regular white or cremini mushrooms for this, but dont hesitate to make it if regular mushrooms are all that is available.

title: Garlic Soup With Spinach
description: I made a lot of turkey stock after Thanksgiving and pulled some out for this spinach-packed, very quick and easy soup. A vegetarian version made simply with water and garlic is equally delicious.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Austin Chronicle: Some barbecue masters in Texas lost their lease. So now theyre serving their grub out of their own trailer. Perfect brisket and magnificent Hill Country sunsets? Count us in.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Coughlins Remarks on Flat-Lining Giants
description: The Giants finished a nothing-special 9-7 last season but won their division and earned a home game in their playoff opener on their way to a championship.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Hollywoods 2012 Comeback, and Reviewing Amazons Reviews
description: Movie attendance was up 5.6 percent, despite a weak summer, punctuated by mass killings at a screening in Aurora, Colo., of the latest Batman feature, Brooks Barnes writes. Ticket revenue at North American theaters is projected to jump by 6 percent, to $10.8 billion, according to an analysis by Hollywood.com. In 2012, industry executives say, the increase from foreign sales was even more critical, salvaging the prospects of movies that were mild disappointments in the United States like Ice Age: Continental Drift, from 20th Century Fox, which made $68 million in China alone.

title: London Stock Exchange Revises Offer for Clearinghouse
description: LONDON  The London Stock Exchange Group said on Monday that it had revised the terms of its takeover proposal for LCH.Clearnet, citing the changing regulatory environment.

title: An Interview With Maya MacGuineas
description: The Times Annie Lowrey interviews Maya MacGuineas of Fix the Debt on her organizations stance on the fiscal negotiations.

title: Eggs With Chicken Livers
description: The chef Frank De Carlo of Peasant shows Mark Bittman how to make a simple, flavorful, funky dish for the cold weather.

title: Eggs, Chicken Livers and a Secret Ingredient
description: WHEN I asked Frank DeCarlo  the chef at Peasant, on Elizabeth Street, and a friend  to show me a big-flavored, funky, simple dish that he loved, he suggested a chicken liver frittata.

title: After Protests, Lockdown in New Delhi
description: The New Delhi authorities shut down the heart of the capital for a second day, snarling traffic and disrupting the commute of tens of thousands of workers a day before the Christmas holiday.

title: Game Theory: A Year When Real-World Violence Crept Into Play
description: Dear Stephen, Kirk, gentle readers and online trolls,

title: 100 Cars and Concepts Captured in Wood
description: Matteo Ragni, a designer and architect , set up his company, TobeUs, in 2007 after watching his children play with flimsy and disposable toys. He came up with the idea of getting his designer friends to provide ideas for basic, durable toys made of Lebanese cedar by craftsmen in Lombardy.

title: A Political Insider Who Knows His Way Around the Holiday Buffet Table
description: Alan Flacks got the inside tip from a law clerk.

title: Judge Takes Aim at Another S.E.C. Settlement
description: An obscure settlement announced in March 2011 has triggered questions from a federal judge about how much accountability the Securities and Exchange Commission should demand when it resolves a case.

title: On Our Radar: A Parched Southwest
description: New projections by researchers indicate that dry spells will get progressively worse in coming decades in California, Nevada, the Colorado River headwaters region and Texas, putting greater stress on agriculture, ecosystems and a growing population. [Nature Climate Change]

title: Bond Vigilantes and the Power of Three
description: Matthew Yglesias picks up on a point Ive tried to make at some length recently: the popular story about how an attack by bond vigilantes can cause an interest rate spike and turn America into Greece, Greece I tell you, is incoherent. (Heres a 2010 example from Alan Greenspan  the piece in which he declares it regrettable that the vigilantes havent yet attacked, but grudgingly concedes that low rates might persist well into next year, that is, into 2011. So what has he learned from the failure of his prophecy? Nothing, of course). Its not just that there have so far been no signs of the bond vigilantes; its that even if for some reason the vigilantes did attack, its very hard to see how they could cause a recession in a country that retains its own currency and doesnt have large amounts of debt denominated in foreign currency.

title: Case Pits Adoptive Parents Against Tribal Rights
description: WASHINGTON  What has been the toughest decision for you? Charlie Rose asked Justice Antonin Scalia in a television interview a few weeks ago. He meant the most personally wrenching.

title: Because You Watched Live Theater: The Netflix Plays Coming to Ars Nova
description: To date, a Netflix subscription may not have done much more than killed valuable hours of your free time, caught you up on missed episodes of Futurama and turned you on to the suggestions of its enigmatic recommendation engine. (Enjoyed vintage reruns of Sesame Street? Why not try The Taking of Pelham 1-2-3?) But now that video service has inspired its own dramatic series, The Netflix Plays, which will be presented at Ars Nova, the nonprofit Manhattan theater, by its Play Group, from Jan. 30 through Feb. 9, its press representatives said on Monday.

title: Image of the Day: Dec. 24
In the Bay Area, Bagels as Good as Brooklyns
description: Berkeley, Calif.

title: Dont Mistake Investing Folklore for Personalized Advice
description: Carl Richards is a financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

title: A Shot, or Not?
description: Q. Should a 65-year-old who has never had chickenpox be vaccinated against it?

title: 4 Firefighters Shot, 2 Fatally, in New York; Gunman Dead
description: WEBSTER, N.Y.  It was a simple call to put out a car fire, the sort of routine job that firefighters tackle all the time. The fire truck hurtled to the assignment early Monday in this drowsy town on the shores of Lake Ontario that was preparing for the joys of Christmas.

title: The Twelve Days of Christmas Puzzle
description: On the twelfth day of Christmas, my true love gave to me: twelve Drummers Drumming, Eleven Pipers Piping, ten Lords-a-Leaping, nine Ladies Dancing, eight Maids-a-Milking, seven Swans-a-Swimming, six Geese-a-Laying, five Gold Rings, four Colly Birds, three French Hens, two Turtle Doves and a Partridge in a Pear Tree.

title: The Best in Womens
description: From microprints to iridescence, the best in womens fashion and beauty from T. See interactive feature >>

title: How Much Milk Should Children Drink?
description: Cows milk is the primary source of vitamin D for children, but dairy products can interfere with the absorption of iron. Pediatricians have never known how much milk a child should drink. Now researchers have established that for most children, two cups a day achieves the right balance.

title: Street Style: 1990s-Inspired
description: The best of readers photos from the week of Dec. 17.

title: Warhols Mao Portraits Banned From a Show in China
description: Even though Maos face can be found in work by many Chinese artists, government officials in China have nonetheless vetoed the inclusion of Andy Warhols famous rendition of the Great Leader in a retrospective of his work traveling there, Bloomberg reported. Eric Shiner, director of the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh, said that when he heard last month that officials in Chinas Ministry of Culture objected to displaying 10 Mao portraits, he asked them to reconsider.

title: Whats On Monday
description: 7:30 P.M. (Cinemax) LOVE ACTUALLY (2003) Hugh Grant, above, portrays a British prime minister and twinkly bachelor who fancies a member of his household staff (Martine McCutcheon) at 10 Downing Street  and nearly causes an international crisis when he protects her virtue from the president of the United States (Billy Bob Thornton)  in this ensemble comedy written and directed by Richard Curtis, who also wrote Bridget Joness Diary, Notting Hill and Four Weddings and Funeral. The cast is rounded out by Emma Thompson as the prime ministers sister, a middle-aged housewife whose husband (Alan Rickman) is besotted with his secretary (Heike Makatsh); Liam Neeson as a widower and single stepfather wallowing in grief; Colin Firth as a writer cuckolded by his own brother who is smitten with his Portuguese housekeeper; and Martin Freeman and Joanna Page as actors who fall in love while working as body doubles in a sex scene on a movie set, only to end their first date with a chaste kiss on the cheek. A. O. Scott, writing in The New York Times, called the movie an indigestible Christmas pudding. He added that a genuine comic spark comes from Bill Nighy, playing a washed-up, dissolute rock star named Billy Mack, who is trying for a comeback with a treacly Christmas record.

title: From the Battlefields of Iraq to a Fight in Congos National Parks
description: William Coppelers journey to the 7th World Ranger Conference in Tanzania in November began two years ago, not long after the Iraq veteran had left the Armys 25th Infantry Division for life back home in Port Clinton, Ohio.

title: Pedestrian Accidents More Deadly in Men
description: More than twice as many men as women die in pedestrian-vehicle accidents. Now researchers have partly determined why.

title: Our Top 10 Photo Books of 2012
description: What is a book? Believe it or not, the question was asked more than once in the photo departments informal but very serious deliberations over the best books of 2012. There was much agonizing and jockeying for favorites as we tried to reduce an array of more than 500 books to just 10 favorites. Ultimately, the most important question, the one that ruled the day, was Which books do you most want to have on your shelf? Here are the answers, in no particular order.

title: Merry Christmas From the Minifigs and Motherlode
Relaxed Rules Restore Old Opportunities
description: As part of a 2012 cease-fire agreement between Hamas and Israel, Gazans were granted permission to fish 6 miles off the coast, doubling the previous limit.

title: Test Run: Facebooks Poke App Is a Head-Scratcher
description: A photo of my friend Peters dog pops up on my phone for three seconds, then disappears. I respond with a picture of an enormous pile of nachos Im working on at a Brooklyn bar.

title: Really? The Claim: Green Tea Helps Burn Fat
description: THE FACTS

title: Gaza Cease-Fire Helps Fishermen, but Risks Remain
description: GAZA CITY  Khader Bakr, a 19-year-old fisherman, was thrilled to hear that he could now fish up to six nautical miles from the coast, up from the three-mile limit Israel had had in place since 2009. The change was part of the cease-fire deal that halted last months fighting in Gaza between Israel and Hamas.

title: California Law Tests Company Responses to Carbon Costs
description: LOS BANOS, Calif.  The Morning Star Companys three plants in California emit roughly 200,000 metric tons of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere each year  about the same amount as the Pacific Island nation of Palau  as they turn tomatoes into ketchup, spaghetti sauce and juice used by millions of consumers around the world.

title: Celebrities Selling Homes Scrub Off the Star Dust
description: On a fan Web site devoted to Julian Casablancas, the lead singer of the band the Strokes, and his wife, Juliet, there are pictures of the happy-looking couple in all sorts of settings: at a football game, walking a red carpet and crossing the street holding hands. There are also photographs of an apartment they own and are hoping to sell  here, some nice arched doorways, there, a guitar hanging on the wall  along with the date and time of an open house and a link to the address.

title: Seeking Answers in Genome of Gunman
description: In a move likely to renew a longstanding ethical controversy, geneticists are quietly making plans to study the DNA of Adam Lanza, 20, who killed 20 children and seven adults in Newtown, Conn. Their work will be an effort to discover biological clues to extreme violence.

title: Game Theory: Caring About Make-Believe Body Counts
description: Dear Chris, Kirk and the rest,

title: Food vs. Fuel in 2013
description: In coming days, the Environmental Protection Agencys to-do list will include setting a standard for the amount of advanced biofuels that refiners will be required to blend into gasoline and diesel supplies in 2013. The question is tricky because production in one category, cellulosic fuel from nonfood sources like corn cobs, stalks, wood chips and garbage, has not met the target set by Congress. The E.P.A. has the authority to adjust the quotas as needed, but the issue is complicated.

title: A New Focus on the Post in Post-Traumatic Stress
description: Psychological trauma dims tens of millions of lives around the world and helps create costs of at least $42 billion a year in the United States alone. But what is trauma, exactly?

title: An E-mail for Santa
description: Dear Diary:

title: B.M.I. Can Predict Health Risks
description: Some scientists believe that body mass index, a calculation involving the ratio of height to weight, is an inaccurate measure of obesity-related risks because it does not account for body shape, fat mass and lean mass. But a new study finds that B.M.I. works at least as well as other body measurements, and better than some, to predict certain health problems.

title: Is Paying to Message Strangers a New Texting Business?
description: Cellphone carriers are making less money from text messages thanks to free messaging services offered by Facebook, Apple and other tech companies. But now Facebook is running a test to see if it can make some money by charging people to send messages to strangers.

title: Walkabout  12/24: Airports Gird for Storm, and Vegas Gets an Airline
description: Storm on Santas Heels After dumping six feet of snow in California, a major storm headed east today, likely to add chaos to the usual holiday travel slog. (NBC)

title: Wrights Law: A Teachers Unique Lesson
description: In 2012, The Times profiled Jeffrey Wright, who uses wacky experiments to teach children about the universe, but it is his own personal story that teaches them the true meaning of life.

title: The Black, the White and the Angry
description: Its better than Lincoln, my teenage daughter said, as the end credits rolled at a screening of Quentin Tarantinos Django Unchained. She was teasing me  its a sad fact of my life that some of the people Im fondest of do not seem to share my fondness for Steven Spielbergs latest movie  but also suggesting an interesting point of comparison.

title: Protesters Disrupt Egyptian Bloggers Speech in Israel
description: Last Updated, 7:01 p.m. Palestinian students disrupted a dissident Egyptian bloggers address at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem on Sunday.

title: From Bang to Whimper: A Heart Drugs Story
description: On June 23, 2005, American medicine managed to take a small step forward and a giant step backward at precisely the same time, with government approval of the first medication to be earmarked for a specific racial group. It was BiDil, a drug designed to treat heart failure in blacks.

title: With a Parent Off Again at War, a Holiday of Pride and Isolation
description: FORT CAMPBELL, Ky.  Signs of the season have been everywhere at Fort Campbell High School over the last couple of weeks: a student soloist sang the Carpenters Merry Christmas, Darling at the annual holiday concert, a big tree sparkled in the cafeteria under the Screaming Eagle emblem of the 101st Airborne Division, and thousands of parents were deployed yet again in Afghanistan.

title: The Fed and Interest Rates
description: In response to todays column, Im getting a lot of the usual: namely, the claim that low interest rates dont prove anything, because the Fed has been buying up all the federal governments debt issue. This is always said with an air of great wisdom; in fact, its remarkably foolish, managing to be wrong in three distinct ways.

title: Obstacles to Financing for Retired Chimpanzees
description: As the National Institutes of Health reduces its use of chimpanzees in invasive biomedical research, it is moving more chimps to retirement homes. But the agency could face a problem in paying for their continuing support, officials say.

title: Sun Pokes Through the Rage
description: Justin Vivian Bond has a visceral imagination. During a recent performance of the Yuletide show Snow Angel, at 54 Below, Mx. Bond imagined that his/her self-described freakishness was caused by a traumatized mothers suddenly curdled breast milk when her favorite soap opera was interrupted by Walter Cronkites announcing President John F. Kennedys assassination.

title: Violence and Mental Illness (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Overstating Roma History
description: To the Editor:

title: Buried Emotions (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Andy Ricker to Open Whiskey Soda Lounge in Brooklyn
description: If you were not convinced that Brooklyn was an East Coast version of Portland, Ore., the chef Andy Ricker, who owns Pok Pok Ny in Brooklyn, keeps adding to the case. In the spring, he plans to open a Whiskey Soda Lounge, like the one he has in Portland, just a few doors down from Pok Pok Ny. This branch, in a small space, will serve drinks and Thai-style drinking food snacks that Mr. Ricker described as spicy-salty-sour. He sees it as a holding pen for customers waiting for tables at the restaurant. And he plans to serve Ikes Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings, a cult favorite.

title: Laws of Physics Cant Trump the Bonds of Love
description: Jeffrey Wright is well known around his high school in Louisville, Ky., for his antics as a physics teacher, which include exploding pumpkins, hovercraft and a scary experiment that involves a bed of nails, a cinder block and a sledgehammer.

title: Game Theory: Shooter Games Get Easier, and That Makes Change Harder
description: Dear Stephen, Chris, assorted friends and frenemies,

title: Ancient Marine Reptiles Swam in Rivers Too
description: Mosasaurs were large, ancient relatives of monitor lizards. They were common during the Late Cretaceous period, 66 million to 100 million years ago, and were found near shallow marine areas in salt water.

title: A Happy Ending, Sort of, Comes With No Closure
description: West of Memphis, a work of fierce documentary advocacy directed by Amy Berg (Deliver Us From Evil), follows the successful crusade to free three men convicted of murder 18 years ago in a sloppy, hysterical rush to justice.

title: An Oratorio Gets Its Day
description: It has been a season of relief for those New York Bach fans perpetually disappointed that their masters Christmas Oratorio is not a holiday perennial on the order of Handels Messiah.

title: Thousands of Children Are at Risk in Central Africa, Aid Agency Warns
description: A large measles epidemic is spreading in Central Africa, endangering the lives of thousands of children, the medical charity Doctors Without Borders warned last week.

title: Big Money and Mischief in Reagan-Era Hollywood
description: William Stadiems specialty has been collaborating on gossipy tell-alls with minor celebrities. Very minor celebrities, but well-positioned ones. Mr. Stadiems books include Mr. S: My Life With Frank Sinatra, with George Jacobs, Sinatras keenly observant valet, and Marilyn Monroe Confidential: An Intimate Personal Account, with Lena Pepitone, who worked for Monroe as a maid. According to reader feedback on the Goodreads site, the Monroe book is a better written treatment of National Enquirer-type material. If you read it by a pool and dropped it in the water, a reader says, you wouldnt be all that sorry.

title: Making a Sandwich by the Book
description: Do you really need a cookbook to make a sandwich? Not for PB&J, perhaps, but what if you are tempted by soft scrambled eggs and ricotta on fresh focaccia, or sardines with pickled eggs and salsa verde? Thats when you should open the Saltie cookbook, based on the menu at this compact sandwich shop in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Besides recipes for sandwiches and their components, it has desserts, soups, eggs and salads. An easily assembled cock-a-leekie makes a delicious cold-weather supper. The method is unusual: bring a whole chicken to a boil, then let it cool in the liquid for an hour, after which the chicken is done and you have your broth. Prunes add color and a touch of sweet richness.

title: Smoked Fish From Long Island
description: Phil Karlin, a commercial fisherman based in Cutchogue, N.Y., has started making and selling various smoked fish products under the name North Fork Smoked Fish. His line includes smoked blue fish fillets and a creamy smoked blue fish pt, a slightly spicier Caribbean pt made with smoked swordfish, a mixed smoked-fish dip, and hot-smoked Norwegian salmon pt (below) and fillets, all tailor-made for easy entertaining. The pts and dips are appetite-whetters. The succulent fish fillets can be served alongside a salad, in a sandwich or broken up into a chowder.

title: As Forests Disappear, Examining the Mechanisms of Their Death
description: LOS ALAMOS, N.M.  Everywhere, trees are dying.

title: Turkish Breads Seek a Niche in the Bagel Capital
description: In Eastern Mediterranean regions, Balkan countries and the Arab world there is a popular snack that looks like a large bagel and comes beaded with sesame seeds. It has various names, but in Turkey its called simit, and it is the star attraction at a new shop in Manhattan called Simit & Smith. The Smith is fictitious; the Turkish entrepreneurs behind the enterprise added it to make the name more American-sounding, said Burak Atay, the managing partner. They opened on the Upper West Side last week and already have a bakery and store in Cliffside Park, N.J. Two spots are planned for the financial district in early 2013.

title: The Wretched Lift Their Voices
description: In the first long act of Les Misrables, Anne Hathaway opens her mouth, and the agony, passion and violence that have decorously idled in the background of this all-singing, all-suffering pop opera pour out. Its a gusher! Shes playing Fantine, the factory worker turned prostitute turned martyr, and singing the showstopping I Dreamed a Dream, her gaunt face splotched red and brown. The artful grunge layered onto the cast can be a distraction, as you imagine assistant dirt wranglers anxiously hovering off camera. Ms. Hathaway, though, holds you rapt with raw, trembling emotion. She devours the song, the scene, the movie, and turns her astonishing, cavernous mouth into a vision of the void.

title: For the Home Mixologist, One Tool for 10 Tasks
description: A Swiss Army knife for the bar? Why not, especially in a small apartment. This gadget, the Bar10der, combines everything you need, except the shaker and alcohol, to make a drink. The muddler at one end doubles as a reamer. A strainer, knife, zester, channel knife, stirrer, bottle opener and corkscrew all pull out of the handle for use. There is a double jigger, for an ounce and a half-ounce. The cushioned rubber-clad handle is easy to grip, and you have a choice of colors: azure, purple, lime or orange.

title: 12 Restaurant Triumphs of 2012
description: AT the end of my first year in the restaurant critics chair, the New York dining landscape still looks like a wonderland to me.

title: The Years Farewells
description: A few of the notable restaurants that closed in 2012.

title: The Dishes of 2012 That Dazzled on Their Own
description: Many restaurants that didnt make the top 12 of the year still served memorable dishes. Pete Wells lists eight of the best.

title: The Top 12 Restaurants of 2012
description: Pete Wells shares his list of the years best restaurants.

title: A New Calf Has Arrived in Brooklyn
description: Updated, Dec. 26 | Brooklyns bovine population has grown by one: a calf was born at the Prospect Park Zoo, officials announced Monday.

title: The Trocks Tackle Laurencia
description: The all-male drag company Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo is currently staging the Soviet-era ballet Laurencia at the Joyce Theater.

title: Going to Sleep While We Wait for Santa
description: Were not sure if Santa Claus will leave a luxury car with a giant bow in the driveway, a motorcycle in the garage or a Matchbox car in the stocking, but we do know he wont leave anything if were awake. So Wheels is taking a not-so-long winters nap tonight and tomorrow. But rest assured well be back on Wednesday. Merry Christmas to all!

title: In Performance: Alice Ripley of A Civil War Christmas
description: A Civil War Christmas, Paula Vogels play with music, is set during the grim holiday season of 1864. Alice Ripley, who plays Mary Todd Lincoln and other characters, sings a medley of Yellow Rose of Texas and Aint That a Rockin All Night. The show runs through Dec. 30 at New York Theater Workshop.

title: Buried Treasure That Is Filled With Mystery
description: IF you have never bought truffles because, frankly, you do not know how to begin and you are afraid you will get skunked, well, you are not alone. Serious home cooks and even food pros are bamboozled all the time. Its actually pretty difficult and always expensive to attain good-quality truffles, especially for retail customers. In fact, acquiring truffles is so fraught with potential fraud that you might wonder whether the dining experience is worth the financial risk.

title: The Chemistry Sets of Yesteryear
description: From Chemcraft to the Midgetlab,  chemistry sets flourished from the early through the mid-20th century, featuring everything from gender-specific kits to tabletop labs complete with Atomic Energy.

title: A Science Toy Spectacular
description: This week we take up a history of science toys. And if youve ever wondered what toys the reporters and editors at the Science Times adored as children, well, we got that too.

title: Columbus Circle, 2:38 P.M.
Practical to Career-Oriented to Just Plain Fun
description: Harry Potter fans will appreciate the origin of the chemistry set: In 18th century England, university students were given supply lists and sent to shops in London that assembled kits for each course of study, from geology to mineralogy and chemistry.

title: A Haunting Tale, Perfect for Christmas
description: At holiday time, the Metropolitan Museum of Art draws countless visitors to its Medieval Sculpture Garden to see the splendid Christmas tree and 18th-century Neapolitan crche. The garden has also been a special site for holiday concerts. The museum has put much thought over the years into choosing appropriate seasonal music, especially early music.

title: Gifts That Keep Giving (if Not Exploding)
description: Ask scientists of a certain age about their childhood memories, and odds are theyll start yarning about the stink bombs and gunpowder they concocted with their chemistry sets. Dangerous? Yes, but fun.

title: Whats Your Best Meal of 2012?
description: Pete Wells has listed his best new restaurants of the year, along with some of the best dishes he tasted. Now we look to you. Share your best restaurant meals of the year by tweeting us at @nytdining, using the hashtag #bestmeal2012.
