Your pick doesnt have to be from a new restaurant, or even a place in New York City; it simply has to be something delicious, intriguing, stimulating or just so good you couldnt stop thinking about it.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, India, Afghanistan and West Bank.

title: Russian Prosecutor Seeks Acquittal in Lawyers Death
description: MOSCOW  A prosecutor unexpectedly pressed Monday for the acquittal of the only official to be tried in the case of Sergei L. Magnitsky, a lawyer whose death in prison three years ago generated an international furor over Russian human rights abuses.

title: No Requiem for Earth, Only Celebration
description: The world did not end on Friday as the ancient Maya calendar foretold. But if any apocalyptic forces were kicking around the planet that day, they were combated by a performance that evening at Carnegie Hall of The Creation, Haydns astonishing oratorio that depicts Gods making of the world, presented by the New York Virtuoso Singers, the Orchestra of St. Lukes and a roster of vocal soloists, conducted by Harold Rosenbaum.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Free Beer

title: Not Even the Russians Can Do This Laurencia
description: Tory Dobrin, the artistic director of the all-male drag company Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo, affectionately known as the Trocks, first saw a clip of the Soviet-era ballet  Laurencia  on television in the early 80s, and it stayed with him. The ballet shows its choreographer, Vakhtang Chabukiani, dancing in a ripped shirt, with a bare midriff and torn pants, surrounded by women in peasant skirts and blouses.

title: What He Does for Love
description: For the last couple of months, VH1 has been showing the reality show Marrying the Game, which chronicled the wedding preparations of the Game, the abrasive, derivative rapper, and his longtime girlfriend, Tiffney Cambridge. By the end of the season, though, the two were at loggerheads, and the wedding was off, at least partly because of the Games heavy focus on completing work on Jesus Piece, his fifth album.

title: No Means No, and More From Wise Grandparents
description: Parental Guidance, a new comedy with Billy Crystal, is about a minor-league baseball announcer who, after hes canned for being an old shtick in the mud (he doesnt tweet), develops a new relationship with his daughter and grandkids. Actually, he teaches everyone a lot of lessons  its revenge of the geezer  allowing him to have his curmudgeonly cake and eat it too. Mostly, though, Parental Guidance is what families who are desperate to get out of the house over the holidays and need to bridge the generational divide will see after theyve seen Les Misrables.

title: In Performance: Alice Ripley
description: The actress sings Yellow Rose of Texas from A Civil War Christmas.

title: Qatar 2022: Nine Years Can Go By Fast
description: Every four years, soccer fans around the world revel in what has been called the biggest sporting event on the planet  the World Cup.

title: More on a Man Who Flew More Than a Million Miles
description: AS the end of the year approaches, many business travelers anxiously do the mileage math. That is, how many miles did I fly this year on a given airline? Was it enough to hit the mark for whichever elite-status level Im pursuing for next year?

title: Harmonizing Two Holidays
description: Marc Kudisch and Jeffry Denman rely too much on well-worn themes to make The Holiday Guys: Happy Merry Hanu-Mas!, their new seasonal stage show, a must-see addition to the December crush. But its moderately diverting, nonthreatening and nontaxing, which seem to be the main theatrical criteria at this time of year. And when the two men put aside the predictable banter and just sing, its downright pleasant.

title: Thats No Mouse King in the Trailer
description: Reality television viewers familiar with Chris March from his stint as a Project Runway contestant or his endearingly wacky Bravo spinoff, Mad Fashion, will know this designer and sometime drag artist as an outsize personality with a cuddly exuberance to match his girth. But that personality is largely AWOL from his holiday dansical, Chris Marchs The Butt-Cracker Suite!, playing at Here.

title: How the Ravens Used Play-Action to Beat the Giants
description: Jonathan Bales breaks down a big play each week of the season.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: These Were a Few of Their Favorite Things
description: Science Times asked five noted scientists about the toys they remember from childhood.

title: An Update on the Assad Inner Circle
description: The nearly two-year-old uprising has killed and wounded some members of the presidential family, and led others into exile.

title: Getting Polio Campaigns Back on Track
description: How in the world did something as innocuous as the sugary pink polio vaccine turn into a flash point between Islamic militants and Western crusaders, flaring into a confrontation so ugly that teenage girls  whose only offense is that they are protecting children  are gunned down in the streets?

title: Women of Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Citys Law Tracking Energy Use Yields Some Surprises
description: In courting tenants over the last six years, 7 World Trade Center has trumpeted its gold LEED rating, an emblem of sound environmental citizenship.

title: Jack Klugman, Actor of Everyman Integrity, Dies at 90
description: Jack Klugman, the rubber-mugged character actor who leapt to television stardom in the 1970s as the slovenly sportswriter Oscar Madison on The Odd Couple and as the crusading forensic pathologist of Quincy, M.E., died on Monday at his home in the Woodland Hills section of Los Angeles. He was 90.

title: Markets Quiet, Awaiting Move on Impasse
description: It was supposed to be an easy week.

title: Endless Emotions Over N.F.L.s Longest Game
description: Ed Podolak loves this time of year. Invariably, he is asked about his momentous game on Dec. 25, 1971, when he amassed 350 total yards, still a postseason record, even though his Kansas City Chiefs lost in double overtime to the Miami Dolphins, 27-24, in the longest contest in N.F.L. history.

title: Aid for Children, Facilitated by Wings
description: IM the president of the United States Fund for Unicef, and I travel for a lot of reasons. First and foremost, I go places so I can see firsthand the work that Unicef is doing on the ground.

title: Future of Corporate Tower May Hinge on a New Use
description: The AT&T Building, a lavish $200 million headquarters with a seven-story arch at 550 Madison Avenue, was a symbol of a resurgent New York when it opened in 1983 after a decade of municipal woes and corporate flight.

title: Dressing Up for Success
description: In September, a pedestrian walking on Central Park South in Manhattan might have noticed the name Jumeirah being stripped from the marquee of the Essex House, a luxury hotel. The property became a JW Marriott. Earlier, it was a Westin.

title: Getting Food Aid to Storm-Ravaged New Yorkers
description: To the Editor:

title: Make Room for God, Pope Says at Christmas Eve Mass
description: ROME  Pope Benedict XVI, delivering his annual Christmas Eve message in a voice that sometimes seemed to waver, called on the faithful to make room for God in their thoughts and busy, technology-filled lives.

title: Blame for Our Record on Treaties
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexico Finds Unlikely Allies in Trade Fight
description: As tomato growers in Florida and some other states fight a 16-year-old agreement that they contend allows farmers in Mexico to export tomatoes at a price below their costs, the Mexican farmers are finding allies in the United States.

title: A Prayer at Christmas
description: Providence, R.I.

title: These Wretched Vessels
description: I asked a friend of mine what she wanted for Christmas.

title: 7-Eleven Shifts Focus to Healthier Food Options
description: The chain that is home of the Slurpee, Big Gulp and self-serve nachos with chili and cheese is betting that consumers will stop in for yogurt parfaits, crudit and lean turkey on whole wheat bread.

title: Christmas Ornaments, Child Labor
description: Ithaca, N.Y.

title: The 2012 Sidney Awards I
description: At the start of the 1980s, about 5 percent of Harvard students were Asian-American. But the number of qualified Asian-American applicants rose so that by 1993 roughly 20 percent of Harvard students had Asian heritage.

title: Officials Push to Postpone Swearing-In of Chvez
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Top officials in the government of President Hugo Chvez, who is recuperating from cancer surgery in Cuba, say they will postpone his inauguration, now set for Jan. 10, if he is too ill to return to Venezuela to begin his new term.

title: Deployed Yet Again
description: Students at Fort Campbell High School live with the emotions of parents who carry the burdens of war.

title: Unpacking Christmas
description: Almost everyone who keeps Christmas seriously and loves this season for reasons secular or sacred cherishes the ritual of going through the decorations that have gathered over time. Each year, the Christmas archive is unpacked again. Here are the oldest ornaments for the tree  hand-me-downs over several generations, terribly fragile, their color faded but no less powerful in memory for that.

title: Jack Klugman, Character Actor, Dies
description: Jack Klugman, the character actor who leapt to television stardom in the 1970s as the slovenly sportswriter Oscar Madison on The Odd Couple, died on Monday.

title: A Pleasant Surprise Amid the Sure Things
description: The N.F.L. has never seen a rookie class make a larger impact than this years group. Now, with the playoff field nearly set, the extraordinary nature of these rookies is coming into focus.

title: F.B.I. Counterterrorism Agents Monitored Occupy Movement, Records Show
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Bureau of Investigation used counterterrorism agents to investigate the Occupy Wall Street movement, including its communications and planning, according to newly disclosed agency records.

title: Indiana: No Bond for 3 in Fatal Arson
description: Three people charged with murder and arson for causing an Indianapolis house explosion were jailed without bond after a court hearing on Monday. A Marion County judge entered not guilty pleas for the defendants  Monserrate Shirley; her boyfriend, Mark Leonard; and his brother Bob Leonard  who were arrested on Friday. They were accused of tampering with Ms. Shirleys gas fireplace to fill her residence with gas and using the microwave to spark the Nov. 10 blast, which killed two neighbors and damaged surrounding homes. Investigators believe the three were trying to collect insurance money on the house.

title: Another Try at Nuclear Negotiations
description: After a six-month hiatus, the United States and other major powers are trying to resume negotiations with Iran over its nuclear program. Iran has been enriching uranium in defiance of United Nations Security Council resolutions for six years, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has threatened military strikes if these activities are not halted by next spring or early summer. It is imperative that all sides make every effort to reach a diplomatic solution. War, of course, would be disastrous. But so would an Iran with a nuclear weapon.

title: Where Streets Are Darkest, Christmas Still Comes
description: Residents of neighborhoods devastated by Hurricane Sandy celebrate the holidays.

title: Troops in Afghanistan Find Cheer With a Yule Logon
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Marine Cpl. Brett Bass will do what a lot of American service members hope to this Christmas Day: Im going to give myself a gift of not turning on my alarm clock, he said.

title: The Power of a Moms Love
description: Its Christmas. The fiscal cliff is still approaching, guns remain a huge problem and the political paralysis in Washington isnt abating. But, in the spirit of the season, lets put aside our national troubles for this one day and talk about something a little more inspiring. Lets talk about what a mothers love can accomplish.

title: Approaching Illness as a Team
description: The Cleveland Clinic, long considered a premier medical system, is gaining new renown for innovation in improving the quality of care while holding down costs.

title: After Looking East to the Knicks, Nash Cut West to the Lakers
description: LOS ANGELES  In the beginning, it was hard for Steve Nash to picture himself wearing the purple-and-gold uniform of the Lakers, his archrival for eight years when he played for the Phoenix Suns.

title: Real and Virtual Firearms Nurture a Marketing Link
description: As Electronic Arts prepared to market Medal of Honor Warfighter, the latest version of its top-selling video game released in October, it created a Web site that promoted the manufacturers of the guns, knives and combat-style gear depicted in the game.

title: No Easy Route if Assad Opts to Go, or to Stay, in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  President Bashar al-Assad of Syria sits in his mountaintop palace as the tide of war licks at the cliffs below.

title: Caring for a Toddler Who Rules the House
description: Jose Valentin is the head of a four-person household. Technically.

title: Hackers of Football Teams Web Site Demand Apology in Rape Case
description: Computer hackers hijacked the Web site of a prominent Ohio high school football team late Sunday, threatening to release the personal data of school officials, coaches and every player on the team if those involved in a suspected rape did not publicly apologize to the girl and her family.

title: Key West Looks at Identity as It Plots Tourism Future
description: KEY WEST, Fla.  There is no better motto for this raucous southernmost point on the American map than One Human Family.

title: A Republican Mayoral Possibility Unsettles Democrats
description: I served as City Hall bureau chief during the temple-throbbing Age of Giuliani. Almost alone among the men who vowed daily loyalty to Rudolph W. Giuliani  and the mayoral inner circle often was a male preserve  Joe Lhota qualified as media-friendly.

title: Religious Exemptions and the Liberal State: A Christmas Column
description: On Sunday in these pages, Molly Worthen reported on the decline of the Protestant civil religion that has undergirded our common life for so long (One Nation Under God?). That might come as a surprise to the millions of TV viewers who watched the memorial service held in Newtown, Conn., a little more than a week ago. Despite a few gestures in the direction of Catholics and religious minorities (and no gestures at all in the direction of non-believing atheists and agnostics), the tenor of the service was deeply Protestant, as were the remarks of President Obama (that famous Muslim!) who seemed more preacher than chief executive as he repeatedly struck biblical chords and ended by recalling Jesuss call to send the little children to him.

title: In Their Hours of Need
description: Can the Giants still make the playoffs? Yes, but it will require four specific results and a long day of waiting. Heres a potential timeline of events for Sunday that could end with the Giants slipping into the postseason.

title: Tebows Inactivity Speaks Volumes on Jets
description: If the perfect microcosm of the Jets season was modeled after one game, Sundays 27-17 loss to the San Diego Chargers would be an apt candidate.

title: Fire and Flooding in Breezy Point
description: The fires that enveloped the community of Breezy Point, Queens, on the night that Hurricane Sandy hit, left a hole in the heart of this genial shore community.

title: Frenzy Over Teaching Test Is Symptom of Italys Myriad Woes
description: ROME  Luisa Ribolzi, an expert on education in Italy, likened a teaching job at a public school when the economy is bad to a ship to jump on for everyone who is swimming in the sea.

title: Clinging to Now, but Looking to Future Changes
description: One day after a deflating blowout loss that kind of, sort of, maybe felt like the end of the season (but actually wasnt), it was difficult to know which way to look with the Giants.

title: Gaza: Rights Group Accuses Militants of Unlawful Rocket Attacks on Israel
description: Human Rights Watch said Monday that armed Palestinian groups in Gaza had violated the laws of war by firing hundreds of rockets toward population centers in Israel during eight days of fighting in November. Three Israeli civilians, a soldier and a civilian contractor at a military base were killed by the rocket fire. The group said that two Palestinians were killed, apparently by rockets that fell short, and that the militants endangered Gaza civilians by firing from densely populated areas. More than 150 Palestinians were killed by Israel airstrikes and shelling. A spokesman for Hamas, the Islamic militant group that controls Gaza, rejected the report as biased, telling Reuters that the Palestinians were defending themselves. Human Rights Watch, a nongovernmental group based in New York, has criticized Israel for what it called unlawful attacks on a house that killed 12 people, and on Palestinian journalists during the conflict. Israel has insisted that it fired on legitimate targets.

title: Antigovernment Graffiti Restored, Courtesy of Government
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For decades, visitors to Alcatraz Island had trouble deciphering the faded red graffiti on the old prisons rusted water tower.

title: China: 89 Abducted Children Rescued
description: The police have broken up nine child trafficking rings, rescuing 89 children and arresting 355 suspects, the Ministry of Public Security announced Monday. According to the official Xinhua news service, the gangs abducted children in several provinces in the south and then sold them elsewhere in China. The raid was part of a nationwide crackdown on kidnappers, who often seize boys. Most of the stolen children are sold to families who want a male heir but face limitations imposed by Chinas strict family-planning policies. The Chinese government says that 10,000 children are kidnapped each year, but some experts suggest the number may be as high as 70,000.

title: Russia: More Trouble for an Activist
description: Federal authorities on Monday announced another criminal case against Aleksei Navalny, the anticorruption advocate and political opposition leader  the fourth over all and the second one this month. Mr. Navalny, left, has denied all of the allegations, describing them as politically motivated retribution for his activities. The federal Investigative Committee on Monday accused Mr. Navalny of stealing more than $3 million from the Union of Right Forces, a liberal party that is now defunct, in 2007. The authorities have also accused Mr. Navalny and his brother of conspiring to steal money in business deals. In addition, Mr. Navalny has been questioned in connection with a protest last May and has been accused of defrauding a timber company. Mr. Navalny, responding on Twitter to the latest charges, posted, Enough.

title: Battered Seaside Haven Recalls Its Trial by Fire
description: They expected the sea to come, though not like this. Tim Dufficy, 26, one of the volunteer firefighters, had relocated his two cars to the rooftop lot of a Brooklyn mall so they would be up high. Of potential risks, fire did not rouse much concern. They began the evening contemplating turkey.

title: A Start-Up Sees a Gold Rush Among the Stars
description: BELLEVUE, Wash.  The job description and title, Chief Asteroid Miner, are not what you are likely to come across on a job-search Web site. Besides, the position is taken. Chris Lewicki, the president of Planetary Resources, a company based in this city just east of Seattle, has it on his business cards.

title: Historic Boston Churchs Decision to Sell Rare Psalmbook Divides Congregation
description: BOSTON  When the leadership at Old South Church decided it was time to fix up their home, they turned to a fund-raising option most likely available only to a Colonial-era institution like this one, founded in this citys primordial hinterlands: selling a copy of a rare psalmbook, printed across the river in Cambridge in 1640, that could fetch up to $20 million at auction.

title: Lottery Numbers
Game With Sets and Runs
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Lets talk about being literal.

title: A Gap Between Humphriess Salary and Value
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Holiday on Tuesday (Christmas)
description: NEW YORK

title: Richard Adams, Same-Sex Spouse Who Sued U.S., Dies at 65
description: Richard Adams, who nearly four decades ago legally married his male partner in Colorado and, in the first lawsuit of its kind, tried unsuccessfully to have their marriage recognized by the federal government, died on Dec. 17 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 65.

title: Friend of Former Commissioner Is Acquitted of Lying in Inquiry
description: A Bronx jury acquitted a friend of Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York police commissioner, on Monday of a charge involving perjury to a grand jury in 2006 over renovation work to Mr. Keriks apartment.

title: Corrections: December 25, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: What Kept Chinas Search Engines Busy in 2012
description: HONG KONG  With an estimated 600 million Chinese now having access to the Internet, it seems both instructive and important to find out about their end of the global online conversation. What have they been reading and searching for this year? What has them worried, or optimistic? What have they been blogging and blathering about?

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Dec. 25, 2012.
description: No one really cares. Your father goes, gets deployed. War  its normal. Its not like a big deal that were still at war.

title: Warfighter Video Game Is Linked to Gun Makers
description: It has not yet been two weeks since Adam Lanza used two handguns and an assault rifle to kill 20 first-graders and six adults at Sandy Hook Elementary in Newtown, Connecticut.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 9 P.M. (BBC America) DOCTOR WHO: THE SNOWMEN In this annual holiday episode, a Scrooge-like Doctor (Matt Smith), mourning the loss of Amy and Rory to the Weeping Angels, takes on a new companion, Clara (Jenna-Louise Coleman, above with Mr. Smith). Now its up to her to persuade him to board the Tardis and save Christmas from the villainous Doctor Simeon (Richard E. Grant) and his army of snowmen.

title: Merry Christmas!
Adding Indian Spice to Christmas
description: For those who celebrate Christmas, the meal eaten to mark the holiday can be as important as the ritual of exchanging gifts or decorating a green tree.

title: Charles Durning, Prolific Character Actor, Dies at 89
description: Charles Durning, who overcame poverty, battlefield trauma and nagging self-doubt to become an acclaimed character actor, whether on stage as Big Daddy in Cat on a Hot Tin Roof or in film as the lonely widower smitten with a cross-dressing Dustin Hoffman in Tootsie, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89.

title: Forget the Sleigh, Bring On Air Force One
description: Of all the first ladys official duties, the Christmas Eve phone calls to young children eagerly anticipating news of Santas arrival must rank among the least prone to complication.

title: Hark! The Herald of Christmas Past
description: One hundred years ago, in celebration of the holiday season, The New York Herald Tribune European edition (a forerunner of todays IHT) published its annual Christmas supplement. The richly illustrated pages contained original artwork and articles on a variety of topics.

title: Record-Breaking Weekend in the N.F.L.
description: Chase Stuart writes about the historical and statistical side of football at his site, FootballPerspective.com.

title: A Conservative Case for the Welfare State
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Safety Agency Blasts Grinches Who Use Safety to Spoil Christmas Fun
description: LONDON  Britains health and safety watchdog has come out with a timely indictment of petty officialdom for using the excuse of supposedly protecting the public in order to spoil everyones Christmas fun.

title: Chinese and Syrians Are in Prayers of the Pope
description: ROME  Speaking from the balcony of St. Peters Basilica, Pope Benedict XVI called on Tuesday for religious freedom in China and peace for the defenseless in Syria in his Christmas message.

title: Chinese Driver Runs Down Students
description: HONG KONG  A man angry over a court ruling in the case of his daughters murder used his car to run down a group of high school students in northern China, causing 13 to be hospitalized with injuries, the local government and the state news media reported on Tuesday. It was the second major attack on students in China in less than two weeks.

title: Pass the Hat, Save the Arts?
description: PARIS  In the early rush to turn crowd-funding online into a new source of public revenue to buy everything from medieval ivory statues in France to a gallery for dinosaur bones in Canada, theres a cautionary tale: It doesnt always work.

title: Tuesday Reading: Unpacking Christmas Memories
Q&A: Selling Your Own iBooks
description: If I use the iBooks Author program to create my own e-book, do I have to sell it through Apples online bookstore?

title: Navigating Retail Holiday Return Policies
description: Now that the holiday shopping frenzy is over, its time for the traditional Returning of the Gifts.

title: The Best in Culture
description: A collection of the years best in art, music and film. See interactive feature >>

title: Israel to Review Curbs on Womens Prayer at Western Wall
description: JERUSALEM  Amid outrage across the Jewish diaspora over a flurry of recent arrests of women seeking to pray at the Western Wall with ritual garments in defiance of Israeli law, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has asked Natan Sharansky, the chairman of the Jewish Agency, to study the issue and suggest ways to make the site more accommodating to all Jews.

title: Mandela Is Looking Better, President Says After Visit
description: JOHANNESBURG  President Jacob Zuma of South Africa gave a largely upbeat assessment on Tuesday of the health of Nelson Mandela, the nations first black president and anti-apartheid icon, who has spent more than two weeks in the hospital for a lung infection and gallstones.

title: TV Watch: India's 'Child Bride'
description:
One of the top-rated shows in India, "Child Bride," is about Anandi, an underage girl
who was forced into an arranged marriage by her parents.

title: Dont Come To This Land, My Daughter
description: This is a soap opera about female infanticide in India.

title: Is That Christmas Tree Kosher?
description: JERUSALEM  More than two decades ago, the Israeli belly dancer Ilana Raskin won a Supreme Court case against the Israeli rabbinate. It had withheld a license for serving kosher food in the hotel where she was to perform because it found such acts immodest and immoral. She prevailed in court, on the argument that the rabbinate, which is the only Israeli institution permitted to issue kosher-food licenses, should do so only on grounds pertaining to the preparation and serving of food.

title: TV Watch:  I Do
description: This is a new soap opera about Zoya, an Indian girl who returns home from New York and has to adjust to her traditional Muslim community. The romances are predictable but the setting isn't.

title: Pick Your All-Time New York City N.B.A. Team
description: New York City high schools have produced at least 211 N.B.A. and A.B.A. players, including 12 Hall of Famers. Choose and share a team of your own.

title: Game Theory: Making Room for the Women
description: Women. You must have heard of them. Theyre like real gamers, only with little hands and silly, squeaky voices and constant gripes about being marginalized and hypersexualized and threatened with rape in online multiplayer settings.

title: A Onetime Drug Dealer, Now Working to Combat a Plague of Gun Violence
description: Rudy Suggs, 48, has already lived one life, and now he is on his second. The first was as a gun-toting drug dealer in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, a few blocks from where he grew up. The second is as an anti-gun-violence activist, working the same streets he used to roam late into the night to prevent gunshots before they happen.

title: Gaming Workplace Workouts
description: The company Nextjump splits its employees into workout teams and rewards them for going to the gym.

title: Spike Lee Goes After Django Unchained
description: He may not have seen it, but the film director Spike Lee already has an opinion about Django Unchained. In a recent interview with Vibe, he said he would not watch Quentin Tarantinos latest film, set in the antebellum South, which opened in theaters on Tuesday. I cant speak on it cause Im not gonna see it, he said. The only thing I can say is its disrespectful to my ancestors, to see that film.

title: Q. and A. With Michael Bradley
description: Before his 20th birthday, Michael Bradley fulfilled a dream when he signed a contract to play for Heerenveen in the Netherlands. Since then, Bradley, 25, has played in Germany (Borussia Mnchengladbach), in England (on loan to Aston Villa) and in Italy (first for Chievo Verona and now for Roma).

title: Former Official Stole Millions in Real Estate, Russia Says
description: MOSCOW  The police said Tuesday that they had arrested a former official of a federal agency that manages state enterprises on charges of stealing $330 million in property, a theft noteworthy even by the standards of Russian public corruption.

title: Ben Affleck Says No to a Senate Run
description: Any Massachusetts residents dreaming of having an Oscar winner who publicly rubbed up J. Lo as their Washington envoy are due for disappointment. Ben Affleck declared that he would not compete for John Kerrys Senate seat if Mr. Kerry is confirmed as secretary of state. I love Massachusetts and our political process, but I am not running for office, Mr. Affleck wrote on his Facebook page.

title: The View from Notre Dame: Tickets to Ride
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  The players had not left the Los Angeles Coliseum after Notre Dame defeated Southern California on Nov. 24 when the Fighting Irish senior Danny Kinasz secured his seat for the plane ride to Miami for the Bowl Championship Series title game on Jan. 7.

title: Clout Diminished, Tea Party Turns to Narrower Issues
description: The Tea Party might not be over, but it is increasingly clear that the election last month significantly weakened the once-surging movement, which nearly captured control of the Republican Party through a potent combination of populism and fury.

title: Mine, All Mine: Ski Areas Rent Whole Mountains
description: Having a private ski mountain seems the stuff of ski-bum fantasy. But for little more than the price of a daily lift ticket (if overall cost is divided equally), a few ski areas offer the chance for skiers to act like king (or queen) of the mountain for the day.

title: What to Play on Boxing Day
description: It was fun putting together the Christmas Dozen Playlist that accompanied my eggnog column. And I couldnt have done it without my friend Sean, an M.T.A. subway motorman, whose holiday gift to his friends is a painstakingly compiled, wonderfully idiosyncratic music mix; he introduced me to three of the numbers I included on my playlist: Toots and the Maytals Christmas Feeling Ska; BeauSoleils Papa St. Nick; and William Bells Everyday Will Be Like a Holiday. (I did not consult with Questlove, but he has some tips for holiday-party playlist-making, too.)

title: Gunman Who Killed 2 Firefighters Left Chilling Note
description: WEBSTER, N.Y.  On Monday morning when darkness was still raw, William Spengler Jr. armed himself with a rifle, a revolver and a shotgun. He had killed before. Harboring a deep-seated hatred of his sister, who lived with him, and a desire to harm his neighbors on a beachfront strip off Lake Ontario, Mr. Spengler composed a rough, typewritten plan that foretold of the destruction to come.

title: Design Unveiled for Haiti Stadium
description: It has been nearly three years since an earthquake devastated Haiti.

title: Motive Unclear in Killing by Woman in Afghan Force
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Sergeant Nargis went to work Monday with murder on her mind.

title: Game Theory: Challenging the Industry
description: Helen,

title: Russian Says Ban on U.S. Adoption Flouts Treaties
description: MOSCOW  Russias deputy prime minister for social affairs has warned President Vladimir V. Putin that a proposed ban on adoptions of Russian children by American citizens would violate several international treaties as well as an agreement on adoptions ratified this year between the Russian government and the United States.

title: The Triumphs and Failures of Deal Makers in 2012
description: It is time to award the Deal Professor As, the grade for the best deals and deal makers of 2012. Unfortunately, there were also a large number of Fs this year. Here is the top and bottom of the class, in alphabetical order:

title: Celtics Subdue Nets in Christmas Day Opener
description: The scoreboard is inanimate, reflecting only cold results and momentary fate, but it can occasionally serve as an emotional and spiritual marker, reflecting the brilliant highs and the most wrenching lows of the N.B.A. calendar.

title: Now in 3-D, Christmas With the Queen
description: For the first time, Queen Elizabeth II marked Christmas in a third dimension. Speaking from London, the queen videotaped her traditional holiday address to the British public in 3-D, and even donned 3-D glasses to watch it from Buckingham Palace. In the annual remarks, which she writes herself, the queen paid tribute to servicemen and women whose sense of duty takes them away from family and friends over the holidays, and highlighted a year that included the 60th anniversary of her reign and the London Olympic Games, The Associated Press reported.

title: A Mass Holiday Homecoming Saddles a Rural Irish Town
description: RATHKEALE, Ireland  Christmas in Ireland is a time of homecomings, with joyous family reunions at airports and ferry piers. But the largest single gathering of all briefly turns this little town into the only place in Ireland where armed police officers patrol the streets 24 hours a day to deter internecine feuds and other disorderly conduct.

title: In Hopes of Healthier Chickens, Farms Turn to Oregano
description: FREDERICKSBURG, Pa.  The smell of oregano wafting from Scott Sechlers office is so strong that anyone visiting Bell & Evans these days could be forgiven for wondering whether Mr. Sechler has forsaken the production of chicken and gone into pizza.

title: From the 17th Century, Gleeful Jinks Aplenty, More Low Than High
description: How do you hold an audience of the young and hip captive, let alone keep them laughing, wolf-whistling and hooting with delight through a three-and-a-half-hour evening fashioned from the dusty bones of 17th-century popular theater? Ed Sylvanus Iskanders raucous production of Amy Freeds anachronism-flaunting Restoration Comedy at the Flea Theater answers that question.

title: Its Not Just a Job; Its a Musical
description: The song Millwork, a haunting slice of blue-collar melancholia, has been recorded by its composer, James Taylor, and covered by artists from Emmylou Harris to Eddie Vedder, Bruce Springsteen to Bette Midler. But as performed with a gorgeous sorrowful twang by Marie-France Arcilla in Working: A Musical, at 59E59 Theaters, this evocative ballad belongs unequivocally to the woman standing before us: a mother of three who toils as an assembly-line steam-press operator in a luggage factory, reflecting on her wasted life.

title: Heart Disease in Military Shows Steep Drop Since Korean War
description: A new study shows that the rate of American service members with signs of coronary artery disease has declined sharply in the last half century, falling to roughly 1 in 10 military personnel today from about 8 in 10 during the Korean War.

title: Ever Independent, Lieberman Moves On, Calling Partisan Fighting a Cancer
description: WASHINGTON  There was Joseph I. Lieberman, in the midst of his extended farewell tour of interviews, speeches and personal appearances (This feels like the Last Waltz of the Band, he said), talking about how much people have hated him.

title: Google Apps Challenging Microsoft in Business
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It has taken years, but Google seems to be cutting into Microsofts stronghold  businesses.

title: Modern Dance Groups to Get Hurricane Sandy Aid
description: Among the huge outpouring of relief for damages from Hurricane Sandy nearly two months after it hit, a modest effort is on the horizon for the shoestring but vibrant world of modern dance in New York City. Starting in early January checks from $1,000 to $5,000 will go out to companies, choreographers and theaters knocked back on their heels by the destruction and flooding.

title: Pats on the Back, and a Nod to Artistic Versatility
description: The annual Kennedy Center Honors are always a heartening reminder that amid the din of day-to-day pop culture, real and enduring artistic achievement is taking place, even if we forget to notice. But the 35th installment of the awards, which will be broadcast Wednesday night on CBS, is particularly satisfying, a delicious mix of highbrow and not so highbrow, beginning with a man who memorably dressed as a woman and ending with a rock n roll symphony.

title: Extraordinary Actors Ennobling the Ordinary
description: Youve heard and probably used the phrase perfectly ordinary in various contexts. Today consider it in a new one: as an excellent description of what Jack Klugman and Charles Durning did so very, very well.

title: After Storm, Moving to Update a Mall at the South Street Seaport
description: Nearly two months after Hurricane Sandy devastated the South Street Seaport on the East River in Lower Manhattan, Dumpsters still line its cobblestone streets and nearly all of the stores west of Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive remain closed.

title: Nick J. Romito
description: Mr. Romito, 30, is the founder and chief executive of View the Space, a new real estate technology business that creates online video tours, primarily of office space, and provides data-tracking services to commercial real estate companies, among them SL Green Realty, Vornado Realty Trust and Silverstein Properties.

title: Voice of Calm in Debate on Guns
description: In Living With Guns Craig R. Whitney, a former correspondent and editor for The New York Times, writes that he is motivated by the belief that Americans on both sides of the debate about guns can and must find common ground. He hopes to defuse the prevailing hysteria by establishing that both sides are correct in at least one fundamental assertion.

title: Iran Suggests Attacks on Computer Systems Came From the U.S. and Israel
description: Iran reported a number of new cyberattacks on Tuesday, saying foreign enemy hackers tried in recent months to disrupt computer systems at a power plant and other industries in a strategically important southern coastal province as well as at a Culture Ministry information center.

title: The View from Alabama: Saban Delivers Again
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  The University of Alabamas football program reached a fork in the road after the 2006 season.

title: Concerns About the Safety of Drilling
description: To the Editor:

title: After the Airport Closes
description: Developments on the sites of decommissioned airports are being closely watched, as growing demand for air travel puts pressure on other urban airports with little space to grow.

title: Idled City Airports Are Finding a Second Life as Housing
description: DENVER  When excavators digging on the land that was formerly Denvers Stapleton Airport unearthed an old Cessna, J. W. Duff, the 86-year-old owner of the J. W. Duff Aircraft Company was not surprised. Lots of planes were disposed of by burial when the airport was still in operation, Mr. Duff said. Finding something unexpected is just one of the many challenges of turning idled airports into something else.

title: Hotel Review: Andaz Shanghai
description: UPSHOT

title: In Toronto, a Locavores Life Made Easy
description: FOR some, the term locavore has gone from revolutionary to groan-worthy, conjuring images of holier-than-thou elites with the means to worry about not just where, but by whom, their cheese is made. And yet, as easy as it might be to dismiss eating from harvests no more than 100 miles from home as a lark of the privileged, the movement is still gaining converts.

title: Sometimes the Instruments Upstage the Instrumentalists
description: Even people barely aware of classical music have heard of Strads. The stringed instruments made by Antonio Stradivari and his family, part of a trailblazing group of 17th- and 18th-century Italian luthiers, are more famous than most of the works played on them.

title: The True Meaning of an N.B.A. Feast
description: Eighteen grueling years as a professional basketball player and Jerry Stackhouse was slipping into uniform, color-coordinated sneakers included, for the first time on Christmas Day. A benefit of having never held down a roster spot on one of the chosen holiday elite has been quality family time at home, nestled comfortably in front of expanding television screens.

title: Fiscal Cutoff Would Pinch at First, Then Get Steadily Worse
description: Quick action by President Obama and Congress could still help the economy escape the full impact of hundreds of billions in tax increases and automatic spending cuts set to take effect shortly after the last minutes of 2012 tick away next week. But if the deadlock in Washington persists much longer than a few weeks, the consequences will quickly mount, economists warn.

title: In Race Around World, Boat Relies on the Power of Wind, Water and Sun
description: Bernard Moitessier of France surprised the sailing world by peeling away from the first solo, nonstop, around-the-world race when he was on the cusp of finishing in 1969. He said in his reports to passing ships that he had found enlightenment on the high seas. He continued to go two-thirds of the way around the globe before landing in the South Pacific because he could.

title: Downtown, Before the Gentry Moved In
description: For some of us its still a bit of a shock to encounter a Whole Foods on the corner of Bowery and Houston Street with a sign outside that reads, Bowery Self-Serve Cookie Bar: Because Its Been That Kind of Day. For more than a century, after all, and until very recently, the Bowery was known for trafficking in substances considerably stronger than cookies.

title: No Shushes Amid Joy And Pride In the Youth
description: The modern shunning of applause between movements is one of the more tired and unnatural conventions of the classical music world, Vivien Schweitzer rightly observed in a recent concert review in The New York Times.

title: The TV Watch Abroad
description: Alessandra Stanley, the chief television critic of The New York Times, is going abroad to watch foreign television this year.

title: On Indian TV, I Do Means to Honor and Obey the Mother-in-Law
description: MUMBAI, India  Mothers-in-law are not a joke on Indian TV.

title: To Reach Younger Buyers, Vintners Think Outside the Bottle
description: PERSUADING consumers to drink anything other than bottled wine is an uphill climb. Glass bottles are the gold standard, so newer brands are turning to sleek, eco-friendly containers and promoting them through social media to reach younger wine drinkers.

title: Remembrance of Passions (and Follies) Lost
description: The word melancholy occurs several times in Tabu, Miguel Gomess odd and sometimes entrancing new film, memorably at the beginning, where it is used (in a voice-over) to describe a Portuguese explorer making his wistful way through the wilds of Africa, haunted by ghosts and threatened by crocodiles. This poor, intrepid soul is a character in a movie that is watched by Pilar (Teresa Madruga), a middle-aged single woman living in modern Lisbon. Her unadventurous, middle-class euro zone existence is melancholy in its own way. Like the explorer, Pilar is filmed in narrow-screen black-and-white, which casts a glow of nostalgic mystery over her everyday dealings with friends and neighbors.

title: Why, God?
description: WASHINGTON

title: Japans Population
description: To the Editor:

title: How Can We Best Measure College Success?
description: To the Editor:

title: Credit Range
description: FICO provides the credit scores of roughly 200 million Americans.

title: Giving Siblings an Edge
description: To the Editor:

title: Media Coverage of Killings
description: To the Editor:

title: Lincoln Center, 1:31 P.M.
description: The Big Apple Circus performed at Lincoln Center on Christmas.

title: Bahrain, a Brutal Ally
description: Isa Town, Bahrain

title: Our Failed Approach to Schizophrenia
description: Washington

title: Fraud in Preschool Special Education
description: Over the last several months, the New York State comptrollers office has painted a damning portrait of fraud and malfeasance in the program that spends $2 billion a year on special education for preschool children with learning, developmental and other disabilities. The comptrollers latest audit points squarely at the states Education Department, which clearly needs to do a better job of overseeing this troubled program. But the Legislature, too, has a role to play in rooting out fraud.

title: Asleep at the Wheel: Bad Luck, or a Crime?
Intentional Bias in North Carolina
description: A North Carolina trial judge recently resentenced three death-row inmates to life without parole under the states Racial Justice Act, which allows inmates to have their sentences reduced if it can be shown they were tainted by racial bias. In the trials of two blacks and one Lumbee Indian, the judge found powerful evidenceof such bias.

title: Give Chuck a Chance
description: In case you havent heard, President Obama is considering appointing Chuck Hagel, a former United States senator from Nebraska and a Purple Heart winner, as the next secretary of defense  and this has triggered a minifirefight among Hagel critics and supporters. I am a Hagel supporter. I think he would make a fine secretary of defense  precisely because some of his views are not mainstream. I find the opposition to him falling into two baskets: the disgusting and the philosophical. It is vital to look at both to appreciate why Hagel would be a good fit for Defense at this time.

title: Stop Subsidizing Obesity
description: Not long ago few doctors  not even pediatricians  concerned themselves much with nutrition. This has changed, and dramatically: As childhood obesity gains recognition as a true health crisis, more and more doctors are publicly expressing alarm at the impact the standard American diet is having on health.

title: Russias Desire for Cars Grows, and Foreign Makers Take Notice
description: NIZHNY NOVGOROD, Russia  Sleek and glistening, the General Motors sedans creep off the assembly line here. They are as new as cars can get. And so is the assembly line, where the first test cars emerged this month.

title: Nowadays, Odd Couple Would Have to Be Rich Couple, Too
description: The Odd Couple, a beloved sitcom that ran for five years beginning in 1970, just lost its other half. Jack Klugman, the cleanliness-challenged sportswriter Oscar Madison, died at age 90 on Monday, never again to infuriate his fictional and anal-retentive roommate, a photographer named Felix Unger, played by Tony Randall, who died in 2004.

title: Obama to Leave Hawaiian Vacation Early to Work on Fiscal Deal
description: KAILUA, Hawaii  President Obama is planning to cut his Christmas vacation short and return to Washington to make a last-ditch push for a compromise on a tax and spending dispute that remains stubbornly unresolved.

title: One Illness After Another, and an Eviction Looming
description: As the water surged through the basement apartment of a Coney Island town house during Hurricane Sandy, Jeffrey Cowen, a cherubic and chatty sort, tried to calm down the two tenants who had remained with him in the building.

title: Transactions
description: Recent Sale

title: Updating Manns Status From Stuffy to Chatty
description: LBECK, Germany  The latest sensation from the literary lion Thomas Mann is more than a century old and runs over 500 characters, not pages, long.

title: Colonel Wilders Lightning Brigade
description: Newly promoted rebel brigadier general John Hunt Morgan set out on a cavalry raid into Kentucky on Dec. 22, 1862. His objective: the railroad between Nashville and Cincinnati, the primary supply line for Gen. William Rosecranss Army of the Cumberland. Rosecrans was getting ready to move his 44,000 men against the 38,000 soldiers under Gen. Braxton Bragg, based in Murfreesboro, just 26 miles from Nashville. The Federal general didnt have enough cavalry to simultaneously support a movement on Bragg and a hunt for Morgans 3,000 raiders, but he could ill afford to let supply disruptions threaten his attack plans: President Lincoln was growing impatient for results.

title: The Dawning of Domestic Drones
description: The drones are coming to a neighborhood near you.

title: Immigration and Policing
description: The Obama administration on Friday announced a policy change that  if it works  should lead to smarter enforcement of the immigration laws, with greater effort spent on deporting dangerous felons and less on minor offenders who pose no threat.

title: First Fighting Islamists, Now the Free Market
description: CAIRO  Hamdeen Sabahi was the most popular leader in the fight against Egypts new Islamist-backed constitution. Now he is preparing for his next battle: against Islamist leaders plans for Western-style free-market reforms.

title: Perfect 10? Never Mind That. Ask Her for Her Credit Score.
description: As she nibbled on strawberry shortcake, Jessica LaShawn, a flight attendant from Chicago, tried not to get ahead of herself and imagine this first date turning into another and another, and maybe, at some point, a glimmering diamond ring and happily ever after.

title: City in North Is Captured, Syrian Rebels Announce
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Rebel fighters in Syria said they had taken control of a strategic town on the Turkish border on Tuesday, and the international envoy to Syria said in Damascus that he had yet to receive any response from President Bashar al-Assad to proposals he delivered to halt the countrys deepening war.

title: Coming Back: Under New Management
description: L+M Development Partners has its work cut out for it as it starts renovations on Ocean Village, a long-neglected low-income housing development on the Rockaway Peninsula.

title: A New Owner and, Many Hope, a New Lease on Life
description: There is a sparkling view of the now-docile Atlantic Ocean from the window of an apartment on the 19th floor of Building 2 of Ocean Village, an eyesore of a low-income housing complex in the Arverne section of the Rockaway Peninsula. Turn around, and the view is far less lovely. The apartment is empty, one of about 350 vacant units in the disheveled towers, its kitchen uprooted and walls smudged with grime.

title: A German Resurgence, Feet First
description: GELSENKIRCHEN, Germany  The resurgence of German soccer began, like the countrys economic comeback, after a long slide toward stagnation amid dire prophecies of impending irrelevance.

title: Chinese Officials Find Misbehavior Now Carries Cost
description: BEIJING  The Chinese have become largely inured to tales of voracious officials stockpiling luxury apartments, $30,000 Swiss watches or enough stolen cash to buy their mistress a Porsche.

title: Charles Durning, Versatile Actor, Dies
description: Charles Durning, who was an acclaimed character actor in Cat on a Hot Tin Roof and Tootsie, died on Dec. 24.

title: Nash Helps Lakers Get Back at Knicks
description: LOS ANGELES  All the Lakers have wanted for weeks was their team back, and here it was, just in time for Tuesdays high-profile rematch against the Knicks.

title: Corrections: December 26, 2012
Catholic Schools Open Doors to Storm-Tossed Students
description: The scene at St. Patrick School in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, seemed no different from that at any other parochial school: Students stood bright-eyed and fidgety in choirlike rows around the auditorium stage, rehearsing carols for an annual Christmas pageant.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Dec. 26, 2012
description: I just figured, the oil field is here and Id make the money while I could. I didnt want to waste the money and go to school when I could make just as much.

title: Legal Curbs Said to Hamper A.T.F. in Gun Inquiries
description: MARTINSBURG, W.Va.  The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives has been without a permanent director for six years, as President Obama recently noted. But even if someone were to be confirmed for the job, the agencys ability to thwart gun violence is hamstrung by legislative restrictions and by loopholes in federal gun laws, many law enforcement officials and advocates of tighter gun regulations say.

title: Egocentric Persons Mantra
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Writers in general tend to be a self-involved bunch, but Dan Schoenholz takes the cake. His puzzle is all about himself. Or rather, ME. No, not me ME. Him ME. Stay with me on this.

title: A Finals Reunion Comes Out the Same
description: MIAMI  A decade and a half has passed since the N.B.A. finals have featured the same matchup for two straight years.

title: Richard Baum, 72, Dies; Connected China Watchers on the Web
description: Richard Baum, who presided over Chinapol, an online discussion group about China that has become an essential forum for many experts, diplomats and journalists, died Dec. 14 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 72.

title: Lottery Numbers
Pay in Oil Fields Is Luring Youths in Montana
description: SIDNEY, Mont.  For most high school seniors, a college degree is the surest path to a decent job and a stable future. But here in oil country, some teenagers are choosing the oil fields over universities, forgoing higher education for jobs with salaries that can start at $50,000 a year.

title: Los Angeles Weighs Law Banning Elephant Shows
description: LOS ANGELES  The Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus train has been bringing four-ton Asian elephants to this city since 1919.

title: Fired, but Firing Back, Over Dealings in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  Eric W. Paynes world has shrunk. The man who oversaw millions of dollars in city contracts today watches every dime in his family budget. He has not worked full time since 2009. He and his family were evicted last summer, and now their lives spill from boxes in a cramped town house in suburban Virginia.

title: Study Finds Modest Declines in Obesity Rates Among Young Children From Poor Families
description: A new national study has found modest declines in obesity among 2- to 4-year-olds from poor families, a dip that researchers say may indicate that the obesity epidemic has passed its peak among this group.

title: For Akaka, a Senate Role as No. 1 on the Roll
description: WASHINGTON  It is a name that has echoed prominently through the Senate for years, even though most Americans know very little about the person himself.

title: Facade of Manhattan Luxury Building Collapses
description: Any holiday celebrating in the luxury apartments in the ONeill Building in Manhattan came to an abrupt end on Tuesday night when the buildings facade collapsed and it was evacuated, Fire Department officials said.

title: N.B.A. Replay: Dec. 25
description: The Celtics pounded the Nets, the Lakers stopped the Knicks and the Heat survived the Thunder.

title: Japans Premier Resigns, Making Way for a Predecessor
description: TOKYO  Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda resigned Wednesday ahead of a vote in Parliament to return former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to power, ending the countrys three-year break from decades of near-constant rule by the conservative Liberal Democratic Party.

title: Exercise and the Ever-Smarter Human Brain
description: Anyone whose resolve to exercise in 2013 is a bit shaky might want to consider an emerging scientific view of human evolution. It suggests that we are clever today in part because a million years ago, we could outrun and outwalk most other mammals over long distances. Our brains were shaped and sharpened by movement, the idea goes, and we continue to require regular physical activity in order for our brains to function optimally.

title: Buy, Sell, Adopt: Child Trafficking in China
description: HONG KONG  In announcing the rescue of 89 abducted Chinese children on Christmas Eve, a senior police official said baby boys could now be purchased in Chinas interior for less than $5,000  and then resold for three times that amount in the wealthier coastal provinces.

title: A German Resurgence, Feet First
description: Nicholas Kulish writes in Wednesdays Times about the revival of German soccer, both on the field and on the balance sheet, in recent years, and about what the changes might mean for the countrys prospects in the game in the future.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 3 Afghans by U.S. Base
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber killed three Afghans on Wednesday in an unsuccessful attempt to enter an American military base in eastern Afghanistan, American and Afghan officials said.

title: Ex-Premier Is Chosen to Govern Japan Again
description: TOKYO  Parliament formally elected Shinzo Abe as prime minister on Wednesday, ending a three-year break from decades of near-constant rule by his conservative Liberal Democratic Party.

title: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 26
description: NEWS The Tea Party might not be over, but its increasingly clear that the U.S. election last month significantly weakened the movement, which had nearly captured control of the Republican Party through a potent combination of populism and fury. Trip Gabriel reports.

title: China Opens Longest High-Speed Rail Line
description: HONG KONG  China began service Wednesday morning on the worlds longest high-speed rail line, covering a distance in eight hours that is about equal to that from New York to Key West, Fla., or from London across Europe to Belgrade, Serbia.

title: Sachin Was Us, and We Were Sachin
description: If love is defined by that which gives without expecting anything in return, then I guess we love our cricketers.

title: The Images of 2012: Sports
description: The year started triumphantly for New York sports fans as the Giants won Super Bowl XLVI with a narrow last-minute victory over the New England Patriots. In addition, the Nets moved to Brooklyn and returned major professional sports to the land the Dodgers had forsaken.

title: A Budget for Regulation
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: Week 17 N.F.L. Game Probabilities and Motivations
description: Week 17 can be a tough one for predicting N.F.L. games. Some teams have playoff futures on the line, or at least a significant seeding advantage, and they may face teams with nothing to play for. This can create mismatched motivation levels and personnel decisions for which a purely mathematical model cannot account.

title: The Gypsies Dance
description: MADRID  The Seville-born Spanish choreographer and dancer Israel Galvn looks unprepossessing: trim and lithe, his beard flecked with gray. Yet his style is explosively eclectic. From taut whirls and arching leaps he snaps into angular poses and syncopated glides.

title: From a Tiny Projector, a Big Picture
description: As consumers switch from laptops to tablets and smartphones, the makers of projectors are adapting.

title: Russian Measure Banning Adoptions by American Citizens Is Sent to Putin
description: MOSCOW  The upper chamber of Parliament on Wednesday unanimously approved a bill to ban adoptions of Russian children by United States citizens, sending the measure to President Vladimir V. Putin, who has expressed support but not yet said if he will sign it.

title: A Vote for Pete Carroll as Coach of the Year
description: Morning links for your consideration:

title: Tip of the Week: Start Menu Alternatives for Windows 8
description: The new interface of Microsofts Windows 8 operating system may be disorienting at first for those who have spent years automatically heading toward the Start menu. While the new Windows 8 Start screen is a colorful alternative for displaying frequently used programs, widgets and apps, it may not appeal as much to people who favor things in lists, or who are not using a touch-screen computer.

title: Dance the Smartphone Tango Without Me
description: I havent got a smartphone. I dont even have a cellphone.

title: Love, Ages Apart
description: GOOD and great directing can appear self-evident. You know it when you see it even if it can be hard to explain what exactly youre seeing. As Andrew Sarris wrote in The American Cinema, his magnificent, sublimely eccentric taxonomy of good, bad and fringe directors, direction is a relatively mysterious, not to say mystical, concept of creation. He dedicated the next few hundred pages of his landmark book to help unravel that mystery.

title: Spielbergian, on a Budget
description: MY two favorite American movies of 2012 were Lincoln and Beasts of the Southern Wild, a big shiny Hollywood apple and a sweet little Sundance orange, with, at least at first glance, nothing much in common. If you were so inclined, you could plot these two films at opposite ends of the spectrum that currently defines American cinema, where the very big movies cluster at one end, the very small at another, with less and less in the middle.

title: Welcome to the Friars Club
description: Dear Diary:

title: Game Theory: A Playwright on the Art of Video Games
description: So its the end of 2012, and it feels like gaming is pushing through its creative adolescence. There are glimpses of what it might become. Thus, for games to take their rightful place among other creative works its important to ask what they do that other forms cannot.

title: Getting the Dirt on Hurricane Sandy
description: On Oct. 29, waters from Hurricane Sandys 13-foot surge dredged up sediment from the citys waterways and sent it barreling through the streets and into basements and backyards. As the floods receded, residents of neighborhoods with toxic Superfund canals worried that waterborne chemicals had contaminated their homes, streets and parks, rendering them unsafe.

title: Daily Report: Google Moves Onto Microsofts Turf in Business Software
description: It has taken years, but Google seems to be cutting into Microsofts stronghold  businesses, reports Quentin Hardy in Wednesdays New York Times.

title: Wednesday Reading: Renting Your Own Private Ski Resort
This Year in Small Business: Not Impressed!
description: Another year of The Dashboard is behind us, and its time to look back at our favorite comments, blogs, opinions and videos of 2012, the ones that had the biggest impact on small-business owners. Enjoy.

title: Capital-biased Technological Progress: An Example (Wonkish)
description: Ever since I posted about robots and the distribution of income, Ive had queries from readers about what capital-biased technological change  the kind of change that could make society richer but workers poorer really means. And it occurred to me that it might be useful to offer a simple conceptual example  the kind of thing easily turned into a numerical example as well  to clarify the possibility. So here goes.

title: The Best in Mens
description: The roundup of our favorite stories of 2012 in mens fashion. See interactive feature >>

title: Dan Stevens Has Something to Say About Downton Abbey
description: Be forewarned that this post deals with developments on Downton Abbey that British viewers are now aware of, but which have not yet occurred in the American broadcast of that series. In other words, major spoilers ahead.

title: Christmas After Sandy
description: In Red Hook, Brooklyn, congregants attended Christmas Mass at Visitation Church, which has experienced a resurgence since Hurricane Sandy.

title: Leading Off: The Great Christmas Dilemma
description: To walk around New York, or any city, on Christmas is to understand the joy of a little quiet. The consumerism-run-amok atmosphere of the buying season takes a well-earned pause, all but a few stores resting in their iron gate cocoons. People wander around just walking; not shopping, just walking. O.K., that part may be unique to New York.

title: Dennis Lehane Offers Literary Reward for Missing Dog
description: When a character goes missing in a Dennis Lehane novel, usually nothing good results. But Mr. Lehane, the author of best-selling novels like Mystic River and Gone Baby Gone, is trying to make the best of the disappearance of a beloved dog, and is offering an unusual reward to the person who helps return her: he said he would name a character after that person in a coming novel.

title: Protecting Freedom(Works)
description: OK, the story of the fight at FreedomWorks  which ended with Dick Armey being sent away with a $8 million severance package  is getting even more bizarre. From the WaPo:

title: Grace Notes, Far From Hollywood
description: Bestiaire

title: Is Growth Over?
description: Its taken me a while to get around to Bob Gordons stimulating essay suggesting that the great days of economic growth are behind us. Its not that different from things hes been saying before, and I have in the past had a lot of sympathy for that view. I now believe, however, that his technological pessimism is wrong  or if you prefer, its the wrong kind of pessimism. But this is definitely a discussion worth having.

title: In the Company of Captain Cook
description: A young boy conscripted aboard a ship of seasoned sailors. A journey to faraway lands in an uncharted world. A tale of cannibals and exotic creatures and devastating illness. This could be the makings of the latest young adult action thriller. Instead its a strikingly illustrated picture book for older readers, piquantly evocative of centuries-old historical events.

title: An Early Tale of the Internet
description: Last Friday I interviewed Peter E. Hart, an electrical engineer who was an early artificial intelligence researcher, about one of the first robots, a machine named Shakey that was designed at SRI International beginning in 1966. SRI was one of the laboratories from which many personal computing and networking technologies were first developed.

title: In Speaker Dock, a Minimalist Home for the iPhone 5
description: Capitalizing on the sudden need for iPhone 5 docking stations, Harman has released the JBL OnBeat Micro speaker dock that features the must-have Apple Lightning connector.

title: Consequences of a Political Deadlock
description: TimesCast: Fiscal impasse adds to economic anxiety. | At Jerusalems Western Wall, women fight against ultra-Orthodox beliefs. | Christmas after Hurricane Sandy in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

title: These Worlds Take a Lot of Work
description: A CREW of hundreds came together to create the locations for Peter Jacksons Hobbit trio of prequels to his Lord of the Rings movies. Some of the artists who brought their expertise to Rings are back. Dan Hennah, who won an Oscar for set decoration in Return of the King, served as the production designer on the new films. And Joe Letteri, whose work at Weta Digital gave form and texture to the character Gollum, has returned to Middle-earth, now with a more advanced set of technological tools at his disposal.

title: The End of Spider-Man (at Least for Now)
description: Comic book fans who pick up Issue No. 700 of The Amazing Spider-Man, which arrived in stores on Wednesday, will see what Marvel Comics is promising as the final fight between Spider-Man and his longtime nemesis Dr. Octopus. The end result has the villain taking over the heros mind, body, costume and mission. Dr. Octopus, who is convinced he can do a better job than Peter Parkers alter ego, begins his adventures as the wall-crawling hero in The Superior Spider-Man, the first issue of which will be available Jan. 9.

title: Reminder: Campaign Finance Donor Search Will Be Deprecated
description: If youre a regular user of the presidential donor information returned by our Campaign Finance API, dont forget: that request type will be deprecated this Friday, Dec. 28. We wont be creating a new version; were removing the data from our servers completely. Please update your code, and leave a comment if you have questions or concerns.

title: Storm Weakened a Fragile System for Mental Care
description: When a young woman in the grip of paranoid delusions threatened a neighbor with a meat cleaver one Saturday last month, the police took her by ambulance to the nearest psychiatric emergency room. Or rather, they took her to Beth Israel Medical Center, the only comprehensive psychiatric E.R. functioning in Lower Manhattan since Hurricane Sandy shrank and strained New Yorks mental health resources.

title: Even in a Lockout Year, Rangers Raise a Banner
description: The N.H.L. lockout has derailed a lot of plans, like teams celebrating last seasons accomplishments at their home openers.

title: Crowdfunding Rules Are Unlikely to Meet Deadline
description: When the Jobs Act became law in April, supporters proclaimed a new era for small businesses seeking to raise money.

title: Image of the Day: Dec. 26
RocketHub Ponders Its Future in Crowdfunding
description: We have published a story about why the Securities and Exchange Commission has struggled to write the rules that will carry out equity crowdfunding for small businesses. One company that has been at the forefront of the effort to influence those rules is RocketHub, a donation- and rewards-based crowdfunding site based in New York. Itself a small business, RocketHub debuted in 2010 and now has about 10 employees, including its four founders  but is still viewed as one of the largest American crowdfunding platforms.

title: Your Best Meal of 2012, New York Edition
description: We asked you to tweet your favorite meal of the year using the hashtag #bestmeal2012, and received so many responses that weve split the highlights into two categories to feature here on Diners Journal. First up are New York City places, some of which youll also find on Pete Wellss list of the best new restaurants of the year. Restaurants that are further afield will be gathering in a post this afternoon. Tell us your #bestmeal2012 by tweeting us at @nytdining.

title: Video: A Red Hook Church Rebounds After Hurricane
description: In Red Hook, Brooklyn, people attended Christmas Mass at Visitation Church, which has experienced a resurgence since Hurricane Sandy.

title: Syrian General Whose Task Was Halting Defections Flees
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrias government suffered an embarrassing new setback as the top general responsible for preventing defections within the military became a defector himself, making what insurgents described on Wednesday as a daring back-roads escape by motorcycle across the border into Turkey.

title: Exploring the Roots of an Emerging Planet-Spanning Mind
description: Im grateful to Krista Tippett, the host of the captivating public radio program On Being, for including me in an exploration of the present-day resonance of noosphere, the concept of anemerging global intelligenceshaped in the early 20th century by Pierre Teilhard de Chardin, a French Jesuit priest, philosopher and paleontologist (with others). You can read two of Teilhards most influential books touching on this concept  The Phenomenon of Man and The Future of Man  online.

title: Every Bird Counts, but Some Make the Heart Beat Faster
description: Binoculars at the ready, a small group of birders fanned out through the field, searching for a brown-and-gray bird that was stubbornly refusing to show itself.

title: Senator Daniel K. Akaka in the Roll Call
description: Senator Daniel K. Akaka's name can be heard in the roll call vote for the Affordable Care Act.

title: Senator Daniel K. Akaka
description: Senator Daniel K. Akakas name can be heard in the roll call for a vote to authorize the use of United States military force against Iraq in October 2002.

title: Nine Ski Apps to Make the Most of the Mountain
description: Headed to the mountains for the holidays? Here are nine ski-friendly apps that will help you make the most of your trip.

title: Only Known Leo Motorcycle to Be Auctioned
description: LAS VEGAS  The recent discovery of the only known example of a Leo motorcycle, which is scheduled to be auctioned here Jan. 10 by Bonhams, raises more questions than answers.

title: Grim Prognosis for a 60-Ton Whale Stranded on a Beach in Queens
description: Updated, 12:56 p.m. Thursday | The whale has died. See latest post.

title: When Going Solo Is Not the Goal
description: A NEWSPAPER. Gum. A bottle of water.

title: Author of Twitter Account Isnt Philip Roth
description: 12:33 p.m. | Updated

title: Catching the Sights, Not the Bugs
description: Friends and family so often asked Dr. Charles E. Davis, a specialist in microbiology and infectious disease, how to avoid getting sick when they travel abroad, he decided to put all of his advice in one place. The result is The International Travelers Guide to Avoiding Infections, released this year by Johns Hopkins University Press. Below are edited excerpts with Dr. Davis in a discussion about precautions international travelers should take before and after trips to far-flung destinations.

title: In Soccer as in Life, Will a Resurgent Germany Dominate a Weakened Europe?
description: Our colleague Nicholas Kulish has written a year-end sports piece sure to get folks thinking. The resurgence of German soccer began, like the countrys economic comeback, after a long slide toward stagnation amid dire prophecies of impending irrelevance, Nick writes.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 4 P.M. (AMC) CASINO (1995) Martin Scorsese directs this crime drama based on the nonfiction book by Nicholas Pileggi that follows Ace Rothstein (Robert De Niro), a gambling savant hired by the Mafia to run a casino in Las Vegas in the 1970s and to ensure that the bosses back home always receive a piece of the profits. His muscle is Nicky Santoro (Joe Pesci), whose criminal activities and proclivity for violence spiral out of control. Mr. Pileggi, Mr. De Niro and Mr. Pesci, all Goodfellas alumni, are back in familiar capacities, joining Mr. Scorsese to do what they do best, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. But, she added, Casino also has a new ingredient in Sharon Stone, above with Mr. De Niro, who will be nobodys idea of Hollywood fluff after this spectacular, emblematic performance. As Ginger McKenna, a gorgeous hustler who falls from the ranks of Vegass royalty to its lowest depths, she represents the full range of this films stark extremes. Ms. Stone, above with Mr. De Niro, received an Oscar nomination.

title: Senator Lieberman's Farewell
description: On the eve of his retirement, Senator Joseph Lieberman reflects on his political career and the proper role of bipartisanship.

title: Worried About Taxes, Some Consumers Cut Back
description: As time ticks away for a resolution to the so-called fiscal cliff mess, some consumers arent taking any chances.

title: Game Theory: Considering Video Games as Ballet
description: Like Lucy, when I write and think about video games, I try to focus on what the medium can do that the canonical arts  books, movies, theater, dance, music, television, painting, sculpture, comics, whatever  cannot. But I think its also worth emphasizing how video games resemble the culturally accepted arts. Theyre more alike than different. In 2012, I started reading a couple of books  one new, the other newish  about the history of other art forms, and their infancies would be very familiar to gamers.

title: Business Travelers in Haiti Will Have a New Marriott
description: Digicel, the telecommunications giant, and Marriott International recently broke ground on a $45 million hotel in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, that is to open in early 2015.

title: Sneaking Back, From Out of Nowhere
description: JEAN-LOUIS TRINTIGNANT has been, for better than half a century, one of the great stealth actors of the movies. He knows how to catch an audience unaware.

title: Fire Hits World Trade Center Construction Trailers
description: A fire at the World Trade Center construction site damaged three construction trailers on Wednesday but did not affect any buildings and injured no one, the authorities said.

title: Outcry Over Newspapers Map of Handgun Permit Holders
description: 8:45 p.m. | Updated In the days after the Connecticut school killings, a newspaper in nearby Westchester County, N.Y., decided to respond by publishing the names and addresses of handgun permit holders in its readership area. The newspaper, The Journal News, said that informing people about legal weapons in their neighborhoods was a public service.

title: No Questions on N.R.A. Plan, but Plenty of Comments
description: The National Rifle Association didnt take any questions at its news conference last Friday, announcing its National School Shield program to have armed guards in every school. But there were plenty of harsh words on Twitter, many from celebrities  even those not included in the Demand a Plan video that has gotten millions of YouTube views.

title: How to Read Like a Staff Writer Who Writes About Everything
description: Susan Dominus recently wrote for the magazine about dieting in France, a mysterious case of twitching teens and the woman who took the fall for JPMorgan Chase.

title: Senators to Return With 5 Days Left and No Clear Fiscal Path
description: WASHINGTON  With just five days left to make a deal, President Obama and members of the Senate were set to return to Washington on Thursday with no clear path out of their fiscal morass even as the Treasury Department warned that the government will soon be unable to pay its bills unless Congress acts.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Protecting Medical Records and Santas Naughty List
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: How Much Is That Pop Star in the Window?
description: An older singing star, past her prime, walks into an empty, down-home radio station, the place where it all began. The janitor assumes shes just another visitor. She reflects on how she got her start, became a star and lost something along the way.

title: Quirks of the Game: N.B.A. Schedule Short-Circuits Rivalries
