description: When the Knicks beat the Brooklyn Nets, 100-97, on Dec. 11 on a Jason Kidd 3-pointer it seemed like the battle for the city had just gone up a notch. The N.B.A. has to be loving this, Knicks Coach Mike Woodson said after the game.

title: In Performance: Brandon J. Dirden
description: Brandon J. Dirden as Boy Willie in the Signature Theaters revival of August Wilsons Piano Lesson.

title: New Years in Times Square Goes Digital
description: TimesCast Media+Tech: Song apps to keep the party going. | A conversation with Allures 85-year-old plastic surgery editor, Joan Kron. | A look at the social media tied to the ball drop.

title: Potent Winter Storm Moves East After Pouncing on Wide Area of the Country
description: A powerful winter storm that spawned tornadoes in the Deep South and brought Christmas Day snow to Dallas moved east on Wednesday, bringing blizzard conditions in Indiana and Ohio, severe thunderstorms to the Southeast and snow, driving rain, high winds and travel snarls to the Northeast.

title: Car Buyers Lack Interest in Electric Cars, Study Says
description: Mainstream car shoppers are simultaneously ignorant and apathetic about plug-in electric vehicles. Thats the essential finding of a new study from the Indiana University School of Public and Environmental Affairs. The study, which is based on a survey of 2,300 adult drivers in 21 large American cities in fall 2011, is a snapshot of driver sentiment 18 months ago.

title: NBCs Display of a 30-Shot Gun Magazine Prompts a Police Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  The Metropolitan Police Department said on Wednesday that it had opened an investigation into whether NBC and David Gregory, the host of Meet the Press, broke the law when Mr. Gregory displayed a high-capacity gun magazine during an interview on Sunday with the vice president of the National Rifle Association.

title: How the Cloud Changes Software Consulting
description: Moving to the cloud isnt just changing the way businesses work by adding more collaboration. It changes the consulting businesses that actually sell most of the software used by business.

title: Words Well Worth a Picture
Hidden Passions, Visible in Clothes
description: THE shock of infidelity among the aristocracy of 19th-century Russia was the theme of Tolstoys Anna Karenina. So while audacious, it makes a certain kind of sense that the director Joe Wrights film adaptation (written by Tom Stoppard) would be so willfully unfaithful to the book, let alone to the fashions of the day. Can you believe that Anna? Who does she think she is, flaunting about in all that Chanel jewelry before Coco was even born? Actually, what the lead characters wear in this telling has less to do with Cossack hats and astrakhan than with a style all its own  one based primarily in the extravagantly feminine lines of 1950s couture, reflecting a different period of promise. Think of Balenciaga, not Bolshoi

title: On Thursday, a Bowl Date; After That, Uncertainty
description: As the ball traced an arc toward the sideline, and the clock ticked down, college football seemed to hold its breath.

title: Scene City
description: A sold-out reunion party for Bar dO in New York City.

title: Carrying a Torch for Bar dO
description: ALL sorts of crazy things happen when the drag performer Joey Arias does a show. During much of the 1990s, Mr. Arias presided over a Weimar-esque show at Bar dO, a lounge on Bedford Street where he performed in various states of undress and seemed to channel Billie Holiday from beyond the grave.

title: Our Best Holiday Tech Gifts
description: 11:24 a.m. | Updated with more tech gifts.

title: The Gift of After-Hours Medical Care
description: A new study shows that people who have after-hours access to their doctor use the emergency room less.

title: Tiger Cubs on the Prowl in Russias Far East, and Elsewhere
description: The Wildlife Conservation Society is reporting that this year has seen significant progress in safeguarding tigers and some of their last havens in Russia, Thailand and India  three countries where the endangered species still has a solid base from which populations could expand if protections increase. The organization today released this image, taken by an automated camera last year in eastern Siberia.

title: Newly Released Books
description: In this months new novels, characters fight against significant barriers to emotional connection. A young woman falls in love with a suicidal quadriplegic, a troubled brother and sister build a secret life, and a bitter old man turns vampiric to put a spring back in his step.

title: Hedge Fund Seeks Ouster of SandRidge Energys Board
description: A New York hedge fund filed papers with federal securities regulators on Wednesday seeking to oust the board at SandRidge Energy, the latest salvo in its continuing campaign against the struggling Oklahoma City oil and gas company.

title: The Soundtrack to Your Life, With a Stream of Discoveries
description: Gone is the heyday of the vinyl record. The cassette tape is all but forgotten. Even the CD is losing its relevance; my children are amused by the idea that a little silver disc has music on it.

title: Pogie Awards for the Brightest Ideas of 2012
description: Good evening, and welcome to The Dalles, Ore.! Here in the cafetorium of the James A. Garfield Middle School, we meet every year for the biggest event in technology: the Pogie awards!

title: FreshDirect Goes Dark After a Domain Name Glitch
description: It was a blue Christmas for FreshDirect, the Long Island City-based company that delivers groceries to homes throughout New York City and its suburbs. For a significant chunk of the holiday, visitors to the companys Web site reported finding only a generic placeholder for sites whose domain names are out of date  or out of whack.

title: Compromising Dolls and Pink Panthers
description: A New Novel, the current exhibition at Luxembourg & Dayan gallery, is not for the squeamish. The upper floors of the gallerys town house on East 77th Street in Manhattan contain several dioramalike installations inhabited by stuffed doll figures who, to judge from all the pills and drug paraphernalia strewed around, have been on an extended binge.

title: Near Tokyo, a Minimalist House on a Mountain Slope
description: A two-bedroom crescent-shaped house outside Tokyo is on the market for $2.1 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Japan
description: MINIMALIST HOUSE WITH MOUNT FUJI VIEWS OUTSIDE TOKYO

title: Looking for Opportunity Where Few Others Invest
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  Investors started poking around for deals here five years ago, as the war-torn country began to move past its legacy of genocide and coups. When the global financial crisis struck, Cambodias fast-growing economy crashed and the dollars flowing from abroad evaporated.

title: Homes for $1.5 Million
description: Properties in Atlanta, New Hampshire and New Mexico.

title: What You Get for ... $1.5 Million
description: ATLANTA

title: CDs Know That Ears Have Eyes
description: MOST of us think we know where fine art roosts: museums, galleries, studios, maybe the stray subway car. But one of the more unexpected places to find striking, thought-provoking art, year in and year out, is on the album covers of ECM Records.

title: A Little Extra Power When You Need It
description: Smartphones are convenient, until they run out of power. To help provide an extra jolt of juice, MyCharge has introduced a line of rechargeable power banks that are compatible with a variety of devices.

title: Photo Replay: Dec. 26
description: A view of the day in sports, including Premier League soccer and cyclo-cross in Belgium.

title: Light Reading: How the Kindle Paperwhite Works
description: Amazon and Barnes & Noble added lighting systems to their newest readers, the Kindle Paperwhite and the Nook Simple Touch, to make it easier for people to read in the dark.

title: Tasting Fame Again, Tweet by Tweet
description: IN the 1990s, Sally Jessy Raphael was the doyenne of daytime television, a bespectacled redhead whose mild, auntish mien belied the sensational tabloid fodder that her syndicated talk show was built upon.

title: The Curator of the Brooklyn Look
description: THIS is probably the understatement of the year, but the time when the phrase Brooklyn look at best conjured Tony Maneros white pantsuit is long past. For one thing, the look is decidedly feminine. For another, its more about day-to-day coping and nesting than peacocklike display.

title: Pasolinis Legacy: A Sprawl of Brutality
description: It is only at our moment of death that our life, to that point undecipherable, ambiguous, suspended, acquires a meaning. So said the filmmaker Pier Paolo Pasolini in a 1967 interview. The idea that death defines a person has seldom been more vividly illustrated than in the case of Pasolini, whose extraordinary life and work are invariably seen through the prism of his gruesome end.

title: Her Story, Give or Take a Few Lines
description: IN her modernist Upper East Side co-op, Joan Kron talks enthusiastically about new ideas she has for Allure magazine, where she is an editor-at-large covering her chosen subject, plastic surgery. She wants to turn a couple into documentaries, a storytelling technique she picked up after recently auditing a film class. After a recent knee surgery, she looks forward to regularly climbing back into her favorite pair of black kitten-heeled Jimmy Choos.

title: Your Best Meals of 2012, International Edition
description: A few hours ago we published a selection of your #bestmeal2012 tweets that was limited to meals eaten in New York City. (Pete Wellss list of the best new restaurants in New York this year can be found here.) The tweets below name restaurants scattered far beyond the five boroughs.

title: Pictures of the Day: Nigeria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Nigeria, Syria and Mexico.

title: East of the East River, Room for Competition
description: Compared with a decade ago, when Bird largely flew solo, many upscale Brooklyn boutiques now compete for coveted brands.

title: Dynamic Former Netanyahu Aide Shifts Israeli Campaign Rightward
description: JERUSALEM  Naftali Bennett is not a serious contender to be Israels next prime minister. He has never held elective office, and the faction he represents currently fills five or seven of Parliaments 120 seats, depending on how you count.

title: A Widow Finds That Debt Is a Stubborn Companion
description: One song is about a man giving up cigarettes too late in life. Another consists of a teenager lying to her parents about the plot to My Friend Irma Goes West, a Martin and Lewis comedy, because she didnt go to the movies at all but has been in a parked car with her boyfriend. (Mom and Dad buy the lie.) And then there are lines like, No one absolves failure.

title: Coca Licensing Is a Weapon in Bolivias Drug War
description: TODOS SANTOS, Bolivia  There is nothing clandestine about Julin Rojass coca plot, which is tucked deep within acres of banana groves. It has been mapped with satellite imagery, cataloged in a government database, cross-referenced with his personal information and checked and rechecked by the local coca growers union. The same goes for the plots worked by Mr. Rojass neighbors and thousands of other farmers in this torrid region east of the Andes who are licensed by the Bolivian government to grow coca, the plant used to make cocaine.

title: Art Larsen, Quirky Tennis Champion, Dies at 87
description: Art Larsen, a national tennis champion whose career was marked by eccentricity and cut short by a motor scooter accident that nearly killed him, died on Dec. 7 in San Leandro, Calif. He was 87.

title: Improving Working Conditions at Foxconn
description: The Fair Labor Association assesses and monitors labor practices at manufacturing plants and recommends improvements. After Apple joined in January, the F.L.A. inspected three huge Foxconn factories in China that make iPads, iPhones and other devices. Inspectors identified 360 specific remediations to address a host of issues. In an August report, the F.L.A. said Foxconn had carried out 284 of those improvements.

title: Shimmer and Clatter and Howls and Grunts
description: When the New York Philharmonic introduced Contact!, a new and much-needed contemporary-music concert series, in December 2009, the initial thrust was on freshly composed works, largely by Americans. In subsequent seasons Contact! lost focus as older pieces and European composers came to dominate the mix, even if the reasons were understandable.

title: The Whole Nine Yards About a Phrases Origin
description: When people talk about the whole nine yards, just what are they talking about?

title: Toyota Agrees to Settle Lawsuit Tied to Accelerations
description: DETROIT  Toyota Motor agreed on Wednesday to pay more than $1 billion to settle a class-action lawsuit related to issues of unintended acceleration in its vehicles.

title: Daring With Makeup for New Years Eve
description: A few techniques to try to dazzle the holiday parties.

title: SportAccord World Mind Games in Beijing
description: On many bridge deals one side usually makes a mistake that benefits the opponents. But occasionally both sides play well, as in the diagramed deal from the individual event at the second SportAccord World Mind Games in Beijing this month. It was an excellent battle between West, Disa Eythorsdottir of Huntsville, Ala., and South, Nevena Senior from England.

title: A General Battles His Own Army
description: According to Fred Kaplans new book about Gen. David H. Petraeus and his attempt to re-envision American military strategy, the general had a philosophy about publicity. I have a Front Page of The Washington Post rule, he told attendees at a counterinsurgency field manual workshop in 2006. If you dont want to see something on the front page of The Washington Post, then dont do it, dont say it.

title: Bolivia Makes Inroads Toward Reducing Coca Production
description: The nation is trying a nontraditional approach to eradicating coca production without violence and without the United States.

title: In Italy, Shantytowns of Refugees Reflect Paradox on Asylum
description: ROME  The abandoned university building on the outskirts of Rome, colloquially known as Salaam Palace, was once a sparsely populated makeshift shelter where new arrivals from Africa  fleeing war, persecution and economic turmoil  squatted to create their own refuge.

title: Scouting Report
description: EVENTS

title: Shopping Snapshots: Dec. 27
description: Four questions for Colleen Sherin, the senior fashion director of Saks Fifth Avenue; Prism, a popular line of sunglasses and swimwear from London, has added handbags; some favorite essentials for a beach-side sojourn.

title: Tapping Into Parisian Luxury
description: Pierre-Yves Rochon originally designed the Perle faucet for the honeymoon suite at the Four Seasons Hotel Georges V in Paris (he was the interior designer who oversaw the propertys renovation). At a glance, it looks elegant but not particularly flashy. Then you notice the crystal droplets covering the faucets spout and handles. Rarely has so much bling been used without garish effect. I was thinking about how, when it rains, drops of water attach to glass on a window, Mr. Rochon said.

title: George Nelson Pieces Once Again Meet Their Market
description: By George, theyre back. So-called Miniature chests, designed for Herman Miller by George Nelson, were introduced in 1954. The dainty pieces, which rest on aluminum bases, stayed in production until 1963  a time when the company was abandoning residential furniture to focus on its office business. Miller has twice tried to revive the Japanese-inspired goods: once in 1994, when it reintroduced its home collection (they failed to sell), and again in 2005 (the chests were made in Asia, and the poor quality of the craftsmanship ultimately doomed the project). Bringing the chests back is one of my favorite examples of doing the right thing, said Ben Watson, creative director of Herman Miller, who is resurrecting a number of forgotten items from the companys archives. This time around, the chests are made in the United States and have the same hand-fitted drawers as the originals. They are available in a wide range of solid woods with white or black metal pulls. The six-drawer chest is $2,809, the nine-drawer chest, $3,192; the optional base, $418. Information: hermanmiller.com/collection or (616) 654-3000.

title: Making Anyone Feel Beautiful
description: YOU can sit down, you know, Veronica Webb told a model who was waiting to be photographed in a cardigan and T-shirt that Ms. Webb had designed. The outfit was part of her first fashion collection, which goes on sale today as an exclusive to the social shopping site OpenSky.

title: An Architectural Model Maker Is Happy to Shrink Your Home
description: Michael DelPriore of Ryerson Studio makes free-standing, eerily lifelike models of houses, commercial spaces and city parks. With computer programs like AutoCAD available, you might assume that physical models, built shingle by shingle, are pass. But Mr. DelPriore, 56, still does a brisk business, usually for architects, who use his little buildings in client presentations. Recently he opened his practice to commissions from the general public. Now anyone willing to spend upward of $10,000 can have a doll-size version of a real or imagined dream home. From his workplace in Kingston, N.Y., he spoke to a reporter about translating mansions into minis.

title: Clean Your Plate, if Only to Admire It
description: A new plate is helping to modify eating habits. Control plates, produced by Slim & Sage, are nine inches in diameter and designed with a pattern easily divided into quarters. Two of the quarters are for vegetables; the others for lean proteins and grains.

title: Why Isnt This Man Smiling?
description: A HALLMARK of pop art is taking a ubiquitous but overlooked totem of capitalist enterprise and reinventing it. Andy Warhol had the Campbells soup can. Claes Oldenburg had the lipstick tube. Nate Lowman, 33, has his: the smiley face.

title: A Shop That Frames a World of Embroidery
description: Coral & Tusk is a fantastical world of embroidery, with creatures and feathers stitched on napkins, pillows and even gift cards. The force behind the thread is Stephanie Housley, 37, a textile designer who started the company five years ago. I come from a long line of Appalachian women who did loads of hand work, she said. My grandma could make a doll or toy out of anything. There are plenty of dolls in this 1,200-square-foot space in South Williamsburg, Brooklyn. All began as Ms. Housleys hand drawings, which she scans, then redraws stitch by stitch in a computer file. The files are sent to India to be machine embroidered, but thanks to Ms. Housleys method, the finished goods are quirky, with perfectly imperfect stitching that makes each piece look hand-made. Prices range from $10 for a felt charm to $230 for a floor cushion. 109 South Fifth Street (Bedford Avenue), Room 401, Brooklyn; coralandtusk.com or (718) 388-4188.

title: All of ABC Carpet and Mxyplyzyk on Sale
description: Mxyplyzyk will close its doors at the end of this week, ending 22 years of supplying the West Village with decorative objects. The stores entire inventory will be up to 50 percent off through Friday; 125 Greenwich Avenue (13th Street), mxyplyzyk.com or (212) 989-4300.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. I recently bought expensive kitchen appliances. Should I take them with me when I sell?

title: Best Pop Shows of 2012
description: The pop and jazz critics of The New York Times recall some of their favorite live events of of the year.

title: Shopping for Calendars
description: Roger Fawcett-Tang, a graphic artist, goes shopping for calendars of the perpetual variety.

title: Calendars
description: THE world did not end last week, as some had feared it would. But the year will certainly end next week, which means users of old-school analog calendars will need to start anew.

title: In the London Suburbs, a Home Rebuilt Around a View
description: One glimpse of an unbroken view of sloping farmland was enough to convince a family of their future homes potential.

title: Back to Broadway to Play Dress-Up
description: ON a rare morning when rain threatens in Los Angeles, the mist swirls down into the canyon where Albert Wolsky, the veteran costume designer, opens his door for a visitor. Just a few days after his 82nd birthday, he is back at home after finishing up his work on the revival of The Heiress, currently playing on Broadway.

title: Pops Big Nights
description: A concert is always more than just a rendering of songs. Its a musical revamp, a real-time test, a spectacle, a pop-up community, perhaps a dance party or an incipient riot  and, even in the YouTube era, an ephemeral, site-specific experience. Here the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times recall some of their favorite live events of 2012, in order of importance. JON PARELES

title: Bringing the Countryside Indoors
description: WHEN Sue and David Black first laid eyes on their home 11 years ago, it was potential they saw, not charm.

title: Eat, Drink, Be Nice
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: If Youre Tired of Instagram, Here Are Some Alternatives
description: Instagram has backpedaled furiously from its apparent effort to own all the photographs posted on its site. But if you are looking for an alternative anyway, there are some.

title: Kicking a Movie-a-Day Habit, After Four Years in Theaters
description: With the new year approaching, people resolve to kick all sorts of bad habits. Sam Barron is no different  he vows to try to kick his four-year habit of chronic cinema addiction.

title: An Appetite for Weight Management Tools
description: WHEN I received the results of a routine cholesterol test this summer, I was certain there had been some kind of mistake. Im young, unstressed and healthy, or so I imagined. I work out, too, and most impartial observers  and some partial ones  would describe me as lean. Plus, I eat a nutritious diet, I swear. So why did my LDL levels surpass my I.Q.  or, for that matter, Einsteins?

title: Buffing Up the Butler
description: CAN housework help you live longer? A New York Times blog post by Gretchen Reynolds last month cited research linking vigorous activity, including housework, and longevity. The study, which tracked the death rates of British civil servants, was the latest in a flurry of scientific reports crediting domestic chores with health benefits like a lowered risk for breast and colon cancers. In one piquant study published in 2009, researchers found that couples who spent more hours on housework had sex more frequently (with each other) though presumably not while vacuuming. (The report did not specify.)

title: Untamed Motorization Wraps an Indian City in Smog
description: NEW DELHI  When an acrid blanket of gray smog settled over Indias capital last month, environmentalists warned of health hazards, Indias Supreme Court promised action and state officials struggled to understand why the air had suddenly gone so bad.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Winter Storm Moves Eastward
description: A powerful winter storm that spawned tornadoes in the Deep South and brought Christmas Day snow to Dallas moved eastward on Wednesday.

title: How Giving Became Cool
description: It was 15 years ago that Ted Turner needed something interesting to say in a speech  and decided, in a rush, to give away $1 billion.

title: Dont Let Pro-Israel Extremists Sink Chuck Hagel
description: Washington

title: Holiday Doldrums
description: Republicans are apparently in a funk this holiday season.

title: South Africa: Mandela Is Released From the Hospital
description: Nelson Mandela, South Africas former president, was released from the hospital late Wednesday, ending a 19-day hospital stay. Mr. Mandela, 94, has been in frail condition for several years. He retired from public life in 2004 and was last seen publicly in 2010, though he receives frequent visits from old friends. He was hospitalized on Dec. 8 and treated for a lung infection; he also had surgery to remove gallstones, government officials said. Mac Maharaj, a spokesman for South Africas current president, Jacob Zuma, said that Mr. Mandela would be staying at home in a suburb of Johannesburg and receiving high-level care there. Mr. Mandela was elected in South Africas first fully democratic elections in 1994.

title: Giants Shift Highlights Linebackers Struggles
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When the Giants linebackers walked into their meeting room one day last week, a universal feeling of surprise quickly spread. Instead of seeing the customary three-linebacker starting lineup that the team used nearly all season, the players saw on their sheets that the Giants were planning to use a different setup against the Baltimore Ravens, one that had four linebackers, including several second-year players, on the field together.

title: M.T.A. Challenges the City Over Billboard Restrictions
description: For decades the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has subsidized subway and bus fares by selling advertising space on billboards affixed to its elevated train trestles and to the stilts towering over its railroad yards and tracks.

title: From Tehran to the B Train
description: When I moved to New York City two years ago, I asked my friends here which neighborhood was the safest. Youll be fine wherever you live, they assured me.

title: Poaching of Jungle Elephants Strikes Gabon
description: Once thought of as a model in protecting elephants from poachers, Gabon faces the same obstacles as other countries.

title: In Gabon, Lure of Ivory Is Hard for Many to Resist
description: OYEM, Gabon  This lush country, often called a forest republic, used to stand proudly apart from its shaky neighbors, like the Democratic Republic of Congo and the Central African Republic, tropical disaster zones where state failure, rebel marauders and loose weapons conspired to spell doom for endangered wildlife.

title: The Year in Questions
description: If, as Soren Kierkegaard believed, life is best understood backward, then the holidays are an ideal time to attempt to unravel the secrets of our age through an end-of-the-year quiz. Below are more than a hundred questions to ponder over a cup of coffee, with your feet up. For, as Kierkegaard also knew, Far from idleness being the root of all evil, it is rather the only true good. (Answers here.)

title: Implicit Quotas for Asians at Colleges?
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington State Senators Cross Aisle and Tilt Ideological Balance
description: OLYMPIA, Wash.  From the governor-elect on down, through both chambers of the Legislature, a tincture of blue political monoculture drifts through Washington State politics like mist through the pines.

title: When Prayer Really Counts in Air Travel
description: The call to prayer, a five-times-a-day ritual for strict adherents to Islam, is reaching new heights in Iran.

title: Hawaiis Lieutenant Governor to Succeed Inouye
description: HONOLULU  Hawaiis lieutenant governor, a rising political star here who is unknown on the national scene, will become the states next United States senator, filling a leadership vacuum in Honolulu and in Washington after the death of Senator Daniel K. Inouye last week.

title: The Gun-Game Complex
description: In its bizarre response last week to the shootings in Newtown, Conn., the National Rifle Association heaped blame on vicious, violent video games for corrupting young Americans and called them the filthiest form of pornography. As it turns out, many of those very games have marketing relationships with the makers of firearms and ammunition, which are also big financial supporters of the N.R.A., through deals that appear to be designed to increase sales of their deadly wares.

title: For Fire Victims in Upstate Ambush, a Chance to Grieve and Survey the Destruction
description: WEBSTER, N.Y.  The residents of a waterfront neighborhood in this western New York community returned on Wednesday to survey what little remained of their homes for the first time since a man set a fire that destroyed seven houses in a plot to lure and kill emergency responders.

title: Egypts Flawed Constitution
description: Ideally, a new constitution in Egypt would unite citizens around a consensus vision for their country and set a firm foundation for a democratic transition. The Islamist-backed constitution that took effect this week has only exacerbated divisions and left millions of non-Islamists feeling disenfranchised, angry and determined to force changes in the document.

title: In Sled Hockey, a Slower Pace but Hard Shots and Hits
description: NEWINGTON, Conn.  Back on her wheelchair and in the dressing room with her teammates, Sara Tabor said it had not been such a bad day on the ice. Her team, the Rangers, had lost twice, but she scored a goal after nearly bowling over a goaltender with her sled.

title: What's 'Just Right' for the Young Reader?
Fiscal Endgame
description: Just before the Christmas break, negotiations on the so-called fiscal cliff ended on an absurdist note. House Republicans not only rejected President Obamas overly generous budget deal, including his offer to lift the income threshold for higher tax rates to $400,000 a year from $250,000, they also rejected their own leaderships proposal to raise the threshold for higher taxes to $1 million and to preserve tax breaks for the heirs of multimillion-dollar estates.

title: Morsi Admits Mistakes in Drafting Egypts Constitution
description: CAIRO  President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt took responsibility on Wednesday for mistakes during the run-up to ratification of the new Constitution and urged Egyptians to appreciate the fierce disagreements about it as a healthy phenomenon of their new democracy.

title: Dockworkers Strike Threatens to Close East Coast Ports
description: Anyone who has seen On the Waterfront knows East Coast longshoremen can be a tough bunch.

title: The N.R.A. at the Bench
description: There has been plenty written about the National Rifle Association in recent days. But nothing that Ive seen has focused on the gun lobbys increasingly pernicious role in judicial confirmations. So heres a little story.

title: After 460 Starts, a War Horses Last Stand
description: Only four pacers born in the last 40 years have won more races than Tattlers Jet, but last week it looked as if he, after 460 starts, might miss his final chance to win one more.

title: Brad Corbett, Who Owned Texas Rangers, Dies at 75
description: Brad Corbett, whose turbulent tenure as principal owner of the Texas Rangers baseball team brought the franchise Steinbrenner-like hubris and pocketbook diplomacy, but only middling success, died Monday at home in Fort Worth. He was 75.

title: The Cloud Challenges Amazon
description: For some on Christmas Eve, White Christmas was a blackout on Netflix.

title: Signs of Changes Taking Hold in Electronics Factories in China
description: CHENGDU, China  One day last summer, Pu Xiaolan was halfway through a shift inspecting iPad cases when she received a beige wooden chair with white stripes and a high, sturdy back.

description: In response to questions from The Times, Apple issued the following statement:

description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,154 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Nets Tumble to .500 as Williams Sits With Injury
description: MILWAUKEE  The star point guard Deron Williams sat on the bench, dressed in a gray suit, unable to help his Nets teammates.

title: Factory Conditions in China
description: The final chapter of the iEconomy series, which examines challenges posed by increasingly globalized high-tech industries, looks at what changes have been made at the factories in China.

title: After Christmas, Returns and Relief
description: It is serenaded weeks before it arrives by radio stations and heralded by a monthlong parade of tinsel in nearly every store window in town. It is a date for which gift-givers have scrimped and saved, home cooks have basted and baked, and, perhaps underscoring its significance most of all, for which children have tried to behave.

title: Yankees Add Insurance in the Outfield
description: The Yankees search for a right-handed-hitting outfielder has led them to the former Atlanta Braves outfielder Matt Diaz, who has agreed to a minor league deal with the team and will be invited to spring training, according to a baseball official who has knowledge of the agreement.

title: Jury Awards $1.17 Billion in Patent Suit
description: Carnegie Mellon University said it was awarded $1.17 billion by a federal jury in Pittsburgh on Wednesday in a unanimous verdict that found the Marvell Technology Group had sold billions of semiconductors using technology developed at the university without a license.

title: Sneakers and Hope for a Single Mother
description: The biggest clue might have been her right sneaker. The young mother had worn those Nikes every single day for six years, and now her big toe protruded through a hole in the front. As Faven Weinu walked through the rain or snow in Brooklyn, people would freak out, but she did not listen to them  she was, as she put it, disconnected.

title: Doctors Warned on Divided Loyalty
description: WASHINGTON  With hospitals buying up medical practices around the country and seeking to make the most of their investment, the American Medical Association reached out to doctors this week to remind them that patient welfare must always come first and not be overridden by the economic interests of hospitals that now employ doctors in ever-growing numbers.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, Dec. 27, 2012
description: The regime army has lost control over most of the country.

title: Lottery Numbers
Campus Protests Return, but Over Rebranding
description: COLLEGE students can have visceral reactions to many things  dormitory life, cafeteria food, midterms. And in this age of instant criticism online, another item can be added to that list: protests against the efforts of universities to refresh their logos, slogans and mascots.

title: Corrections: December 27, 2012
description: NATIONAL

title: Balneotherapy Locale
description: Administrivial Do-Gooder Fun Puzzle Alert! Wordplay star and debonair constructor-about-town Trip Payne has launched another fun puzzle extravaganza that you can help fund and enjoy. Kick in a little or a lot to enjoy his 12 interconnected puzzles that will be available for your solving pleasure in July of 2013. To find out more, click here.

title: Elwood V. Jensen, Pioneer in Breast Cancer Treatment, Dies at 92
description: Elwood V. Jensen, a medical researcher whose studies of steroid hormones led to new treatments for breast cancer that have been credited with saving or extending hundreds of thousands of lives, died on Dec. 16 in Cincinnati. He was 92.

title: The Sled Hockey Rangers
description: The Rangers are a part of the Northeast Sled Hockey League, which holds five games one Sunday per month in Newington, Conn.

title: Ray Collins of the Mothers of Invention Dies
description: Ray Collins, a singer whose dispute with one guitarist led him to hire another, Frank Zappa, with whom he went on to form the avant-garde rock group the Mothers of Invention, died on Dec. 24 in Pomona, Calif. He was in his middle 70s.

title: Hobbled by Injuries, Knicks Win on Last Shot
description: PHOENIX  J. R Smith walked on the court and looked up at the scoreboard. It said the game was tied at 97-97, and Smith knew the ball  and the games biggest moment  was coming to him. Smith then closed his eyes and bowed his head. He meditated.

title: Woman Hit by Bus Near Central Park Dies
description: A woman who was hit by a bus while crossing the street near Central Park has died, police said late Wednesday.

title: Too Young to Have a Heart Attack
description: The foreshadowing escaped me: The night before we left for our summer vacation in Michigan, I accidentally stepped on my Kindle  which, like my heart, I cannot live without  and broke it. Reduced to reading novels on my iPhone, I made the best of it several days later, sitting in a sunroom overlooking Eight Point Lake, where my family gathers each year with friends.

title: Prius Tops Consumer Reports List of Best New-Car Values
description: Consumer Reports released on Thursday its annual list of Best and Worst New-Car Values.

title: Delhi Police Deploy Mimes Against Sexual Assault
description: How well Delhis police protect women, particularly from sexual attacks, has become an increasingly politicized issue after the Dec. 16 gang rape of a medical student on a moving bus. Protesters outraged over the crime, and the rise in reported rape cases in the city, have been calling for Delhis police commissioner, Neeraj Kumar, to step down.

title: Whats On Thursday
description: NOON (FX) ENEMY OF THE STATE (1998) Will Smith, above, is Robert Clayton Dean, a model citizen who is framed for murder by a rogue government official (Jon Voight) and his team of agents in this conspiracy-filled fever dream, directed by Tony Scott. Gene Hackman is the grizzled retired government operative with the technological know-how who can help Robert clear his name. Janet Maslin, writing in The New York Times, said that while Mr. Scott, has done popular culture no great favor by pioneering the Simpson-Bruckheimer school of empty but sensation-packed filmmaking, he now looks like a veritable Billy Wilder beside latter-day Top Gunners like Michael (Armageddon) Bay. She added, As a grand old man of the thrill-happy genre, Mr. Scott gives this film a fine cast, a modicum of wit on the run and a reasonably human dimension.

title: Missing Syrian Official Discussed Defection in Twitter Dialogue, Activist Says
description: As my colleague Rick Gladstone reports, the recent disappearance of Syrias Foreign Ministry spokesman, Jihad Makdissi, has been followed by unconfirmed reports about his possible defection.

title: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 27
description: NEWS China began service Wednesday morning on the worlds longest high-speed rail line, from Beijing to Guangzhou  covering a distance in eight hours that is about equal to that from New York to Key West, Florida, or from London across Europe to Belgrade, Serbia. Keith Bradsher reports from Hong Kong.

title: Prime Minister Singh Warns Business as Usual Will Not Work
description: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh addressed a meeting of the National Development Council in New Delhi on Thursday. The meeting was called to finalize a draft of Indias 12th five-year plan (2012-17) that aims for faster, more inclusive and sustainable growth. Mr. Singh emphasized the need to improve gender inequality and said that business as usual, will not help achieve high economic growth.

title: Capturing a Childhood Idyll in France
description: Youre piggybacking on your brothers shoulders, the wind on your face as you run through the grass (below). Youre messy, climbing, hair astray. Youre belly-down on a swing. Flying.

title: The S.E.C. at a Turning Point
description: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: Squabbles in Garmsir
description: GARMSIR, Afghanistan  You know, were very worried about the future, Hamid Khan, the telecommunications director in Garmsir, southern Afghanistan, said to Major Thomas McAvoy, the civil affairs officer attached to Kilo Company, Third Battalion, Ninth Marine Regiment. When Najibullah was president, he also had a plan to take control of the districts and build the government.

title: U.N. Envoy Calls for a Transitional Government in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Lakhdar Brahimi, the international envoy on a mission to Damascus seeking an end to the escalating civil conflict in Syria, said Thursday that a transitional government with full executive authority should be established, perhaps within months, and should rule the country until elections could be held.

title: After Delhi Rape Victim Leaves India, Questions Raised About Medias Role
description: On Wednesday night, the entrance of Safdarjung Hospital in New Delhi resembled a carnival, overrun with police officers, eager journalists and curious passersby. At least two dozen television news vans were staked outside, awaiting the latest word on the condition of the 23-year-old woman who was gang-raped on a Delhi bus last week.

title: Tebow Expresses Disappointment at Being Called Quitter
description: Ryan calculates his chance of holding his job would be greater if McElroy played and lost than if Tebow played and won.Gregg Easterbrook, Tuesday Morning Quarterback at ESPN.com

title: On Our Radar: A Beached Whale
description: Rescue coordinators say there is little they can do to save an emaciated 60-foot whale that washed up on a beach in the Breezy Point section of Queens.3:02 p.m. | Updated The whale has been confirmed dead. [The New York Times]

title: The Invisible Ax  People, Profit and Progress on Humanitys Planet
description: I recently traveled for the first time to Taiwan, where I saw inspiring efforts to give a decent life to orangutans and other wildlife cast off by the exotic-pet trade and to collect and conserve rare tropical flora from around the world. Ill be posting more on those projects in January.

title: A Poachers Redemption
description: Jeffrey Gettleman, The Timess Nairobi bureau chief, reports on how Kenyas wildlife conservation corps is learning from a reformed poacher how to counter the growing threat to elephants.

title: Putin Signs Bill That Bars U.S. Adoptions, Upending Families
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin signed a bill on Friday that bans the adoption of Russian children by American citizens, dealing a serious blow to an already strained diplomatic relationship. But for hundreds of Americans enmeshed in the costly, complicated adoption process, the impact was deeply personal.

title: As Enigmatic as Her Picture
Thursday Reading: The Ultimate Housework Workout
Japan Hints It May Revise an Apology on Sex Slaves
description: TOKYO  A top official hinted Thursday that Japans newly installed conservative government might seek to revise a nearly two-decade-old official apology to women forced into sexual slavery during World War II, a move that would most likely outrage South Korea and possibly other former victims of Japanese militarism.

title: Stalemate in Washington Is Eroding Confidence of Consumers
description: For months, consumers have powered spending, while businesses pulled back ahead of the looming fiscal impasse in Washington. Now, as doubts grow about whether the president and Congress can reach a compromise before a year-end deadline, evidence has emerged that consumers, too, are becoming more pessimistic about the economy.

title: Futurism and Policy
description: As regular readers have noticed, Ive been spending a fair bit of time recently thinking about issues of long-term growth. Why? Partly just as a break from fiscal cliffery and the endless battle against dumb short-run macro. But its also true that the long run matters for policy: given how much public debate focuses on things like the state of Social Security or Medicare in the year 2040, its definitely worth trying to figure out what we know or dont know about what our economy might look like in the year 2040.

title: SeaWorld Files to Go Public
description: SeaWorld Entertainment, the Blackstone Group-controlled theme park operator famous for its killer whales, filed for an initial public offering on Thursday.

title: Strong Sales for Cat on a Hot Tin Roof With Scarlett Johansson
description: The Scarlett Johansson-led revival of Cat on a Hot Tin Roof is off to a strong start on Broadway, grossing $843,215 for its first seven preview performances last week  more money than any of the last three Broadway revivals of the play made in a single week, even after adjusting for inflation. Those revivals starred Anika Noni Rose (in 2008), Ashley Judd (2003) and Kathleen Turner (1990) in the role of Maggie, which Ms. Johansson is playing in the new production, whose box-office sales have benefited from the advent of premium ticket pricing of up to $175 a seat last week.

title: The Best in Travel
description: From Nicaragua to China, Ts suggestions on what to see and do. See interactive feature >>

title: Going Beyond Disney in Orlando
description: Quick, name five reasons to go to Orlando. Here are mine: Puerto Rican delicacies, alternative cinema, craft beer, African-American history and psychic readings.

title: A Perp Walk of Outstanding New York Politicians
description: With 2012 just about over, we in New York have reason to hold heads high. We showed over the past year that we remain a leader when it comes to political corruption. Its not easy staying at the top of your game. But we New Yorkers proved, once again, that we have what it takes.

title: Daily Report: Changes Afoot at Electronics Factories in China
description: Shifts in how Apple deals with manufacturers like Foxconn have convinced executives at other electronics companies that they must also overhaul how they interact with foreign plants and workers, Keith Bradsher and Charles Duhigg report on Thursday in The New York Times. These changes may come at a cost to their bottom lines, though, analysts say, probably not so much as to affect consumer prices. As Apple and Foxconn became fodder for Saturday Night Live and questions during presidential debates in the last year, device designers and manufacturers concluded the industrys reputation was at risk.

title: As Swing Districts Dwindle, Can a Divided House Stand?
description: In 1992, there were 103 members of the House of Representatives elected from what might be called swing districts: those in which the margin in the presidential race was within five percentage points of the national result. But based on an analysis of this years presidential returns, I estimate that there are only 35 such Congressional districts remaining, barely a third of the total 20 years ago.

title: What Were Reading
description: The New York Daily News: Here come ol flattop  the Starbucks coffee cup  with a Lennon-ish message to help talk bickering lawmakers down off the fiscal cliff: Come Together.  Patrick Farrell

title: Someones Mom Has Other Identities
description: FOR someone who pretty much worships Laurie Metcalf, Joe Mantello isnt making her life easy in The Other Place, opening Jan. 10 on Broadway. I used to leave the stage for a total of, like, 10 seconds, Ms. Metcalf said of her experience in the show. But we changed that.

title: E.P.A. Chief Set to Leave; Term Fell Shy of Early Hope
description: Lisa P. Jackson is stepping down as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency after a four-year tenure that began with high hopes of sweeping action to address climate change and other environmental ills but ended with a series of rear-guard actions to defend the agency against challenges from industry, Republicans in Congress and, at times, the Obama White House.

title: Capturing Climate Change Digitally
description: The changing palette of colors in a forest signals more than the arrival of a new season. For those who know how to look, the colors also reveal how much carbon dioxide the trees are absorbing from the atmosphere during photosynthesis, a new study suggests. By analyzing thousands of photographs of a forest canopy less than 40 miles outside London, the researchers were able to estimate carbon uptake over a two-year period based on the leaves hues.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Gun Laws May Trip Up NBC, and a Third Act for Some Stars
description: The Washington, D.C., police are investigating whether NBC and David Gregory, the anchor of Meet the Press, broke the districts gun laws during an exclusive interview with Wayne LaPierre of the National Rifle Association, Michael S. Schmidt reported. Mr. Gregory brandished an empty magazine that can hold up to 30 bullets while asking Mr. LaPierre what harm would come from banning such equipment. However, in Washington, possessing even an empty magazine is against the law, and, according to the police, NBC asked for permission to display the magazine and was told that it could not. NBC has declined to comment on the matter.

title: E.P.A. Chief to Step Down
description: After a tenure that began with bold initiatives but wound down with defensive maneuvers, Lisa P. Jackson is resigning as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, John M. Broder reports. Her departure comes as many are questioning President Obamas commitment to dealing with climate change and other environmental problems.

title: Arnold Schwarzenegger: By the Book
description: The actor, former governor and author of the memoir Total Recall says todays cleaned-up versions of Grimms fairy tales are nothing like the horror versions he read as a child.

title: E-Book Reading Is Up, Study Says
description: The printed page/ was just half a millenniums brief wonder, theorized John Updike in a late poem. Exactly when the old order will be completely overthrown is in some dispute, however.

title: Things I Saw  No. 49
description: Suggestions for what youd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

title: Four Tips for Taking Frosty Photos
description: As a beginning photographer, Mark Theriots best source of subjects were to be found at the nearby Mississippi River. Having nothing else to shoot, it drove me outside, he said. In time he developed into a noted outdoor photographer, specializing in pictures of birds, and especially eagles.

title: Libraries See Opening as Bookstores Close
description: At the bustling public library in Arlington Heights, Ill., requests by three patrons to place any title on hold prompt a savvy computer tracking system to order an additional copy of the coveted item. That policy was intended to eliminate the frustration of long waits to check out best sellers and other popular books. But it has had some unintended consequences, too: the librarys shelves are now stocked with 36 copies of Fifty Shades of Grey.

title: On the Block: 1956 Lancia Aurelia B24S Spider
description: Its a groaner, but the story underlines how little exposure Americans have had to this revered European brand: A proud owner of a Lancia Aurelia pulled into a gas station and was asked, What kind of car is that?

title: Betrayed While Asleep, Afghan Police Die at Hands of Their Countrymen
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A wave of betrayal has left at least 17 Afghan policemen dead in the past 10 days  all killed in their sleep, at the hands of those close to them.

title: For Dead Whale of Breezy Point, Necropsy and Beach Burial
description: Updated, 5:28 p.m. | On the windswept beach at Breezy Point on Thursday afternoon, the researcher cut a small, raw cube out of the side of the giant whale, deposited the morsel in a vial of formaldehyde and screwed the cap shut. It was a messy job.

title: Thanks, Mom, for Not Telling the World I Pulled a Knife on You
description: I dont remember what my mother and I were fighting about, but I do remember the moment when I pulled out a knife. I was 15, and we were arguing about something. As is often the case with adolescent fights, it was probably about something ridiculous, like my outfit.

title: The Music They Made
description: A sound collage featuring a sampling of the musicians who died in 2012.

title: The Music They Made
description: Welcome to the fifth annual installment of The Music They Made, a sound collage featuring the musicians who died in the past year. As in past versions, a few (entirely coincidental and random) themes emerged in the mix for 2012. We find a statistically improbable number of divas (Whitney, Etta, Donna, Chavela), two of the greatest soul bassists ever to record  and more sitar than you would expect, all of it sounding as fresh as the day it was played. The artists were young and old, famous and belatedly famous. You can play the full versions of the songs sampled above on Spotify.

title: Hello, This Is Your Gift Card Calling
description: 4:38 p.m. Updated / To add comment from GameStop.

title: Another Day, Another Year-End List
description: In most parts of life, the calendar marks the passage of time, with the end of the year prompting people to pause and reflect on the year past, then resolve to make resolutions that wont make it out of January. In journalism, the flipping of the calendar pages means only one thing: lists. And sports journalism is always right out there at the front of the pack of lists. Want the 12 surprising moments of the year in sports. Check. Breakout athletes of the year? How bout 30 of them? A string of memories from the minds of a dozen or so of The Timess writers? Got em!

title: City Hopes Money Grows From Fallen Trees
description: Talk about making lemonade out of lemons. Hurricane Sandy toppled hundreds of trees throughout the metropolitan area, including many in the New York City-owned watersheds along reservoirs in Westchester County. Instead of discarding the downed trees or burning them, the city is selling them.

title: In Flurry of Activity, Only Muted Hope for Fiscal Deal
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will meet with Congressional leaders on Friday, and House Republicans summoned lawmakers back for a Sunday session, in a last-ditch effort to avert a fiscal crisis brought on by automatic tax increases and spending cuts scheduled to hit next week.

title: Image of the Day: Dec. 27
A Factory Upgrade
description: TimesCast: Bolivias unorthodox approach to the drug war. | Working conditions at Chinas electronics factories examined firsthand.

title: The Unfulfilled Promise of Promised Land
description: I recently attended a Manhattan screening of Promised Land, a new feature film written by and starring Matt Damonand John Krasinskithat aims to examine Americas natural gas drilling boom as a case study in what happens when real people and real money collide, as Krasinski explained in publicity materials.

title: Broadway to Pay Tribute to Charles Durning and Jack Klugman
description: Broadway theaters will honor two acclaimed actors on two consecutive evenings, dimming their lights at 8 p.m. on Thursday in memory of Charles Durning, and again at 8 p.m. on Friday in recognition of Jack Klugman, the Broadway League said on Thursday.

title: Game Theory: The Awkward Adolescence of Gaming
description: Jenn, Chris, Stephen and Friends,

title: Monitoring Mandela and the Soul of a Nation
description: PLETTENBERG BAY, South Africa  After almost three weeks of treatment for a recurrent lung infection, Nelson Mandela, the 94-year-old icon of South Africas triumph over apartheid, was discharged from a hospital late Wednesday. But a terse statement from his physicians saying he would not return immediately to his remote, rural home at Qunu in the Eastern Cape region raised questions that his family and associates sought to answer a day later.

title: Rebels Are Advancing Toward Capital of Central African Republic
description: JOHANNESBURG  Rebels on Thursday inched closer to the capital of the Central African Republic, one of Africas most fragile states, threatening to topple an elected government that has had an unsteady grip on power for nearly a decade.

title: Steinway Decides to Keep the Keys of Its Kingdom
description: The corporate owner of the piano maker Steinway & Sons says the company is no longer up for sale. In a news release issued Wednesday, the company  Steinway Musical Instruments Inc.  said that in July 2011 it began studying the possible sale of itself or its band instrument division. Several expressions of interest came in but the company decided against them. It also said it was shutting down a possible deal to sell the band unit to an investor group led by two board members.

title: A Sexual Musical, Now Middle-Aged
description: A FEW weeks ago The New York Times reported that the sexually frank 1974 musical revue Let My People Come will be revived this winter for eight Fridays at the Underground, a bar just south of Columbia University. According to the producer, John Forslund, the original lyrics and sketches will be revised and updated, and while the revival will feature far less nudity than the original, there will still be ample opportunity to see cast members, both male and female, in the buff.

title: In Performance: Brandon J. Dirden of The Piano Lesson
description: August Wilsons play The Piano Lesson is about a family at odds over the fate of an intricately carved piano with a multigenerational history. In this scene, Boy Willie, played by Brandon J. Dirden, explains why he wants to sell the instrument, much against the wishes of his sister. The play continues through Jan. 20 at the Signature Theater.

title: Accountants Skirt Shareholder Lawsuits
description: The accountants who service publicly traded companies are likely to have something to be thankful for this year: shareholders are not filing federal securities fraud lawsuits against them.

title: Speaking August Wilsons Words Can Change You
description: THE blue coats, the actor Brandon J. Dirden whispered as he sat down for an interview in the cafeteria of The New York Times. Eating dinner at nearby tables were groups of uniformed workers who were catering an event that night. It was only a few years ago that Mr. Dirden wore the same ultramarine outfit, in the exact same building, dreaming of the stage instead of treading it.

title: Three Mothers, One Bond
description: WE found out by text message. Dont get on the plane. The birth mother is unsure.

title: Future Inequality, According to the CBO
description: Aha: in its long-term assessment of Social Security (pdf), the CBO makes its assumptions explicit. Kudos to them for doing this, by the way; even if you disagree, its helpful to know how they arrive at their conclusions.

title: Bolivias Unorthodox Approach
description: The Timess William Neuman discusses how Bolivias experiment has led to a significant drop in coca plantings.

title: Lenore Norman, a Quiet Force for Landmarks Preservation, Dies at 83
description: If you love New York Citys architectural heritage, you owe a debt of gratitude to Lenore Norman. Chances are, you didnt know that. She would have been pleased.

title: Wheres That Picasso? An App Can Help
description: For every interest, there is an app to help you find out where to enjoy it. Like cigars? Cigar Boss will tell you where to buy habaneros. Do you ski? There are too many guides to resorts to count. But art is a little harder to locate with your smartphone. It is this gap that the makers of the popular app Art Authority seek to fill. They have added a more location-focused app called Art Alert to steer you to famous works.

title: Ingrates and Clumsy Guests
description: My husband and I have nine grandchildren ranging in age from 10 to 22. They are all wonderful. We live at a distance; so every year, we send each of them Christmas and birthday gifts. We love shopping for them and try to choose things they will enjoy. But we never hear a peep back. Not a single thank you. Ever. Its as if the gifts disappear into a black hole. But isnt commanding thanks awkward?

title: For Rosemarys Chef, Great White Whale Was an Octopus
description: As any great songwriter (Leonard Cohen, for example) can tell you, some songs arrive in the flash of a few inspiration-dense minutes, while others crawl toward completion over the course of many (often maddening) years.

title: Gay Republicans Take Out Ad Criticizing Hagel
description: The White House may not be making any more announcements about President Obamas new national security team this week, but that hasnt stopped the anti-Chuck Hagel drumbeat.

title: Obama Returns to Washington, With Bo
description: President Obama returned to the White House on Thursday to resume efforts to end a partisan impasse on a fiscal deal without his wife and daughters, who remain on vacation in Hawaii. His only companion: the family dog, Bo.

title: Suddenly Reeling, the Nets Fire Their Coach
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It was 30 months ago that the images rose in Midtown Manhattan, a blue-tinted mural of an international hip-hop icon and a Russian billionaire, under the audacious heading The blueprint for greatness.

title: Bank C.E.O.s on Thinning Ice
description: At least one of the three big bank chief executives to survive the financial crisis could be without a job by the end of 2013.

title: Deep Down, He Wants to Help
description: Im not a bad guy, Steve Butler insists, and one of the reasons Promised Land works is that hes right. Played by Matt Damon (who wrote the screenplay with John Krasinski), Steve, a corporate predator who is also a true believer in his companys cause, is both the apparent villain and a magnet for the audiences sympathy.

title: In Bronx Gym, Man Who Went Astray Leads Youths on Straight Path
description: On a recent night in the South Bronx, Fernando Laspina peeked out the front window of El Maestro and Juan Laportes Boxing Gym and saw a cold, steady rain falling on the dimly lighted, rugged streets of his troubled youth.

title: Planning Obama's Second Inauguration
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York discusses the preparations for President Obama's second inauguration on January 21, 2013.

title: Instantly Yours, for a Fee
description: Ivy Wu did not immediately need the navy lace cocktail dress she ordered the other day. But when a representative from Shoptiques, an e-commerce site, arrived at her Midtown Manhattan office with the dress only hours after Ms. Wu, 26, had placed her order, I was really impressed that it was here, she said.

title: Sanchez Is Back as Starter for Finale
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  A mere four months, not four epochs, have passed since Mark Sanchez had his finest game of the season, throwing three touchdown passes in a 48-28 victory against Buffalo that left the entire Jets organization giddy.

title: Cool Quilts in Prospect Park
description: The excitement of the youngest members of the Misers household, in the days and weeks leading up to Christmas, is a joy to behold. Whats not quite so wonderful, once the gifts have been unwrapped and assimilated, the food consumed and the tree disposed of, is the task of keeping those little minds and bodies occupied until school starts up again.

title: A Stiletto Workout? It Can Be Done
description: YOURE going to a stiletto class? my husband balked. That sounds like a lawsuit waiting to happen.

title: Flooding Is Worse Than Normal in Storm-Hit Communities in New Jersey
description: Storm weary coastal communities in southern New Jersey awoke to more flooding on Thursday, with high tide bringing waters that lapped the bumpers of fire trucks and sent debris and at least one refrigerator floating down submerged streets.

title: Instagram Flap Shows Confusion Over Control of Content
description: The ruckus (now lawsuit) over whether Instagram would use your pictures to make money has drawn new attention to an unresolved battle of the Web era: Who owns your stuff online?

title: A Pay Cut for Tim Cook? Not Really
description: This year, Apple became the most highly valued public company in history and generated $156.5 billion in revenue  nearly 50 percent more than in 2011. So how much did Timothy D. Cook, the companys chief executive, take home?

title: Drinking, Driving, Teenagers and New Years Eve
description: If theyre old enough to serve in the military, they should be old enough to drive.

title: Tap Served With Brass Punch
description: Maurice Hines cant stop moving. Even when relatively stationary from the waist up, this effusively good-natured dancer, choreographer and singer, who recently turned 69, shuffles his feet, rotates his legs and twitches with an uncontainable urge to swoop and tap. You might say he is driven by a compulsion to swing.

title: South Asia Through Modernist Binoculars
description: Radical Terrain is the last of three small, carefully judged, back-to-back exhibitions in the series Modernist Art From India at the Rubin Museum of Art. How lucky New York is to have a museum willing and able to do such shows, unfamiliar in content but large with history. If we relied on our big institutions, which so often spoon-feed us what we already know, we would be unaware that India even had a modern art, never mind one of variety and complexity.

title: Aamanns-Copenhagen
description: Inside the Danish restaurant that is rebooting an endangered food tradition: the smorrebrod.

title: Morsels of Denmark, Anchored by Earthy Bread
description: When the original Aamanns opened in Copenhagen in 2006, locals embraced it as an invigorating reboot of an endangered food tradition: the smorrebrod, or open-face sandwich. As Mile End in Brooklyn has reinvented the Jewish deli, and Parm in NoLIta reworked the Italian-American sandwich shop, Aamanns took up an institution that had become neglected and synthetic, re-engineered it with traditional methods and good ingredients, then served it up proudly with a side of modern design.

title: CBS Broadcast of Kennedy Center Honors Draws 8 Million Viewers
description: CBSs broadcast of the Kennedy Center Honors, a 35-year holiday tradition for the network, attracted more than eight million viewers on Wednesday, easily outdrawing its competitors for the night.

title: New Credit Card Fees Possible but Unlikely
description: Some retailers will soon have the option of charging extra fees to customers who pay with credit cards, as a result of a legal settlement in an antitrust lawsuit involving MasterCard, Visa and the big card-issuing banks.

title: Snow Fall Tells a Story About an Avalanche and a Newspapers Digital Progress
description: With its spectacular graphics and photography, and its beautifully written narrative, Snow Fall: The Avalanche at Tunnel Creek was a compelling project, even for those who might not have been particularly interested in the topic.

title: Joan Kron and Plastic Surgery Journalism
description: Joan Kron, an editor at Allure magazine, discusses how she got into plastic surgery journalism.

title: Porsche Wins Dismissal of Hedge Fund Short Squeeze Lawsuit
description: A New York State appeals court dismissed a lawsuit brought by hedge funds against Porsche on Thursday, handing the German automaker a big victory in the long-running legal battle over its attempted takeover of Volkswagen.

title: Car Factories Offer Hope for Spanish Industry and Workers
description: MADRID  Despite the economic gloom that has enshrouded it since the onset of the global financial crisis, Spain has at least one industrial bright spot: The country and its skilled, if underemployed, work force have once again become a beacon for European carmakers.

title: Swift Holds On to Top Spot in a Big Week for Music Sales
description: Taylor Swift held on to the No. 1 spot on the Billboard chart for a sixth week, beating releases by T.I. and Bruno Mars, as well as the 12-12-12 charity album, in one of the biggest sales weeks of the year for the music industry.

title: Deal Unlikely Before Fiscal Deadline
description: Lawmakers return to Washington from the Christmas recess with only days left before the United States economy goes over the so-called fiscal cliff.

title: Iranian Leader Fires Woman From Cabinet
description: Irans president on Thursday dismissed his health minister, the only woman to serve in the cabinet since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, after she publicly criticized the governments response to acute shortages of medicine imports, an indirect consequence of the Western sanctions imposed on the country.

title: Unwrapped After Christmas, a Tenor
description: When, close to midnight on Wednesday, the American tenor Bryan Hymel appeared for his curtain call at the end of the Metropolitan Operas performance of the Berlioz epic Les Troyens, the entire cast lined up onstage and applauded along with the audience during the prolonged ovation. This gesture from the singers seemed not just a welcoming tribute to a young colleague making his Met debut on short notice in the daunting role of Aeneas. The cast members, especially the beaming mezzo-soprano Susan Graham, who was again a vocally sumptuous and alluring Dido, seemed genuinely grateful to Mr. Hymel for saving the day by giving an impassioned and confident performance of a heroic role that dominates this formidable French opera.

title: Underbelly of a Brotherhood
description: The reliance of our government on the National Guard to pick up the slack in war zones  and the subsequent weakening of our ability to respond to homeland disasters  is a fertile topic that movies so far have neglected to exploit. And though Allegiance dips a toe in that water, this well-acted debut feature from Michael Connors (a former Army captain) is too limited in ambition and scope to satisfy our expectations.

title: Vying for Fluency in Many Languages
description: Trisha Baga must feel as if she had died and gone to heaven. Her poetically frowzy installations of video projections, paintings, sculptures and scattered objects can be seen now in two New York museums  in a lobby gallery solo show at the Whitney Museum of American Art and in New Pictures of Common Objects, a group show at MoMA PS 1  and she has a sprawling exhibition at Greene Naftali in Chelsea, a gallery admired by the art world cognoscenti. A New York resident, she also had solo shows in London and Munich in 2012. And she is only 27.

title: Chris McCaw: Marking Time
description: Yossi Milo

title: Al Loving : Torn Canvas
description: Gary Snyder Gallery

title: Richard Walker: House Paintings
description: Alexandre Gallery

title: Haroon Mirza: Preoccupied Waveforms
description: New Museum Studio 231

title: Colors of the Universe: Chinese Hardstone Carvings
description: Metropolitan Museum of Art

title: Suburban Sprawl
description: Theres a touching paradox in the first chapter of Jami Attenbergs caustic, entertaining and bighearted new novel, The Middlesteins. Edie, 5 years old and 62 pounds, is already too solid, in her mothers estimation, too big for her age. But how can her mother not feed her, when she and her husband feel that food is made of love, and love . . . made of food? How can these parents deny Edie life-giving nourishment when Edies father, a Jewish immigrant from Ukraine, nearly starved on his journey to Chicago and has never been able to get enough to eat since? Even though its clear that young Edie suffers under her own weight  she huffs and puffs up the stairs like someones gassy old uncle after a meal  her mother cant refuse her the liverwurst and rye bread she loves. This is a Jewish mother after all, and those of us whove had one know that the message, when it comes to food, is always have a little more. Its an attitude that comes not just from love, but also from fear; a history fraught with disaster and hunger gives rise to the feeling that one must always be prepared. Therefore, bubbeleh, have another matzo ball.

title: Wheelies: The Social Media Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Todays Scuttlebot: MySpace Reinvented Again, and Nothing Major
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: City Agency Warns of Local Fiscal Problems Ahead
description: Whatever happens in Washington as the deadline for a fiscal deal approaches, New York City is facing some daunting financial topography of its own in the coming year and beyond, the citys Independent Budget Office warned on Thursday.

title: Chicago Fire Episode Hits Too Close to Home for Webster, N.Y.
description: 5:29 p.m. | Updated An NBC station in upstate New York expressed regret on Thursday for televising a repeat of Chicago Fire, a network drama about firefighters, that bore resemblances to a real-life Christmas Eve shooting there.

title: Has the Fat Lady Finally Sung?
description: With Richard Wagner turning 200 on May 22, what better way for the venerable Teatro alla Scala in Milan to celebrate than to open its season this month with his Lohengrin?

title: 36 Hours in El Paso, Tex.
description: SITUATED at the intersection of Texas, Mexico and New Mexico, El Paso is a city with a distinct flavor. It juxtaposes authentic Mexican culture with a growing hipster scene, and though its one of the largest cities in Texas, it still often ends up as a mere pit stop on I-10. Once the storied heart of the Old West (and playground of Billy the Kid), El Paso has recently gained much of the big-city feel of its neighbor across the border, Ciudad Jurez. It has come into its own with new theaters, restaurants and nightclubs, many of them transplants from its sister city, the epicenter of the Mexican drug war.

title: Views of El Paso, Tex.
description: From a chic restaurant in a strip mall to prickly pear mimosas in the desert, take a tour of this Texas town.

title: Cats and Coffee in Seoul
description: If you like your caffeine with a feline theme, youll be right at home in Seoul, where a number of quirky cafes have sprung up.

title: Unusual Auction Lots, Some With Sad Histories, Head for Public View
description: In a year of good and bad stewardship of antiques, museums opened that are devoted to handbags, gelato artifacts and the 1970s band Cheap Trick, and museums closed and sold off displays of wax figures, farm equipment and bicycle memorabilia. The best news of 2012 is that six major auction lots, brought back from warehouse stints and the brink of decay and dispersal, are now headed for public view:

title: In a Weak Market for Mergers and Acquisitions, Signs of Strength
description: Paul T. Schnell has worked on some of the biggest mergers announced this year, a period in which, he says, the business of buying and selling companies is in the doldrums.

title: Woman Posed as Aunt of Newtown Victim to Commit Fraud, the F.B.I. Says
description: A Bronx woman who the police say posed as a relative of a boy killed in the mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in order to solicit donations was arrested on Thursday and charged with lying to federal agents.

title: Five Days Until the Fiscal Deadline
description: TimesCast Politics: The treasury secretary warns the U.S. will reach its borrowing limit on Monday. | The implications of the fiscal deadline on personal finances. | Planning Obamas inauguration.

title: In Boost to U.S. Plans, BBC World News Is Added to Time Warner Cable
description: 9:16 a.m. | Updated In a sign of progress for its push to get on cable and satellite systems across the United States, the BBC World News channel is now available in about 10 million homes that subscribe to Time Warner Cable.

title: Seeing a Movie Over the Holidays? Best to Find a Comfy Seat
description: LOS ANGELES  The top three movies at the box office have a combined running time of 8 hours and 11 minutes  but whos counting?

title: Wild Yeasts, Distinctive Tastes
description: Wild yeast adds funkiness and hints of tropical fruit to beer.

title: Brettanomyces, a Funky Yeast, Makes Flavorful Beers
description: DENVER

title: Native Talents, Shrugging at Europe
description: The Whitney Museum is New Yorks go-to institution for the crazy-quilt history of early- and mid-20th-century American art, and its new permanent-collection display, American Legends: Calder to OKeeffe, is one of its best in years. It features 15 artists, each represented by concentrated clusters of work that in some cases amount to mini-career retrospectives and that together create an immersive sense of the vitality of the prewar period.

title: Empty Pages in a Show Filled With Words
description: Ed Ruscha has never been particularly precious about print. For him books  even his own artists books  have always been disposable. His breakout work, Twenty-Six Gasoline Stations, was a photo essay that looked more like a users manual; it set the tone for much Conceptual art and was followed by other, equally deadpan compendiums (Every Building on the Sunset Strip, Nine Swimming Pools).

title: All the Fizz in a New Year of Culture
description: THE year may not be over yet, but sometimes it is hard to tamp down the enthusiasm of critics, reporters and editors for whats aesthetically ahead. In picking their favorite possibilities for 2013, writers for The New York Times have identified a high-octane cast in Parsifal at the Metropolitan Opera, a celebration of Cambodian culture, a series of major video game releases and a sizzling dose of televised Bacon, as in the actor Kevin.

description: Comedy

description: The critics make their Oscar choices.

description: TWEETS

title: Personal Finances and the Fiscal Cliff
description: Ron Lieber, the Your Money columnist, discusses the implications of the fiscal deadline on personal finances.

description: Photos from Afghanistan, West Bank, Pakistan and India.

description: Dance

title: This Weeks Movies | Dec. 28, 2012
description: The New York Times critics on Les Misrables, Django Unchained and West of Memphis.

title: A Nod to New Amsterdam
description: FOR years it has been the odd man out, the bad penny, a brutalized little 1830s brick house at 19 South William Street, plopped onto one of the most picturesque blocks downtown. Now a recent renovation has given this longtime party pooper a steampunk air in the midst of a riot of Flemish and Tudor revival architecture.

description: Art

description: REMAKE THE HOLIDAYS

title: To Givers of Down Payments
description: HOME buyers trying to scrape together enough money to cover the typical 20 percent down payment frequently look to relatives for help.

description: Theater

title: Spare Times Listings for Dec. 28-Jan. 3
description: Around Town

title: A Gilded Island, Swirling With Intrigue
description: FISHER ISLAND, Fla.

title: The After-Studio Apartment
description: AFTER living in assorted roommate situations, Brian Landman bought his first apartment seven years ago. He paid $245,000 for a standard-issue studio in a postwar co-op building on East 35th Street in Murray Hill. His monthly maintenance was in the mid-$700s.

title: Jamming Ritually
description: Cascade to the rhythms, open up your mind/Cut loose from the furious snakes, unwind, the Disco Biscuits sang in Digital Buddha, a song that popped up as excerpts in both their sets on Wednesday night at the Best Buy Theater. Thats as good a mission statement as any for this long-running jam band. The Disco Biscuits were starting their regular year-end stint in New York City, including three more Best Buy shows and New Years Eve at the Theater at Madison Square Garden. Its a familiar and welcome ritual, complete with lasers flashing grids and canopies over the dancing crowd and videos traversing sci-fi geography as the band stays busy with its instruments. The musicians have to be listening to one another intently; often, they stay in the shadows.
