title: Neighborhood Joint: El Sabroso
description: Tony Molina, the owner of El Sabroso, in the garment district of Manhattan, greets each customer with How are you, my friend? before rattling off the days menu.

title: Songs and Laughs for the New Years Eve Countdown
description: PEOPLE dont go out on New Years Eve in anticipation of a great new year. They go out to erase 300-some-odd days of demons and to squeeze in a few more before the ball drops and forces reassessment. Its a night in which everyone gets a free pass for misbehavior, because the next morning, society insists that youre born anew.

title: Secrets Out: No-Frills Lunch Is Served Here
description: Look closely or youll miss it.

title: Promoting Foreman Grills With a Weight-Loss Contest
description: JUST in time for the New Years resolution season, George Foreman Cooking is introducing an elaborate marketing campaign that uses a weight-loss contest to promote the grill brands appliances.

title: Dead Accounts to Close on Broadway
description: Dead Accounts, Theresa Rebecks play starring Katie Holmes and Norbert Leo Butz, will close on Sunday, Jan. 6 at the Music Box Theater, the shows producers announced on Thursday. When it closes the show will have played 27 previews and 44 regular performances.

title: New Video of Fatal Shooting at West Bank Checkpoint Shows Officers Final Shot
description: Sarit Michaeli, a spokeswoman for the Israeli human rights group BTselem, wrote to The Lede on Thursday to draw our attention to the fact that more video of a fatal shooting at a checkpoint in Hebron this month has been posted online.

title: Lawmakers Look to Boost Guns in School
description: While the federal government and some states ponder more rigorous gun control laws after the shootings at a Connecticut elementary school, some Texas legislators have taken the opposite approach. They have emphasized what they see as a need to make firearms more available, and their discussions have included increasing access to guns for teachers and other school personnel.

title: Blogging Up the Race for Speaker
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Seattle Player Wins Appeal of Drug Test
description: The Seattle Seahawks Richard Sherman, one of the N.F.L.s best cornerbacks, on Thursday won his appeal of a positive test for performance-enhancing drugs and will not be suspended.

title: 80 Murder Confession Raises Calls to Require Police to Record Interrogations
description: LIVINGSTON, Tex.  Max Soffar slurred his words in 1980 as he confessed to shooting two teenagers while robbing a Houston bowling alley, a confession that can be heard over the hisses and crackles of an audiotape. Only two hours of at least 26 hours of questioning over three days were recorded, according to the police officers who were at the interrogation.

title: A Plea From the Admissions Office to Go for the Dangerous Essay
description: Daniel Grayson is the associate director of undergraduate admissions at Tufts University in Medford, Mass.

title: GTT
A Price Tag for the Gowanus Cleanup
description: The Superfund cleanup of the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn is expected to cost $467 million to $504 million and will require dredging the 1.8-mile waterway to remove contaminated sediment, the federal Environmental Protection Agency said on Thursday.

title: The Year in Pop
description: The critics Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the years biggest pop trends, and those that will be reshaping the genre for years to come.

title: Fontella Bass, 72, Singer of Rescue Me, Is Dead
description: Fontella Bass, the singer whose 1965 hit Rescue Me was an indelible example of the decades finest pop-soul, died on Wednesday in St. Louis. She was 72.

title: One-Stoplight Town Seeks Just One Mayor
description: LITTLE MOUNTAIN, S.C.  Wanted: a mayor for this tiny South Carolina town.

title: Russia: Ex-Official Called in Graft Case
description: Russian investigators have summoned a former defense minister, Anatoly E. Serdyukov, for questioning on Friday in a corruption case involving the sale of land formerly owned by the military to a private company. The police say the federal government lost $233 million in the case, one of several high-profile investigations into corruption under way in Moscow this winter.

title: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, U.S. Commander in Gulf War, Dies at 78
description: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, who commanded the American-led forces that crushed Iraq in the 1991 Persian Gulf war and became the nations most acclaimed military hero since the midcentury exploits of Generals Dwight D. Eisenhower and Douglas MacArthur, died on Thursday in Tampa, Fla. He was 78.

title: Developers of Wind Farms Run a Race Against the Calendar
description: WASHINGTON  Forget about parties, resolutions or watching the ball drop. To Iberdrola Renewables, New Years Eve will mean checking on last-minute details like the data connections between 169 new wind turbines in New Hampshire, Massachusetts and California and its control center in Portland, Ore.

title: Illinois: Chicago Schools Accused of Discrimination
description: The Chicago Teachers Union filed a suit in federal court on Wednesday charging that the Chicago Public Schools discriminate against African-American teachers and staff members in selecting schools for turnaround, in which faculty and staff members are dismissed and replaced. The lawsuit alleges that the district selects schools with a high percentage of African-American teachers for turnaround, while taking no action against other similarly performing schools. More than half the 347 tenured teachers who were terminated by the district in recent turnarounds were African-American, the lawsuit said, although black teachers make up less than 30 percent of the districts tenured teaching staff.

title: Is Growth Over?
description: The great bulk of the economic commentary you read in the papers is focused on the short run: the effects of the fiscal cliff on U.S. recovery, the stresses on the euro, Japans latest attempt to break out of deflation. This focus is understandable, since one global depression can ruin your whole day. But our current travails will eventually end. What do we know about the prospects for long-run prosperity?

title: The 2012 Sidney Awards, Part II
description: Sixty years ago, scientists believed that schizophrenia was caused by emotional conflict with the patients parents. A cold mother would deliver conflicting messages of hope and rejection and drive her child into madness.

title: Closing Loopholes Isnt Enough
description: REPUBLICANS in Congress say they will do anything rather than raise tax rates. Apparently, that includes rushing headlong over the fiscal cliff and throwing the economy into a possible recession.

title: The Short Life of the Camel Corps
description: The Civil War featured many dazzling innovations: ironclads, hot-air balloons, the Gatling gun. But if armored warships and more powerful guns pointed to the future of warfare, another innovation, hailed at the time as a forerunner of combat to come, certainly did not: the United States Armys Camel Corps.

title: Republicans Must Support Public Financing for Contraception
description: Washington

title: Putting the Choke Further in the Past
description: If there was a subtext to the Nets firing of Avery Johnson two days after Christmas, P. J. Carlesimo had been around long enough to recognize the plot lines sooner than most. He starred in an earlier version of the movie, but long before the classic coach-killing caper became a more spurious whodunit of backdoor maneuvers.

title: The Battle for Aleppo
description: As winter descends, the fightings direction has shifted in favor of the rebels, but it is unclear whether they can maintain an organized campaign.

title: Battle for Syrian City Lays Both Sides Weaknesses Bare
description: ALEPPO, Syria  The sniper walked through the rubble near this citys front lines. He was searching for another spot from where he might catch a Syrian soldier in his rifle scopes cross hairs.

title: Matsui, Star in Two Continents, Is Retiring
description: Like the United States, Japan has its own baseball royalty, and the princes are high school players drafted by the Yomiuri Giants. Being chosen by the hallowed Giants  Japans equivalent of the Yankees, the Lakers and the Cowboys combined  does not guarantee success. But the princes who succeed on and off the field are all but certain to be anointed kings.

title: Gerry Anderson, 83, Dies; Made Futuristic Puppets
description: Gerry Anderson, a British filmmaker who transformed old-fashioned puppets into futuristic action heroes in the 1960s in the hugely popular childrens show Thunderbirds, and later cast real people in series including  U.F.O. and Space: 1999, died on Wednesday in Oxfordshire, England. He was 83.

title: Michigan: Law on Cities in Crisis Is Signed
description: Weeks after Michigan voters repealed a law that gave emergency managers sweeping control over the states most financially troubled cities, Gov. Rick Snyder, a Republican, signed a new law on Thursday determining how the state will handle cities headed into crisis. As with the old law, the new law allows appointed emergency managers to take broad steps like discarding labor contracts, but also allows local officials to find other options.

title: An Affront to Michigan Women
description: Despite clear public support for womens reproductive rights, Michigans Republican-controlled Legislature used the just-ended lame-duck session to ram through harmful measures eliminating insurance coverage of abortions and imposing medically unnecessary regulations on providers of safe and legal abortion care.

title: Irans Slowing of Enrichment Efforts May Show It Wants a Deal, Analysts Say
description: WASHINGTON  By subtly putting its hands on the brakes of its uranium enrichment efforts, Iran may be signaling that it wants to avoid a direct confrontation over its nuclear program, at least in the near term, according to United States and other Western officials. The action has also led some analysts to conclude that Irans leaders are showing signs that theymay be more interested in a deal to end the nuclear standoff with the West.

title: A Tougher Assault Weapons Ban
description: New legislation proposed by Senator Dianne Feinstein in response to the Newtown, Conn., murders would provide a far more effective ban on military-style assault weapons than the loophole-riddled law that lapsed in 2004.

title: Massachusetts: Markey Seeking Senate Seat
description: Representative Edward J. Markey will run for Senator John Kerrys vacant seat, The Boston Globe reported Thursday. Mr. Markey, a Democrat, is one of the first to bid for the seat since President Obama nominated Mr. Kerry last week to be secretary of state. First elected to Congress in 1976, Mr. Markey, 66, has been particularly active on environmental issues. He co-sponsored the climate bill to reduce heat-trapping gases that passed the House in 2009 before stalling. Mr. Kerry is expected to be confirmed, opening up the seat he has held for 28 years. The special election is expected to take place in May or June.

title: Time to Confront Climate Change
description: Four years ago, in sharp contrast to the torpor and denial of the George W. Bush years, President Obama described climate change as one of humanitys most pressing challenges and pledged an all-out effort to pass a cap-and-trade bill limiting greenhouse gas emissions.

title: Do We Still Need Libraries?
The Marketing of Toys Based on Gender
description: To the Editor:

title: Hailing a Cab With an App
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Conservatives and the Republican Party
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking Answers After Newtown
description: To the Editor:

title: Along Coast, Hurricane Left Housing Market in Turmoil
description: John Vento knew exactly how much his home was worth. The retired New York City police officer put his two-family house in the New Dorp Beach area of Staten Island on the market for $580,000 in February. Soon after, he refused an offer of $510,000.

title: 22 Police Officers Kidnapped in Attacks on Pakistani Posts
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistani Taliban kidnapped at least 22 policemen after coordinated attacks on multiple security check posts in northwestern Pakistan on Thursday, Pakistani officials said. Two policemen were reported killed in related gun battles with the militants.

title: Man Admits to Smuggling Asian Fossils of Dinosaurs
description: The description accompanying Lot 49315 at Heritage Auctions in May was striking: a superb Tyrannosaurus skeleton, a remnant of a vanished animal that ruled the food chain of the ancient flood plains that are todays Gobi Desert.

title: NYU Langone Reopens for Surgery as Its Recovery Moves Ahead
description: NYU Langone Medical Center opened its doors to surgical patients on Thursday, almost two months after Hurricane Sandy overflowed the banks of the East River and forced the evacuation of hundreds of patients.

title: Summoned Back to Work, Senators Chafe at Inaction
description: WASHINGTON  Senators bade hasty goodbyes to families, donned ties and pantsuits in lieu of sweat pants and Christmas sweaters and one by one returned to the Capitol on Thursday to begin the business of doing nothing in particular.

title: Will Japan Unapologize to Comfort Women?
description: The New York Timess Tokyo bureau chief, Martin Fackler, writes that Japans new (and former) prime minister, Shinzo Abe, and his conservative government may revise Japans 1993 apology for forcing thousands of women to be sex slaves in the service of Japanese soldiers during World War II.

title: With Focus on Unity, China Embraces Its Pre-Communist Past
description: GUANGZHOU, China  It was 1926, not long after the fall of the Qing dynasty, and much of China had been divided among warlords. In the south, leaders of the young Kuomintang mustered an army. At its head rode Chiang Kai-shek, who called to his side officers he had helped train, and together they marched north to take down the warlords, one by one.

title: 2 Men in Court on Charges They Aided Sri Lankan Terrorists
description: Two men extradited from Canada on charges of supporting a Sri Lankan rebel group that has been designated a foreign terrorist organization by the United States were ordered held without bond Thursday during an appearance in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Suit Settled Over Claims of Sex Abuse at Poly Prep
description: An elite Brooklyn private school agreed to settle a lawsuit brought by former students accusing the school of covering up decades of sexual abuse of hundreds of boys by a star football coach.

title: Once 7-1, a Playoff Shoo-In Is Struggling Just to Get In
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill.  In one sentence Wednesday afternoon, Bears Coach Lovie Smith spoke of the playoffs.

title: Slain in Their Sleep, Afghan Police Are Betrayed by Their Own
description: The fear of insider attacks has been an even bigger concern for Afghan security forces than it has been for NATO and American forces, The Timess Rod Nordland wrote on Friday.

title: Unemployment Deepens Storms Loss as Businesses Stay Closed
description: In the Rockaways, none of the 450 employees of the Madelaine Chocolate Company will receive a paycheck this week. Until a few days ago, the floor of the companys 200,000-square-foot complex was a muddy, sludgy, chocolaty mess, and its factory has temporarily closed. Outside, foiled Santas and candy roses lay victim to the hurricane.

title: Turkish Journalist Accused of Terrorist Plot Is Freed Pending Trial
description: ISTANBUL  A court in Istanbul released Soner Yalcin, a prominent journalist, from prison on Thursday after he had spent nearly two years behind bars, charged with plotting to overthrow the government with 12 other defendants.

title: Rare Choreography of Cooperation for Riders Caught Between an F and an M
description: They toil in a city of haggard indifference and missed connections, where the simplest task can devolve into a competitive sport.

title: Frank Calabrese, Chicago Mob Hit Man, Dies at 75
description: Frank Calabrese, also known as Frankie Breeze, a Chicago loan shark and hit man responsible for at least 13 murders, died in prison on Tuesday in Butner, N.C. He was 75.

title: It Can Go From Liquid to Frozen
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  This being Friday, we have no theme to discuss, so lets get right to whats nice about this late-week puzzle.

title: Giants Hope Rushers, and Offense, Can Reclaim Early Form
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Tom Coughlin said it would take some soul searching from the Giants this week to right a ship sinking toward a long and lonely off-season.

title: Corrections: December 28, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Man Pushed to His Death Under Train in Queens
description: A young woman pushed a man to his death under an oncoming train at the 40th Street-Lowery Street subway station in Sunnyside, Queens, on Thursday evening, law enforcement authorities said.

title: The Equestrian Federation Speaks Out
description: The equestrian organizations chief executive, John Long, offered his views on the Mandarino case and the broader issues it raises for the sport.

title: Feltons Broken Pinkie Reshuffles the Lineup for the Knicks
description: SACRAMENTO  Raymond Felton was the first player to leave the Knicks locker room after a thrilling, last-second 99-97 victory over the Phoenix Suns on Wednesday night. As Felton swung the door open, a loud chorus of cheers and laughter could be heard as teammates high-fived one another.

title: General Schwarzkopf, American Commander, Dies
description: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, who commanded the American-led forces that crushed Iraq in the 1991 Persian Gulf war, has died.

title: Islamists Harsh Justice Is on the Rise in North Mali
description: BAMAKO, Mali  Moctar Tour was strapped to a chair, blindfolded, his right hand bound tight to the armrest with a rubber tube. A doctor came and administered a shot. Then Mr. Tours own brother wielded a knife, the kind used to slaughter sheep, and methodically carried out the sentence.

title: Pacer Finishes 2nd in His 461st and Final Start
description: Tattlers Jet did not finish his career in the winners circle, but he showed characteristic toughness in a sea of mud and snow Thursday at Monticello Raceway. A 14-year-old gelding, he overcame a poor trip to finish a fast-closing second in the 461st and last start of his remarkable 12-year career.

title: Jumping for Show
description: Records show horses competing at equestrian events have tested positive since 2010 for substances like cocaine, antipsychotics and depressants.

title: Carbon Taxes Make Ireland Even Greener
description: DUBLIN  Over the last three years, with its economy in tatters, Ireland embraced a novel strategy to help reduce its staggering deficit: charging households and businesses for the environmental damage they cause.

title: Firefighters Attacker Didnt Hide Past Killing, a Neighbor Says
description: The man who ambushed firefighters in western New York before fatally shooting himself was not shy about discussing his role in a previous killing, neighbors said Thursday.

title: Sudden Death of Show Pony Clouds Image of Elite Pursuit
description: Early on the morning of May 26, Kristen Williams and her daughter, Katie, arrived at a barn on the grounds of the Devon Horse Show, where elite competitors in full dress have entertained spectators for the last century on Philadelphias Main Line.

title: Neediest | Foster Care to Fatherhood
description: Anthony Pantoja grew up shuttling among foster care, group homes and the streets. Today he is a college student, and a father.

title: Father, 21, Seeks to Provide the Life He Never Had
description: In his moments alone, Anthony Pantoja found only temporary sanctuary, so his pencil provided a more reliable means of escape.

title: Cliff Osmond, Prolific Character Actor, Dies at 75
description: Cliff Osmond, a prolific character actor on film and television, most notably in a run of Billy Wilder comedies, died on Dec. 22 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 75.

title: Lottery Numbers
Former Pitcher Sentenced for Attempted Murder Is Reportedly Released
description: The former All-Star reliever Ugueth Urbina was released from a Venezuelan prison Saturday after serving five and half years of a 14-year sentence for the attempted murder of several workers at his familys ranch in October 2005, according to several reports from Venezuela.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Dec. 28, 2012
description: I didnt realize how much I didnt want to be here until I got here.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 10 P.M. (HBO2) COLLATERAL (2004) Jamie Foxx is Max, a taxi driver who picks up Vincent (Tom Cruise, above left, with Mr. Foxx), a man visiting Los Angeles to meet with clients. Max soon discovers that Vincents clients are court witnesses he wants to kill on instructions from a drug dealer (Javier Bardem). Max is then forced to drive Vincent from one assignment to the next. Mark Ruffalo plays the detective who follows the trail of bodies left in their wake. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said that this thriller, directed by Michael Mann, is about a lot of different things, about how Los Angeles lights up at night, how cars become prostheses of ourselves and how driving with the radio on can be bliss. She added: But as with all of Mr. Manns movies, Collateral is finally about men and work, and about how being a man is itself a kind of job.

title: Delhi Gang Rape Patient Has Brain Injury and Is Fighting for Life, Doctors Say
description: The medical condition of the 23-year-old woman who was raped by several men and thrown off a moving bus on Dec. 16 is worse than previous reports had indicated, according to the Singapore hospital where she is being treated.

title: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 28
description: NEWS Even as the world makes plans to recapture northern Mali by force, the Islamists who rule the region show no qualms about continuing their harsh application of Shariah law. At least 14 amputations have been performed since the takeover last spring, and Islamists have warned that others will soon share the same fate. Adam Nossiter reports from Bamako, Mali.

title: Debating the Death Penalty for Rape in India
description: A gang rape in Delhi has revived the debate about which crimes merit the death penalty in India, as calls for justice for the victim have quickly morphed into demands that the six suspects in police custody be executed.

title: Babies, Beasts and the Bizarre From Times Contests Past
description: A dog, standing tall and proud on its hind legs, pushes a wicker carriage along a sidewalk. Inside, a spotted rabbit plays the role of infant. The two actors stare directly into each others eyes.

title: Week 17 Matchups: Sound and Fury, Signifying Something
description: Through a 17-week N.F.L. season, there are certain players who stand out each week as the most interesting story line for their team. With many of the playoff teams already decided, we chose this week to take a look at the players who stood out, not only on the field but off it.

title: App Smart Extra: The Melodies Linger On
description: Streaming music, and streaming radio apps like Pandora and Spotify, were the topics of this weeks App Smart column. They let you listen to music you do not necessarily have in your own collection. They can also be an excellent way to break out of a musical rut and discover new sounds.

title: Lomas Brown, Scott Mitchell and What the Tape Reveals
description: Did Lomas Brown really allow Sean Jones a free shot at his quarterback? A few thoughts:

title: United States Lags in Alzheimers Support
description: This month, the United States Senate Special Committee on Aging released a report examining how five nations  the United States, Australia, France, Japan and Britain  are responding to growing numbers of older adults with Alzheimers disease and dementia.

title: China Toughens Its Restrictions on Use of the Internet
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese government issued new rules on Friday requiring Internet users to provide their real names to service providers, while assigning Internet companies greater responsibility for deleting forbidden postings and reporting them to the authorities.

title: Arguing About the Meaning of Work
description: NEW YORK  It is possible to think of the American political conversation today as a big argument about the nature, meaning and value of work.

title: Q&A: Going Deeper Into FileVault
description: Q.

title: An Industrys Future, Blowing in the Wind
description: As I note in Fridays paper, construction of new wind farms is going to grind to a halt with the end, at least temporarily, of two wind power subsidies. Whats next?

title: Game Theory: The Passion Behind Wreck-It Ralph
description: I grew up when video games were a brand-new form of entertainment. I remember seeing Pong for the first time and thinking it was the cheapest animated show I had ever seen. Once I realized that it was an interactive game and that I could control what was happening on the screen, I was captivated. A love affair was born.

title: A Portrait of Interfaith Giving
description: Dear Diary:

title: Russian Acquittal Escalates Human Rights Feud With U.S.
description: MOSCOW  A judge issued an acquittal on Friday of the only official to have gone to trial in Russia in the case of Sergei L. Magnitsky, a lawyer whose death in prison three years ago inspired the United States Congress to pass a law addressing human rights abuses in Russia.

title: Friday Reading: Going Beyond Disney in Orlando
Week 17 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
description: Jason and Justin Sablich provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy.

title: The Best in Design
description: A celebration of objects and furnishings: the best in design this year from T. See interactive feature >>

title: A Double Shot of Misunderstanding
description: One of the enduring fantasies of the pundit class  most dramatically demonstrated by the ludicrous Politico piece on What Insiders Know  is that all we need to fix our economic problems is to get the great and the good together and bypass those pesky elected officials. Business leaders, in particular, are presumed to have the know-how to deal with all the important issues.

title: Woman Sought After 2nd Fatal Shove Onto Subway Tracks This Month
description: Like so many busy New Yorkers in a hurry to get where they have to go, Sunando Sen peered out over the tracks on an elevated subway stop in Queens on Thursday evening, anxiously awaiting the next train.

title: Daily Report: Online Retailers Push Same-Day Shipping
description: This holiday season, same-day shipping replaced free shipping as the new must-have promotion for e-commerce companies, Stephanie Clifford and Claire Cain Miller report in Fridays New York Times. Same-day shipping is logistically complicated and money-losing  and may not even be a service that consumers want or need, analysts say. But retailers big and small are willing to take the risk. Even the Postal Service has introduced a same-day option for retailers. And the reason is simple: fear of Amazon.com.

title: Moscow Urges Peace Talks on Reluctant Syrians
description: LONDON  Russia has pushed itself to the forefront of efforts to resolve the Syrian crisis with an end-of-year diplomatic flurry aimed at bringing the Damascus regime and the mainstream opposition to the negotiating table.

title: Pearson to Take Stake in Nook Unit
description: 8:35 p.m. | Updated

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Tighter Internet Rules in China, and Thunderbirds Creator Dies
description: New rules issued by the Chinese government Friday will make it easier to monitor who is using the Internet and tamp down some of the vibrant discourse on the countrys Twitter-like microblogs, Keith Bradsher reported. That discourse in recent weeks has publicized sexual and financial scandals that have led to the resignations or dismissals of at least 10 local officials, as well as accounts in Bloomberg News and The New York Times about the wealth of the countrys top leaders. The rules, which come with much greater legal force than earlier regulations, require Internet users to provide their real names to service providers, while assigning Internet companies greater responsibility for monitoring what appears online. The government also included a mandate for businesses in China to be more cautious in gathering and protecting electronic data.

title: Russia Calls for Meeting With Syrian Opposition
description: MOSCOW  Russia has shown a burst of diplomatic energy before talks here on Saturday with the United Nations envoy on Syria, perhaps seeing a chance for a breakthrough that would temper the criticism it has drawn in the West and the Arab world during the course of the nearly two-year-old Syrian conflict.

title: Policy Implications of Capital-Biased Technology: Opening Remarks
description: Ill be writing more about this in weeks to come, but I guess Id better say something right away about the implications of a declining labor share in GDP. Again, the data so far look like this:

title: Environmental Taxes in Ireland
description: Taxes on garbage and fossil fuels are part of Irelands novel strategy to shrink its debt.

title: Suspect in Subway Killing
description: A surveillance video released by the New York Police Department shows a woman suspected of killing a man by pushing him into the path of a subway train on Dec. 27, 2012.

title: What Were Reading
description: Reuters: According to Chinas state news agency, Xinhua, the government will soon enact a set of much stricter food safety laws, partly prompted by a new round of testing of KFC chickens. Abysmal is the word used to describe the governments record on preventing food-borne illness and adulterations

title: The Versatility of Spinach
description: Spinach goes well with all kinds of foods. Its also a green that is easy to find year-round. As Martha Rose Shulman writes in this weeks Recipes for Health:

title: Nets Coach Undone by a Fast Clock
description: The Nets, you might have noticed, are in a big hurry. Yes, they got their shiny new arena, annexed an entire borough of New York City as their territory, all but exhausted themselves scrubbing their image of all traces of New Jersey and years of losing and, worse, years of irrelevance. Which is why they were in such a frantic state after losing 10 of 13 games that in the time it took for their star player to pull his coach-sinking snit out of his bag of tricks, Avery Johnson went from coach of the month in November to N.B.A. road kill in December

title: Ive Just Seen a Fake: Beatles and Presley Top List of Most-Forged Autographs
description: You might want to double-check your beloved autographed copy of Magical Mystery Tour and be certain it was signed by Paul McCartney and not, say Pete McCourtney, or youll be looking like quite the fool on the hill. A ranking of the years most-forged celebrity autographs puts the Beatles near the top of that list, alongside performers like Elvis Presley and Michael Jackson, as well as notable individuals like John F. Kennedy and Neil Armstrong, Reuters reported.

title: The Great Smog of China
description: LONDON  My mornings in my home in Beijing always follow the same routine. Wake up. Make coffee. Check Air Quality Index online. Feel faintly depressed.

title: Motherlodes Greatest Hits, 2012 Edition
description: What do the readers of a blog subtitled Adventures in Parenting like? Relatable parents, writing about the broader questions of being a parent  but with some bling, please.

title: Youth Killed by Hit-and-Run Truck Driver in Queens
description: 9:46 p.m. | Updated An 11-year-old boy was killed by a hit-and-run dump-truck driver in Jackson Heights, Queens, on Friday morning, the police said.

title: Delhi Rape Victims Condition Deteriorates
description: The Singapore hospital treating the 23-year-old woman who was raped by several men in a moving bus on Dec. 16 in Delhi issued the following statement on Friday:

title: Crime Is Up and Bloomberg Blames iPhone Thieves
description: Updated, 11:50 a.m. | Hold onto your iPhones!

title: Mergers That Benefit Market Structure
description: Larry Tabb is the chief executive of the Tabb Group, a financial markets research and strategic advisory firm, and TabbForum, a capital markets community Web site.

title: Great Footage! And Jets Notice
description: Havard Rugland does not have the pedigree one might expect for someone who has become an Internet sensation for kicking a football. He knows next to nothing about the sport. Just ask him to name the quarterback of the New England Patriots or the Denver Broncos.

title: On Our Radar: Promised Land
description: Writing in The Times, A.O. Scott praises Promised Land, Gus Van Sants new film about the battle over fracking, as a film that works, mainly by putting character ahead of story and inviting the actors to be warm, funny and prickly. At the papers Dot Earth blog, however, Andrew C. Revkin suggests that the film may not satisfy many people, not least because its main characters too often border on caricature. For those interested in learning more, check out this video of a Times Talks event in which the paper interviewed Mr. Van Sant and Matt Damon, who stars in the film. And this feature focuses on Mr. Damons screenwriting collaboration with John Krasinski. [The New York Times]

title: The Wayward Essay
description: In its quality of attention and faith in the salvific power of the right words in the right order, the essay resembles nothing so much as a secular prayer. That, at least, was the original point. The essay has proved wayward, which has been the great secret to its longevity.

title: Bouquet Garni
description: Does the term bouquet garni intimidate you? Dont let it! Melissa Clark shows why.

title: Basic Cooking Starts With Stew
description: IF you read enough 19th-century novels, youre likely to run into the description of the ever-bubbling stew pot. Its the caldron at the ready to feed a famished family, a parade of visitors, the hungry vicar on his afternoon stroll or whatever other literary stereotype comes to call.

title: The Music They Made, Spotified
description: For the past five years, Ive been putting together a video feature to accompany the magazines annual The Lives They Lived issue. The sound collage, called The Music They Made, features samplings of songs from musicians who died in the past year. If you want to play the full songs featured in this years video  and why wouldnt you!  you can use the Spotify playlist below.

title: Handled With Care
description: I have been here many times before. Not to this particular library but to others like it. Some have been on college campuses, others in private homes. Some have sprawled through many rooms, including the bathroom; others were confined to a single space. One had no windows; another overlooked a lake. Most were crowded. All were dusty.

title: Paperback Row
description: ZONA: A Book About a Film About a Journey to a Room,  by Geoff Dyer. (Vintage, $15.) In Andrei Tarkovskys 1979 film Stalker, two Russian intellectuals are guided by a tormented fool to a post-apocalyptic government-restricted area called the Zone. (Within the Zone lies the so-called Room, where innermost hopes are revealed and even realized.) In Dyers vivid analysis, he watches himself watching the film, contemplating his own desires and what he considers to be the most distinctive feature of Tarkovskys art: the sense of beauty as force.

title: Editors Choice
description: MARMEE & LOUISA: The Untold Story of Louisa May Alcott and Her Mother,  by Eve LaPlante. (Free Press, $26.) Alcotts toiling, much put-upon mother was the complex core of Little Women; LaPlantes dual biography attempts to save her from invisibility.

title: Up Front
description: Siri Hustvedt has long explored the intersections and interplay of science and storytelling. Her study of neuropsychoanalysis in The Shaking Woman; Or, A History of My Nerves was inspired by Montaigne, and her novels are peopled by deeply philosophical painters, poets and psychiatrists. At the moment, shes just completed another novel and is preparing a lecture on hysteria to present to a neurophysiology conference.

title: The Rope, the App and Van Gogh in Amsterdam
description: AMSTERDAMConsolation for disappointed art lovers who arrive in this city and realize that the Van Gogh Museum is closed for renovation: Follow the red braided rope.

title: Shock to the Senses
description: Since his first extraordinary work, Migraine, was published in 1970, the neurologist Oliver Sacks has been writing a particular kind of medical literature. His detailed explications of a single patients symptoms, his emphasis on the subjective experience of illness, his willingness to share stories from his own life and his references to medical texts from earlier centuries are not only atypical of how most neurologists work today, they defy the status quo. And yet, Sacks work is part of a long tradition of descriptive, narrative, case-oriented medical writing he has himself called romantic.

title: This Weeks Movies: Dec. 28
description: This week, Times critics look at Tom Hoopers Les Misrables, Quentin Tarantinos Django Unchained and the documentary West of Memphis. See all of this weeks reviews here.

title: Approaching the Fiscal Deadline
description: TimesCast: Amid a flurry of activity, time is running out for a deal on taxes. | Keeping Ireland green with carbon taxes. | How doping came to the equestrian world.

title: Strays
description: Not many things are better than a kitten.

title: Crimes Without Punishment
description: It might seem surprising that only now  14 years after Jos Saramago won the Nobel Prize in Literature and two years after his death  is this major novel, first published in Portugal in 1980, appearing in English translation. Then again, politically radical fiction is often a tough sell in our market. While Saramago was an outspoken member of his countrys Communist Party (Marx was never so right as now, he remarked at the outset of the recent global financial crisis), in his best-known work his politics are embedded in allegory or fantasy, allowing readers to view them as loosely humanist or to overlook them entirely. Not so with Raised From the Ground. Still, whats apt to strike readers of this book is not so much that its radical but that its topical. What kind of world, it asks, divides into those who make a profession of idleness and those who want work but cant get it? The novel even ends with descriptions of a kind of Occupy movement  though one with higher stakes  as peasants take over farm estates whose owners have relocated rather than pay their workers a living wage.

title: Must Win
description: The season with a high school team genre has proved particularly durable since Buzz (then H. G.) Bissingers Friday Night Lights became the touchstone some two decades ago, generating its own branded feature film, television series and follow-up e-book. It set the standard for countless similar tales, most notably Michael Lewiss Blind Side and the Academy Award-winning documentary Undefeated.

title: Coming of Age in Rochester
description: In his first novel, Maverick Jetpants in the City of Quality, the Rochester native Bill Peters depicts his hometown as a city in decay, haunted by past glories and racked by vandalism. The narrator, Nate, is about to turn 21. He lives with his mother and her current squeeze, Fake Dad No. 3. Mostly, he drifts and looks for work in a somewhat desultory fashion. His ambition, such as it is, is to join his best friend, Necro (n Andrea: Everyone in Rochester is Italians), at Kodak, the firm that made Rochester famous. But its 1999, and the prospects are bleak for old-fashioned companies like Kodak and for Rust Belt cities like Rochester, whose nickname hasnt been City of Quality since the 1960s.

title: Stage Manager
description: Writing in his memoirs, Tennessee Williams remembers paying a visit to Thornton Wilder after the New Haven opening of A Streetcar Named Desire (1947). Wilder  then at the height of his eminence, having won Pulitzers for both Our Town (1938) and The Skin of Our Teeth (1942)  dismissed Williamss latest effort with the air of one delivering a papal bull, as Williams put it. A lady like Stella, Wilder declared, would never marry a vulgarian like Stanley Kowalski. This character, Williams reflected of his colleague at the time, has never had a good lay. With the perspicacity that would lead him to become, arguably, our greatest postwar playwright, Williams had pretty much hit the nail on the head.

title: They Get Around
description: Joyce E. Chaplin faces a challenge in Round About the Earth. Shes written a 535-page history of circumnavigation, from the voyages of Ferdinand Magellan (1519-22) to the Dutch teenager Laura Dekker (2011-12), which is to say the history of a highly conceptual and antiquated exploit. We all sense that encircling the planet is  or was  quite a feat. But a feat of what, exactly? Today its possible to book a round-the-world air ticket simply by tapping a smartphone. After Magellans expedition did it the first time, one wonders if theres any sense in recording all those who came after.

title: Soviet Dreams
description: A superstitious tradition, meant to protect children from vengeful spirits, persists in Spanish-speaking countries  naming babies for the opposite qualities that benevolent parents might be expected to wish upon their offspring. Parents who want their daughters to lead joyful lives might name them Dolores (sorrows, pain) or Soledad (loneliness). A boy might be called Tristn (the sad one). But Andrey Platonov, the beleaguered Soviet writer who died in 1951 of tuberculosis (contracted from his son, who had been infected in Stalins gulag), seems to have pursued the reverse strategy when, in the mid-1930s, he began work on an allegorical novella entitled Happy Moscow, to see whether it was objectively impossible to write a bona fide Soviet work of fiction.

title: Rogues Gallery
description: Isabella Stewart Gardner was decidedly eccentric. She walked lions, not dogs; drank beer, not sherry; and bathed opposite improving maxims rather than wallpaper patterns. (Some were more ominous than others: Secret of two, secret of God; secret of three, secret of all.) Such behavior made her reputation, though it was her magnificent art collection, assembled with the help of the young Bernard Berenson, that won her lasting fame. In 1903, Gardner opened her Venetian-style gallery  then called Fenway Court  to the city of Boston, enriching generations to come.

title: Secret Loves
description: Near the end of the title story in My Escapee, Corinna Vallianatoss taut and delicate collection, the resident cat at a rest home, the pet meant to comfort and slow the hammering of an unhealthy heart, dies in the lobby. White heads gather around Algebras corpse to sigh and accuse. One woman collapses and is denounced as a fake. Dont pretend you loved that cat, Ginny, the main character, says. To which the womans husband replies: She loved the thought of her. She truly did.

title: A World of Color
description: If only Titian had left us the scathing letters and soul-baring sonnets of his contemporary Michelangelo, whose image as a tortured genius has enchanted biographers since the Renaissance. In their place we have just a smattering of Titians business correspondence and a few official statements. His friendship with the ferocious satirist and pornographer Pietro Aretino is the stuff of speculation. So too are his relations with the models and companions who appear in masterpieces like the Venus of Urbino, which transforms one of Venices highest-priced courtesans into a goddess of love, taunting us with her half-smile while resting her hand in a forbidden realm.

title: Destination: Wellness
description: SO Im sitting in a hotel in upstate New York with my feet in a bucket of warm water charged with electricity when it suddenly hits me that maybe getting well wasnt going to be as much fun as I thought it was going to be.

title: Wellness, A to Y (the Z for Zen Is Silent)
description: Not only is wellness a tough one to define, but its terminology can be equally impossible to interpret. Here is a helpful rundown of some of the terms, attractions and techniques in the land of the well.

title: Hitting the Wellness Circuit
description: Sculpture and healing, massage and mineral baths, on a quest to demystify wellness tourism.

title: A Fish With Nowhere to Hide
description: Luiz Rocha, the curator of ichthyology at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from Belize, where he conducts research on the social wrasse, one of the worlds most endangered fish.

title: For Some, the Slopes. For Her, the Cheese.
description: LETS get this straight up front: Im no skier. But when my French sister-in-law and her athletic husband, who hails from Grenoble (he basically grew up on skis), suggested we meet up for a slopeside family reunion in France last January, I was just as elated as my ski-obsessed husband and children.

title: Sichuans Tibetan Corner, Outside of Time
description: HIGH on the Tibetan plateau, a few dozen red-robed monks of the Lhagang Monastery sat facing one another, rocking back and forth as they chanted with faces turned upward, to the heavens.

title: Restaurant Report: Belcampo Meat Co. in Larkspur, Calif.
description: Though rich in dining options, San Francisco is not quite as besotted with all things meat as other major American cities. New York has the Spotted Pig and Swine; Los Angeles has Animal and Lazy Ox. But the Bay Area, perhaps still under the thrall of flower children grown gray, has yet to welcome a meat temple of its own. Belcampo Meat Co., a restaurant and butcher shop that opened in November in Larkspur, 30 minutes north of San Francisco, aims to change that.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Literary Manhattan

title: Weekend Fare
description: A free tasting of winter ales from France paired with cheeses will be featured on Saturday from 1 to 4 p.m. at Ideal Cheese shop, 942 First Avenue, in Midtown East.

title: Exit Lines
description: MY father spoke to his college roommate every day for 50 years. Though the two lived in different states, 800 miles apart, they were business partners, sounding boards and friends. Then one day my father called and his friend wasnt there. He had died the night before of a terminal illness, which he had never told my father about. The two never said goodbye.

title: Nadal Crosses Off Australian Open as Illness Is Added to Injury
description: Rafael Nadals comeback has been postponed again after six months away from competitive tennis, and this time he said the crux of the matter was not his troublesome left knee.

title: How to Prepare When Next Years Tax Rates Are Anyones Guess
description: This was the week we were supposed to get a grand bargain. Instead, we got an undignified stalemate.

title: The Future of Your Taxes
description: In this weeks Your Money column, I tried to make the case that the current brinkmanship in Washington is a bit of a sideshow to a long-term problem that nobody much wants to discuss: we havent come close to charging ourselves enough money to pay for all of the things weve promised to one another.

title: Inside the List
description: QUOTING QUENTIN:  Ayana Mathiss first novel, The Twelve Tribes of Hattie  reviewed in next weeks issue, and already anointed by Oprah Winfrey  holds steady at No. 10 in its second week on the hardcover fiction list. Mathis told me recently that shes become obsessed with Faulkner, especially with this passage from The Sound and the Fury, in which Quentin, considering suicide in Boston, sees a black man on the bus and has a moment of fleeting insight: They come into white peoples lives like that in sudden sharp black trickles that isolate white facts for an instant in unarguable truth like under a microscope; the rest of the time just voices that laugh when you see nothing to laugh at, tears when no reason for tears. They will bet on the odd or even number of mourners at a funeral. A brothel full of them in Memphis went into a religious trance ran naked into the street. It took three policemen to subdue one of them. Yes Jesus O good man Jesus O that good man.

title: Chronicling Ballets Pain and Passion
description: Henry Leutwylers photographs of the New York City Ballet are collected in a new book, and some are on display at the Foley Gallery.

title: Giving History a Bel Canto Twist
description: WEARING a black dress and clutching a Bible, the mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato walked stiffly on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera during a recent rehearsal for Donizettis Maria Stuarda, which will open on New Years Eve and be broadcast Live in HD on Jan. 19. First kneeling, then standing, her aching movements in the final scenes reflected the title characters physical demise after years of imprisonment.

title: Special Edition of Chrysler 300 to Honor Motown
description: Chrysler has announced that it will offer a special edition Motown version of the 300 sedan. To be introduced at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit and offered for sale in the spring, the car comes with the blessing of Berry Gordy Jr., Motowns founder. Mr. Gordy also appears in a new television advertisement publicizing the Motown edition and promoting Motown: The Musical, a production based on Mr. Gordys life set to open on Broadway in April.

title: Gay Fathers in Israel, in Real Life and in Sitcoms
description: TEL AVIV

title: Friends First, Talk-Show Hosts Later
description: LAST year the comedians Nikki Glaser and Sara Schaefer were preparing to record an installment of their weekly podcast, You Had to Be There, at Ms. Schaefers Brooklyn apartment when Ms. Glaser got a phone call she had been waiting for.

title: Mad Science and Pop Hits
description: FOR pop 2012 was a year of rewired consensus. A year in which Taylor Swift finally accepted her pop-star birthright, waved casually at country and then bravely entered dubstep. A year in which the critic-consensus R&B star was Frank Ocean, who spent most of the year spilling out feelings and then averting his eyes. A year in which Carly Rae Jepsen suffocated the mainstream and then evaporated. A year in which Psy, a B-list Korean pop star, unleashed a video (and song) that became the first to surpass one billion views on YouTube, redefining virality in pop along the way.

title: Bryants Number Lately Has Been 30 a Night
description: An occasional look at N.B.A. statistics and the players behind them.

title: Popcast: The Year in Pop Trends
description: This week on Popcast, Times pop critics Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss larger themes in pop in 2013  a conversation from which this weeks Arts and Leisure roundtable was adapted.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Jami Attenberg discusses her novel The Middlesteins; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Maxwell Carter talks about The Art Forger by B. A. Shapiro; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Dec. 30  Jan. 5
description: BEFORE his death on Aug. 6 Marvin Hamlisch had been scheduled to conduct the New York Philharmonic in its annual New Years Eve gala. Now the orchestra will toast this composer and conductor in ONE SINGULAR SENSATION: CELEBRATING MARVIN HAMLISCH, on PBS stations on Monday at 8 p.m. (Check local listings.)

title: The Eurozones Next Stop
description: The euro zone looks to Asia.

title: Newspaper on Cape Cod Apologizes for a Veteran Reporters Fabrications
description: HYANNIS, Mass.  When an editor at The Cape Cod Times was reading the newspaper last month, she thought an article about the Veterans Day parade from the day before seemed slightly off.

title: Photo Replay: Dec. 28
description: A view of the day in sports, including cyclo-cross in Belgium and World Cup skiing.

title: In a Crisis, Humanists Seem Absent
description: Since the Newtown massacre on Dec. 14, the tableau of grief and mourning has provided a vivid lesson in the religious variety of America. An interfaith service featuring President Obama, held two days after Adam Lanza killed 20 children and six adults at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Connecticut, included clergy members and representatives from Bahai, Catholic, Jewish, Muslim and both mainline and evangelical Protestant congregations.

title: The View from Wisconsin: In Alvarez They Trust
description: Longtime fans of Stanford might be feeling a bit of dj vu come Jan. 1 in Pasadena.

title: Partial Deal With Union Averts a Strike at 14 Ports
description: Dockworkers dropped their threat of an imminent strike against ports from Boston to Houston after their union and shipping companies reached a deal on the main point of their dispute, a federal mediator announced on Friday.

title: 2012: The Year in Pictures
description: Colum McCann reflects on the images  disturbing, inspired and absurd  that shaped our collective consciousness this year.

title: Senate Leaders Set to Work on a Last-Minute Tax Agreement
description: WASHINGTON  At the urging of President Obama, the Democratic and Republican leaders of the Senate set to work Friday night to assemble a last-minute tax deal that could pass both chambers of Congress and avert large tax increases and budget cuts next year, or at least stop the worst of the economic punch from landing beginning Jan. 1.

title: For a Great Salad, Pretend You Are French
description: THERE must be something deep within the collective French psyche that intuitively grasps how to create a good salad. How else can you explain the fact that you can get an excellent one just about anywhere in France? A meal without salad, as a first course or to refresh the palate after the main course, is nearly unheard of there.

title: Five Years Later, Some Countries Still Lag
description: Five years ago, in the fourth quarter of 2007, the United States economy peaked before what became known as the Great Recession set in. Some countries, China and Australia among them, never saw their economies decline, but most did, and some of the largest economies remain smaller than they were in 2007. The world economy  measured by total gross domestic product in 56 countries for which data are available  is now about 6 percent larger. But share prices have yet to fully recover in most countries.

title: Some Subway Arrival Times Are Now Just an Apple Device Away
description: Updated, 3:25 p.m. | The Metropolitan Transportation Authority released a smartphone app on Friday that will provide real-time information on subway arrivals for six of the systems numbered lines and the 42nd Street shuttle.

title: Book Review Podcast: An Expansive Protagonist
description: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Julie Orringer reviews Jami Attenbergs caustic, entertaining and bighearted new novel, The Middlesteins, which stars Edie Middlestein, a woman who is slowly eating herself to death. The book traces the impact of Edies problem on the rest of her family. Ms. Orringer writes:

title: The Sweet Spot | Sweetest of the Year
description: The best moments of 2012 from A. O. Scott and David Carr  two guys, sitting at a table, talking.

title: Tomorrow, It Will Snow, Perfectly
description: The ideal city snowstorm, meteorological Platonists say, blankets the landscape without burying it, beautifies but does not burden, transforms and cocoons without paralyzing or even particularly inconveniencing.

title: The Sweet Spot: Dec. 28
description: The best moments of 2012 from A. O. Scott and David Carr  two guys sitting at a table, talking.

title: Imagining a Future of Lower Hedge Fund Fees
description: Anticipated publication of this column around 2020:

title: Past Turmoil Leaves a Lasting Impression on Todays Investors
description: IF there was one word that applied to investing this year, it was uncertainty.

title: Ratan Tata, the Man Who Brought Tata to the World
description: Ratan N. Tata, chairman of the Tata Group, retired Friday after over two decades at the helm of Indias largest business conglomerate.

title: Cara Shepley and Genshi Ezawa
description: CARA SHEPLEY and Genshi Ezawa are keenly aware of just how different they are. Ms. Shepley is a lawyer from Baltimore; Mr. Ezawa is part of a long line of Soto Zen Buddhist priests in southern Japan.

title: A Coal Sales Ticker Next to a Clean Energy Claim?
description: Dec. 29, 12:38 a.m. | Updated below |Electricity, including that generated by coal combustion, has been a boon for humanity. In fact, theres much truth in the headline on Indur M. Goklanys new analysis for the anti-regulatory Cato Institute: Humanity Unbound: How Fossil Fuels Saved Humanity from Nature and Nature from Humanity. (Ill post more on that paper soon, including an interview with Goklany.)

title: Image of the Day: Dec. 28
The Race to Senior Citizenship
description: Over the next two decades, more and more people will turn 65 each day, but the number of new 25-year-olds available to help pay their health care costs will not rise anywhere nearly as quickly.

title: Headmistress, Jilted Lover, Killer, Then a Force for Good in Jail
description: Jean S. Harris, the private-school headmistress whose 1981 trial for the murder of a prominent Scarsdale, N.Y., physician galvanized a nation with its story of vengeance by a woman scorned, died on Sunday at an assisted-living center in New Haven. She was 89.

title: Dealing With Uncertainty
description: As Paul Sullivan writes in this weeks Wealth Matters column, 2012 was a year of uncertainty, and it looks as if 2013 will at least begin that way. And with investors memories of the collapse in equity markets in 2008 still fresh, financial advisers say they have spent much of the last 12 months trying to get their clients to let go of their fears.

title: Summing Up a Year in Pictures
description: In 2012, The New York Times brought its print and online readers comprehensive, immediate and intimate visual coverage of news around the world and in the New York region, including: brutal urban warfare in Syria, Hurricane Sandys destruction, a hard-fought election victory for President Obama and the mass murder of adults and children at a Connecticut elementary school.

title: A Female Warriors Exploits, Blow by Blow
description: Everything on the stage rumbles during Mulan the Musical. And quite a bit off the stage too.

title: Williams Dismisses View That He Caused Coachs Firing
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Deron Williams claimed responsibility Friday, not for his coachs firing or any perceived role in it, but for the circumstances that prompted it.

title: Wheelies: The Promotion Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: A Peoples Exodus, and a Familys
description: There seems to be a calendar malfunction with the presentation of The Last Seder at Theater Three. The eight-day Jewish December holiday that ended recently is Hanukkah, the Festival of Lights. Passover and its Seder, the traditional meal and retelling of the exodus from Egypt? Thats in the spring.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Jack Kirbys Kamandi
description: Jack Kirby, who died in 1994, was one of the comic-book industrys most famous creators. Much has been written about his contributions to Marvel Comics  he worked with Stan Lee in creating the Fantastic Four, the Incredible Hulk and the X-Men, among others  and the continuing legal battle in which Mr. Kirbys family is trying to win the copyright to those figures.

title: A Long-Closed Park Is Soon to Reopen, Improved Yet Still Hard to Reach
description: All David Shuffler wanted to do when he was 14 years old was play basketball on the street and go to Starlight Park  which despite its name was a dimly lighted, dusty sliver tucked between the Bronx River and the Sheridan Expressway.

title: A Buildup of Building Permits
description: The good news: Building permits for new developments are back on the rise, which means much-needed apartments should soon follow. The bad news: It still wont be enough.

title: The Rental Tide Subsides
description: Apartment rents in New York City have been rising rapidly for several years, but signs are now emerging that the market has hit a speed bump and is finally shifting to a slower gear.

title: The Sport of Tycoons
description: IT was a year of record-high sales for luxury real estate. But 2012 will also enter the books for its chart-topping listings, as sellers sought to ride the wave of irrational exuberance for trophy properties.

title: Woman Dies After a Gang Rape That Galvanized India
description: NEW DELHI  As protests grew in India Saturday over the death of a young woman who was raped in Delhi this month by several men in a moving bus, police said her attackers would be charged with murder.

title: Video Shown of Apparent Execution of Afghan Soldier
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Mohammad Jans killers did not even do him the decency of looking him in the eye.

title: Freedom of Choices
description: I appreciated Glamours latest cover story, 500 Ways to Just Be Yourself, styled with verve by Anne Christensen on the adorable Anne Hathaway. But whos counting?

title: Dreams of Open Everything
description: Software is not merely about automating every aspect of our lives anymore. Some of its makers want to change the way we all interact, spreading their supposed egalitarian excellence.

title: Union and N.H.L. to Discuss New Offer
description: After owners made an extensive new proposal, the N.H.L. and the players union agreed Friday to resume bargaining this weekend in a bid to end the 104-day lockout and salvage the 2012-13 season.

title: Bouquet Garni Basics
description: This weeks video shows how to make a bouquet garni, which basically means tying up a little bouquet of herbs with kitchen string and throwing them in bubbling liquid  a stew or soup (like Scotch broth), or a pot of beans or grains. The herbs give up their flavor to the pot, and tying them up makes them easy to dispose of so you dont need to pick out thyme branches as you eat.

title: Childhood, Uncensored
description: LAUREN MYRACLE has been called Satan, a pedophile, and a corrupter of youth, yet her series of books about a trio of Atlanta teenagers, written entirely in text messages, has sold a total of 1.5 million copies. She has been hailed as this generations Judy Blume for her candor, but outraged parents have lobbied to ban her books, which tackle topics like erections, that awkward first bra purchase, and clueless flirting that leads one sophomore to have a hot-tub encounter with a teacher. (Spoiler: her BFFs rescue her in the nick of time.)

title: Frustrations With Robocalls, and the Joy of the Ordinary
description: I LOVE going back over the year and looking at readers responses to my column. It provides a perspective I lack when Im focusing on one column at a time and receiving comments piecemeal.

title: In a 5-Year Comparison, the U.S. Recovery Fares Well
description: Five years ago, the world economy seemed to be doing fine.

title: Last Call for a Mumbai Cab
description: The Padmini taxi, a mainstay on Mumbais streets for decades, is being phased out as the city modernizes its cab fleet.

title: Shedding Door Pulls, Mumbai Taxis Rattle Into History
description: MUMBAI, India

title: Art Insurance Losses from Hurricane Sandy May Reach $500 Million
description: Two months after Hurricane Sandy caused severe flooding in many Chelsea galleries, the bill for the art worlds recovery is shaping up to be hefty. By mid-November, AXA Art Insurance, one of the largest art insurers, estimated that it would be paying out $40 million, and a Reuters report last week quoted industry estimates suggesting that insurance losses for flooded galleries and ruined art may come to as much as $500 million  or the rough equivalent of what the art insurance business takes in each year. That would amount to the largest loss the art world and its insurers have ever sustained.

title: Stretching Trucks Mileage
description: PERHAPS youve recently been surprised to drive up behind an 18-wheeler on the Interstate whose trailer doors appeared to be ajar. No need to be alarmed: what you saw was probably one of several attempts at improving the fuel economy of long-haul trucks.

title: Another Journey Comeback Tour
description: TESTED 2012 Dodge Journey R/T

title: Oxymoron From Italy: The Civilized Supercar
description: MARANELLO, Italy

title: Thrilling by the Dozen
description: The F12 succeeds the 599 GTB, assuming the role of Ferraris top two-seat grand touring machine.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: A celebration of the writers, thinkers, athletes, scientists and others who died in 2012.

title: Anthony Wont Return to Face Kings
description: SACRAMENTO  Carmelo Anthony will miss his sixth game of the season Friday night when the Knicks play the Sacramento Kings. Anthony, who has a hyperextended left knee, did not participate in the Knicks shootaround, but he did appear to be walking better than in the previous two days.

title: Living In | Chelsea
description: A 27-block neighborhood with a diverse housing stock, from low-slung to high-rise, and affordable to luxury.

title: Calling Activists and Artists of All Stripes
description: IF West 23rd Street needed putting on a map, a cartographer could perhaps rely on a couple of its pop music landmarks: the Chelsea Hotel, once an inspiration for artists like Leonard Cohen, Bob Dylan and Joni Mitchell (as in her classic Chelsea Morning); and, just across the street, the century-old former Y.M.C.A. building that is said to have sparked the Village Peoples late-70s anthem of the same name.

title: The Week in New York Region Pictures, Dec. 28
description: Subjects include the popular Peppermint Pig candy from Sarasota Springs; Christmas in areas hit hard by Hurricane Sandy; and a finback whale that washed ashore in Breezy Point.

title: Less Familiar, but Still a SoHo Presence
description: BACK in the late 1960s and the 1970s, when SoHo had the intimacy and cohesion of a small village, nearly everyone knew Shael Shapiro. The slight, gentle architect with a flair for rescuing decaying buildings was a fixture in this onetime center of the citys art world. Even well into the 1980s, as SoHo began morphing into an outdoor shopping mall, his was a familiar face.

title: Q & A
description: Liability for Injured Workers

title: Pakistan to Lift YouTube Ban, as a Viral Video Star Is Welcomed Home
description: Pakistans interior minister announced on Friday that the country plans to lift a ban on YouTube that was imposed in September, following violent protests over a crude anti-Islam film uploaded to the site by an Egyptian-American. The government acted to rescind the ban just hours after the star of one of the years most popular YouTube videos, a singing Pakistani fishmonger, was given a heros welcome upon his return to the city of Lahore from Britain.

title: The Evolving Style of Michelle Obama
description: A selection of sheaths, prints, gowns and cardigans worn by the first lady.

title: First in Fashion
description: ITS a good bet that when Michelle Obama accompanies her husband to his inaugural next month, and later the round of balls, she will not be thinking of her critics or those White House aides who once fretted about the political fallout from her designer fashion. Thats because she has turned the seemingly frivolous into political capital of her own.

title: A Mountain Goat for Top Poet Perch?
description: If one were establishing the odds of a songwriter being named the United States Poet Laureate, the logical favorite might be Bob Dylan. Or Paul Simon. But what about John Darnielle?

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $21,450,000
description: Throughout his career as a developer, David Edelstein has had a knack for buying low and selling high, and he has done it again with the Upper East Side town house that he owned with his wife, Susan, at 122 East 70th Street. The five-story brick and limestone house, which they bought for $12.85 million in 2010, sold for $21.45 million, making it the biggest sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Watching Dancers Grow, as Cultivated by a Daredevil
description: PARIS  On May 22, 1987, two female dancers in green leotards and black tights stood on the empty stage of the Palais Garnier here, in a pool of light. The women, hands on hips, each swiveled a point-shoe tip on the floor idly and glanced up at two golden cherries inexplicably suspended over their heads. Then one gave an almost imperceptible shrug and walked off, and the other began to dance, suddenly galvanized by a rhythmic, electronic crash of sound.

title: An Illustrated Talk With Maurice Sendak
description: When Christoph Niemann stumbled on a Fresh Air interview with Maurice Sendak, wild things started to transpire.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A five-bedroom house in Mendham, N.J., and a  five-bedroom French Provincial in Great Neck, N.Y.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Battery Park City condo, an Upper West Side condo and a Park Slope condo.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Dec. 28
description: Subjects include the New York City Ballet, Back to Back Theater and the Crossing.

title: Ancient Arts Center Discovered Under Romes Piazza Venezia
description: ROMEEighteen feet below one of Romes most-trafficked junctions is a 900-seat arts center dating back to the second-century reign of Emperor Hadrian, Italian archaeologists have announced.

title: Friday Night Music: Feist and Mountain Man
description: Yes, its early, but Im fiscally exhausted, and am calling it a day. No particular reason to post this performance; its just that I happened to stumble across this wonderful live version of Undiscovered First, which I especially like because the performers seem tired and out of it until they start playing, and then you watch the power of the song take over:

title: On the Worlds Plates, a Bit of New York
description: HONG KONG

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Dec. 28
description: More photographs.

title: Democratic Establishment Voices Support for Markeys Bid to Succeed Kerry
description: The Democratic ranks are closing behind Representative Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts in the race to succeed Senator John Kerry, who hopes to become secretary of state.

title: Lawmakers Suggest New Rules to Speed Up Senate Business
description: A bipartisan group of eight senators on Friday proposed a detailed set of Senate rule changes that could speed the legislative process considerably but would stop short of the most dramatic changes to the filibuster that some Democrats are demanding.

title: Back Finds a Taste of Success With Tijuana Club
description: With the Mexican Apertura set to kick off next week, Club Tijuana left back Edgar Castillo is hoping to build off his success in a championship-winning season in 2012.

title: On Bended Knee? Not Always
description: WHEN it comes to fevered pitches spoken from the heart, December is truly the month for marriage proposals. With 2012 wrapping up, a year when neither recession nor high wind and water got in the way of those seeking memorable ways of prompting a yes! from the targets of their affections, we searched high and low for the most interesting proposals submitted this year to the Weddings/Celebrations pages of The Times.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kashmir and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Kashmir, New York, Germany and Nepal.

title: Questions Remain Over Hewletts Big Charge on Autonomy Acquisition
description: The $5 billion fight over accusations of improper accounting brought by Hewlett-Packard shows no sign of abating.

title: BMW Recalling 2,385 Motorcycles for Kickstand Problem
description: BMW is recalling 2,385 of its 2012-13 motorcycles to keep gravity from having its way with them.

title: Bahrain Detains Officer for Slapping Man
description: Although Bahrain has previously failed to prosecute members of its security forces caught on video shooting unarmed protesters, this week an officer who slapped a man with a baby in his arms was detained after video of the incident attracted wide attention.

title: At a Gastro Pub, an English Bent
description: THERE is much to like about the Rocky Hill Inn. Tucked into a crossroads kind of town in central New Jersey, the homey spot, with roots back to 1745, draws a local, multigenerational crowd to its bustling tavern and serene dining room.

title: Small-Plate Offerings in a Spirited Setting
description: CAN a restaurant earn a rating of Dont Miss if the reviewer had a bad experience on the first of two visits? It can if I am the reviewer and the restaurant is as good as Lula Trattoria in Mineola.

title: For the 40th Year, Diversity
description: As the Long Island wine industry enters its 40th year in 2013, the conventional notion that merlot is its defining specialty continues to be strongly challenged.

title: TV Where Too Far Is Never Far Enough
description: Our big dilemma going into the end of the season is whether we may actually be pushing the envelope too far, says the protagonist of The King of Pain, one of 2012s most enjoyable novels for anyone who is a fan of reality television or simply likes monitoring the continuing train wreck that its more tawdry regions have become.

title: Full of Hospitality, and Exuberantly Greek
description: PONTOS TAVERNA, just half a block from the Garden Cinema in downtown Norwalk, is an old-fashioned Greek place, with a family atmosphere that comes straight from the owner. Nikolaos Kiriakidis opened Pontos in April of 2011 with his seven siblings; his father, Teddy (the chef); and his mother, Anna (the hostess). We worked in other restaurants, Nikolaos Kiriakidis explained, and finally decided to open our own.

title: Main Facade Intact at Ladies Mile Landmark, but Damage Is Serious
description: News of a facade collapse on Tuesday at the former ONeill & Company dry-goods emporium conjured images of significant architectural loss. This gleaming white facade on the Avenue of the Americas, from 20th to 21st Streets, is among the largest single expanses of ornamental cast-iron in the city. Its signature elements  gold-colored beehive domes at each corner turret and Hugh ONeills name boldly inscribed in the pediment  make it especially memorable.

title: For 12 Days of Christmas, 6 Brandenburg Concertos
description: Almost a year ago Trinity Church announced that it would cut back its remarkable music program. The offerings and their quality had blossomed since the 2010 arrival of Julian Wachner as director of music and arts, but they did not come cheap.

title: A Taste of Americana, Off the Bone and on Tap
description: When I heard about Holy Smoke, a barbecue spot in Mahopac, from three people  all food connoisseurs  in four days, I knew I needed to check it out. Though it has been around since 2004, it is on a sleepy residential strip of Route 6N, and so has remained somewhat of a secret. Not among local residents, however. And not among the craft beer and barbecue lovers who visit from around the New York City area. Holy Smoke was rocking the first time I went. Diners enter through the no-fuss bar, where, on that visit, people were lined up and crowding around the rooms high-top tables. The proprietor, Chris Casino, was pouring the brews  Holy Smoke has 30 taps devoted to such delicious and artfully named drafts as Tregs Mad Elf and Southern Tier Old Man Winter, and an impressive lineup of bourbons as well. If you are a Budweiser or wine drinker, however, you are pretty much out of luck (they do offer Sutter Home by the glass).

title: Home for the Holidays, or Not: The Ultimate Holiday Escape
description: Thank you for your responses to our call for expat holiday posts. We received funny and sad, heart-wrenching and heartwarming posts and comments.

title: Trying, Desperately, to Lose the Family Baggage
description: Laurel Ollstein, the author of Esthers Moustache, which is playing at the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch, said in an interview recently that her new comedy has a magic realism quality to it.

title: Men Doing Yoga: Better Skip the Headstands
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebrating Heritage, and Drawing Others In
description: EAST ISLIP, N.Y.

title: Week in Pictures for Dec. 28
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the popular Peppermint Pig candy from Sarasota Springs; Christmas in areas hit hard by Hurricane Sandy; and a finback whale that washed ashore in Breezy Point.

title: Beached Whale Buried After Necropsy
description: The necropsy of the emaciated 60-foot finback whale that beached itself at Breezy Point in Queens found lesions in the animals stomach and kidneys on Friday, but it is not clear what, if anything, they had to do with the animals death, a biologist with the National Marine Fisheries Service said.

title: Digital Diary: Facebook Poke and the Tedium of Success Theater
description: Theres a big problem in social media right now.

title: Seeking the Why Behind Horrific Acts
description: To the Editor:

title: Wal-Mart in Mexico
description: To the Editor:

title: A Place to Reflect
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill Cunningham | Christmas Week
description: On the Street: New Yorkers on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day, in Bryant Park and Rockefeller Center.

title: Republican Holiday Blues
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitman in Washington
description: Among the countless Northerners shocked by the Union defeat at Fredericksburg, Va., in December 1862 was the Brooklyn poet and journalist Walt Whitman. In Whitmans case the shock was personal: his brother George was among the wounded. He quickly packed his bags and rushed south to the Union position. When Whitman arrived at the field hospital set up in a mansion, he found a scene from hell, watched over by an imposing angel: Clara Barton moved amid screams of surgery, ministering to youths, bandaging the bleeding and soothing the dying with low-spoken words and water.

title: Sprawling Memphis Aims to Be a Friendlier Place for Cyclists
description: MEMPHIS  John Jordan, a 64-year-old condo appraiser here, has been pedaling his cruiser bicycle around town nearly every day, tooling about at lunchtime or zipping to downtown appointments.

title: Museum of History & Industry in Seattle
description: A revamped History & Industry Museum has a new home on Lake Union in Seattle.

title: Ryan Wants to Be Jets Coach for Next 15 Years
description: In an animated news conference Friday, Jets Coach Rex Ryan vehemently denied a report that he would be looking to leave the team if the owner Woody Johnson did not make off-season upgrades to the offense.

title: Woman Helped Firefighters Killer Get Gun He Used in Ambush, Police Say
