description: The police arrested a woman in western New York on Friday who they said helped a man acquire the weapon he is believed to have used to kill two firefighters in an ambush that left two others injured.

title: Iran: Navy Begins War Games Near Vital Waterway
description: Irans naval forces began six days of war games on Friday in the Gulf of Oman near the Strait of Hormuz, the narrow waterway considered vital to international oil tanker traffic. Accounts in the state-run news media said the war games, covering a 400,000-square-mile area, were devised to test combat ships, submarines, reconnaissance methods and a new version of the Thunder surface-to-air midrange missile. The official Islamic Republic News Agency quoted a commander, Rear Adm. Habibollah Sayyari, as saying the exercises were meant to transmit a message of friendship to neighbors and display the armed forces military capabilities. Iran, which periodically conducts such naval maneuvers, has said it could close the Strait of Hormuz as retaliation for Western sanctions imposed over Irans disputed nuclear energy program.

title: The Taboo of Menstruation
description: Bettiah, India

title: Place of Prominence for Mr. Met
description: Having gutted their team of veteran players during the off-season, the Mets might be forgiven for trying to usher in someone that fans might recognize. That someone is Mr. Met.

title: Italy: Departing Leader Backs a New Centrist Coalition
description: Mario Monti, the departing caretaker prime minister, said Friday that he would back a centrist grouping in national elections expected in February. Mr. Monti, left, governed for 13 months before resigning this month. Although he said that he would not be a candidate  as a senator for life, he does not need to run in elections  his statement solidifies him as a de facto third-party leader. Traditionally, political groups have named a candidate for prime minister before elections. The grouping led by Mr. Monti, who in recent days has been endorsed by the powerful Roman Catholic Church, will challenge the center-right leader, former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, who has adopted a populist stance critical of the euro; and the center-left leader, Pierluigi Bersani, whose Democratic Party is leading in polls.

title: Papers Show Rare Friction for Thatcher and Reagan
description: LONDON  The bond between Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and President Ronald Reagan, both in office in the 1980s, has become a kind of gold standard, showing what the special relationship between Britain and the United States can be when their leaders share a political creed.

title: Vikings Still Trust Their Passer (Often to Hand Off)
description: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  The details sound like a folk song. Minnesota Vikings quarterback Christian Ponder married on a Monday two weeks ago, just across the state line in Hudson, Wis., with no witnesses besides his bride  the ESPN broadcaster Samantha Steele  and the St. Croix County commissioner who presided.

title: Save Mali Before Its Too Late
description: Bamako, Mali

title: Card-Table Romance Brings Marriage
description: Janet Robertson of Timonium, Md., outside Baltimore, and R. Jay Becker of New York City met at the 2011 Summer Nationals in Toronto. Becker proposed on a beach in Bali at sunset on March 1, and they are getting married Sunday at the home of Andrea and Lew Finkel in Jupiter, Fla.

title: Standing on Tradition While Stretching the Boundaries of Bluegrass
description: The Infamous Stringdusters, who headlined the Bowery Ballroom on Thursday night, have the lineup of a traditional bluegrass band: fiddle, banjo, Dobro, guitar and bass. They played and sang like one, too, with flying fingers and close harmonies, when they took up bluegrass standards like Orange Blossom Special or Deep Ellum Blues. But in the years since the group emerged from Nashville in 2007, the Stringdusters, like a lot of other young string bands, have ignored purism, applied their virtuosity to untraditional tunes and structures and found a wider audience along the jam-band circuit.

title: Glimpses of France Through the Centuries
description: Have you seen a Monet yet? a visitor in the third gallery of the Wadsworth Atheneums cleverly named Medieval to Monet show murmured to her friend. She was afraid shed missed something among the paintings of religious subjects, mythological scenes and extravagantly decked-out aristocrats.

title: Versions of Sugar Plums
description: How can anyone foresee the career developments of individual ballet dancers? Stand back, and they seem determined by the whims of fate. Close up, fate seems scarcely involved. We all know that intensely human matters contribute: directorial taste, personal talent, discipline, health and character.

title: Loss of Inouye Means Loss of Clout for Hawaii
description: HONOLULU  No man is an island. But in Hawaii, Daniel K. Inouye sure seems like one.

title: A Place Comfortable With Boeing, Anarchists and Frasier
description: SEATTLE  Everything connects. The first commercial aircraft made by Boeing, in 1919, hangs from the ceiling. It has no wheels because it regularly landed on Lake Union here after airmail runs to Canada. You can see that lake through a hole in the floor of this building, a former Naval Reserve Armory that was built out over the water in 1942. And above that hole now rises a commissioned 65-foot-high sculpture made by John Grade from the planks of a century-old schooner that also plied Lake Union.

title: Eight Are Charged With Chilean Singers 1973 Murder After Military Coup
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Eight retired army officers were charged on Friday with the murder of a popular songwriter and theater director, Vctor Jara, who was tortured and killed days after the 1973 military coup in a stadium that had been turned into a detention center.

title: Legs and Legends in a Domestic Setting
description: New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Senate Passes $60.4 Billion for Storm Aid; Bills Fate in House Is Unclear
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate approved $60.4 billion in emergency spending on Friday to pay for recovery efforts in states ravaged by Hurricane Sandy, at one point fending off a Republican bid to reduce the aid package by more than half.

title: Federal Power to Intercept Messages Is Extended
description: WASHINGTON  Congress gave final approval on Friday to a bill extending the governments power to intercept electronic communications of spy and terrorism suspects, after the Senate voted down proposals from several Democrats and Republicans to increase protections of civil liberties and privacy.

title: A Fierce Playmaker Who Shrugs Off Praise
description: CINCINNATI  Choosing his favorite catch as a Bengal would figure to be a strenuous exercise for A. J. Green, what with the one-handed miracle at Kansas City, the double-coverage touchdown against the Steelers and that end-zone fade in Denver all vying with a few other candidates.

title: Russian Adoption Ban Brings Uncertainty and Outrage
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin on Friday signed into law a ban on adoptions of Russian children by American citizens, apparently blocking the departure from Russia of hundreds of orphans who had already been told that they would soon go home with new parents.

title: Hurricane Sandy Alters Utilities Calculus on Upgrades
description: After Hurricane Sandy wreaked havoc with power systems in the Northeast, many consumers and public officials complained that the electric utilities had done far too little to protect their equipment from violent storms, which forecasters have warned could strike with increasing frequency.

title: Revisiting Crimes, From the Broker Who Kept a Key, to the Burglar With Bricks
description: In Midtown Manhattan, a door opened, and an empty apartment presented itself. A man entered with a long tool in his hand and got right to work. He had no idea that a small, high-definition camera was secretly recording his movements.

title: New Effort in Congress to Extend Disputed Farm Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Hoping to stave off the expiration of dozens of farm programs and a return to an antiquated 1949 farm law that could lead to a doubling of the price of milk, Senate and House leaders worked Friday to devise legislation that would extend the current farm bill.

title: Delhi Rape Victims Trauma Too Severe to Overcome
description: A 23-year-old woman, whose rape in Delhi on Dec. 16 galvanized thousands to protest for better treatment of women, died on Saturday morning. The full statement from Kelvin Loh, chief executive of Mount Elizabeth Hospital, where she was being treated, is below:

title: A Record Worth Wilting For: Death Valley Is Hotter Than ...
description: FURNACE CREEK, Calif.  For Death Valley, a place that embraces its extremes, this has long been an affront: As furnace-hot as it gets here, it could not lay claim to being the hottest place on earth. That honor, as it were, has gone since 1922 to a city on the northwestern tip of Libya.

title: Counting Blessings After a Harrowing Storm Escape
description: When Hurricane Sandy hit New York City, Yuliana Oleynik and Stanislav Izgiayev trekked for three miles through flooded streets to deliver their two children to safety. Their son Nicholas, then 10 months, rode atop Mr. Izgiayevs shoulders, while Ms. Oleynik was responsible for their other child, Isaac, whom she was quite literally carrying: She was seven and a half months pregnant.

title: Covering J. R. Smith
description: J. R. Smith of the Knicks shows off his 70-plus tattoos.

title: F.D.A. Clears Anticlotting Drug by Bristol and Pfizer
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved Eliquis, an anticlotting drug that has been highly anticipated by cardiologists and is expected to be a blockbuster for Bristol-Myers Squibb, which will make the drug, and Pfizer, which will help market it.

title: Covering J. R. Smith: A Knick Talks About His Tattoos
description: Knicks guard J.R. Smith broke for the baseline Wednesday night, caught the ball and went airborne in one sweeping motion, split his legs in the course of his leap, and drained the game-winner against the Phoenix Suns with a flick of his right wrist while falling into the stands. It was, for sure, a certain kind of body art.

title: Afghan Prosecutor Faces Criticism for Her Pursuit of Moral Crimes
description: HERAT, Afghanistan

title: Still Waiting for Sandy Relief
description: Republicans havent made it easy for the Northeast to get the $60.4 billion in aid it needs to recover from Hurricane Sandy. They have objected to the amount  which is considerably less than the $82 billion requested by the regions governors  and tried to slash it. They have demanded that $3.4 billion of the aid for flood control be offset by spending cuts in other programs. And in the Senate, as on virtually all bills, they filibustered the aid package proposed by President Obama.

title: Keeping Parolees Out of Prison
description: To cut state corrections costs, which have quadrupled over the last decade to about $52 billion annually, many states are remaking hair-trigger parole systems that send large numbers of people back to jail, not for new crimes but for technical violations like failing a drug test or missing an appointment with a parole officer.

title: Guns and Mental Illness
description: Many years ago, when I was a young reporter at Texas Monthly magazine, I spent the better part of six months in the company of a man who suffered from schizophrenia. His name was Fred Thomas; he was 23 years old; and he had been steadily deteriorating since high school, which is when most men first show symptoms of the disease.

title: Revival of Hitachi the Company Is a Detriment to Hitachi the City
description: HITACHI, Japan  The biggest annual loss on record by a Japanese manufacturer jolted executives into action at the Hitachi Corporation, the century-old electronics and engineering behemoth that takes its name from this wind-swept industrial city on the Pacific Coast.

title: In Russia, Exile in Comfort for Leaders Like Assad
description: BARVIKHA, Russia  A few years back, before he settled in this bucolic town in a pine forest near Moscow, Askar Akayev, then the president of Kyrgyzstan, had a very stressful day.

title: Lottery Numbers
They Have Their Pride
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Well, you knew it was bound to happen. Someone was going to try to break the quadruple stack, and if you were going to take an educated guess and say that that someone might be Joe Krozel, youd be correct.

title: Corrections: December 29, 2012
description: NATIONAL

title: The Deadly Fantasy of Assault Weapons
description: Adam Lanza shot 20 children and six adults at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., using a semiautomatic, military-style assault rifle made by Bushmaster. William Spengler Jr. used the same type of Bushmaster rifle to kill two firefighters last week in Webster, N.Y. The Washington snipers, John Allen Muhammad and Lee Boyd Malvo, also used a Bushmaster in a spree that killed 10 people in 2002.

title: Former Greek Official Is Said to Have Obstructed Tax Inquiry
description: ATHENS  A former Greek finance minister appeared to be implicated Friday in the tampering of the so-called Lagarde list of Greeks with Swiss bank accounts after prosecutors revealed that three of his relatives had been removed from the list.

title: 414 Homicides in 12 Is a Record Low for New York City
description: Murders in New York have dropped to their lowest level in over 40 years, city officials announced on Friday, even as overall crimes increased slightly because of a rise in thefts  a phenomenon based solely on robberies of iPhones and other Apple devices.

title: Bowl Game Mirrors Season as Rutgerss Hope Peters Out
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  It was not the type of game that deserved extra plays, but the Russell Athletic Bowl provided them anyway Friday night, going to overtime to produce a 13-10 victory for Virginia Tech against Rutgers, decided by Cody Journells 22-yard field goal.

title: Rape in the Worlds Largest Democracy
description: The brutal gang rape of a young woman in New Delhi this month has cast a cold light on how badly India treats its women.

title: Nets Beat the Bobcats but Pine for Jackson
description: In a quiet moment of a dreary Friday night at Barclays Center, a single voice screeched from the lower bowl, with emphatic desperation.

title: Dwindling Adoptions
description: When Russias president, Vladimir Putin, signed a law on Friday banning the adoption of Russian children by Americans, it brought the issue of international adoptions by United States citizens back into the spotlight.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 29, 2012
description: The hour for immediate action is here. It is now.

title: As Walmart Makes Safety Vows, Its Seen as Obstacle to Change
description: When Walmarts chief executive, Michael Duke, appeared at a Council on Foreign Relations meeting in New York this month, a raucous crowd of protesters awaited him. Walmart was confronting reports of bribery in Mexico, a wave of labor demonstrations in the United States and, perhaps most critically, questions about a grisly fire that had killed 112 workers at a Bangladeshi garment factory used by several Walmart suppliers.

title: The One-Two Punch of Chinese Web Censorship
description: Our colleague Keith Bradsher reports on Chinas efforts to tighten the reigns on the Internet, issuing new rules on Friday requiring Internet users to provide their real names to service providers, and giving companies more responsibility to delete forbidden posts and report them to authorities.

title: What to Expect in New York in 2013
description: The Timess Metro reporters forecast what will make news in the city and region in the coming year.

title: Grief and Anger in India After Death of Delhi Rape Victim
description: The death of a 23-year-old woman who came to symbolize the horrible treatment women face daily in India after she was raped by several men on a moving bus prompted sorrow and rage in India on Saturday morning.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Holiday on Tuesday (New Years Day)
description: NEW YORK

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: A Trainer Keeps Up With His Toddler
description: Sunday is the one day of the week when Court Wing, the head trainer and a founder of CrossFit NYC, doesnt train clients in the high-intensity, boot-camp-style conditioning routine that he describes as a mix of powerlifting, track and field, and gymnastics. That is not to say that Mr. Wing, 44 and a Seattle native, doesnt work out. His Sundays are usually devoted to recovery work  fitness-fan-speak for flexibility and range-of-motion training. He also exercises by chasing his 20-month-old son, Asher, around his apartment in Astoria, Queens, while his wife, Morgan, 36, a social worker, takes a bit of well-deserved rest.

title: A Wish List for Next Year in New York
description: Although it is hard to recall what we obsessed over before the emergencies of very recent memory, it was, in fact, a long and eventful year in the life and culture of New York City. We fought about teacher evaluations and a plan for the New York Public Librarys central branch to move rarely used books offsite. We watched gleefully as members of the Park Slope Food Co-op squabbled with parliamentary intensity over whether to introduce a boycott of Israeli products.

title: A Soul Surfer Who Dances With Winter Waves
description: NOW that beach weather has finally rolled round, Banshidhar Medeiros, 59, a factory worker from Queens and a lifelong surfer, can be found paddling out at sunrise on almost any day the surf is up.

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 11:15 A.M. (Showtime) STARDUST (2007) Charlie Cox is Tristan, a young man desperate to prove that he would do anything to win the love of his lady fair (Sienna Miller), which includes bringing her a falling star that recently crashed near their village. But to reach the star he must travel to the magical realm of Stormhold, where the star takes the form of a human (Claire Danes, above with Mr. Cox). He also encounters a rapidly aging witch, Lamia (Michelle Pfeiffer), and the cross-dressing captain (Robert De Niro) of a flying pirate ship. Directed by Matthew Vaughn and adapted from the graphic novel written by Neil Gaiman and illustrated by Charles Vess, this fantasy tale barrels forward with a fearless audacity, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. Mr. Holden found Ms. Pfeiffers Lamia to be as deliciously evil a witch as the movies have ever invented. He added, As the embodiment of every vain, wicked stepmother in fairy tale literature mixed with the cauldron-tending crones of Macbeth (Lamia is one of three cackling sisters), Ms. Pfeiffer goes for broke with the relish of a star who figures she has nothing to lose.

title: A Kaleidoscope of Lights and Crowds
description: Times Square is so crowded, so bright with distractions, that visitors may feel they have walked into an overpopulated and hypercommercial future. But the squares identity is rooted in the early 1900s, when earlier technologies  the subway and the electric light bulb  made possible its development, from a shabby center for the horse and livery businesses to a hub for news media, entertainment and, increasingly, shopping.

title: Where Ethnicity Was Fluid
description: IN Bengali Harlem and the Lost Histories of South Asian America (Harvard University Press, $35), Vivek Bald, who teaches writing and digital media at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has produced an engaging account of a largely untold wave of immigration: Muslims from British India who arrived in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Merging Cars and Bikes

title: Nocturnal Signs, With Character
description: Images from James and Karla Murrays New York Nights, a new book of photos of a vanishing city.

title: Knicks Fight All the Way Back, Only to Be Blindsided at the Buzzer
description: SACRAMENTO  The Knicks faced a daunting task Friday night when they found themselves down by 27 points in a road game in which they were without Carmelo Anthony, their top scorer, and Raymond Felton, their starting point guard.

title: The Norwegian Football Wonder
description: Our colleague David Picker writes about Havard Rugland, a Norwegian with a good foot who knew nothing at all about American football, but  thanks to his viral video  has a tryout for the New York Jets football team.

title: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 29
description: NEWS Officials appealed for calm as protesters gathered after the death of the student who was attacked by a group of men in New Delhi. Heather Timmons and Sruthi Gottipati report from New Delhi.

title: Protests Across India Over Death of Gang Rape Victim
description: Bring white roses, some suggested. Get angry, some said. Dont resort to violence, others begged.

title: Frances 75 Percent Tax Rate Struck Down on Constitutional Grounds
description: Frances Constitutional Council overturned a 75 percent tax rate on incomes above 1 million euros, or $1.3 million, on Saturday.

title: Six Charged With Murder in India After Rape Victims Death
description: NEW DELHI  As protests grew in India on Saturday over the death of a young woman who was raped in New Delhi this month by several men in a moving bus, the police said six men accused of attacking her had been charged with murder.

title: European Union Plans to Accentuate the Positive in 2013
description: LONDON  With the prospect of more troubles ahead for the European Union in 2013, officials have launched a campaign to remind its 500 million citizens of the benefits of belonging to the 27-nation alliance.

title: Rex Ryans Denials and Latest Jets Drama
description: In retrospect, the New York Post season preview cover with the Jets depicted as clowns might have been understated.Heres an attempt to sort out the latest drama in Jetsland.

title: On the Economics and Politics of Deficits
description: Evan Soltas of Wonkblog and Joe Weisenthal of Business Insider both make the same point, in more detail, that I tried to make in my series on ONE TRILLION DOLLARS: the current budget deficit is overwhelmingly the result of the depressed economy, and its not clear that we have a structural budget problem at all, let alone the fundamental mismatch between what we want and what were willing to pay for that people like to claim exists. Heres another chart, showing the primary federal balance  that is, not counting interest payments  since 1972 (data from CBO):

title: Once Upon a Time, 200 Years Later, in Pictures
description: This month marks the bicentennial of the publication of Jacob and Wilhelm Grimms Kinder-und Hausmrchen  Childrens and Household Tales, in English, but more commonly known as Grimms Fairy Tales. The collection of stories  Sleeping Beauty, Little Red Riding Hood and Rumpelstiltskin are just a few of the most well known  have been revised, retold, reinterpreted and even Disneyfied so many times over the past two centuries that its easy to forget the original tales were a potent mix of the macabre, fantastical and downright creepy.

title: Russias Adoption Ban Plays Politics With Most Vulnerable
description: Even my 7-year-old knows there are some things that you just dont use as ammunition in an argument.

title: On Skis, Sharpening a Relationship With Risk
description: I know what Ive become. The vegan restaurant answers my calls with, Chakra roll again, Melissa? The only action my Patagonia jacket gets is walking to Equinox. I pay $14 for a vodka/soda. It has been seven years since I moved to Manhattan from a mountain hiking town of 7,537 people in California. I cant remember the last time I dug a hole to poop in. Ive gone city soft.

title: Insisting on Assads Exit Will Cost More Lives, Russian Says
description: MOSCOW  Russias foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, said Saturday that there was no possibility of persuading President Bashar al-Assad to leave Syria, leaving little hope for a breakthrough in the standoff. He also said that the opposition leaders insistence on Mr. Assads departure as a precondition for peace talks would come at the cost of more and more lives of Syrian citizens in a conflict that has already killed tens of thousands.

title: Big Dream, Rude Awakening
description: AMHERST, Mass.  Hung from lampposts and tacked to bulletin boards, the maroon and white banners were everywhere this past fall on the pastoral campus of the University of Massachusetts.

title: Fast Learners Newest Lesson Focuses on Self-Preservation
description: ASHBURN, Va.  Almost a year ago, Bill Polian, then the president of the Indianapolis Colts, was scouting players to possibly take with the first overall draft pick. He told the teams owner, Jim Irsay, that there was no question Robert Griffin III was a cant-miss player, perhaps a once-in-a-lifetime prospect, and that either he or Andrew Luck would lead you to the promised land.

title: Finally, Something James Doesnt Do
description: Occasionally, an N.B.A. player comes so close to perfection in one aspect of the game that he turns his attention to another skill. Think of Wilt Chamberlain leading the league in assists or Michael Jordan eschewing the slam dunk competition for the 3-point contest. For LeBron James, who has conquered virtually every obstacle put in front of him, the next frontier appears to be a complete avoidance of personal fouls.

title: Senate Seeks Bipartisan Formula to Reach Tax Deal
description: WASHINGTON  Senate leaders and their aides spent Saturday searching for a formula to extend tax cuts for most Americans that could win bipartisan support in the Senate and final approval in the fractious House by the new year, hoping to prevent large tax increases and budget cuts that could threaten the fragile economy.

title: Matchup: Eagles (4-11) at Giants (8-7)
description: 1 p.m. Eastern, Fox

title: Matchup: Jets (6-9) at Bills (5-10)
description: 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

title: A Discovery, Marooned in Libyas Revolution
description: As Adam Nagourney reports in The Times, Death Valley is experiencing a burst of civic pride over reclaiming a world temperature record: a 134-degree reading registered on July 10, 1913, at Greenland Ranch in California.

title: Tynes, Recalling 06 Chiefs, Knows Giants Arent Done Yet
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  For Giants kicker Lawrence Tynes, the feeling of confusion came rushing back quickly. As soon as the final game of the 2006 N.F.L. season was mentioned to him last week, Tynes  who was then with the Kansas City Chiefs  began shaking his head.

title: Jets Fiasco With Tebow Ranks Right Down There
description: Last November, about two hours after Tim Tebow and the Denver Broncos beat the Jets, 17-13, on a last-minute touchdown, paramedics rushed to Denver International Airport. Jets Coach Rex Ryan feared he was having a heart attack.

title: French Council Strikes Down 75% Tax Rate
description: PARIS  Frances Constitutional Council on Saturday struck down the Socialist governments plan to impose a 75 percent marginal income tax rate on the wealthy, a measure that figured prominently among the campaign promises of President Franois Hollande and that had become a divisive emblem of his approach to cutting the budget deficit.

title: Amish Await Hate Crime Sentences
description: Members of an isolated Amish community in eastern Ohio fear long prison sentences for 16 community members convicted of attacking other Amish and cutting their beards and hair.

title: Braced for Hardship, an Amish Clan Awaits Sentences in Shearing Attacks
description: BERGHOLZ, Ohio  At their afternoon meeting in a bare farmhouse room, in a circle with infants on their laps and toddlers tugging at their skirts, the women of this breakaway Amish settlement have some most un-Amish matters to discuss.

title: A Year After Attacks, an Amish Community Grapples With Its Future
description: The insular clan led by Samuel Mullet Sr., who was convicted of hate crimes, is awaiting the sentencing of its members who were convicted in the attacks last year.

title: Variety: Un Divertente Gioco Acrostico
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Man, I really hope that title is accurate. Its supposed to say A Fun Acrostic, but you know how online translation services can be. Apologies in advance if Ive inadvertently insulted anyones mother.

title: Community Says Punitive Cutting of Hair Began as a Reminder to Repent
description: BERGHOLZ, Ohio  More than a year before the violent beard-cutting assaults on outside Amish that brought notoriety and felony convictions to the insular Bergholz settlement, several followers of Samuel Mullet Sr., the clans leader, used similar practices on each other.

title: In Next Scene: A Dark Cloud Lifts
description: CHICAGO  Before he died, Declan Sullivan wrote screenplays. He made short films, played trumpet, loved music and movies, studied business and, in his remaining free time at Notre Dame, videotaped football practice for the Fighting Irish.

title: N.F.L. Maneuvering Gives TV a Prime Attraction for Prime Time
description: The planning for the final day of the N.F.L.s regular season began almost three weeks ago, when NBC lobbied the league to let it show the Dallas Cowboys game against the New Orleans Saints last Sunday, instead of the Seattle-San Francisco game it was eventually awarded.

title: A Place to Discover the Next Great Play
description: WITH its new monthly Theater in the Loft series, which kicks off Jan. 13 in the 100-seat Loft at the South Orange Performing Arts Center, the Midtown Direct Rep theater company intends to introduce little-known plays with potential, said Sandy Rustin, one of the companys two artistic directors, who lives in Maplewood.

title: Coal Giant Drops Claim That it is the Global Leader in Clean Energy Solutions
description: Peabody Energy, the biggest private-sector coal company in the world, has removed the claim that it is the global leader in clean energy solutions from its home page. The two images below show the shift (sometime between Dec. 19 and Dec. 29), with the claim now reading that the company is the global leader in clean coal solutions:

title: Woman Is Charged With Murder as a Hate Crime in a Fatal Subway Push
description: A 31-year-old woman was arrested on Saturday and charged with second-degree murder as a hate crime in connection with the death of a man who was pushed onto the tracks of an elevated subway station in Queens and crushed by an oncoming train.

title: Winters Deadly Bite Returns to Refugee Camps of Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The snow that fell on a refugee camp in Kabul last week left thick powder piled voluptuously on the sagging roofs of huts and skinny tree branches, turning the squalor into a winter wonderland. The mistake of a toddler named Janan was to play in it.

title: Leaders Response Magnifies Outrage in India Rape Case
description: NEW DELHI  India often seems to careen from crisis to crisis, with protests regularly spilling onto the streets over the latest outrage or scandal, a nation seemingly always on the boil. But when things settle, as they inevitably do, little seems to change. Public anger usually cools to a simmer.

title: Personal Finance Advice, Taken to the Woodshed
description: ITS rare to come across a realistic and readable book about personal finance. Most are laden with rosy promises, followed by acronyms and turgid advice. Helaine Olen, a freelance journalist, offers an exception with Pound Foolish: Exposing the Dark Side of the Personal Finance Industry (Portfolio, $27.95). Its a take-no-prisoners examination of the ways she says we have been scared, misled or bamboozled by those purporting to help us achieve financial security.

title: Dont Just Talk About Change. Show It.
description: I WAS born in 1956. I should have been reading in grade school, but Im dyslexic  I have trouble reading, writing and spelling  and few people knew much about the condition in those days. My mother realized that something was wrong, but she didnt know what. She advocated for me at school and told my teachers not to give up on me. I attended five grammar schools because my mother was constantly looking for something to help me. It was a lonely childhood, and I hate to think how I might have ended up if she hadnt been so supportive.

title: Progress Where They Make iPhones
description: Apple, whose products the world cannot get enough of, has been justifiably criticized for poor working conditions and low wages at the factories of its chief supplier in China, Foxconn. Now, however, there are signs that all the negative attention, including reports in this newspaper, has caused the companies to make changes, like raising wages, limiting work hours and providing chairs with backs instead of stools at workstations.

title: Angline Templier
description: Angline Templier is a French winemaker at the matriarchal Champagne house of J. Lassalle. She and her mother and grandmother oversee an annual production of 100,000 bottles of artisanal Champagne from their 27 acres in the rural town of Chigny les Roses in northeastern France.

title: Venezuelan Finds Asylum, and a Career, in New York
description: It is very difficult for Maria Marquez, 33, to talk about her past. She can be specific about certain things, but not many. The danger just feels too real.

title: Why the Economy Needs Tax Reform
description: Over the next four years, tax reform, done right, could be a cure for much of what ails the economy. Higher taxes, raised progressively, could encourage growth by helping to pay for long-neglected public investment in education, infrastructure and basic research. More revenue would also reduce budget deficits, helping to put the nations finances on a stable path. Greater progressivity would reduce rising income inequality, and with it, inequality of opportunity that is both an economic and social scourge.

title: Drones for South Korea
description: Less than a month after North Koreas latest missile test, the Obama administration has offered to sell South Korea advanced spy drones so it can keep a closer eye on its northern adversary. The decision raises some concerns, and Congress would be wise to ask a lot of questions before going along, including whether the deal is part of a comprehensive strategy or just a way to penalize North Korea.

title: So Many Snapshots, So Few Voices Saved
description: I just got my voice back. At least Im told its my voice. A surgeon did a couple of hours work on one of my vocal cords, removing a papilloma, and on Christmas Day, after two weeks of silence, I spoke.

title: Hitting China With Humor
description: Beijing

title: Conservation Militias Fight Poaching in Kenya
description: The Kenyan government is struggling to win the war in the fight against illegally killed elephants.

title: To Save Wildlife, and Tourism, Kenyans Take Up Arms
description: ARCHERS POST, Kenya  Julius Lokinyi was one of the most notorious poachers in this part of Kenya, accused of single-handedly killing as many as 100 elephants and selling the tusks by the side of the road in the dead of night, pumping vast amounts of ivory into a shadowy global underground trade.

title: How to Read in 2013
description: COME what may in the next 12 months, 2013 has this much going for it: Its a year without a midterm election, and a year thats as far removed as possible from the next presidential race. This means that for a blessed 365 days you can be a well-informed and responsible American citizen without reading every single article on Politico, without hitting refresh every 30 seconds on your polling-average site of choice, without channel-hopping between Chris Matthewss hyperventilating and Dick Morriss promises of an inevitable Republican landslide.

title: Things I Saw  No. 50
description: Suggestions for what youd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

title: You Can Go Home Again, for an Extra $4,586
description: THE Haggler is always a little reluctant to print air travel nightmare stories, in large part because there are so many of them. And whenever one problem is solved in this space, dozens of new ones show up. So lets make a rule: By all means, send your travel nightmare story, but only if it is more grueling and costly than the one you are about to read  which, as we shall see, sets the ordeal bar very, very high.

title: Two Wars Against Cancer
description: MY identical twin sister, Karen, and I have two older brothers. We were raised in Blue Bell, Pa., where my father was a family physician and my mother was a nurse. We spent summers on Long Beach Island, N.J., where both of us were waitresses at a busy seafood restaurant.

title: The Power of a Hot Body
description: As I waited with a throng of Parisians in the Rambuteau Metro station on a blustery day, my frozen toes finally began to thaw. Alone we may have shivered, but together we brewed so much body heat that people began unbuttoning their coats. We might have been penguins crowding for warmth in Antarcticas icy torment of winds. Idly mingling, a human body radiates about 100 watts of excess heat, which can add up fast in confined spaces.

title: Wishful Thinking and Middle-Class Taxes
description: IN the continuing fiscal negotiations between President Obama and House Republicans, both sides have, from the very beginning, agreed on one point: Taxes on the middle class must not rise. But maybe its time to reconsider this premise. An unwavering commitment to keep middle-class taxes low could be one reason the political process has become so deeply dysfunctional.

title: Video Shows Plane Crashing on to Moscow Highway
description: Last Updated, Sunday, 6:10 p.m. A Russian passenger jet overshot the runway at Vnukovo airport near Moscow on Saturday and crashed into a highway, killing at least four people, all of them crew members, the authorities said.

title: Ratings for Citi Field Bonds Lowered
description: With one glaring exception, the Mets appear to be in cost-cutting mode this winter. Yes, David Wright agreed to an eight-year, $138 million contract this month.

title: Sure, Big Data Is Great. But So Is Intuition.
description: It was the bold title of a conference this month at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and of a widely read article in The Harvard Business Review last October: Big Data: The Management Revolution.

title: Conquering Your Fears of Giving Feedback
description: This interview with   Karen May, vice president for people development at Google, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Beyond the Temporary Fix
description: To the Editor:

title: Due Diligence, Long Forgotten
description: To the Editor:

title: The Power of Mad
description: To the Editor:

title: Fiscal Cliff: Changes Set to Occur if Congress Takes No Action
description: Several tax and spending changes will occur over the next year if the White House and Congress fail to reach a deal to avert them.

title: Were Obamas Early Ads Really the Game Changer?
description: Many post-mortems of the 2012 presidential campaign suggest that Mitt Romney erred by allowing President Obama to define him early through an advertising blitz in battleground states. Certainly Mr. Obamas advisers have trumpeted the success of this strategy. A few weeks after the election, a Bloomberg News article about an appearance by the Obama campaign strategist David Axelrod said:

title: An Idea Promised the Sky, but India Is Still Waiting
description: NEW DELHI  The idea was, and still is, captivating: in 2011, the Indian government and two Indian-born tech entrepreneurs unveiled a $50 tablet computer, to be built in India with Googles free Android software. The government would buy the computers by the millions and give them to its schoolchildren.

title: Questcor Finds Profits, at $28,000 a Vial
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.

title: Notable Opinion Art of 2012
description: The New York Times opinion section commissions at least 30 original illustrations each week, more than 1,500 each year. Our tradition of using art to bring an incisive, witty or provocative perspective on current affairs dates to the creation of the Op-Ed page in 1970, and expanded with the creation of the Sunday Review section (formerly the Week in Review) in 2011. Here is a sampling of illustrations from the past year.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Dec. 30
description: As the deadline to avert the automatic tax increases and spending cuts of the so-called fiscal cliff draws near, the Sunday shows feature members of Congress and, most notably,President Obama, who will join NBCs Meet the Press.

title: Ai Weiwei and the Communist Party, Tormenting Each Other
description: My Sunday column is about the great Chinese artist Ai Weiwei and the challenge he and people like him present to the Chinese leadership. I do think its a sign of progress that Ai is today free from prison and able to needle the Party. One of the ways to measure the new leader, Xi Jinping, will be whether Ai is left alone  and whether Liu Xiaobo, the Nobel Peace Prize-winning writer, is released from jail.

title: Pakistan Lifts, Then Reinstates, YouTube Ban
description: As my colleague Salman Masood reported on Twitter, online rejoicing at the end of Pakistans three-month ban on YouTube was short-lived on Saturday, as the government reimposed the ban shortly after it was lifted following reports that copies of a low-budget film mocking the Prophet Muhammad appeared in searches of the site.

title: Plus Ten
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  How do you decide whether youve enjoyed solving a crossword puzzle? I realize that enjoyment is more of a visceral experience than an intellectual one, but I think its worth taking a closer look at this thing we do and figuring it out.

title: Mystery Powder Leads to Evacuations in Greenwich Village
description: A search for narcotics in a Greenwich Village apartment on Saturday morning led to a call to the bomb squad and evacuations after detectives discovered explosive powder, the police said.

title: A Spending-Limits Bill Serves as a Great Excuse
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Medicaid Waiver Presents Structuring Challenges
description: By years end, health care providers across Texas will have submitted proposals to state leaders to transform the way they care for the poor and the uninsured. They have been spurred by a Medicaid waiver Texas officials sought and received in 2011 from the federal government, one that ties financing to cooperation, cost efficiency and better patient outcomes.

title: Dancing the Apocalypse Away, Extravagantly
description: Elvira Butz, a septuagenarian adventurer who has dived to the Titanic aboard a Russian submersible, trekked solo through the rain forests of Papua New Guinea and searched for meteorites in Antarctica, spent the final minutes of Dec. 21, 2012, the day the Mayans supposedly predicted the world would end, dancing to Gangnam Style at the base of a 30-foot replica of a Mayan pyramid built on the shore of Lake Austin.

title: In Mexico, a New Approach to Stanching Drug Violence
description: NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico  The military tank that had stood at the entrance to this Mexican border city since 2008 was not here on Christmas Eve. Neither was the machine gun turret that pointed down this gritty towns main street.

title: Building Congregations Around Art Galleries and Cafes as Spirituality Wanes
description: DALLAS  The mural painted on the side of a building in the Deep Ellum warehouse district here is intentionally vague, simply showing a faceless man in a suit holding an umbrella over the words Life in Deep Ellum. Inside there are the trappings of a revitalization project, including an art gallery, a yoga studio and a business incubator, sharing the building with a coffee shop and a performance space.

title: Smoke but Little Fire After Manhole Blasts in SoHo
description: The explosion echoed in the streets of SoHo on Saturday afternoon as tourists walked along dampened sidewalks and a crowd gathered inside the Fanelli Cafe, one of New York Citys older restaurants.

title: Pakistan Lifts YouTube Ban, for 3 Minutes
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A ban on YouTube, which Pakistan imposed after an anti-Islam video caused riots in much of the Muslim world, was lifted Saturday, only to be reinstated  after three minutes  when it was discovered that blasphemous material was still available on the site.

title: Biden Is Back for a 2nd Run at Gun Limits
description: WASHINGTON  Never much known for restraint, Joseph R. Biden Jr. did not hold back during a presidential primary debate in 2007 when a voter asking about gun rights in a recorded video displayed a fearsome-looking semiautomatic rifle and declared, This is my baby.

title: Drone Spy Wars
description: Al Qaeda and Taliban-supported death squads accuse tribesmen of collaborating with the United States, and often force them to confess on video before executing them.

title: Drone War Spurs Militants to Deadly Reprisals
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  They are dead men talking, and they know it. Gulping nervously, the prisoners stare into the video camera, spilling tales of intrigue, betrayal and paid espionage on behalf of the United States. Some speak in trembling voices, a glint of fear in their eyes. Others look resigned. All plead for their lives.

title: A Soul Surfer, in Winter
description: Freezing temperatures cannot keep Banshidhar Medeiros, 59, a meditation student and lifelong surfer from Queens, from finding his bliss in winter waves.

title: Stunned and Battered, Knicks Need Break
description: The Knicks returned to New York on Saturday physically beaten up and coming off one of their most agonizing losses of the season, a 106-105 defeat to the Kings in Sacramento.

title: UConn Repays Stanford by Ending Long Streak
description: STANFORD, Calif.  For the viewing public, this was a matchup between the nations top-ranked teams. For Connecticut, there was also the small matter of revenge.

title: Sloshing and Churning, Syracuse Routs West Virginia in Pinstripe Bowl
description: A few years ago, a matchup between Syracuse and West Virginia would have constituted a typical Saturday afternoon Big East game, maybe on a crisp day in October. For 56 years, from 1955 to 2011, they battled that way, always in the regular season.

title: Coming Soon to Belgian Village, a French Film Idol Fleeing Taxes
description: NCHIN, Belgium  The last time a big star lit up this sleepy village of potato fields and rain-drenched pastures was in 1667, when the Sun King, Louis XIV of France, stopped by for the day. But even he may not have created quite the commotion caused by Grard Depardieu, the celebrated actor, turbulent bon vivant and, since a visit to the mayors office here on Dec. 7 to register as a resident, Frances most reviled tax exile.

title: Halfway Houses Prove Lucrative to Those at Top
description: The Kintock Group, the second-largest operator of halfway houses in New Jersey, is a nonprofit agency that is financed almost entirely by government contracts. But it is run like a well-heeled family business.

title: Jeffrey Potter, Biographer of Pollock, Dies at 94
description: Jeffrey Potter was an aspiring writer working as a building contractor in the Hamptons in 1949 when he developed a friendship with a gruff, taciturn neighbor who shared his passion for oversized machines like backhoes, bulldozers, dredgers and jacks big enough to lift a house from its foundations.

title: A Veteran Hangs on to His Title, but a Young Champion Is Dethroned
description: A changing of the guard was anticipated in the top ranks this year. It was the mens champion, now 43, whom many thought to be vulnerable. But it was the teenage womens champion who was dethroned.

title: Nets Talk Over Lunch and Win After Dinner
description: A Russian billionaire and a coaching lifer from Scranton, Pa., walked into a Greek restaurant, providing the setup for a corny punch line or perhaps an agenda for the future of the Nets. Or maybe it was just a lunch.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, Dec. 30
description: We just cant afford a politically self-inflicted wound to our economy.

title: Corrections: December 30, 2012
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Megan Healey, JC Leston
description: Megan Marie Healey and J Christian Leston were married Saturday in Hicksville, N.Y. Frank Crivello, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola.

title: Seth Thayer Jr. and Gregory Tinder
description: Seth Alexander Thayer Jr. and Gregory Nelson Tinder were married Saturday at their home in Northport, Me. R. Declan OConnor, a notary public and a friend of the couple, officiated.

title: Ryan Murphy, Courtney Jeske
description: Ryan Chandra Murphy and Courtney Aaron Jeske are to be married Sunday afternoon at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New York. Msgr. Robert B. OConnor, the pastor of the church, officiated.

title: Sara Chidester and Stephen Gould
description: Dr. Sara Janine Chidester and Dr. Stephen Alexander Gould are to be married Sunday at Catlin Gardens, an inn in Slate Hill, N.Y. Cantor Judith K. Steel is to officiate with the Rev. Harold Steindam, a minister of the United Church of Christ, taking part.

title: Dolores Swirin, Paul Yao
description: Dolores Anne Swirin and Paul Lin Yao were married Monday at the couples apartment in Brooklyn. Cantor Lisa B. Segal officiated.

title: Matthew Sobaski, David Marchi
description: Matthew Christopher Sobaski and David John Marchi were married Thursday in New York. The Rev. Alma Daniel, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts.

title: Allison Rothman, Paul Strachman
description: Allison Elizabeth Rothman and Paul Pinkhas Strachman were married Saturday evening at Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn. Rabbi Arthur D. Weiner officiated.

title: Beth DeWoody and Firooz Zahedi
description: Beth Rudin DeWoody and Firooz Zahedi were married Wednesday afternoon by Patricia Alexander, a Florida notary, at the brides house in West Palm Beach, Fla. That evening, Koginka Kamaru Xue, a shaman, led a spiritual ceremony in the same location.

title: Grace Clawater and Mark Doramus Jr.
description: Rebekah Grace Clawater, a daughter of Hollee Hedge Clawater and D. Wayne Clawater of Houston, was married Saturday in Houston to Mark Christopher Doramus Jr., a son of Laura Laker Doramus and Mr. Doramus Sr. of Little Rock, Ark. The Very Rev. Dr. J. Pittman McGehee performed the ceremony at Christ Church Episcopal Cathedral, of which he is a former dean.

title: Sasha Rutizer and Jenifer Markowitz
description: Army Capt. Sasha Noel Rutizer and Jenifer Robin Markowitz were married Saturday at the Hillyer Art Space in Washington. Judge Douglas Miles of the El Paso County Court in Colorado received permission from Superior Court of the District of Columbia to officiate. Rabbi Kenneth Block took part in the ceremony.

title: Trending in Asia in 2012: Our Top 10
description: Our most popular Asia posts of 2012, by the number of readers and/or the number of comments:

title: How to Blog Asia for the MSM
description: If youre a close reader of IHT Rendezvous, youre jonesing for a fix of Mark McDonald right about now. Our peripatetic Asia bloggers last day writing was Wednesday. Hes moving on to other assignments. Well miss him.

title: Elegy in Neon
description: NEW YORK CITY exists in a perpetual state of reinvention. That is its nature. What was here yesterday is something else today and will be something new again tomorrow. That change sustains the city, imparts it with a vital energy that keeps it from becoming a frozen museum of itself, like Paris or Rome.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: The end of the year is always a time of reflection for journalists, who look back on the changes and transformations that occurred in the year gone by. In Open Magazine, Manu Joseph describes the rise of the New Rebel, the young, educated and affluent person who is angered by the state of the nation.He writes: Till not so long ago, they were never a crowd except in happy times  a college festival or a rock concert. But now they walk in giant furious swarms, having done their apprenticeship in rebellion under Team Anna last year, holding English placards, abusing the few politicians whose names they know. Nobodys votebank, orphaned by their own republic, they march to some monument or other to become news.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: The longest rail tunnel in India, which cuts through the foothills of the Pir Panjal mountain range, opened for a trial run on Thursday, the Hindustan Times reported. The 11-kilometer, or 6.8-mile, railway track cost the government 13 billion rupees, or $236 million. It will connect Kashmir to the rest of the country via rail for the first time. The track is expected to be functional next year.

title: Giants Probabilities for Playoffs
description: Under the headline The Indescribable Collapse of the Incomprehensible 2012 Giants, Greg Hanlon of CapitalNewYork.comsummed up what Giants fans know well:

title: At Delhi Protest Ground, Talk of Causes Behind Violence Against Women
description: The body of the 23-year-old victim of a fatal gang rape in New Delhi this month was returned to India from Singapore early Sunday, as calls for government action and protests in response to the attack continued to rouse people across India.

title: Game Theory: The Year of Antisocial Gaming
description: It had been a while since any of my friends had spent significant time together online in Call of Duty or Madden or World of Warcraft or any of the big-budget experiences we knew as multiplayer gaming. Things like deadlines, dinner parties and changing diapers were taking up all of our time. But suddenly, here we were, playing and competing with one another just like the old days.

title: Day of Seesaw Talks Produces No Accord on Fiscal Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  Senate leaders on Sunday failed to produce a fiscal deal with just hours to go before large tax increases and spending cuts were to begin taking effect on New Years Day, despite a round of volatile negotiations over the weekend and an attempt by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to intervene.

title: 2012: The Year in Graphics
description: A selection of graphics and interactives from 2012 with information on how they were produced.

title: Fisher Island: Paradise Built
description: Three miles off the coast of Miami lies a 216-acre man-made island that has long been home to the rich and powerful. But legal troubles may intrude upon the seclusion residents covet.

title: Disruptions: The Real Hazards of E-Devices on Planes
description: Over the last year, flying with phones and other devices has become increasingly dangerous.

title: Several Eras End at One Lower East Side Building
description: The collapse and demolition in 2006 of the First Roumanian-American Congregation synagogue at 89 Rivington Street  the cantors Carnegie Hall  seemed to have eradicated almost every trace of what was once a large and vibrant Jewish community.

title: 19 Shiite Pilgrims Bound for Iran Are Killed in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  At least 19 Shiite pilgrims, including four women, were killed Sunday when their convoy of three buses in southwestern Pakistan was struck by a remotely detonated bomb, officials said. At least 25 other people were wounded in the attack in the Mastung district of Baluchistan Province.

title: In Europe, Focus Begins to Shift to the Speed of a Nascent Recovery
description: SAY what you will about the euro zones quarreling policy makers. They can claim at least one achievement during 2012: their common currency still has a heartbeat.

title: The Hostage Drama Begins
description: It sure looks as if were going over the fiscal cliff, but that may be the least of our problems. The debt ceiling is a much bigger and more dangerous issue, and it looks very much as if Republicans are set to destroy the full faith and credit of the United States if they cant get their way.

title: The Hobbit Holds Lead at Busy Movie Theaters
description: Bloody violence (Django Unchained) and dirty actors singing (Les Misrables) both intrigued North American movie audiences over the weekend, but it was a furry-footed holdover that claimed the No. 1 spot: The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey, distributed by Warner Brothers, took in a robust $32.9 million, for a new three-week domestic total of $222.7 million.

title: Afghan Camps Receive Winter Aid, but Officials Say It Isnt Enough
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees on Sunday distributed emergency cold-weather supplies to families in a refugee camp where two days earlier a 3-year-old died of exposure to the freezing temperatures.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 10 P.M. (ABC) DICK CLARKS NEW YEARS ROCKIN EVE WITH RYAN SEACREST 2013 Taylor Swift, Carly Rae Jepsen and Neon Trees join Mr. Seacrest, above, in New York to help ring in the new year during this celebration from Times Square. Fergie of the Black Eyed Peas hosts segments from Los Angeles with appearances by Brandy, Flo Rida, Karmin, OneRepublic and Pitbull. New Years Rockin Eve Celebrates Dick Clark, recalling the TV host, who died in April at 82, leads in at 8.

title: Newtown Shooting the Worst Day of His Presidency, Obama Says
description: President Obama said Sunday that the day of the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., was the worst of his presidency and that he wanted new legislation limiting access to some types of firearms passed within the first year of his second term.

title: Is Our Austerians Learning?
description: Paul Solman has a post on Greg Mankiws attempt at a gotcha over my views circa 2003 on the consequences of deficits. As Solman notes, not only are the situations very different, Ive also long since acknowledged that I was wrong, and have explained how and why I modified my views as a result. Extra bonus: notice how Mankiw, faced with the failure of his gotcha, immediately tries to claim that he wasnt actually saying what he was, in fact, saying.

title: Dr. Rita Levi-Montalcini, Nobel Winner, Dies at 103
description: Dr. Rita Levi-Montalcini, a Nobel Prize-winning neurologist who discovered critical chemical tools that the body uses to direct cell growth and build nerve networks, opening the way for the study of how those processes can go wrong in diseases like dementia and cancer, died on Sunday at her home in Rome. She was 103.

title: Republicans Consider Changing Electoral Vote Counting to Improve Presidential Odds
description: WASHINGTON  Not too long ago, political analysts assumed the Republicans had a clear advantage in the Electoral College, the system according to which each state, based on population, is given electors that in almost all cases are awarded on a winner-take-all basis, determining who will be the president of the United States. Today, its the Democrats who have the edge.

title: Big Depositors Seek a New Safety Net
description: On the first day of the New Year, $1.5 trillion of bank deposits will lose an unlimited government guarantee that was granted during the financial crisis to assure skittish customers that their cash was safe. For a handful of boutique firms that service banks, its a boon for business.

title: Heavens to Betsy
description: Given this blogs growing readership, I find it necessary every once in a while to remind people of the rules on commenting. In particular, the Grey Lady is very Victorian; comments containing obscenities will not be posted except through oversight. For what its worth, by the way, when I do the moderation myself  which is some of the time  the obscene language seems more common in supportive than critical comments. Hey, I often feel like cursing too. No matter, its still forbidden

title: How to Help
description: The aid organization with the most permanent presence in Kabuls refugee camps is a respected Afghan group, Aschiana, which also runs schools that provide students with hot lunches. Aschianas United States fund-raising branch can be reached at www.aschiana-foundation.org, and their Afghan office is at www.aschiana.com.

title: Afghan Troop Deaths Rise as Army Expands Its Role
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan government has hit a grim record in its quest to take over the countrys security from coalition forces: more than 1,000 soldiers died in 2012, a roughly 20 percent increase from 2011.

title: Mellower? Maybe, but the Barbs Still Sting
description: To describe Sandra Bernhard nowadays as a mellower version of the comic sniper she used to be is not to say that she has lost her edge. In her monologues on Friday evening at Joes Pub, where she is performing a series of end-of-the-year shows, this comedian and singer, now 57 (but looking two decades younger), seemed on top of current trends in music and fashion as ever. And she flung out some choice but unprintable words for the year we are leaving behind.

title: For Day Laborers, Used to Scraping By, Hurricane Creates a Wealth of Work
description: The day after the storm, Manuel Sinchi, like some other New Yorkers, gathered a few friends, hopped on his bicycle and headed down to badly stricken Coney Island to volunteer his services.

title: When the Costume Isnt Enough
description: The title character in The Bald Soprano, the absurdist Ionesco play, never shows up, but watch for her at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: New Years Honors From the Queen
description: The fashion designer Stella McCartney (below), the actor Ewan McGregor, the singer Kate Bush and the cartoonist Quentin Blake were among those named to receive New Years Honors from Queen Elizabeth II, The Associated Press reported. Ms. McCartney will be recognized for her efforts in creating the Olympic uniforms for the British athletes in the 2012 London Summer Games; Mr. McGregor for his overall work in film; Ms. Bush for her music; and Mr. Blake, perhaps best known for his work on books by Roald Dahl, for his art.

title: A 17th-Century Genius, a Quack, or Perhaps Both
description: In 2002 the New York Institute for the Humanities organized a symposium under the title Was Athanasius Kircher the Coolest Guy Ever, or What? The highlights of this 17th-century German Jesuit polymaths sprawling rsum, summed up in John Glassies brisk new biography, suggest the question wasnt completely absurd.

title: Giants Do Their Part but Miss Out on Playoffs
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  At some point in the coming days, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin plans to find a quiet moment and gather some of his veteran players together to ask them the singular question that will linger for him all winter, spring and summer.

title: Obama Vows to Fix Flaws Discovered in Benghazi Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, in his most detailed comments on an independent inquirys report on the attack against the American diplomatic compound in Libya that killed four Americans on Sept. 11, said Sunday that the security and management flaws identified were huge problems that reflected sloppiness in how the State Department safeguards its missions abroad.

title: Richard Rodney Bennett, British Composer, Dies at 76
description: Richard Rodney Bennett, the British composer who in a long, distinguished career moved with ease among classical concert music, jazz and film, died on Dec. 24 in New York, where he had lived since 1979. He was 76.

title: Philadelphia School District Plans to Close Dozens of Schools
description: PHILADELPHIA  Like many public schools here, University City High School is underused, underfinanced and underperforming.

title: Analyzing a Deal From Bridge Baron
description: Some players, especially those who give lessons, have an eye for an instructive deal. One is Steve Conrad of Manhasset, N.Y., who teaches on cruise ships and writes math problems for a living.

title: Jets End Season With a Thud, and More Jolts May Be Coming
description: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y.  A Jets season that was so poor as to be unforgettable ended perhaps the only way it could have, with a dreadful loss Sunday.

title: A Campaign Seeks to Infuse a Bank With Humanity
description: IN their purest form, banks offer their customers a banal product  a safe place to keep and manage their money. To set themselves apart they advertise myriad services like digital banking and reward programs and rely increasingly on convenient locations, catchy songs or celebrity spokesmen to get the message across.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: In observance of the New Years holiday, the bond markets will close early at 2 p.m. on Monday. Both the stock and bond markets will be closed on Tuesday.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released this week includes the I.S.M. manufacturing index for December and construction spending for November (Wednesday); ADP employment for December and weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and unemployment for December, the I.S.M. service index for December and factory orders for November (Friday).

title: 2012: The Year in Culture
description: A look back at performances, exhibitions, films, books, movies and video games.

title: Religions Role in Altruism and Survival
description: To the Editor:

title: Ride the Waves
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  What a fun puzzle with which to end our solving year. I really liked this one, both for its simplicity and for its clever theme. Jeffrey Harriss puzzle made me smile.

title: Debate Over Womens Prayer at the Western Wall
description: To the Editor:

title: Instead of Gun Control, Try Bullet Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Will Turkey Squander Its Opportunity to Lead?
description: Instead of Turkey leading the post-Arab Spring Middle East, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan is setting a new standard of intolerance. Fourteen months after he touted Turkey as an example for the region, Mr. Erdogan is polarizing politics in his country and squelching dissent.

title: For a Civilian-Military Dialogue
description: To the Editor:

title: A Documentary Maker Puts Money on an Oscar Ad
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  Steven C. Barber, a filmmaker, was looking at a used Lexus to replace his 2001 Chevy when the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences released its lists of Oscar-eligible scores and songs this month. The music from his documentary, Until They Are Home, made both.

title: In Germany, Merkels Main Rival Appears to Stumble From Gaffe to Gaffe
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkels challenger in next years election may have already blurted out his own binders full of women gaffe early in the German campaign.

title: Israel, in Shift, Lets Building Materials Cross Into Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  For the first time in five years, Israel on Sunday allowed 20 truckloads of building materials into Gaza for use by the private sector, according to Israeli and Palestinian officials. One of the first tangible concessions under a cease-fire deal reached after eight days of intensive fighting in November, it signaled a shift in Israels approach to the Palestinian enclave.

title: William Baer Confirmed as Justice Department Antitrust Chief
description: William J. Baer was confirmed by the Senate on Sunday as the governments top antitrust lawyer, placing him in charge of the Justice Department division that reviews corporate mergers and prosecutes price-fixing cases.

title: No I in His Team, Including Him
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass.  The coach called for a bunt, but the 13-year-old batter had other plans. He was the teams unquestioned star. He would move along the runner with a base hit. Maybe even an extra-base hit.

title: Catherine ONeill, Advocate for Women and Children, Dies at 70
description: Catherine ONeill, whose travels with the International Rescue Committee to refugee camps led her, along with the actress Liv Ullmann and others, to found the Womens Commission for Refugee Women and Children, died Wednesday in Los Angeles. She was 70.

title: Maxim Recruits a Readership in Uniform
description: CRAWFORDSVILLE, Ark.  Scaling elevator shafts and sliding through sewers in mud-caked fields at a military training camp here would not be what most people would call a vacation. But for 10 Special Operations soldiers from the Army, Navy, Marines and Air Force, participating in an event called the Maximum Warrior contest, these challenges had a singular aim: to be in Maxim magazine.

title: Among Top News Stories, a War Is Missing
description: Look closely at the end-of-the-year lists of 2012s top news stories. Whats missing? The 11-year-old war in Afghanistan and American-led counterterrorism efforts around the world.

title: Giants Focus Shifts to 2013
description: A capsule look at the Giants 42-7 win over the Eagles:

title: Still Hurt, Stoudemire Is Itching to Help Knicks
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Knicks Amare Stoudemire could play for the first time this season on Tuesday against the Portland Trail Blazers. Although his injured knee is not healed, he said, he is ready to do what he can.

title: Lets Give Up on the Constitution
description: Washington

title: Amid Lockout Talks, Shorter Schedule Options Swirl
description: With the clock ticking and options dwindling for playing a truncated schedule to save the N.H.L. season, new bargaining between the league and the players association is expected to open Monday in New York.

title: Brewing Up Confusion
description: Howard Schultz, the C.E.O. of Starbucks, has a reputation as a good guy, a man who supports worthy causes. And he presumably thought he would add to that reputation when he posted an open letter urging his employees to promote fiscal bipartisanship by writing Come together on coffee cups.

title: U.S. Clears DNA Firms Acquisition by Chinese
description: The federal government has given national security clearance to the controversial purchase of an American DNA sequencing company by a Chinese firm.

title: Has Facebook Ruined Love?
Huge Child-Support Debt Doesnt Ensure Time in Jail
description: At first Lisa Sand wanted to see her ex-husband in prison. He had skipped out on making child support payments, missing court dates in Nassau County Family Court before leaving New York and eventually fleeing the country altogether. A fugitive for almost 20 years, he owed Ms. Sand and their two children $1 million.

title: A Factory on Bicycle Wheels, Carrying Hope of a Better Life
description: MEXICO CITY  The sound of a surprising opportunity rose above the tumult of traffic. Factory for electronic textiles offering work, came the message, shouted from a megaphone that sat in the basket of a white bicycle pedaled by Amor Muoz, an artist in a black jumpsuit. One hundred pesos an hour!

title: Babes in Arms
description: From: David Keene, president

title: For Liberals in Egypt, a Champion Who Quips
description: CAIRO  As a new Constitution engraves Islam ever more firmly into Egyptian law, a young comics escalating battle with a group of ultraconservative television sheiks has become an early skirmish over the application of Islamic law, or Shariah.

title: Readers Respond to the Armed Society Series
description: After the massacre at an elementary school in Newtown, Conn., earlier this month, The Stone published a series of essays that examined the philosophical implications of the use, possession and regulation of weapons. Readers responded with thousands of thoughtful comments. Below is a selection of their writing. The Editors

title: Clintons Blood Clot Is Located Near Her Brain, Doctors Say
description: WASHINGTON  Doctors treating Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday said that she suffered a blood clot in a vein between her brain and skull behind her right ear but predicted that she would make a full recovery.

title: Jane Holmes Dixon, Bishop Who Stared Down Barriers, Dies at 75
description: Jane Holmes Dixon, a former eighth-grade teacher and homemaker who was ordained an Episcopal priest in her 40s and was the second woman to be elevated to bishop in the history of the Episcopal Church, died on Dec. 25 at her home in Washington. She was 75.

title: Washout at Jones Beach
description: New York State parks officials have a huge job ahead of them in repairing Jones Beach State Park, which was dilapidated before Hurricane Sandy and devastated after, its boardwalk crumpled and its buildings ravaged. The parks central mall, designed in Robert Moses day to evoke an ocean liner, today looks like a ships deck after a bad encounter with a very large, cold, floating object somewhere in the North Atlantic.

title: Lure of Green Cards Brings Big Investments for Remote Resort in Vermont
description: JAY, Vt.  At this remote outpost by the Canadian border, Bill Stenger is overseeing what he says is the biggest economic development project that Vermont has ever seen.

title: Family of Chinese Regulator Profits in Insurance Firms Rise
description: SHANGHAI  Relatives of a top Chinese regulator profited enormously from the purchase of shares in a once-struggling insurance company that is now one of Chinas biggest financial powerhouses, according to interviews and a review of regulatory filings.

title: Owners Say on Eagles Reid Could Come Soon
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Philadelphia Eagles Coach Andy Reid and the owner, Jeffrey Lurie, are scheduled to sit down soon, probably on Monday morning, to discuss Reids employment. For many weeks, it has been widely considered a foregone conclusion that Reid, who has coached the Eagles for the last 14 seasons, would be fired. Several news outlets have reported that Reid was fired Friday.

title: Engineering a Reversal of Fortune in 2013
description: In business, all years are critical  make a big mistake and you wont have the chance to make another one. But in the media, wave after wave of transformation mean the coming year is particularly important.

title: Envoy to Syria Warns of Slide to Hellish Fiefs With Huge Toll
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The international envoy to Syria, Lakhdar Brahimi, drew a grim portrait on Sunday of the countrys future in the absence of a political solution, warning of a state carved up by warlords and a death toll that would rapidly surge, while conceding that there was little sign that the antagonists intended to negotiate.

title: Green Cards for Vermonts Kingdom
description: The head of Jay Peak ski resort in Vermonts Northeast Kingdom is using a federal visa program called EB-5 to weatherproof his resort and kick-start the local economy.

title: Game Not Known for Ferocity Claims a Casualty Who Was
description: Christie Moore Freel lost count of the nights her husband, Ryan, arrived home from the ballpark with a tale that added to her growing concern over his health.

title: Two Rookies Who Had Stumbling Starts Achieve Promising Finishes
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  David Wilson did not seem to be aware that the Giants had been eliminated from postseason contention when he began talking to reporters.

title: In Kabul, Deadly Cold Returns
description: Afghan refugees living in Kabul camps battle deadly cold as winter sets in.

title: The Militarys Dirty Secret
description: Pentagon officials have long declared their determination to eradicate the militarys notorious culture of sexual violence. To judge from data made public in the last couple of months, they have a long way to go.

title: No Easy Answers in Mali
description: The extremist Islamist militias that seized control of northern Mali in April have imposed their fanatical beliefs and barbaric punishments on the regions defenseless people, sending tens of thousands of refugees fleeing into neighboring Mauritania. And they have given sanctuary to notorious terrorist groups like Nigerias Boko Haram and Algerias Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, a group that Washington suspects may have been involved in the September attack on the American consulate in Libya.

title: Settlement Expected on Past Abuses in Home Loans
description: Banking regulators are close to a $10 billion settlement with 14 banks that would end the governments efforts to hold lenders responsible for foreclosure abuses like faulty paperwork and excessive fees that may have led to evictions, according to people with knowledge of the discussions.

title: A Broken System for Tracking Guns
description: As President Obama looks to reduce gun violence after the Connecticut massacre through reforms like reinstating the assault weapons ban, he and supporters of sane gun laws in Congress need to be equally serious about strengthening the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, the beleaguered agency charged with enforcing federal firearm regulations.

title: Philadelphia Plans to Close Some Schools
description: The strapped school district has proposed an unprecedented downsizing that would close 37 schools by June.

title: First Responders Mourn an Ambushed Firefighter
description: WEBSTER, N.Y.  Hundreds of firefighters, police officers and other emergency workers from as far away as California, and some from Canada, came to Webster Schroeder High School here in a show of support for Michael J. Chiapperini, 43, one of two volunteer firefighters fatally shot last Monday in an ambush by a gunman who later killed himself.

title: A Lucrative Stock Sale
description: Relatives of high-ranking Chinese officials have seen impressive returns from shares of Ping An Insurance, a financial powerhouse in China.

title: No Record for Peterson, but Vikings Will Play On
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Adrian Peterson ran onto the field at the Metrodome on Sunday with two goals: break Eric Dickersons N.F.L. single-season rushing record of 2,105 yards and help the Minnesota Vikings clinch an N.F.C. wild-card berth. Id be satisfied with both, he said last week.

title: After Career in Beauty, Facing Challenge of Failing Vision
description: Kevin Clements once led a glamorous life.

title: Experts Forecast the Cost of Failure to Compromise
description: Even if President Obama and Republicans in Congress can reach a last-minute compromise that averts some tax increases before Mondays midnight deadline, experts still foresee a significant drag on the economy in the first half of 2013 from the fiscal impasse in Washington.

title: N.F.L. Rewind: Week 17
